column3: Texas Senate passes abortion bill
column4: AUSTIN, Texas  — Republicans in the Texas Legislature passed an omnibus abortion bill that is one of the most restrictive in the nation, but Democrats vowed Saturday to fight both in the courts and the ballot box as they used the measure to rally their supporters.

column3: Texas Senate passes abortion bill
column4: More than 2,000 demonstrators filled the Capitol building in Austin to oppose the bill, and state troopers drug six out of the Senate chamber for trying to disrupt the debate.

column3: Texas Senate passes abortion bill
column4: The Republican majority ultimately passed the bill unchanged just before midnight, with all but one Democrat voting against it.

column3: Homeland Security chief Napolitano to resign
column4: Janet Napolitano is resigning as head of the Homeland Security Department and seeking a post as president of the University of California, the long-time Obama confidant announced Friday.

column3: Homeland Security chief Napolitano to resign
column4: Officials told Fox News that Napolitano does not plan to leave her post until September.

column3: Homeland Security chief Napolitano to resign
column4: But she announced the move on Friday after it began to break in the media, revealing that she has been nominated to lead the California university system.

column3: Homeland Security chief Napolitano to resign
column4: "For more than four years I have had the privilege of serving President Obama and his Administration as the Secretary of Homeland Security," she said in a statement.

column3: Homeland Security chief Napolitano to resign
column4: "The opportunity to work with the dedicated men and women of the Department of Homeland Security, who serve on the frontlines of our nation's efforts to protect our communities and families from harm, has been the highlight of my professional career.

column3: Homeland Security chief Napolitano to resign
column4: We have worked together to minimize threats of all kinds to the American public."

column3: Homeland Security chief Napolitano to resign
column4: Napolitano has ridden out a rocky tenure, having endured a string of lawsuits and multiple controversies regarding the agencies that DHS oversees.

column3: Homeland Security chief Napolitano to resign
column4: Among the complaints, Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents accused the department leadership in a lawsuit of failing to properly enforce immigration law.

column3: Homeland Security chief Napolitano to resign
column4: Their complaints center on the practice of using "prosecutorial discretion" -- allowing department lawyers to selectively determine which immigrants to pursue for deportation, and which to let go.

column3: Homeland Security chief Napolitano to resign
column4: Her aides claimed it was a matter of prioritizing resources, though some agents claimed it ran afoul of immigration law.

column3: Homeland Security chief Napolitano to resign
column4: Napolitano's department later enacted a Dream Act-style policy giving young illegal immigrants a reprieve.

column3: Homeland Security chief Napolitano to resign
column4: "Secretary Napolitano's tenure at the Department of Homeland Security was defined by a consistent disrespect for the rule of law," Sen. Jeff Sessions, R-Ala., one of her chief critics, said in a statement.

column3: Homeland Security chief Napolitano to resign
column4: The news of her departure apparently caught Napolitano's staff by surprise, Fox News is told.

column3: Homeland Security chief Napolitano to resign
column4: Officials, though, said the view among many at the department is that Napolitano has been "out of sight, out of mind" for a while -- particularly since she declared "the system worked" after a terrorist tried, unsuccessfully, to set off a bomb on a Detroit-bound flight in 2009.

column3: Homeland Security chief Napolitano to resign
column4: She came under criticism for that comment, and again for saying several months later that the attempted bombing in Times Square was merely a "one-off."

column3: Homeland Security chief Napolitano to resign
column4: The secretary had a knack for attracting Republican ire, for times when she appeared to downplay the global terrorist threat.

column3: Homeland Security chief Napolitano to resign
column4: She once, for instance, described terrorism as "man-caused disasters."

column3: Homeland Security chief Napolitano to resign
column4: The agencies within the DHS have also been a popular target of lawmakers.

column3: Homeland Security chief Napolitano to resign
column4: Most recently, the Transportation Security Administration was compelled to back off a policy allowing small knives on planes after intense pushback from Congress.

column3: Homeland Security chief Napolitano to resign
column4: At the same time, Napolitano has been working with other agencies to pump more resources to the border regions to curb illegal immigration, and has been tasked with responding to a series of major natural disasters.

column3: Homeland Security chief Napolitano to resign
column4: Obama, in a written statement, praised Napolitano for her service.

column3: Homeland Security chief Napolitano to resign
column4: "She's worked around the clock to respond to natural disasters, from the Joplin tornado to Hurricane Sandy, helping Americans recover and rebuild.

column3: Homeland Security chief Napolitano to resign
column4: Since day one, Janet has led my administration's effort to secure our borders, deploying a historic number of resources, while also taking steps to make our immigration system fairer and more consistent with our values," he said.

column3: Homeland Security chief Napolitano to resign
column4: Napolitano, a former Arizona governor, has led the Homeland Security Department since the start of the Obama administration.

column3: Homeland Security chief Napolitano to resign
column4: She is one of the handful of Cabinet members to have stayed with the administration this long.

column3: Homeland Security chief Napolitano to resign
column4: The California university system announced late Friday morning that Napolitano had been nominated for president.

column3: Homeland Security chief Napolitano to resign
column4: She was recommended on a unanimous vote.

column3: Homeland Security chief Napolitano to resign
column4: The Board of Regents will vote next Thursday -- if confirmed, Napolitano will be the first female president of the university.

column3: House Republicans Push Through Farm Bill, Without Food Stamps
column4: WASHINGTON — Republicans muscled a pared-back agriculture bill through the House on Thursday, stripping out the food stamp program to satisfy recalcitrant conservatives but losing what little Democratic support the bill had when it failed last month.

column3: House Republicans Push Through Farm Bill, Without Food Stamps
column4: It was the first time food stamps had not been a part of the farm bill since 1973.

column3: House Republicans Push Through Farm Bill, Without Food Stamps
column4: The 216-to-208 vote saved House Republican leaders from an embarrassing reprisal of the unexpected defeat of a broader version of the bill in June, but the future of agriculture policy remains uncertain.

column3: House Republicans Push Through Farm Bill, Without Food Stamps
column4: The food stamp program, formally called the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, was 80 percent of the original bill’s cost, and it remains the centerpiece of the Senate’s bipartisan farm bill.

column3: House Republicans Push Through Farm Bill, Without Food Stamps
column4: Even in a chamber used to acrimony, Thursday’s debate in the House was particularly brutal.

column3: House Republicans Push Through Farm Bill, Without Food Stamps
column4: Democrats repeatedly called for roll-call votes on parliamentary procedures and motions to adjourn, delaying the final vote by hours and charging Republicans over and over again with callousness and cruelty.

column3: House Republicans Push Through Farm Bill, Without Food Stamps
column4: Republicans shouted protests, trying to silence the most strident Democrats, and were repeatedly forced to vote to uphold their own parliamentary rulings.

column3: House Republicans Push Through Farm Bill, Without Food Stamps
column4: Representative Frank D. Lucas, Republican of Oklahoma, the chairman of the House Agriculture Committee, said he would try to draft a separate food stamp bill “as soon as I can achieve a consensus.” But conservatives remain determined to extract deep cuts to the program — cuts that members of both parties in the House and Senate have said they cannot support.

column3: House Republicans Push Through Farm Bill, Without Food Stamps
column4: House and Senate negotiators could produce a compromise measure with the robust food stamp program the Senate wants, but such a bill would almost certainly have to pass the House with significant Republican defections.

column3: House Republicans Push Through Farm Bill, Without Food Stamps
column4: Asked before the vote Thursday if he would allow a compromise bill to come to a final vote in the House, Speaker John A. Boehner of Ohio shrugged and said: “If ands and buts were candy and nuts, every day would be Christmas.

column3: House Republicans Push Through Farm Bill, Without Food Stamps
column4: You’ve heard that before.

column3: House Republicans Push Through Farm Bill, Without Food Stamps
column4: My goal right now is to get the farm bill passed.

column3: House Republicans Push Through Farm Bill, Without Food Stamps
column4: We’ll get to those other issues later.” By splitting farm policy from food stamps, the House effectively ended the decades-old political marriage between urban interests concerned about nutrition and rural areas who depend on farm subsidies.

column3: House Republicans Push Through Farm Bill, Without Food Stamps
column4: “We wanted separation, and we got it,” said Representative Marlin Stutzman, Republican of Indiana, one of the bill’s chief authors.

column3: House Republicans Push Through Farm Bill, Without Food Stamps
column4: “You’ve got to take these wins when you can get them.” Democrats denounced the bill as a naked attempt to make draconian cuts in the food stamp program.

column3: House Republicans Push Through Farm Bill, Without Food Stamps
column4: “A vote for this bill is a vote to end nutrition in America,” said Representative Rosa DeLauro of Connecticut.

column3: House Republicans Push Through Farm Bill, Without Food Stamps
column4: Senator Debbie Stabenow of Michigan, the chairwoman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, called the House measure “an insult to rural America.” Anti-hunger groups called passage of the farm bill without the food stamp program a disgrace.

column3: House Republicans Push Through Farm Bill, Without Food Stamps
column4: “Today’s vote is the latest smoking gun that the House majority isn’t truly interested in deficit reduction,” said Joel Berg, executive director of the New York City Coalition Against Hunger.

column3: House Republicans Push Through Farm Bill, Without Food Stamps
column4: “They’re interested in supporting special interest groups over hungry Americans.” The 608-page bill keeps the changes that were in the version that failed last month, and amendments were not allowed.

column3: House Republicans Push Through Farm Bill, Without Food Stamps
column4: The bill would save about $20 billion by consolidating or cutting numerous farm subsidy programs, including $5 billion paid annually to farmers and landowners whether they plant crops or not.

column3: House Republicans Push Through Farm Bill, Without Food Stamps
column4: The money saved from eliminating those payments would be directed into the $9 billion crop insurance program, and new subsidies would be created for peanut, cotton and rice farmers.

column3: House Republicans Push Through Farm Bill, Without Food Stamps
column4: The bill adds money to support fruit and vegetable growers, and it restores insurance programs for livestock producers, which expired in 2011, leaving thousands of operations without disaster coverage during last year’s drought.

column3: House Republicans Push Through Farm Bill, Without Food Stamps
column4: The bill also made changes to a dairy program that sets limits to the amount of milk produced and sold in the United States.

column3: House Republicans Push Through Farm Bill, Without Food Stamps
column4: One new proposal from last month would also repeal a provision in the current farm bill, called “permanent law,” that causes farm programs to revert to 1949 price levels if a new farm bill is not passed.

column3: House Republicans Push Through Farm Bill, Without Food Stamps
column4: Congress has traditionally maintained the provision to prod lawmakers into passing a farm bill or face large increases in farm program expenditures.

column3: House Republicans Push Through Farm Bill, Without Food Stamps
column4: Without the provision, many lawmakers and farm groups fear there would be no incentive for Congress to pass a farm bill on time.

column3: House Republicans Push Through Farm Bill, Without Food Stamps
column4: One overlooked provision in the bill came from Representative Dan Benishek, Republican of Michigan, a surgeon, and would require additional economic and scientific analyses before a 2010 law to improve the food safety system goes into effect.

column3: House Republicans Push Through Farm Bill, Without Food Stamps
column4: A spokesman for Mr. Benishek, Kyle Bonini, said it was meant to protect farmers “from being hit with more costly regulations.” But food safety advocates said that they were surprised by the provision and that it would effectively halt implementation of the law, which gives the Food and Drug Administration greater authority over food production.

column3: House Republicans Push Through Farm Bill, Without Food Stamps
column4: Erik D. Olson, director of food programs at the Pew Charitable Trusts, which was involved in promoting the law, called the provision “an extremely troubling development.” No Democrats voted for the measure Thursday, and 12 Republicans voted against it — mainly the most conservative members, with a scattering of moderates.

column3: House Republicans Push Through Farm Bill, Without Food Stamps
column4: Republican discipline on the final vote was something of a rebuke to conservative advocacy groups like the Club for Growth and Heritage Action, which had worked against the bill, even after the food stamp program was stripped out.

column3: House Republicans Push Through Farm Bill, Without Food Stamps
column4: But its removal engulfed a bill that for years had passed with overwhelming bipartisan support in acrimony.

column3: House Republicans Push Through Farm Bill, Without Food Stamps
column4: “They cannot help themselves from turning nonpartisan, bipartisan legislation into ‘my way or the highway,’ ” Representative Steny H. Hoyer of Maryland, the Democratic whip, said of his Republican colleagues.

column3: House Republicans Push Through Farm Bill, Without Food Stamps
column4: In the early 1970s, as rural members of Congress saw their numbers start to decline, a deal was struck to include food stamps in the farm bill so lawmakers would be able to muster enough votes to pass it.

column3: House Republicans Push Through Farm Bill, Without Food Stamps
column4: But both nutrition programs and farm subsidies have grown tremendously in the past 20 years, and a new breed of legislators, many of them elected in 2010 and backed by the Tea Party, are more concerned with federal spending than building coalitions to pass a farm bill.

column3: House Republicans Push Through Farm Bill, Without Food Stamps
column4: Last week, 532 farm organizations, including the American Farm Bureau Federation, the nation’s largest farm lobby, called on lawmakers not to split the farm bill into two pieces of legislation.

column3: House Republicans Push Through Farm Bill, Without Food Stamps
column4: In a letter on Thursday, Bob Stallman, president of the Farm Bureau, called the split disappointing.

column3: House Republicans Push Through Farm Bill, Without Food Stamps
column4: But after the vote, Mr. Stallman said the group would move ahead with getting a new five-year farm bill.

column3: House Republicans Push Through Farm Bill, Without Food Stamps
column4: “While we were hopeful the farm bill would not be split, nor permanent law repealed, we will now focus our efforts on working with lawmakers to deliver a farm bill to the president’s desk for his signature by September,” he said.

column3: House Republicans Push Through Farm Bill, Without Food Stamps
column4: For different reasons, the Club for Growth also opposed the bill.

column3: House Republicans Push Through Farm Bill, Without Food Stamps
column4: Chris Chocola, the political action committee’s president, said a new farm support program, called the “shallow loss” program, would guarantee farmers 90 percent of their income and “essentially locks in high commodity prices forevermore.” He also protested that Republican leaders had refused to guarantee that the food stamp program would not be included in the final measure that comes out of negotiations with the Senate.

column3: House narrowly passes farm bill after Republicans carve out food stamps
column4: The House on Thursday narrowly passed a massive farm bill, after Republicans took the risky step of carving out the food stamp program -- a move Democrats effectively boycotted.

column3: House narrowly passes farm bill after Republicans carve out food stamps
column4: The bill passed on a 216-208 vote.

column3: House narrowly passes farm bill after Republicans carve out food stamps
column4: Zero Democrats voted for it.

column3: House narrowly passes farm bill after Republicans carve out food stamps
column4: House Democrats spent most of the afternoon lambasting their Republican colleagues for dropping the food stamp component, making clear that House Speaker John Boehner would need to rely on Republicans only to pass the bill.

column3: House narrowly passes farm bill after Republicans carve out food stamps
column4: After some marathon nose-counting, GOP leaders were able to minimize the number of Republican defectors -- just 12 Republicans voted against it on Thursday.

column3: House narrowly passes farm bill after Republicans carve out food stamps
column4: The farm bill historically has been a vehicle for both billions in farm subsidies and billions in food stamps.

column3: House narrowly passes farm bill after Republicans carve out food stamps
column4: Twinning the two massive programs has in the past helped win support from rural-state lawmakers and those representing big cities.

column3: House narrowly passes farm bill after Republicans carve out food stamps
column4: But after the bill failed in the House last month amid opposition from rank-and-file Republicans, House leaders removed the food stamp portion in a bid to attract conservative support.

column3: House narrowly passes farm bill after Republicans carve out food stamps
column4: The fate of the measure is unclear, though, as the matter now kicks back to the Senate or to a so-called conference committee to resolve differences between the two chambers' bills.

column3: House narrowly passes farm bill after Republicans carve out food stamps
column4: The Democratic-led Senate overwhelmingly passed a farm bill with smaller cuts to food stamps, but would be reluctant to go along with a bill that carves out food stamps.

column3: House narrowly passes farm bill after Republicans carve out food stamps
column4: Senate Agriculture Committee Chairwoman Debbie Stabenow, D-Mich., said splitting the bill would be a "major mistake" -- though she has also indicated a willingness to try building off anything the House passes.

column3: House narrowly passes farm bill after Republicans carve out food stamps
column4: The White House has vowed to veto.

column3: House narrowly passes farm bill after Republicans carve out food stamps
column4: A statement released overnight said that the food stamp program "is a cornerstone of our nation's food assistance safety net, and should not be left behind as the rest of the Farm Bill advances."

column3: House narrowly passes farm bill after Republicans carve out food stamps
column4: Though Boehner was able to hold together his own caucus, Democrats reacted furiously at the move to drop food stamps.

column3: House narrowly passes farm bill after Republicans carve out food stamps
column4: "It's all about denying the working poor the right to food," Rep. Jim McGovern, D-Mass., claimed, accusing Republicans of attacking "poor people."

column3: House narrowly passes farm bill after Republicans carve out food stamps
column4: One by one, members of the Congressional Black Caucus lined up to assail the proposal.

column3: House narrowly passes farm bill after Republicans carve out food stamps
column4: "There are poor children in poor areas that I represent," Rep. Emanuel Cleaver, D-Mo., said.

column3: House narrowly passes farm bill after Republicans carve out food stamps
column4: Republicans, while concerned about the ballooning cost and enrollment in the $80 billion-a-year food stamp program, are not by any means eliminating food stamps by taking it out of the farm bill.

column3: House narrowly passes farm bill after Republicans carve out food stamps
column4: They would instead deal with it as a separate bill.

column3: House narrowly passes farm bill after Republicans carve out food stamps
column4: Boehner, aside from battling Democrats, was also contending with influential conservative groups leaning on the House to reject the bill, claiming the farm subsidies are still too expensive.

column3: House narrowly passes farm bill after Republicans carve out food stamps
column4: "Although the bill does not contain the $750 billion in food stamp spending like (the previous bill) it does nothing to make 'meaningful reforms' to America's farm policy," the conservative Heritage Foundation, which helped kill the bill the last time, said in a statement.

column3: House narrowly passes farm bill after Republicans carve out food stamps
column4: House Agriculture Chairman Frank Lucas, R-Okla., said as recently as last week that he opposed splitting the bill.

column3: House narrowly passes farm bill after Republicans carve out food stamps
column4: But he has now reluctantly agreed to the strategy, saying he would support it if his Republican leaders could deliver the votes.

column3: House narrowly passes farm bill after Republicans carve out food stamps
column4: Late Wednesday, he gave a reserved endorsement of the plan to the GOP-controlled Rules Committee, which determines the procedures for floor debate.

column3: House narrowly passes farm bill after Republicans carve out food stamps
column4: "Maybe the old dynamic of how we have done things since 1965 isn't valid anymore," he said.

column3: House narrowly passes farm bill after Republicans carve out food stamps
column4: "Maybe it is time to try something different."

column3: House narrowly passes farm bill after Republicans carve out food stamps
column4: The bill would also repeal laws from the 1930s and 1940s, essentially eliminating all old farm policy, which some conservatives like.

column3: House narrowly passes farm bill after Republicans carve out food stamps

column3: House narrowly passes farm bill after Republicans carve out food stamps
column4: Repealing those decades-old laws could mean that Congress would have little incentive to create new farm bills, however, and could make many farm programs permanent.

column3: GOP reaching out to Dems on immigration
column4: Updated 07/11/2013 07:40 PM EDT The House Republican leadership is reaching out to top House Democrats to assess their support for a piecemeal approach to immigration reform, according to sources involved in the discussions.

column3: GOP reaching out to Dems on immigration
column4: The House’s immigration gameplan is to pass individual bills rather than take the comprehensive approach advocated by the Senate.

column3: GOP reaching out to Dems on immigration
column4: Speaker John Boehner’s (R-Ohio) team isn’t trying to cut a deal with Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.), these aides caution.

column3: GOP reaching out to Dems on immigration
column4: But deeply-divided Republicans want to get a read on what members of the minority party would back when immigration reform comes to the floor.

column3: GOP reaching out to Dems on immigration
column4: Story Continued Below The legislation under discussion between Republicans and Democrats includes bills reworking the employment verification system and legislation to toughen border security, according to sources both involved in and familiar with the talks.

column3: GOP reaching out to Dems on immigration
column4: In strategy sessions and planning meetings, Republicans have said that support for immigration reform is soft among GOP lawmakers — and leadership is skeptical that there is backing for anything more drastic than border security and E-verify.

column3: GOP reaching out to Dems on immigration
column4: ( PHOTOS: 20 quotes on immigration reform) Moving legislation before the August recess is now almost completely out of the question — lawmakers are going to have to spend the month at home, with immigration lingering.

column3: GOP reaching out to Dems on immigration
column4: These contacts are in the early stages, but the discussions are aimed at running up big bipartisan majorities for a series of GOP-authored bills, that could counter the bipartisan Senate bill.

column3: GOP reaching out to Dems on immigration
column4: In short, Democrats would smooth the prospects for passage.

column3: GOP reaching out to Dems on immigration
column4: Those talks with Democrats weren’t the focus of a closed-door GOP immigration strategy meeting, which took place Wednesday in the Capitol basement.

column3: GOP reaching out to Dems on immigration
column4: In that meeting, leadership and bold-faced Republican lawmakers tried to explain that something needs to happen — and soon.

column3: GOP reaching out to Dems on immigration
column4: ( Also on POLITICO: Immigration reform heads for slow death) Boehner called the immigration debate “important,” and said Republicans need a plan.

column3: GOP reaching out to Dems on immigration
column4: Majority Leader Eric Cantor (R-Va.) said Republicans should present an alternative to the Senate’s plan — just like the party did during the economic stimulus debate in 2009.

column3: GOP reaching out to Dems on immigration
column4: More than Cantor and perhaps even Boehner, Rep. Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) is someone who is catching Republicans’ eyes.

column3: GOP reaching out to Dems on immigration
column4: The 2012 vice presidential nominee and House Budget Committee chair, who has been quietly meeting for months on immigration reform, took to the microphone at Wednesday’s meeting, saying that the GOP needs to tackle immigration — and now.

column3: GOP reaching out to Dems on immigration
column4: Immigrants, he said, are important to the country’s economic vitality.

column3: GOP reaching out to Dems on immigration
column4: The issue might be urgent, but it won’t be smooth.

column3: GOP reaching out to Dems on immigration
column4: House Republicans face logistical peril by entering into negotiations armed with small bills after Democrats passed a big, aggressive reform package.

column3: GOP reaching out to Dems on immigration
column4: ( PHOTOS: Pols react to immigration deal) The debate will also get lumped in with a busy fall, at a time when Congress will be jousting over government funding and the debt limit.

column3: GOP reaching out to Dems on immigration
column4: So, if immigration reform actually happens — far from a certainty — it seems increasingly likely to be tossed into a year-end rush, in a way mirroring the 2012 fiscal cliff panic, the 2010 extension of Bush tax rates and other panicked legislating that Washington has become so accustomed to.

column3: GOP reaching out to Dems on immigration
column4: But immigration reform will be more challenging: there is no deadline.

column3: GOP reaching out to Dems on immigration
column4: Logistics and timing are only two of the reasons this policy debate is challenging.

column3: GOP reaching out to Dems on immigration
column4: The party is split in multiple directions.

column3: GOP reaching out to Dems on immigration
column4: Follow @politico

column3: House Republicans throw brakes on immigration push
column4: The momentum that helped carry the massive immigration overhaul through the Senate last month is beginning to fade, as House Republicans slam the brakes on the debate while rejecting the Senate's bill entirely.

column3: House Republicans throw brakes on immigration push
column4: The discontent in the House Republican caucus was evident in a closed-door meeting late Wednesday.

column3: House Republicans throw brakes on immigration push
column4: Cheers erupted when GOP leaders said they would not take up the Senate-passed bill.

column3: House Republicans throw brakes on immigration push
column4: "One thing is clear.

column3: House Republicans throw brakes on immigration push
column4: House Republicans want to do this on our terms and not on the Senate's terms and not on the president's terms," said Rep. Michael McCaul, R-Texas, chairman of the House Homeland Security Committee.

column3: House Republicans throw brakes on immigration push
column4: Senate leaders, who had been banking on the assumption that political pressures would force the House to act, are now watching as the House weighs options that would be a direct challenge to those who crafted the original bill.

column3: House Republicans throw brakes on immigration push
column4: Sens.

column3: House Republicans throw brakes on immigration push
column4: John McCain, R-Ariz., and Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., who helped write the Senate bill, still voiced optimism after emerging Thursday from a meeting with President Obama and Vice President Biden.

column3: House Republicans throw brakes on immigration push
column4: McCain said his message to House colleagues is "we are ready to negotiate" and stressed that the two chambers can find "common ground."

column3: House Republicans throw brakes on immigration push
column4: House Speaker John Boehner also said "Republicans ought to be part of the solution."

column3: House Republicans throw brakes on immigration push
column4: But the House is taking a very different approach.

column3: House Republicans throw brakes on immigration push
column4: Boehner and other GOP leaders said Wednesday they will take a "step-by-step" approach -- meaning they will break the legislation into a series of smaller bills.

column3: House Republicans throw brakes on immigration push
column4: And that's if rank-and-file Republicans will agree to vote on anything.

column3: House Republicans throw brakes on immigration push
column4: Sources told Fox News that Republicans repeatedly voiced concern Wednesday about border security.

column3: House Republicans throw brakes on immigration push
column4: But they raised another concern that could signal major problems ahead -- that if the House passes anything, the proposal would then go to what is known as a conference committee, where select lawmakers from each chamber would try and hammer out a compromise.

column3: House Republicans throw brakes on immigration push
column4: The concern is that the conference committee could produce a bill that House Republicans can't abide.

column3: House Republicans throw brakes on immigration push
column4: Rep. Kevin Cramer, R-N.D., said the members are fearful and don't "trust the conference process."

column3: House Republicans throw brakes on immigration push
column4: Sources told Fox News that Boehner repeatedly stood up during the meeting to tell members he would not appoint any House members to a conference committee who don't reflect the position of the chamber.

column3: House Republicans throw brakes on immigration push
column4: "But they're not hearing that," groused one Republican member.

column3: House Republicans throw brakes on immigration push
column4: "It just goes over their head."

column3: House Republicans throw brakes on immigration push
column4: White House Press Secretary Jay Carney on Wednesday said the administration knew this would be an "uphill battle."

column3: House Republicans throw brakes on immigration push
column4: "Hard things are hard," he said.

column3: House Republicans throw brakes on immigration push
column4: Fox News' Chad Pergram contributed to this report.

column3: Farm bill 2013: House leadership redoubles its efforts
column4: Updated 07/11/2013 01:16 PM EDT Rolling the dice, House Republicans pushed ahead toward floor votes Thursday on a pared-back farm bill that strips out nutrition programs to appease conservatives and reduces the net 10-year costs to about $195.6 billion.

column3: Farm bill 2013: House leadership redoubles its efforts
column4: Behind the scenes, the GOP worked relentlessly to line up the last of 218 votes to avoid a repeat of last month’s embarrassing collapse.

column3: Farm bill 2013: House leadership redoubles its efforts
column4: By a 223-195 margin the bill survived a first procedural test.

column3: Farm bill 2013: House leadership redoubles its efforts
column4: But the whole strategy remained a political high-wire act uniting Democrats in opposition even as it left the agriculture community badly split.

column3: Farm bill 2013: House leadership redoubles its efforts
column4: Story Continued Below The opening debate was emotionally charged with members of the Congressional Black Caucus lining up in a fury and Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) warning: “This passes a threshold we should never go past.” ( Also on POLITICO: Obama threatens veto on farm bill) House Rules Committee Chairman Pete Sessions (R-Texas) insisted that the goal was simply to “bifurcate” the legislation and get one piece — most relevant to farmers — to conference with the Senate.

column3: Farm bill 2013: House leadership redoubles its efforts
column4: But he was met with a blast from Rep, Jim McGovern (D-Mass.

column3: Farm bill 2013: House leadership redoubles its efforts
column4: ), who said backroom deals had been made to “gut” the nutrition title in the months ahead.

column3: Farm bill 2013: House leadership redoubles its efforts
column4: Powerful cotton, rice, peanut and sugar cane interests were working with the GOP to round up votes.

column3: Farm bill 2013: House leadership redoubles its efforts
column4: But the two leading agriculture groups — the American Farm Bureau Federation and National Farmers Union — came out strongly against the GOP strategy, which breaks with nearly a half-century of practice in farm bills.

column3: Farm bill 2013: House leadership redoubles its efforts
column4: A fresh 608-page text was filed only Wednesday evening, minus Title IV covering nutrition programs including food stamps and local food banks.

column3: Farm bill 2013: House leadership redoubles its efforts
column4: Amendments adopted in last month’s farm debate are wrapped into the new measure.

column3: Farm bill 2013: House leadership redoubles its efforts
column4: But as reported by the Rules panel, the bill will now be protected from further changes under expedited proceedings on the House floor.

column3: Farm bill 2013: House leadership redoubles its efforts
column4: At the same time, there are two significant revisions to supplant decades-old commodity price and production provisions for grains, upland cotton and milk, for example.

column3: Farm bill 2013: House leadership redoubles its efforts
column4: Dating back to 1938 and 1949, these have been a “permanent law” backstop of sorts for farm bills and source of political leverage for commodity groups.

column3: Farm bill 2013: House leadership redoubles its efforts
column4: But they are largely impractical today and the new commodity title will now take their place as the new permanent law going forward.

column3: Farm bill 2013: House leadership redoubles its efforts
column4: On the surface, this is a change advocated by conservatives.

column3: Farm bill 2013: House leadership redoubles its efforts
column4: But the full impact on different sectors was still being sorted out, and it appears sugar, cotton and rice stand to gain potentially.

column3: Farm bill 2013: House leadership redoubles its efforts
column4: “We are quite concerned that without a workable nutrition title, it will prove to be nearly impossible to adopt a bill that can be successfully conferenced with the Senate’s version,” said Farm Bureau President Bob Stallman in a letter Thursday morning urging “no” votes by the House on the rule and bill.

column3: Farm bill 2013: House leadership redoubles its efforts
column4: Stallman also warned that “to replace permanent law governing agricultural programs without hearing from so much as a single witness on what that law should be replaced with is not how good policy is developed.” Altogether, it made for an extraordinary political spectacle — and one that led many agriculture lobbyists to keep their heads down.

column3: Farm bill 2013: House leadership redoubles its efforts
column4: “If you want to make a cow patty stink, turn it over,” one veteran told POLITICO.

column3: Farm bill 2013: House leadership redoubles its efforts
column4: “There’s so much kindling around here, I don’t want to strike a match.” Driving the legislative train was Majority Leader Eric Cantor (R-Va.), who had a major role in the collapse of the farm bill last month and hopes to recover now by dividing the package into two parts to appease conservatives.

column3: Farm bill 2013: House leadership redoubles its efforts
column4: Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio) also stepped up his involvement, meeting with wavering members.

column3: Farm bill 2013: House leadership redoubles its efforts
column4: And in a conference call Wednesday with more than two dozen farm groups, Boehner’s chief of staff Mike Sommers bluntly warned that this could be their last chance at getting a farm bill this year.

column3: Farm bill 2013: House leadership redoubles its efforts
column4: The talking points used by Sommers are revealing of the mind-set behind the Republican strategy.

column3: Farm bill 2013: House leadership redoubles its efforts
column4: Sommers said the leadership was committed to getting a farm bill, but after the collapse of the measure in June, the GOP had only two choices — moving to the right or left.

column3: At Restaurant, Delay Is Help on Health Law
column4: â Eric King has worked diligently to keep his familyâs 35-year-old seafood restaurant here viable, most recently by expanding the menu beyond its well-loved crab cakes and other traditional dishes to draw a younger, freer-spending crowd.

column3: At Restaurant, Delay Is Help on Health Law
column4: The restaurant, Shanty Grille, is on track to make a profit this year â about $80,000, Mr. King predicts â for the first time since the economic downturn.

column3: At Restaurant, Delay Is Help on Health Law
column4: Yet the prospect of providing health insurance to every full-time worker or paying a penalty starting in January, a provision of the Obama health care law, has overshadowed the good news.

column3: At Restaurant, Delay Is Help on Health Law
column4: Businesses with the equivalent of more than 50 full-time employees are subject to the rule, and Shanty Grille hovers right around that threshold.

column3: At Restaurant, Delay Is Help on Health Law
column4: Then came last weekâs announcement that the mandate would be delayed a year after business owners begged the Obama administration for more time.

column3: At Restaurant, Delay Is Help on Health Law
column4: Mr. King, who had been fretting for three years about whether the restaurant would be subject to the mandate and how it would affect the bottom line, was thrilled.

column3: At Restaurant, Delay Is Help on Health Law
column4: âIt gives us another year to plan,â he said Friday, sitting in the Grilleâs sleek, newly expanded pub as customers cracked crabs at the bar.

column3: At Restaurant, Delay Is Help on Health Law
column4: âIf we fall below the 50, fantastic.

column3: At Restaurant, Delay Is Help on Health Law
column4: If weâre above, then weâll have another year to figure out how to offset these costs.â Shanty Grille already provides health insurance to 9 of its 85 employees, paying part of the premium for each at a total cost of about $26,000 a year.

column3: At Restaurant, Delay Is Help on Health Law
column4: The chosen group includes the restaurantâs managers and chefs â skilled workers, Mr. King said, whom âI really want to take care of and retain.â Others can opt into the plan, but only if they pay the full cost, about $4,700 this year.

column3: At Restaurant, Delay Is Help on Health Law
column4: Only one, a waitress in her 50s, has done so.

column3: At Restaurant, Delay Is Help on Health Law
column4: (Mr. King and his wife and children are insured through a smaller family business across the street, a fish market that does not employ enough people to have to comply with the mandate.)

column3: At Restaurant, Delay Is Help on Health Law
column4: If Mr. King had the equivalent of 50 full-time employees under the health care law, which uses a complex formula to determine precisely who is eligible for coverage, he estimates that would have to cover a total of 22 employees.

column3: At Restaurant, Delay Is Help on Health Law
column4: That would bring his costs to about $62,000 a year if premiums did not rise, he said.

column3: At Restaurant, Delay Is Help on Health Law
column4: âIf thereâs no return on your investment,â he said, âthereâs not really a point anymore.

column3: At Restaurant, Delay Is Help on Health Law
column4: I put in 70, 75 hours a week.

column3: At Restaurant, Delay Is Help on Health Law
column4: Is it really worth it?â Restaurant owners have been among the most vocal critics of the employer mandate, saying it could hurt them more than other businesses in part because their profit margins tend to be low.

column3: At Restaurant, Delay Is Help on Health Law
column4: Some have said they will lay off workers or shift more of them to part-time status to avoid having to comply.

column3: At Restaurant, Delay Is Help on Health Law
column4: Mr. King thinks his current system is fair â he offers insurance to his most valuable employees, who are also the most likely to stick around â and points to low turnover as evidence that his uninsured servers, busboys, dishwashers, line cooks and hosts are content.

column3: At Restaurant, Delay Is Help on Health Law
column4: Most are young and in good health.

column3: At Restaurant, Delay Is Help on Health Law
column4: He said ânot a soulâ among the employees at Shanty Grille had asked him to comply with the mandate.

column3: At Restaurant, Delay Is Help on Health Law
column4: âMost of my servers are 25 to 30 years old,â he said.

column3: At Restaurant, Delay Is Help on Health Law
column4: âTheyâd rather take the $200 a month and put it in a bar bill as opposed to insurance.â Yet at least one of Mr. Kingâs young, uninsured employees is anxious about not having medical coverage â so much that this week, he is starting a second job that comes with health benefits.

column3: At Restaurant, Delay Is Help on Health Law
column4: The employee, Vince Ritter, a bartender, started working at Shanty Grille a decade ago, when he was 16.

column3: At Restaurant, Delay Is Help on Health Law

column3: At Restaurant, Delay Is Help on Health Law

column3: At Restaurant, Delay Is Help on Health Law
column4: That makes him nervous, he said, because he plays sports and has seen uninsured friends â including a colleague at Shanty Grille who tore a knee ligament on the basketball court â have to pay thousands of dollars for urgent care.

column3: Israel Urges US Not to Freeze Egypt Aid
column4: JERUSALEM — Israel has urged Washington not to suspend its annual $1.3 billion in aid to Cairo in the wake of the ouster of Egyptian president Mohammed Morsi by the military, news reports said Tuesday.

column3: Israel Urges US Not to Freeze Egypt Aid
column4: Under U.S. law, all military and economic aid must be suspended to any country where the government is overthrown by the military, although Washington has not yet determined whether it considers the June 30 removal of Morsi was actually a coup — a claim made by the Muslim Brotherhood, to which the ousted president belongs.

column3: Israel Urges US Not to Freeze Egypt Aid
column4: According to a senior U.S. official quoted by Haaretz newspaper, Israel's top political echelon had engaged in "marathon phone calls" with Washington over the weekend, warning that any suspension of aid could impact on Israel's security and even undermine its 1979 peace treaty with Egypt.

column3: Israel Urges US Not to Freeze Egypt Aid
column4: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu phoned Secretary of State John Kerry, Defense Minister Moshe Yaalon spoke with Pentagon chief Chuck Hagel, and Israel's National Security Adviser Yaakov Amidror consulted with his U.S. counterpart, Susan Rice, he said.

column3: Israel Urges US Not to Freeze Egypt Aid
column4: "The Israelis warned that cutting military aid to Egypt would likely impact negatively on Israel's security, especially given the possibility of further security deterioration in Sinai.

column3: Israel Urges US Not to Freeze Egypt Aid
column4: They also warned that halting the aid could undermine Israel's peace treaty with Egypt," the paper said.

column3: Israel Urges US Not to Freeze Egypt Aid
column4: U.S. aid to Egypt, which began as a direct result of the treaty, has continued uninterrupted since 1979, and Israel fears any chance in U.S. policy could undermine the Egyptian army's commitment to the treaty.

column3: Israel Urges US Not to Freeze Egypt Aid
column4: A senior official in Netanyahu's office refused to confirm or deny the report.

column3: Israel Urges US Not to Freeze Egypt Aid
column4: The Sinai Peninsula, which borders Israel and the Hamas-run Gaza Strip, has seen a rise in Islamist militancy since the overthrow of former president Hosni Mubarak in February 2011, that has resulted in a rise in attacks on the Jewish state as well as on Egypt's own forces stationed there.

column3: Israel Urges US Not to Freeze Egypt Aid
column4: Last week, the Israeli army confirmed it had "authorized" the deployment of Egyptian military reinforcements in the peninsula "in order to contend with security threats in Sinai that pose a threat to both Israel and Egypt."

column3: Israel Urges US Not to Freeze Egypt Aid
column4: The 1979 treaty imposes strict controls on the numbers of troops permitted to operate there.

column3: Israel Urges US Not to Freeze Egypt Aid
column4: Israel's public radio ran a similar report on Israeli efforts to dissuade Washington from halting aid to Cairo.

column3: Israel Urges US Not to Freeze Egypt Aid
column4: Speaking to the station, an Israeli official said Egypt was likely to go through "a period of chronic instability."

column3: Israel Urges US Not to Freeze Egypt Aid
column4: "The Muslim Brotherhood will not easily give up power, we must expect more violence and perhaps more changes in the leadership," he said.

column3: Israel Urges US Not to Freeze Egypt Aid
column4: Since Morsi's ouster, Netanyahu has ordered his ministers to stay silent on the unfolding political crisis in Egypt.

column3: ‘Turn Texas blue’ hits headwinds with abortion
column4: Democrats are gearing up to spend millions of dollars to “turn Texas blue” by bringing in a new generation of Latino voters.

column3: ‘Turn Texas blue’ hits headwinds with abortion
column4: So when an abortion fight flared in Austin this summer, it seemed the stars had aligned — liberals had a hot-button cause to galvanize new supporters who just might stick around for the long haul.

column3: ‘Turn Texas blue’ hits headwinds with abortion
column4: Story Continued Below There’s just one problem: Latinos as a group oppose abortion more strongly than most other voting groups.

column3: ‘Turn Texas blue’ hits headwinds with abortion
column4: Right from the start the effort is running into headwinds, since the battle over the anti-abortion bill is sure to create a month-long spectacle that draws attention to an issue that might galvanize liberals nationally, but isn’t very appealing to the very voters Democrats hope to win over in the state.

column3: ‘Turn Texas blue’ hits headwinds with abortion
column4: In their candid moments, Democrats acknowledge that abortion isn’t the issue they would have picked to lead the pitch for Latino votes.

column3: ‘Turn Texas blue’ hits headwinds with abortion
column4: The fight was forced upon them, they say, when Gov.

column3: ‘Turn Texas blue’ hits headwinds with abortion
column4: Rick Perry added the anti-abortion bill to last month’s special session and revived it in a second special session that started July 1.

column3: ‘Turn Texas blue’ hits headwinds with abortion
column4: ( PHOTOS: Scenes from Texas abortion rights protest) “Is this the issue we would have picked to turn Texas blue?

column3: ‘Turn Texas blue’ hits headwinds with abortion
column4: No,” Terri Burke, executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union of Texas, said with a laugh.

column3: ‘Turn Texas blue’ hits headwinds with abortion
column4: “It was kind of thrust at us.

column3: ‘Turn Texas blue’ hits headwinds with abortion
column4: We didn’t pick it.” On the surface, at least, the polls don’t look promising for a party that’s basking in the national spotlight because of a fight over abortion rights.

column3: ‘Turn Texas blue’ hits headwinds with abortion
column4: The Pew Forum on Religion and Public Life found that 53 percent of Hispanic Catholics say abortion should be illegal in all or most cases.

column3: ‘Turn Texas blue’ hits headwinds with abortion
column4: That’s a lower percentage than white evangelical Protestants and Mormons, but it’s higher than all other religious voting groups, including white Catholics, white mainline Protestants, black Protestants, and Jews.

column3: ‘Turn Texas blue’ hits headwinds with abortion
column4: And Steve Munisteri, the chairman of the Texas Republican Party, cited a poll by the Wilson Perkins Allen research firm that found a 2-1 “pro-life” margin among the state’s Hispanic voters.

column3: ‘Turn Texas blue’ hits headwinds with abortion
column4: The poll, conducted for the state GOP, showed that 62 percent of Texas Hispanics who voted in the 2012 election described themselves as pro-life while just 32 percent called themselves pro-choice, according to Chris Perkins, the pollster who worked on the survey.

column3: ‘Turn Texas blue’ hits headwinds with abortion
column4: ( PHOTOS: Wendy Davis's filibuster) Some Democratic strategists say the key to winning over Latinos is to avoid focusing too much on any one issue — especially abortion.

column3: ‘Turn Texas blue’ hits headwinds with abortion
column4: Matt Angle says the party’s candidates should develop a broader pitch on a whole range of issues that are important to Latinos, but one powerful message, he says, is “overreach” by imposing such strict health and safety standards that many of the state’s health clinics have to shut down.

column3: ‘Turn Texas blue’ hits headwinds with abortion
column4: “If it’s only about one issue, then you’re going to fall short someplace,” said Angle, a longtime state strategist who has worked on other projects to rebuild Democratic strength.

column3: ‘Turn Texas blue’ hits headwinds with abortion
column4: Most liberals agree Democrats will need heart paddles to make the state competitive.

column3: ‘Turn Texas blue’ hits headwinds with abortion
column4: The party hasn’t won a statewide race since 1994, it lost control of the Legislature years ago, and President Barack Obama won just 41 percent of the vote there in 2012.

column3: ‘Turn Texas blue’ hits headwinds with abortion
column4: And the party has suffered a series of other humiliations the whole way.

column3: ‘Turn Texas blue’ hits headwinds with abortion
column4: At one point it became so weak that it couldn’t stop Gene Kelly, a perennial candidate who shares the same name as the dancer, from winning the nomination to the U.S. Senate.

column3: ‘Turn Texas blue’ hits headwinds with abortion
column4: But most Texas Democrats don’t think Latinos’ anti-abortion views will sink their hopes.

column3: ‘Turn Texas blue’ hits headwinds with abortion
column4: For one thing, other polls that have taken a deeper look at Latinos’ abortion views show their opposition is softer than it looks, according to James Aldrete, an Austin-based consultant.

column3: ‘Turn Texas blue’ hits headwinds with abortion
column4: He cited a poll earlier this year by Lake Research Partners that found that Latinos refused to hold other people to their own moral standards on abortion — 74 percent said women have the right to make their own decisions without interference from politicians, and a similar percentage said they wouldn’t judge women who decide they’re not ready to be parents.

column3: Asiana President Says Pilot Was in Training
column4: SEOUL, South Korea — It was Lee Kang-guk’s first attempt to land a Boeing 777 at San Francisco International Airport, and it ended in disaster.

column3: Asiana President Says Pilot Was in Training
column4: The crash of Asiana Airlines Flight 214 on Saturday killed two passengers, injured 180 others and tarnished the reputation of South Korea’s aviation industry, whose leaders had thought it was leaving a poor safety record behind.

column3: Asiana President Says Pilot Was in Training
column4: “For him, this was a training flight, as he was switching to a new type of plane,” Asiana Airlines’ president, Yoon Young-doo, said Monday of Mr. Lee.

column3: Asiana President Says Pilot Was in Training
column4: Mr. Lee, 46, a 19-year veteran with Asiana, has logged more than 9,700 hours of flying, piloting A320s and Boeing 737s and 747s to various destinations, including San Francisco.

column3: Asiana President Says Pilot Was in Training
column4: He had just 43 hours of flying time with Boeing 777s, and had made eight landings with them, in London, Los Angeles and Narita, Japan.

column3: Asiana President Says Pilot Was in Training
column4: He was still on a "familiarization flight" program when he was at the controls Saturday; a senior colleague with more experience landing 777s, including at San Francisco, sat beside him as co-pilot.

column4: He refused to speculate about whether the cockpit decision to let Mr. Lee, instead of one of his more experienced colleagues, land the plane had contributed to the accident; he said that investigators, including those from the United States National Transportation Safety Board, were looking into all possibilities.

column4: Any challenge to the pilots would have been further complicated by the shutdown of a ground-based electronic system called a glide slope indicator, which helps keep planes at the correct descent angle.

column3: Asiana President Says Pilot Was in Training
column4: But the pilots had been notified that the system had been turned off, government and Asiana officials here said.

column3: Asiana President Says Pilot Was in Training
column4: “Ultimately, it’s the trainer pilot who is responsible for the flight,” Mr. Yoon, the Asiana president, said, referring to Lee Jeong-min, 49, the more experienced pilot who sat in the co-pilot’s seat when Lee Kang-guk was landing the plane.

column3: Asiana President Says Pilot Was in Training
column4: He had 3,220 hours of flying time with 777s.

column3: Asiana President Says Pilot Was in Training
column4: “Familiarization flights” are part of the routine for pilots learning to fly a new kind of plane, officials at both the Transportation Ministry and Asiana said.

column3: Asiana President Says Pilot Was in Training
column4: At Asiana, the pilots are required to go through manual and simulator training — Asiana has run its own simulator training center since 1998 — and make 20 familiarization flights in the presence of more experienced “mentor” or “trainer” pilots.

column3: Asiana President Says Pilot Was in Training
column4: The crash Saturday was Asiana’s third accident involving fatalities since its founding in 1988.

column4: In 2011, a 747 cargo jet bound for Shanghai crashed into the sea off Korea’s southern coast, killing two pilots.

column4: In 1987, a Korean Air 707 disintegrated over waters near Myanmar in an explosion that South Korea attributed to a North Korean terrorist attack.

column4: All 115 people on board were killed.

column3: Asiana President Says Pilot Was in Training
column4: Eighty people died in 1989 when a Korean Air DC10 passenger jet crashed while landing in Tripoli, Libya.

column3: Asiana President Says Pilot Was in Training
column4: In 1997, a Korean Air 747 slammed into a hill while approaching the airport in Guam, killing 225 people.

column4: Since then, South Korea has tightened safety regulations and pilot qualification requirements, as well as improving pilot training.

column3: Asiana President Says Pilot Was in Training
column4: It also has struggled to address long-running skepticism over its cockpit culture.

column4: Both Asiana and Korean Air have been gradually hiring more nonveterans, including foreign pilots, partly because there were not enough South Korean Air Force veterans to meet the rising demand for pilots — especially in recent years, when they expanded overseas routes as budget airlines joined the competition for the domestic market.

column3: Asiana President Says Pilot Was in Training
column4: Now they fill roughly half of the cockpits.

column4: (Mr. Lee was one of them, joining Asiana in 1994 as a trainee pilot.)

column3: Pilots, airport, plane offer many targets for NTSB probe
column4: Updated 07/08/2013 09:51 AM EDT Federal investigators have a lot to look at as they try to puzzle out the reason for Saturday’s crash-landing of an Asiana Airlines Boeing 777 in San Francisco.

column3: Pilots, airport, plane offer many targets for NTSB probe
column4: The National Transportation Safety Board is following its usual protocol of being cautious with doling out information, and early indications point to some sort of pilot error.

column3: Pilots, airport, plane offer many targets for NTSB probe
column4: But the accident presents several obvious areas of interest for investigators.

column3: Pilots, airport, plane offer many targets for NTSB probe
column4: Among them: Story Continued Below • The plane’s approach: Numerous news accounts and witness reports suggest the plane came in for a landing short of the runway, way too low and with its nose pitched up too high.

column3: Pilots, airport, plane offer many targets for NTSB probe
column4: Early indications suggest this odd angle and placement contributed to the tail striking the airport’s seawall, probably precipitating the crash and breakup of the plane.

column3: Pilots, airport, plane offer many targets for NTSB probe
column4: The NTSB will examine whether this was due to pilot error or the result of some mechanical failure.

column3: Pilots, airport, plane offer many targets for NTSB probe
column4: • The airport: Glide Path, a navigation system that aids pilots as they land their planes, had been turned off due to maintenance work at the time of the crash.

column3: Pilots, airport, plane offer many targets for NTSB probe
column4: But the Glide Path helper is far from essential to making a safe landing, and is primarily used to help with landing in bad weather.

column3: Pilots, airport, plane offer many targets for NTSB probe
column4: ( PHOTOS: San Francisco plane crash) The weather at the airport Saturday was clear enough to conduct flights without instrumentation, and a system of lights that helps pilots who are landing by sight was functioning.

column3: Pilots, airport, plane offer many targets for NTSB probe
column4: NTSB Chairwoman Debbie Hersman told CNN this morning that “there are a number of other tools available to the pilots, some less sophisticated like the lights, the precision approach lights that … show you if you are too high or too low coming in, but also some things that are more technologically advanced, like things on this airplane that can give you GPS information.” • The plane: Boeing’s 777 has a solid safety record, with just two major incidents since it was placed into service in 1995 — the one on Saturday, plus another involving a crash landing.

column3: Pilots, airport, plane offer many targets for NTSB probe
column4: In January 2008 a British Airways flight from China landed hard about 1,000 feet short of the runway at Heathrow Airport in London, injuring 47 people.

column3: Pilots, airport, plane offer many targets for NTSB probe
column4: ( Also on POLITICO: NTSB chairwoman: 'Striking' damage to Flight 214) An NTSB investigation into the Heathrow incident revealed that ice pellets had formed in the fuel, clogging the fuel-oil heat exchanger and blocking fuel from reaching the plane’s engines.

column3: Pilots, airport, plane offer many targets for NTSB probe
column4: The Rolls-Royce engines used on that plane were later redesigned.

column3: Pilots, airport, plane offer many targets for NTSB probe
column4: But the Asiana plane involved in Saturday’s crash was equipped with a Pratt and Whitney engine that was not included in the NTSB’s previous recommendations on engine icing.

column3: Pilots, airport, plane offer many targets for NTSB probe

column3: Pilots, airport, plane offer many targets for NTSB probe

column3: Egyptian Nobelist Is Chosen to Be Prime Minister
column4: CAIRO — Egypt’s new leaders struggled to put together a new government on Saturday, with disagreements over who should be the interim prime minister spilling out into public view and showcasing the divisions among those who had endorsed the overthrow of the country’s first democratically elected president.

column3: Egyptian Nobelist Is Chosen to Be Prime Minister
column4: State news media initially reported that Mohamed ElBaradei, the Nobel Prize-winning diplomat and a vocal critic of Egypt’s last three leaders, had been chosen as prime minister, a move that would have given the generals who ousted President Mohamed Morsi a head of government likely to appeal to the country’s liberals and to the West.

column3: Egyptian Nobelist Is Chosen to Be Prime Minister
column4: But within hours, the fissures that had vexed Mr. Morsi’s rule re-emerged to undo the reported decision.

column3: Egyptian Nobelist Is Chosen to Be Prime Minister
column4: The ultraconservative party Al Nour, the one Islamic faction that had backed the military takeover, said it would refuse to work with Mr. ElBaradei because of his liberal views.

column3: Egyptian Nobelist Is Chosen to Be Prime Minister
column4: Around midnight, after hours of contradictory news coverage, the new interim president then backed away from the earlier reports that Mr. ElBaradei had been offered the job.

column3: Egyptian Nobelist Is Chosen to Be Prime Minister
column4: The continued chaos underlined the struggle for stability in Egypt, which has lurched from crisis to crisis since the Arab Spring revolution that overthrew President Hosni Mubarak in 2011.

column3: Egyptian Nobelist Is Chosen to Be Prime Minister
column4: Since then, Islamists and liberals have battled for power, even after Mr. Morsi and the once-banned Muslim Brotherhood won multiple rounds of elections.

column3: Egyptian Nobelist Is Chosen to Be Prime Minister
column4: Mr. Morsi was ultimately unseated by the country’s generals on Wednesday for failing to bring Egypt’s political factions together, with many saying that the Islamists had taken too much power.

column3: Egyptian Nobelist Is Chosen to Be Prime Minister
column4: But with the reports that Mr. ElBaradei had been named prime minister on Saturday, the pendulum appeared to have swung the other way.

column3: Egyptian Nobelist Is Chosen to Be Prime Minister
column4: Although the military ousted Mr. Morsi in the name of national reconciliation, Mr. ElBaradei’s apparent rejection underscored the difficulty a military-appointed government may have in bridging Egypt’s divides.

column3: Egyptian Nobelist Is Chosen to Be Prime Minister
column4: Mr. ElBaradei, who is respected worldwide for his work on nuclear issues for the United Nations, was a strong advocate of toppling President Mubarak, but has not enjoyed wide popularity on the Egyptian streets.

column3: Egyptian Nobelist Is Chosen to Be Prime Minister

column3: The real jobs numbers: 2014, 2016
column4: Updated 07/08/2013 08:31 AM EDT NEW YORK - Welcome to the good-news-could-be-bad-news economy.

column3: The real jobs numbers: 2014, 2016
column4: Friday’s Labor Department report showing a better-than-expected gain of 195,000 jobs in June was a heartening sign for many that the economic recovery continues to move ahead at a modest pace.

column3: The real jobs numbers: 2014, 2016
column4: But it could ultimately turn out to be bad news, especially for Democrats, because it means that the Federal Reserve might start winding down its extraordinary efforts to boost the economy later this year.

column3: The real jobs numbers: 2014, 2016
column4: Story Continued Below And if the Fed takes the juice away too soon it could tank the stock market, crush housing prices, snuff out the four-year-old economic recovery, and make life exceedingly difficult for any Democrat who hopes to run in 2016 for what will essentially be President Barack Obama’s third-term.

column3: The real jobs numbers: 2014, 2016
column4: ( Also on POLITICO: Economy adds 195K jobs in June) “This jobs report is a data-point that will get people wondering if the Fed will really start pulling back as soon as September, as many people are expecting,” said Nigel Gault co-chief economist at the Parthenon Group.

column3: The real jobs numbers: 2014, 2016

column4: Fed moves and pronouncements from central bank chairman Ben Bernanke may seem like the province of quick trading market jockeys and green eyeshade economists.

column3: The real jobs numbers: 2014, 2016

column3: The real jobs numbers: 2014, 2016
column4: But they will also have an enormous impact on the economy and political landscape for the 2014 midterms and 2016 general election.

column3: The real jobs numbers: 2014, 2016

column3: The real jobs numbers: 2014, 2016
column4: And the jobs being created are not the kind of high-wage positions that tend to drive a robust economy.

column3: The real jobs numbers: 2014, 2016
column4: The number of workers who want full-time jobs but were only employed part time surged by 322,000 to 8.2 million, a figure some attributed to employers declining hire workers full-time in order to avoid the mandate to provide coverage under President Barack Obama’s health reform law.

column3: The real jobs numbers: 2014, 2016
column4: The unemployment rate was unchanged at 7.6 percent.

column3: The real jobs numbers: 2014, 2016
column4: Despite all this, the Fed still appears to be planning to start winding down its asset purchases as soon as September, a precursor to eventually increasing interest rates, on the theory that economy will soon be able to stand on its own.

column3: The real jobs numbers: 2014, 2016
column4: If the Fed gets it wrong and pulls the plug too quickly, economists say it could send interest rates soaring and tip the economy back into recession.

column3: The real jobs numbers: 2014, 2016
column4: That in turn could rob Democrats of one of the advantages they have in the 2014 midterms and make the environment much less hospitable to Hillary Clinton or any other Democrat who hopes to succeed Obama in 2016.

column3: Why We Remember the Fourth of July
column4: Independence Day is an important holiday for all Americans.

column3: Why We Remember the Fourth of July
column4: Each July Fourth we celebrate that moment in history when the Second Continental Congress formally adopted the Declaration of Independence -- the earth-shattering document that asserted man’s natural right to “life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness” -- and the new nation’s declared sovereignty from the humiliating tyrannies of an imperial power.

column3: Why We Remember the Fourth of July
column4: But it’s also worth mentioning, too, that the impending success of the “American experiment” was hardly a foregone conclusion -- despite what so many of us believe today or perhaps were taught in school.

column3: Why We Remember the Fourth of July
column4: “No event in American history which was so improbable at the time has seemed so inevitable in retrospect as the American Revolution,” historian Joseph J. Ellis wrote in his Pulitzer Prize winning book Founding Brothers: The Revolutionary Generation.

column3: Why We Remember the Fourth of July
column4: Indeed, Americans today perhaps just assume that under the leadership of Washington, Adams, and Jefferson -- during those early and chaotic years -- the United States would eventually become, in Ellis’ words, “the oldest enduring republic in world history.” Not so.

column3: Why We Remember the Fourth of July
column4: “No one present at the start knew how it would turn out in the end,” Ellis argues, least of all the Founders themselves.

column3: Why We Remember the Fourth of July
column4: This is a fact I suspect most of us overlook.

column3: Why We Remember the Fourth of July
column4: And yet the United States today is the beau ideal for many developing nations.

column3: Why We Remember the Fourth of July
column4: Our most cherished political institutions -- a bicameral legislature, an autonomous judiciary, and a duly elected chief executive -- serve as a template for burgeoning democracies everywhere.

column3: Why We Remember the Fourth of July
column4: Clearly, the United States has created, over time, a framework that has ushered in unprecedented opportunities for advancement and social mobility.

column3: Why We Remember the Fourth of July
column4: For example, when the nation was founded in the late eighteenth century, there were only 2.5 million people living in the United States.

column3: Why We Remember the Fourth of July
column4: Today there are more than 300 million.

column3: Why We Remember the Fourth of July
column4: One hopes that this is precisely what the Founders imagined when they spoke about forming “a more perfect union” -- a fluid yet imperfect society that is continually developing and growing and becoming more prosperous.

column3: Why We Remember the Fourth of July
column4: But it seems to me we are facing a perilous future.

column3: Why We Remember the Fourth of July
column4: Too many of us seem to disregard the Founders as nothing more than “dead white men” -- statesmen who most notably failed to secure citizenship rights for all Americans and resolve the slavery question in their own time.

column3: Why We Remember the Fourth of July
column4: Liberals, for their part, often scoff when conservatives show even the slightest hint of reverence for the nation’s Founders and the principles they embraced.

column3: Why We Remember the Fourth of July
column4: But those progressives forget, perhaps, that the 56 delegates who founded the nation established, for all of us, the very pillars of freedom and opportunity that make living in the United States today so highly regarded throughout the world.

column3: Why We Remember the Fourth of July
column4: If for no other reason -- on this quintessentially American holiday -- this is why we should celebrate and remember them.

column3: Why We Remember the Fourth of July
column4: We have much to be grateful for.
