column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: CAIRO — Egypt’s military officers removed the country’s first democratically elected president, Mohamed Morsi, on Wednesday, suspended the Constitution and installed an interim government presided over by a senior jurist.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: Tahrir Square, where tens of thousands of opponents of the government had gathered each night since Sunday to demand Mr. Morsi’s removal, erupted in fireworks and jubilation at news of the ouster.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: At a square near the presidential palace where Mr. Morsi’s Islamist supporters had gathered, men broke into tears and vowed to stay until he was reinstated or they were forcibly removed.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: “The dogs have done it and made a coup against us,” they chanted.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: “Dying for the sake of God is more sublime than anything,” a speaker declared.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: Mr. Morsi rejected the generals’ actions as a “complete military coup.” Military vehicles and soldiers in riot gear had surrounded the rally in the hours before the takeover, and tensions escalated through the night.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: Within hours, at least seven people had died and more than 300 were injured in clashes in 17 provinces between Mr. Morsi’s supporters and either civilian opponents or security forces.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: By the end of the night, Mr. Morsi was in military custody and blocked from all communications, one of his advisers said, and many of his senior aides were under house arrest.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: Egyptian security forces had arrested at least 38 senior leaders of the Muslim Brotherhood, including Saad el-Katatni, the chief of the group’s political party, and others were being rounded up as well, security officials said.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: No immediate reasons were given for the detentions.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: For Mr. Morsi, it was a bitter and ignominious end to a tumultuous year of bruising political battles that ultimately alienated millions of Egyptians.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: Having won a narrow victory, his critics say, he broke his promises of an inclusive government and repeatedly demonized his opposition as traitors.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: With the economy crumbling, and with shortages of electricity and fuel, anger at the government mounted.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: The generals built their case for intervention in a carefully orchestrated series of maneuvers, calling their actions an effort at a “national reconciliation” and refusing to call their takeover a coup.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: At a televised news conference late on Wednesday night, Gen. Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi said that the military had no interest in politics and was ousting Mr. Morsi because he had failed to fulfill “the hope for a national consensus.” The general stood on a broad stage, flanked by Egypt’s top Muslim and Christian clerics as well as a spectrum of political leaders including Mohamed ElBaradei, the Nobel Prize-winning diplomat and liberal icon, and Galal Morra, a prominent Islamist ultraconservative, or Salafi, all of whom endorsed the takeover.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: Despite their protestations, the move plunged the generals back to the center of political power for the second time in less than three years, following their ouster of President Hosni Mubarak in 2011.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: Their return threatened to cast a long shadow over future efforts to fulfill that revolution’s promise of a credible, civilian democracy.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: But General Sisi sought to present a very different image from the anonymous, numbered communiqués from the Supreme Council of the Armed Forces that were solemnly read over state television to announce Mr. Mubarak’s exit, and the general emphasized that the military had no desire to rule.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: “The armed forces was the one to first announce that it is out of politics,” General Sisi said at the start.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: “It still is, and it will remain away from politics.” Under a “road map” for a post-Morsi government devised by a meeting of civilian, political and religious leaders, the general said, the Constitution would be suspended, the chief justice of the Supreme Constitutional Court, Adli Mansour, would become acting president, and plans would be expedited for new parliamentary and presidential elections under an interim government.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: At the White House, President Obama urged the military to move quickly to return Egypt to a democratically elected government, saying, “We are deeply concerned by the decision of the Egyptian Armed Forces to remove President Morsi and suspend the Egyptian Constitution.” The president notably did not refer to the military’s takeover as a coup — a phrase that would have implications for the $1.3 billion a year in American military aid to Egypt.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: Still, there was no mistaking the threat of force and signs of a crackdown.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: Armored military vehicles rolled through the streets of the capital, surrounded the presidential palace and ringed in the Islamists.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: The intelligence services put travel bans on Mr. Morsi and other top Brotherhood leaders.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: The Brotherhood’s satellite television network was removed from the air along with two other popular Islamist channels.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: The police arrested at least two prominent Islamist television hosts and many others who worked at those channels, as well as people who worked at a branch of the Al Jazeera network considered sympathetic to Mr. Morsi, security officials said.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: And state television resumed denouncing the Brotherhood as it once did under Mr. Mubarak.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: Moments after the General Sisi spoke late Wednesday, Mr. Morsi released a short video over a presidential Web site delivering a final, fiery speech denouncing the ouster.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: “I am the elected president of Egypt,” he declared.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: “I am ready to sit down and for everybody to sit with me and to negotiate with everybody.” “The revolution is being stolen from us,” he repeated.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: Minutes later, the Web site was shut down, the video disappeared and he e-mailed journalists a statement “as the president of the Republic and the Chief Commander of the Armed Forces” urging all to follow the rules of the recently approved Constitution.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: Then he called the takeover “a complete military coup which is categorically rejected by all the free people of the country who have struggled so that Egypt turns into a civil democratic society.” And in a sign of how little Mr. Morsi ever managed to control the Mubarak bureaucracy he took over, the officers of the Presidential Guard who had been assigned to protect him also burst into celebration, waving flags from the roof of the palace.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: Although the tacit control of the generals over Egyptian politics is now unmistakable, General Sisi laid out a more detailed and faster plan for a return to civilian governance than the now-retired generals who deposed Mr. Mubarak did two years ago.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: General Sisi made no mention of any period of military rule and granted the acting president, Mr. Mansour, the power to issue “constitutional decrees” during the transition.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: Mr. Mansour was named to the bench by Mr. Mubarak two decades ago, before Mr. Mubarak sought to pack the court with more overtly political loyalists or anti-Islamists.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: Mr. Mansour ascended to the post of chief only a few days ago and, while he is said to be highly regarded, not much is known of his views or how much authority he will truly wield.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: General Sisi called for the formation of a “technocratic government” to administer affairs during the transition and also of a politically diverse committee of experts to draft constitutional amendments.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: It was not clear who would form the government or the committee.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: The general said that the constitutional court would set the rules for the parliamentary and presidential elections, and the court would also “put forward a code of ethics to guarantee freedom of the press and achieve professionalism and credibility” in the news media.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: The general’s plan bore a close resemblance to one proposed in recent days by the ultraconservative Islamist Nour Party, and suggested that he was seeking to bring in at least some Islamists as well as liberals and leftists to support the overthrow of the Muslim Brotherhood.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: The Nour Party, which quickly endorsed the plan, had joined other political groups in accusing Mr. Morsi and the Brotherhood of monopolizing power at the price of a dangerous political polarization.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: But unlike liberals, the ultraconservative Islamists were keen to avoid the installation of a liberal like Mr. ElBaradei as a transitional prime minister, or to see the current Constitution — with its prominent recognition of Islamic law — scrapped instead of revised.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: It was unclear if the generals planned to allow the Brotherhood to compete in parliamentary elections and potentially retake its dominant role in the legislature, which could give it the ability to name a new prime minister.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: Brotherhood leaders urged Islamists to resist.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: “The people will not surrender,” Essam el-Erian, a senior Brotherhood political leader, declared on the group’s satellite channel before it disappeared from the air.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: “The military will reach the point when the conflict is no longer between political opponents.

column3: Army Ousts Egypt’s President; Morsi Decries ‘Complete Military Coup’
column4: Instead the military will be in confrontation with a large sector of the people — I daresay the bigger part.”

column3: Administration delays key ObamaCare insurance mandate
column4: The Obama administration announced Tuesday that it is delaying a major provision in the health care overhaul, putting off until 2015 a requirement that many employers offer health insurance.

column3: Administration delays key ObamaCare insurance mandate
column4: The announcement was made late Tuesday by the Treasury Department, at the beginning of the holiday week while Congress was on recess.

column3: Administration delays key ObamaCare insurance mandate

column3: Administration delays key ObamaCare insurance mandate

column3: Administration delays key ObamaCare insurance mandate

column3: Obama tells Egyptian President Morsi to address protesters' concerns
column4: President Obama called Egyptian President Mohammed Morsi late Monday night to express his concerns about violence against women in anti-government demonstrations and to give Mr. Morsi some advice about running a democracy.

column3: Obama tells Egyptian President Morsi to address protesters' concerns
column4: Mr. Obama “underscored his deep concern about violence during the demonstrations, especially sexual assaults against female citizens.” He told Mr. Morsi “to make clear to his supporters that all forms of violence are unacceptable.” Amid widespread demonstrations against the new government, the Egyptian military told Mr. Morsi late Monday that it will take over in two days if he doesn’t address the protesters’ concerns adequately.

column3: Obama tells Egyptian President Morsi to address protesters' concerns
column4: SEE ALSO: Egypt’s Morsi rebuffs military demands; Muslim Brotherhood cries ‘coup’ While on a visit to Tanzania, Mr. Obama told Mr. Morsi that “democracy is about more than elections; it is also about ensuring that the voices of all Egyptians are heard and represented by their government, including the many Egyptians demonstrating throughout the country.” The White House said Mr. Obama “encouraged” Mr. Morsi to show that he is responsive to protesters’ concerns, and he “underscored that the current crisis can only be resolved through a political process.” Mr. Obama also told the Egyptian leader that he is “committed to the safety of U.S. diplomats and citizens in Egypt and stressed his expectation that the government of Egypt continue to protect U.S. diplomatic personnel and facilities.”

column3: Office of Personnel Management: Benefits now available to same-sex spouses
column4: The same-sex spouses of federal employees can begin applying for benefits including health insurance and retirement accounts immediately, the Obama administration said Friday, two days after the Supreme Court overturned a key provision of the Defense of Marriage Act.

column3: Office of Personnel Management: Benefits now available to same-sex spouses
column4: The Office of Personnel Management offered the guidance in a letter to the heads of executive departments and  agencies, detailing access to many of the benefits to which legally married same-sex spouses will now have the same access heterosexual married couples do, including health, life, dental, vision and long-term care insurance.

column3: Office of Personnel Management: Benefits now available to same-sex spouses
column4: Story Continued Below The memo, signed by acting director Elaine Kaplan, does not go into detail about the benefits available to same-sex couples who marry in one state but live in another where those unions are not legal.

column3: Office of Personnel Management: Benefits now available to same-sex spouses
column4: By omitting a specific reference to state laws, and repeating that benefits will be available to all legally married couples, OPM appears to be making the case that couples will have access to the listed benefits regardless of the state in which they live.

column3: Office of Personnel Management: Benefits now available to same-sex spouses
column4: ( PHOTOS: Reactions to Supreme Court’s gay marriage rulings) President Barack Obama said Thursday that, “speaking as a president, not a lawyer,” he believes couples married in one state should be treated as married in all 50 states, but that his administration is working on the legalities of making that reality.

column3: Office of Personnel Management: Benefits now available to same-sex spouses

column3: Office of Personnel Management: Benefits now available to same-sex spouses

column3: Office of Personnel Management: Benefits now available to same-sex spouses
column4: “Thousands of gays and lesbians serve our country every day in the federal government.

column3: Office of Personnel Management: Benefits now available to same-sex spouses
column4: They, and their spouses and children, deserve the same respect and protection as every other family.

column3: Office of Personnel Management: Benefits now available to same-sex spouses
column4: Under the president’s direction, the Justice Department is leading the implementation of the repeal of Section 3 of DOMA.

column3: Office of Personnel Management: Benefits now available to same-sex spouses
column4: After the high court’s Wednesday ruling, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel also said that the Pentagon will move quickly to expand benefits to same-sex couples.

column3: Office of Personnel Management: Benefits now available to same-sex spouses
column4: Attorney General Eric Holder welcomed Friday’s announcement.

column3: Office of Personnel Management: Benefits now available to same-sex spouses
column4: “Americans in same-sex marriages are entitled to equal protection and equal treatment under the law,” he said in a statement.

column3: Office of Personnel Management: Benefits now available to same-sex spouses
column4: “By extending health insurance and other important benefits to federal employees and their families, regardless of whether they are in same-sex or opposite-sex marriages, the Obama administration is making real the promise of this important decision.” The changes announced Friday “will make a meaningful, positive difference in the lives of many,” Holder said.

column3: Office of Personnel Management: Benefits now available to same-sex spouses
column4: “As the president directed, the Department of Justice will continue to coordinate with other federal agencies to implement this ruling as swiftly and smoothly as possible.

column3: Office of Personnel Management: Benefits now available to same-sex spouses
column4: I look forward to sharing additional information as it becomes available..”

column3: Government announces benefits for gay federal workers after court ruling
column4: \--Dental and vision insurance.

column3: Government announces benefits for gay federal workers after court ruling
column4: Current enrollees may call directly to make the necessary changes.

column3: Government announces benefits for gay federal workers after court ruling

column3: Government announces benefits for gay federal workers after court ruling

column3: Government announces benefits for gay federal workers after court ruling

column3: Government announces benefits for gay federal workers after court ruling

column3: Government announces benefits for gay federal workers after court ruling

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: WASHINGTON -- The Senate passed a politically fraught immigration reform bill on Thursday that would give a path to citizenship to some of the estimated 11 million undocumented immigrants living in the U.S., bringing them out of the shadows and preventing continued record deportations that have separated hundreds of thousands of families.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: The bill passed 68 to 32, picking up all Democrats and 14 Republicans.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: Undocumented immigrants and advocates in the crowd, many of them young so-called Dreamers, broke out into applause and chants of "yes we can!"

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: after Vice President Joe Biden, who came to the Senate to preside over the proceedings, read the results.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: Senators in the bipartisan "gang of eight" that drafted the bill -- Sens.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: John McCain (R-Ariz.), Marco Rubio (R-Fla.), Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.), Jeff Flake (R-Ariz.), Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.), Dick Durbin (D-Ill.), Bob Menendez (D-N.J.) and Michael Bennet (D-Colo.) -- patted each other on the back.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: Just before the vote Thursday, Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.) dedicated the decision, in part, to the late Sen. Ted Kennedy (D-Mass.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: ), who worked for reform but never saw it signed into law.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: "Senator Kennedy knew the day would come when a group of senators, divided by party, but united by love of country, would see this fight to the finish," Reid said.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: "So the day is today.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: And while I am sad that Senator Kennedy isn’t here to see history made, I know he is looking at us proudly and loudly."

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: Although sponsors didn't get to the 70 votes they hoped for, the full support from Democrats and addition of Republican votes was significant.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: McCain, Rubio, Flake and Graham were joined in voting "yes" by Republican Sens.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: Lamar Alexander (Tenn.), Kelly Ayotte (N.H.), Jeff Chiesa (N.J.), Susan Collins (Maine), Bob Corker (Tenn.), Orrin Hatch (Utah), Dean Heller (Nev.), John Hoeven (N.D.), Mark Kirk (Ill.), and Lisa Murkowski (Alaska).

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: The bill doesn't please everyone, but its passage is a victory for those who have been working on the issue for years and watched immigration reform fail six years ago.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: It addresses undocumented immigrants, legal immigration, border security, employer hiring and an entry-exit system so the government knows if foreign nationals leave the country when their visa expires.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: The path to citizenship is long -- likely 13 years or more -- and arduous, but advocates are thrilled that it would exist at all, given opposition from many Republicans and the failure of bills to carve out such a path in the past.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: Dreamers, young undocumented immigrants who came to the U.S. as children, would be able to earn green cards in five years, as would some agricultural workers.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: The bill adds huge increases in border security, bolstered by an amendment from Corker and Hoeven that helped bring on board unsure Democrats and Republicans.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: The amendment would prevent green card status for undocumented immigrants until the government deploys 20,000 additional border agents, mandates E-Verify to prevent businesses from hiring unauthorized workers, completes a 700-mile border fence and adds to entry-exit systems to track whether foreign nationals overstay their visas.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: Although those border security measures and other pieces of the bill come at a cost, the Congressional Budget Office has estimated that the legislation would shrink the deficit by nearly than $900 billion, minus expenses from the Corker-Hoeven amendment.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: The bill has vehement opponents in Sens.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: Jeff Sessions (R-Ala.), Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa), John Cornyn (R-Texas), Mike Lee (R-Utah) and Ted Cruz (R-Texas), along with 27 others who voted in opposition to the bill.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: They argue that the bill is "amnesty" because undocumented immigrants would receive provisional legal status to stay in the U.S. before border and enforcement measures are met.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: They also allege that the bill won't ensure those measures will actually be met.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: Grassley and Cornyn blocked two efforts to vote on additional amendments on Wednesday and Thursday, taking a measure from Sen.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: Rob Portman (R-Ohio) off the table, which led to him voting in opposition.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: "If they come up short, since they bragged so much about getting 70 votes, it's going to be a strategic defeat for them," Grassley told reporters shortly before the vote began.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: Graham said it wasn't a problem.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: "This is overwhelming support for the bill," he told reporters after the vote.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: "Why did I want 70?

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: I'm just greedy.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: This is incredibly pleasing."

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: The opponents have expressed hope that the bill will die in the House, which is a possibility, given Republican opposition there.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: Lee said earlier Thursday on the Senate floor that the legislation is doomed to fail anyway, resigned that it would pass in the upper chamber.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: "If this bill passes today, it will be all but relegated to the ash heap of history, as the House appears willing to tackle immigration reform the right way," Lee said ahead of the vote.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: "The sponsors of this bill had the best of intentions, but in my opinion, intentions aren’t enough."

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: Although a bipartisan House group is working on a comprehensive immigration bill, its members hit a roadblock earlier this month when Rep. Raul Labrador (R-Idaho) dropped out.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: The House is more likely to pursue a piecemeal approach, led by Judiciary Committee Chairman Bob Goodlatte (R-Va.) and Immigration Subcommittee Chairman Trey Gowdy (R-S.C.).

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: Some measures, including one to make it a crime to be in the country without status, have already passed the Judiciary Committee.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: Goodlatte issued a statement after the vote Thursday, saying he congratulated the Senate but has "many concerns about its bill," giving no indication his committee would consider the gang of eight plan.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: "While the Senate has every right to pass solutions it deems appropriate, the House does as well," he said.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: "That’s the American legislative process."

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio) reiterated on Thursday that he intends for the House to pursue its own immigration reform approach, rather than taking up the Senate bill.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: "The House is not going to take up and vote on whatever the Senate passes," Boehner told reporters at a press conference.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: "For any legislation, including a conference report, to pass the House, it's going to have to be a bill that has the support of a majority of our members," he added later, referring to Republicans.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: House Chief Deputy Whip Peter Roskam (R-Ill.) told reporters at a National Review event earlier in the day that "it is a pipe dream to think that bill is going to the floor and is going to be voted on."

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: Some House Republicans have said they don't want the lower chamber to take up immigration reform at all, even piecemeal, and threatened a revolt if Boehner holds a vote on the Senate bill.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: Rep. Mo Brooks (R-Ala.) said on the "Laura Ingraham Show" on Thursday that he is in the minority for not wanting to pass any immigration legislation that would allow for a conference committee to combine the House and Senate bills in "nefarious ways."

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: "I'm one of those who believes that this is fraught with peril," Brooks said.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: "If we were to pass a bill that's a good bill on immigration, on enforcing and securing our borders, on whatever topic related to immigration we may want to pass a bill on, it can become a vehicle."

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: The bill's supporters in the Senate said they hope the House passes legislation that can be combined with the bill, and perhaps adds things they weren't able to include.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: "This isn't the end of the process, we're kind of at halftime," Hoeven said after the vote.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: "So the next thing is to figure out how we get the House to engage."

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: Flake, who served in the House before joining the Senate this year, predicted his former colleagues would feel pressure to act.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: He said he'd urge them, particularly those from Arizona, to consider the border security elements in the bill.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: "When people read that title, they'll be surprised at what's in it," he told reporters.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: "Having served over there, whenever a good substantive bill comes with a significant vote, it's tough to ignore," he said.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: "Particularly this one -- there's going to be a lot of pressure to bring something up."

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: President Barack Obama promised to continue to press the House to move on immigration reform, and asked others to join in.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: "Today, the Senate did its job," he said in a statement.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: "It's now up to the House to do the same.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: As this process moves forward, I urge everyone who cares about this issue to keep a watchful eye.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: Now is the time when opponents will try their hardest to pull this bipartisan effort apart so they can stop commonsense reform from becoming a reality.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: We cannot let that happen."

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: Regardless of the bill's political future, its passage was a significant moment for the immigrant activists that crowded into the gallery to watch the vote.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: Biden asked those in attendance to keep silent -- part of the Senate's rules of decorum -- but many of them began to chant anyway.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: "I've been waiting for this moment all my life," said Lissette Moreno, an undocumented, 29-year-old Texan who has lived in the United States since she was 5 and has earned two college degrees.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: "All my life I've lived in fear.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: I'm very happy for myself, my family and my community."

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: This is a developing piece and has been updated.

column3: Immigration Reform Passes: Your Move, House
column4: Danielle Schlanger, Michael McAuliff and Sabrina Siddiqui contributed reporting.

column3: Senate Passes Massive Immigration Bill
column4: WASHINGTON (TheBlaze/AP) — The Senate has passed massive immigration legislation that will offer a pathway to citizenship to millions of illegal immigrants, while promising border security in the future.

column3: Senate Passes Massive Immigration Bill
column4: The vote was 68-32, far more than the majority needed to send the measure to the House.

column3: Senate Passes Massive Immigration Bill
column4: Prospects there are not nearly as good and many conservatives are opposed.

column3: Senate Passes Massive Immigration Bill
column4: Vice President Joe Biden presided, and senators cast their votes from their desks, both steps reserved for momentous votes.

column3: Senate Passes Massive Immigration Bill
column4: The bill, a priority for President Barack Obama, would amount to the most sweeping changes in decades to the nation’s immigration laws.

column3: Senate Passes Massive Immigration Bill
column4: After three weeks of debate, there was no doubt about the outcome.

column3: Senate Passes Massive Immigration Bill
column4: Fourteen Republicans joined all 52 Democrats and two independents to support the bill.

column3: Senate Passes Massive Immigration Bill
column4: Here are the 14 GOP senators who voted for the legislation: Marco Rubio (Fla.) Lamar Alexander (Tenn.) Lisa Murkowski (Alaska) Kelly Ayotte (N.H.) Jeffrey Chiesa (N.J.) Susan Collins (Maine) Bob Corker (Tenn.) Jeff Flake (Ariz.) Lindsey Graham (S.C.) Orrin Hatch (Utah) Dean Heller (Nev.) John Hoeven (N.D.) Mark Kirk (Ill.) John McCain (Ariz.) Division among Republicans was evident as potential 2016 presidential contenders split.

column3: Senate Passes Massive Immigration Bill
column4: Sen. Marco Rubio of Florida was one of the Gang of 8, while Sens.

column3: Senate Passes Massive Immigration Bill
column4: Rand Paul of Kentucky and Ted Cruz of Texas were opposed to the bill.

column3: Senate Passes Massive Immigration Bill
column4: The legislation’s chief provisions includes numerous steps that advocates claim will fight future illegal immigration – some added in a late compromise that swelled Republican support for the bill – and to check on the legal status of job applicants already living in the United States.

column3: Senate Passes Massive Immigration Bill
column4: At the same time, it offers a 13-year path to citizenship to as many as 11 million immigrants now living in the country unlawfully.

column3: Senate Passes Massive Immigration Bill
column4: Critics, like Sen. Cruz, say border security provisions will never come to fruition if legalization occurs first.

column3: Senate Passes Massive Immigration Bill
column4: He has referenced a similar bill that Congress passed in 1986, which made hollow promises relating to border security in exchange for amnesty for illegal immigrants.

column3: Senate Passes Massive Immigration Bill
column4: Immediately after the vote, Sen. Paul appeared on Fox News and expressed similar concerns and explained why he voted against the bill.

column3: Senate Passes Massive Immigration Bill
column4: Under the deal brokered last week by Republican Sens.

column3: Senate Passes Massive Immigration Bill
column4: John Hoeven of North Dakota and Bob Corker of Tennessee and the Gang of 8, the measure requires 20,000 new Border Patrol agents, the completion of 700 miles of fencing and deployment of an array of high-tech devices along the U.S.-Mexico border.

column3: Senate Passes Massive Immigration Bill
column4: Those living in the country illegally could gain legal status while the border security plan was being implemented, but would not be granted permanent resident green cards or citizenship.

column3: Senate Passes Massive Immigration Bill
column4: A plan requiring businesses to check on the legal status of prospective employees would be phased in over four years.

column3: Senate Passes Massive Immigration Bill
column4: Other provisions would expand the number of visas available for highly skilled workers relied upon by the technology industry.

column3: Senate Passes Massive Immigration Bill
column4: A separate program would be established for lower-skilled workers, and farm workers would be admitted under a temporary program.

column3: Senate Passes Massive Immigration Bill
column4: In addition, the system of legal immigration that has been in effect for decades would be changed, making family ties less of a factor and elevating the importance of education, job skills and relative youth.

column3: Senate Passes Massive Immigration Bill
column4: With the details of the Senate bill well-known, House Speaker John Boehner said at a news conference the separate legislation the House considers will have majority support among Republicans.

column3: Senate Passes Massive Immigration Bill
column4: He also said he hopes the bill will be bipartisan, and he encouraged a group of four Democrats and three Republicans trying to forge a compromise to continue their efforts.

column3: Senate Passes Massive Immigration Bill
column4: He offered no details on how a House bill could be both bipartisan and supported by more than half of his own rank and file, given that most of the bills that have moved through the House Judiciary Committee recently did so on party line votes over the protests of Democrats.

column3: Senate Passes Massive Immigration Bill
column4: None envisions legal status for immigrants now in the country illegally.

column3: Senate Passes Massive Immigration Bill
column4: Boehner declined to say if there were circumstances under which he could support a pathway to citizenship, but he made clear that securing the border was a priority.

column3: Senate Passes Massive Immigration Bill
column4: “People have to have confidence that the border is secure before anything else is really going to work.

column3: Senate Passes Massive Immigration Bill
column4: Otherwise, we repeat the mistakes of 1986,” he said, referring to the last time Congress overhauled the immigration system.

column3: Senate Passes Massive Immigration Bill
column4: Here’s how the Senate vote count turned out: Senate Gang of Eight Vote by Becket Adams TheBlaze’s Becket Adams contributed to this report.

column3: Senate Passes Massive Immigration Bill
column4: – [related]

column3: Proposition 8 Decision, DOMA Ruling Prompt Reactions From Politicians
column4: The Supreme Court ruled on two major gay marriage cases Wednesday, deciding the fate of California's Proposition 8 and the Defense of Marriage Act.

column3: Proposition 8 Decision, DOMA Ruling Prompt Reactions From Politicians
column4: Politicians reacted to the news with a flood of tweets, statements and Facebook posts.

column3: Proposition 8 Decision, DOMA Ruling Prompt Reactions From Politicians
column4: Below, a slideshow of politicians' reactions to the rulings:

column3: Supreme Court issues two illegitimate decisions on same-sex marriage
column4: Wednesday, the Supreme Court did what many of us hoped would never happen – the justices have invalidated Section 3 of the federal Defense of Marriage Act and refused to consider the lower court decision invalidating Proposition 8.

column3: Supreme Court issues two illegitimate decisions on same-sex marriage
column4: I’m furious.

column3: Supreme Court issues two illegitimate decisions on same-sex marriage
column4: We at the National Organization for Marriage (NOM) and tens of millions of other Americans will never accept it.

column3: Supreme Court issues two illegitimate decisions on same-sex marriage
column4: It’s wrong, plain and simple.

column3: Supreme Court issues two illegitimate decisions on same-sex marriage
column4: There’s a stench to these decisions that has stained the Supreme Court.

column3: Supreme Court issues two illegitimate decisions on same-sex marriage
column4: [pullquote] In my view, the worst of the two decisions is the Proposition 8 case.

column3: Supreme Court issues two illegitimate decisions on same-sex marriage
column4: The National Organization for Marriage and our allies fought with everything we had to preserve marriage, the foundation of society itself.

column3: Supreme Court issues two illegitimate decisions on same-sex marriage
column4: We were the largest contributor to putting Proposition 8 on the ballot, actively campaigned for its passage, and contributed hundreds of thousands of dollars to help preserve it through many legal challenges.

column3: Supreme Court issues two illegitimate decisions on same-sex marriage
column4: The refusing to hear the Proposition 8 appeal has rewarded the utter dereliction of duty by California’s Governor and Attorney General, whose legal obligation was to defend initiatives adopted by the people.

column3: Supreme Court issues two illegitimate decisions on same-sex marriage
column4: That leaves in place the erroneous decision of a single San Francisco federal court judge, who issued a Dred Scott and Roe v Wade type of decision – an illegitimate attempt to legislate from the bench.

column3: Supreme Court issues two illegitimate decisions on same-sex marriage
column4: The Supreme Court has blown it, rewarding corrupt public officials and judges and invalidating the right of the people of California to define marriage in the way that marriage has actually existed throughout human history – the union of one man and one woman.

column3: Supreme Court issues two illegitimate decisions on same-sex marriage
column4: Over 7 million Californians voted in favor of Proposition 8.

column3: Supreme Court issues two illegitimate decisions on same-sex marriage
column4: Not content to let voters have their say, homosexual activists from Hollywood and New York hired celebrity lawyers Ted Olson and David Boies to sue and the case now known as Hollingsworth v. Perry began.

column3: Supreme Court issues two illegitimate decisions on same-sex marriage
column4: Frankly, I’ve never seen such corruption in the judicial system as I have seen in this case.

column3: Supreme Court issues two illegitimate decisions on same-sex marriage
column4: First, a homosexual judge in a long-term gay relationship was assigned the case, and refused to disclose his relationship before declaring that marriage is unconstitutional.

column3: Supreme Court issues two illegitimate decisions on same-sex marriage
column4: Then Stephen Reinhardt, the senior judge in the uber-liberal Ninth Circuit wrote the appeals court opinion invalidating Proposition 8 despite the fact that his own wife advised the lawyers challenging the initiative.

column3: Supreme Court issues two illegitimate decisions on same-sex marriage
column4: To make matters worse, the elected officials responsible for defending the vote of the people and who swore an oath to do so – then Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger, current Governor Jerry Brown, and state Attorney General Kamala Harris – shamefully abandoned their duty and left marriage defenseless.

column3: Supreme Court issues two illegitimate decisions on same-sex marriage
column4: The Supreme Court has rewarded this corruption and effectively given negligent public officials a pocket veto over ballot measures they don’t like.

column3: Supreme Court issues two illegitimate decisions on same-sex marriage
column4: All they have to do now is refuse to defend a law passed by the people, and it will crash and burn in the courts.

column3: Supreme Court issues two illegitimate decisions on same-sex marriage
column4: Despite the loss of marriage in California, the Supreme Court has taken pains to limit the impact of their decision to California by basing their ruling on narrow legal grounds.

column3: Supreme Court issues two illegitimate decisions on same-sex marriage
column4: It does not apply to any other state – at least for now.

column3: Supreme Court issues two illegitimate decisions on same-sex marriage
column4: But you can bet that homosexual activists and their rapacious lawyers won’t let it rest at that.

column3: Supreme Court issues two illegitimate decisions on same-sex marriage
column4: And that brings me to the federal Defense of Marriage Act ruling.

column3: Supreme Court issues two illegitimate decisions on same-sex marriage
column4: In a separate case the Court invalidated Section 3 of DOMA.

column3: Supreme Court issues two illegitimate decisions on same-sex marriage
column4: The ruling will force the federal government to recognize same-sex relationships as “marriages” in the few outlier states that have bought into the lie and rejected thousands of years of history and common sense.

column3: Supreme Court issues two illegitimate decisions on same-sex marriage
column4: And it will create chaos as same-sex couples move to other states that have held true, and demand the same recognition from and in those states.

column3: Supreme Court issues two illegitimate decisions on same-sex marriage
column4: The Supreme Court clearly also got that case wrong, but the ruling is not nearly as important as the Prop 8 ruling.

column3: President Obama’s climate speech: 10 takeaways
column4: Updated 06/26/2013 02:23 PM EDT President Barack Obama outlined a wide-ranging climate plan Tuesday that’s centered on greenhouse gas regulations for power plants — while making a surprise mention of the Keystone XL oil pipeline and defending his increasingly embattled nominee for EPA administrator.

column3: President Obama’s climate speech: 10 takeaways
column4: “The question now is whether we will have the courage to act before it is too late,” Obama said in a lengthy speech at Georgetown University that formally introduced his second-term climate agenda.

column3: President Obama’s climate speech: 10 takeaways
column4: “And how we answer will have a profound impact on the world we leave behind not just to you but to your children and your grandchildren.

column3: President Obama’s climate speech: 10 takeaways
column4: As a president, as a father and as an American, I am here to say we need to act.” Story Continued Below Here’s what you need to know about the speech and Obama’s climate plan: ( WATCH: Obama's full speech on climate change) 1\.

column3: President Obama’s climate speech: 10 takeaways
column4: Obama dropped a Keystone bombshell Despite expectations that the president would steer clear of mentioning Keystone — and the fact that the White House plan never mentions the project — Obama announced that he would support building the pipeline only if it won’t “significantly” increase greenhouse gas emissions.

column3: President Obama’s climate speech: 10 takeaways
column4: Obama didn’t say if he thinks Keystone can meet that standard, although a draft State Department study issued in March called the project’s environmental impact negligible.

column3: President Obama’s climate speech: 10 takeaways
column4: “Our national interest will be served only if this project does not significantly exacerbate the problem of carbon pollution,” Obama said.

column3: President Obama’s climate speech: 10 takeaways
column4: “The net effects of the pipeline’s impact on our climate will be absolutely critical to determining whether this project is allowed to go forward.” In its draft study in March, the State Department downplayed worries that Keystone would inspire a huge, carbon-spewing increase in oil production from Canada’s tar sands region — arguing that Canadians will tap that supply “with or without the proposed project,” and that the crude could be exported by rail.

column3: President Obama’s climate speech: 10 takeaways
column4: Greens disagree, saying the pipeline is critical to whether Canada has any incentive to ramp up production.

column3: President Obama’s climate speech: 10 takeaways
column4: Both supporters and opponents of the pipeline issued statements during the speech calling Obama’s words favorable for their side.

column3: President Obama’s climate speech: 10 takeaways
column4: ( Also on POLITICO: Obama urges action on climate change) 2\.

column3: President Obama’s climate speech: 10 takeaways
column4: The president went to bat for McCarthy Obama reserved special praise for Gina McCarthy, his nominee to head the Environmental Protection Agency.

column3: President Obama’s climate speech: 10 takeaways
column4: McCarthy’s nomination was already being held up by Senate Republicans’ complaints that the agency is secretive, and Obama’s climate push has prompted some top GOP lawmakers to warn that she faces even more trouble.

column3: President Obama’s climate speech: 10 takeaways
column4: “The Senate should confirm her without any further obstruction or delay,” Obama said, noting that McCarthy, who currently heads the EPA’s air office, has worked for past Republican governors.

column3: President Obama’s climate speech: 10 takeaways
column4: And he took a few shots at Republicans who question climate science.

column3: President Obama’s climate speech: 10 takeaways
column4: “We don’t have time for a meeting of the Flat Earth Society,” Obama said.

column3: President Obama’s climate speech: 10 takeaways
column4: “Sticking your head in the sand might make you feel safer, but it’s not going to protect you from the coming storm.” ( Also on POLITICO: Coal industry no fan of President Obama plan) 3\.

column3: President Obama’s climate speech: 10 takeaways
column4: Obama is done waiting for Congress Obama tried to get a cap-and-trade bill through Congress during his first term, and in this year’s State of the Union address he gave lawmakers one final ultimatum.

column3: President Obama’s climate speech: 10 takeaways
column4: “If Congress won’t act soon to protect future generations, I will,” he said in the February speech.

column3: President Obama’s climate speech: 10 takeaways
column4: “I will direct my Cabinet to come up with executive actions we can take, now and in the future, to reduce pollution, prepare our communities for the consequences of climate change and speed the transition to more sustainable sources of energy.” But even at the time, the universal expectation was that Congress had zero chance of passing any serious climate legislation.

column3: President Obama’s climate speech: 10 takeaways
column4: His rollout Tuesday acknowledged that reality.

column3: President Obama’s climate speech: 10 takeaways
column4: Now, the president is directing agencies from the Department of Agriculture to the EPA to take action — with the main onus falling on the EPA.

column3: President Obama’s climate speech: 10 takeaways
column4: ( Also on POLITICO: Experts' verdict: Plan is not enough) 4\.

column3: President Obama’s climate speech: 10 takeaways
column4: The plan won’t target all parts of the economy The days when it seemed possible to impose an economywide cap on greenhouse gas emissions are long gone.

column3: President Obama’s climate speech: 10 takeaways
column4: Instead, the president is taking a piecemeal approach that focuses on one sector of the economy at a time.

column3: President Obama’s climate speech: 10 takeaways
column4: In his first term, he tackled transportation, which accounts for about 30 percent of the country’s greenhouse gas output, by imposing tough standards to reduce vehicles’ emissions and increase fuel economy.

column3: President Obama to unveil sweeping climate plan
column4: President Barack Obama’s new climate initiative will impose deadlines for EPA to write rules throttling carbon dioxide emissions at U.S. power plants, part of a series of efforts that could hit the coal industry hard both at home and abroad — but also create jobs and spark the economy, the administration says.

column3: President Obama to unveil sweeping climate plan
column4: Tuesday’s long-awaited roll-out at Georgetown University will lay out a three-part strategy to lessen U.S. greenhouse gas emissions, help lead international climate talks and protect the U.S. from the effects of climate change.

column3: President Obama to unveil sweeping climate plan
column4: Story Continued Below The plan is a blend of new and old.

column3: President Obama to unveil sweeping climate plan
column4: ( Also on POLITICO: Experts' verdict: Obama's climate effort not enough) It features updated versions of the president’s first-term emphasis on tightening vehicle emissions standards, fostering the development of “clean coal” technology and offering billions of dollars for green energy, as well as a renewed push to lead international climate talks.

column3: President Obama to unveil sweeping climate plan
column4: It will seek to push solar and wind energy on federal lands and subsidized housing, as well as encourage coal users to switch to natural gas.

column3: President Obama to unveil sweeping climate plan
column4: And it takes aim again at the oil and gas industry tax breaks that Obama has unsuccessfully urged Congress to kill.

column3: President Obama to unveil sweeping climate plan
column4: The administration is nonetheless hoping for support from industry, something it succeeded in attracting for Obama’s first-term deal that dramatically tightened fuel efficiency limits for cars.

column3: President Obama to unveil sweeping climate plan
column4: The plan says the White House aims to “encourage the development of a global market” for natural gas, as well as “continue to promote the safe and secure use of nuclear power worldwide.” ( Also on POLITICO: Obama's race against time on climate) And the White House is doubling down on the president’s past green-jobs rhetoric, saying that “these steps will also spark the sort of innovation that drives economic growth and creates good-paying jobs that can’t be shipped overseas; help modernize our power plants by equipping them with the latest technology … and move our economy towards cleaner, more efficient forms of energy that will cut our reliance on foreign oil.” But by including efforts to help states and cities gird their roads, bridges, and shorelines against rising seas and other effects of climate change, the administration is making a tacit acknowledgment that it’s too late to prevent the damage altogether.

column3: President Obama to unveil sweeping climate plan
column4: Even before Obama had a chance to give his speech, the president was drawing praise from environmental group but also complaints from some members of Congress that he was acting rashly — or too late.

column3: President Obama to unveil sweeping climate plan
column4: “You can’t do something that is unattainable,” Democratic Sen. Joe Manchin, from coal-friendly West Virginia, told POLITICO on Monday.

column3: President Obama to unveil sweeping climate plan
column4: “It’s unreasonable.

column3: President Obama to unveil sweeping climate plan
column4: What they’re doing has never been done.” But Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) offered the opposite perspective when asked if this was a speech Obama should have given early in his first term.

column3: President Obama to unveil sweeping climate plan
column4: “If you’re asking me is he a little bit late in this, the answer is yes,” Sanders said.

column3: President Obama to unveil sweeping climate plan
column4: The White House sought to heighten the historic import of the speech by noting it will take place on the steps of the university’s Old North building, where past presidential visitors included George Washington and Abraham Lincoln.

column3: President Obama to unveil sweeping climate plan
column4: But the centerpiece of Obama’s effort will be thoroughly modern: long-expected Environmental Protection Agency regulations targeting both new and existing power plants, which would have an especially big impact on those burning coal.

column3: President Obama to unveil sweeping climate plan
column4: Obama will issue a presidential memorandum “directing the EPA to start the important work” of regulating carbon emissions from both new and existing coal plants, a senior administration official told reporters Monday.

column3: President Obama to unveil sweeping climate plan
column4: The more important of those two is the existing-plant rule, both because it could require costly retrofits and because those plants are the largest source of carbon dioxide emissions in the U.S., at around 40 percent.

column3: President Obama to unveil sweeping climate plan
column4: Obama’s memo will specifically direct EPA to issue a draft rule for existing plants by next June, finish a rule by June 2015 and then work with states to implement the rule.

column3: President Obama to unveil sweeping climate plan
column4: He will also direct EPA to propose a new rule for future power plants by September, a White House official said.

column3: President Obama to unveil sweeping climate plan
column4: EPA had already proposed a draft rule for future plants but missed an April deadline for finishing it, prompting several states and cities to threaten lawsuits.

column3: President Obama to unveil sweeping climate plan
column4: The delay provoked speculation that the agency would make major changes in the rule, perhaps relaxing some features in hopes of protecting it from court challenges.

column3: Obama planning to sidestep Congress for next phase in climate change agenda
column4: President Obama will announce Tuesday he is planning to sidestep Congress to implement a national plan to combat climate change that will include the first-ever federal regulations on carbon dioxide emitted by existing power plants, despite adamant opposition from Republicans and some energy producers.

column3: Obama planning to sidestep Congress for next phase in climate change agenda
column4: In a speech at Georgetown University Tuesday, Obama will announce he's issuing a presidential memorandum to implement the regulations, meaning none of the steps involved in the plan will require congressional approval.

column3: Obama planning to sidestep Congress for next phase in climate change agenda
column4: In addition, Obama will say he is directing his administration to allow enough renewables on public lands to power 6 million homes by 2020, effectively doubling the capacity from solar, wind and geothermal projects on federal property.

column3: Obama planning to sidestep Congress for next phase in climate change agenda
column4: Obama also was to announce $8 billion in federal loan guarantees to spur investment in technologies that can keep carbon dioxide produced by power plants from being released into the atmosphere.

column3: Obama planning to sidestep Congress for next phase in climate change agenda
column4: In taking action on his own, Obama is also signaling he will no longer wait for lawmakers to act on climate change, and instead will seek ways to work around them.

column3: Obama planning to sidestep Congress for next phase in climate change agenda
column4: The linchpin of Obama's plan, and the step activists say will have the most dramatic impact, involves limits on carbon emissions for new and existing power plants.

column3: Obama planning to sidestep Congress for next phase in climate change agenda
column4: The Obama administration has already proposed controls on new plants, but those controls have been delayed and not yet finalized.

column3: Obama planning to sidestep Congress for next phase in climate change agenda
column4: Tuesday's announcement will be the first public confirmation that Obama plans to extend carbon controls to coal-fired power plants that are currently pumping heat-trapping gases into the atmosphere.

column3: Obama planning to sidestep Congress for next phase in climate change agenda
column4: "This is the holy grail," said Melinda Pierce of Sierra Club, an environmental advocacy group.

column3: Obama planning to sidestep Congress for next phase in climate change agenda
column4: "That is the single biggest step he can take to help tackle carbon pollution."

column3: Obama planning to sidestep Congress for next phase in climate change agenda
column4: However, critics say that Obama's changes will create more problems for America's coal industry.

column3: Obama planning to sidestep Congress for next phase in climate change agenda
column4: "This proposal will buttress an EPA proposed rule issued last year for new power plants that will essentially ban coal’s use in the future," Tom Borelli, a senior fellow at FreedomWorks, told FoxNews.com.

column3: Obama planning to sidestep Congress for next phase in climate change agenda
column4: Forty percent of U.S. carbon dioxide emissions, and one-third of greenhouse gases overall, come from electric power plants, according to the U.S. Energy Information Administration, the Energy Department's statistical agency.

column3: Obama planning to sidestep Congress for next phase in climate change agenda
column4: Obama is expected to lay out a broad vision Tuesday, without detailed emission targets or specifics about how they will be put in place.

column3: Obama planning to sidestep Congress for next phase in climate change agenda
column4: Instead, the president will launch a process in which the Environmental Protection Agency will work with states to develop specific plans to rein in carbon emissions, with flexibility for each state's circumstances.

column3: Obama planning to sidestep Congress for next phase in climate change agenda
column4: Under one scenario envisioned by the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental group, states could draw on measures such as clean energy sources, carbon-trapping technology and energy efficiency to reduce the total emissions released into the air.

column3: Obama planning to sidestep Congress for next phase in climate change agenda
column4: Heather Zichal, Obama's senior energy and climate adviser, told environmental groups Monday that Obama is working with Housing and Urban Development Secretary Shaun Donovan on a target for renewable energy to be produced at federally assisted housing projects.

column3: Obama planning to sidestep Congress for next phase in climate change agenda
column4: She framed the Obama's efforts in the U.S. as part of a broader, global movement to combat climate change, trumpeting the role the U.S. can play in leading other nations to stem the warming of the planet.

column3: Obama planning to sidestep Congress for next phase in climate change agenda
column4: Paul Bledsoe, who worked on climate issues in the Clinton White House, said Zichal renewed a pledge Obama made in in his first year in office, during global climate talks in Copenhagen, to cut U.S. carbon emissions by about 17 percent by 2020, compared to 2005 levels.

column3: Obama planning to sidestep Congress for next phase in climate change agenda
column4: "This is a policy fulfillment of what the president has been talking about and trying to accomplish for five years or more," said Bledsoe, now a senior fellow at the German Marshall Fund of the United States.

column3: Obama planning to sidestep Congress for next phase in climate change agenda
column4: One key issue Obama is not expected to address Tuesday is Keystone XL, a pipeline that would carry oil extracted from tar sands in western Canada to refineries along the Texas Gulf Coast.

column3: Obama planning to sidestep Congress for next phase in climate change agenda
column4: A concerted campaign by environmental activists to persuade Obama to nix the pipeline as a "carbon bomb" appears to have gained little traction.

column3: Obama planning to sidestep Congress for next phase in climate change agenda
column4: The oil industry has been urging the president to approve the pipeline, citing jobs and economic benefits.

column3: Obama planning to sidestep Congress for next phase in climate change agenda
column4: Obama raised climate change as a key second-term issue in his inaugural address in January, but has offered few details since.

column3: Obama planning to sidestep Congress for next phase in climate change agenda
column4: In his February State of the Union, he issued an ultimatum to lawmakers: "If Congress won't act soon to protect future generations, I will."

column3: Obama planning to sidestep Congress for next phase in climate change agenda
column4: The poor prospects for getting any major climate legislation through a Republican-controlled House were on display last week when Speaker John Boehner responded to the prospect that Obama would put forth controls on existing power plants by deeming the idea "absolutely crazy."

column3: Obama planning to sidestep Congress for next phase in climate change agenda
column4: "Why would you want to increase the cost of energy and kill more American jobs?"

column3: Obama planning to sidestep Congress for next phase in climate change agenda
column4: said Boehner, R-Ohio, echoing the warnings of some industry groups.

column3: Obama planning to sidestep Congress for next phase in climate change agenda
column4: Sidestepping Congress by using executive action doesn't guarantee Obama smooth sailing.

column3: Obama planning to sidestep Congress for next phase in climate change agenda
column4: Lawmakers could introduce legislation to thwart Obama's efforts.

column3: Obama planning to sidestep Congress for next phase in climate change agenda
column4: And the rules for existing power plants will almost certainly face legal challenges in court.

column3: Obama planning to sidestep Congress for next phase in climate change agenda
column4: The Supreme Court has upheld the EPA's authority to regulate greenhouse gases under the Clean Air Act, but how the EPA goes about that effort remains largely uncharted waters.

column3: Obama planning to sidestep Congress for next phase in climate change agenda
column4: Even if legal and political obstacles are overcome, it will take years for the new measures to be put in place, likely running up against the end of Obama's presidency or even beyond it.

column3: Obama planning to sidestep Congress for next phase in climate change agenda
column4: White House aides say that's one reason Obama is ensuring the process starts now, while there are still more than three years left in his final term.

column3: Obama planning to sidestep Congress for next phase in climate change agenda
column4: Under the process outlined in the Clean Air Act, the EPA cannot act unilaterally, but must work with states to develop the standards, said Jonas Monast, an attorney who directs the climate and energy program at Duke University.

column3: Obama planning to sidestep Congress for next phase in climate change agenda
column4: An initial proposal will be followed by a months-long public comment period before the EPA can issue final guidance to states.

column3: Obama planning to sidestep Congress for next phase in climate change agenda
column4: Then the states must create actual plans for plants within their borders, a process likely to take the better part of a year.

column3: Obama planning to sidestep Congress for next phase in climate change agenda
column4: Then the EPA has another four months to decide whether to approve each state's plan before the implementation period can start.

column3: Obama planning to sidestep Congress for next phase in climate change agenda
column4: The Associated Press contributed to this report.

column3: Plane for Havana Leaves Moscow Without Snowden
column4: WASHINGTON — Frustrated Obama administration officials pressed Russia on Monday to turn over Edward J. Snowden, the national security contractor who disclosed surveillance programs, while warning China of “consequences” for letting him flee to Moscow.

column3: Plane for Havana Leaves Moscow Without Snowden
column4: As Mr. Snowden remained out of sight, apparently holed up in Moscow awaiting word of his fate, what started as a dramatic escape story involving a self-described whistle-blower evolved into a diplomatic incident in which the United States faces an open rift with one major power and a tense standoff with another.

column3: Plane for Havana Leaves Moscow Without Snowden
column4: Hopes for a quick resolution had faded by nightfall.

column3: Plane for Havana Leaves Moscow Without Snowden
column4: Secretary of State John Kerry said China’s decision to allow Mr. Snowden to leave Hong Kong despite an arrest request from the United States would have “without any question some effect, an impact on the relationship, and consequences.” He called on Russia to expel Mr. Snowden.

column3: Plane for Havana Leaves Moscow Without Snowden
column4: “I would urge them to live by the standards of the law, because that’s in the interest of everybody,” Mr. Kerry said.

column3: Plane for Havana Leaves Moscow Without Snowden
column4: He pointed out that the United States in the past two years had transferred seven prisoners Russia had sought, though the parallel is not exact, since Mr. Snowden is not being held by the Russian government.

column3: Plane for Havana Leaves Moscow Without Snowden
column4: At the White House, President Obama’s press secretary, Jay Carney, reinforced what he called “our frustration and disappointment with Hong Kong and China,” calling their refusal to detain Mr. Snowden a “serious setback” in relations.

column3: Plane for Havana Leaves Moscow Without Snowden
column4: He said the Hong Kong authorities had been notified that Mr. Snowden’s passport had been revoked, and he dismissed their explanation that they had no legal basis to stop Mr. Snowden.

column3: Plane for Havana Leaves Moscow Without Snowden
column4: “We do not buy the suggestion that China could not have taken action,” Mr. Carney said.

column3: Plane for Havana Leaves Moscow Without Snowden
column4: American officials also openly mocked China and Russia as states that repress free speech and transparency and therefore are hardly apt refuges for someone fighting government secrecy in the United States.

column3: Plane for Havana Leaves Moscow Without Snowden
column4: “I wonder if Mr. Snowden chose China and Russia as assistants in his flight from justice because they’re such powerful bastions of Internet freedom,” Mr. Kerry said sarcastically during a stop in New Delhi.

column3: Plane for Havana Leaves Moscow Without Snowden
column4: Mr. Carney said Mr. Snowden’s chosen destinations indicated “his true motive throughout has been to injure the national security of the United States.” The strong words went beyond typical diplomatic language and underscored the growing ramifications of the case for the United States.

column3: Plane for Havana Leaves Moscow Without Snowden
column4: The Obama administration’s inability, at least for now, to influence China, Russia and countries in Latin America that may accept Mr. Snowden for asylum, like Ecuador, brought home the limits of American power around the world.

column3: Plane for Havana Leaves Moscow Without Snowden
column4: Ecuador’s foreign minister, Ricardo Patiño, criticized the United States on Monday for its pursuit of Mr. Snowden.

column3: Plane for Havana Leaves Moscow Without Snowden
column4: “The one who is denounced pursues the denouncer,” Mr. Patiño said at a news conference in Hanoi, Vietnam, a stop on a previously scheduled diplomatic visit to Asia.

column3: Plane for Havana Leaves Moscow Without Snowden
column4: “The man who tries to provide light and transparency to issues that affect everyone is pursued by those who should be giving explanations about the denunciations that have been presented.” Ecuador’s president, Rafael Correa, wrote on his Twitter account, “We will analyze very responsibly the Snowden case and with absolute sovereignty will make the decision we consider the most appropriate.” The United States remains Ecuador’s leading trading partner, but Washington’s influence in Quito has been slight since Mr. Correa became president in 2007.

column3: Plane for Havana Leaves Moscow Without Snowden
column4: He has repeatedly flouted and tweaked the United States, by for example stopping American antidrug flights out of a military base in Manta, and expelling the American ambassador in 2011 after WikiLeaks cables suggested she felt Mr. Correa had tolerated police corruption.

column3: Plane for Havana Leaves Moscow Without Snowden
column4: A range of American officials, including the deputy secretary of state and the F.B.I.

column3: Plane for Havana Leaves Moscow Without Snowden
column4: director, spent Monday reaching out to their Russian counterparts seeking cooperation, without any apparent result.

column3: Plane for Havana Leaves Moscow Without Snowden
column4: Mr. Snowden, who spent Sunday night in the transit zone of Moscow’s Sheremetyevo airport, did not board the flight for Havana he was said to have booked, and he made no public appearance or statement.

column3: Plane for Havana Leaves Moscow Without Snowden
column4: American officials said they believed he was still in Moscow, but it was unclear whether his failure to continue on to Cuba, Ecuador or elsewhere was a sign that Russia was considering handing him over to the United States, sheltering him itself, planning to allow him to leave later or trying to extract information from him before deciding.

column3: Plane for Havana Leaves Moscow Without Snowden
column4: The United States and Russia do not have an extradition treaty.

column3: Plane for Havana Leaves Moscow Without Snowden
column4: Nikolay N. Zakharov, a spokesman for Russia’s Federal Security Service, or F.S.B., declined to say if intelligence officials had met with Mr. Snowden, nor would he say if they had sought to examine any secret files he was said to be carrying.

column3: Plane for Havana Leaves Moscow Without Snowden
column4: “On this question, we will not comment,” Mr. Zakharov said.

column3: Plane for Havana Leaves Moscow Without Snowden

column3: Inside the border deal that almost failed
column4: Updated 06/21/2013 06:04 PM EDT Sen. Chuck Schumer spent Tuesday privately urging President Barack Obama and the entire Democratic caucus to just be patient — a border security deal they could accept was still within reach.

column3: Inside the border deal that almost failed
column4: But after a testy, 45-minute call that night with a lead Republican negotiator of a possible compromise, Schumer could no longer follow his own advice.

column3: Inside the border deal that almost failed
column4: Story Continued Below The New York Democrat began to lose hope.

column3: Inside the border deal that almost failed
column4: Rather than deliver immigration reform with the 70-plus-vote show of force that Schumer had hyped so often, Democrats and the Gang of Eight would have to scratch and scrape their way to a filibuster-proof majority.

column3: Inside the border deal that almost failed
column4: And yet, less than 24 hours later, they had a deal.

column3: Inside the border deal that almost failed
column4: The answer to their problem turned out to be simple: Throw money at it.

column3: Inside the border deal that almost failed

column3: Inside the border deal that almost failed

column3: Inside the border deal that almost failed
column4: And by Wednesday afternoon, Republican negotiators led by North Dakota Sen. John Hoeven and Tennessee Sen. Bob Corker had dropped their demand to make the path to citizenship for country’s 11 million undocumented immigrants contingent upon the government achieving a 90 percent apprehension rate along the border.

column3: Inside the border deal that almost failed
column4: In return, they secured a staggering $30 billion for what is now being called a “border surge.” “Frankly they ended up having to give more,” said Hoeven, who had the contentious phone call with Schumer.

column3: Inside the border deal that almost failed
column4: ( Also on POLITICO: 70 votes now possible in immigration deal) The Gang of Eight, the White House and Republican senators still need to resolve differences over restricting immigrant access to government benefits.

column3: Inside the border deal that almost failed
column4: But the agreement on border security eases passage next week of the overall bill and renews hopes among the Gang of Eight that it is closing in on an improbable, overwhelmingly bipartisan victory that few would’ve predicted only six months ago.

column3: Inside the border deal that almost failed
column4: “Today,” Schumer said from the Senate floor Thursday, “is a breakthrough day.” Obama has had little role in the Senate debate thus far, intentionally.

column3: Inside the border deal that almost failed
column4: But at the height of the talks Tuesday, the president weighed in with Schumer from Air Force One while traveling through Europe.

column3: Inside the border deal that almost failed

column3: Inside the border deal that almost failed
column4: Schumer said they were trying to find a different benchmark, and Obama told him to keep working toward an agreement.

column3: Inside the border deal that almost failed
