column3: Inside the border deal that almost failed
column4: Democrats were eager to quell the growing perception that the bill was weak on the border, in the hopes of pushing the House into action.

column3: Inside the border deal that almost failed
column4: And Republicans, struggling to right their woes with Hispanic voters, were eager to find a bill that gave them sufficient political cover on the border — while appeasing their business allies hungry for an immigration law.

column3: Inside the border deal that almost failed
column4: Money broke the impasse — more money than Democrats, Republicans and veterans of past immigration fights could have ever imagined.

column3: Inside the border deal that almost failed
column4: The original Gang of Eight bill included $6.5 billion for border security, and they thought that was an extraordinary, even unnecessary, investment after years of infrastructure and manpower buildup along the Southwest border.

column3: Inside the border deal that almost failed

column3: Obama renews push for nuclear arms cuts in Berlin speech
column4: President Obama renewed his push for a reduction in the world's nuclear stockpiles during a wide-ranging speech in Berlin on Wednesday, claiming the U.S. could continue to maintain a strong deterrent while ultimately striving toward eliminating nuclear weapons.

column3: Obama renews push for nuclear arms cuts in Berlin speech
column4: "So long as nuclear weapons exist, we are not truly safe," Obama said.

column3: Obama renews push for nuclear arms cuts in Berlin speech
column4: Speaking at the Brandenburg Gate, Obama proposed a one-third reduction in U.S. and Russian strategic nuclear warheads.

column3: Obama renews push for nuclear arms cuts in Berlin speech
column4: This would lower the total number of warheads in each country to between 1,000 and 1,100.

column3: Obama renews push for nuclear arms cuts in Berlin speech
column4: The potential reductions would be from a current limit of 1,550, the number set in the New START treaty that was ratified by the Senate in December 2010.

column3: Obama renews push for nuclear arms cuts in Berlin speech
column4: Though Obama is likely to meet some resistance in Congress to further eroding America's stockpile, the president held out what he acknowledged was a "distant" goal of ridding the world of nuclear weapons -- and in the short term, moving beyond "Cold War nuclear postures."

column3: Obama renews push for nuclear arms cuts in Berlin speech
column4: He addressed the nuclear reduction effort during a speech that focused in large part on Germany's and Berlin's tumultuous history.

column3: Obama renews push for nuclear arms cuts in Berlin speech
column4: To the symbolic backdrop of the Brandenburg Gate, Obama lauded German citizens who chose "whether to be defined by a wall or whether to tear it down."

column3: Obama renews push for nuclear arms cuts in Berlin speech
column4: The president also reprised his high-profile appearance in the German capital during his 2008 presidential race.

column3: Obama renews push for nuclear arms cuts in Berlin speech
column4: The crowd on Wednesday was far smaller, and also at a different venue.

column3: Obama renews push for nuclear arms cuts in Berlin speech
column4: German Chancellor Angela Merkel denied him the option of speaking at the Brandenburg Gate in 2008, saying only sitting presidents were granted such an honor.

column3: Obama renews push for nuclear arms cuts in Berlin speech
column4: As Obama addressed German history and the nuclear issue, he also covered a series of what some might call lofty goals -- tackling climate change, closing Guantanamo Bay and ending AIDS.

column3: Obama renews push for nuclear arms cuts in Berlin speech
column4: Obama tried to make the case that even though the Berlin Wall came down 23 years ago and the threat of nuclear war has dissipated, the type of activism apparent during the Cold War needs to be applied to such current challenges as climate change, counterterrorism and the push for democratic values beyond the United States and Europe.

column3: Obama renews push for nuclear arms cuts in Berlin speech
column4: Obama did not propose any timeline for achieving the proposed nuclear cuts.

column3: Obama renews push for nuclear arms cuts in Berlin speech
column4: Obama is fresh from a two-day summit of the Group of Eight industrial economies.

column3: Obama renews push for nuclear arms cuts in Berlin speech

column3: Obama renews push for nuclear arms cuts in Berlin speech

column3: In Berlin, Obama calls for dramatic nuclear cuts
column4: Updated 06/20/2013 08:14 AM EDT President Barack Obama called Wednesday for “peace with justice” as he proposed reducing U.S. nuclear arsenals by as much as one-third in a wide-ranging call for action delivered on the eastern side of Berlin’s Brandenburg Gate.

column3: In Berlin, Obama calls for dramatic nuclear cuts
column4: “Our work is not yet done.

column3: In Berlin, Obama calls for dramatic nuclear cuts
column4: For we are not only citizens of America or Germany, we are citizens of the world,” Obama said, drawing on John F. Kennedy’s 1963 speech on the west side of the the city, in which he called on Berliners to look ahead to “the day of peace with justice” and to the rest of mankind.

column3: In Berlin, Obama calls for dramatic nuclear cuts
column4: “We may not live in fear of nuclear annihilation — but as long as nuclear weapons exist, we are not truly safe.” Story Continued Below He said the United States is now looking to do more to reduce that threat.

column3: In Berlin, Obama calls for dramatic nuclear cuts

column3: In Berlin, Obama calls for dramatic nuclear cuts
column4: Obama has directed the Defense Department to strengthen its non-nuclear capabilities, to reduce the role of nuclear weapons in deterring non-nuclear attacks, and to reduce the role of nuclear launches in contingency planning.

column4: New START calls for the United States and Russia to cut their arsenals to 1,550 nuclear warheads by 2018.

column3: In Berlin, Obama calls for dramatic nuclear cuts
column4: Obama’s proposal, which would bring that number down to about 1,000, comes as tensions between the United States and Russia over Syria have been on stark display — most recently on Monday, as Obama and Russian President Vladimir Putin delivered a cold joint statement at the G8 summit, and appeared to make little progress on the issue.

column3: In Berlin, Obama calls for dramatic nuclear cuts
column4: In another big speech in a major European city, in Prague during the spring of 2009, Obama set an even more ambitious long-term goal: “a world without nuclear weapons.” It’s a hope he’s reiterated since, including at last year’s Nuclear Security Summit in Seoul, and one in which he’s said he still believes.

column3: In Berlin, Obama calls for dramatic nuclear cuts
column4: Obama spent much of his speech Wednesday leaning on Kennedy’s “Ich bin ein Berliner” speech given 50 years ago next week, as he laid out a vision in which the United States and Germany “pursue peace and justice not only for our countries, but for all mankind.” While remaining “vigilant” about terror threats, “we must move beyond the mindset of perpetual war,” Obama said, echoing the philosophy he laid out last month in his speech on counterterrorism in the post-post-9/11 era.

column3: In Berlin, Obama calls for dramatic nuclear cuts
column4: In the United States, “that means redoubling our efforts to close the prison at Guantanamo,” he said to cheers.

column3: Supreme Court rules human genes cannot be patented
column4: WASHINGTON –  The Supreme Court ruled Thursday that companies cannot patent parts of naturally-occurring human genes, a decision with the potential to profoundly affect the emerging and lucrative medical and biotechnology industries.

column3: Supreme Court rules human genes cannot be patented
column4: The high court's unanimous judgment reverses three decades of patent awards by government officials.

column3: Supreme Court rules human genes cannot be patented
column4: It throws out patents held by Salt Lake City-based Myriad Genetics Inc. on an increasingly popular breast cancer test brought into the public eye recently by actress Angelina Jolie's revelation that she had a double mastectomy because of one of the genes involved in this case.

column3: Supreme Court rules human genes cannot be patented
column4: Justice Clarence Thomas, who wrote the court's decision, said that Myriad's assertion -- that the DNA it isolated from the body for its proprietary breast and ovarian cancer tests were patentable -- had to be dismissed because it violates patent rules.

column3: Supreme Court rules human genes cannot be patented
column4: The court has said that laws of nature, natural phenomena and abstract ideas are not patentable.

column3: Supreme Court rules human genes cannot be patented
column4: "We hold that a naturally occurring DNA segment is a product of nature and not patent eligible merely because it has been isolated," Thomas said.

column3: Supreme Court rules human genes cannot be patented
column4: Patents are the legal protection that gives inventors the right to prevent others from making, using or selling a novel device, process or application.

column3: Supreme Court rules human genes cannot be patented
column4: The U.S. Patent and Trademark Office has been awarding patents on human genes for almost 30 years, but opponents of Myriad Genetics Inc.'s patents on the two genes linked to increased risk of breast and ovarian cancer say such protection should not be given to something that can be found inside the human body.

column3: Supreme Court rules human genes cannot be patented
column4: The company has used its patent to come up with its BRACAnalysis test, which looks for mutations on the breast cancer predisposition gene, or BRCA.

column3: Supreme Court rules human genes cannot be patented
column4: Those mutations are associated with much greater risks of breast and ovarian cancer.

column3: Supreme Court rules human genes cannot be patented
column4: Women with a faulty gene have a three to seven times greater risk of developing breast cancer and also have a higher risk of ovarian cancer.

column3: Supreme Court rules human genes cannot be patented
column4: Myriad sells the only BRCA gene test.

column3: Supreme Court rules human genes cannot be patented
column4: Opponents of its patents say the company can use the patents to keep other researchers from working with the BRCA gene to develop other tests.

column3: Supreme Court rules human genes cannot be patented
column4: "Today, the court struck down a major barrier to patient care and medical innovation," said Sandra Park, a lawyer for the American Civil Liberties Union Women's Rights Project.

column3: Supreme Court rules human genes cannot be patented
column4: "Myriad did not invent the BRCA genes and should not control them.

column3: Supreme Court rules human genes cannot be patented
column4: Because of this ruling, patients will have greater access to genetic testing and scientists can engage in research on these genes without fear of being sued."

column3: Supreme Court rules human genes cannot be patented
column4: Jolie revealed last month that her mother died of ovarian cancer and that her maternal grandmother also had the disease.

column3: Supreme Court rules human genes cannot be patented
column4: She said she carries a defective BRCA1 gene that puts her at high risk of developing breast and ovarian cancers, and her doctor said that the test that turned up the faulty gene link led Jolie to have both of her healthy breasts removed to try to avoid the same fate.

column3: Supreme Court rules human genes cannot be patented
column4: Companies have billions of dollars of investment and years of research on the line in this case.

column3: Supreme Court rules human genes cannot be patented
column4: Their advocates argue that without the ability to recoup their investment through the profits that patents bring, breakthrough scientific discoveries to combat all kinds of medical maladies wouldn't happen.

column3: Supreme Court rules human genes cannot be patented
column4: But "genes and the information they encode area not patent eligible ... simply because they have been isolated from the surrounding genetic material," Thomas said.

column3: Supreme Court rules human genes cannot be patented
column4: In a concurring opinion, Justice Antonin Scalia said "the portion of the DNA isolated from its natural state sought to be patented is identical to that portion of the DNA in its natural state."

column3: Supreme Court rules human genes cannot be patented
column4: A Myriad spokesman did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

column3: Supreme Court rules human genes cannot be patented
column4: The court did rule that synthetically created DNA, known as cDNA, can be patented "because it is not naturally occurring," Thomas said.

column3: Supreme Court rules human genes cannot be patented
column4: And Thomas noted there are still ways for Myriad to make money off its discovery.

column3: Supreme Court rules human genes cannot be patented
column4: "Had Myriad created an innovative method of manipulating genes while searching for the BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes, it could possibly have sought a method patent," he said.

column3: Supreme Court rules human genes cannot be patented
column4: And he noted that the case before the court did not include patents on the application of knowledge about the two genes.

column3: Supreme Court rules human genes cannot be patented
column4: The case is 12-398, Association for Molecular Pathology v. Myriad Genetics, Inc.

column3: Revolt Among Republicans on Immigration Bill: 70 House Members Risk Careers in Planned Showdown With Leadership
column4: UPDATE: House Speaker John Boehner said Thursday he doesn’t “intend” to push an immigration bill that violates Republican Party “principles.” UPDATE II: Three Republican House members leading the effort appeared on “The Glenn Beck Program” Thursday night to explain their opposition to the immigration bill.

column3: Revolt Among Republicans on Immigration Bill: 70 House Members Risk Careers in Planned Showdown With Leadership
column4: — Seventy House Republicans are planning a politically risky showdown with Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio) to try to force additional debate on an immigration bill they say will mean amnesty for illegal immigrants and have dire consequences for the country.

column3: Revolt Among Republicans on Immigration Bill: 70 House Members Risk Careers in Planned Showdown With Leadership
column4: The 70 members are petitioning for a special Republican conference meeting on the bill, a “highly unusual” move to go head-to-head with the speaker, according to Reps. Michele Bachmann (Minn.), Steve King (Iowa) and Louie Gohmert (Texas), who are serving as spokespersons for the group.

column3: Revolt Among Republicans on Immigration Bill: 70 House Members Risk Careers in Planned Showdown With Leadership
column4: Bachmann, King and Gohmert told TheBlaze the group is invoking the Hastert Rule: requiring support from a majority of the majority to bring a bill forward.

column3: Revolt Among Republicans on Immigration Bill: 70 House Members Risk Careers in Planned Showdown With Leadership
column4: The petition is expected to go to the House leadership on Friday, but it’s possible some signatories might remove their names due to political risk, or that Boehner could head off the challenge by striking a deal.

column3: Revolt Among Republicans on Immigration Bill: 70 House Members Risk Careers in Planned Showdown With Leadership
column4: Going against leadership in such a way could have harsh political consequences for the signatories, including retaliation such as permanently getting passed over for chairmanship positions.

column3: Revolt Among Republicans on Immigration Bill: 70 House Members Risk Careers in Planned Showdown With Leadership
column4: A Boehner spokesman did not comment on the letter.

column3: Revolt Among Republicans on Immigration Bill: 70 House Members Risk Careers in Planned Showdown With Leadership
column4: Boehner is on a tight schedule for getting immigration reform passed in the House, predicting this week that Congress could finalize a bill for President Barack Obama’s signature by the end of the year.

column3: Revolt Among Republicans on Immigration Bill: 70 House Members Risk Careers in Planned Showdown With Leadership
column4: Any major challenge could ignite pushback from the American public that could force lawmakers to scrap the bill, as happened in the 2007 immigration effort.

column3: Revolt Among Republicans on Immigration Bill: 70 House Members Risk Careers in Planned Showdown With Leadership
column4: The three representatives told TheBlaze that more than half of the Republicans in the House were elected after 2007, and have no concept of how strongly the public opposed the bill.

column3: Revolt Among Republicans on Immigration Bill: 70 House Members Risk Careers in Planned Showdown With Leadership
column4: In an interview with World Net Daily this week, Bachmann predicted that if the immigration bill becomes law, “the whole political system will change.” “This is President Obama’s number one political agenda item because he knows we will never again have a Republican president, ever, if amnesty goes into effect.

column3: Revolt Among Republicans on Immigration Bill: 70 House Members Risk Careers in Planned Showdown With Leadership
column4: We will perpetually have a progressive, liberal president, probably a Democrat, and we will probably see the House of Representatives go into Democrat hands and the Senate will stay in Democrat hands,” Bachmann said.

column3: Revolt Among Republicans on Immigration Bill: 70 House Members Risk Careers in Planned Showdown With Leadership
column4: She also said that if it passes, the bill will create a permanent progressive class.

column3: Revolt Among Republicans on Immigration Bill: 70 House Members Risk Careers in Planned Showdown With Leadership
column4: “That’s what’s at risk right now.

column3: Revolt Among Republicans on Immigration Bill: 70 House Members Risk Careers in Planned Showdown With Leadership
column4: It may sound melodramatic, I don’t mean it that way, but this is that big and that important,” Bachmann said.

column3: Gang of Eight seeks alternative to John Cornyn amendment
column4: Sen. Marco Rubio initially praised a border security proposal from Sen. John Cornyn, helping to make it the leading choice of conservatives demanding tighter enforcement measures.

column3: Gang of Eight seeks alternative to John Cornyn amendment
column4: Now others in the Gang of Eight fear Cornyn’s plan could sink their entire immigration deal.

column3: Gang of Eight seeks alternative to John Cornyn amendment
column4: Story Continued Below Sen. John McCain (R-Ariz.) is beginning to speak out forcefully against the Cornyn language, bombarding the Texas Republican with critical comments from the Senate floor.

column3: Gang of Eight seeks alternative to John Cornyn amendment
column4: Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) is lobbying other Republicans on potential compromises.

column3: Gang of Eight seeks alternative to John Cornyn amendment
column4: And Rubio, although he said Wednesday that the Cornyn plan “dramatically improves the bill,” is working on a package that others in the Gang of Eight hope could emerge as an alternative.

column3: Gang of Eight seeks alternative to John Cornyn amendment
column4: ( PHOTOS: At a glance: The Senate immigration deal) The fear of some bill proponents: the longer the Cornyn plan hangs out there, the more likely it will become a magnet for Republicans — and accepting anything short of it will be considered a sacrifice.

column3: Gang of Eight seeks alternative to John Cornyn amendment
column4: If that happens, then the Gang of Eight won’t be able to get the large bipartisan majority that its leaders, including McCain and Sen. Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.), are seeking.

column3: Gang of Eight seeks alternative to John Cornyn amendment
column4: The border security showdown is the first major challenge to the Senate’s bipartisan immigration overhaul since it hit the floor this week, dividing the GOP and testing the ability of the Gang of Eight to negotiate a solution that picks up key Republicans without alienating Democrats.

column3: Gang of Eight seeks alternative to John Cornyn amendment
column4: “It’s a poison pill,” McCain said of the Cornyn plan.

column3: Gang of Eight seeks alternative to John Cornyn amendment
column4: “Hopefully we can have an alternative that satisfies some of the concerns without killing the bill.

column3: Gang of Eight seeks alternative to John Cornyn amendment
column4: … It’s not possible for us to support his amendment as it is presently written because it is a poison pill.” ( PHOTOS: 20 quotes on immigration reform) But with no Gang-sanctioned alternative yet, a number of Republicans — including some viewed as swing votes — are gravitating toward the Cornyn plan.

column3: Gang of Eight seeks alternative to John Cornyn amendment
column4: It would block undocumented immigrants from gaining green cards until the government meets certain border security metrics, which Democrats view as so subjective that they may never be reached.

column3: Gang of Eight seeks alternative to John Cornyn amendment
column4: There is grumbling among some Democrats that they’re in this bind because Rubio — a key Gang member — made border security an issue by saying it needed to be tightened in order to get 60 Senate votes.

column3: Gang of Eight seeks alternative to John Cornyn amendment
column4: Then, the Florida Republican embraced the Cornyn plan when it was announced last week.

column3: Gang of Eight seeks alternative to John Cornyn amendment
column4: And on Sean Hannity’s radio show Wednesday, Rubio described it as “an excellent place to start in terms of having that conversation.” But when pressed by Hannity to say he wouldn’t back reform unless complete control of the border is guaranteed, Rubio hedged.

column3: Gang of Eight seeks alternative to John Cornyn amendment
column4: “The thing I’m trying to avoid is all that ultimatum language because I think it undermines what we’re trying to do,” he said.

column3: Gang of Eight seeks alternative to John Cornyn amendment
column4: “I’m not here to blow anything up.

column3: Gang of Eight seeks alternative to John Cornyn amendment
column4: I want to make this thing better.” ( Also on POLITICO: Reid warns Republicans on border security) Throughout the debate, Rubio has sought to publicly align himself with conservatives and keep his distance from the Gang of Eight, even as he continues to privately work with the group.

column3: Gang of Eight seeks alternative to John Cornyn amendment
column4: The members have tolerated the seemingly-conflicting messages at times from Rubio because his continued involvement is critical to lining up GOP votes – and the Gang still truly believe that Rubio is committed to the bill and won’t agree to changes that gut the delicate compromise.

column3: Gang of Eight seeks alternative to John Cornyn amendment
column4: But the machinations on border security is sharpening the divide, at least publicly, between Rubio and the rest of the group.

column4: Updated 06/12/2013 11:32 PM EDT Controversial surveillance practices that spilled into public view through a series of dramatic leaks last week have helped to avert “dozens of terrorist events” in recent years, National Security Agency Director Keith Alexander told a Senate committee Wednesday.

column3: NSA chief defends dual cyber, intel roles
column4: However, the longer the NSA director spoke before the Senate Appropriations Committee, the less clear it became just which surveillance programs he was crediting for those successes.

column4: Story Continued Below His answer came in response to a question from Sen. Patrick Leahy (D-Vt.) about call-tracking surveillance conducted under Patriot Act Section 215.

column3: NSA chief defends dual cyber, intel roles
column4: ( PHOTOS: Pols, pundits weigh in on NSA report) Alexander said it was difficult to segregate information obtained under that provision from another practice disclosed by leak last week: a system that gathers bulk data from internet providers, e-mail services and social media sites.

column3: NSA chief defends dual cyber, intel roles
column4: That system is aimed at foreigners outside the United States, though it sometimes data from Americans or foreigners on U.S. soil is swept in as well.

column3: NSA chief defends dual cyber, intel roles
column4: “These authorities complement each other.

column3: NSA chief defends dual cyber, intel roles
column4: The reality is, they work together,” said Alexander.

column3: NSA chief defends dual cyber, intel roles
column4: It was also not clear whether Alexander was attributing the prevention of dozens of terrorist events to the phone-call tracking program or to the use of Section 215 more generally.

column3: NSA chief defends dual cyber, intel roles
column4: Beyond the mass collection of phone records revealed last week, that provision can be used to acquire a variety of business records.

column3: NSA chief defends dual cyber, intel roles
column4: “Clearly, this authority is being used for something more than phone records,” Sen. Dick Durbin (D-Ill.) said.

column3: NSA chief defends dual cyber, intel roles
column4: However, Alexander made it clear there are limits to the NSA’s surveillance Sen. Susan Collins (R-Maine) asked whether it was true that the NSA had the ability to tap into Americans’ phone calls and electronic communications.

column3: NSA chief defends dual cyber, intel roles
column4: “False.

column3: NSA chief defends dual cyber, intel roles
column4: I know of no way to do that,” Alexander responded.

column3: NSA chief defends dual cyber, intel roles
column4: The NSA chief, who is also a four-star Army general who oversees the U.S. Cyber Command, said he is pressing to declassify information on how often the information has been useful.

column3: NSA chief defends dual cyber, intel roles
column4: “I’m pushing for that,” he said.

column3: NSA chief defends dual cyber, intel roles
column4: “We do want to get this right and it has to be vetted across the community so what we give you, you know, is accurate.” Leahy complained that the intelligence community has been dismissive of past congressional efforts to rein in the practices.

column3: NSA chief defends dual cyber, intel roles
column4: The “intelligence community has told us we obviously don’t have the ability as simple senators to know things as well as you do,” Leahy said, paraphrasing what he’s been told about NSA’s programs as: “Congress shouldn’t tinker with it at all.

column3: NSA chief defends dual cyber, intel roles
column4: We should simply trust you.” The Senate hearing was called to address efforts to protect Americans from cyber attacks, but it took less than an hour for senators to turn their focus to the question of government surveillance.

column3: NSA chief defends dual cyber, intel roles
column4: At the outset of the session, Senate Appropriations Committee Chairwoman Barbara Mikulski (D-Md.)

column3: NSA chief defends dual cyber, intel roles
column4: encouraged her colleagues to put off questions about the hot surveillance issues to other hearings to take place in the future.

column3: NSA chief defends dual cyber, intel roles
column4: Multiple times she interrupted their questions of Alexander about domestic surveillance to plead with them to put off questions on the phone records programs.

column3: NSA chief defends dual cyber, intel roles
column4: “In the last several days, many intelligence issues have been in the press…I understand that these are issues that are very much on the public’s mind and members of the Senate,” Mikulski said.

column3: NSA chief defends dual cyber, intel roles
column4: “That’s not today.

column3: NSA chief defends dual cyber, intel roles
column4: That’s for another day.” However, Mikulski was clearly sensitive to suggestions she was trying to steer the hearing away from the surveillance issues that have dominated the news in recent days.

column3: NSA chief defends dual cyber, intel roles
column4: She publicly took exception to a BuzzFeed reporter’s tweet saying Mikulski was “trying hard” to keep other senators from delving into the data mining issue ”There is no attempt here to muzzle — stifle any senator from asking any line of question,” Mikulski insisted.

column3: NSA chief defends dual cyber, intel roles
column4: While he wasn’t immediately asked about the revelations of phone-call tracking and Web surveillance aimed at foreigners, Alexander used part of his opening statement to defend his workforce as respectful of privacy.

column3: Report Outlines Accusations of Misconduct by Diplomats
column4: WASHINGTON — A former ambassador who oversaw an audit of the State Department’s Bureau of Diplomatic Security has outlined several cases of alleged misconduct by American diplomats and security agents as part of an inquiry into whether senior officials interfered with politically delicate investigations.

column3: Report Outlines Accusations of Misconduct by Diplomats
column4: The misconduct — which the State Department said had been investigated — included the solicitation of sex from prostitutes, possibly minors; the existence of an “underground drug ring” that supplied drugs to security officers in Baghdad; and an agent’s falsely claiming full pay while working fewer hours, according to a report by Larry M. Dinger, the former ambassador who oversaw the audit for the State Department’s inspector general.

column3: Report Outlines Accusations of Misconduct by Diplomats
column4: The report did not substantiate any of the accusations, and in some instances made clear that they were based on rumor or hearsay.

column3: Report Outlines Accusations of Misconduct by Diplomats
column4: “Sometimes the sources are one or more other agents who became aware of the case from colleagues in what, given cubicles, can be a collegial environment,” wrote Mr. Dinger, who until August 2011 served as chargé d’affaires in Myanmar, formerly known as Burma.

column3: Report Outlines Accusations of Misconduct by Diplomats
column4: The accusations nonetheless raised a flurry of questions about the management of the State Department under Hillary Rodham Clinton, who stepped down in February as secretary of state but who remains the focus of intense speculation over her political plans in 2016.

column3: Report Outlines Accusations of Misconduct by Diplomats
column4: Other cases involved members of Mrs. Clinton’s security detail who were accused of hiring prostitutes on trips to Russia and Colombia “despite obvious counterintelligence issues.” The allegations of misconduct were first reported by CBS News on Monday and amplified by The New York Post on Tuesday, and they provoked a second day of questioning at the State Department and the White House.

column3: Report Outlines Accusations of Misconduct by Diplomats
column4: “There’s a process in place for reviewing any sort of allegation of misconduct the likes of which you mentioned,” the White House press secretary, Jay Carney, said at a briefing Tuesday, adding, “We’re not going to prejudge anyone or anything before all the facts are determined.” The report cited allegations of sexual assaults by a security supervisor at the American Embassy in Beirut, Lebanon.

column3: Report Outlines Accusations of Misconduct by Diplomats
column4: In another case, an investigator for the Bureau of Diplomatic Security reported that he had determined that an ambassador in Europe had “routinely ditched his protective security detail” to solicit sex.

column3: Report Outlines Accusations of Misconduct by Diplomats
column4: In both cases, diplomatic security agents suggested that their investigations had been circumscribed or blocked by superiors.

column3: Report Outlines Accusations of Misconduct by Diplomats
column4: The State Department’s spokeswoman, Jen Psaki, said all accusations had been investigated but declined to discuss individual cases or whether those accused had been exonerated.

column3: Report Outlines Accusations of Misconduct by Diplomats
column4: The report became public as a result of a civil suit filed in 2011 by Richard P. Higbie, a diplomatic security agent who accused the State Department of blocking his career.

column3: Report Outlines Accusations of Misconduct by Diplomats
column4: His lawyers sought the department’s internal documents after Aurelia Fedenisn, a former investigator who worked on the inspector general’s report, complained that the final draft had been toned down.

column3: Report Outlines Accusations of Misconduct by Diplomats
column4: Damon Mathias, a lawyer for Mr. Higbie and Ms. Fedenisn, said Ms. Fedenisn became concerned that the report had underplayed the interference into investigations.

column3: State Department accused of covering up sex and prostitution investigation
column4: WASHINGTON –  The U.S. State Department’s ability to investigate wrongdoing by its staff is under question after a report that the agency tried to cover up several crimes committed has surfaced.

column3: State Department accused of covering up sex and prostitution investigation
column4: Some of the allegations are against then-Secretary of State Hillary Clinton’s security detail who allegedly hired prostitutes, a U.S. ambassador accused of trolling public parks for paid sex and a security official in Beirut committing sexual assaults on foreign nationals.

column3: State Department accused of covering up sex and prostitution investigation
column4: An internal memo from the State Department’s inspector general listed eight examples of wrongdoing by agency staff or contractors.

column3: State Department accused of covering up sex and prostitution investigation
column4: The memo also seems to indicate that the government agency tried to use its authority to stop the investigation and instead, opting to have the official, whose name has not been released, meet with Undersecretary of State for Management Patrick Kennedy in Washington.

column3: State Department accused of covering up sex and prostitution investigation
column4: The official was then allowed to return to his job overseas.

column3: State Department accused of covering up sex and prostitution investigation
column4: State Department spokeswoman Jen Psaki told reporters during Monday’s daily briefing that the department’s Bureau of Diplomatic Security has requested a “review by outside, experienced law enforcement officers” who are working with the IG’s office to make “expert assessments about our current procedures.” Rep. Ed Royce, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, called the allegations of misconduct appalling and said he would ask congressional staff members to start an investigation into all of the accusations.

column3: State Department accused of covering up sex and prostitution investigation
column4: However, Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid stonewalled reporters Tuesday when asked about the alleged misconduct and possible cover up.

column3: State Department accused of covering up sex and prostitution investigation
column4: "I don't know what you're talking about," the Nevada Democrat said.

column3: State Department accused of covering up sex and prostitution investigation
column4: "What are you talking about?

column3: State Department accused of covering up sex and prostitution investigation
State Department accused of covering up sex and prostitution investigation
column4: I don't know what you're talking about."

column3: State Department accused of covering up sex and prostitution investigation
column4: According to the memo first obtained by CBS News, four members of Clinton’s security detail received one-day suspensions.

column3: State Department accused of covering up sex and prostitution investigation
column4: Allegations of misconduct are not new and have plagued the Obama administration for awhile.

column3: State Department accused of covering up sex and prostitution investigation
column4: In April 2012, members of the president’s Secret Service detail were caught in a prostitution scandal involving 12 women they picked up during an official trip to Colombia.

column3: State Department accused of covering up sex and prostitution investigation
column4: The Secret Service was slow to disclose any information and issued only limited public statements in the weeks following the incident in Cartagena.

column3: State Department accused of covering up sex and prostitution investigation
column4: In the end, a dozen agents, officers, supervisors and 12 other U.S. military personnel were implicated in a night of heavy drinking and misconduct.

column3: State Department accused of covering up sex and prostitution investigation
column4: The Secret Service forced eight employees from their jobs.

column3: State Department accused of covering up sex and prostitution investigation
column4: The military canceled the security clearances of all 12 enlisted personnel.

column3: State Department accused of covering up sex and prostitution investigation
column4: Fox News' James Rosen contributed to this report.

column3: McConnell: Immigration bill has ?serious flaws?
column4: Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell said Tuesday that the immigration bill making its way to the chamber floor later in the day has “serious flaws” that must be fixed before the legislation can pass.

column3: McConnell: Immigration bill has ?serious flaws?
column4: Mr. McConnell said he won’t launch a filibuster of the bill in a key test vote scheduled for Tuesday afternoon, but said the bill is still in danger unless its border security provisions can be stiffened and the bill is amended to deny illegal immigrants access to taxpayer-funded benefits like tax credits.

column3: McConnell: Immigration bill has ?serious flaws?
column4: “I’m going to need more than an assurance from [Homeland Security Secretary Janet] Napolitano, for instance, that the border is secure to feel comfortable about the situation on the border,” the Kentucky Republican said.

column3: McConnell: Immigration bill has ?serious flaws?
column4: He said the key to fixing the bill will be to have an open amendment process.

column3: McConnell: Immigration bill has ?serious flaws?
column4: And indeed, the jockeying over amendments has already begun.

column3: McConnell: Immigration bill has ?serious flaws?
column4: SEE ALSO: Obama throws weight behind immigration overhaul bill Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, Nevada Democrat, has said he will allow amendments but signaled he will keep tight reins on which amendments reach the floor.

column3: McConnell: Immigration bill has ?serious flaws?
column4: His goal is to protect the crux of the immigration deal, which offers illegal immigrants quick legalization but withholds the full path to citizenship until after more money is spent on border security, the government creates a new verification system to check workers, and immigration authorities begin to track entries and exits at airports and seaports.

column3: McConnell: Immigration bill has ?serious flaws?
column4: Mr. Reid told Univision, a Spanish-language television network, that he will allow some small changes but nothing “major.” SEE ALSO: Union launches ad blitz to sway GOP on immigration He has a tricky task ahead of him.

column3: McConnell: Immigration bill has ?serious flaws?
column4: In 2007 — the last time the Senate debated a bill — Mr. Reid’s heavy hand in controlling amendments threatened to derail the bill, and he had to relent.

column3: McConnell: Immigration bill has ?serious flaws?
column4: When fellow Democrats passed an amendment cutting the number of guest-workers from the bill, it threw a wrench in the core of that year’s deal, and the bill died in a bipartisan filibuster.

column3: McConnell: Immigration bill has ?serious flaws?
column4: Sen. Marco Rubio, the Florida Republican who helped write this year’s bill and is considered the key to selling the measure to conservatives, has said he needs to see changes to border security and the entry-exit system.

column3: McConnell: Immigration bill has ?serious flaws?
column4: On Tuesday he said he’ll introduce an amendment requiring that illegal immigrants seeking green cards prove they’ve learned English — not just enrolled in language classes, as the bill currently allows.

column3: Obama Presses Immigration Bill as Senate Opens Debate
column4: WASHINGTON — As the Senate voted overwhelmingly Tuesday to begin debating an overhaul of the nation’s immigrations laws, President Obama offered a wholehearted endorsement of the bipartisan proposal, which presents him with a chance to reach the kind of landmark accord with Republicans that has eluded him on the budget and gun violence.

column3: Obama Presses Immigration Bill as Senate Opens Debate
column4: For Mr. Obama, who has picked his shots in the immigration debate to avoid stirring partisan anger on Capitol Hill, it was a moment of promise and peril.

column3: Obama Presses Immigration Bill as Senate Opens Debate
column4: While he threw his weight behind the bill, he conceded that it would not satisfy all sides and said he anticipated a bruising fight over issues like border security and the path to citizenship.

column3: Obama Presses Immigration Bill as Senate Opens Debate
column4: The president, however, may have more leverage than in previous battles, not least because many Republicans believe rewriting the immigration laws is critical for the long-term viability of their party given the nation’s demographic shifts, even if doing so risks alienating parts of their base.

column3: Obama Presses Immigration Bill as Senate Opens Debate
column4: Republican willingness to weigh significant changes in immigration policy was evident in the 84-to-15 vote to begin what is expected to be a monthlong debate on the bill, a lopsided majority that comprised 52 Democrats, 2 independents and 30 Republicans.

column3: Obama Presses Immigration Bill as Senate Opens Debate
column4: The opponents were all Republicans.

column3: Obama Presses Immigration Bill as Senate Opens Debate
column4: Advocates hailed the vote as an encouraging sign for the measure’s eventual passage.

column3: Obama Presses Immigration Bill as Senate Opens Debate
column4: But Senate veterans warned that the procedural victory did not preclude Republicans from ultimately rejecting the legislation, which would provide a path to citizenship for 11 million people who are in the country illegally.

column3: Obama Presses Immigration Bill as Senate Opens Debate
column4: “This bill isn’t perfect; it’s a compromise,” the president said at a carefully choreographed White House appearance with advocates of reform.

column3: Obama Presses Immigration Bill as Senate Opens Debate
column4: “Going forward, nobody is going to get everything they want.

column3: Obama Presses Immigration Bill as Senate Opens Debate
column4: Not Democrats, not Republicans, not me.” Though the Senate’s Republican leader, Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, often an impediment to Democratic initiatives, voted to allow debate, he said he would vote against the bill unless major changes were made.

column3: Obama Presses Immigration Bill as Senate Opens Debate
column4: “These include, but are not limited to, the areas of border security, government benefits and taxes,” he said.

column3: Obama Presses Immigration Bill as Senate Opens Debate
column4: The House speaker, John A. Boehner, said he feared that the Senate bill “doesn’t go far enough.” Speaking on ABC News before the vote, Mr. Boehner said he had “real concerns with the Senate bill,” especially on border security and internal enforcement.

column3: Obama Presses Immigration Bill as Senate Opens Debate
column4: A vote to allow a debate is no guarantee of a bill’s passage: the Senate cleared that threshold on legislation to tighten the nation’s gun laws, but its key provision, to tighten background checks on gun buyers, still went down to defeat.

column3: Obama Presses Immigration Bill as Senate Opens Debate
column4: At the same time, this procedural vote was larger than one in 2007, when the Senate last debated immigration reform, and Mr. Obama was clearly determined to seize the moment.

column3: Obama Presses Immigration Bill as Senate Opens Debate
column4: “If you’re serious about actually fixing the system, then this is the vehicle to do it,” Mr. Obama declared.

column3: Obama Presses Immigration Bill as Senate Opens Debate
column4: “If you’re not serious about it, if you think that a broken system is the best America can do, then I guess it makes sense to try to block it.” Speaking in the East Room, Mr. Obama surrounded himself with supporters of the bill, including a former police chief in Los Angeles and New York, William J. Bratton; Thomas J. Donahue, the president of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce; Julián Castro, the mayor of San Antonio; Steve Case, an entrepreneur and a founder of AOL; and Richard L. Trumka, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.

column3: Obama Presses Immigration Bill as Senate Opens Debate
column4: While Mr. Obama speaks about the need to overhaul the immigration system at schools and factories across the country, the East Room event was his most concerted push for it since he spoke in Las Vegas in January, around the time a group of Republican and Democratic senators presented a draft framework for legislation.

column3: Obama Presses Immigration Bill as Senate Opens Debate
column4: That speech, analysts said, drew a positive response from some influential Republican lawmakers, and the White House appeared to be trying to replicate the experience.

column3: Obama Presses Immigration Bill as Senate Opens Debate
column4: But they warned not to overestimate Mr. Obama’s role in the debate now.

column3: Obama Presses Immigration Bill as Senate Opens Debate
column4: “It propels it forward, but this has already got a lot of juice,” said Angela Maria Kelley, an expert on immigration at the Center for American Progress.

column3: Obama Presses Immigration Bill as Senate Opens Debate
column4: “In the Senate, there’s a lot of clarity about people’s positions.” Other experts said Mr. Obama had learned from hard experience during the health care and budget debates about the right time to lie low and the right time to insert himself in the process.

column3: Obama Presses Immigration Bill as Senate Opens Debate
column4: “There’s no question that the president has a delicate dance,” said Ben Johnson, the executive director of the American Immigration Council.

column3: Obama Presses Immigration Bill as Senate Opens Debate
column4: “He’s got to strike the right tone and the right balance of using the office effectively and not trampling on the process that’s currently under way.” A senior White House official said Mr. Obama’s involvement was important because the bill’s success would hinge on winning the support of Hispanic voters, and “there is no Republican with the credibility to sell this to that community — only the president can.” On Tuesday, though, senators seemed more immersed in their own debate than in reacting to Mr. Obama.

column3: Obama Presses Immigration Bill as Senate Opens Debate
column4: “Well, he doesn’t vote in the Senate anymore, so right now we’re just focused on getting it passed in the Senate in a responsible way,” said Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida, who was one of the architects of the bill and is one of his party’s most prominent Hispanics.

column3: Obama Presses Immigration Bill as Senate Opens Debate
column4: Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, said the Democrats “promised immigration reform in 2009, they didn’t deliver, so they need to step up to the plate there.” Another member of the so-called Gang of Eight behind the bill, Senator Robert Menendez, Democrat of New Jersey, said Mr. Obama’s remarks echoed the principles in the legislation, but added of Republicans, “Some of them have Obamaphobia, so no matter what he does, they won’t be happy.” Mr. Boehner said he expected that the “House bill will be to the right of where the Senate is,” but he would not say whether he expected any legislation that came out of the House to include a path to citizenship for undocumented immigrants.

column3: Obama Presses Immigration Bill as Senate Opens Debate
column4: Mr. Obama, in an attempt to allay fears about immigration changes, said the bill before the Senate included the tightest border control provisions in American history.

column3: Obama Presses Immigration Bill as Senate Opens Debate
column4: He said twice that illegal crossings were “near their lowest levels in decades.” But the president also insisted on a path to citizenship for immigrants here illegally — a provision that has continued to be a sticking point between the senators who drafted the legislation and conservative Republicans, especially in the House, who believe that approach represents amnesty for those who broke the law to enter or stay in the country.

column3: Obama Presses Immigration Bill as Senate Opens Debate
column4: The process, he said, would be long and arduous, requiring people to pay taxes as well as a penalty, learn English, and then go to the back of the line behind applicants for American citizenship who entered the country lawfully.

column3: Obama Presses Immigration Bill as Senate Opens Debate
column4: The average wait would be 13 years, he said.

column3: Obama Presses Immigration Bill as Senate Opens Debate
column4: “This is no cakewalk,” he said, “but it’s the only way we can make sure that everyone who’s here is playing by the same rules.”

column3: Glenn Beck, Michael Moore call NSA whistleblower Edward Snowden a hero
column4: Conservative radio commentator Glenn Beck and liberal Hollywood movie-maker Michael Moore have found common ground on the National Security Agency whistleblower, Edward Snowden: He’s a hero.

column3: Glenn Beck, Michael Moore call NSA whistleblower Edward Snowden a hero
column4: Both took to Twitter to opine on their favorable impressions of the information leaker, Politico reported.

column3: Glenn Beck, Michael Moore call NSA whistleblower Edward Snowden a hero
column4: Mr. Beck’s tweet: “I think I have just read about the man for which I have waited.

column3: Glenn Beck, Michael Moore call NSA whistleblower Edward Snowden a hero
column4: Earmarks of a real hero.” Mr. Beck also tweeted: “The NSA patriot leader is just another chance for America to regain her moral compass and set things right.

column3: Glenn Beck, Michael Moore call NSA whistleblower Edward Snowden a hero
column4: No red or blue.

column3: Glenn Beck, Michael Moore call NSA whistleblower Edward Snowden a hero
column4: Just truth.” And Mr. Moore‘s: “Hero of the Year #EdwardSnowden NSA tech assistant reveals he is the source of stories on U.S. Gov’t domestic spying.”

column3: Senate Digs In for Long Battle on Overhaul of Immigration
column4: WASHINGTON — After seven months of steadily building momentum, the push for a comprehensive overhaul of the immigration system enters its most crucial phase this week in the Senate, where Republicans remain divided over how much to cooperate with President Obama as they try to repair their party’s standing among Hispanic voters.

column3: Senate Digs In for Long Battle on Overhaul of Immigration
column4: Republican leaders are betting that passage of an 867-page bipartisan overhaul will halt the embarrassing erosion of support among Latinos last year that helped return Mr. Obama to the Oval Office.

column3: Senate Digs In for Long Battle on Overhaul of Immigration
column4: But the party’s conservative activists are vowing opposition, dead set against anything linked to Mr. Obama and convinced that the immigration bill is nothing more than amnesty for lawbreakers.

column3: Senate Digs In for Long Battle on Overhaul of Immigration
column4: That intraparty clash will play out for the next three weeks on the Senate floor, as Republican supporters of the bill — aided behind the scenes by the Obama administration — seek modest changes that they hope will secure broad support among both parties.

column3: Senate Digs In for Long Battle on Overhaul of Immigration
column4: Senator Kelly Ayotte, Republican of New Hampshire, announced on Sunday on CBS’s “Face the Nation” that she would support the immigration bill, calling it a “thoughtful bipartisan solution to a tough problem.” At the same time, conservative Republican senators, led by Jeff Sessions of Alabama and Ted Cruz of Texas, are preparing an onslaught of amendments that threaten to unravel the carefully crafted compromise.

column3: Senate Digs In for Long Battle on Overhaul of Immigration
column4: Their goal is to defeat the bill altogether or, at the least, prevent it from providing a path to citizenship for the estimated 11 million immigrants who are in this country without authorization.

column3: Senate Digs In for Long Battle on Overhaul of Immigration
column4: “It will definitely give amnesty today,” Mr.

column3: Senate Digs In for Long Battle on Overhaul of Immigration
column4: Sessions said on Friday as the chamber prepared for the debate, which is scheduled to begin on Tuesday.

column3: Senate Digs In for Long Battle on Overhaul of Immigration
column4: The final vote in the Senate, which is set to come by the time senators leave for their Fourth of July break, could shape the future of the Republican Party and help determine the political strength of the conservative movement heading into next year’s midterm elections.

column3: Senate Digs In for Long Battle on Overhaul of Immigration
column4: If all 54 Democratic senators vote for the bill, which is unlikely, supporters would need six Republicans to prevent a filibuster and pass the legislation.

column3: Senate Digs In for Long Battle on Overhaul of Immigration
column4: For the president, the passage of a bipartisan immigration bill would be a critical piece of his legacy, made even more important by the Republican defeat in April of the gun-control measures he was pushing.

column3: Senate Digs In for Long Battle on Overhaul of Immigration
column4: A failure to pass the immigration legislation would reignite anger among Mr. Obama’s Latino supporters and raise questions about his ability to move an agenda forward in his final three and a half years in office.

column3: Senate Digs In for Long Battle on Overhaul of Immigration
column4: In his weekly radio address on Saturday, Mr. Obama urged Congress to give him a bill to sign by the end of the summer.

column3: Senate Digs In for Long Battle on Overhaul of Immigration
column4: “We know the opponents of reform are going to do everything they can to prevent that,” he said.

column3: Senate Digs In for Long Battle on Overhaul of Immigration
column4: “They’ll try to stoke fear and create division.

column3: Senate Digs In for Long Battle on Overhaul of Immigration
column4: They’ll try to play politics with an issue that the vast majority of Americans want addressed.

column3: Senate Digs In for Long Battle on Overhaul of Immigration
column4: And if they succeed, we will lose this chance to finally fix an immigration system that is badly broken.” The legislation, which would be the first major immigration overhaul since President Ronald Reagan backed amnesty for illegal immigrants in 1986, was drafted over the last several months by the so-called Gang of Eight, a bipartisan group of senators.

column3: Senate Digs In for Long Battle on Overhaul of Immigration
column4: It is largely in step with the president’s goals of offering a path to citizenship for the millions of illegal immigrants already in the country while tightening border security and expanding legal entry into the country for families and workers.

column3: Senate Digs In for Long Battle on Overhaul of Immigration
column4: But no one expects the bill to pass the Senate without some modifications.

column3: Senate Digs In for Long Battle on Overhaul of Immigration
column4: Mr. Obama’s Republican allies on the issue — in particular SenatorsMarco Rubio of Florida, a member of the bipartisan group, and Tom Coburn of Oklahoma — warned last week that the president could lose their support without stronger efforts to secure the border, as well as other changes.

column3: Senate Digs In for Long Battle on Overhaul of Immigration
column4: “I’m trying to get to where I can say yes,” Mr. Coburn said as senators prepared to clear the way for what could be weeks of debate in the full chamber.

column3: Senate Digs In for Long Battle on Overhaul of Immigration
column4: “But the only way you can say yes and sell it to the American people is to know that the border is secure, and this bill doesn’t do it.” Mr. Obama will try to set the tone for the legislative fight with a speech at the White House on Tuesday.

column3: Senate Digs In for Long Battle on Overhaul of Immigration
column4: But the battle will quickly shift to the Capitol, where the biggest struggle may be over how far to go in securing America’s border with Mexico against illegal crossings.

column3: Senate Digs In for Long Battle on Overhaul of Immigration
column4: White House officials say they expect Democrats will have to make compromises on border security by accepting some amendments that tighten enforcement.

column3: Senate Digs In for Long Battle on Overhaul of Immigration
column4: But they said Democrats would resist any amendments that significantly undermine the core of the bill — a certain path to citizenship for those already in the country.

column3: Senate Digs In for Long Battle on Overhaul of Immigration
column4: “We are willing to toughen up border — many of our colleagues feel that’s important — but without forsaking our principles,” said Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York and a member of the bipartisan group.

column3: Senate Digs In for Long Battle on Overhaul of Immigration
column4: He said border security demands must be reasonable “so that if, God forbid, there’s a president in 2017 who hates immigration reform, it will still go forward.” Mr. Obama has stayed clear of personally directing the legislative process from the West Wing, on the theory that his participation would make it more difficult for Republicans to support it.

column3: Senate Digs In for Long Battle on Overhaul of Immigration
column4: But administration officials are working behind the scenes with allies from both parties in the Senate to provide technical support as they draft friendly amendments to the legislation.

column3: Senate Digs In for Long Battle on Overhaul of Immigration
column4: They are also helping lawmakers develop talking points and prepare side-by-side comparisons to help defeat efforts intended to undermine the bill.

column3: Senate Digs In for Long Battle on Overhaul of Immigration
column4: “The process to date in the Senate and House has been marked by strong bipartisan cooperation,” said Denis McDonough, the president’s chief of staff.

column3: Senate Digs In for Long Battle on Overhaul of Immigration
column4: “Our hope and expectation is that the momentum will carry over onto the Senate floor to produce a bill with broad support.” Yet opposition to an overhaul has become increasingly vocal.

column3: Senate Digs In for Long Battle on Overhaul of Immigration
column4: Members of the bipartisan group spent much of last week scrambling to try to shore up Republican support for the bill.

column3: Senate Digs In for Long Battle on Overhaul of Immigration
column4: Senator Lindsey Graham, a South Carolina Republican and member of the group, quipped that he had spent much of his time “informing, begging, listening.” The stakes for Republicans, Mr. Graham said, are too high not to try to push an overhaul through.

column3: Senate Digs In for Long Battle on Overhaul of Immigration
column4: “If we’re not able to pass immigration reform in 2013 and it’s the Republican Party’s fault, we’re dead in 2016,” he said.

column3: Senate Digs In for Long Battle on Overhaul of Immigration
column4: Advocates say they are pushing for a strong bipartisan vote in the Senate — some have predicted as many as 70 yes votes — to help propel the bill through the House, where it is expected to face a tougher path.

column3: Senate Digs In for Long Battle on Overhaul of Immigration
column4: Senior legislative aides have privately expressed annoyance that Mr. Rubio has offered potential concessions to Republicans like Senator John Cornyn of Texas, whom many Democrats do not view as someone who will ever support the bill.

column3: Senate Digs In for Long Battle on Overhaul of Immigration
column4: Mr. Cornyn has said he plans to offer an amendment that would require the apprehension of at least 90 percent of all people crossing the border illegally, a target that advocates say is unrealistic.

column3: Senate Digs In for Long Battle on Overhaul of Immigration
column4: An aide to Mr. Rubio said the senator was simply trying to improve the bill.

column3: Senate Digs In for Long Battle on Overhaul of Immigration
column4: Mr. Rubio is also working on an amendment that would take the authority to produce and carry out a border security plan away from the Department of Homeland Security and place it with Congress.

column3: Senate Digs In for Long Battle on Overhaul of Immigration
column4: On the Hugh Hewitt radio show on Tuesday, Mr. Rubio said he did not think the bill in its current form had the necessary 60 votes to get through the Senate, and warned that without significant border security improvements, “I think we’ve got a bill that isn’t going to become law.”

column3: Obama Calls Surveillance Programs Legal and Limited
column4: WASHINGTON — President Obama offered a robust defense of newly revealed surveillance programs on Friday as more classified secrets spilled into public, complicating a summit meeting with China’s new president focused partly on human rights and cybersecurity.

column3: Obama Calls Surveillance Programs Legal and Limited
column4: Mr. Obama departed from his script at a health care event in California to try to reassure Americans that he had not abused government authority by collecting telephone call logs and foreigners’ e-mail messages.

column3: Obama Calls Surveillance Programs Legal and Limited
column4: But the disclosure hours later of secret contingency planning to target other countries for possible cyberattacks made his get-together with President Xi Jinping later in the day all the more awkward because cyberattacks by the Chinese are high on the American agenda.

column3: Obama Calls Surveillance Programs Legal and Limited
column4: The latest of three documents published over three days by the British newspaper The Guardian added to the understanding of the Obama administration’s approach to national security in an age of multifaceted threats and became another factor in the renewed debate over the balance between privacy and security.

column3: Obama Calls Surveillance Programs Legal and Limited
column4: The identity of the person who gave those documents to The Guardian and The Washington Post is not known, but The Post has described its source as a career intelligence officer angry at “what he believes to be a gross intrusion on privacy” by the Obama administration.

column3: Obama Calls Surveillance Programs Legal and Limited
column4: Once a critic of President George W. Bush’s hawkish policies, Mr. Obama was ready with an explanation for why he has preserved and extended some of them when a reporter asked him at the health care event if he could assure Americans that the government was not building a database of their personal information.

column3: Obama Calls Surveillance Programs Legal and Limited
column4: “Nobody is listening to your telephone calls,” Mr. Obama said.

column3: Obama Calls Surveillance Programs Legal and Limited
column4: “That’s not what this program’s about.” But he argued that “modest encroachments on privacy” were “worth us doing” to protect the country, and he said that Congress and the courts had authorized those programs.

column3: Obama Calls Surveillance Programs Legal and Limited
column4: A National Security Agency telephone surveillance program collects phone numbers and the duration of calls, not the content, he said.

column3: Obama Calls Surveillance Programs Legal and Limited
column4: An Internet surveillance program targets foreigners living abroad, not Americans, he added.

column3: Obama Calls Surveillance Programs Legal and Limited
column4: “There are some trade-offs involved,” Mr. Obama said.

column3: Obama Calls Surveillance Programs Legal and Limited
column4: “I came with a healthy skepticism about these programs.

column3: Obama Calls Surveillance Programs Legal and Limited
column4: My team evaluated them.

column3: Obama Calls Surveillance Programs Legal and Limited
column4: We scrubbed them thoroughly.” In the end, he concluded that “they help us prevent terrorist attacks.” But the disclosures united liberal Democrats and libertarian Republicans in accusing him of abandoning values he once espoused.

column3: Obama Calls Surveillance Programs Legal and Limited
column4: “We believe the large-scale collection of this information by the government has a very significant impact on Americans’ privacy, whether senior government officials recognize that fact or not,” Senators Ron Wyden of Oregon and Mark Udall of Colorado, both Democrats, wrote in a joint response to the president’s remarks.

column3: Obama Calls Surveillance Programs Legal and Limited
column4: Senator Richard J. Durbin, the Senate’s No.

column3: Obama Calls Surveillance Programs Legal and Limited
column4: 2 Democrat and an Obama ally from Illinois, rebuffed the president’s contention that Congress had been kept abreast of the programs, saying only a handful of top leaders are regularly briefed.

column3: Obama Calls Surveillance Programs Legal and Limited
column4: “To say that there’s Congressional approval suggests a level of information and oversight that’s just not there,” he said in an interview.

column3: Obama Calls Surveillance Programs Legal and Limited
column4: He added that the sort of data mining revealed in recent days “really pushes the role of government to the limit.” Advocates of Congressional intervention said public pressure could revive legislation to at least force more transparency about the programs.

column3: Obama Calls Surveillance Programs Legal and Limited
column4: “The timing has never been better to revisit our past decisions,” said Senator Mike Lee, a Utah Republican.

column3: Obama Calls Surveillance Programs Legal and Limited
column4: But it was not clear whether there would be a popular backlash to the programs beyond some outrage on Twitter and Facebook, and even critics like Mr. Durbin were skeptical.

column3: Obama Calls Surveillance Programs Legal and Limited
column4: Many Americans interviewed around the country on Friday shared concerns about their civil liberties but expressed a certain grudging resignation as well.

column3: Obama Calls Surveillance Programs Legal and Limited
column4: In Congress, the main vehicle for any changes, a reauthorization of the 1978 law that created the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court, passed only last December and is not due for renewal for five years.

column3: Obama Calls Surveillance Programs Legal and Limited
column4: During the debate last winter, the Senate voted on a bipartisan basis to reject amendments to force transparency or curtail surveillance.

column3: Obama Calls Surveillance Programs Legal and Limited
column4: Moreover, beyond Mr. Durbin, Congressional leaders and senior lawmakers on the intelligence committees expressed few qualms.

column3: Obama Calls Surveillance Programs Legal and Limited
column4: The House speaker, John A. Boehner, Republican of Ohio, said Mr. Obama must be more forceful in explaining the programs but declined to discuss his own position.

column3: Obama Calls Surveillance Programs Legal and Limited
column4: Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the Democratic majority leader, dismissed concerns.

column3: Obama Calls Surveillance Programs Legal and Limited
column4: “Everyone should just calm down and understand this isn’t anything that is brand new,” he said.

column3: Obama Calls Surveillance Programs Legal and Limited
column4: Just hours after the president spoke, The Guardian posted online a copy of a classified directive Mr. Obama signed last year laying out conditions under which the president could order cyberattacks against another country, akin to the attacks on Iran’s uranium enrichment plant.

column3: Obama Calls Surveillance Programs Legal and Limited
column4: The directive ordered the government to “identify potential targets of national importance” against which offensive cyberoperations “can offer a favorable balance of effectiveness and risk as compared with other instruments of national power.” That means, in essence, that the Pentagon’s Cyber Command and the intelligence agencies would maintain lists of targets around the world that could be damaged more effectively, and more covertly, by a computer attack than by a missile or bomber attack.

column3: Obama Calls Surveillance Programs Legal and Limited
column4: As previously reported, the document says only the president can authorize offensive cyberoperations, just as only he can authorize the use of nuclear weapons.

column3: Obama Calls Surveillance Programs Legal and Limited
column4: The directive also reserves the right to take “anticipatory action against imminent threats” to protect critical infrastructure in the United States, including power utilities, cellphone networks and financial markets.

column3: Obama Calls Surveillance Programs Legal and Limited
column4: That raised the possibility that the United States could strike first if it feared a large attack from China or another country.

column3: Obama Calls Surveillance Programs Legal and Limited
column4: Officials have blamed China for a variety of computer spying and cyberattacks, a subject featured on Mr. Obama’s agenda with Mr. Xi in Southern California.

column3: Obama Calls Surveillance Programs Legal and Limited
column4: Josh Earnest, a White House spokesman, said the revelations would not hinder the president’s discussions with Mr. Xi.

column3: Obama: Massive seizures 'modest encroachments'
column4: President Obama Friday defended his administration’s massive seizure of private citizens’ phone records, email and Internet activities as “modest encroachments on privacy” that are necessary to fight the war on terrorism.

column3: Obama: Massive seizures 'modest encroachments'
column4: “Nobody is listening to your telephone calls,” Mr. Obama said at a hastily arranged news conference in San Jose, Calif. “They’re not looking at peoples’ names and they’re not looking at content.

column3: Obama: Massive seizures 'modest encroachments'
column4: We have established a process and a procedure that the American people should feel comfortable about.” The president sought to quell a growing furor that erupted Wednesday night with the news that the National Security Agency, at the request of the FBI, was routinely collecting the phone records of millions of Verizon customers in the U.S. Late Thursday, the government also acknowledged that the NSA is gathering Internet users’ personal data, such as email, photos and online chats in real time, from the computer servers of at least nine large Web service providers under a top secret program called “Prism.” SEE ALSO: ‘Prism’ a vital program used to collect personal Web data, Clapper insists The revelations have created a storm of protest among privacy advocates and in Congress, where many lawmakers said they were unaware of the scope of the programs.

column3: Obama: Massive seizures 'modest encroachments'
column4: Mr. Obama said Friday that lawmakers are “fully briefed” on the programs periodically.

column3: Obama: Massive seizures 'modest encroachments'
column4: “Every member of Congress has been briefed on this program,” Mr. Obama said.

column3: Obama: Massive seizures 'modest encroachments'
column4: “These are programs that have been authorized by broad bipartisan majorities repeatedly since 2006.

column3: Obama: Massive seizures 'modest encroachments'
column4: Your duly elected representatives have been consistently informed on what exactly we’re doing.” With regard to the surveillance of Web data and emails, Mr. Obama insisted, “This does not apply to U.S. citizens, and it does not apply to people living in the United States.” SEE ALSO: Whistleblower’s NSA warning: ‘Just the tip of the iceberg’ While Mr. Obama sought to reassure the public that government agents aren’t targeting individuals without probable cause, he also raised the possibility that he himself might be on such a “list” someday after he leaves office.

column3: Obama: Massive seizures 'modest encroachments'
column4: “I will leave this office at some point, sometime in the next three and a half years,” Mr. Obama said.

column3: Obama: Massive seizures 'modest encroachments'
column4: “After that I will be a private citizen.

column3: Obama: Massive seizures 'modest encroachments'
column4: And I suspect that, on a list of people who might be targeted so that somebody could read their emails, or listen to their phone calls, I’d probably be pretty high on that list.

column3: Obama: Massive seizures 'modest encroachments'
column4: So it’s not as though I don’t have a personal interest in making sure my privacy is protected.” Mr. Obama said he must balance national security interests with the protections of individual freedom guaranteed in the Constitution.

column3: Obama: Massive seizures 'modest encroachments'
column4: “I came in with a healthy skepticism about these programs,” he said.

column3: Obama: Massive seizures 'modest encroachments'
column4: “My team evaluated them.

column3: Obama: Massive seizures 'modest encroachments'
column4: My assessment, and my team’s assessment, was that they help us prevent terrorist attacks.” The president said there is a system of checks and balances in place among federal judges and Congress and the executive branch to make sure the surveillance programs are not abused.

column3: Obama: Massive seizures 'modest encroachments'
column4: “We’ve got congressional oversight and judicial oversight,” he said.

column3: Obama: Massive seizures 'modest encroachments'
column4: “If people can’t trust not only the executive branch but also don’t trust Congress and don’t trust federal judges to make sure that we’re abiding by the Constitution and due process and rule of law, then we’re going to have some problems here.” He said the government employees involved in America’s national security “take this work very seriously.” “They cherish our Constitution,” Mr. Obama said.

column3: Obama: Massive seizures 'modest encroachments'
column4: “They operate like professionals.

column3: Obama: Massive seizures 'modest encroachments'
column4: The last thing they’d be doing is taking programs like this to listen to somebody’s phone calls.”

column3: Massive Government Surveillance Program Exposed, All Americans Affected

column3: Massive Government Surveillance Program Exposed, All Americans Affected

Bush after the al-Qaeda attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

column3: U.S. job market stumbles in May, adding just 138,000 jobs
column4: U.S. job growth came in below expectations in May, with employers adding just 138,000 jobs while the unemployment rate fell to 4.3 percent, the lowest it has been in more than 16 years, federal economists reported Friday morning.

column3: U.S. job market stumbles in May, adding just 138,000 jobs
column4: Economists surveyed by Bloomberg had expected an increase of 180,000 in non-farm payrolls, which would have been in line with average monthly gains seen over the past year.

column3: U.S. job market stumbles in May, adding just 138,000 jobs
column4: The job market has been strong in recent months, and most traders expect the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates later this month, despite the slightly weaker May figure.

column3: U.S. job market stumbles in May, adding just 138,000 jobs
column4: Yet further negative news could cause the Fed to reconsider its plan of gradually raising interest rates later this year, as the central bank eases off its efforts to stimulate the economy.

column3: U.S. job market stumbles in May, adding just 138,000 jobs
column4: “The overall report still leaves the Fed on target for June, but it underscores their trepidation about moving in December,” said Diane Swonk, a Chicago-based economist.

column3: U.S. job market stumbles in May, adding just 138,000 jobs
column4: “They’ve got good reason to be cautious.” The unemployment rate was down slightly from 4.4 percent last month, a figure economists had already seen as low.

column3: U.S. job market stumbles in May, adding just 138,000 jobs
column4: Yet economists said the drop was due in part to a contraction in the labor force, since the unemployment rate measures only those who are actively looking for work but can't find it.

column3: U.S. job market stumbles in May, adding just 138,000 jobs
column4: The labor force participation rate declined by 0.2 percentage points to 62.7 percent in May.

column3: U.S. job market stumbles in May, adding just 138,000 jobs

column3: U.S. job market stumbles in May, adding just 138,000 jobs
column4: “The slight drop in the unemployment rate is due to would-be workers leaving the labor force and not getting jobs.” To some economists, these trends suggest that the economy is already well on its way to providing some kind of a job for nearly all Americans who are willing and able to work.

column3: U.S. job market stumbles in May, adding just 138,000 jobs
column4: “The May number makes it look more likely that we have hit a plateau with people coming back off the sidelines,” said Jed Kolko, chief economist for jobs site Indeed.

column3: U.S. job market stumbles in May, adding just 138,000 jobs
column4: The employment gains were led by the service sector, including health care, which has seen business expand as America's aging population demands more medical services.

column3: U.S. job market stumbles in May, adding just 138,000 jobs
column4: The mining sector, which has been a focus of President Trump's, also added 7,000 jobs, continuing a rebound since a low point in October 2016.

column3: U.S. job market stumbles in May, adding just 138,000 jobs
column4: Yet the manufacturing sector shed jobs — a reminder, said Kolko, that most of America's growth is now coming from services.

column3: U.S. job market stumbles in May, adding just 138,000 jobs
