column3: U.S. job market stumbles in May, adding just 138,000 jobs
column4: “These continued improvements have real impact on the lives of American families, as more people take home a paycheck.” The Labor Department also revised its estimates for job gains in March and April, lowering the combined figure by 66,000 jobs.

column3: U.S. job market stumbles in May, adding just 138,000 jobs
column4: Average hourly earnings were up by 2.5 percent from the previous year to $26.22, continuing a streak of relatively weak wage growth.

column3: U.S. job market stumbles in May, adding just 138,000 jobs
column4: As the economy continues to expand and reaches a point where nearly everybody who wants a job can find one — what economists call full employment — companies should have to start raising wages to attract new workers.

column3: U.S. job market stumbles in May, adding just 138,000 jobs
column4: But although the U.S. economy has been adding jobs at a furious pace, workers still aren’t seeing very rapid wage growth.

column3: U.S. job market stumbles in May, adding just 138,000 jobs
column4: Economists are divided about what exactly is causing this, said Mark Zandi, chief economist at Moody’s Analytics.

column3: U.S. job market stumbles in May, adding just 138,000 jobs
column4: Some believe the United States is not yet at full employment, because we are still not seeing a significant pickup in wage growth.

column3: U.S. job market stumbles in May, adding just 138,000 jobs

column3: U.S. job market stumbles in May, adding just 138,000 jobs
column4: Low productivity growth and the relatively low skill level of many American workers who are getting pulled into the labor market are likely holding back a more rapid increase in wages, Swonk said.

column4: She also pointed to the replacement of more highly paid retiring baby boomers with more lowly paid millennials.

column4: Most traders believe the Fed is highly likely to hike interest rates at its upcoming meeting on June 13-14.

column3: U.S. job market stumbles in May, adding just 138,000 jobs
column4: As of Friday morning, traders saw a 93.5 percent chance of a rate hike.

column3: U.S. job market stumbles in May, adding just 138,000 jobs
column4: Minutes from the Fed’s May 2-3 meeting that were released last week showed that some central bankers were concerned that progress toward the Fed’s inflation target had slowed.

column3: U.S. job market stumbles in May, adding just 138,000 jobs
column4: Yet most still judged that the Fed should hike rates “soon” if economic data came roughly in line with their expectations.

column3: Unemployment at 16-Year Low in May Jobs Report
column4: Employers scaled back on hiring in May adding 138,000 jobs, below forecasts for a job gains of 185,000, yet this was enough to push the unemployment rate lower.

column3: Unemployment at 16-Year Low in May Jobs Report
column4: According to the Labor Department, the unemployment rate fell to 4.3 percent from 4.4 percent, which is the lowest it has been since 2001.

column3: Unemployment at 16-Year Low in May Jobs Report

column3: Unemployment at 16-Year Low in May Jobs Report
column4: Job gains in March were revised down to 50,000 from 79,000 while April’s figures were also lowered to 174,000 from 211,000.

column3: Unemployment at 16-Year Low in May Jobs Report
column4: Despite the headline miss in May, job creation last month was above the three-month average of 121,000 jobs.

column3: Unemployment at 16-Year Low in May Jobs Report
column4: “Today’s jobs report reflects that the labor market is tightening, and there’s not as much room for slack as the economy reaches full employment….it’s tough to continue to add 200,000 jobs each month with our unemployment rate below 5%,” said Steve Rick, chief economist at CUNA Mutual Group, reports Fox Business.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Choices Reflect Change in Foreign Tone
column4: WASHINGTON — President Obama named Susan E. Rice and Samantha Power to major national security posts on Wednesday, promoting two outspoken voices for humanitarian intervention on a foreign policy team known for its deep caution in dealing with conflicts abroad.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Choices Reflect Change in Foreign Tone
column4: The president they serve has steadfastly resisted intervening in the most dire human-rights calamity he has faced since taking office: the civil war in Syria.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Choices Reflect Change in Foreign Tone
column4: Given Mr. Obama’s well-known skepticism about the dangers of more direct involvement, it is not clear whether Ms. Rice and Ms. Power can — or even want to — change his mind about more aggressive action.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Choices Reflect Change in Foreign Tone
column4: But there is little doubt that along with two other recent additions to his national security team, Secretary of State John Kerry and Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel, they will bring a different tone to foreign policy in Mr. Obama’s second term.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Choices Reflect Change in Foreign Tone
column4: At the same time, the resignation of Tom Donilon as national security adviser, which precipitated Wednesday’s announcement, could create complications for a White House that takes pride in a smooth-running operation that Mr. Donilon has overseen for more than two and a half years.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Choices Reflect Change in Foreign Tone
column4: Ms. Rice, who is taking Mr. Donilon’s job, and Ms. Power, who is replacing Ms. Rice as ambassador to the United Nations, joined forces in 2011, along with Hillary Rodham Clinton, then the secretary of state, to persuade Mr. Obama to back a NATO-led intervention in Libya.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Choices Reflect Change in Foreign Tone
column4: Yet neither Ms. Rice, 48, nor Ms. Power, 42, has spoken out in favor of a more aggressive response in Syria, attesting to both the insoluble nature of the conflict and the discipline of the White House.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Choices Reflect Change in Foreign Tone
column4: In introducing Ms. Rice, who like Ms. Power worked on his 2008 campaign, Mr. Obama praised her mix of idealism and pragmatism.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Choices Reflect Change in Foreign Tone
column4: “Everybody understands Susan is a fierce champion for justice and human dignity,” he said in a Rose Garden ceremony.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Choices Reflect Change in Foreign Tone
column4: “But she’s also mindful that we have to exercise our power wisely and deliberately.” How Ms. Rice wields her enhanced power could have implications for what has been a generally harmonious national security team.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Choices Reflect Change in Foreign Tone
column4: Given her foreign policy background, strong views and personal ties to Mr. Obama, some believe her appointment will further consolidate foreign policy decision-making in the White House.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Choices Reflect Change in Foreign Tone
column4: In an interview, Ms. Rice said she viewed her role as bringing “as much rigor to our problem-solving as possible.” “My style is to be collegial,” she added.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Choices Reflect Change in Foreign Tone

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Choices Reflect Change in Foreign Tone
column4: White House officials played down suggestions that Mr. Kerry was at risk of being marginalized, noting that he had carved out a prominent role in dealing with the Syrian conflict as well as in trying to revive peace talks between the Israelis and the Palestinians.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Choices Reflect Change in Foreign Tone
column4: “John Kerry is going to be a very aggressive diplomat,” said Benjamin J. Rhodes, a deputy national security adviser.

column4: “We support him diving headfirst into some very tough issues.” Mr. Rhodes said that although Ms. Rice and Ms. Power adhered to the tenets of liberal interventionism, which holds that the United States has an obligation to defend human rights aggressively, neither reflexively advocated the use of military force.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Choices Reflect Change in Foreign Tone
column4: During the administration’s debate last summer about whether to supply the Syrian rebels with weapons — a proposal pushed by the director of the Central Intelligence Agency at the time, David H. Petraeus, and favored by Mrs. Clinton — Ms. Rice sided with officials who opposed it.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Choices Reflect Change in Foreign Tone
column4: Mr. Obama shelved the idea.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Choices Reflect Change in Foreign Tone
column4: Over time, friends of Ms. Rice said, she has become more open to providing lethal aid because it could change the momentum in what has become a stalemate.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Choices Reflect Change in Foreign Tone
column4: But she is said to be wary of any halfway strategy, which she believes would do more harm than good.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Choices Reflect Change in Foreign Tone
column4: Ms. Power, an Irish-born academic who worked on human-rights issues on the National Security Council during Mr. Obama’s first term, favors a more aggressive response in Syria than most people in the administration do, according to people who know her.

column4: “I have seen U.N. aid workers enduring shellfire to deliver food to the people of Sudan,” she said Wednesday, “yet I’ve also seen U.N. peacekeepers fail to protect the people of Bosnia.” Ms. Power and Ms. Rice, who are friends, each bring their own anguished histories to these questions.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Choices Reflect Change in Foreign Tone

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Choices Reflect Change in Foreign Tone

column4: Years later, she told Ms. Power, who was then a journalist writing about the episode, that “I swore to myself that if I ever faced such a crisis again, I would come down on the side of dramatic action, going down in flames if that was required.” However fervent these new officials are, some former officials say they may not make a big difference.

column4: The timing of the announcement of Mr. Donilon’s departure raised questions, coming just two days before a meeting between Mr. Obama and China’s president, Xi Jinping, in Southern California that Mr. Donilon largely organized.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Choices Reflect Change in Foreign Tone
column4: But Mr. Donilon insisted that he had planned to leave at the end of Mr. Obama’s first term, and that he stayed on at the president’s request to break in the new team.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Choices Reflect Change in Foreign Tone
column4: Colleagues of Mr. Donilon said his most lasting policy legacy would be the administration’s shift in priorities from the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq to the fast-growing economies of Asia.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Choices Reflect Change in Foreign Tone

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Choices Reflect Change in Foreign Tone
column4: While Asia has not been a focus for either Ms. Rice or Mr. Kerry, Mr. Rhodes said that was not necessary because the policy had been set.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Choices Reflect Change in Foreign Tone

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Choices Reflect Change in Foreign Tone
column4: “That allows some leeway for her to bring her experience as a strategist and foreign policy thinker to bear,” Mr. Rhodes said.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Choices Reflect Change in Foreign Tone
column4: Mr. Obama appeared genuinely pleased to introduce his new team.

column4: He referred jokingly to Ms. Rice’s reputation for being assertive, noting that he plays basketball with Ms. Rice’s brother, John, and “it runs in the family, throwing the occasional elbow.” Pausing for a moment, he added, “but hitting the big shot.”

column3: Obama administration defends Verizon records order
column4: Updated 06/07/2013 09:52 AM EDT President Barack Obama is looking forward to national debate over surveillance policies triggered by the disclosure Wednesday of a highly classified National Security Agency program to obtain records of telephone calls made by million of Americans, the White House said Thursday.

column3: Obama administration defends Verizon records order
column4: White House Spokesman Josh Earnest told reporters traveling with Obama on Air Force One that the discussion about balancing national security and individual privacy is a valuable one.

column3: Obama administration defends Verizon records order

Mark Kirk (R-Ill.) said he was concerned that data on calls by members of Congress and Supreme Court justices could have been swept up in the program, though Holder said there was “no intention to do anything of that nature.” Elsewhere on Capitol Hill, the top two leaders of the Senate Intelligence Committee said Thursday that the widespread monitoring of Verizon phone calls made in the United States has been going on for years, and that Congress is regularly briefed on it.

column4: Sens.

column3: Obama administration defends Verizon records order

column3: Obama administration defends Verizon records order

column3: NSA seizes phone records of Verizon customers
column4: The National Security Agency is collecting the telephone records of millions of U.S. customers of Verizon under a top-secret court order issued in April, according to a report Wednesday evening in the Guardian newspaper.

column3: NSA seizes phone records of Verizon customers
column4: The order, a copy of which has been obtained by the Guardian, a publication in the United Kingdom, requires Verizon on an “ongoing, daily basis” to give the NSA information on all telephone calls in its systems, both within the U.S. and between the U.S. and other countries.

column3: NSA seizes phone records of Verizon customers
column4: The order is in force until July 19, according to the court order.

column3: NSA seizes phone records of Verizon customers
column4: The left-leaning British newspaper said the order was granted to the FBI on April 25.

column3: NSA seizes phone records of Verizon customers
column4: SEE ALSO: White House defends NSA collection of Verizon phone records; insists no eavesdropping The document indicates that the Obama administration is collecting phone records of millions of citizens in bulk, whether or not they are suspected of wrongdoing.

column3: NSA seizes phone records of Verizon customers
column4: The order was signed by Judge Roger Vinson of the secret Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court, according to the document posted online by the Guardian.

column3: NSA seizes phone records of Verizon customers
column4: A spokeswoman for the White House national security council declined to comment on the report Wednesday night.

column3: NSA seizes phone records of Verizon customers
column4: Former Vice President Al Gore commented on his Twitter account: “In digital era, privacy must be a priority.

column3: NSA seizes phone records of Verizon customers
column4: Is it just me, or is secret blanket surveillance obscenely outrageous?” SEE ALSO: GOP Sen. Graham says he’s ‘glad’ NSA is collecting phone records And the ACLU’s deputy legal director, Jameel Jaffer, said the program “could hardly be more alarming.” “It’s a program in which millions of innocent people have been put under the constant surveillance of government agents,” Mr. Jaffer said.

column3: NSA seizes phone records of Verizon customers
column4: “It’s analogous to the FBI stationing an agent outside every home in the country to track who goes in and who comes out.

column3: NSA seizes phone records of Verizon customers
column4: It is beyond Orwellian, and it provides further evidence of the extent to which basic democratic rights are being surrendered in secret to the demands of unaccountable intelligence agencies.” It was not immediately clear why the order singles out Verizon for a general seizure of records and does not mention AT&T, Sprint or other major cellphone providers.

column3: NSA seizes phone records of Verizon customers
column4: The order states says Verizon “shall produce to the National Security Agency (NSA) upon service of this Order, and continue production on an ongoing daily basis thereafter for the duration of this Order … an electronic copy of the following tangible things: all call detail records or ‘telephony metadata’ created by Verizon for communications (i) between the United States and abroad; or (ii) wholly within the United States, including local telephone calls.” As word of the court order broke Wednesday evening, Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. said in an interview that the government needs to strike a better balance between press freedom and safeguarding national secrets.

column3: NSA seizes phone records of Verizon customers
column4: “I’m a little concerned that things have gotten a little out of whack,” Mr. Holder told NBC.

column3: NSA seizes phone records of Verizon customers
column4: “I think that we can do a better job than we have.

column3: NSA seizes phone records of Verizon customers
column4: We can reform those regulations, reform those guidelines, to better reflect that balance.” Mr. Holder is under fire for wide-ranging investigations of the news media in an effort to determine the source of leaks of sensitive government information.

column3: NSA seizes phone records of Verizon customers
column4: A government watchdog, the Center for Constitutional Rights, condemned the report of the unprecedented NSA surveillance.

column3: NSA seizes phone records of Verizon customers
column4: “As far as we know this order from the FISA court is the broadest surveillance order to ever have been issued: it requires no level of suspicion and applies to all Verizon subscribers anywhere in the U.S.,” the group said.

column3: NSA seizes phone records of Verizon customers
column4: “It also contains a gag order prohibiting Verizon from disclosing information about the order to anyone other than their counsel.” The Center, based in New York, said several senators have questioned the Patriot Act’s constitutionality in such cases.

column3: NSA seizes phone records of Verizon customers
column4: “The Patriot Act provision requires the FBI to notify Congress about the number of such warrants, but this single order covering millions of people is a deceptive end-run around that disclosure requirement,” the group said.

column3: NSA seizes phone records of Verizon customers
column4: (Corrected paragraph:) ACLU Legislative Counsel Michelle Richardson called for an immediate end to the program, saying it exposed “the growing gap between the public’s and the government’s understandings” of modern surveillance.

column3: NSA seizes phone records of Verizon customers
column4: “Congress should initiate a full investigation,” she added.

column3: The real reason Obama tapped Susan Rice for national security adviser
column4: President Obama tapped UN Ambassador Susan Rice Tuesday to serve as our nation's next national security adviser.

column3: The real reason Obama tapped Susan Rice for national security adviser
column4: Tuesday morning my reaction was why appoint Susan Rice as national security adviser?

column3: The real reason Obama tapped Susan Rice for national security adviser
column4: She will be a DISASTER.

column3: The real reason Obama tapped Susan Rice for national security adviser
column4: Here's why: I spent seven years working for the most successful NSC adviser in history, Henry Kissinger.

column3: The real reason Obama tapped Susan Rice for national security adviser
column4: I watched him conceive new policies, negotiate with foreign leaders, ride herd over the bureaucracy, massage the press and foreign policy intelligentsia and work behind the scenes with congressional leaders.

column3: The real reason Obama tapped Susan Rice for national security adviser
column4: [pullquote] Susan Rice can’t do any of those things.

column3: The real reason Obama tapped Susan Rice for national security adviser
column4: She has zero credibility with the media, on Capitol Hill, with the foreign policy community and foreign leaders, and is so badly tarnished by the Benghazi scandal that she walks into the job on Day One weak and wounded.

column3: The real reason Obama tapped Susan Rice for national security adviser
column4: The most obvious problem is her disastrous performance on the Sunday talk shows peddling the administration’s fairy tale on Benghazi; when she was either complicit in the cover-up or incompetent.

column3: The real reason Obama tapped Susan Rice for national security adviser
column4: Either she knew what really happened and deliberately lied to the American people or she was a mere actress who read the script she was given and didn’t know enough to question whether the words she spoke were accurate.

column3: The real reason Obama tapped Susan Rice for national security adviser
column4: Rice might have been able to overcome the Benghazi debacle if she had other strong credentials, for example being a senior military officer like Colin Powell and Brent Scowcroft, or a respected academic like Henry Kissinger and Zbig Brzezinski.

column3: The real reason Obama tapped Susan Rice for national security adviser
column4: But  Susan Rice is none of these.

column3: The real reason Obama tapped Susan Rice for national security adviser
column4: When the spotlight was on her at the U.N. she was an ineffective ambassador who couldn't get Russia or China on board to deal with Syria or impose strict sanctions against Iran.

column3: The real reason Obama tapped Susan Rice for national security adviser
column4: Not only did she fail to persuade those key members of the Security Council, she didn't know it  until after the votes on sanctions were taken!

column3: The real reason Obama tapped Susan Rice for national security adviser
column4: Benghazi was supposed to be her audition for the Secretary of State job -- go on all the Sunday talk shows and be the Obama administration’s primary spokesman.

column3: The real reason Obama tapped Susan Rice for national security adviser
column4: She was so eager for the try out that she didn't stop and ask why they wanted her.

column3: The real reason Obama tapped Susan Rice for national security adviser
column4: The decision to send someone from the administration to appear on all five talk shows is a decision made at the highest levels of the White House.

column3: The real reason Obama tapped Susan Rice for national security adviser
column4: It should have been the Secretary of State, or maybe Secretary of Defense, or CIA chief, or NSC Adviser or White House Chief of Staff – they were part of the decision process.

column3: The real reason Obama tapped Susan Rice for national security adviser
column4: Susan Rice was the one senior administration official who knew nothing about events leading up to Benghazi and the attack itself, yet the White House asked her to go on those shows?

column3: The real reason Obama tapped Susan Rice for national security adviser
column4: Alarm bells should have gone off in her head!

column3: The real reason Obama tapped Susan Rice for national security adviser
column4: I checked their schedules and most of the other senior officials were in Washington and available that morning.

column3: The real reason Obama tapped Susan Rice for national security adviser
column4: It’s just that they were smarter than Rice and realized it was a poisoned chalice.

column3: The real reason Obama tapped Susan Rice for national security adviser
column4: So what is Obama thinking with the Rice appointment?

column3: The real reason Obama tapped Susan Rice for national security adviser
column4: He’s doubling down and circling the wagons.

column3: The real reason Obama tapped Susan Rice for national security adviser
column4: He's rewarding Rice for being a loyal (if incompetent) soldier.

column3: The real reason Obama tapped Susan Rice for national security adviser
column4: He is hanging tough on the scandals and claiming that he knew nothing about them until he read about them in the papers.

column3: The real reason Obama tapped Susan Rice for national security adviser
column4: On the other hand, maybe Obama's appointment of Rice is smarter than it looks on the surface.

column3: The real reason Obama tapped Susan Rice for national security adviser
column4: By appointing Rice to the NSC job the president can invoke executive privilege and claim she doesn’t have to testify on Capitol Hill.

column3: The real reason Obama tapped Susan Rice for national security adviser
column4: And even if she does talk about Benghazi, at some point, she will certainly be a loyal soldier if she is now sitting just steps from the Oval Office.

column3: The real reason Obama tapped Susan Rice for national security adviser
column4: But despite what the president might want the Benghazi isn't over, not by a long shot.

column3: The Face of the Benghazi Talking Points Controversy Is Receiving a Promotion - and You Won't Believe Her Replacement
column4: President Barack Obama’s top national security adviser Tom Donilon is resigning and will be replaced by U.S. ambassador to the United Nations Susan Rice, marking a significant shakeup to the White House foreign policy team.

column4: Donilon has been a key foreign policy adviser to Obama since he first took office.

column4: But the 58-year-old had been expected to depart sometime this year, with Rice seen as the likely candidate to replace him.

column4: Last month, State Department spokesowman Victoria Nuland was nominated as assistant secretary of state.

column3: The Face of the Benghazi Talking Points Controversy Is Receiving a Promotion - and You Won't Believe Her Replacement
column4: Obama considered nominating Rice as his second-term secretary of state, but she withdrew amid the GOP criticism, saying she didn’t want her confirmation fight to be a distraction for the White House.

column4: Obama will also name Samantha Power, a human rights expert and former White House adviser, to replace Rice as the U.S. ambassador to the United Nations.

column4: She has long been connected to Obama and during the president’s first campaign was in line for a top post.

column4: Her policy, dubbed “responsibility to protect,” has informed Obama decisions from early on.

column4: He’s also played a key role in the administration’s counterterrorism strategy, including the raid that led to the death of Osama bin Laden, and in managing the complex U.S. ties with Russia.

column3: Obama Picks 3 for Top Appeals Court, Setting Up Battle
column4: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s announcement of three nominees to an important federal appeals court on Tuesday is adding fuel to a larger fight on Capitol Hill over whether the minority party in the Senate has too much power to thwart a president’s agenda.

column3: Obama Picks 3 for Top Appeals Court, Setting Up Battle
column4: In a formal Rose Garden ceremony normally reserved for Supreme Court hopefuls and prominent cabinet nominees, Mr. Obama announced plans to fill, at the same time, all three vacancies on the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.

column3: Obama Picks 3 for Top Appeals Court, Setting Up Battle
column4: Republicans quickly objected, saying that Mr. Obama and his Senate allies were trying to intimidate them into approving the nominees.

column3: Obama Picks 3 for Top Appeals Court, Setting Up Battle
column4: The fight has major implications for Mr. Obama’s agenda and legacy, the judicial system and Capitol Hill politics.

column3: Obama Picks 3 for Top Appeals Court, Setting Up Battle
column4: With these nominations, the White House is trying to install judges it hopes will be more ideologically sympathetic on a court that has overturned some important initiatives of the president’s first-term agenda on environmental, regulatory and labor issues.

column3: Obama Picks 3 for Top Appeals Court, Setting Up Battle
column4: The court, typically considered the second-most important after the Supreme Court, has a fairly conservative makeup.

column3: Obama Picks 3 for Top Appeals Court, Setting Up Battle
column4: And Mr. Obama failed to win confirmation of any nominee to it until last month, because both of his administration’s slowness to put new judges forward and of Republican efforts to block his appointments More broadly, he and Senate Democrats hope to use the nominations to focus public attention on what they consider Republican obstruction of his choices for the cabinet and the courts, as well as of his legislative priorities.

column3: Obama Picks 3 for Top Appeals Court, Setting Up Battle
column4: Exasperated by the constant threat of filibusters, Democrats appear to be edging closer to forcing a change to the chamber’s rules that would limit the minority party’s power to block and delay.

column3: Obama Picks 3 for Top Appeals Court, Setting Up Battle

column3: Obama Picks 3 for Top Appeals Court, Setting Up Battle

column3: Obama Picks 3 for Top Appeals Court, Setting Up Battle

column3: Obama Picks 3 for Top Appeals Court, Setting Up Battle

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret e-mail addresses
column4: Some top political appointees in the Obama administration are using secret government e-mail addresses, and several federal agencies have so far failed to disclose their addresses to the Associated Press despite a three-month old request, the AP reported Tuesday morning.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret e-mail addresses
column4: Those making use of secret addresses include Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius, the wire service said.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret e-mail addresses
column4: AP requested the addresses using a Freedom of Information Act request earlier this year.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret e-mail addresses
column4: The AP article published Tuesday morning says the Labor Department initially asked the wire service to pay $1 million to cover the cost of researching the request and providing the information that was being sought.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret e-mail addresses
column4: The agencies involved say e-mails sent from or received by private accounts are still provided when specific requests for information are made, just like emails from regular government addresses.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret e-mail addresses
column4: They justified the accounts as necessary to avoid flooding their inboxes, and said they were a good way for officials to separate internal business from e-mails they exchange with the public.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret e-mail addresses
column4: The AP reports that the following 10 agencies have failed to turn over a list of their secret e-mail addresses, but added that all the agencies say they are working on responding: Environmental Protection Agency The Pentagon Veterans Affairs Transportation Treasury Justice Housing and Urban Development Homeland Security Commerce Agriculture Health and Human Services responded but initially didn't include e-mail addresses for Sebelius.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret e-mail addresses
column4: After the AP objected, it turned over three addresses for her, including one secret address.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret e-mail addresses
column4: It asked the AP not to publish the address, but the AP decided to publish it anyway, explaining that it did so because Sebelius is a high-ranking civil servant.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret e-mail addresses
column4: Others with secret addresses that have been discovered so far include Donald Berwick, who headed the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, and Gary Cohen, a deputy administrator working on health insurance reform.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: The Obama administration on Tuesday defended officials' use of private email accounts to conduct government business and denied that they were in any way "secret" -- though the public faces hurdles in gaining access to that information.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: The Associated Press reported earlier that some of President Obama's political appointees were using "secret" government emails accounts -- a situation that could complicate their responsibility to turn over emails under public records requests and congressional inquiries.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: One of those officials, Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius, denied that her account was "secret" when asked by Fox News about the report.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: "There's a public email and a private email," she said, adding that anyone could formally request to have access to that information.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: Sebelius explained that she needed the alternative account to deal with the influx of messages.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: "27-28,000 come into the public email, about 400 come into the private email.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: It's just a management issue.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: I can't possibly answer or screen all of them, and I want people to get timely answers," she said.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: White House Press Secretary Jay Carney gave a similar explanation, saying the practice is "consistent with prior administrations."

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: "Having alternate email addresses for Cabinet secretaries and other high-profile official makes eminent sense, as much as it does for columnists for example, of major publications who provide email addresses for their readers, but have alternative work email addresses," he said.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: Carney said all their email accounts, public and otherwise, were subject to congressional oversight and requests by citizens under the U.S. Freedom of Information Act.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: "There's nothing secret," Carney said.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: But if it's not secret, it's certainly difficult to find.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: The AP reviewed hundreds of pages of government emails released under the federal open records law and couldn't independently find instances when material from any of the secret accounts it identified was turned over.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: Congressional oversight committees told the AP they were unfamiliar with the few nonpublic government addresses that AP identified so far, including one for Sebelius.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: The White House said the practice was also used by previous administrations, but its scale across the government remains a mystery: Most federal agencies have failed to turn over lists of political appointees' email addresses, which the AP sought under the Freedom of Information Act more than three months ago.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: The Labor Department initially asked the AP to pay more than $1 million for its email addresses.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: The AP asked for such addresses following last year's disclosures that former chiefs at the Environmental Protection Agency had used separate email accounts at work.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: The practice is separate from officials who use personal, nongovernment email accounts for work, which generally is discouraged due to laws requiring that most federal records be preserved.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: Having separate accounts could put an agency in a difficult spot when it is compelled to search for and release emails as part of congressional or internal investigations, civil lawsuits and public records requests.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: That's because employees assigned to compile such responses would necessarily need to know about the accounts to search them.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: Secret accounts also drive perceptions that government officials try to hide actions or decisions.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: "What happens when that person doesn't work there anymore?

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: He leaves and someone makes a request (to review emails) in two years," said Kel McClanahan, executive director of National Security Counselors, an open government group.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: "Who's going to know to search the other accounts?

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: You would hope that agencies doing this would keep a list of aliases in a desk drawer, but you know that isn't happening."

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: Agencies where the AP so far has identified secret addresses, including the Labor Department and HHS, said maintaining nonpublic email accounts allows senior officials to keep separate their internal messages with agency employees from emails they exchange with the public.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: They also said public and nonpublic accounts would always be searched in response to official requests and the records would be provided as necessary.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: In its review, the AP found only one instance of a secret address being published: An email from Labor Department spokesman Carl Fillichio to 34 coworkers in 2010 was turned over to an advocacy group, Americans for Limited Government.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: It included as one recipient the nonpublic address for Seth D. Harris, now the acting labor secretary, who maintains at least three separate email accounts.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: Google can't find any reference on the Internet to the secret address for Sebelius.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: Ten agencies have not yet turned over lists of email addresses, including the Environmental Protection Agency and the departments of Defense, Veterans Affairs, Transportation, Treasury, Justice, Housing and Urban Development, Homeland Security, Commerce and Agriculture.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: All have said they are working on a response to the AP.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: Carney would not say whether White House officials also use secret accounts, noting that the president's staff, like Congress, is exempt from turning over materials under the open records law.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: But Carney said that early in his tenure as press secretary, after his email address had been announced publicly, Carney changed his address to avoid being inundated by emails and spam.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: The Health and Human Services Department initially turned over to the AP the email addresses for roughly 240 appointees -- except none of the email accounts for Sebelius, even one for her already published on its website.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: After the AP objected, it turned over three of Sebelius' email addresses, including a secret one.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: It asked the AP not to publish the address, which it said she used to conduct day-to-day business at the department.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: Most of the 240 political appointees at HHS appeared to be using only public government accounts.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: The AP decided to publish the secret address for Sebelius -- KGS2@hhs.gov -- over the government's objections because the secretary is a high-ranking civil servant who oversees not only major agencies like the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services but also the implementation of Obama's signature health care law.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: Her public email address is Kathleen.Sebelius@hhs.gov.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: At least two other senior HHS officials -- Donald Berwick, former head of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, and Gary Cohen, a deputy administrator in charge of implementing health insurance reform -- also had secret government email addresses, according to the records obtained by the AP.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: A spokesman for Cohen, Brian Cook, said the nonpublic address that HHS listed in its records -- Gary.Cohen1@cms.hhs.gov -- was created after Cohen rejoined the department in August 2012 following a brief absence and all emails now are directed to his public government email account.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: Cook called the suggestion that Cohen ever had a secret account "news to everyone, including Gary."

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: The Interior Department gave the AP a list of about 100 government email addresses for political appointees who work there but none for the interior secretary at the time, Ken Salazar, who has since resigned.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: Spokeswoman Jessica Kershaw said Salazar maintained only one email address while serving as secretary, but she would not disclose it.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: She said the AP should ask for it under the Freedom of Information Act, which would take months longer.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: The Labor Department initially asked the AP to pay slightly more than $1.03 million when the AP asked for email addresses of political appointees there.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: It said it needed to pull 2,236 computer backup tapes from its archives and pay 50 people to pore over old records.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: Those costs included three weeks to identify tapes and ship them to a vendor, and pay each person $2,500 for nearly a month's work.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: But under the department's own FOIA rules -- which it cited in its letter to the AP -- it is prohibited from charging news organizations any costs except for photocopies after the first 100 pages.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: The department said it would take 14 weeks to find the emails if the AP had paid the money.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: Fillichio later acknowledged that the $1.03 million bill was a mistake and provided the AP with email addresses for the agency's Senate-confirmed appointees, including three addresses for Harris.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: His secret address was harris.sd@dol.gov.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: His other accounts were one for use with labor employees and the public, and another to send mass emails to the entire Labor Department, outside groups and the public.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: The Labor Department said it did not object to the AP publishing any of Harris' email addresses.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: Late last year, the EPA's critics -- including Republicans in Congress -- accused former EPA Administrator Lisa Jackson of using an email account under the name "Richard Windsor" to sidestep disclosure rules.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: The EPA said emails Jackson sent using her Windsor alias were turned over under open records requests.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: The agency's inspector general is investigating the use of such accounts, after being asked to do so by Congress.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: An EPA spokeswoman described Jackson's alternate email address as "an everyday, working email account of the administrator to communicate with staff and other government officials."

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts
column4: It was later determined that Jackson also used the email address to correspond sometimes with environmentalists outside government and at least in some cases did not correct a misperception among outsiders they were corresponding with a government employee named Richard Windsor.

column3: Top Obama appointees using secret email accounts

column3: NJ Sen. Frank Lautenberg Dies at 89; Christie to Appoint Temporary Replacement
column4: Frank Lautenberg, the last World War II veteran serving in the United States Senate, died of natural causes this morning at the age of 89: Frank R. Lautenberg, who rose from a poor Paterson boyhood to become a multimillionaire businessman and New Jersey’s longest-serving U.S. senator, died Monday at 89 of viral pneumonia, his office said.

column3: NJ Sen. Frank Lautenberg Dies at 89; Christie to Appoint Temporary Replacement
column4: The oldest member of the Senate, Lautenberg had struggled with health problems since late last year, when he missed several weeks of votes because of what he said was flu and bronchitis.

column3: NJ Sen. Frank Lautenberg Dies at 89; Christie to Appoint Temporary Replacement
column4: The death of Lautenberg, a Democrat, creates a vacancy that Gov.

column3: NJ Sen. Frank Lautenberg Dies at 89; Christie to Appoint Temporary Replacement
column4: Christie, a Republican, will fill.

column3: NJ Sen. Frank Lautenberg Dies at 89; Christie to Appoint Temporary Replacement
column4: Lautenberg returned to Washington in February and announced he would not seek re-election in 2014, but hoped to complete a series of accomplishments before his term ended.

column3: NJ Sen. Frank Lautenberg Dies at 89; Christie to Appoint Temporary Replacement

column3: Robert Gibbs: Darrell Issa must apologize
column4: Former White House press secretary Robert Gibbs on Monday called on Rep. Darrell Issa to apologize after the California congressman bashed the current administration spokesman as a “paid liar.” “Well, first of all, Darrell Issa should call Jay Carney and apologize this morning,” Gibbs said on MSNBC’s “Morning Joe.” Story Continued Below He also called the fact that Issa is the chairman of the House Oversight Committee possibly the “biggest joke in all of Washington.” ( PHOTOS: 8 key players in IRS scandal story) His comments came a day after Issa (R-Calif.) called White House press secretary Jay Carney a “paid liar” in light of the controversy surrounding the IRS and a division in the agency that scrutinized conservative groups.

column3: Robert Gibbs: Darrell Issa must apologize
column4: “Their paid liar, their spokesperson … he’s still making up things about what happened and calling this a local rogue,” Issa said on Sunday, speaking on CNN’s “State of the Union.” “I mean, it’s a stunning thing,” Gibbs said of Issa’s charges.

column3: Robert Gibbs: Darrell Issa must apologize
column4: “It’s why five people in this town take Darrell Issa seriously and it’s the surest bet the Republicans are very much on the verge of overplaying their hand publicly and the American people will lose interest in their side of this.

column3: Robert Gibbs: Darrell Issa must apologize
column4: They want to see the IRS cleaned up, but they will understand quickly that Darrell Issa is doing nothing more than politicizing this event.”

column3: IRS Battle Turns Ugly, Personal: Former Obama Adviser Calls Issa a 'Suspected Arsonist' and 'Insurance Swindler'
column4: After Rep. Darrell Issa (R-Calif.) labeled Jay Carney a “paid liar” and charged that the Internal Revenue Service’s targeting of conservative groups was likely directed from someone in Washington, D.C., David Plouffe, a former Obama adviser, responded — via Twitter.

column3: IRS Battle Turns Ugly, Personal: Former Obama Adviser Calls Issa a 'Suspected Arsonist' and 'Insurance Swindler'
column4: And he took some intense personal jabs at the congressman.

column3: IRS Battle Turns Ugly, Personal: Former Obama Adviser Calls Issa a 'Suspected Arsonist' and 'Insurance Swindler'
column4: The back-and-forth started on Sunday, as TheBlaze previously reported.

column3: IRS Battle Turns Ugly, Personal: Former Obama Adviser Calls Issa a 'Suspected Arsonist' and 'Insurance Swindler'
column4: Issa, speaking explicitly about the IRS scandal, lashed out at the White House’s handling of the situation.

column3: IRS Battle Turns Ugly, Personal: Former Obama Adviser Calls Issa a 'Suspected Arsonist' and 'Insurance Swindler'
column4: “The administration is still — their paid liar, their spokesperson, picture behind — he’s still making up things about what happens and calling this local rogue,” Issa said on Sunday’s edition of CNN’s “State of the Union.” “The reason that [IRS administrator] Lois Lerner tried to take the Fifth [Amendment] isn’t because there’s a rogue in Cincinnati, it’s because this is a problem that was coordinated, in all likelihood, right out of Washington headquarters and we’re getting to proving it.” Plouffe didn’t take too kindly to these comments.

column3: IRS Battle Turns Ugly, Personal: Former Obama Adviser Calls Issa a 'Suspected Arsonist' and 'Insurance Swindler'
column4: In fact, the former Obama campaign manager took to Twitter and brought up some old allegations that were once waged against Issa.

column3: IRS Battle Turns Ugly, Personal: Former Obama Adviser Calls Issa a 'Suspected Arsonist' and 'Insurance Swindler'
column4: “Strong words from Mr Grand Theft Auto and suspected arsonist/insurance swindler,” Plouffe wrote.

column3: IRS Battle Turns Ugly, Personal: Former Obama Adviser Calls Issa a 'Suspected Arsonist' and 'Insurance Swindler'
column4: “And loose ethically today.” [blackbirdpie url=”https://twitter.com/davidplouffe/status/341313483184414720″] The initial charge — and the response from Plouffe — offer a rare glimpse into uninhibited and public spats between political figures.

column3: IRS Battle Turns Ugly, Personal: Former Obama Adviser Calls Issa a 'Suspected Arsonist' and 'Insurance Swindler'
column4: Considering the severity of the former Obama administration official’s claims, one wonders: Do his charges have any validity?

column3: IRS Battle Turns Ugly, Personal: Former Obama Adviser Calls Issa a 'Suspected Arsonist' and 'Insurance Swindler'
column4: CNN provides some background about Issa’s past: In 1972, then-19-year-old Issa too was arrested under suspicion of stealing a car, but Issa claims it was a case of mistaken identity and the charges were ultimately dropped.

column3: IRS Battle Turns Ugly, Personal: Former Obama Adviser Calls Issa a 'Suspected Arsonist' and 'Insurance Swindler'
column4: In 1982, the office and factory of two companies Issa had purchased, Quantum Enterprises and Steal Stopper International, caught on fire.

column3: IRS Battle Turns Ugly, Personal: Former Obama Adviser Calls Issa a 'Suspected Arsonist' and 'Insurance Swindler'
column4: The insurance company’s investigation found “suspicious burn patterns” and company officials noted that in the month before the fire Issa had increased his insurance from $100,000 to $462,000.

column3: IRS Battle Turns Ugly, Personal: Former Obama Adviser Calls Issa a 'Suspected Arsonist' and 'Insurance Swindler'
column4: As the New Yorker’s Ryan Lizza noted, the “Ohio state fire marshal never determined the cause of the fire and no one was ever charged with a crime”; Issa and the insurance company settled out of court.

column3: IRS Battle Turns Ugly, Personal: Former Obama Adviser Calls Issa a 'Suspected Arsonist' and 'Insurance Swindler'
column4: Plouffe’s tweet, without this background knowledge, could lead some to believe that Issa was, indeed, a suspected arsonist who sought to nab insurance money through deceit.

column3: IRS Battle Turns Ugly, Personal: Former Obama Adviser Calls Issa a 'Suspected Arsonist' and 'Insurance Swindler'
column4: When asked why he brought up the congressman’s past problems, the former Obama staffer attempted to attach Issa’s past to the present.

column3: IRS Battle Turns Ugly, Personal: Former Obama Adviser Calls Issa a 'Suspected Arsonist' and 'Insurance Swindler'
column4: Plouffe told CNN that his opponent’s “ethics issues are far more recent.

column3: IRS Battle Turns Ugly, Personal: Former Obama Adviser Calls Issa a 'Suspected Arsonist' and 'Insurance Swindler'
column4: Look at ethics complaints filed.” These complaints — filed by liberal groups, as CNN notes — are not indicative of wrongdoing.

column3: IRS Battle Turns Ugly, Personal: Former Obama Adviser Calls Issa a 'Suspected Arsonist' and 'Insurance Swindler'
column4: Currently, there are no official ethics judgments against Issa.

column3: IRS Battle Turns Ugly, Personal: Former Obama Adviser Calls Issa a 'Suspected Arsonist' and 'Insurance Swindler'
column4: Plouffe’s response to the congressman’s claims that the administration is hedging may have simply been delivered out of frustration or anger.

column3: IRS Battle Turns Ugly, Personal: Former Obama Adviser Calls Issa a 'Suspected Arsonist' and 'Insurance Swindler'
column4: Or, perhaps he was looking to spawn visceral responses in readers who would see the tweet as calling into question Issa’s overall character.

column3: At Reagan library, Rand Paul calls for inclusiveness
