column4: Showing his youthful exuberance, Paul told the crowd – which appeared older than who he usually speaks to – that Republicans need to be “the party of passion.” “When I think of a man coming over the hill singing, I think of the passion of Patrick Henry—‘Give me liberty or give me death’—combined with the energy of The Proclaimers song—‘I will walk 500 miles and I will walk five hundred more, just to be the guy who walked a thousand miles to fall down at your door.’”

column3: Rand Paul outlines agenda, potential 2016 presidential platform in Reagan Library speech
column4: SIMI VALLEY, Calif. — Sen. Rand Paul put a palatable price tag on federal spending Friday night — precisely.

column3: Rand Paul outlines agenda, potential 2016 presidential platform in Reagan Library speech
column4: The Kentucky Republican said Uncle Sam’s acceptable payout peg is is “actually for $2.6 trillion dollars’ worth of government.” The rising libertarian star and potential 2016 presidential candidate laid down the spending marker during a defining policy speech on the home turf of a Republican icon, former President Ronald Reagan.

column3: Rand Paul outlines agenda, potential 2016 presidential platform in Reagan Library speech
column4: SEE ALSO: PAUL: Security precautions for immigration reform “Sometimes conservatives get tagged as being against all government,” Mr. Paul told an audience packed with supporters as well as skeptics at the Reagan Library here, an hour northeast of Los Angeles.

column3: Rand Paul outlines agenda, potential 2016 presidential platform in Reagan Library speech
column4: “I’m not against all government.

column3: Rand Paul outlines agenda, potential 2016 presidential platform in Reagan Library speech
column4: I’m actually for $2.6 trillion dollars worth,” he said.

column3: Rand Paul outlines agenda, potential 2016 presidential platform in Reagan Library speech
column4: “I’m for spending what comes in, but nothing in excess of what comes in.” Most conservative Republicans tell conservative audiences what they want to hear, however improbable the goal of actually shrinking government.

column3: Rand Paul outlines agenda, potential 2016 presidential platform in Reagan Library speech
column4: SEE ALSO: Sen. Rand Paul blasts colleague John McCain’s trip to Syria But Mr. Paul wanted to define himself for those skeptics as not being an “all government is bad” libertarian –- an image his father, former Texas Rep. Ron Paul, had among some of his fellow Republicans.

column3: Rand Paul outlines agenda, potential 2016 presidential platform in Reagan Library speech
column4: It is an image that the younger Mr. Paul knows makes him scary to some fellow Republicans.

column3: Rand Paul outlines agenda, potential 2016 presidential platform in Reagan Library speech
column4: Nonetheless, he did not shy away from identifying himself with his philosophical heritage and his basic worldview.

column3: Rand Paul outlines agenda, potential 2016 presidential platform in Reagan Library speech
column4: “I am a libertarian-conservative who spends most of my free time outdoors,” he said at one point, seeking to make the case that conservatives are not indifferent about preserving the environment.

column3: Rand Paul outlines agenda, potential 2016 presidential platform in Reagan Library speech
column4: “I bike and hike and kayak., I compost, I plant trees,” he said.

column3: Rand Paul outlines agenda, potential 2016 presidential platform in Reagan Library speech
column4: “In fact, I have a giant Sequoia I’m trying to grow in Kentucky.” Mr. Paul argued that Republicans “care just as deeply about the environment as Democrats, but we also care about jobs.

column3: Rand Paul outlines agenda, potential 2016 presidential platform in Reagan Library speech
column4: We want common sense regulations to be balanced with economic growth and jobs.” Then Mr. Paul addressed what he considers one of the GOP’s biggest problems – being defined negatively by the top opinion-makers of American cultural tastes and standards.

column3: Rand Paul outlines agenda, potential 2016 presidential platform in Reagan Library speech
column4: “To win in California and other bluish states, Republicans will have to change current perceptions,” he said.

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: WASHINGTON -- President Barack Obama on Friday stepped into the hyper-partisan fight over student debt, warning about the economic dangers posed by rising debt burdens and urging Congress to pass legislation to prevent interest rates on some loans from doubling as a hard deadline looms on July 1.

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: His speech comes against a backdrop of rising tuition, increasing debt burdens, record relative interest rates on federal student loans and growing worries that student debt -- once seen as a ticket to a college degree and a well-paying job -- may be restraining the U.S. economy as debt-laden graduates curtail consumption.

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: The average new college graduate carries more than $26,000 in student debt, Obama said, flanked by college students at the White House.

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: “That doesn’t just hold back our young graduates.

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: It holds back our entire middle class,” he said.

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: Student loan payments “can last for years, even decades, which means young people are putting off buying their first car or their first house -- the things that grow our economy and create new jobs,” Obama added.

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: If Congress and the White House fail to agree, interest rates on subsidized Stafford loans for undergraduate students are set to double from 3.4 to 6.8 percent on July 1 because of the expiration of a 2007 law that had gradually lowered the rate.

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: The hike would affect about one quarter of new federal student loan dollars.

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: The doubled rates would cost affected borrowers, who come from middle- and lower-income households, about $1,000 more over the average 12-year life of each loan.

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: House Republicans are pushing a bill that would tie interest rates on all federal student loans to the U.S. government’s cost to borrow for 10 years.

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: The White House has put forward a similar proposal, but it would freeze the rate for the life of the loan.

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: Assuming interest rates do not spike, the administration's plan likely would be cheaper for students.

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: The Republicans’ plan, however, caps interest rates.

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: The Republican bill “fails to lock in low rates for students next year," Obama said.

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: "That's not smart.

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: It eliminates safeguards for lower-income families.

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: That's not fair.

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: It could actually cost a freshman starting school next fall more over four years than if we did nothing at all.” If the stakes sound familiar, it's because the Washington gridlock, intensified by election-year politics last year, resulted in a short-term fix when the interest rate was supposed to double last July.

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: Obama made a similar push then, launching a campaign called "Don't Double My Rate," though he delivered the message primarily on college campuses in battleground states Colorado, Iowa and North Carolina, as well as on Jimmy Fallon's late night talk show.

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: "If this sounds like deja vu all over again, that's because it is," Obama said Friday.

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: "We went through this last summer.

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: Some of you were here.

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: … Eventually Congress listened to parents and all the young people who said, don't double my rate."

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: He asked college students to call their representatives to urge them to keep the rates down.

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: Last year, furious Republicans on Capitol Hill accused the president of pandering to the youth to recapture a vote that helped propel him to the White House in 2008.

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: It wasn't until GOP presidential nominee Mitt Romney endorsed an extension of the lower rate that Republican lawmakers relented.

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: Congress kept the rate at 3.4 percent for one year.

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: To keep the decrease in interest income from affecting the government’s annual budget deficit, interest rates on federal loans for graduate students rose.

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: While the battle ultimately ended with an extension of the lower rates, some advocates worry that outcome will be harder to achieve this time around -- perhaps because of partisan rancor.

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: "Last year, the issue became a political football and student aid got politicized," said Chris Lindstrom, a higher education advocate with Public Interest Research Group.

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: "The issue had previously enjoyed bipartisan support and last year it became very partisan and we continue to have that divide."

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: "Quite a few factors make it harder for us to win the low rate extension this year," Lindstrom added.

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: "Nonetheless, we need to try."

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: Other student loan experts reckon that the impending reauthorization of the Higher Education Act, the law that governs federal aid to higher education, and a flood of proposals on Capitol Hill may improve prospects for a bipartisan compromise.

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: For example, many proposed bills in Congress call for the government to tie student borrowing costs to the federal government’s, rather than the current system of arbitrarily set interest rates.

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: If lawmakers eventually strike a deal to lower students’ cost to borrow from the federal government, they would have to either allow the compromise to increase budget deficits or reduce spending on other programs.

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: This year, the Obama administration is set to record nearly $51 billion in profit off student borrowers, according to the Congressional Budget Office.

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: The government profits by borrowing at near-record low rates and then charging students interest rates last set by Congress in 2007, when borrowing costs across the economy were much higher.

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: Obama's speech likely will kick off a new wave of advocacy, as students are expected to march on Capitol Hill to make their case next week.

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: It is already drawing criticism from Republicans, who preemptively lashed out at the White House for what they believe is an effort to point fingers at them rather than look for ways to compromise.

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: Even as Obama spoke, staffers for GOP leadership took to Twitter to imply the event was merely an effort to distract from recent scandals facing the administration.

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: Rep. Luke Messer (R-Ind.)

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: made a similar point during an appearance on MSNBC Friday morning.

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: "It’s not only a distraction from issues like Benghazi and the IRS and Department of Justice, but it’s a distraction from the fact that the real threat to college-age students in America today is not a few more dollars on their student loan, it’s the fact that the explosive growth of debt, the fact that the jobs in this economy for young people entering the marketplace have been the people probably most hurt by the Obama policies," he said.

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: "It’s time for the president to stop politicizing the student loan issue," Rep. John Kline (R-Minn.), who chairs the House education committee, said in a statement shortly after Obama finished speaking.

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: "The president and House Republicans agree on the need for a long-term, market-based plan that will take politicians out of the business of arbitrarily setting student loan interest rates."

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: House Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio) piled on, calling the speech "misguided and deeply disappointing."

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: Republicans have also picked up one of Obama's tricks as they prep for the fight.

column3: Obama Poses Student Loan Challenge To Republicans
column4: GOP leadership debuted the hashtag #YouDeserveBetter on Friday, though time will tell if they can beat the president at his own game.

column3: Obama on student loan rates: like deja-vu all over again
column4: As I mentioned he would be earlier this week, President Obama dedicated his Friday morning to educating the youths he used as backdrops at the White House about why it is that the GOP’s idea to fix this cyclical federal student-loan battle by tying interest rates to the market, instead of the president’s own plan allowing politicians to continue to arbitrarily determine the interest rates that they deem appropriate, is such a very terrible take on the problem.

column3: Obama on student loan rates: like deja-vu all over again
column4: It went pretty much exactly as you’d expect.

column3: Obama on student loan rates: like deja-vu all over again
column4: Key words: “Fair.” “Investments.” “Not the time for us to turn our back on young people.” Ugh.

column3: Obama on student loan rates: like deja-vu all over again
column4: Let us overlook for a moment the fact that the president is perpetuating a student-loan bubble via a broken system that floods that market with too much demand that in turn causes college prices to just keep right on rising, and focus instead on the fact that the differences between the president’s and the GOP’s plans will have a negligible impact on actual student-loan payments.

column3: Obama on student loan rates: like deja-vu all over again
column4: This is just politics as usual, via the WSJ: House Education Chairman John Kline’s bill sets floating rates on new Stafford loans at the 10-year Treasury rate plus 2.5%, while also protecting borrowers by capping the rates at 8.5%.

column3: Obama on student loan rates: like deja-vu all over again
column4: Under this plan, a borrower can consolidate his loans after graduation to achieve a fixed rate.

column3: Obama on student loan rates: like deja-vu all over again
column4: Mr. Obama’s plan is purely for fixed, not floating, rates at the 10-year Treasury rate plus 0.93% or 2.93% depending on the type of Stafford loan, and it has no rate cap.

column3: Obama on student loan rates: like deja-vu all over again
column4: We wish both the House and Mr. Obama would drive a harder bargain on behalf of the taxpayer, but they aren’t separated by a difference of philosophy.

column3: Obama on student loan rates: like deja-vu all over again
column4: A spread of 93 or 293 basis points means the President cares about young people, but 250 basis points signifies unspeakable cruelty?

column3: Obama on student loan rates: like deja-vu all over again
column4: … Under either plan, rates for new Stafford loans for undergraduates will not nearly rise all the way to 6.8% from 3.4%, as they are scheduled to do on July 1.

column3: Obama on student loan rates: like deja-vu all over again
column4: But the White House likes to run against a doubling of rates even when, as in this case, they are running unopposed.

column3: Obama on student loan rates: like deja-vu all over again
column4: It has been a good political issue for Team Obama in the past, and there’s another reason they may regard it as favorable ground to attack imaginary adversaries.

column3: Obama on student loan rates: like deja-vu all over again
column4: Hey, if President Obama really wants to focus in on helping young people with life after college, maybe we could worry a little less about piddling, stimulus-esque, big-government market interferences and a little more on our sluggish economy and 16 percent youth unemployment rate?

column3: Obama on student loan rates: like deja-vu all over again
column4: Anyone?

column3: Arizona mother who was jailed in Mexico on drug charges is now free, back home
column4: An Arizona mother of seven who was jailed last week on drug charges is now free, after a judge reviewed security footage of her boarding the bus and dismissed the charges.

column3: Arizona mother who was jailed in Mexico on drug charges is now free, back home
column4: “I’m free, I’m free, I’m free,” said Yanira Maldonado, 42, on Friday morning, from her Arizona home on Fox News.

column3: Arizona mother who was jailed in Mexico on drug charges is now free, back home
column4: “At first, I was sad … but my faith kept me going.” Ms. Maldonado was arrested last week by Mexican military officials who claimed she had smuggled 12 pounds of marijuana aboard a bus.

column3: Arizona mother who was jailed in Mexico on drug charges is now free, back home
column4: Her attorney said those charged were trumped and pointed to the complexity of the operation — the marijuana was placed in several packets and attached with hooks beneath a bus seat — as proof that she was being framed.

column3: Arizona mother who was jailed in Mexico on drug charges is now free, back home
column4: Security footage of Ms. Maldonado boarding the bus showed she was only carrying blankets, bottles of water and a small purse — nothing that would enable her to carry aboard so much marijuana.

column3: Arizona mother who was jailed in Mexico on drug charges is now free, back home
column4: The judge dismissed her case and freed her after viewing the footage, Fox News reported.

column3: Arizona mother who was jailed in Mexico on drug charges is now free, back home
column4: Upon exiting jail late Thursday evening, Ms. Maldonado hugged her husband, and thanked her attorneys and U.S. State Department workers for their help.

column3: Secret Service: New ricin letter sent to Obama
column4: A ricin-laced letter addressed to President Barack Obama was intercepted before reaching the president, the Secret Service confirmed Thursday.

column3: Secret Service: New ricin letter sent to Obama
column4: The letter was similar to those sent last week to New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg and the gun control group he backs.

column3: Secret Service: New ricin letter sent to Obama
column4: “The White House mail screening facility intercepted a letter addressed to the White House that were similar to letters previously addressed to Mayor Bloomberg in New York,” Secret Service spokesman Edwin Donovan said in a statement to POLITICO.

column3: Secret Service: New ricin letter sent to Obama
column4: “This letter has been turned over to the FBI Joint Terrorism Task Force for testing and investigation.” Story Continued Below NBC News reported that the text of the letter was identical to those sent to Bloomberg, including the line “what’s in this letter is nothing compared to what I’ve got planned for you.” ( Also on POLITICO: What is ricin?)

column3: Secret Service: New ricin letter sent to Obama
column4: The threatening letters to Bloomberg and the Washington office of his gun control organization, Mayors Against Illegal Guns, both referenced the “debate on gun laws,” according to a New York Police Department spokesman.

column3: Secret Service: New ricin letter sent to Obama
column4: Those letters were discovered over the Memorial Day weekend.

column3: Secret Service: New ricin letter sent to Obama
column4: “Anonymous threats to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg in letters opened in New York City on Friday and by the director of the Mayors Against Illegal Guns in Washington, D.C., on Sunday contained material that when tested locally, preliminarily indicated the presence of ricin,” New York City Police Department Deputy Commissioner Paul J. Browne said in a statement.

column3: Secret Service: New ricin letter sent to Obama
column4: Bloomberg said Wednesday the threats would not affect his gun control push.

column3: Secret Service: New ricin letter sent to Obama
column4: “In terms of why they’ve done it, I don’t know,” Bloomberg said.

column3: Secret Service: New ricin letter sent to Obama
column4: “The letter obviously referred to our anti-gun efforts.

column3: Secret Service: New ricin letter sent to Obama
column4: But there’s 12,000 people who are gonna get killed this year with guns and 19,000 that are gonna commit suicide with guns and we’re not gonna walk away from these efforts.”

column3: Secret Service: Suspicious letter to White House intercepted
column4: The letter has been turned over to the FBI's Joint Terrorism Task Force for testing and investigation.

column3: Secret Service: Suspicious letter to White House intercepted
column4: It was unclear how the letter, intercepted Wednesday by the White House facility, was similar to the ricin-laced ones addressed to Bloomberg.

column3: Secret Service: Suspicious letter to White House intercepted
column4: Two threatening letters postmarked in Louisiana and containing traces of the deadly poison ricin were sent to Bloomberg in New York and to his gun-control group in Washington, officials said.

column3: Secret Service: Suspicious letter to White House intercepted
column4: The anonymous letters were opened in New York on Friday at the city's mail facility in Manhattan and in Washington on Sunday at an office used by Mayors Against Illegal Guns, the nonprofit started by Bloomberg, police said Wednesday.

column3: Secret Service: Suspicious letter to White House intercepted
column4: Police said preliminary testing indicated the presence of ricin in both letters involving Bloomberg, but that more testing would be done.

column3: Secret Service: Suspicious letter to White House intercepted
column4: Police said the threats contained references to the debate on gun laws and an oily pinkish-orange substance.

column3: Secret Service: Suspicious letter to White House intercepted
column4: Last month, authorities in Washington intercepted a letter addressed to Obama that contained a "suspicious substance."

column3: Secret Service: Suspicious letter to White House intercepted
column4: This letter was similar to one mailed to Mississippi Republican Sen. Roger Wicker, which tested positive for ricin.

column3: Holder Faces New Round of Criticism After Leak Inquiries
column4: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr., a lightning rod of Republican attacks during President Obama’s first term, is now contending with a new round of criticism over the Justice Department’s campaign against leaks to the news media.

column3: Holder Faces New Round of Criticism After Leak Inquiries
column4: This time it is the news media and even some Democrats who are upset with Mr. Holder, who in recent days has taken steps seemingly aimed at assuaging them.

column3: Holder Faces New Round of Criticism After Leak Inquiries
column4: He endorsed the enactment of a “media shield” law and invited leaders of news organizations to meet with him Thursday to discuss tightening rules on warrants and subpoenas for reporters’ records as part of leak investigations.

column3: Holder Faces New Round of Criticism After Leak Inquiries
column4: Even as Mr. Holder has sought to regain his footing, Republicans have resumed their criticism, accusing him of misleading Congress in testimony over whether the Justice Department has considered prosecuting journalists under the Espionage Act for publishing government secrets.

column3: Holder Faces New Round of Criticism After Leak Inquiries
column4: In a letter Wednesday, the House Judiciary Committee chairman, Representative Robert W. Goodlatte of Virginia, and a Republican colleague, Representative Jim Sensenbrenner of Wisconsin, expressed “great concern” about Mr. Holder’s testimony before the committee this month, saying it “appeared to be at odds” with court documents that have come to light involving a warrant for e-mails of James Rosen, a Fox News reporter.

column3: Holder Faces New Round of Criticism After Leak Inquiries
column4: The prospect of a new round of perjury accusations from Congress has underscored that the furor over the leak investigations might pose a new threat to Mr. Holder, who surprised many Democrats by choosing to stay on after Mr. Obama’s re-election.

column3: Holder Faces New Round of Criticism After Leak Inquiries
column4: For now, Democrats on the House Judiciary Committee are standing by Mr. Holder, even though the ranking member, Representative John Conyers Jr. of Michigan, pronounced himself “deeply troubled” by some of the investigative tactics used in recent leak cases.

column3: Holder Faces New Round of Criticism After Leak Inquiries
column4: “Certainly, it is fair to ask additional questions about the Rosen investigation, and any role the attorney general may have played in it, but I do not believe it credible to level charges that he may have intentionally misled the committee on this matter before we know the facts of the case in question,” Mr. Conyers said.

column3: Holder Faces New Round of Criticism After Leak Inquiries
column4: In his only recent interview, Mr. Holder told The Daily Beast that the investigations obeyed existing laws and guidelines, but he also said the rules “need to be updated.” He called the furor “an opportunity for the department to consider how we strike the right balance between the interests of law enforcement and freedom of the press.” The Daily Beast article also paraphrased unnamed aides as saying Mr. Holder was “also beginning to feel a creeping sense of personal remorse.” Reid Weingarten, a lawyer who has been a friend of Mr. Holder’s for three decades, said Mr. Holder had discussed no such feelings with him.

column3: Holder Faces New Round of Criticism After Leak Inquiries
column4: Rather, Mr. Weingarten said, the disclosure to Fox News of the existence of a rare intelligence source in North Korea was “a horrible leak and he was charged with the responsibility to get at it.” That raised what he said Mr. Holder described to him as a trade-off between press freedoms and the need to identify leakers — a problem for which there are no easy answers because it pits “two laudable goals” against each other.

column3: Holder Faces New Round of Criticism After Leak Inquiries
column4: “He’s not immune from the criticism, but I think he sees this First Amendment-security conflict as almost impossibly difficult,” Mr. Weingarten said, adding: “He hasn’t confessed or cried to me, that’s for sure.

column3: Holder Faces New Round of Criticism After Leak Inquiries
column4: What I sense in conversations with him is how horribly difficult the dilemma is when you have this situation.

column3: Holder Faces New Round of Criticism After Leak Inquiries
column4: It’s important to get it right, and if we didn’t get it right — and that’s a big if — let’s button up the process now.” Matthew Miller, a friend and former top aide to Mr. Holder, portrayed the attorney general’s proposal to tighten laws and guidelines on when news media records may be obtained as coming out of a realization that one cannot expect law enforcement officials to do anything less than what the rules permit when pursuing a particular case.

column3: Holder Faces New Round of Criticism After Leak Inquiries
column4: Meanwhile, Mr. Holder has invited representatives from several major news organizations to discuss whether and how the Justice Department’s regulations for leak investigations should be modified.

column3: Holder Faces New Round of Criticism After Leak Inquiries
column4: Some news organizations, including The New York Times, declined.

column3: Holder Faces New Round of Criticism After Leak Inquiries
column4: “We will not be attending the session at D.O.J.,” said Jill Abramson, its executive editor.

column3: Holder Faces New Round of Criticism After Leak Inquiries
column4: “It isn’t appropriate for us to attend an off-the-record meeting with the attorney general.

column3: Holder Faces New Round of Criticism After Leak Inquiries
column4: Our Washington bureau is aggressively covering the department’s handling of leak investigations at this time.

column3: Holder Faces New Round of Criticism After Leak Inquiries
column4: Evidently, there will be a future session with department officials on the substance of how the law should be applied in leak cases and I am hopeful that our counsel, David McCraw, will be able to participate.” However, Martin Baron, the executive editor of The Washington Post, said that while he would prefer the meeting be on the record, he would go “in order to represent our interests as journalists and to raise our concerns.

column3: Holder Faces New Round of Criticism After Leak Inquiries
column4: I’ll also listen to what the attorney general has to say.

column3: Holder Faces New Round of Criticism After Leak Inquiries
column4: I trust that our journalists will report on this as vigorously as they would any other subject.” A representative of The Associated Press said the executive editor, Kathleen Carroll, would attend only if the session was on the record.

column3: Holder Faces New Round of Criticism After Leak Inquiries
column4: Mr. Holder at first appeared to sidestep the furor over leaks.

column3: Holder Faces New Round of Criticism After Leak Inquiries
column4: It began on May 13 with a disclosure by The Associated Press that the Justice Department had obtained calling logs for its reporters’ phone lines in connection with a 2012 leak involving a foiled bomb plot in Yemen.

column3: Holder Faces New Round of Criticism After Leak Inquiries
column4: The subpoena was controversial because the department did not provide any advance notice to The A.P., which would have allowed it to negotiate or challenge it in court.

column3: Holder Faces New Round of Criticism After Leak Inquiries
column4: But Mr. Holder quickly revealed that he had recused himself from overseeing that investigation and so it was his deputy, James M. Cole, who had approved the subpoena.

column3: Holder Faces New Round of Criticism After Leak Inquiries
column4: In testimony on May 15, Mr. Holder also distanced himself from the notion that reporters who write about national security secrets should be indicted under the Espionage Act, saying: “With regard to the potential prosecution of the press for the disclosure of material, that is not something that I’ve ever been involved in, heard of or would think would be a wise policy.” Since then, however, a 2010 search warrant for e-mails of Mr. Rosen, the Fox News reporter, came to light in connection with a leak investigation into a State Department analyst.

column3: Holder Faces New Round of Criticism After Leak Inquiries
column4: An affidavit says there was probable cause to believe Mr. Rosen had violated the Espionage Act.

column3: Holder Faces New Round of Criticism After Leak Inquiries
column4: Mr. Holder approved the warrant.

column3: Holder Faces New Round of Criticism After Leak Inquiries
column4: Law enforcement officials said the affidavit included that language to invoke an exception to a law that otherwise bars search warrants for reporters’ work product, and noted that while the analyst accused of leaking, Stephen Kim, was indicted in August 2010, Mr. Rosen was not charged.

column3: Holder Faces New Round of Criticism After Leak Inquiries
column4: On Wednesday, a Justice Department official said that Mr. Holder’s “testimony concerning the potential prosecution of the press was consistent with the underlying facts with respect to the investigation and ultimate prosecution of Mr. Kim.”

column3: Holder runs into roadblocks on off-the-record meetings with news organizations
column4: Fox News joined several other major media outlets Thursday in refusing to send a representative to a meeting with Attorney General Eric Holder on the department's surveillance of reporters if Holder continues to insist that the session be off the record.

column3: Holder runs into roadblocks on off-the-record meetings with news organizations
column4: Michael Clemente, Fox News' executive vice president, decided that Fox News will not attend the off-record talks.

column3: Holder runs into roadblocks on off-the-record meetings with news organizations
column4: Fox News had been invited to a Friday session at the Department of Justice headquarters in Washington.

column3: Holder runs into roadblocks on off-the-record meetings with news organizations
column4: With the decision, the two news outlets known to have been targeted by the Justice Department for surveillance -- the other being the Associated Press -- are now declining to participate in the first phase of Holder's internal review over the controversy.

column3: Holder runs into roadblocks on off-the-record meetings with news organizations
column4: Several other outlets are also refusing to attend.

column3: Holder runs into roadblocks on off-the-record meetings with news organizations
column4: Both the Associated Press and Fox News had their phone records pulled by the Justice Department, in the course of two separate leak investigations.

column3: Holder runs into roadblocks on off-the-record meetings with news organizations
column4: The department went a step further in the Fox News case, seizing the personal emails of correspondent James Rosen, while accusing him of being a criminal "co-conspirator" in the application for the search warrant.

column3: Holder runs into roadblocks on off-the-record meetings with news organizations
column4: Holder, who agreed to conduct a review of DOJ guidelines over investigations that involve journalists, had set up meetings with members of the media for Thursday and Friday.

column3: Holder runs into roadblocks on off-the-record meetings with news organizations
column4: He ran into immediate resistance, though, after calling for the meetings to be off the record, meaning the discussions would not be reportable.

column3: Holder runs into roadblocks on off-the-record meetings with news organizations

column4: She said AP expects its attorneys to be included in any planned meetings between the attorney general's office and media lawyers on the legal specifics.

column3: Holder runs into roadblocks on off-the-record meetings with news organizations
column4: Our Washington bureau is aggressively covering the department's handling of leak investigations at this time."

column4: The Huffington Post also announced it would not attend the meeting at DOJ headquarters.

column4: CNN similarly said it would not attend an off-record meeting, but would agree to go if the attorney general made the session on the record.

column4: We would be willing to consider an on-the-record discussion," CBS News spokeswoman Sonya McNair said.

column3: Holder runs into roadblocks on off-the-record meetings with news organizations
column4: Politico's editor-in-chief, John Harris, though, did attend Thursday's session, as did representatives from the Washington Post, New Yorker, Wall Street Journal and New York Daily News.

column4: ABC News also announced that they would attend, but would press for the meeting to be held on the record.

column3: Holder runs into roadblocks on off-the-record meetings with news organizations
column4: The planned meetings are to take place over the coming weeks.

column3: Holder runs into roadblocks on off-the-record meetings with news organizations
column4: The department said Holder plans to engage with news media organizations, including print media, wire services, radio, television, online media and news and trade associations.

column3: Holder runs into roadblocks on off-the-record meetings with news organizations
column4: Discussions are to include news media executives and general counsels as well as government experts in intelligence and investigative agencies.

column3: Holder runs into roadblocks on off-the-record meetings with news organizations
column4: The meetings come as Holder faces intense scrutiny from lawmakers over his May 15 testimony in which he claimed to be unaware of any "potential prosecution" of the press, despite knowing about the investigation that targeted Fox News' James Rosen.

column4: House Judiciary Committee Chairman Rep. Bob Goodlatte, R-Va., and Rep. James Sensenbrenner, Jr., R-Wis., voiced "great concern" in a letter to Holder on Wednesday, asking a number of questions about the department's dealings with the press, and alleging that the Fox News case "contradicts" his testimony at the hearing two weeks ago.

column3: Holder runs into roadblocks on off-the-record meetings with news organizations
column4: The committee confirmed earlier this week it was looking into Holder's testimony.

column3: Holder runs into roadblocks on off-the-record meetings with news organizations
column4: Appearing before the House Judiciary Committee, Holder insisted that "the potential prosecution of the press for the disclosure of material" is not something he was involved in or knew about.

column3: Holder runs into roadblocks on off-the-record meetings with news organizations
column4: It emerged days later that the Justice Department obtained access to Rosen's emails -- after filing an affidavit that accused him of being a likely criminal "co-conspirator" in the leak of sensitive material regarding North Korea.

column4: Rosen was never charged, and never prosecuted.

column4: But he was effectively accused of violating the federal Espionage Act.

column3: Holder runs into roadblocks on off-the-record meetings with news organizations
column4: "At no time during the leak case ... before or after the FBI sought the search warrant, have prosecutors sought approval to bring criminal charges against the reporter," the official said.

column4: White House Press Secretary Jay Carney said on Wednesday that it appears Holder testified truthfully.

column3: Obamacare Reminder: Even If You Like Your Plan, You Can't Necessarily Keep It
column4: Let's begin with a verbatim quote from President Obama from July of 2009, touting the legislative perfection that would be Obamacare: “If you like your doctor, you will be able to keep your doctor.

column3: Obamacare Reminder: Even If You Like Your Plan, You Can't Necessarily Keep It
column4: Period.

column3: Obamacare Reminder: Even If You Like Your Plan, You Can't Necessarily Keep It
column4: If you like your health care plan, you will be able to keep your health care plan.

column3: Obamacare Reminder: Even If You Like Your Plan, You Can't Necessarily Keep It
column4: Period.

column3: Obamacare Reminder: Even If You Like Your Plan, You Can't Necessarily Keep It
column4: No one will take it away.

column3: Obamacare Reminder: Even If You Like Your Plan, You Can't Necessarily Keep It
column4: No matter what.” Many people who buy their own health insurance could get surprises in the mail this fall: cancellation notices because their current policies aren't up to the basic standards of President Barack Obama's health care law.

column3: Obamacare Reminder: Even If You Like Your Plan, You Can't Necessarily Keep It
column4: They, and some small businesses, will have to find replacement plans — and that has some state insurance officials worried about consumer confusion.

column3: Obamacare Reminder: Even If You Like Your Plan, You Can't Necessarily Keep It
column4: Also, it doesn't seem to square with one of the president's best known promises about his health care overhaul: "If you like your health care plan, you'll be able to keep your health care plan."

column3: Obamacare Reminder: Even If You Like Your Plan, You Can't Necessarily Keep It
Obamacare Reminder: Even If You Like Your Plan, You Can't Necessarily Keep It
column4: The Obama administration did not respond directly to questions about the potential fallout from cancellation notices ... For the most part, state insurance commissioners are giving insurers the option of canceling existing plans or changing them to comply with new federal requirements.

column3: Obamacare Reminder: Even If You Like Your Plan, You Can't Necessarily Keep It
column4: A document circulated to House Democrats by Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi — and obtained by BuzzFeed — offers some details of the timing of the health-care plan: Rates and details of plans will become public in September for the 34 states that haven’t put together their own plans.

column3: Obamacare Reminder: Even If You Like Your Plan, You Can't Necessarily Keep It
column4: The goals, Pelosi writes in a “dear colleague” letter that begins the document, are “to educate our constituents about the new law, help to implement it, and strengthen the hands of those who have worked for this historic reform.”

column3: The Obamacare Shock
column4: The Affordable Care Act, a k a Obamacare, goes fully into effect at the beginning of next year, and predictions of disaster are being heard far and wide.

column3: The Obamacare Shock
column4: There will be an administrative “train wreck,” we’re told; consumers will face a terrible shock.

column3: The Obamacare Shock
column4: Republicans, one hears, are already counting on the law’s troubles to give them a big electoral advantage.

column3: The Obamacare Shock
column4: No doubt there will be problems, as there are with any large new government initiative, and in this case, we have the added complication that many Republican governors and legislators are doing all they can to sabotage reform.

column3: The Obamacare Shock
column4: Yet important new evidence — especially from California, the law’s most important test case — suggests that the real Obamacare shock will be one of unexpected success.

column3: The Obamacare Shock
column4: Before I can explain what the news means, I need to make a crucial point: Obamacare is a deeply conservative reform, not in a political sense (although it was originally a Republican proposal) but in terms of leaving most people’s health care unaffected.

column3: The Obamacare Shock
column4: Americans who receive health insurance from their employers, Medicare or Medicaid — which is to say, the vast majority of those who have any kind of health insurance at all — will see almost no changes when the law goes into effect.

column3: The Obamacare Shock
column4: There are, however, millions of Americans who don’t receive insurance either from their employers or from government programs.

column3: The Obamacare Shock
column4: They can get insurance only by buying it on their own, and many of them are effectively shut out of that market.

column3: The Obamacare Shock
column4: In some states, like California, insurers reject applicants with past medical problems.

column3: The Obamacare Shock
column4: In others, like New York, insurers can’t reject applicants, and must offer similar coverage regardless of personal medical history (“community rating”); unfortunately, this leads to a situation in which premiums are very high because only those with current health problems sign up, while healthy people take the risk of going uninsured.

column3: The Obamacare Shock
column4: Obamacare closes this gap with a three-part approach.

column3: The Obamacare Shock
column4: First, community rating everywhere — no more exclusion based on pre-existing conditions.

column3: The Obamacare Shock
column4: Second, the “mandate” — you must buy insurance even if you’re currently healthy.

column3: The Obamacare Shock
column4: Third, subsidies to make insurance affordable for those with lower incomes.

column3: The Obamacare Shock
column4: Massachusetts has had essentially this system since 2006; as a result, nearly all residents have health insurance, and the program remains very popular.

column3: The Obamacare Shock
column4: So we know that Obamacare — or, as some of us call it, ObamaRomneyCare — can work.

column3: The Obamacare Shock
column4: Skeptics argued, however, that Massachusetts was special: it had relatively few uninsured residents even before the reform, and it already had community rating.

column3: The Obamacare Shock
column4: What would happen elsewhere?

column3: The Obamacare Shock
column4: In particular, what would happen in California, where more than a fifth of the nonelderly population is uninsured, and the individual insurance market is largely unregulated?

column3: The Obamacare Shock
column4: Would there be “sticker shock” as the price of individual policies soared?

column3: The Obamacare Shock
column4: Well, the California bids are in — that is, insurers have submitted the prices at which they are willing to offer coverage on the state’s newly created Obamacare exchange.

column3: The Obamacare Shock
column4: And the prices, it turns out, are surprisingly low.

column3: The Obamacare Shock
column4: A handful of healthy people may find themselves paying more for coverage, but it looks as if Obamacare’s first year in California is going to be an overwhelmingly positive experience.

column3: The Obamacare Shock
column4: What can still go wrong?

column3: The Obamacare Shock
column4: Well, Obamacare is a complicated program, basically because simpler options, like Medicare for all, weren’t considered politically feasible.

column3: The Obamacare Shock
column4: So there will probably be a lot of administrative confusion as the law goes into effect, again especially in states where Republicans have been doing their best to sabotage the process.

column3: The Obamacare Shock
column4: Also, some people are too poor to afford coverage even with the subsidies.

column3: The Obamacare Shock
column4: These Americans were supposed to be covered by a federally financed expansion of Medicaid, but in states where Republicans have blocked Medicaid expansion, such unfortunates will be left out in the cold.

column3: The Obamacare Shock
column4: Still, here’s what it seems is about to happen: millions of Americans will suddenly gain health coverage, and millions more will feel much more secure knowing that such coverage is available if they lose their jobs or suffer other misfortunes.

column3: The Obamacare Shock
column4: Only a relative handful of people will be hurt at all.

column3: The Obamacare Shock
column4: And as contrasts emerge between the experience of states like California that are making the most of the new policy and that of states like Texas whose politicians are doing their best to undermine it, the sheer meanspiritedness of the Obamacare opponents will become ever more obvious.

column3: The Obamacare Shock
column4: So yes, it does look as if there’s an Obamacare shock coming: the shock of learning that a public program designed to help a lot of people can, strange to say, end up helping a lot of people — especially when government officials actually try to make it work.

column3: Michele Bachmann retiring under fire
column4: Updated 05/29/2013 10:47 PM EDT Rep. Michele Bachmann (R-Minn.) — the tea-party firebrand facing investigations and a daunting reelection race — abruptly announced on Wednesday morning that she will not seek reelection to a fifth term.

column3: Michele Bachmann retiring under fire
column4: Her move marked a spectacular fall for a congresswoman with a bull’s eye on her back every congressional cycle: Less than two years ago, she won the Iowa straw poll and was briefly regarded as a serious contender for the GOP presidential nomination.

column3: Michele Bachmann retiring under fire
column4: Story Continued Below Bachmann, 57, who took office in 2007, said in a video posted on her website: “My good friends: After a great deal of thought and deliberation, I have decided next year I will not seek a fifth congressional term to represent the wonderful people of the Sixth District of Minnesota.

column3: Michele Bachmann retiring under fire
column4: After serious consideration, I am confident that this is the right decision.” ( PHOTOS: Michele Bachmann’s most controversial quotes) The congresswoman added on the eight-and-a-half-minute video: “[T]he law limits anyone from serving as president of the United States for more than eight years.

column3: Michele Bachmann retiring under fire
column4: And in my opinion, well, eight years is also long enough for any individual to serve as a representative for a specific congressional district.” With Bachmann’s departure, the tea party’s voice in Congress will dim.

column3: Michele Bachmann retiring under fire
column4: She is the movement’s third big-name figure in recent months to leave Congress — Jim DeMint of South Carolina resigned from the Senate in January to take over the Heritage Foundation.

column3: Michele Bachmann retiring under fire
column4: And in November, Florida Rep. Allen West, another conservative bomb thrower, lost reelection.

column3: Michele Bachmann retiring under fire
column4: Ironically, the retirement may improve Republicans’ chances of holding Minnesota’s conservative 6th Congressional District, which broke for Mitt Romney by nearly 15 percentage points in 2012.

column3: Michele Bachmann retiring under fire
column4: Democrats had Bachmann at the top of their target list after she barely survived reelection last year.

column3: Michele Bachmann retiring under fire
column4: The Democrat who came close to defeating her, Jim Graves, was gearing up for a rematch.

column3: Michele Bachmann retiring under fire
column4: ( Also on POLITICO: Carville on Bachmann: 'Sad day') Bachmann’s decision comes as she faces a  growing swirl of investigations into her campaign finances, with the The Federal Election Commission and the Office of Congressional Ethics opening investigations into whether her campaign concealed payments to an Iowa state senator who did work for her 2012 presidential bid.

column3: Michele Bachmann retiring under fire
column4: Last week, the FBI reportedly joined the inquiry.

column3: Michele Bachmann retiring under fire
column4: In Graves, she was up against an opponent who came within 5,000 votes — or 1.2 percent points — of unseating her last November.

column3: Michele Bachmann retiring under fire
column4: Graves, a wealthy hotel company executive who poured $250,000 of his own funds into the 2012 contest, released a poll last week showing him with a narrow lead over the congresswoman.

column3: Michele Bachmann retiring under fire
column4: The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, which provided Graves with little help in 2012, had indicated that it planned to get behind the challenger aggressively in Round Two.

column3: Michele Bachmann retiring under fire
column4: Though Bachmann would have had an enormous war chest, the defeat of West — another tea party hero with a national following and big money — showed that such figures are not invincible.

column3: Michele Bachmann retiring under fire
column4: ( PHOTOS: Michele Bachmann’s career) Potential Republican candidates for the seat include state Reps. Tim Sanders and Matt Dean, state Sen. Michelle Fischbach, and St.

column4: Cloud Mayor Dave Kleis.

column3: Michele Bachmann retiring under fire
column4: In the video released Wednesday morning, Bachmann insisted that her decision to not seek reelection had nothing to do with the Graves challenge, nor from the investigations.

column3: Michele Bachmann retiring under fire
column4: Bachmann aides have repeatedly said the congresswoman has done nothing improper.

column3: Michele Bachmann retiring under fire
column4: “Be assured: My decision was not in any way influenced by any concerns about my being reelected to Congress.

column3: Michele Bachmann retiring under fire
column4: … I have every confidence that if I ran, I would again defeat the individual who I defeated last year, who recently announced he is once again running.

column3: Rep. Michele Bachmann won't seek re-election to House
column4: For a few weeks in 2011, Rep. Michele Bachmann was on top of the GOP, having chased Minnesota Gov.

column3: Rep. Michele Bachmann won't seek re-election to House
column4: Tim Pawlenty from the GOP presidential field and racing to the front of the pack.

column3: Rep. Michele Bachmann won't seek re-election to House
column4: But Mrs. Bachmann eventually came crashing back down to earth and on Wednesday she announced that she would not seek re-election to Congress — ending an astonishing political career that captured the roiling politics of the last four years.

column3: Rep. Michele Bachmann won't seek re-election to House
column4: “I think it is a mistake to see her as simply a kind of fleeting figure,” said Larry Jacobs, political science professor at the University of Minnesota.

column4: “She reflects an era and a kind of moment in American politics that shows the tensions with the Republican Party between Liberty Republicans and more establishment Republicans willing to compromise.

column3: Rep. Michele Bachmann won't seek re-election to House
column4: “It also shows the limits and the inability of the tea party to find a popular platform that could win majorities, and that is what happened to Michelle Bachmann.” Mrs. Bachmann announced her decision via an eight-minute video on her campaign website, saying she wasn’t swayed by polls showing her in a tight re-match race in 2014 against Democrat Jim Graves, who she narrowly defeated just six months ago.

column3: Rep. Michele Bachmann won't seek re-election to House
column4: “I have every confidence that if I ran, I would again defeat the individual who I defeated last year, who recently announced he is once again running,” she said in her video.

column3: Rep. Michele Bachmann won't seek re-election to House
column4: The Tea Party Express, which bills itself as the nation’s largest tea party political action committee, praised Mrs. Bachmann, 57, as “strong advocate” for the grass-roots movement’s push for “fiscal responsibility and limited government.” The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, meanwhile, said that the “Tea Party brand of extremism and obstruction have infected the entire Republican Congress, and her influence shows no signs of waning.” A proud social conservative, Mrs. Bachmann made an immediate splash in the GOP presidential race by winning the Iowa straw poll in the summer of 2011, boosting her as the conservative alternative to former Massachusetts Gov.

column3: Rep. Michele Bachmann won't seek re-election to House
column4: Mitt Romney.

column3: Rep. Michele Bachmann won't seek re-election to House
column4: Six months later, though, voters had turned.

column3: Rep. Michele Bachmann won't seek re-election to House
column4: She placed sixth in the Iowa caucuses and dropped out of the race with her campaign more than $1 million in debt.

column3: Rep. Michele Bachmann won't seek re-election to House
column4: “Electability is always an important issue to caucusgoers in both parties and she had difficulty passing that threshold,” said David Yepsen, director of the Paul Simon Public Policy Institute at Southern Illinois.

column3: Rep. Michele Bachmann won't seek re-election to House
column4: Mrs. Bachmann instead ran for her House seat again, winning re-election but keeping a lower profile on Capitol Hill, where she has been dogged by investigations into whether her presidential campaign violated finance laws.

column3: Rep. Michele Bachmann won't seek re-election to House
column4: But in recent days she had shown signs of getting her grove back.

column4: Last month, she revived the House Tea Party Caucus, and she also led a news conference this month protesting the IRS’s treatment of conservative groups — an event that drew Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, Kentucky Republican.

column3: Rep. Michele Bachmann won't seek re-election to House
column4: That same day she also saw the House pass her bill to repeal “Obamacare,” and had begun running campaign ads touting the vote.

column3: Rep. Michele Bachmann won't seek re-election to House
column4: Mr. Jacobs said that the timing of Mrs. Bachmann’s announcement suggests there could be more bad news to come for the congresswoman.

column3: Rep. Michele Bachmann won't seek re-election to House
column4: “There was every sign of a Bachmann revival effort and to all of a sudden pull the plug on running re-election after putting in the time and money and making the political commitment, tells me that there is another shoe to drop,” Mr. Jacobs said.

column3: Rep. Michele Bachmann won't seek re-election to House
column4: William McGinley, the lawyer representing Mrs. Bachmann, has said that she will be cleared of any wrongdoing.

column3: Rep. Michele Bachmann won't seek re-election to House

column3: John McCain in Syria, meets rebels
column4: Updated 05/28/2013 07:58 AM EDT Sen. John McCain, one of the Senate’s loudest voices for further intervention in Syria, snuck into the country and met with rebel leaders Monday, his office confirmed to POLITICO.

column3: John McCain in Syria, meets rebels
column4: The Arizona Republican made the trip from Turkey into Syria alongside Gen. Salam Idris, according to The Daily Beast, which first reported McCain’s visit.

column3: John McCain in Syria, meets rebels
column4: Idris leads the Supreme Military Council of the Free Syrian Army and accompanied McCain as they met with rebel leaders from throughout the country.

column4: McCain’s visit, which lasted several hours, is the first by a U.S. official since Ambassador to Syria Robert Ford visited earlier this month.

column3: John McCain in Syria, meets rebels

column3: John McCain in Syria, meets rebels
column4: “We need American help to have change on the ground; we are now in a very critical situation.” The Obama administration has been hesitant to get more involved in the Syrian conflict, which has claimed 70,000 lives so far.

column3: John McCain in Syria, meets rebels

column3: McCain sneaks across border, visits Syrian rebels

column3: McCain sneaks across border, visits Syrian rebels

column3: McCain sneaks across border, visits Syrian rebels

column3: Republicans see 'Obamacare' debacle as key to 2014
column4: WASHINGTON (AP) — If Republicans were writing a movie script for next year's congressional elections, the working title might be "2014: Apocalypse of Obamacare."

column3: Republicans see 'Obamacare' debacle as key to 2014
column4: The plot: The rollout of President Barack Obama's health care law turns into such a disaster that enraged voters rebuke him by rewarding the GOP with undisputed control of Congress.

column3: Republicans see 'Obamacare' debacle as key to 2014
column4: But there's a risk for Republicans if they're wrong and the Affordable Care Act works reasonably well, particularly in states that have embraced it.

column3: Republicans see 'Obamacare' debacle as key to 2014
column4: Republicans might be seen as obstinately standing in the way of progress.

column3: Republicans see 'Obamacare' debacle as key to 2014
column4: The law already has been a political prop in two election seasons, but next year will be different.

column3: Republicans see 'Obamacare' debacle as key to 2014
column4: Voters will have a real program to judge, working or dysfunctional.

column3: Republicans see 'Obamacare' debacle as key to 2014
column4: Will affordable health care finally be a reality for millions of uninsured working people?

column3: Republicans see 'Obamacare' debacle as key to 2014
column4: Or will premiums skyrocket as the heavy hand of government upends already fragile insurance markets for small businesses and individuals?

column3: Republicans see 'Obamacare' debacle as key to 2014
column4: "The end of this movie has not been written," said Robert Blendon, a Harvard professor who tracks public opinion on health care.

column3: Republicans see 'Obamacare' debacle as key to 2014
column4: He says next year's movie actually will be a documentary: what happens in states that fully put the law in place and those that resist — "a message of reality."

column3: Republicans see 'Obamacare' debacle as key to 2014
column4: One of the most prominent doomsayers is Senate Republican leader Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, who predicts "Obamacare" probably will be the biggest issue of 2014 and "an albatross around the neck of every Democrat who voted for it."

column3: Republicans see 'Obamacare' debacle as key to 2014
column4: "This thing can't possibly work," says McConnell.

column3: Republicans see 'Obamacare' debacle as key to 2014
column4: "It will be a huge disaster in 2014."

column3: Republicans see 'Obamacare' debacle as key to 2014
column4: Counting on that, House Republicans are busy framing an election narrative, voting to repeal the health law and trying to link it to the scandal over the Internal Revenue Service's targeting of tea party groups.

column3: Republicans see 'Obamacare' debacle as key to 2014
column4: It could help excite the conservative base.

column3: Republicans see 'Obamacare' debacle as key to 2014
column4: But Democratic pollster Celinda Lake doubts reality will follow the GOP script.

column3: Republicans see 'Obamacare' debacle as key to 2014
column4: Next year, "we won't have to worry about the mythology laid out by the right wing about Obamacare: death panels and dramatic cuts to Medicare," she said.

column3: Republicans see 'Obamacare' debacle as key to 2014
column4: Sen. Patty Murray, D-Wash., said uninsured people in her state will have over 200 coverage options to choose from.

column3: Republicans see 'Obamacare' debacle as key to 2014
column4: "We have been hearing the fear, but in states like mine, people are seeing the reality," she said.

column3: Republicans see 'Obamacare' debacle as key to 2014
column4: In just about five months, people without access to coverage through their jobs can start shopping for subsidized private insurance in new state markets.

column3: Republicans see 'Obamacare' debacle as key to 2014

column3: America's female soldiers: Bravely serving and dying in the line of duty
column4: Brittany Gordon was a 24-year-old Army intelligence analyst when an Afghan suicide bomber detonated an explosive vest under his military uniform in Kandahar province, killing her instantly and adding her name to the growing ranks of female American service members killed in the line of duty.

column3: America's female soldiers: Bravely serving and dying in the line of duty
column4: Gordon, of St. Petersburg, Fla., died Oct. 13, 2012, along with five others, when a delegation including U.S. coalition members was delivering furniture to an intelligence office in a remote area of Kandahar.

column3: America's female soldiers: Bravely serving and dying in the line of duty
column4: She was on her first deployment to Afghanistan and had volunteered for the mission that ended in her death.

column3: America's female soldiers: Bravely serving and dying in the line of duty
column4: “Brittany had a contagious passion for helping and protecting those less fortunate than she,” her mother, Brenda Thompson Gordon, told FoxNews.com.

column3: America's female soldiers: Bravely serving and dying in the line of duty
column4: “Not only was her contribution to protect the freedom that we enjoy, but it was to empower women to lead and have confidence in themselves.

column3: America's female soldiers: Bravely serving and dying in the line of duty
column4: “She was very special.

column3: America's female soldiers: Bravely serving and dying in the line of duty
column4: I am so proud of her,” Gordon said.

column3: America's female soldiers: Bravely serving and dying in the line of duty
column4: “She led by example with a cheerful confidence.

column3: America's female soldiers: Bravely serving and dying in the line of duty
column4: There are givers and there are takers and she was definitely a giver.

column3: America's female soldiers: Bravely serving and dying in the line of duty
column4: She volunteered for this.

column3: America's female soldiers: Bravely serving and dying in the line of duty
column4: “She was my only child,” she added, fighting back tears.

column3: America's female soldiers: Bravely serving and dying in the line of duty
column4: “The hardest part is when you put everything into one child and it’s all gone.” Gordon was one of 44 U.S. servicewomen killed in Afghanistan since the conflict began there in 2001.

column3: America's female soldiers: Bravely serving and dying in the line of duty
column4: Another 335 female soldiers have been wounded.

column3: America's female soldiers: Bravely serving and dying in the line of duty
column4: [pullquote] The number of female casualties has risen as more women, like Gordon, join the U.S. military in combat roles alongside their male counterparts.

column3: America's female soldiers: Bravely serving and dying in the line of duty
column4: According to the U.S. government, 110 female U.S. soldiers died in Iraq and another 636 were wounded.

column3: America's female soldiers: Bravely serving and dying in the line of duty
column4: Fifteen were killed in the Persian Gulf War, which began in 1990.

column3: America's female soldiers: Bravely serving and dying in the line of duty
column4: Eight women were killed in the Vietnam War, two in the Korean War, 543 in World War II and 359 in World War I – although all those women served in non-combat roles, mostly as nurses assisting soldiers in battlefields.

column3: America's female soldiers: Bravely serving and dying in the line of duty
column4: Women were first allowed to serve in non-combat positions in 1901.

column3: America's female soldiers: Bravely serving and dying in the line of duty
column4: It was almost a century later, in the early 1990s, that they were allowed to enter combat units.

column3: America's female soldiers: Bravely serving and dying in the line of duty
column4: But they were restricted from the front lines after the Pentagon ruled they could not serve in artillery, armor, infantry and other similar roles.

column3: America's female soldiers: Bravely serving and dying in the line of duty
column4: That ban, however, was overturned in January 2013, when the Defense Department announced women were now permitted to serve in front-line combat positions.

column3: America's female soldiers: Bravely serving and dying in the line of duty
column4: While it took centuries for the U.S. government to formally approve women in combat roles, females have served unofficially on the battlefield since the American Revolution.

column3: America's female soldiers: Bravely serving and dying in the line of duty
column4: Margaret Corbin assisted her husband, artilleryman John Corbin, and 600 American troops in defending Fort Washington in Northern Manhattan from a fleet of British soldiers on Nov. 16, 1776.

column3: America's female soldiers: Bravely serving and dying in the line of duty
column4: When her husband was fatally wounded, Corbin took over and fired his cannon from the top of a ridge, today known as Fort Tryon.

column3: America's female soldiers: Bravely serving and dying in the line of duty
column4: Corbin, who was severely wounded in the battle, later became the first woman in American history to receive a pension from Congress for her service in the military.

column3: America's female soldiers: Bravely serving and dying in the line of duty
column4: Cristina Corbin is a Fox News reporter based in New York.

column3: America's female soldiers: Bravely serving and dying in the line of duty

column3: Hagel: Cadets must stamp out sex assault 'scourge'
column4: WEST POINT, N.Y. –  Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel told cadets at the U.S. Military Academy at West Point on Saturday that they must stamp out the “scourge” of sexual assault in the military.

column3: Hagel: Cadets must stamp out sex assault 'scourge'
column4: A day after President Barack Obama delivered a similar edict to U.S.

column3: Hagel: Cadets must stamp out sex assault 'scourge'
column4: Naval Academy graduates, Hagel's message comes amid a series of widespread incidents of sexual misconduct across the armed services in recent months and a new report showing that the problem is growing.

column3: Hagel: Cadets must stamp out sex assault 'scourge'
column4: The challenge is particularly poignant for the West Point crowd, since earlier in the week an Army sergeant was charged with secretly photographing and videotaping at least a dozen women at the upper New York state academy, including in a bathroom.

column3: Hagel: Cadets must stamp out sex assault 'scourge'
column4: "Sexual harassment and sexual assault in the military are a profound betrayal — a profound betrayal — of sacred oaths and sacred trusts," Hagel told 1,007 graduating cadets during a cold, rainy outdoor ceremony.

column3: Hagel: Cadets must stamp out sex assault 'scourge'
column4: "This scourge must be stamped out.

column3: Hagel: Cadets must stamp out sex assault 'scourge'
column4: We are all accountable and responsible for ensuring that this happens.

column3: Hagel: Cadets must stamp out sex assault 'scourge'
column4: We cannot fail the Army or America.

column3: Hagel: Cadets must stamp out sex assault 'scourge'
column4: We cannot fail each other and we cannot fail the men and women that we lead."

column3: Hagel: Cadets must stamp out sex assault 'scourge'
column4: Hagel, who served in the Army in Vietnam, took the opportunity to reflect on his own time in uniform and the lessons that he said must resonate as the soldiers take on the job of helping to transform the military.

column3: Hagel: Cadets must stamp out sex assault 'scourge'
column4: It was his first graduation address as defense chief.

column3: Hagel: Cadets must stamp out sex assault 'scourge'
column4: The graduates, he said, must be the generation of leaders who will stop the debilitating and insidious threats of suicide, sexual assault and drug and alcohol abuse that are hurting the all-volunteer force.

column3: Hagel: Cadets must stamp out sex assault 'scourge'
column4: Wounded twice during his roughly one year at war, Hagel has two Purple Hearts and is the first man to become secretary of defense after serving only in the enlisted corps.

column3: Hagel: Cadets must stamp out sex assault 'scourge'
column4: Reflecting on his military service, Hagel said his time in the Army shaped him forever.

column3: Hagel: Cadets must stamp out sex assault 'scourge'
column4: "In Vietnam, I learned that combat is a furnace that can consume you, or it can forge you into something better and stronger than you were before," said Hagel, who took over the job as Pentagon chief at the end of February.

column3: Hagel: Cadets must stamp out sex assault 'scourge'
column4: He also told the graduates that they must begin to build the future Army as the service recovers from the strains of more than a decade of war in Iraq and Afghanistan.

column3: Hagel: Cadets must stamp out sex assault 'scourge'
column4: Future conflicts, he said, will take on new and unfamiliar forms, and the military must be ready to face them even as budget cuts force the service to curtail training and trim the number of soldiers from a wartime high of about 570,000 to 490,000.

column3: Hagel: Cadets must stamp out sex assault 'scourge'
column4: But he said that readiness will be strained by health and social problems.

column3: Hagel: Cadets must stamp out sex assault 'scourge'
column4: Pentagon leaders have been struggling to deal with what they have come to call an epidemic of sexual assaults in the military.

column3: Hagel: Cadets must stamp out sex assault 'scourge'
column4: A Pentagon report released this month estimated that as many as 26,000 military service members may have been sexually assaulted last year and that thousands of victims are unwilling to come forward despite new oversight and assistance programs.

column3: Hagel: Cadets must stamp out sex assault 'scourge'
column4: The estimate was based largely on anonymous surveys.

column3: Hagel: Cadets must stamp out sex assault 'scourge'
column4: According to the report, the number of sexual assaults actually reported by military service members rose 6 percent to 3,374 in 2012.

column3: Hagel: Cadets must stamp out sex assault 'scourge'
column4: And nearly 800 of those simply sought help but declined to file complaints against their attackers.

column3: Hagel: Cadets must stamp out sex assault 'scourge'
column4: Spurred on by furious Congress members, the Defense Department has ordered the services to come up with ways to curb the problem and better help the victims.

column3: Hagel: Cadets must stamp out sex assault 'scourge'
column4: In the latest case, Sgt.

column3: Hagel: Cadets must stamp out sex assault 'scourge'
column4: 1st Class Michael McClendon is facing charges of dereliction of duty, mistreatment, entering a women's bathroom without notice, and taking and possessing inappropriate photos and videos of at least a dozen women who were naked or in various states of undress.

column3: Hagel: Cadets must stamp out sex assault 'scourge'
column4: The women have been notified by the Army about the matter.

column3: Hagel: Cadets must stamp out sex assault 'scourge'
column4: He was charged May 14 with violating four articles of the Uniform Code of Military Justice, but some of the allegations date back to 2009.

column3: Hagel: Cadets must stamp out sex assault 'scourge'
column4: He has been transferred to Fort Drum, N.Y.

column3: Hagel: Cadets must stamp out sex assault 'scourge'
column4: It isn't immediately clear if McClendon has a lawyer.

column3: Hagel: Cadets must stamp out sex assault 'scourge'
column4: Joint Chiefs of Staff Chairman Martin Dempsey has called the problem a crisis and said the women who serve in the military are losing confidence that it can be solved.
