column3: Obama Speaks to Naval Graduates About Sexual Assault Issue
column4: ANNAPOLIS, Md.

column3: Obama Speaks to Naval Graduates About Sexual Assault Issue
column4: — President Obama used a commencement speech before Naval Academy graduates on Friday to urge them to follow their “inner compass” and to warn that rising numbers of sexual assaults in the military threatened to erode America’s faith in the armed forces.

column3: Obama Speaks to Naval Graduates About Sexual Assault Issue
column4: The president praised the military as the nation’s “most trusted institution,” but took note of the recent cases in which service members have been charged with sexual assault.

column3: Obama Speaks to Naval Graduates About Sexual Assault Issue
column4: He said those people “threaten the trust and discipline which makes our military strong.” “We need your honor, that inner compass that guides you,” the president said, essentially using the platform at Navy-Marine Corps Memorial Stadium to scold those who have strayed from that direction recently.

column3: Obama Speaks to Naval Graduates About Sexual Assault Issue
column4: “Even more than physical courage, we need your moral courage — the strength to do what’s right, even when it’s unpopular.” In his four years in office, Mr. Obama has presided over a military that has often convulsed with change.

column3: Obama Speaks to Naval Graduates About Sexual Assault Issue
column4: He pushed for the end to “don’t ask, don’t tell” so that gay men and lesbians could serve openly.

column3: Obama Speaks to Naval Graduates About Sexual Assault Issue
column4: He has sought to bring an end to both major overseas wars.

column3: Obama Speaks to Naval Graduates About Sexual Assault Issue
column4: And he has watched as the armed forces have grown more diverse.

column3: Obama Speaks to Naval Graduates About Sexual Assault Issue
column4: Of the 1,047 graduates Friday, 206 were women — the most in the history of the academy.

column3: Obama Speaks to Naval Graduates About Sexual Assault Issue
column4: Before the president spoke, under cloudy, drizzly skies, Ray Mabus, the secretary of the Navy, said jokingly that the graduates had completed a journey “you began once you turned down your acceptance to West Point.” It was the second time Mr. Obama had addressed the graduates of the academy, most of whom will receive commissions in the Navy, the Marine Corps or the Air Force, and he was welcomed with enthusiastic cheers as he congratulated them on becoming the military’s latest officers.

column3: Obama Speaks to Naval Graduates About Sexual Assault Issue
column4: He echoed his remarks from a day earlier, telling the graduates that they enter the services at a time of transition in the war against terrorism.

column3: Obama Speaks to Naval Graduates About Sexual Assault Issue
column4: “We still need to conduct precise, targeted strikes against terrorists before they kill our citizens,” he said, noting the end of the Iraq war and next year’s expected end of the American role in Afghanistan.

column3: Obama Speaks to Naval Graduates About Sexual Assault Issue
column4: But he said, “we need to stay ready for the full range of threats.” Mr. Obama affirmed his plans to redefine the way America wages the fight against terrorism.

column3: Obama Speaks to Naval Graduates About Sexual Assault Issue
column4: In a speech at the National Defense University on Thursday, the president said the country needed to continue to attack terrorist cells while getting off the war footing it has been on for more than a decade.

column3: Obama Speaks to Naval Graduates About Sexual Assault Issue
column4: That message is most likely to be of intense interest to the graduates as they prepare for military careers.

column3: Obama Speaks to Naval Graduates About Sexual Assault Issue
column4: Mr. Obama has largely ended the war in Iraq and is winding down American involvement in Afghanistan.

column3: Obama Speaks to Naval Graduates About Sexual Assault Issue
column4: In the four years since the president last spoke at commencement here, the specter of the growing number of sexual assaults in the armed forces gave the speech more of a somber tone.

column3: Obama Speaks to Naval Graduates About Sexual Assault Issue
column4: Mr. Obama said that the episodes threatened to undermine the military’s credibility just as failures of integrity undermine trust in politicians, financial institutions and government workers.

column3: Obama Speaks to Naval Graduates About Sexual Assault Issue
column4: “As we’ve seen again in recent days,” the president said, apparently referring to the actions of officials at the Internal Revenue Service in targeting conservative groups.

column3: Obama Speaks to Naval Graduates About Sexual Assault Issue
column4: “It only takes the misconduct of a few to further erode the people’s trust in their government.” He referred directly to the sexual assaults, saying that “if we want to restore the trust that the American people deserve to have in their institutions, all of us have to do our part.” The issue has become a major concern in the wake of several episodes, some involving military officials who were supposed to be in charge of preventing sexual assaults.

column3: Obama Speaks to Naval Graduates About Sexual Assault Issue
column4: A Pentagon study this month estimated that as many as 26,000 members of the military were sexually assaulted last year.

column3: Obama Speaks to Naval Graduates About Sexual Assault Issue
column4: After summoning his top military officials to the White House this month, Mr. Obama said they told him they were ashamed of the behavior of some in the services.

column3: Obama Speaks to Naval Graduates About Sexual Assault Issue
column4: At a news conference early this month, Mr. Obama expressed impatience with his commanders on the issue.

column3: Obama Speaks to Naval Graduates About Sexual Assault Issue
column4: “I don’t want just more speeches or awareness programs or training but, ultimately, folks look the other way,” Mr. Obama said in an East Room event with Park Geun-hye, the president of South Korea.

column3: Obama Speaks to Naval Graduates About Sexual Assault Issue
column4: “If we find out somebody is engaging in this stuff, they’ve got to be held accountable — prosecuted, stripped of their positions, court-martialed, fired, dishonorably discharged.

column3: Obama Speaks to Naval Graduates About Sexual Assault Issue
column4: Period.

column3: Obama Speaks to Naval Graduates About Sexual Assault Issue
column4: It’s not acceptable.” Concerns about sexual harassment and sexual assault in the military are not new.

column3: Obama Speaks to Naval Graduates About Sexual Assault Issue
column4: In 1991, dozens of women were assaulted by members of the Navy and the Marines at a Las Vegas hotel where the Tailhook Association was having its annual convention.

column3: Obama Speaks to Naval Graduates About Sexual Assault Issue

column3: Amid his own challenges, Obama calls on Navy grads to hold themselves accountable
column4: After some some initial light-hearted comments, the president’s tone became more serious, urging the midshipmen who would become officers by the end of the ceremony, to rely on the high standards they learned at the academy throughout their careers.

column3: Amid his own challenges, Obama calls on Navy grads to hold themselves accountable
column4: He broadly referred to scandals involving bad behavior and poor judgement by servicemen in Afghanistan and Iraq, and more specifically to a recent spike in sexual assaults in the military.

column3: Amid his own challenges, Obama calls on Navy grads to hold themselves accountable

column4: “Those who commit sexual assault,” he said, “are not only committing a crime, they threaten the trust and discipline that makes our military strong.” Many of the midshipmen who became officers Friday will go on to leadership roles in the Navy and Marine Corps, Mr. Obama noted.

column3: Amid his own challenges, Obama calls on Navy grads to hold themselves accountable
column4: “As you go forward in your careers, we need you to carry forth the values that you’ve learned at this institution because our nation needs them now more than ever,” he said.

column3: Amid his own challenges, Obama calls on Navy grads to hold themselves accountable
column4: “Never ask them to do what you don’t ask of yourself,” he said.

column3: Amid his own challenges, Obama calls on Navy grads to hold themselves accountable
column4: “Live with integrity and speak with honesty and take responsibility and demand accountability.” Earlier in his remarks, Mr. Obama commended the midshipmen for their hard work and service over the last four years, he also sprinkled his opening remarks with light-hearted references to off-duty time students have spent at local Annapolis watering holes “To the entire brigade of midshipmen, you embody the highest virtues of this venerable institution,” he said.

column3: Amid his own challenges, Obama calls on Navy grads to hold themselves accountable
column4: “And yet I know that some of you at times have enjoyed yourselves at other local institutions like McGarvey’s and Armadillo’s,” he said to cheers.

column3: Amid his own challenges, Obama calls on Navy grads to hold themselves accountable
column4: “But today is a day of celebration and also forgiveness.

column3: Amid his own challenges, Obama calls on Navy grads to hold themselves accountable
column4: And so in keeping with the tradition, I declare all midshipmen on restriction for minor conduct offense are hereby absolved.”

column3: I.R.S. Official Invokes 5th Amendment at Hearing
column4: WASHINGTON — The Internal Revenue Service official who first disclosed that the agency had targeted conservative groups for special scrutiny, and in doing so ignited a controversy that has ensnared the White House, denied on Wednesday that she had ever provided false information to Congress.

column3: I.R.S. Official Invokes 5th Amendment at Hearing
column4: She then invoked her Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination and declined to testify at a House hearing on the agency’s actions.

column3: I.R.S. Official Invokes 5th Amendment at Hearing
column4: As the official, Lois Lerner, appeared under subpoena before the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform, she sternly told her questioners that accusations that she had misled Congress in previous testimony were false.

column3: I.R.S. Official Invokes 5th Amendment at Hearing
column4: “I have not done anything wrong.

column3: I.R.S. Official Invokes 5th Amendment at Hearing
column4: I have not broken any laws,” said Ms. Lerner, who leads the I.R.S.’s division on tax-exempt organizations.

column3: I.R.S. Official Invokes 5th Amendment at Hearing
column4: “I have not violated any I.R.S.

column3: I.R.S. Official Invokes 5th Amendment at Hearing
column4: rules and regulations, and I have not provided false information to this or any other Congressional committee.” Ms. Lerner has become a person of intense interest to Congressional investigators, who insist that she made, at best, incomplete statements when she said she first learned that her subordinates had singled out Tea Party groups after reading news media reports last year.

column3: I.R.S. Official Invokes 5th Amendment at Hearing
column4: An inspector general’s report found, however, that she was briefed on their actions as early as June 2011.

column3: I.R.S. Official Invokes 5th Amendment at Hearing
column4: After she refused on Wednesday to say anything more to the committee, despite attempts by Representative Darrell Issa of California, the committee’s Republican chairman, to persuade her otherwise, Mr. Issa tried to dismiss her and her lawyer.

column3: I.R.S. Official Invokes 5th Amendment at Hearing
column4: But that upset other Republicans, who said that Ms. Lerner should not be let go so quickly.

column3: I.R.S. Official Invokes 5th Amendment at Hearing
column4: “You don’t get to tell your side of the story and then not be subjected to cross-examination,” said Representative Trey Gowdy of South Carolina.

column3: I.R.S. Official Invokes 5th Amendment at Hearing
column4: “She ought to stand here and answer our questions.” Mr. Issa made a second attempt to persuade her to change her mind.

column3: I.R.S. Official Invokes 5th Amendment at Hearing
column4: But when she declined, he dismissed her again.

column3: I.R.S. Official Invokes 5th Amendment at Hearing
column4: Ms. Lerner then left the hearing room with her lawyer to a whir of camera shutters.

column3: I.R.S. Official Invokes 5th Amendment at Hearing
column4: That exchange set the tone for a contentious hearing that veered into veiled accusations that the White House had a larger role in the controversy than previously disclosed, as well as outright attacks on President Obama’s character.

column3: I.R.S. Official Invokes 5th Amendment at Hearing
column4: Mr. Issa said he reserved the right to recall Ms. Lerner later.

column3: I.R.S. Official Invokes 5th Amendment at Hearing
column4: commissioner; Neal S. Wolin, the deputy secretary of the Treasury Department; and J. Russell George, the Treasury inspector general who looked into the accusations of targeting.

column3: I.R.S. Official Invokes 5th Amendment at Hearing
column4: And as the hearing continued, Republicans and Democrats pressed ahead with one point on which they agree these days: that an inept I.R.S.

column3: I.R.S. Official Invokes 5th Amendment at Hearing

column4: commissioner, on whether he had visited the White House.

column3: I.R.S. Official Invokes 5th Amendment at Hearing

column4: targeting never came up?

column3: I.R.S. Official Invokes 5th Amendment at Hearing

column3: I.R.S. Official Invokes 5th Amendment at Hearing
column4: In follow-up questioning by Representative Gerald E. Connolly, a Virginia Democrat, Mr. Shulman offered what he said was one of the many plausible explanations why he would have visited the White House.

column3: I.R.S. Official Invokes 5th Amendment at Hearing
column4: “The Easter Egg Roll with my kids,” he said.

column3: Obama to defend drone strikes, reignite Gitmo debate in key speech today
column4: U.S. drone strikes have killed four Americans, including one who was “specifically targeted” and three others who were not targets, Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. said in a letter to Congress on Wednesday, publicly confirming the strikes for the first time.

column3: Obama to defend drone strikes, reignite Gitmo debate in key speech today
column4: The revelation was made a day before President Obama lays out a drone policy in a major speech at the National Defense University, where he also is expected to reignite his push to transfer detainees from the detention facility at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, which houses suspected terrorists.

column3: Obama to defend drone strikes, reignite Gitmo debate in key speech today
column4: “He will discuss why the use of drone strikes is necessary, legal and just, while addressing the various issues raised by our use of targeted action,” a White House official said Wednesday night, previewing the remarks on the condition of anonymity.

column3: Obama to defend drone strikes, reignite Gitmo debate in key speech today
column4: SEE ALSO: Rumsfeld: ‘There is clearly going to be a use for drones’ The official also said Mr. Obama has signed guidance laying out the full standards for lethal strikes, and Mr. Holder said in his letter that classified guidance will be provided to some members of Congress.

column3: Obama to defend drone strikes, reignite Gitmo debate in key speech today
column4: After news reports last year revealed the extent of the drone strike program, Mr. Obama promised to seek firmer legal footing for the program by going to Congress with more details, and Wednesday’s letter was the first step in that.

column3: Obama to defend drone strikes, reignite Gitmo debate in key speech today
column4: In the five-page letter, Mr. Holder said the U.S. specifically targeted Anwar al-Awlaki in a September 2011 drone strike in Yemen.

column3: Obama to defend drone strikes, reignite Gitmo debate in key speech today
column4: He also listed the three other Americans who he said had been incidentally killed in strikes: Samir Khan, Jude Kenan Mohammed and Abderrahman Anwar al-Awlaki, the targeted man’s son.

column3: Obama to defend drone strikes, reignite Gitmo debate in key speech today
column4: Mr. Holder called it “an unfortunate but undeniable fact” that Americans had been killed, but said U.S. citizenship doesn’t make someone immune from being targeted.

column3: Obama to defend drone strikes, reignite Gitmo debate in key speech today
column4: The drone executive program has been controversial since it began under President George W. Bush.

column3: Obama to defend drone strikes, reignite Gitmo debate in key speech today
column4: Mr. Obama expanded the program, but use of the strikes has begun to decline.

column3: Obama to defend drone strikes, reignite Gitmo debate in key speech today
column4: The New York Times reported this year that strikes in Pakistan peaked in 2010, and strikes in Yemen this year are half the rate they were last year.

column3: Obama to defend drone strikes, reignite Gitmo debate in key speech today
column4: Still, members of Congress have demanded answers on the program, and Mr. Obama is preparing to give them details of how he decides who is placed on the targeted killing list.

column3: Obama to defend drone strikes, reignite Gitmo debate in key speech today
column4: The administration will send Congress a classified document laying out details this week, and Mr. Obama will provide some public details Thursday.

column3: Obama to defend drone strikes, reignite Gitmo debate in key speech today
column4: In his letter Wednesday, Mr. Holder said the conditions for ending up on the target list are that the executive branch has determined “after a thorough and careful review” that the target poses “an imminent threat of violent attack” against the U.S., that the person cannot be captured, and that the operation falls under acceptable war practices.

column3: Obama to defend drone strikes, reignite Gitmo debate in key speech today
column4: He said al-Awlaki was put on the list because he encouraged and helped the Christmas Day bomber in 2009 and played a key role in an October 2010 plot to detonate explosives on two U.S.-bound cargo planes, including developing and testing the explosive devices.

column3: Obama to defend drone strikes, reignite Gitmo debate in key speech today
column4: “The decision to target Anwar al-Awlaki was lawful, it was considered, and it was just,” the attorney general said, adding that he, other Justice Department attorneys and “other departments and agencies” concluded that al-Awlaki was an appropriate target.

column3: Obama to defend drone strikes, reignite Gitmo debate in key speech today
column4: Mr. Holder said the administration gave “the relevant congressional committees” a heads-up that al-Awlaki was on the kill list in February 2010, more than a year before the fatal strike.

column3: Obama to defend drone strikes, reignite Gitmo debate in key speech today
column4: One of the other men killed, Mohammed, was indicted on charges of conspiracy to support terrorists and conspiracy to commit murder in a foreign country.

column3: Obama to defend drone strikes, reignite Gitmo debate in key speech today
column4: Mohammed grew up in North Carolina, where he reportedly trained for the attacks before going to Pakistan.

column3: Obama to defend drone strikes, reignite Gitmo debate in key speech today
column4: WRAL, a television station in North Carolina, reported that family members had heard he was killed in a drone attack, but the government had not confirmed those reports.

column3: Obama to defend drone strikes, reignite Gitmo debate in key speech today
column4: Khan was killed in the same strike that killed al-Awlaki in Yemen, while al-Awlaki’s son was killed weeks later in another strike, according to reports.

column3: Obama to defend drone strikes, reignite Gitmo debate in key speech today

column3: Obama to defend drone strikes, reignite Gitmo debate in key speech today
column4: “It is the president’s view that we should be determined, as he is, to see the Guantanamo Bay detention facility closed,” White House press secretary Jay Carney said Wednesday.

column4: “Keeping it open is not efficient, it’s not effective, and it’s not in the interests of our national security.” Federal law blocks Mr. Obama from bringing any of the detainees at Guantanamo to the U.S., but it does allow him to transfer them to other countries — as long as the Defense Department certifies that they are not likely to return to the battlefield.

column3: Obama to defend drone strikes, reignite Gitmo debate in key speech today

column3: Obama, in a Shift, to Limit Targets of Drone Strikes
column4: WASHINGTON — President Obama plans to open a new phase in the nation’s long struggle with terrorism on Thursday by restricting the use of unmanned drone strikes that have been at the heart of his national security strategy and shifting control of them away from the C.I.A.

column3: Obama, in a Shift, to Limit Targets of Drone Strikes
column4: to the military.

column3: Obama, in a Shift, to Limit Targets of Drone Strikes
column4: In his first major speech on counterterrorism of his second term, Mr. Obama hopes to refocus the epic conflict that has defined American priorities since the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, and even foresees an unspecified day when the so-called war on terror might all but end, according to people briefed on White House plans.

column3: Obama, in a Shift, to Limit Targets of Drone Strikes
column4: As part of the shift in approach, the administration on Wednesday formally acknowledged for the first time that it had killed four American citizens in drone strikes outside the battlefields of Afghanistan and Iraq, arguing that its actions were justified by the danger to the United States.

column3: Obama, in a Shift, to Limit Targets of Drone Strikes
column4: Mr. Obama approved providing new information to Congress and the public about the rules governing his attacks on Al Qaeda and its allies.

column3: Obama, in a Shift, to Limit Targets of Drone Strikes
column4: A new classified policy guidance signed by Mr. Obama will sharply curtail the instances when unmanned aircraft can be used to attack in places that are not overt war zones, countries like Pakistan, Yemen and Somalia.

column3: Obama, in a Shift, to Limit Targets of Drone Strikes
column4: The rules will impose the same standard for strikes on foreign enemies now used only for American citizens deemed to be terrorists.

column3: Obama, in a Shift, to Limit Targets of Drone Strikes
column4: Lethal force will be used only against targets who pose “a continuing, imminent threat to Americans” and cannot feasibly be captured, Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. said in a letter to Congress, suggesting that threats to a partner like Afghanistan or Yemen alone would not be enough to justify being targeted.

column3: Obama, in a Shift, to Limit Targets of Drone Strikes
column4: The standard could signal an end to “signature strikes,” or attacks on groups of unknown men based only on their presumed status as members of Al Qaeda or some other enemy group — an approach that administration critics say has resulted in many civilian casualties.

column3: Obama, in a Shift, to Limit Targets of Drone Strikes
column4: In effect, this appears to be a step away from the less restricted use of force allowed in war zones and toward the more limited use of force for self-defense allowed outside of armed conflict.

column3: I.R.S. Official Denies Misleading Congress
column4: WASHINGTON — The Internal Revenue Service official who first disclosed that the agency had targeted conservative groups for special scrutiny, and in doing so ignited a controversy that has ensnared the White House, denied on Wednesday that she had ever provided false information to Congress.

column3: I.R.S. Official Denies Misleading Congress
column4: She then invoked her Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination and declined to testify at a House hearing on the agency’s actions.

column3: I.R.S. Official Denies Misleading Congress
column4: As the official, Lois Lerner, appeared under subpoena before the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform, she sternly told her questioners that accusations that she had misled Congress in previous testimony were false.

column3: I.R.S. Official Denies Misleading Congress
column4: “I have not done anything wrong.

column3: I.R.S. Official Denies Misleading Congress
column4: I have not broken any laws,” said Ms. Lerner, who leads the I.R.S.’s division on tax-exempt organizations.

column3: I.R.S. Official Denies Misleading Congress
column4: “I have not violated any I.R.S.

column3: I.R.S. Official Denies Misleading Congress
column4: rules and regulations, and I have not provided false information to this or any other Congressional committee.” Ms. Lerner has become a person of intense interest to Congressional investigators, who insist that she made, at best, incomplete statements when she said she first learned that her subordinates had singled out Tea Party groups after reading news media reports last year.

column3: I.R.S. Official Denies Misleading Congress
column4: An inspector general’s report found, however, that she was briefed on their actions as early as June 2011.

column4: But that upset other Republicans, who said that Ms. Lerner should not be let go so quickly.

column3: CONFUSION ERUPTS IN IRS HEARING AFTER LOIS LERNER TRIES TO PLEAD THE 5TH Ã¢â‚¬â€ WATCH IT ALL UNFOLD
column4: The Internal Revenue Service official at the center of the political targeting scandal invoked her constitutional right not to answer lawmakers’ questions on Wednesday, but defiantly asserted that she has done nothing wrong — prompting confusion about how exactly she was using her right not to incriminate herself.

column3: CONFUSION ERUPTS IN IRS HEARING AFTER LOIS LERNER TRIES TO PLEAD THE 5TH Ã¢â‚¬â€ WATCH IT ALL UNFOLD
column4: House Oversight Committee Chairman Darrell Issa (R-Calif.) told Politico that Lois Lerner, who leads the IRS office that determines which organizations receive tax-exempt status, will be brought before his panel again.

column3: CONFUSION ERUPTS IN IRS HEARING AFTER LOIS LERNER TRIES TO PLEAD THE 5TH Ã¢â‚¬â€ WATCH IT ALL UNFOLD
column4: Lerner was the first to publicly disclose earlier this month that the IRS gave extra scrutiny to conservative groups.

column3: CONFUSION ERUPTS IN IRS HEARING AFTER LOIS LERNER TRIES TO PLEAD THE 5TH Ã¢â‚¬â€ WATCH IT ALL UNFOLD
column4: “I have not done anything wrong, I have not broken any laws, I have not violated any IRS rules or regulations and I have not provided false information to this or any other congressional committee,” Lerner told House Oversight and Government Reform Committee members.

column3: CONFUSION ERUPTS IN IRS HEARING AFTER LOIS LERNER TRIES TO PLEAD THE 5TH Ã¢â‚¬â€ WATCH IT ALL UNFOLD
column4: “While I would very much like to answer the committee’s questions today, I have been advised by my counsel to assert my constitutional right not to testify or answer questions related to the subject manner of this hearing.” Lerner added that by asserting her right not to testify, “I know that some people will assume I have done something wrong.

column3: CONFUSION ERUPTS IN IRS HEARING AFTER LOIS LERNER TRIES TO PLEAD THE 5TH Ã¢â‚¬â€ WATCH IT ALL UNFOLD
column4: I have not.

column3: CONFUSION ERUPTS IN IRS HEARING AFTER LOIS LERNER TRIES TO PLEAD THE 5TH Ã¢â‚¬â€ WATCH IT ALL UNFOLD
column4: One of the basic functions of the Fifth Amendment is to protect innocent individuals, and that is the protection I am invoking today.” Issa noted during the hearing that because Lerner had asserted her innocence in her opening statement, “I believe you have not asserted your rights but have effectively waived your rights” and took her refusal to answer as a refusal to testify.

column3: CONFUSION ERUPTS IN IRS HEARING AFTER LOIS LERNER TRIES TO PLEAD THE 5TH Ã¢â‚¬â€ WATCH IT ALL UNFOLD
column4: An incensed Rep. Trey Gowdy (R-S.C.) spoke up that Lerner should testify, agreeing that she already waived her constitutional privilege.

column3: CONFUSION ERUPTS IN IRS HEARING AFTER LOIS LERNER TRIES TO PLEAD THE 5TH Ã¢â‚¬â€ WATCH IT ALL UNFOLD
column4: “You don’t get to tell your side of the story and not be subjected to cross-examination.

column3: CONFUSION ERUPTS IN IRS HEARING AFTER LOIS LERNER TRIES TO PLEAD THE 5TH Ã¢â‚¬â€ WATCH IT ALL UNFOLD
column4: That’s not the way it works.

column3: CONFUSION ERUPTS IN IRS HEARING AFTER LOIS LERNER TRIES TO PLEAD THE 5TH Ã¢â‚¬â€ WATCH IT ALL UNFOLD
column4: She waived her right to Fifth Amendment privilege by issuing an opening statement, she ought to stand here and answer our questions,” Gowdy said, earning applause from the audience.

column3: CONFUSION ERUPTS IN IRS HEARING AFTER LOIS LERNER TRIES TO PLEAD THE 5TH Ã¢â‚¬â€ WATCH IT ALL UNFOLD

column3: Immigration vote shows strength of deal, pitfalls ahead
column4: Less than 24 hours after senators powered their immigration bill through committee, the legislation came under fire in the House, where the former head of immigration enforcement testified that it has too many loopholes that could delay enforcement, let dangerous people in, and hamstring agents from fighting illegal immigration in the future.

column3: Immigration vote shows strength of deal, pitfalls ahead
column4: Key House Republican lawmakers, meanwhile, signaled their worries over the Senate bill, saying they worried it repeated some of the mistakes of the last amnesty in 1986, which auditors said was rife with fraud and failed to follow through on promises of better enforcement.

column3: Immigration vote shows strength of deal, pitfalls ahead
column4: “I cannot find any deadline by which the border is to be secured,” said Rep. Lamar Smith, Texas Republican, at a hearing called to poke holes in the Senate bill.

column3: Immigration vote shows strength of deal, pitfalls ahead
column4: SPECIAL COVERAGE: Immigration Reform The three witnesses who testified included a supporter of the Senate bill, an ardent opponent, and Julie Myers Wood, the former chief of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement in the administration of President George W. Bush, who wants to see legalization but had concerns about the Senate bill.

column3: Immigration vote shows strength of deal, pitfalls ahead
column4: All three agreed with Mr. Smith that there is no absolute requirement in the legislation that the borders be secured before illegal immigrants get legal status.

column3: Immigration vote shows strength of deal, pitfalls ahead
column4: “Not within the bill, not right now,” said David V. Aguilar, former deputy commissioner of U.S. Customs and Border Protection.

column3: Immigration vote shows strength of deal, pitfalls ahead
column4: SEE ALSO: Immigration reform bill clears committee hurdles, heads to full Senate The witnesses were testifying before the House Judiciary Committee the day after an 867-page immigration bill cleared the Senate Judiciary Committee on a 13-5 vote.

column3: Immigration vote shows strength of deal, pitfalls ahead
column4: Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, Nevada Democrat, said he’ll bring the bill to the floor in June, and key Senate Republicans have already signaled they won’t filibuster to block the bill from reaching the floor.

column3: Immigration vote shows strength of deal, pitfalls ahead
column4: That sets up what’s likely to be a bruising, in-depth debate covering dozens of amendments.

column3: Immigration vote shows strength of deal, pitfalls ahead
column4: “Although neither Republicans nor Democrats will support each and every aspect of this legislation, it is gratifying to see the momentum behind reforms that will make our country safer and help 11 million undocumented immigrants get right with the law,” Mr. Reid said, adding that the lawmakers who wrote the immigration bill showed “real bravery” in the face of harsh attacks, particularly from conservatives.

column3: Immigration vote shows strength of deal, pitfalls ahead
column4: The crux of the Senate deal, negotiated by four Democrats and four Republicans, offers a quick legal status to illegal immigrants, but withholds a full path to citizenship until the Homeland Security Department spends more money on border security, creates a national electronic system for businesses to check their workers’ legal status, and requires a photo-based entry-exit system to check visitors’ identity.

column3: Immigration vote shows strength of deal, pitfalls ahead
column4: Backers said legalizing illegal immigrants must be part of a deal, and said they don’t want to delay that legalization too long or else it will prevent people from coming forward.

column3: Immigration vote shows strength of deal, pitfalls ahead
column4: They argue that bringing the estimated 11 million illegal immigrants into the open will enhance security.

column3: Immigration vote shows strength of deal, pitfalls ahead
column4: But Ms. Wood, who was in the administration when Mr. Bush pushed for legalization in 2007, listed a series of places where she said the current bill fails.

column3: Immigration vote shows strength of deal, pitfalls ahead
column4: She said it should require in-person interviews of those applying for legalization, it should invest more in interior enforcement, and it should place stiffer requirements on the Homeland Security secretary to follow through on stiffer security.

column3: Immigration vote shows strength of deal, pitfalls ahead
column4: Ms. Wood also said the bill shifts the burden for proving an illegal immigrant should be detained onto the federal government, rather than current law which presumes illegal immigrants should be detained unless there’s a good reason not to.

column3: Immigration vote shows strength of deal, pitfalls ahead
column4: And she said the bill creates too many chances for illegal immigrants to gum up deportations with court appeals.

column3: Immigration vote shows strength of deal, pitfalls ahead
column4: One critical change Ms. Wood suggested was to get the electronic verification system for employers to check workers up and running faster than the five-year deadline in the bill, and to have businesses check not only new employees but their existing workforce.

column3: Immigration vote shows strength of deal, pitfalls ahead
column4: “Five to seven years is too long for all employees to have to go through the system, and the inability to verify the existing workforce is going to create an unclear workforce,” she said.

column3: Immigration vote shows strength of deal, pitfalls ahead
column4: She said that will lead to exploitation of those workers.

column3: Immigration Overhaul Wins PanelÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Backing in the Senate
column4: WASHINGTON — The Senate Judiciary Committee on Tuesday approved a broad overhaul of the nation’s immigration laws on a bipartisan vote, sending the most significant immigration policy changes in decades to the full Senate, where the debate is expected to begin next month.

column3: Immigration Overhaul Wins PanelÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Backing in the Senate
column4: The 13-to-5 vote came as the committee reached a deal on one of the final snags threatening the legislation — and agreed to hold off on a particularly politically charged amendment, which would have added protections for same-sex couples.

column3: Immigration Overhaul Wins PanelÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Backing in the Senate
column4: After intense behind-the-scenes negotiations, Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah, struck an agreement with the group of eight senators who drafted the original bill to address his concerns about visas for skilled foreign workers who could fill jobs in the high-tech industry.

column3: Immigration Overhaul Wins PanelÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Backing in the Senate
column4: By late afternoon on Tuesday, Mr. Hatch had said that he would support the bill out of committee, if not necessarily on the Senate floor, after the committee agreed, via a voice vote, to pass his amendment.

column3: Immigration Overhaul Wins PanelÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Backing in the Senate
column4: “I’m going to vote this bill out of committee because I’ve committed to do that,” Mr. Hatch said.

column3: Immigration Overhaul Wins PanelÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Backing in the Senate
column4: Authors of the legislation hoped for a strong vote out of committee to help the bill as it heads to the Senate floor.

column3: Immigration Overhaul Wins PanelÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Backing in the Senate
column4: Mr. Hatch’s support could help persuade other conservative Republicans to back the bill.

column3: Immigration Overhaul Wins PanelÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Backing in the Senate
column4: He was joined in his “yes” vote by Senators Jeff Flake of Arizona and Lindsey Graham of South Carolina, both Republican members of the bipartisan group.

column3: Immigration Overhaul Wins PanelÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Backing in the Senate
column4: The most emotional part of the committee process, which stretched over five days and 301 amendments, came late Tuesday, when Senator Patrick J. Leahy, the Vermont Democrat who leads the committee, said that he would not offer an amendment allowing United States citizens to apply for permanent resident status, known as a green card, on behalf of their same-sex partners.

column3: Immigration Overhaul Wins PanelÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Backing in the Senate
column4: Mr. Leahy, according to immigration and gay rights advocates, was under pressure from the White House not to offer this amendment.

column3: Immigration Overhaul Wins PanelÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Backing in the Senate
column4: Though both President Obama and Democrats in the bipartisan group support protections for same-sex couples in the bill, Republicans in the group have warned that such provisions would lead them to abandon the legislation.

column3: Immigration Overhaul Wins PanelÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Backing in the Senate
column4: Before Mr. Leahy announced his decision, Democratic senators, all of whom personally supported the provision, engaged in a lengthy and agonizing debate.

column3: Immigration Overhaul Wins PanelÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Backing in the Senate
column4: Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York and an author of the measure, said that not including the provision amounted to “rank discrimination.” But he ultimately concluded, “As much as it pains me, I cannot support this amendment if it will bring down the bill.” Similarly, Senator Al Franken, Democrat of Minnesota, said: “This is the definition of a Hobson’s choice.

column3: Immigration Overhaul Wins PanelÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Backing in the Senate
column4: In my bones, I believe in equality.” But Mr. Graham reflected the view of his Republican colleagues when he said: “You’ve got me on immigration.

column3: Immigration Overhaul Wins PanelÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Backing in the Senate
column4: You don’t have me on marriage.

column3: Immigration Overhaul Wins PanelÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Backing in the Senate
column4: If you want to keep me on immigration, let’s stay on immigration.” Ultimately, Mr. Leahy withheld his amendment “with a heavy heart,” though he can still bring it up on the Senate floor.

column3: Immigration Overhaul Wins PanelÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Backing in the Senate
column4: Mr. Hatch’s amendment, which reflects the compromise he reached after lengthy negotiations led by Mr. Schumer, raises the minimum number of visas annually for high-skilled foreign workers — known as H-1B visas — to 115,000, from 110,000 in the bill, while keeping the maximum at 180,000 a year.

column3: Immigration Overhaul Wins PanelÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Backing in the Senate
column4: More important, aides to Mr. Hatch said, his provision includes a mechanism based on conditions in the labor market, intended to ensure that companies based in the United States can bring in qualified foreign workers when jobs are not filled by Americans, but decreases visas when they are.

column3: Immigration Overhaul Wins PanelÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Backing in the Senate
column4: His provision would also make it easier for employers to hire foreign workers, because it lightens the burden on them to demonstrate that they first tried to hire a qualified American worker.

column3: Immigration Overhaul Wins PanelÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Backing in the Senate
column4: Mr. Hatch’s amendment clarifies distinctions between companies in which the majority of engineers and computer technicians are Americans, and companies with mostly foreign workers.

column3: Immigration Overhaul Wins PanelÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Backing in the Senate
column4: Under the measure, more stringent restrictions would apply to the companies with a foreign labor force, like many Indian outsourcing companies, raising incentives to hire more Americans.

column3: Immigration Overhaul Wins PanelÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Backing in the Senate
column4: Senator Richard J. Durbin of Illinois, a Democratic member of the bipartisan group, had been one of the last holdouts against Mr. Hatch’s amendment.

column3: Immigration Overhaul Wins PanelÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Backing in the Senate
column4: Along with Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, Mr. Durbin worried that Mr. Hatch’s provisions would harm American workers.

column3: Immigration Overhaul Wins PanelÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Backing in the Senate
column4: But on Tuesday, Mr. Durbin signaled that he would support Mr. Hatch’s plan.

column3: Immigration Overhaul Wins PanelÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Backing in the Senate
column4: “I would like to have seen a different amendment, a different bill — you would have as well,” Mr. Durbin said.

column3: Immigration Overhaul Wins PanelÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Backing in the Senate
column4: “But this is a dramatic improvement.” (Mr. Grassley, meanwhile, remained unconvinced, arguing, “Let’s see how much this stinks.”) Mr. Durbin made it clear that he expected Mr. Hatch’s support in return for his own vote in favor of the deal, saying: “A number of us have really leaned a long way in your direction to get your support for immigration reform.” Mr. Hatch had previously said that he believed his amendment “makes this bill a much more acceptable bill,” especially in the Republican-controlled House, where it is likely to face stiff opposition.

column3: Immigration Overhaul Wins PanelÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Backing in the Senate
column4: The agreement represents a win for the high-tech industry, and comes on the heels of intense lobbying by the industry.

column3: Immigration Overhaul Wins PanelÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Backing in the Senate
column4: The Association for Competitive Technology, a trade group, sent 50 executives and application developers to Washington on Monday and Tuesday to meet with lawmakers, including members of the Judiciary Committee.

column3: Immigration Overhaul Wins PanelÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Backing in the Senate
column4: Richard L. Trumka, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., the nation’s largest federation of unions, issued a statement against what he said were Mr. Hatch’s “antiworker amendments.” After passage, President Obama congratulated the committee and called the legislation “largely consistent with the principles of common-sense reform I have proposed and meets the challenge of fixing our broken immigration system.”  He urged the Senate to improve it further on the Senate floor.

column3: Immigration Overhaul Wins PanelÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Backing in the Senate
column4: As the committee was finishing its work, a drumbeat against an immigration overhaul began to pick up.

column3: Immigration Overhaul Wins PanelÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Backing in the Senate
column4: Dozens of high-profile conservative leaders and activists signed an open letter published Tuesday that denounced the bipartisan bill, saying the Senate “would do better to start over from scratch.” The conservatives said the bill was “bloated and unwieldy,” comparing it to President Obama’s health care bill.

column3: Immigration Overhaul Wins PanelÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Backing in the Senate
column4: Still, when the committee voted to approve the legislation Tuesday evening, a cheer and applause rang out through the room, as immigration advocates leapt to their feet, shouting “Yes we can!” and “Sí, se puede!”

column3: After Tornado, Oklahoma Senators Grapple With Past Disaster Aid Opposition
column4: Lawmakers have pledged to send aid to tornado-devastated Oklahoma quickly, but the state's Republican lawmakers -- six of whom voted against disaster aid after Superstorm Sandy -- may be forced to reckon with their past votes against emergency disaster funding.

column3: After Tornado, Oklahoma Senators Grapple With Past Disaster Aid Opposition
column4: Oklahoma's two Republican senators, Jim Inhofe and Tom Coburn, opposed a bill that provided more than $60 billion in emergency aid after Superstorm Sandy devastated the East Coast.

column3: After Tornado, Oklahoma Senators Grapple With Past Disaster Aid Opposition
column4: In addition, three members of Oklahoma's House delegation joined with most Republicans in opposing the legislation.

column3: After Tornado, Oklahoma Senators Grapple With Past Disaster Aid Opposition
column4: Nearly all of the lawmakers have pledged that whatever assistance Oklahomans need will be provided, but the devil will be in the details.

column3: After Tornado, Oklahoma Senators Grapple With Past Disaster Aid Opposition
column4: Coburn, who opposed the Sandy bill because it did not identify spending cuts to offset the cost of the legislation, said in the immediate aftermath of the tornado that he would "absolutely" demand spending cuts in exchange for aid.

column3: After Tornado, Oklahoma Senators Grapple With Past Disaster Aid Opposition
column4: A spokesman for Coburn confirmed this morning that he would not change his position on demanding spending cuts in order to fund disaster aid.

column3: After Tornado, Oklahoma Senators Grapple With Past Disaster Aid Opposition
column4: Other Republicans opposed what they considered to be unrelated spending in the Sandy bill.

column3: After Tornado, Oklahoma Senators Grapple With Past Disaster Aid Opposition
column4: "When a disaster occurs in America and emotions are high, everybody all of a sudden wants to pour money on it," Inhofe said on the Senate floor in 2012.

column3: After Tornado, Oklahoma Senators Grapple With Past Disaster Aid Opposition
column4: Asked about his past vote against Sandy funding, Inhofe said that funding for tornado relief would be "totally different."

column3: After Tornado, Oklahoma Senators Grapple With Past Disaster Aid Opposition
column4: "That was totally different," Inhofe said on MSNBC this morning.

column3: After Tornado, Oklahoma Senators Grapple With Past Disaster Aid Opposition
column4: "They were getting things -- for instance, that was supposed to be for New Jersey.

column3: After Tornado, Oklahoma Senators Grapple With Past Disaster Aid Opposition
column4: They had things in the Virgin Islands.

column3: After Tornado, Oklahoma Senators Grapple With Past Disaster Aid Opposition
column4: They were fixing roads there.

column3: After Tornado, Oklahoma Senators Grapple With Past Disaster Aid Opposition
column4: They were putting roofs on houses in Washington, D.C." "Everybody was getting in and exploiting the tragedy that took place.

column3: After Tornado, Oklahoma Senators Grapple With Past Disaster Aid Opposition
column4: That won't happen in Oklahoma," he added.

column3: After Tornado, Oklahoma Senators Grapple With Past Disaster Aid Opposition
column4: But the $60.4 Sandy relief bill, which languished in Congress because of opposition from Republican lawmakers, may be a cautionary tale.

column3: After Tornado, Oklahoma Senators Grapple With Past Disaster Aid Opposition
column4: The public fight over funding pitted congressional Republicans against one of their party's rising stars, New Jersey Gov.

column3: After Tornado, Oklahoma Senators Grapple With Past Disaster Aid Opposition
column4: Chris Christie, and even some members of their own caucus from the Northeast whose states were affected by the massive storm.

column3: After Tornado, Oklahoma Senators Grapple With Past Disaster Aid Opposition
column4: In the heated rhetoric over the bill, Rep. Peter King, R-N.Y., said Republicans were betraying New Yorkers and New Jerseyans.

column3: After Tornado, Oklahoma Senators Grapple With Past Disaster Aid Opposition
column4: "I'm saying right now ... anyone from New York and New Jersey [who] contributes one penny to congressional Republicans is out of their minds," King said on Fox News in January.

column3: After Tornado, Oklahoma Senators Grapple With Past Disaster Aid Opposition
column4: "Because what [they] did last night was put a knife in the back of New Yorkers and New Jerseyans.

column3: After Tornado, Oklahoma Senators Grapple With Past Disaster Aid Opposition
column4: It's an absolute disgrace."

column3: After Tornado, Oklahoma Senators Grapple With Past Disaster Aid Opposition
column4: It is perhaps in light of that public intraparty meltdown that House Speaker John Boehner, R-Ohio, this morning would not answer questions about whether Republicans would demand that Oklahoma relief funds also be paid for.

column3: After Tornado, Oklahoma Senators Grapple With Past Disaster Aid Opposition
column4: "We'll work with the administration on making sure that they have the resources they need to help the people of Oklahoma," Boehner said repeatedly in answer to questions from reporters.

column3: After Tornado, Oklahoma Senators Grapple With Past Disaster Aid Opposition
column4: So far, the Federal Emergency Management Agency has about $11 billion in its disaster relief fund and a final tallying of the cost of rebuilding parts of Oklahoma likely won't be finished for weeks.

column3: After Tornado, Oklahoma Senators Grapple With Past Disaster Aid Opposition
column4: But already, Republicans are taking some heat.

column3: After Tornado, Oklahoma Senators Grapple With Past Disaster Aid Opposition
column4: After Inhofe's comments this morning, he has been the subject of a storm of ridicule.

column3: After Tornado, Oklahoma Senators Grapple With Past Disaster Aid Opposition
column4: "Inhofe and Coburn: Red state hypocrites.

column3: After Tornado, Oklahoma Senators Grapple With Past Disaster Aid Opposition
column4: Apparently we have deserving and undeserving disasters," wrote Joan Walsh, editor-at-large at Salon.com.

column3: Boehner: Obama admin will get what it needs for Oklahoma
column4: House Speaker John A. Boehner said repeatedly on Tuesday that he will work with the Obama administration to make sure that it has the resources it needs to support Oklahoma in the wake of the deadly tornado that swept through the state Monday.

column3: Boehner: Obama admin will get what it needs for Oklahoma
column4: “Our hearts and our prayers go out to those in Oklahoma who are victimized by this storm, especially our colleague, Tom Cole,” Mr. Boehner said at a morning news conference.

column3: Boehner: Obama admin will get what it needs for Oklahoma
column4: “Moore, Oklahoma, is his hometown, so obviously he’s there, and so I’ve ordered the flags this morning to be lowered to half staff in honor of those who have suffered through this terrible storm.” Asked whether Congress would demand spending offsets to provide relief and about the relief package for Superstorm Sandy, which passed without a majority of GOP support in the House, Mr. Boehner said simply, “Let me just speak on behalf of all of our members, including those from Oklahoma.

column3: Boehner: Obama admin will get what it needs for Oklahoma
column4: We will work with the administration to make sure that they have the resources they need.” SEE ALSO: Obama’s vow to Oklahoma: We will be there ‘as long as it takes’ to recover from tornado CQ Roll Call reported that Sen. Tom Coburn, Oklahoma Republican, wants any federal disaster assistance to be accompanied with spending offsets — a position the spending hawk has consistently taken during his career.

column3: Boehner: Obama admin will get what it needs for Oklahoma
column4: Mr. Coburn said Tuesday he spoke with Department of Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano Monday night about FEMA’s response, and that “any and all available aid will be delivered without delay.” He also told CNN Tuesday the debate about spending and offsets shouldn’t be on peoples’ minds at the moment.

column3: Boehner: Obama admin will get what it needs for Oklahoma
column4: “It’s insensitive to even talk about it now,” Mr. Coburn said.

column3: Boehner: Obama admin will get what it needs for Oklahoma
column4: “It just shows the crassness of Washington versus the sensitivity that we need to have.”

column3: Fact check rips IRS official over Tea Party targeting claims
column4: A detailed fact-check published Monday tore into an IRS official's claim that the agency's scrutiny of conservative groups started in response to an influx of nonprofit applications, showing the practice started well before the forms started flooding in.

column3: Fact check rips IRS official over Tea Party targeting claims
column4: The piece in The Washington Post disputed a central claim that Lois Lerner, head of the exempt organizations division, and other IRS officials made as they admitted to targeting conservative groups for additional scrutiny as they sought tax-exempt status.

column3: Fact check rips IRS official over Tea Party targeting claims
column4: Lerner claimed they did so in response to a "very big uptick" between 2010 and 2012 in the number of applications for a status known as 501(c)(4).

column3: Fact check rips IRS official over Tea Party targeting claims
column4: Indeed, there was an uptick recorded in that time period.

column3: Fact check rips IRS official over Tea Party targeting claims
column4: But, as the Post wrote, "it was relatively small."

column3: AP president blasts unconstitutional" phone records probe"
column4: (CBS News) The Associated Press doesn't question the Justice Department's right to have seized two months' worth of its phone records, the organization's president and CEO Gary Pruitt said Sunday on "Face the Nation."

column3: AP president blasts unconstitutional" phone records probe"
column4: It was the methodology - "so sweeping, so secretively, so abusively and harassingly overbroad," he said - that breached the Constitution.

column3: AP president blasts unconstitutional" phone records probe"
column4: As part of its criminal investigation into who may have leaked information contained in a May 7, 2012, AP story about a foiled terror plot in Yemen, the department "issued a secret subpoena for the phone toll records for 21 AP phone lines and these were phones lines for reporters, direct lines, cell phones, home phones but also the office numbers," Pruitt explained.

column3: AP president blasts unconstitutional" phone records probe"
column4: "So over 100, approximately a hundred journalists used these telephone lines as part of newsgathering and over the course of the two months of the records that they swept up, thousands upon thousands of newsgathering calls were made.

column3: AP president blasts unconstitutional" phone records probe"
column4: "...Under their own rules, they are required to narrow this request as narrowly as possible so as to not tread upon the First Amendment," he went on.

column3: AP president blasts unconstitutional" phone records probe"
column4: "And yet they had a broad, sweeping collection, and they did it secretly.

column3: AP president blasts unconstitutional" phone records probe"
column4: Their rules require them to come to us first but in this case they didn't, claiming an exception, saying that if they had it would have posed a substantial threat to their investigation.

column3: AP president blasts unconstitutional" phone records probe"
column4: But they have not explained why it would and we can't understand why it would."

column3: AP president blasts unconstitutional" phone records probe"
column4: Pruitt said the AP acted "responsibly," holding the story for five days upon receiving guidance from the intelligence community that it posed a national security risk.

column3: AP president blasts unconstitutional" phone records probe"
column4: It was important for the American public to know about the CIA operation that thwarted an al Qaeda plot to detonate a bomb aboard a U.S.-bound airplane, he continued, because "the Department of Homeland security were telling the American public that there was no credible evidence of a terrorist plot related to the anniversary of the killing Of Osama bin Laden."

column3: AP president blasts unconstitutional" phone records probe"
column4: That characterization was "misleading."

column3: AP president blasts unconstitutional" phone records probe"
column4: A call from a Washington, D.C. district attorney last week notified the AP of the subpoenaed phone records, Pruitt said.

column3: AP president blasts unconstitutional" phone records probe"
column4: Since then, he added, "officials that would normally talk to us, and people we talk to in the normal course of newsgathering, are already saying they're a little reluctant to talk to us; they fear that they will be monitored by the government.

column3: AP president blasts unconstitutional" phone records probe"
column4: "...The government has no business having control over all, monitoring all of this newsgathering information from the Associated Press," he continued.

column3: Obama urged to make economy a bigger, bolder topic
column4: WASHINGTON (AP) — Five months into President Barack Obama's second term, allies and former top aides worry that his overarching goal of economic opportunity has been diminished, partly drowned out by controversies seized upon by Republicans in an effort to weaken him.

column3: Obama urged to make economy a bigger, bolder topic
column4: The former White House insiders, including longtime Obama adviser David Axelrod, say Obama needs to make his case anew for government's role in expanding education and innovation and to give, as Obama put it in one of his early seminal speeches, "every American a fighting chance in the 21st century."

column3: Obama urged to make economy a bigger, bolder topic
column4: Among their suggestions is that the president deliver a major address, perhaps at a commencement, that once again places his economic vision at the center of his agenda and speaks to what continues to be the overriding concern of the American public.

column3: Obama urged to make economy a bigger, bolder topic
column4: Instead, absent major legislative victories, Obama's second term has become a series of small actions overshadowed by a trio of recent troubles over the administration's response to the attack in Benghazi, Libya, that killed four Americans, the IRS's targeting of conservative groups and the Justice Department's seizure of Associated Press phone records as part of a leak investigation.

column3: Obama urged to make economy a bigger, bolder topic
column4: "The hardest thing in the hot house of Washington in weeks like this is to get above the maelstrom and really define major issues in your own terms," Axelrod said.

column3: Obama urged to make economy a bigger, bolder topic
column4: "They need to find big platforms, whether it's congressional addresses, commencement speeches, high-profile interviews or a combination of those things and others."

column3: Obama urged to make economy a bigger, bolder topic
column4: As these Democrats see it, there has been an arc of Obama addresses that have spelled out the challenge and the hope of attaining the American Dream, from a 2005 commencement address at tiny Knox College in Galesburg, Ill., to his speech in Osawatomie, Kan., in late 2011, and that the time for another one is now.

column3: Obama urged to make economy a bigger, bolder topic
column4: Over the last two weeks, Obama has been trying to draw attention to his job-creation ideas with small events in Austin and, on Friday, in Baltimore.

column3: Obama urged to make economy a bigger, bolder topic
column4: The daytime visits have been coupled with modest executive initiatives that tend to garner local media attention but get lost in Washington's attention to the contentious issues of the moment.

column3: Obama urged to make economy a bigger, bolder topic
column4: "There does seem to be a risk of getting bogged down in noise," said Jared Bernstein, who was part of Obama's economic team when he served as Vice President Joe Biden's chief economist.

column3: Obama urged to make economy a bigger, bolder topic
column4: "He doesn't need to get out to talk about Benghazi and the IRS and the budget deficit.

column3: Obama urged to make economy a bigger, bolder topic
column4: He needs to talk about investment in the nation's productivity."

column3: Obama urged to make economy a bigger, bolder topic
column4: Obama has called for more government spending on education, public works projects, and research and development and has proposed paying for it largely with higher taxes.

column3: Obama urged to make economy a bigger, bolder topic
column4: But after letting one tax increase on the rich pass at the beginning of the year, Republicans have steadfastly refused any further tax hikes and have resisted Obama's spending plans.

column3: Obama urged to make economy a bigger, bolder topic
column4: The result has been a fruitless search, at least so far, for a "grand bargain" to trim the nation's long-term debt.

column3: Obama urged to make economy a bigger, bolder topic
column4: In the face of Republican-led investigations in Congress and with some conservatives even suggesting impeachment proceedings against the president, some Obama advisers say that boldly elevating the economy would create a sharp contrast and emphasize their belief that Republicans are overplaying their hand.

column3: Obama urged to make economy a bigger, bolder topic
column4: They note that as dissatisfaction with Washington has grown, Obama has continued to hold a substantial edge over the Republicans in Congress.

column3: Obama urged to make economy a bigger, bolder topic
column4: House Speaker John Boehner, R-Ohio, said that creating jobs is the top priority of Republicans, too, but "we're also focused on holding this administration accountable" about what happened in Libya and with the IRS.

column3: Obama urged to make economy a bigger, bolder topic
column4: If Obama has a single long-term governing priority, it is a deep-seated belief that advances in technology and globalization have translated into a significant consumer benefits but have also eroded middle-class gains.

column3: Obama urged to make economy a bigger, bolder topic
column4: "The result has been the emergence of what some call a 'winner take all' economy, in which a rising tide doesn't necessarily lift all boats," he wrote in his 2006 book, "The Audacity of Hope."

column3: Obama urged to make economy a bigger, bolder topic
column4: The opportunity to make a broad shift toward the economy might have presented itself this week, when the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office predicted that the budget deficit for 2013 will be $642 billion — lower than estimated and half of the record $1.4 trillion hit during Obama's first year in office.

column3: Obama urged to make economy a bigger, bolder topic
column4: Instead, that bit of news was overshadowed by the IRS, Benghazi and AP phone record controversies.

column3: Obama urged to make economy a bigger, bolder topic
column4: Armed with a lower deficit number, some of Obama's liberal critics say he should abandon efforts to reduce deficits and focus exclusively on jobs.

column3: Obama urged to make economy a bigger, bolder topic
column4: "They should declare victory," said Lawrence Mishel, president and CEO of the liberal Economic Policy Institute.

column3: Obama urged to make economy a bigger, bolder topic
column4: "Making the big policy and political project the grand bargain has been digging us in a deeper and deeper hole."

column3: Obama urged to make economy a bigger, bolder topic
column4: White House officials say the time to pause and deliver the type of major address that connects Obama's policies to his core beliefs is when it has the possibility of making a major impact.

column3: Obama urged to make economy a bigger, bolder topic
column4: For now, they say, their economic tour across the country is better suited to the moment.

column3: Obama urged to make economy a bigger, bolder topic
column4: "What we think that these tours do is add another dimension to the argument of what we're trying to get done with Congress," White House communications director Jennifer Palmieri said.

column3: Obama urged to make economy a bigger, bolder topic
column4: "That this is not just about budgets, this is about steps that Congress can take legislatively and the president can take unilaterally that will create jobs and help middle-class families."

column3: Obama urged to make economy a bigger, bolder topic
column4: How to emphasize Obama's jobs agenda was a subject Thursday during a meeting between top White House aides and outside Democratic operatives, many of whom had worked for Bill Clinton's administration.

column3: Obama urged to make economy a bigger, bolder topic
column4: They had been called by Obama chief of staff Denis McDonough to consult and offer ideas on how to respond to the most recent uproars.

column3: Obama urged to make economy a bigger, bolder topic
column4: Among those attending were such Clinton aides as Paul Begala and Mike McCurry.

column3: Obama urged to make economy a bigger, bolder topic
column4: "What the president can do is make decisions about what he wants to talk to the American people about," said Democratic consultant Tad Devine, who also attended Thursday's meeting.

column3: Obama urged to make economy a bigger, bolder topic
column4: "And my view is, as someone who spends time sitting in focus groups listening to voters, what's at the top of mind with them is the economy still."

column3: Obama urged to make economy a bigger, bolder topic
column4: ___ Follow Jim Kuhnhenn on Twitter: http://twitter.com/jkuhnhenn

column3: Treasury officials told of IRS probe in June 2012
column4: WASHINGTON — Senior Treasury officials were made aware in June 2012 that investigators were looking into complaints from tea party groups that they were being harassed by the Internal Revenue Service, a Treasury inspector general said Friday, disclosing that Obama administration officials knew there was a probe during the heat of the presidential campaign.

column3: Treasury officials told of IRS probe in June 2012
column4: J. Russell George, the Treasury inspector general for tax administration, testified alongside ousted IRS head Steven Miller, who did little to subdue Republican outrage during hours of intense congressional questioning.

column3: Treasury officials told of IRS probe in June 2012
column4: Both defiant and apologetic, Miller acknowledged agency mistakes in targeting tea party groups for special scrutiny when they applied for tax-exempt status, but he insisted that agents broke no laws and that there was no effort to cover up their actions.

column3: Treasury officials told of IRS probe in June 2012
column4: Miller only stoked the criticism of many Republicans, who are assailing the administration on a sudden spate of other controversies, as well, even as some Democrats tried to contain the political damage.

column4: Treasury Secretary Jack Lew learned in March that an inspector general was investigating the IRS’s targeting of conservative groups, but he did not know the details until last Friday.

column3: Obama tries to talk economy amid din of scandal
column4: While much of Washington was riveted Friday on a Republican-led congressional hearing into abuse of power by the IRS, President Obama traveled to Baltimore to promote a jobs plan and decry lawmakers for “chasing every fleeting issue.” Mr. Obama toured Ellicott Dredges, a firm that manufactures dredging equipment, and praised Democratic lawmakers from Maryland for focusing on programs to help the middle class.

column3: Obama tries to talk economy amid din of scandal
column4: The president didn’t specifically address the IRS and other scandals confronting his administration, but he complained that Washington is too often distracted by partisan games.

column3: Obama tries to talk economy amid din of scandal
column4: “I know it can seem frustrating sometimes when it seems like Washington’s priorities aren’t the same as your priorities,” he told plant workers.

column3: Obama tries to talk economy amid din of scandal
column4: “I know it often seems like folks down there are more concerned with their jobs than with yours.

column3: Obama tries to talk economy amid din of scandal
column4: Others may get distracted by chasing every fleeting issue that passes by.

column3: Obama tries to talk economy amid din of scandal
column4: But the middle class will always be my No.1 folks, period.” The trip was the second installment of Mr. Obama’s “middle-class jobs and opportunity tour,” an effort to promote his economic agenda.

column3: Obama tries to talk economy amid din of scandal
column4: But the president is having difficulty moving forward with his initiatives as his administration grapples with controversies ranging from the IRS to an investigation into last year’s terrorist attack on a diplomatic post in Benghazi, Libya, to a Justice Department leak probe targeting the news media.

column4: The president said the country can’t afford distractions and said Americans deserve leaders who demonstrate “seriousness of purpose.” “The only thing that’s holding us back sometimes is a lack of political will,” he said.

column3: Obama tries to talk economy amid din of scandal
column4: “Sometimes our leadership isn’t focused where we need to be focused.” Mr. Obama advocated $50 billion of infrastructure improvements but said “we’ve had a little difficulty getting our Republican friends to work with us” to approve the new spending.

column4: He announced that he is ordering the federal government to cut red tape to speed up construction projects.

column3: Obama tries to talk economy amid din of scandal

column3: Obama tries to talk economy amid din of scandal

column3: Obama tries to talk economy amid din of scandal

column3: Obama tries to talk economy amid din of scandal

column4: But he said of the dredging company, the oldest of its kind in the U.S., “You all know a thing or two about growing the economy.” Rep. Andy Harris, Maryland Republican, said Mr. Obama “has been dragging his feet for years” on the pipeline project that could provide more jobs to the company he visited.

column3: First IRS hearing opens with tough talk
column4: Updated 05/17/2013 11:15 PM EDT Acting IRS Commissioner Steven Miller struck a defiant tone on Friday under intense questioning from Republicans who railed against “systemic abuse” at the agency.

column3: First IRS hearing opens with tough talk

column3: Outgoing IRS chief apologizes for 'foolish' targeting, GOP rep calls program 'tip of the iceberg'
column4: The hearing, though, was more than just venting.

column3: Outgoing IRS chief apologizes for 'foolish' targeting, GOP rep calls program 'tip of the iceberg'
column4: While Democrats voiced concern that the latest scandal would be used to score "political points," lawmakers on both sides of the aisle scolded the agency.

column3: Outgoing IRS chief apologizes for 'foolish' targeting, GOP rep calls program 'tip of the iceberg'
column4: And they made clear they'd be pressuring the IRS in the weeks to come on several points -- namely, who was responsible and whether lawmakers were overtly lied to last year.

column4: On the first question, they got few answers from Miller during Friday's testimony.

column3: Outgoing IRS chief apologizes for 'foolish' targeting, GOP rep calls program 'tip of the iceberg'
column4: But they repeatedly confronted the acting commissioner -- who was ousted from him job earlier this week -- about his and other officials' failure to disclose the program last year despite being aware of it.

column4: "In fact, we were repeatedly told no such targeting was happening.

column3: Outgoing IRS chief apologizes for 'foolish' targeting, GOP rep calls program 'tip of the iceberg'
column4: That isn't being misled, that's lying," said Rep. Dave Camp, R-Mich., the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee.

column4: Miller seemed to frustrate lawmakers' attempts to dig deeper.

column3: Outgoing IRS chief apologizes for 'foolish' targeting, GOP rep calls program 'tip of the iceberg'
column4: He claimed, a week after the scandal broke and a year after he first learned of the practice, that he still did not know who was responsible.

column3: Outgoing IRS chief apologizes for 'foolish' targeting, GOP rep calls program 'tip of the iceberg'
column4: "I don't have that name," he testified, after Rep. Dave Reichert, R-Wash., asked who was behind the program.

column3: Outgoing IRS chief apologizes for 'foolish' targeting, GOP rep calls program 'tip of the iceberg'
column4: Miller also claimed -- over and over -- he was being honest with Congress during a hearing last year.

column3: Outgoing IRS chief apologizes for 'foolish' targeting, GOP rep calls program 'tip of the iceberg'
column4: "You did not share the information you knew," Reichert charged.

column3: Outgoing IRS chief apologizes for 'foolish' targeting, GOP rep calls program 'tip of the iceberg'
column4: "I answered all questions truthfully," Miller replied.

column3: Outgoing IRS chief apologizes for 'foolish' targeting, GOP rep calls program 'tip of the iceberg'
column4: This claim was met with deep skepticism Friday.

column3: Outgoing IRS chief apologizes for 'foolish' targeting, GOP rep calls program 'tip of the iceberg'
column4: Miller acknowledged he learned of the practice during a May 3, 2012, briefing.

column3: Outgoing IRS chief apologizes for 'foolish' targeting, GOP rep calls program 'tip of the iceberg'
column4: Yet when he was asked about it at a July 25 hearing that year, he said only that some applications fell into a particular category -- and that those organizations were grouped for "consistency" and "quality."

column3: Outgoing IRS chief apologizes for 'foolish' targeting, GOP rep calls program 'tip of the iceberg'
column4: A letter he wrote to a Republican lawmaker the month before also gave a general description of the process without acknowledging that some groups were being singled out based on words like "Tea Party" and "Patriot."

column3: Outgoing IRS chief apologizes for 'foolish' targeting, GOP rep calls program 'tip of the iceberg'
column4: "How can we not conclude that you misled this committee?"

column3: Outgoing IRS chief apologizes for 'foolish' targeting, GOP rep calls program 'tip of the iceberg'
column4: Rep. Paul Ryan, R-Wis., former GOP vice presidential nominee, asked Miller.

column3: Outgoing IRS chief apologizes for 'foolish' targeting, GOP rep calls program 'tip of the iceberg'
column4: Miller said he "did not mislead the committee" and stands by his answer.

column3: Outgoing IRS chief apologizes for 'foolish' targeting, GOP rep calls program 'tip of the iceberg'
column4: Asked whether his answer was "incomplete," he said again he answered "truthfully."

column3: Outgoing IRS chief apologizes for 'foolish' targeting, GOP rep calls program 'tip of the iceberg'
column4: Miller objected to the term "targeting," and claimed political motivations were not at play in the program, which began in 2010.

column3: Outgoing IRS chief apologizes for 'foolish' targeting, GOP rep calls program 'tip of the iceberg'
column4: But he apologized for the program and said "foolish mistakes were made by people trying to be more efficient."

column3: Outgoing IRS chief apologizes for 'foolish' targeting, GOP rep calls program 'tip of the iceberg'
column4: "As acting commissioner, I want to apologize on the behalf of the Internal Revenue Service for the mistakes that we made and the poor service provided," Miller said.

column3: Outgoing IRS chief apologizes for 'foolish' targeting, GOP rep calls program 'tip of the iceberg'
column4: "The affected organizations and the American public deserve better."

column3: Outgoing IRS chief apologizes for 'foolish' targeting, GOP rep calls program 'tip of the iceberg'
column4: The hearing is the first to examine the scandal, and will likely kick off a string of subsequent hearings and investigations.

column3: Outgoing IRS chief apologizes for 'foolish' targeting, GOP rep calls program 'tip of the iceberg'
column4: Republicans made clear that the two retirements or resignations to date would not satisfy their concerns.

column3: Outgoing IRS chief apologizes for 'foolish' targeting, GOP rep calls program 'tip of the iceberg'
column4: Camp ripped the tax-collecting agency over the practice at the start of the hearing.

column3: Outgoing IRS chief apologizes for 'foolish' targeting, GOP rep calls program 'tip of the iceberg'
column4: "Now we know the truth -- or at least some of it," he said.

column3: Outgoing IRS chief apologizes for 'foolish' targeting, GOP rep calls program 'tip of the iceberg'
column4: "We also know that these revelations are just the tip of the iceberg.

column3: Outgoing IRS chief apologizes for 'foolish' targeting, GOP rep calls program 'tip of the iceberg'
column4: It would be a mistake to treat this as just one scandal."

column3: Outgoing IRS chief apologizes for 'foolish' targeting, GOP rep calls program 'tip of the iceberg'
column4: He questioned how high the scandal went, and also suggested there was other targeting of conservatives that has not yet been acknowledged by the agency.

column3: Outgoing IRS chief apologizes for 'foolish' targeting, GOP rep calls program 'tip of the iceberg'
column4: He called it part of a "culture of cover-ups."

column3: Outgoing IRS chief apologizes for 'foolish' targeting, GOP rep calls program 'tip of the iceberg'
