column3: Outgoing IRS chief apologizes for 'foolish' targeting, GOP rep calls program 'tip of the iceberg'
column4: He said the problem is not just personnel, but the size and scope of the IRS.

column3: Outgoing IRS chief apologizes for 'foolish' targeting, GOP rep calls program 'tip of the iceberg'
column4: The inspector general who released a scathing report on the agency also testified Friday.

column3: Outgoing IRS chief apologizes for 'foolish' targeting, GOP rep calls program 'tip of the iceberg'
column4: J. Russell George -- the Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration -- said his findings raised "troubling questions" about the agency, while claiming some of the wrongdoing was apparently done with no-to-little supervision.

column3: Outgoing IRS chief apologizes for 'foolish' targeting, GOP rep calls program 'tip of the iceberg'
column4: But he said all three allegations against the agency turned out to be true -- that it was using "inappropriate criteria" to screen conservative groups, it was delaying applications and it was asking unnecessary questions.

column3: Outgoing IRS chief apologizes for 'foolish' targeting, GOP rep calls program 'tip of the iceberg'
column4: Rep. Sander Levin, D-Mich., the top Democrat on the committee, said the agency's management "completely failed the American people."

column3: Outgoing IRS chief apologizes for 'foolish' targeting, GOP rep calls program 'tip of the iceberg'
column4: At the same time, he urged Republicans not to use the hearing to "score political points."

column3: Outgoing IRS chief apologizes for 'foolish' targeting, GOP rep calls program 'tip of the iceberg'
column4: Republicans, though, expressed more concern after they learned Thursday that the IRS official who led the tax-exempt organizations unit when the targeting took place -- Sarah Hall Ingram -- has since moved over to the IRS office responsible for ObamaCare.

column4: Miller said Friday he was the one who promoted her and called her a "superb civil servant."

column3: Outgoing IRS chief apologizes for 'foolish' targeting, GOP rep calls program 'tip of the iceberg'

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: Things go wrong in government.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: Sometimes it's just bad luck.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: Sometimes it's rank incompetence.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: Sometimes it's criminal wrongdoing.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: Most of the time you never hear about it.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: Or, if you do hear about it, the media eventually gets bored talking about it (see warming, global).

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: But every so often an instance of government wrongdoing sprouts wings and becomes something quite exciting: A political scandal.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: The crucial ingredient for a scandal is the prospect of high-level White House involvement and wide political repercussions.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: Government wrongdoing is boring.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: Scandals can bring down presidents, decide elections and revive down-and-out political parties.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: Scandals can dominate American politics for months at a time.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: On Tuesday, it looked like we had three possible political scandals brewing.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: Two days later, with much more evidence available, it doesn't look like any of them will pan out.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: There'll be more hearings, and more bad press for the Obama administration, and more demands for documents.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: But -- and this is a key qualification -- absent more revelations, the scandals that could reach high don't seem to include any real wrongdoing, whereas the ones that include real wrongdoing don't reach high enough.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: Let's go through them.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: 1) The Internal Revenue Service: The IRS mess was, well, a mess.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: But it's not a mess that implicates the White House, or even senior IRS leadership.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: If we believe the agency inspector general's report, a group of employees in a division called the "Determinations Unit" -- sounds sinister, doesn't it?

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: -- started giving tea party groups extra scrutiny, were told by agency leadership to knock it off, started doing it again, and then were reined in a second time and told that any further changes to the screening criteria needed to be approved at the highest levels of the agency.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: The White House fired the acting director of the agency on the theory that somebody had to be fired and he was about the only guy they had the power to fire.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: They're also instructing the IRS to implement each and every one of the IG's recommendations to make sure this never happens again.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: If new information emerges showing a connection between the Determination Unit's decisions and the Obama campaign, or the Obama administration, it would crack this White House wide open.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: That would be a genuine scandal.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: But the IG report says that there's no evidence of that.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: And so it's hard to see where this one goes from here.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: 2) Benghazi: We're long past the point where it's obvious what the Benghazi scandal is supposed to be about.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: The inquiry has moved on from the events in Benghazi proper, tragic as they were, to the talking points about the events in Benghazi.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: And the release Wednesday night of 100 pages of internal e-mails on those talking points seems to show what my colleague Glenn Kessler suspected: This was a bureaucratic knife fight between the State Department and the CIA.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: As for the White House's role, well, the e-mails suggest there wasn't much of one.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: "The internal debate did not include political interference from the White House, according to the e-mails, which were provided to congressional intelligence committees several months ago," report The Washington Post's Scott Wilson and Karen DeYoung.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: As for why the talking points seemed to blame protesters rather than terrorists for the attack that killed the U.S. ambassador and three other Americans?

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: Well: According to the e-mails and initial CIA-drafted talking points, the agency believed the attack included a mix of Islamist extremists from Ansar al-Sharia, a group affiliated with al-Qaeda, and angry demonstrators.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: White House officials did not challenge that analysis, the e-mails show, nor did they object to its inclusion in the public talking points.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: But CIA deputy director Michael Morell later removed the reference to Ansar al-Sharia because the assessment was still classified and because FBI officials believed that making the information public could compromise their investigation, said senior administration officials, who spoke on the condition of anonymity to describe the internal debate.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: So far, it's hard to see what, exactly, the scandal here is supposed to be.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: 3) AP/Justice Department:.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: This is the weirdest of the three.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: There's no evidence that the DoJ did anything illegal.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: Most people, in fact, think it was well within its rights to seize the phone records of Associated Press reporters.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: And if the Obama administration has been overzealous in prosecuting leakers, well, the GOP has been arguing that the White House hasn't taken national security leaks seriously enough.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: The AP/DoJ fight has caused that position to flip, and now members of Congress are concerned that the DoJ is going after leaks too aggressively.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: But it's hard for a political party to prosecute wrongdoing when they disagree with the potential remedies.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: Insofar as there's a "scandal" here, it's more about what is legal than what isn't.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: The DoJ simply has extraordinary power, under existing law, to spy on ordinary citizens -- members of the media included.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: The White House is trying to change existing law by encouraging Sen. Chuck Schumer to reintroduce the Media Shield Act.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: The Post's Rachel Weiner has a good rundown of what the bill would do.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: It's likely that the measure's national security exemption would make it relatively toothless in this particular case, but if Congress is worried, they always can -- and probably should -- take that language out.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: Still, that legislation has been killed by Republicans before, and it's likely to be killed by them again.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: The scandal metanarrative itself is also changing.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: Because there was no actual evidence of presidential involvement in these events, the line for much of this week was that the president was not involved enough in their aftermath.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: He was "passive."

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: He seemed to be a "bystander."

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: His was being controlled by events, rather than controlling them himself.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: That perception, too, seems to be changing.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: Mike Allen's Playbook, which is ground zero for scandal CW, led Thursday with a squib that says "the West Wing got its mojo back" and is "BACK ON OFFENSE."

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: Yes, the caps are in the original.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: The smarter voices on the right are also beginning to counsel caution.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: "While there’s still more information to be gathered and more investigations to be done, all indications are that these decisions – on the AP, on the IRS, on Benghazi – don’t proceed from [Obama]," wrote Ben Domenech in The Transom, his influential conservative morning newsletter.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: "The talk of impeachment is absurd.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: The queries of 'what did the president know and when did he know it' will probably end up finding out “'just about nothing, and right around the time everyone else found out.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: '” I want to emphasize: It's always possible that evidence could emerge that vaults one of these issues into true scandal territory.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: But the trend line so far is clear: The more information we get, the less these actually look like scandals.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: And yet, even if the scandals fade, the underlying problems might remain.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: The IRS.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: could give its agents better and clearer guidance on designating 501(c)(4), but Congress needs to decide whether that status and all of its benefits should be open to political groups or not.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: The Media Shield Act is not likely to go anywhere, and even if it does, it doesn't get us anywhere close to grappling with the post-9/11 expansion of the surveillance state.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: And then, of course, there are all the other problems Congress is ignoring, from high unemployment to sequestration to global warming.

column3: The scandals are falling apart
column4: When future generations look back on the scandals of our age, it'll be the unchecked rise in global temperatures, not the Benghazi talking points, that infuriate them.

column3: Storm clouds gathering -- your safety, your freedoms and the Obama White House
column4: Government is bad for personal freedom.

column3: Storm clouds gathering -- your safety, your freedoms and the Obama White House
column4: That argument is premised upon the truism that everything government does interferes with freedom because it either prohibits or compels.Everything it owns it has taken from others.

column3: Storm clouds gathering -- your safety, your freedoms and the Obama White House
column4: Much of what it says is divorced from the truth.

column3: Storm clouds gathering -- your safety, your freedoms and the Obama White House
column4: President Obama, like President George W. Bush, has argued that his first job is to keep America safe, and if he impairs personal freedom in the process, that is a small price to pay for safety.

column3: Storm clouds gathering -- your safety, your freedoms and the Obama White House
column4: Many of my colleagues in the media on the left and right have bought this argument, notwithstanding its fallacies.

column3: Storm clouds gathering -- your safety, your freedoms and the Obama White House
column4: Until now.

column3: Storm clouds gathering -- your safety, your freedoms and the Obama White House
column4: This past week, we learned that the IRS has targeted for additional scrutiny the tax exemption applications of groups with whose messages it disagrees.

column3: Storm clouds gathering -- your safety, your freedoms and the Obama White House
column4: We also learned that the Department of Justice obtained the personal telephone records of hundreds of reporters and editors employed by the Associated Press without a search warrant issued by a judge.

column3: Storm clouds gathering -- your safety, your freedoms and the Obama White House
column4: And during this past week we learned that the White House, the Department of State and the CIA all engaged in a conspiracy of disinformation so that the official version of events of what caused the murders of four Americans at our consulate in Benghazi, Libya, would not impair Obama’s re-election campaign in 2012.

column3: Storm clouds gathering -- your safety, your freedoms and the Obama White House
column4: [pullquote] The common threads in all of this government secrecy and lying are a general rejection of government’s moral obligation to tell the truth, a disturbing yet brazen willingness to evade and avoid the restrictions the Constitution has deliberately built around government, and a glib admission that the government can do as it pleases so long as it can politically get away with it.

column3: Storm clouds gathering -- your safety, your freedoms and the Obama White House
column4: The Constitution’s Equal Protection Clause requires that the government treat all similarly situated entities in a similar manner.

column3: Storm clouds gathering -- your safety, your freedoms and the Obama White House
column4: The Constitution’s First Amendment prohibits the government from using the speech and expressive activities of persons in America as a basis for the disparate treatment of them.

column3: Storm clouds gathering -- your safety, your freedoms and the Obama White House
column4: Thus, on its face -- that is, on the basis of what the IRS has admitted and without any further investigation -- we have violations of these constitutional principles.

column3: Storm clouds gathering -- your safety, your freedoms and the Obama White House
column4: If the IRS were to examine the applications for tax exemption of Media Matters with the same level of scrutiny as it does with Tea Party Patriots, it would not run afoul of these principles.

column3: Storm clouds gathering -- your safety, your freedoms and the Obama White House
column4: But Congress has given the IRS broad latitude to scrutinize the behavior of the taxpayers it chooses to scrutinize, and the IRS has given itself authority to probe, prod and plunder wherever it wishes.

column3: Storm clouds gathering -- your safety, your freedoms and the Obama White House
column4: I say “given itself,” because the IRS has rule-making power, which when overlooked by Congress (as is almost always the case) actually serves to enhance IRS powers beyond what Congress permits.

column3: Storm clouds gathering -- your safety, your freedoms and the Obama White House
column4: Short of criminal behavior such as bribery or conspiracy, the IRS employees who have singled out applications for tax exempt status for more scrutiny based on anticipated political expression are subject to removal from office, but they cannot be prosecuted or sued.

column3: Storm clouds gathering -- your safety, your freedoms and the Obama White House
column4: Here again, Congress is to blame, as both Republicans and Democrats have used and abused the IRS to their advantage, and neither party inwardly wants laws that will prevent it from doing so in the future.

column3: Storm clouds gathering -- your safety, your freedoms and the Obama White House
column4: Is this what you expect of our tax collectors?

column3: Storm clouds gathering -- your safety, your freedoms and the Obama White House
column4: The First Amendment also assures the right of professional journalists to seek and protect their sources, and it gives them immunity from government prosecution or retribution for truthfully publishing matters of material public interest, even when it involves information stolen from the government.

column3: Storm clouds gathering -- your safety, your freedoms and the Obama White House
column4: The Supreme Court taught us this in the Pentagon Papers case.

column3: Storm clouds gathering -- your safety, your freedoms and the Obama White House
column4: Moreover, the Fourth Amendment requires that if the government wants private information about who stole its secrets, it needs a search warrant from a judge.

column3: Storm clouds gathering -- your safety, your freedoms and the Obama White House
column4: But the Patriot Act, which was celebrated by some in the media whose telephone records have since been seized, permits federal agents to write their own search warrants when they seek records from a third party like a telephone company and can claim that pursuit of terrorists is at stake.

column3: Storm clouds gathering -- your safety, your freedoms and the Obama White House
column4: The Patriot Act makes a mockery of the Fourth Amendment, and the government knows that.

column3: Storm clouds gathering -- your safety, your freedoms and the Obama White House
column4: When the government chills free speech, we all suffer.

column3: Storm clouds gathering -- your safety, your freedoms and the Obama White House
column4: Thomas Jefferson preferred newspapers without government to government without newspapers.

column3: Storm clouds gathering -- your safety, your freedoms and the Obama White House
column4: Whose personal records will the government authorize itself to seize next?

column3: Storm clouds gathering -- your safety, your freedoms and the Obama White House
column4: The lesson of Benghazi is that we had no lawful right to interfere in the domestic affairs of the Libyan government.

column3: Storm clouds gathering -- your safety, your freedoms and the Obama White House
column4: It was unlawful for Obama to bomb Col. Qaddafi without a congressional declaration of war.

column3: Storm clouds gathering -- your safety, your freedoms and the Obama White House
column4: The organized assault on our consulate was the unintended consequence of us using force to infuse American-style democracy on a people whose culture is unable and unwilling to accept it.

column3: Storm clouds gathering -- your safety, your freedoms and the Obama White House
column4: But the president’s people were terrified that the murder of our ambassador to Libya during the 2012 presidential campaign might impair Obama’s re-election chances.

column3: Storm clouds gathering -- your safety, your freedoms and the Obama White House
column4: So they and he tried to rewrite history, and the more they and he lied, the more they and he needed to lie to cover up their original lies.

column3: Storm clouds gathering -- your safety, your freedoms and the Obama White House
column4: Would you retain an employee who lied to you about the deaths of innocents and lied more to cover up the original lies?

column3: Storm clouds gathering -- your safety, your freedoms and the Obama White House
column4: Now, back to Bush and Obama and the president’s job.

column3: Storm clouds gathering -- your safety, your freedoms and the Obama White House
column4: According to the Constitution, the president’s first job obligation is to preserve, protect and defend the Constitution.

column3: Storm clouds gathering -- your safety, your freedoms and the Obama White House
column4: According to the Constitution, that means preserving Americans’ freedom first and safety second.

column3: Storm clouds gathering -- your safety, your freedoms and the Obama White House
column4: Freedom is our natural state and is the ultimate natural right.

column3: Storm clouds gathering -- your safety, your freedoms and the Obama White House
column4: Safety is a need that we ourselves can provide when unimpeded by the government.

column3: Storm clouds gathering -- your safety, your freedoms and the Obama White House
column4: If the president keeps us safe but not free, he is not doing his job.

column3: Storm clouds gathering -- your safety, your freedoms and the Obama White House
column4: Do you know anyone who feels freer or even any safer because the government trampled personal freedoms and so far has gotten away with it?

column3: Storm clouds gathering -- your safety, your freedoms and the Obama White House
column4: Andrew P. Napolitano, a former judge of the Superior Court of New Jersey, is the senior judicial analyst at Fox News Channel.

column3: Benghazi: New Emails Confirm State Dep't Drove Political Edits to Talking Points
column4: The emails confirm the ABC News report that the so-called "talking points" written by the CIA on the attack underwent extensive revisions – 12 versions – and that substantial changes were made after the State Department expressed concerns.

column3: Benghazi: New Emails Confirm State Dep't Drove Political Edits to Talking Points
column4: The early versions of the talking points, drafted entirely by the CIA, included references to the al Qaeda affiliate Ansar al-Sharia and to previous CIA warnings about terror threats in Benghazi.

column3: Benghazi: New Emails Confirm State Dep't Drove Political Edits to Talking Points
column4: State Department spokesman Victoria Nuland expressed concerns about including those references in the talking points.

column3: Benghazi: New Emails Confirm State Dep't Drove Political Edits to Talking Points
column4: In one email, previously reported by ABC News, Nuland said that including the CIA warnings "could be used by Members [of Congress] to beat the State Department for not paying attention to Agency warnings so why do we want to feed that?

column3: Benghazi: New Emails Confirm State Dep't Drove Political Edits to Talking Points
column4: Concerned …" After some changes were made, Nuland was still not satisfied.

column3: Benghazi: New Emails Confirm State Dep't Drove Political Edits to Talking Points
column4: "These don't resolve all my issues or those of my building leadership," Nuland wrote.

column3: Benghazi: New Emails Confirm State Dep't Drove Political Edits to Talking Points
column4: A senior administration official said that Deputy CIA Director Mike Morrell agreed with Nuland's concerns and made the changes himself.

column3: Benghazi: New Emails Confirm State Dep't Drove Political Edits to Talking Points
column4: There is no email record, however, showing that Morrell shared Nuland's concerns.

column3: Benghazi: New Emails Confirm State Dep't Drove Political Edits to Talking Points
column4: The emails do show that the erroneous "spontaneous demonstrations" talking point was included in the original, CIA-produced drafts.

column3: Benghazi: New Emails Confirm State Dep't Drove Political Edits to Talking Points
column4: However, references to terrorist involvement and prior security warnings were erased at the behest of the State Department, based on nakedly political considerations.

column3: Benghazi: New Emails Confirm State Dep't Drove Political Edits to Talking Points
column4: Note, too, that many of these 100 pages were duplicative, and do not cover the key deliberations of September 12th and 13th -- the days immediately following the attack.

column3: State fretted over Benghazi talking points
column4: Updated 05/16/2013 10:50 PM EDT As the number of people handling the Benghazi talking points grew, the amount of information the document offered shrank.

column3: State fretted over Benghazi talking points
column4: Emails and documents released by the White House Wednesday reveal an editing process that valued caution over comprehensiveness as officials worked to remove language that would have assigned blame for the attack or suggested ways the incident could have been prevented.

column3: State fretted over Benghazi talking points
column4: The release also showed that the CIA, and not the State Department, made the decision to scrub references to Al Qaeda, Al Qaeda-linked groups and prior terrorist attacks in the region.

column3: State fretted over Benghazi talking points
column4: Story Continued Below But the newly public email chains suggest it was the State Department that was most concerned about taking the blame for the attack.

column3: State fretted over Benghazi talking points
column4: State Department spokeswoman Victoria Nuland sought changes to the talking points that would shield the agency — then led by Secretary of State Hillary Clinton — from congressional accusations that it had failed to properly secure the post, given the unstable situation in that area.

column3: State fretted over Benghazi talking points
column4: ( DOCUMENT: White House records on Benghazi talking points) At one point, Nuland even wrote to a chain of administration officials relaying her concern that the talking points could be used as a cudgel against the State Department.

column3: State fretted over Benghazi talking points
column4: It includes language stating that “we do know that Islamic extremists with ties to al-Qa’ida participated in the attack.” That first draft also cites “initial press reporting” that “linked the attack to Ansar al-Sharia,” an Islamic militia group based in Libya, and said the U.S. could not “rule out that individuals had previously surveilled the US facilities, also contributing to the efficacy of the attacks.” ( Also on POLITICO: W.H.

column3: State fretted over Benghazi talking points
column4: Benghazi documents point to CIA) It describes the attacks as “spontaneously inspired by the protests at the US Embassy in Cairo and evolved into a direct assault against the US Consulate and subsequently its annex,” and noted that “on 10 September we warned of social media reports calling for a demonstration in front of the Embassy and that jihadists were threatening to break into the embassy.” 4:20 p.m.: Stephen Preston, the CIA’s general counsel, responds that U.S. officials should avoid making any statements that suggested specific groups were responsible for the attack: “In light of the criminal investigation, we are not to generate statements with assessments as to who did this, etc.

column3: State fretted over Benghazi talking points
column4: — even internally, not to mention for public release.” 4:42 p.m.: In email traffic within the CIA, Morell scrubbed the talking points of the Al Qaeda reference, changing the language to read that the “crowd almost certainly was a mix of individuals from across many sectors of Libyan society.

column3: Holder lashes out at Issa during tense hearing -calls conduct shameful
column4: WASHINGTON –  Eric Holder lashed out at his chief antagonist Wednesday at a congressional hearing where the attorney general was questioned on recent administration scandals, telling Republican Rep. Darrell Issa at the end of a tense exchange that his conduct is "shameful."

column3: Holder lashes out at Issa during tense hearing -calls conduct shameful
column4: Holder’s comments came after Issa accused him of purposely and repeatedly keeping information from Congress.

column3: Holder lashes out at Issa during tense hearing -calls conduct shameful
column4: “No, that’s what you typically do,” Holder responded.

column3: Holder lashes out at Issa during tense hearing -calls conduct shameful
column4: Following crosstalk, Holder added, “That is inappropriate and is too consistent with the way in which you conduct yourself as a member of Congress.

column3: Holder lashes out at Issa during tense hearing -calls conduct shameful
column4: It’s unacceptable and it’s shameful.” The heated exchange with the lawmaker who led the charge against Holder regarding the botched Operation Fast and Furious came during a House Judiciary Committee hearing that examined a new set of scandals.

column3: Holder lashes out at Issa during tense hearing -calls conduct shameful
column4: Holder was grilled on a series of allegations, including the way the agency tried to find out who was behind a government leak to The Associated Press.

column3: Holder lashes out at Issa during tense hearing -calls conduct shameful
column4: The AP, along with several lawmakers, say the Justice Department infringed on the constitutional rights of the press when it secretly obtained two months' worth of phone records.

column3: Holder lashes out at Issa during tense hearing -calls conduct shameful
column4: Lawmakers tried to get answers out of Holder Wednesday but voiced frustration after Holder repeatedly rebuffed questions by claiming he wasn’t involved in the decision-making process.

column3: Holder lashes out at Issa during tense hearing -calls conduct shameful
column4: Wisconsin Rep. James Sensenbrenner was among the group of bipartisan lawmakers who pressed Holder on why the Justice Department secretly collected telephone records.

column3: Holder lashes out at Issa during tense hearing -calls conduct shameful
column4: Holder said he had recused himself from the case because "I am a possessor of information eventually leaked."

column3: Holder lashes out at Issa during tense hearing -calls conduct shameful
column4: He also said he was unable to answer any questions on why the department he oversees failed to negotiate with the AP prior to obtaining subpoenas -- something which is standard practice in these cases.

column3: Holder lashes out at Issa during tense hearing -calls conduct shameful
column4: Holder testified that all the decisions made in the case fell on Deputy Attorney General James Cole’s shoulders.

column3: Holder lashes out at Issa during tense hearing -calls conduct shameful
column4: Sensenbrenner then suggested having Cole testify before the House Judiciary Committee.

column3: Holder lashes out at Issa during tense hearing -calls conduct shameful
column4: While Congress could call Cole to testify, he would be prohibited from discussing any ongoing case.

column3: Holder lashes out at Issa during tense hearing -calls conduct shameful
column4: His testimony would likely yield few answers.

column3: Holder lashes out at Issa during tense hearing -calls conduct shameful
column4: "There doesn't appear to be any acceptance of responsibility for things that have gone wrong," Sensenbrenner said, after suggesting administration officials travel to the Harry Truman Presidential Library and take a photo of the famous sign, "the buck stops here."

column3: Holder lashes out at Issa during tense hearing -calls conduct shameful
column4: Rep. John Conyers, D-Mich., said he was "troubled by the notion that our government would pursue a broad array of phone records over a period of time."

column3: Holder lashes out at Issa during tense hearing -calls conduct shameful
column4: But like Sensenbrenner, he was unable to pull any new information about the AP case from Holder.

column3: Holder lashes out at Issa during tense hearing -calls conduct shameful
column4: On Monday, AP President and CEO Gary Pruitt disclosed the government’s action in a letter to Holder that was made public.

column3: Holder lashes out at Issa during tense hearing -calls conduct shameful
column4: In it, Pruitt called the collection of phone records at four AP bureaus a “massive and unprecedented intrusion” of the news agency’s freedom of press rights granted under the U.S. Constitution.

column3: Holder lashes out at Issa during tense hearing -calls conduct shameful
column4: The AP case immediately sparked bipartisan outrage, leading members of both parties to publicly question the government’s actions.

column3: Holder lashes out at Issa during tense hearing -calls conduct shameful
column4: Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus said the attorney general should resign over the issue, adding: "Freedom of the press is an essential right in a free society."

column3: Holder lashes out at Issa during tense hearing -calls conduct shameful
column4: Holder acknowledged Priebus’s calls for his resignation during his opening remarks, though again noted that he was not behind the subpoena.

column3: Holder lashes out at Issa during tense hearing -calls conduct shameful
column4: On Wednesday, New York Sen. Charles Schumer said he plans to reintroduce legislation that would protect journalists from revealing their sources.

column3: Holder lashes out at Issa during tense hearing -calls conduct shameful
column4: The bill, which was brought up in 2009, has since stalled in Congress.

column3: Holder lashes out at Issa during tense hearing -calls conduct shameful
column4: The Obama administration has been very aggressive in going after government workers leaking classified information.

column3: Holder lashes out at Issa during tense hearing -calls conduct shameful
column4: To date, the White House has brought indictments against five workers.

column3: Holder lashes out at Issa during tense hearing -calls conduct shameful
column4: The Defense Department is pursuing a sixth case against the U.S. Army soldier accused of sending classified documents to the anti-secrecy online group WikiLeaks.

column3: Holder lashes out at Issa during tense hearing -calls conduct shameful
column4: Under Holder’s command, the Justice Department has prosecuted more government officials for alleged leaks under the World War I-era Espionage Act than all of the AGs who came before him – combined.

column3: Projected lower deficit could slow any budget deal
column4: WASHINGTON (AP) — The good news is the budget deficit for the current year is projected to come in well below what was estimated just a few months ago.

column3: Projected lower deficit could slow any budget deal
column4: The bad news for deficit hawks is that the development could further curb the already slowing momentum for a budget pact this year.

column3: Projected lower deficit could slow any budget deal
column4: A Congressional Budget Office study released Tuesday cites higher tax revenues and better-than-expected payments from government-controlled mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac as the key reasons for this year's improved outlook.

column3: Projected lower deficit could slow any budget deal
column4: The budget office now predicts a 2013 budget deficit of $642 billion, more than $200 billion below its February estimate.

column3: Projected lower deficit could slow any budget deal
column4: This year's shortfall would register at 4 percent of the economy, far less than the 10.1 percent experienced in 2009, when the government ran a record $1.4 trillion deficit.

column3: Projected lower deficit could slow any budget deal
column4: While the recovering economy is producing greater revenues, the improving deficit picture also reflects the accumulating effects of prior rounds of spending cuts — mostly tamping down day-to-day agency budgets — and January's tax hike on wealthier earners.

column3: Projected lower deficit could slow any budget deal
column4: Often lost amid Washington's budget battles is that the nation's dysfunctional capital city actually has had success in cutting the deficit — up to $3.9 trillion over the upcoming decade, depending on how one does the math.

column3: Projected lower deficit could slow any budget deal
column4: Now, the improving picture seems likely to make it more difficult for events to force Washington's exhausted budget combatants closer to a deal.

column3: Projected lower deficit could slow any budget deal
column4: For starters, it means that the deadline for increasing the government's borrowing cap has been postponed until October or November, the CBO said.

column3: Projected lower deficit could slow any budget deal
column4: It had been expected that lawmakers would have had to act this summer to increase the so-called debt limit, which could have been a catalyst for a broader budget deal.

column3: Projected lower deficit could slow any budget deal
column4: Last year's deficit was $1.1 trillion, capping four consecutive trillion dollar-plus deficits during President Barack Obama's first term.

column3: Projected lower deficit could slow any budget deal
column4: The accumulated federal debt currently exceeds $16 trillion, almost double what is was at the end of 2006.

column3: Projected lower deficit could slow any budget deal
column4: The deficit picture is expected to continue to improve next year and beyond, with the 2015 deficit now projected at $378 billion, just 2.1 percent of the economy.

column3: Projected lower deficit could slow any budget deal
column4: All told, the budget office predicts deficits over the coming decade of $6.3 trillion, down $618 billion from earlier projections.

column3: Projected lower deficit could slow any budget deal
column4: The CBO report comes as Washington has again hit budget gridlock after enacting a $600 billion-plus tax increase on upper-bracket earners in January.

column3: Projected lower deficit could slow any budget deal
column4: The report could sap momentum from further deficit-cutting efforts since the shortage will fall below 3 percent of the economy for several years, levels considered by many economists to be sustainable.

column3: Projected lower deficit could slow any budget deal
column4: The deficit cuts enacted in previous, hard-fought battles between Obama and Republicans have come disproportionately from the category of the federal budget known as "discretionary" spending.

column3: Projected lower deficit could slow any budget deal
column4: That's the money provided annually in congressional appropriations acts.

column3: Projected lower deficit could slow any budget deal
column4: Such funding goes toward the day-to-day operations of government agencies, including the Pentagon and domestic agencies.

column3: Projected lower deficit could slow any budget deal
column4: Examples include federal aid to schools, medical research, the military and operating national parks and the air traffic control system.

column3: Projected lower deficit could slow any budget deal
column4: The cuts to discretionary programs began in 2011 with two rounds of appropriations bills that have wrung more than $1.5 trillion from projected agency spending over the 2014-2023 time frame.

column3: Projected lower deficit could slow any budget deal
column4: Such savings generally are claimed by taking away much of the inflation increases assumed under Washington's arcane budget rules.

column3: Projected lower deficit could slow any budget deal
column4: There's an additional $300 billion in interest savings because the government has to borrow less money.

column3: Projected lower deficit could slow any budget deal
column4: And $850 billion in deficit cuts over the coming decade comes from the January tax increase on higher-bracket earners and commensurate interest savings.

column3: Projected lower deficit could slow any budget deal
column4: Added to the cuts to agency budgets, and there's a total of $2.7 trillion in deficit savings There's disagreement over how to count $1.2 trillion in additional deficit savings over a decade from across-the-board cuts known as sequestration, which result from the failure of a 2011 deficit "supercommittee" to agree on a plan to replace them.

column3: Projected lower deficit could slow any budget deal
column4: The original idea behind the cuts was that they would be so harsh as to drive the supercommittee to strike a deal.

column3: Projected lower deficit could slow any budget deal
column4: A subsequent "fiscal cliff" solution in January only partially repealed the sequester cuts.

column3: Projected lower deficit could slow any budget deal
column4: Democrats leave the sequester out of their calculations, preferring to replace them in their entirety.

column3: Projected lower deficit could slow any budget deal
column4: But under the rules binding the CBO, the nonpartisan agency that does economic and budget analysis for Congress, they are included in official projections.

column3: Projected lower deficit could slow any budget deal
column4: If one adds in the sequester savings, the amount of already accomplished deficit reduction — measured over the upcoming 2014-2023 budget window — gets as high as $3.9 trillion.

column3: Projected lower deficit could slow any budget deal
column4: The White House's math is a little different, but top advisers to Obama say much of the deficit problem is taken care of.

column3: Projected lower deficit could slow any budget deal
column4: "We have already achieved $2.5 trillion in deficit reduction and believe achieving $1.5 trillion-$1.8 trillion more in a balanced way is the best way to hit that target," White House economic adviser Gene Sperling said in a White House online chat earlier this year.

column3: Projected lower deficit could slow any budget deal
column4: By Sperling's calculations, finding $1.2 trillion in spending cuts or new revenues to eliminate the across-the-board sequester cuts would solve most of the remaining problem.

column3: Projected lower deficit could slow any budget deal
column4: One of the reasons for the burst of additional income tax revenues, the budget office says, is that upper-income taxpayers claimed more income late last year in order to avoid paying the higher capital gains tax rates enacted in January.

column3: Projected lower deficit could slow any budget deal
column4: The CBO predicts that publicly held U.S. debt, currently estimated at 75 percent of gross domestic product, will shrink to 71 percent of gross domestic product over 2017-2019 before inching up again at decade's end.

column3: Projected lower deficit could slow any budget deal
column4: As recently as 2007, the budget office notes, federal debt was just 36 percent of GDP.

column3: Projected lower deficit could slow any budget deal
column4: "Such high and rising debt later in the coming decade would have serious negative consequences," the CBO says, citing longstanding arguments that high deficits and debt reduce national saving and investment and increase the risk of a full-blown fiscal crisis.

column3: Deficit projection reduced to $642 billion, CBO says
column4: The federal budget deficit will plummet to $642 billion this year, congressional budget analysts said Tuesday, reducing their previous forecast by roughly $200 billion.

column3: Deficit projection reduced to $642 billion, CBO says
column4: The Congressional Budget Office credited recovering tax revenues and a one-time infusion of cash from mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac for the dramatic reduction, which puts the nation on track for its smallest deficits since the economic crisis hit in 2008.

column3: Deficit projection reduced to $642 billion, CBO says
column4: Moreover, the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office predicts that the deficit will continue to shrink, falling below 3 percent of the overall economy by 2015, a level economists consider to be economically sustainable.

column3: Deficit projection reduced to $642 billion, CBO says
column4: While the CBO forecasts that deficits will begin rising again by the end of the decade as the baby boom generation taps into Social Security and Medicare, the sunnier outlook is calming Washington’s urgency in pushing for debt reduction.

column3: Senate Leaders Say Congress Able to Handle IRS Probe
column4: U.S. Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell said on Tuesday that Congress is "fully capable" of handling by itself an investigation of the Internal Revenue Service.

column3: Senate Leaders Say Congress Able to Handle IRS Probe
column4: McConnell made the comment when asked by reporters if he saw any need to have a special prosecutor named to examine the tax-collection agency's targeting of conservative groups.

column3: Senate Leaders Say Congress Able to Handle IRS Probe
column4: U.S. Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid echoed those same sentiments Tuesday, saying he believed IRS chief Steven Miller was doing a good job.

column3: Senate Leaders Say Congress Able to Handle IRS Probe
column4: While some Republicans have called for the resignation of Miller, Reid, a Nevada Democrat, told journalists, "As far as I know he is doing a good job" The Department of Justice is working with the Federal Bureau of Investigation to probe the Internal Revenue Service over its targeting of conservative political groups.

column3: Fact-checking claims about the attacks in Benghazi
column4: House Republicans held hearings last week on the 2012 attacks on a diplomatic outpost in Benghazi, Libya.

column3: Fact-checking claims about the attacks in Benghazi
column4: That's renewed a war of words between members of Congress and President Barack Obama.

column3: Fact-checking claims about the attacks in Benghazi
column4: Here's the history: Diplomatic workers staffed a temporary residential outpost in the Libyan city after the death of dictator Moammar Gadhafi.

column3: Fact-checking claims about the attacks in Benghazi
column4: On a night the U.S. ambassador was visiting from the capital in Tripoli, armed Islamic terrorists attacked, setting a toxic diesel-fueled fire that killed the ambassador and a colleague.

column3: Fact-checking claims about the attacks in Benghazi
column4: Americans then drove, chased by attackers, to a nearby annex, where a mortar attack in the morning killed two security contractors.

column3: Fact-checking claims about the attacks in Benghazi
column4: By noon, hasty scrambling by the American and Libyan governments got U.S. workers to safety in Tripoli, along with their four dead comrades.

column3: Fact-checking claims about the attacks in Benghazi
column4: That "annex" was a compound used by the CIA.

column3: Fact-checking claims about the attacks in Benghazi
column4: So, while we’ve seen unclassified reports from a State Department accountability review board, a Senate committee and some House Republicans, and watched testimony before Rep. Darrell Issa’s House committee last week — there’s a layer of secrecy that daunts diplomats and lawmakers alike.

column3: Fact-checking claims about the attacks in Benghazi
column4: We've fact-checked several new claims this week.

column3: Fact-checking claims about the attacks in Benghazi
column4: On May 6, 2013, Rep. Jason Chaffetz, R-Utah, told Fox News that more could have been done that night.

column3: Fact-checking claims about the attacks in Benghazi
column4: "We had people that were getting killed, we had people who are willing to risk their lives to go save them and somebody told them to stand down."

column3: Fact-checking claims about the attacks in Benghazi
column4: Chaffetz said the order was "as sickening and depressing and disgusting as anything I have seen."

column3: Fact-checking claims about the attacks in Benghazi
column4: But the order to keep special forces in Tripoli came after the deaths in Benghazi had already occurred.

column3: Fact-checking claims about the attacks in Benghazi
column4: The mortar attack was over at that point.

column3: Fact-checking claims about the attacks in Benghazi
column4: We rated his statement False.

column3: Fact-checking claims about the attacks in Benghazi
column4: On May 10, Obama's press secretary, Jay Carney, defended the administration against renewed charges that United Nations Ambassador Susan Rice had downplayed the possibility that extremists were involved in the attacks soon after it happened.

column3: Fact-checking claims about the attacks in Benghazi
column4: "Susan Rice, when she went out on the Sunday shows using the very talking points that we're discussing now, talked about the possibility that we knew that, or believed based on the intelligence assessment, that extremists were involved ...

column3: Fact-checking claims about the attacks in Benghazi
column4: Ambassador Rice, in those shows, talked about the possibility that al-Qaida might be involved, or other al-Qaida affiliates might be involved, or non-al-Qaida Libyan extremists (might be involved), which I think demonstrates that there was no effort to play that down."

column3: Fact-checking claims about the attacks in Benghazi
column4: We pulled Rice's comments and found Carney's recollection was not accurate.

column3: Fact-checking claims about the attacks in Benghazi
column4: We found that Rice barely mentioned the potential role of al-Qaida or one of its affiliates, and she urged caution about jumping to conclusions on the one occasion in which she did.

column3: Fact-checking claims about the attacks in Benghazi
column4: We rated Carney's comment Mostly False.

column3: Fact-checking claims about the attacks in Benghazi
column4: On May 13, President Obama said that the facts behind the attacks had been thoroughly investigated by an independent review board.

column3: Fact-checking claims about the attacks in Benghazi
column4: "Over the last several months, there was a review board headed by two distinguished Americans, Mike Mullen and Tom Pickering, who investigated every element of" the Benghazi incident, he said.

column3: Fact-checking claims about the attacks in Benghazi
column4: Actually, the review board did not look at every element of the incident.

column3: Fact-checking claims about the attacks in Benghazi
column4: It looked at most of the security matters involved, but it didn't look at who conducted the attacks or at the administration's public comments in the days following.

column3: Fact-checking claims about the attacks in Benghazi
column4: We rated Obama's statement Mostly False.

column3: Fact-checking claims about the attacks in Benghazi
column4: Finally, we'll look back to an attack made during last year's presidential campaign.

column3: Fact-checking claims about the attacks in Benghazi
column4: Republican candidate Mitt Romney made the charge in a debate that President Obama waited two weeks to call the attack in Libya "terror."

column3: Fact-checking claims about the attacks in Benghazi
column4: We found that Obama did use the word "terror," but that it still took many days for the administration to fully characterize the attack as the work of a terrorist group.

column3: Fact-checking claims about the attacks in Benghazi
column4: We rated the claim Half True.

column3: Eric Holder in the spotlight
column4: Updated 05/15/2013 06:37 AM EDT Attorney General Eric Holder said Tuesday that he’d recused himself from the national security leak investigation in which prosecutors obtained the phone records of Associated Press journalists – but that he’s already started a fresh inquiry into the IRS scrutiny of conservative political groups.

column3: Eric Holder in the spotlight
column4: The comments were the first from Holder or the Justice Department on the twin Obama administration scandals that have burst through in recent days.

column3: Eric Holder in the spotlight
column4: And they come as the Justice Department, and Holder himself, find themselves under increasing pressure.

column3: Eric Holder in the spotlight
column4: Story Continued Below That pressure is likely to grow Wednesday, when the attorney general arrives on Capitol Hill for previously scheduled hearings that have now been reoriented to address the recent inquiries.

column3: Eric Holder in the spotlight
column4: Holder got a preview of his likely Hill reception Tuesday, as both Republican and Democratic senators, including Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.) were critical of the administration’s actions on both fronts.

column3: Eric Holder in the spotlight
column4: ( PHOTOS: Eric Holder’s career) Holder called the original AP story that sparked the probe “a very, very serious leak,” but revealed Tuesday that he had recused himself from the investigation because he had been interviewed by the FBI as part of initial inquiry.

column3: Eric Holder in the spotlight
column4: Explaining his recusal from the leak case, Holder said he took the step “out of an abundance of caution.” “I was one of the people who had knowledge of this matter.

column3: Eric Holder in the spotlight
column4: I have frequent contact with the media,” Holder said.

column3: Eric Holder in the spotlight
column4: He said he stepped aside “to try to make sure this was independent and to avoid even the possibility of the appearance of a conflict.” “I would have been the person leading the investigation,” Holder added.

column3: Eric Holder in the spotlight
column4: “It just seemed better to me to step out.” ( WATCH: Eric Holder's full press conference) The decision to subpoena AP phone records was made by Deputy Attorney General James Cole, said a Justice Department official who asked not to be named.

column3: Eric Holder in the spotlight
column4: The leak probe was launched following an AP story last May about a counter-terrorism investigation in Yemen that involved efforts to bomb an aircraft headed for the United States.

column3: Eric Holder in the spotlight
column4: Holder said Tuesday that leak warranted an aggressive response from the federal government.

column3: Eric Holder in the spotlight
column4: “I have to say this is among, if not the most serious, among the top two or three most serious leaks I have ever seen.

column3: Eric Holder in the spotlight
column4: It put the American people at risk.

column3: Eric Holder in the spotlight
column4: That is not hyperbole.

column3: Eric Holder in the spotlight
column4: It put the American people at risk.

column3: Eric Holder in the spotlight
column4: And trying to determine who was responsible for that I think required very aggressive action,” he said.

column3: Eric Holder in the spotlight
column4: The attorney general said he was not aware of “all that went into the formulation of the subpoena,” but expressed confidence in the Justice Department officials who made the decisions.

column3: Eric Holder in the spotlight
column4: He also said the Obama administration remains supportive of a shield law to protect journalists.

column3: Eric Holder in the spotlight
column4: Holder also disclosed that he’d launched the IRS investigation Friday, calling the agency’s actions targeting Tea Party-related groups “outrageous and unacceptable.” He said the FBI was coordinating with the Justice Department to see if any laws were broken.

column3: Eric Holder in the spotlight
column4: “Those (IRS actions) were, I think, as everyone can agree, if not criminal, outrageous and unacceptable and we are examining the facts to see if they are criminal violations,” he said.

column3: Eric Holder in the spotlight
column4: In a letter to the Associated Press Monday, Cole defended the decision to seek the AP’s phone records.

column3: Attorney General Eric Holder Reveals He Recused Himself From AP Phone Record Investigation
column4: When the floor was opened for questions at a press conference Tuesday, originally about Medicare fraud, reporters focused questions to U.S. Attorney General Eric Holder on the recent revelation of the Department of Justice’s investigation that secretly obtained phone records of Associated Press reporters.

column3: Attorney General Eric Holder Reveals He Recused Himself From AP Phone Record Investigation
column4: As TheBlaze reported from the DOJ’s U.S. Attorneys’ Manual, the “Attorney General’s authorization is normally required before the issuance of any subpoena to a member of the news media or for the telephone toll records of a member of the news media.” Ahead of the press conference, which was scheduled to begin at 1 p.m.

column3: Attorney General Eric Holder Reveals He Recused Himself From AP Phone Record Investigation
column4: ET but was pushed back until 1:30 p.m., it was reported that Holder recused himself of the investigation, meaning he removed himself from the case due to a conflict of interest.

column3: Attorney General Eric Holder Reveals He Recused Himself From AP Phone Record Investigation
column4: When Holder took to the microphone again after announcements regarding Medicare fraud, the first questions launched from reporters were regarding the DOJ’s obtaining of phone records of up to 20 AP reporters and editors over a span of two months.

column3: Attorney General Eric Holder Reveals He Recused Himself From AP Phone Record Investigation
column4: Holder confirmed that early in the investigation that he recused himself out of an “abundance of caution” to avoid the appearance of a conflict of interest because of congressional testimony he had given and his dealings with the news media.

column3: Attorney General Eric Holder Reveals He Recused Himself From AP Phone Record Investigation
column4: Holder placed the authorization of the subpoena to disclose the phone records on the deputy attorney general who was supervising the investigation.

column3: Attorney General Eric Holder Reveals He Recused Himself From AP Phone Record Investigation
column4: “I don’t know all that went into the formulation of the subpoena,” Holder said.

column3: Attorney General Eric Holder Reveals He Recused Himself From AP Phone Record Investigation
column4: But he noted it was a “very serious leak” that prompted the investigation.

column3: Attorney General Eric Holder Reveals He Recused Himself From AP Phone Record Investigation
column4: He said he knew what was compromised in the leak, which gives him the ability to categorize it as one of the most serious or at least within the top three.

column3: Attorney General Eric Holder Reveals He Recused Himself From AP Phone Record Investigation
column4: “It put the American people at risk,” Holder said of the leak.

column3: Attorney General Eric Holder Reveals He Recused Himself From AP Phone Record Investigation
column4: Watch this clip from the conference where Holder says he can’t say how the leak put American’s lives at risk: One reporter heatedly said the revelation of the secretly obtained phone records “leaves us wondering policy-wise if this administration will go after us.” Holder emphasized that going after the press is not the intent of the administration and that he is sure all legal requirements have been met throughout the investigation.

column3: Attorney General Eric Holder Reveals He Recused Himself From AP Phone Record Investigation
column4: “This administration has put a real value on the rule of law and our values of Americans.

column3: Attorney General Eric Holder Reveals He Recused Himself From AP Phone Record Investigation
column4: I think the actions we have taken are consistent with both,” Holder said, addressing the administration’s actions in a variety of divisions.

column3: Attorney General Eric Holder Reveals He Recused Himself From AP Phone Record Investigation
column4: Watch Holder’s response in this clip regarding the Administration’s civil liberties record: Holder also noted that a letter from Deputy Attorney General James Cole would be forthcoming in response to the Associated Press’ letter of protest issued Monday.

column3: Attorney General Eric Holder Reveals He Recused Himself From AP Phone Record Investigation
column4: Holder was also questioned about the scandal regarding the IRS targeting conservative groups.

column3: Attorney General Eric Holder Reveals He Recused Himself From AP Phone Record Investigation
column4: He said he has ordered an investigation to see if there were any criminal violations.

column3: Attorney General Eric Holder Reveals He Recused Himself From AP Phone Record Investigation
column4: Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Priebus earlier Tuesday called for Holder resign, saying he has “trampled on the First Amendment” by allowing the Justice Department to issue secret subpoenas to “spy” on The AP.

column3: Attorney General Eric Holder Reveals He Recused Himself From AP Phone Record Investigation
column4: At the same time, the American Society of News Editors called the actions “outrageous” and “appalling.” In a letter of protest sent to Holder on Monday, AP President and Chief Executive Officer Gary Pruitt said the government sought and obtained information far beyond anything that could be justified by any specific investigation.

column3: Attorney General Eric Holder Reveals He Recused Himself From AP Phone Record Investigation
column4: He demanded the return of the phone records and destruction of all copies.

column3: Attorney General Eric Holder Reveals He Recused Himself From AP Phone Record Investigation
column4: “There can be no possible justification for such an overbroad collection of the telephone communications of The Associated Press and its reporters.

column3: Attorney General Eric Holder Reveals He Recused Himself From AP Phone Record Investigation
column4: These records potentially reveal communications with confidential sources across all of the newsgathering activities undertaken by the AP during a two-month period, provide a road map to AP’s newsgathering operations and disclose information about AP’s activities and operations that the government has no conceivable right to know,” Pruitt said.

column3: Attorney General Eric Holder Reveals He Recused Himself From AP Phone Record Investigation
column4: The Associated Press contributed to this report.

column3: Attorney General Eric Holder Reveals He Recused Himself From AP Phone Record Investigation
