column3: Journalists fume over DOJ raid on AP
column4: Journalists on Monday called the news the Justice Department seized records from phone lines assigned to Associated Press offices and its reporters over a two month period “chilling” and a “dragnet to intimidate the media.” The AP reported the Justice Dept.

column3: Journalists fume over DOJ raid on AP
column4: obtained records that listed incoming and outgoing calls and the duration of those calls for work and personal phone numbers of AP reporters and phone lines for AP offices in New York, Hartford, Conn. and Washington, as well as the main number for AP reporters in the House of Representatives press gallery.

column3: Journalists fume over DOJ raid on AP
column4: The government seized records — which listed incoming and outgoing calls and the call’s length — for more than 20 separate lines assigned to the AP and its reporters, according to the AP.

column3: Journalists fume over DOJ raid on AP
column4: Story Continued Below Fox News’ Greta Van Susteren told POLITICO in an email that the DOJ’s seizure “sounds like a dragnet to intimidate the media,” not a criminal investigation.

column3: Journalists fume over DOJ raid on AP
column4: ( Also on POLITICO: Government seizes AP phone records) “What is stunning is the breadth of the seizure!” Van Susteren said.

column3: Journalists fume over DOJ raid on AP
column4: “If you read the AP President’s letter to DOJ, and if his letter is accurate, the seizure was very broad: 2 months of telephone records involving many who work at AP!

column3: Journalists fume over DOJ raid on AP
column4: 20 phone lines, home and cell?

column3: Journalists fume over DOJ raid on AP
column4: NY, DC, Connecticut employees?

column3: Journalists fume over DOJ raid on AP
column4: That doesn’t sound like a criminal investigation, that sounds like a dragnet to intimidate the media.

column3: Journalists fume over DOJ raid on AP
column4: The US Attorney’s issued statement about the secret seizure was blah, blah, blah.

column3: Journalists fume over DOJ raid on AP
column4: It doesn’t say anything.

column3: Journalists fume over DOJ raid on AP
column4: The DOJ better be following the law and the Constitution.” In a statement on Monday, the DOJ wrote “we take seriously our obligations to follow all applicable laws, federal regulations, and Department of Justice policies when issuing subpoenas for phone records of media organizations.” “Those regulations require us to make every reasonable effort to obtain information through alternative means before even considering a subpoena for the phone records of a member of the media,” the statement read.

column3: Journalists fume over DOJ raid on AP
column4: “We must notify the media organization in advance unless doing so would pose a substantial threat to the integrity of the investigation.

column3: Journalists fume over DOJ raid on AP
column4: Because we value the freedom of the press, we are always careful and deliberative in seeking to strike the right balance between the public interest in the free flow of information and the public interest in the fair and effective administration of our criminal laws.”

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: Lawmakers from both parties sharply questioned the Justice Department over its reported effort to secretly obtain two months of phone records from Associated Press journalists, with House Speaker John Boehner’s office saying “they better have a damned good explanation.” The AP disclosed the department’s actions Monday afternoon, revealing that the news service had recently learned the department obtained records listing outgoing calls for the work and personal phone numbers of AP reporters and various AP offices.

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: In all, the government seized the records for more than 20 separate telephone lines assigned to AP and its journalists in April and May of 2012.

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: Concern about what the AP’s top executive called an “unprecedented intrusion” quickly spanned party lines.

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Patrick Leahy, a Democrat, said he’s “very troubled” by the allegations.

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: “The burden is always on the government when they go after private information -- especially information regarding the press or its confidential sources.

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: I want to know more about this case, but on the face of it, I am concerned that the government may not have met that burden,” Leahy said in a statement.

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: The AP also reported that the Justice Department got records for the main AP number in the House of Representatives press gallery.

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: One congressional source told Fox News this allegation in particular “is not sitting too well” with congressional leadership.

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: House Judiciary Committee Chairman Bob Goodlatte, R-Va., said he plans to ask Attorney General Eric Holder “pointed questions” on the issue at a hearing Wednesday.

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: Boehner spokesman Michael Steel also had pointed words for the administration.

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: “The First Amendment is first for a reason.

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: If the Obama administration is going after reporters’ phone records, they better have a damned good explanation,” he said.

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: The allegations come on the heels of a pair of major controversies for the Obama administration.

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: Fresh testimony and newly released documents last week raised questions about whether top administration officials deliberately distorted the details of the Benghazi attack as they first began providing details to the public last September.

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: Then the IRS acknowledged Friday that it singled out conservative groups like the Tea Party for additional scrutiny as it screened applications for tax-exempt status.

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: House Republican Whip Kevin McCarthy described the AP claims as another blemish for the administration.

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: "I am deeply concerned by numerous reports of misconduct by the administration, from (whistle-blower) testimony regarding Benghazi to the Internal Revenue Service targeting groups based on political ideology and now the Department of Justice monitoring journalists with the Associated Press,” he said.

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: White House Press Secretary Jay Carney referred questions on the issue to the Justice Department, claiming the White House was not involved.

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: “Other than press reports, we have no knowledge of any attempt by the Justice Department to seek phone records of the AP.

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: We are not involved in decisions made in connection with criminal investigations, as those matters are handled independently by the Justice Department.

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: Any questions about an ongoing criminal investigation should be directed to the Department of Justice,” he said.

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: Rules published by the Justice Department require that subpoenas of records of news organizations must be personally approved by the attorney general, but it was not known if that happened in this case.

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: The letter notifying AP that its phone records had been obtained through subpoenas was sent Friday by Ronald Machen, the U.S. attorney in Washington.

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: William Miller, a spokesman for Machen, said Monday that in general the U.S. attorney follows "all applicable laws, federal regulations and Department of Justice policies when issuing subpoenas for phone records of media organizations."

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: But he would not address questions about the specifics of the AP records.

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: "We do not comment on ongoing criminal investigations," Miller said in an email.

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: According to the AP, it was not clear if the records obtained also included incoming calls or the duration of the calls.

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: The exact number of journalists who used the phone lines during that period is unknown, but more than 100 journalists work in the offices where phone records were targeted, on a wide array of stories about government and other matters.

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: In a letter of protest sent to Attorney General Eric Holder on Monday, AP President and Chief Executive Officer Gary Pruitt said the government sought and obtained information far beyond anything that could be justified by any specific investigation.

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: He demanded the return of the phone records and destruction of all copies.

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: "There can be no possible justification for such an over-broad collection of the telephone communications of The Associated Press and its reporters.

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: These records potentially reveal communications with confidential sources across all of the news gathering activities undertaken by the AP during a two-month period, provide a road map to AP's news gathering operations and disclose information about AP's activities and operations that the government has no conceivable right to know," Pruitt said.

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: The government would not say why it sought the records.

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: Officials have previously said in public testimony that the U.S. attorney in Washington is conducting a criminal investigation into who may have provided information contained in a May 7, 2012, AP story about a foiled terror plot.

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: The story disclosed details of a CIA operation in Yemen that stopped an Al Qaeda plot in the spring of 2012 to detonate a bomb on an airplane bound for the United States.

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: In testimony in February, CIA Director John Brennan noted that the FBI had questioned him about whether he was AP's source, which he denied.

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: He called the release of the information to the media about the terror plot an "unauthorized and dangerous disclosure of classified information."

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: Prosecutors have sought phone records from reporters before, but the seizure of records from such a wide array of AP offices, including general AP switchboards numbers and an office-wide shared fax line, is unusual.

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: In the letter notifying the AP, which was received Friday, the Justice Department offered no explanation for the seizure, according to Pruitt's letter and attorneys for the AP.

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: The records were presumably obtained from phone companies earlier this year although the government letter did not explain that.

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: None of the information provided by the government to the AP suggested the actual phone conversations were monitored.

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: Among those whose phone numbers were obtained were five reporters and an editor who were involved in the May 7, 2012, story.

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: The Obama administration has aggressively investigated disclosures of classified information to the media and has brought six cases against people suspected of providing classified information, more than under all previous presidents combined.

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: The American Civil Liberties Union said the use of subpoenas for a broad swath of records has a chilling effect both on journalists and whistle-blowers who want to reveal government wrongdoing.

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: "The attorney general must explain the Justice Department's actions to the public so that we can make sure this kind of press intimidation does not happen again," said Laura Murphy, the director of ACLU's Washington legislative office.

column3: Lawmakers rip Justice Department over AP phone records grab
column4: Fox News' Chad Pergram and the Associated Press contributed to this report.

column3: President Obama waited 3 days to address the IRS scandal. Why?
column4: On Monday, President Obama called the singling out of conservative groups by the Internal Revenue Service "outrageous", adding: "I have no patience with it.

column3: President Obama waited 3 days to address the IRS scandal. Why?
column4: I will not tolerate it."

column3: President Obama waited 3 days to address the IRS scandal. Why?
column4: Obama's strong condemnation of the growing scandal came amid similar denunciations from Democratic elected officials.

column3: President Obama waited 3 days to address the IRS scandal. Why?
column4: Montana Sen. Max Baucus called it an "outrageous abuse of power and a breach of the public’s trust."

column3: President Obama waited 3 days to address the IRS scandal. Why?
column4: West Virginia Sen. Joe Manchin described the IRS' actions as "unacceptable and un-American."

column3: President Obama waited 3 days to address the IRS scandal. Why?
column4: You get the idea.

column3: President Obama waited 3 days to address the IRS scandal. Why?
column4: The question being asked in the political world today is whether the condemnations are too little, too late.

column3: President Obama waited 3 days to address the IRS scandal. Why?
column4: As in, did the Obama Administration -- and other Democrats in the House and Senate -- miss their chance to claim some sort of high(ish) message ground by largely taking a pass on the story when it broke on Friday morning?

column3: President Obama waited 3 days to address the IRS scandal. Why?
column4: Let's revisit how the White House handled the story.

column3: President Obama waited 3 days to address the IRS scandal. Why?
column4: First, press secretary Jay Carney was asked about the story at a press briefing later on Friday.

column3: President Obama waited 3 days to address the IRS scandal. Why?
column4: "If this activity took place, it is inappropriate," Carney said while repeatedly emphasizing that the IRS is "an independent enforcement agency" that has only two political appointees.

column3: President Obama waited 3 days to address the IRS scandal. Why?
column4: Then, on Saturday, Carney issued another, slightly more expansive statement.

column3: President Obama waited 3 days to address the IRS scandal. Why?
column4: "The President believes that the American people expect and deserve to have the very best public servants with the highest levels of integrity working in government agencies on their behalf," it read in part.

column3: President Obama waited 3 days to address the IRS scandal. Why?
column4: "Based on recent media reports, he is concerned that the conduct of a small number of Internal Revenue Service employees may have fallen short of that standard."

column3: President Obama waited 3 days to address the IRS scandal. Why?
column4: Then, silence.

column3: President Obama waited 3 days to address the IRS scandal. Why?
column4: Democrats largely avoided saying or doing anything over the weekend -- even as the story grew worse for the IRS and people like Maine Sen. Susan Collins, not exactly a partisan bomb-thrower, called the episode "absolutely chilling" on Sunday.

column3: President Obama waited 3 days to address the IRS scandal. Why?
column4: We asked around Democratic circles this morning in search of some insight as to the strategy behind most elected Democrats staying (largely) silent while Republicans leapt on the issue like Jamie Lannister jumping into a bear pit.

column3: President Obama waited 3 days to address the IRS scandal. Why?
column4: The White House side of things goes something like this: Carney's main focus in the Friday presser was on the questions raised about the edits made to talking points issued in the wake of the attacks in Benghazi, Libya.

column3: President Obama waited 3 days to address the IRS scandal. Why?
column4: Getting that right was of critical importance and deviating at all from the plan to fully engage on that issue could have had a set of bad political consequences all its own.

column3: President Obama waited 3 days to address the IRS scandal. Why?
column4: The White House also knew that Obama had today's press conference with British Prime Minister David Cameron already on the schedule, an event that would give him/them a chance to adress the IRS issue head on.

column3: President Obama waited 3 days to address the IRS scandal. Why?
column4: And, as Obama himself said today, he only learned of the IRS allegations Friday so offering a blanket condemnation might have been tough in such a short time window.

column3: President Obama waited 3 days to address the IRS scandal. Why?
column4: (There is an argument to be made for a sort of rhetorical middle ground, of course.

column3: President Obama waited 3 days to address the IRS scandal. Why?
column4: The White House could have offered a sort its distaste with the allegations -- much like Obama did today -- over the weekend while also saying that an investigation into the details was ongoing.)

column3: President Obama waited 3 days to address the IRS scandal. Why?
column4: Democratic Congressional strategists offered little in the way of explanation for the relative silence of their incumbents/candidates on the IRS over the weekend other than to say that Senators and House Members typically take their cues from the White House in sticky political situations like this one.

column3: President Obama waited 3 days to address the IRS scandal. Why?
column4: Timing is, of course, many things (if not everything) in politics.

column3: President Obama waited 3 days to address the IRS scandal. Why?
column4: The White House was dealing with a full-frontal assault on Benghazi when the IRS story broke.

column3: President Obama waited 3 days to address the IRS scandal. Why?
column4: Democrats in Congress were wary about getting out in front of a White House that initially played up the "independent" nature of the IRS.

column3: President Obama waited 3 days to address the IRS scandal. Why?
column4: All of which makes sense.

column3: President Obama waited 3 days to address the IRS scandal. Why?
column4: And, all of which allowed Republicans to fill the rhetorical vacuum -- Sen. Mitch McConnell called for a government-wide investigation, House Majority Leader Eric Cantor (Va.) said that hearings would be held -- on an issue that plays into their hands as it is.

column3: President Obama waited 3 days to address the IRS scandal. Why?
column4: Democrats will have to play catch up on the IRS scandal in the coming week.

column3: President Obama waited 3 days to address the IRS scandal. Why?
column4: Of course, if the offending parties within the IRS are let go some time soon that could go a long way to mitigating the Democrats' messaging problem on the issue.

column3: 5 questions on the IRS debacle
column4: A classic Washington scandal is unfolding — complete with accusations of lies, abuse of power and questions about coverups.

column3: 5 questions on the IRS debacle
column4: To add to the intrigue, it involves one of the most hated government agencies: the Internal Revenue Service.

column3: 5 questions on the IRS debacle
column4: Story Continued Below It all started Friday, when an IRS official — in an apparently off-handed remark — acknowledged and apologized for wrongly targeting conservative groups seeking nonprofit status.

column3: 5 questions on the IRS debacle
column4: ( Also on POLITICO: IRS knew of tea party targeting) A firestorm quickly ensued and only deepened over the weekend with revelations that senior IRS officials have known about the targeting practice for several years.

column3: 5 questions on the IRS debacle
column4: Republicans, meanwhile, are calling for additional investigations.

column3: 5 questions on the IRS debacle
column4: Here are five big questions on the rapidly evolving scandal: 1\.

column3: 5 questions on the IRS debacle
column4: What did senior IRS officials know; when did they know it; and were any laws broken?

column3: 5 questions on the IRS debacle
column4: This is what’s clear: Low-level employees in the IRS’s Cincinnati office began flagging conservative groups as early as 2010, according to the Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration.

column3: 5 questions on the IRS debacle
column4: Lois Lerner, who directs the agency’s tax-exempt groups unit, said applications were scrutinized if they included words such as “patriot” or “tea party.” ( Also on POLITICO: Bill would penalize IRS lawbreakers) For now, it appears that the Cincinnati employees took the initiative on their own to start flagging the applications.

column3: 5 questions on the IRS debacle
column4: Lerner has vehemently dismissed GOP accusations that political motivations fueled the program.

column3: 5 questions on the IRS debacle
column4: She said the IRS often centralizes applications that need more study when there’s a sudden growth in similar requests for nonprofit status, but that process wasn’t carried out appropriately this time.

column3: 5 questions on the IRS debacle
column4: Ultimately, about 75 groups were subjected to additional review.

column3: 5 questions on the IRS debacle
column4: Lerner has so far declined to say when she first learned of the targeting practice and told reporters on Friday she didn’t remember when she notified her bosses.

column3: 5 questions on the IRS debacle
column4: ( Also on POLITICO: GOP outrage at IRS grows) But a TIGTA report due out this week will say that senior IRS officials knew about the activities as early as 2011.

column3: 5 questions on the IRS debacle
column4: That would seem to contradict testimony then-IRS Commissioner Doug Shulman provided to Congress in 2012 when he told lawmakers that the agency wasn’t providing extra scrutiny to groups because of their political affiliations.

column3: 5 questions on the IRS debacle
column4: Meanwhile, the details of what the IRS was after are becoming more clear.

column3: 5 questions on the IRS debacle
column4: Lerner said that some of the groups, for instance, were asked for member or donor lists, which isn’t a typical IRS practice.

column3: 5 questions on the IRS debacle
column4: Lerner said it’s not illegal for the IRS to flag groups for extra review when the agency notices a spike in applications from the same type of organizations.

column3: 5 questions on the IRS debacle
5 questions on the IRS debacle
column4: What does this mean for the Obama administration?

column3: 5 questions on the IRS debacle
column4: The IRS developments couldn’t come at a worse time for the White House, which has spent months courting GOP support for everything from gun control to an overhaul of immigration laws.

column3: 5 questions on the IRS debacle
column4: If the administration’s recent GOP charm offensive bought any goodwill, it seems to be on short supply now.

column3: 5 questions on the IRS debacle
column4: Sen. Susan Collins (R-Maine) is exactly the type of moderate lawmaker who might support the administration’s policy goals.

column3: 5 questions on the IRS debacle
column4: But she made clear on Sunday that she isn’t pleased with how the White House — and President Barack Obama in particular — is handling the IRS debacle.

column3: 5 questions on the IRS debacle
column4: “I think that it’s very disappointing the president hasn’t personally condemned this and spoken out,” Collins said on CNN’s “State of the Union.” “The president needs to make it crystal clear that this is totally unacceptable in America.” Meanwhile, Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) has called for Obama to order a “transparent, governmentwide review” to see if similar practices are happening elsewhere in the administration.

column3: Outraged GOP: It's time to audit the IRS; targeting of conservative groups called chilling""
column4: Capitol Hill Republicans on Sunday called the Internal Revenue Service’s targeting of conservative groups “chilling” and demanded a congressional inquiry.

column3: Outraged GOP: It's time to audit the IRS; targeting of conservative groups called chilling""
column4: Sen. Susan M. Collins, Maine Republican, told CNN’s “State of the Union” that the revelation is “truly outrageous” and contributes to the “profound distrust that the American people have in government.” “It is absolutely chilling that the IRS was singling out conservative groups for extra review, and I think it’s very disappointing that the president hasn’t personally condemned this and spoken out,” Ms. Collins said.

column3: Outraged GOP: It's time to audit the IRS; targeting of conservative groups called chilling""
column4: SEE ALSO: Rubio calls for resignation of IRS chief over tea party scrutiny She said President Obama “needs to make crystal clear that this is totally unacceptable in America.” Rep. Mike Rogers, Michigan Republican and chairman of the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence, called the IRS practice a dangerous problem that warrants congressional action.

column3: Outraged GOP: It's time to audit the IRS; targeting of conservative groups called chilling""
column4: “I don’t care if you’re a conservative, a liberal, a Democrat or a Republican, this should send a chill up your spine,” Mr. Rogers said on “Fox News Sunday.” “This is something that we cannot let stand.” SEE ALSO: IRS scandal grows to include debt critics The IRS admitted Friday that some auditors gave heightened scrutiny to applications for tax-exempt status from tea party and other conservative groups during the 2012 election season.

column3: Outraged GOP: It's time to audit the IRS; targeting of conservative groups called chilling""
column4: Lois Lerner, who heads the IRS division that oversees tax-exempt groups, apologized and said the cases were initiated by low-level workers in Cincinnati and were not motivated by political bias.

column3: Outraged GOP: It's time to audit the IRS; targeting of conservative groups called chilling""
column4: But The Associated Press reported Sunday that senior IRS officials knew agents were targeting tea party groups as early as 2011, according to a draft of an inspector general’s report obtained by news outlet.

column3: Outraged GOP: It's time to audit the IRS; targeting of conservative groups called chilling""
column4: Ms. Lerner learned at a meeting in June 2011 that groups with “tea party,” “patriot” or “9/12 Project” in their names were being flagged for additional and often burdensome scrutiny, according to the watchdog report.

column3: Outraged GOP: It's time to audit the IRS; targeting of conservative groups called chilling""
column4: The 9/12 Project is a group started by conservative TV personality Glenn Beck.

column3: Outraged GOP: It's time to audit the IRS; targeting of conservative groups called chilling""
column4: Mr. Beck, in a statement Saturday, said that for more than a year he has been reporting that the IRS unfairly targeted his and other conservatives groups and that “it is nice to see everyone else playing catch-up and finally asking the same questions.” The Treasury Department’s inspector general for tax administration is expected to release the results of a nearly yearlong investigation this week.

column3: Outraged GOP: It's time to audit the IRS; targeting of conservative groups called chilling""
column4: The White House on Friday quickly condemned the IRS practice and said it supports a full review.

column3: Outraged GOP: It's time to audit the IRS; targeting of conservative groups called chilling""
column4: “The fact of the matter is what we know about this is of concern,” White House spokesman Jay Carney told reporters.

column3: Outraged GOP: It's time to audit the IRS; targeting of conservative groups called chilling""
column4: “We certainly find the actions taken, as reported, to be inappropriate.” The Obama administration also moved quickly to distance itself from the independent enforcement agency, noting that the IRS has only two political appointees.

column3: Outraged GOP: It's time to audit the IRS; targeting of conservative groups called chilling""
column4: Ms. Collins said she doesn’t believe the problem is limited to a few rogue IRS employees, noting that groups with “progressive” in their titles weren’t targeted.

column3: Outraged GOP: It's time to audit the IRS; targeting of conservative groups called chilling""
column4: “If it had been just a small group of employees, then you would think that the high-level IRS supervisors would have rushed to make this public, fired the employees involved and apologized to the American people and informed Congress,” she told CNN.

column3: Outraged GOP: It's time to audit the IRS; targeting of conservative groups called chilling""
column4: “None of that happened in a timely way.” Rep. Darrell E. Issa, California Republican and chairman of the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee, said he isn’t satisfied with the IRS apology and that the agency must undergo reforms to ensure such actions aren’t repeated.

column3: Outraged GOP: It's time to audit the IRS; targeting of conservative groups called chilling""
column4: “There has to be accountability for the people who did it,” he said on NBC’s “Meet the Press.” “This mea culpa is not an honest one.” Sen. Dianne Feinstein, California Democrat, also said she is concerned.

column3: Outraged GOP: It's time to audit the IRS; targeting of conservative groups called chilling""
column4: “My understanding is the inspector general is doing a report, that report should be out shortly, and I think we have to take a good look at it,”she said on “Meet the Press.” The Tea Party Patriots, which calls itself the nation’s largest tea party organization, rejected the IRS apology and demanded the immediate resignations of all of those involved in the “deliberate harassment” of tea party groups.

column3: Outraged GOP: It's time to audit the IRS; targeting of conservative groups called chilling""
column4: “We will fight this problem with the IRS and we will win because our freedom depends on our ability to exercise our constitutional rights,” said Jenny Beth Martin, national coordinator for Tea Party Patriots.

column3: Rand Paul accuses Hillary Clinton of 'dereliction of duty' on Libya
column4: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa -- Sen. Rand Paul sharply attacked former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, declaring that her actions in the months leading up to the killing of the U.S. ambassador to Libya last year were "inexcusable, it was a dereliction of duty, and it should preclude her from holding higher office."

column3: Rand Paul accuses Hillary Clinton of 'dereliction of duty' on Libya
column4: His remarks, which drew cheers Friday night from a crowd of about 500 Republican activists gathered here for the party's annual Lincoln Day dinner, previewed what could become an often-heard line of attack if Clinton runs for president in 2016.

column3: Rand Paul accuses Hillary Clinton of 'dereliction of duty' on Libya
column4: Coming from Paul (R-Ky.), who is openly considering his own run, the words illustrated how the debate over the deaths of Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens and three other Americans last Sept. 11 in Benghazi, Libya, has become tied up with the politics of the next campaign.

column3: Rand Paul accuses Hillary Clinton of 'dereliction of duty' on Libya
column4: PHOTOS: The controversy over Benghazi Republicans have been doggedly critical of the Obama administration for its handling of the Benghazi killings, with most of their attention focused on the question of how and why administration officials altered the "talking points" that the U.S. ambassador to the U.N., Susan Rice, used in describing the attacks on Sunday morning talk shows the weekend after the attacks.

column3: Rand Paul accuses Hillary Clinton of 'dereliction of duty' on Libya
column4: While that issue has clearly found a receptive audience among Republican Party activists, it so far has gotten little traction among voters at large, who continue to give President Obama relatively healthy marks for his handling of foreign policy.

column3: Rand Paul accuses Hillary Clinton of 'dereliction of duty' on Libya
column4: Paul, however, focused on a different issue -- one that may be more readily accessible to a wider group of voters.

column3: Rand Paul accuses Hillary Clinton of 'dereliction of duty' on Libya
column4: In the months before the attacks, he noted, the State Department repeatedly had turned down requests from diplomatic personnel in Libya for more security.

column3: Rand Paul accuses Hillary Clinton of 'dereliction of duty' on Libya
column4: Clinton, testifying before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, on which Paul sits, said that the cables asking for additional resources had been handled by lower-level officials in the department and had never reached her desk.

column3: Rand Paul accuses Hillary Clinton of 'dereliction of duty' on Libya
column4: That, Paul said, was exactly the problem.

column3: Rand Paul accuses Hillary Clinton of 'dereliction of duty' on Libya
column4: When asked by committee members whether she had read those requests, "She said, 'No.'

column3: Rand Paul accuses Hillary Clinton of 'dereliction of duty' on Libya
column4: She says, 'I'm busy, I get lots of cables,'" Paul said.

column3: Rand Paul accuses Hillary Clinton of 'dereliction of duty' on Libya
column4: "A I say, Look, I don't expect you to read every cable from Bulgaria or Estonia, but I do expect you from one of the five most dangerous countries in the world, Libya, to be reading those cables.'

column3: Rand Paul accuses Hillary Clinton of 'dereliction of duty' on Libya
column4: " Administration officials have said Congress did not provide enough money to cover all the State Department's security needs, but Paul ridiculed that argument, pointing to examples of other places where State spent money on lesser priorities.

column3: Rand Paul accuses Hillary Clinton of 'dereliction of duty' on Libya
column4: Earlier, in a news conference, Paul compared the Benghazi killings with an earlier foreign policy crisis, the deaths of American military personnel in Mogadishu, Somalia, in 1993.

column3: Rand Paul accuses Hillary Clinton of 'dereliction of duty' on Libya
column4: Left unspoken, but clearly a subtext, was that the incident marked one of the low points of the presidency of Hillary Clinton's husband, Bill Clinton.

column3: Rand Paul accuses Hillary Clinton of 'dereliction of duty' on Libya
column4: The Kentucky senator's speech here is part of a round of visits he is making to states that play a major role in the Republican presidential nominating process.

column3: Rand Paul accuses Hillary Clinton of 'dereliction of duty' on Libya
column4: Next week, he plans a trip to New Hampshire.

column3: Rand Paul accuses Hillary Clinton of 'dereliction of duty' on Libya
column4: He also plans a trip later this month to California, where he will combine fundraising with a speech at the Reagan Library.

column4: The top-ranking Republican on the Senate Armed Services Committee said President Barack Obama could possibly be impeached over what happened in Benghazi.

column4: Sen. James Inhofe (R-Okla.) said in a radio interview Thursday that “of all the great cover-ups in history” — including the Pentagon papers, Iran-Contra and Watergate — Benghazi “is going to go down as the most serious, most egregious coverup in American history.” “We may be starting to use the I-word before too long,” Inhofe said on the Las Vegas-based “Rusty Humphries Show.” “The I-word meaning impeachment?” Humphries asked.

column3: Top GOP Senator Says Obama Could Be Impeached Over Ã¢â‚¬ËœMost Egregious Cover-Up in American HistoryÃ¢â‚¬â„¢

column4: “I’m not talking about it now, this is something that could endure until after the ’14 election — this is not a short story, this is something that was re-discovered after eight months…this is clearly an orchestrated coverup,” he said.

column3: Oh My: IRS Admits Inappropriately" Targeting Conservative Groups in 2012"
column4: Congrats, fellow paranoiacs -- you were right.

column3: Oh My: IRS Admits Inappropriately" Targeting Conservative Groups in 2012"
column4: The AP reports: The Internal Revenue Service inappropriately flagged conservative political groups for additional reviews during the 2012 election to see if they were violating their tax-exempt status, a top IRS official said Friday.

column3: Oh My: IRS Admits Inappropriately" Targeting Conservative Groups in 2012"
column4: Organizations were singled out because they included the words "tea party" or "patriot" in their applications for tax-exempt status, said Lois Lerner, who heads the IRS division that oversees tax-exempt groups.

column3: Oh My: IRS Admits Inappropriately" Targeting Conservative Groups in 2012"
column4: In some cases, groups were asked for their list of donors, which violates IRS policy in most cases, she said.

column3: Oh My: IRS Admits Inappropriately" Targeting Conservative Groups in 2012"
column4: "That was wrong.

column3: Oh My: IRS Admits Inappropriately" Targeting Conservative Groups in 2012"
column4: That was absolutely incorrect, it was insensitive and it was inappropriate.

column3: Oh My: IRS Admits Inappropriately" Targeting Conservative Groups in 2012"
column4: That's not how we go about selecting cases for further review," Lerner said at a conference sponsored by the American Bar Association.

column3: Oh My: IRS Admits Inappropriately" Targeting Conservative Groups in 2012"
column4: "The IRS would like to apologize for that," she added.

column3: Oh My: IRS Admits Inappropriately" Targeting Conservative Groups in 2012"
column4: Lerner said the practice was initiated by low-level workers in Cincinnati and was not motivated by political bias.

column3: Oh My: IRS Admits Inappropriately" Targeting Conservative Groups in 2012"
column4: After her talk, she told The AP that no high level IRS officials knew about the practice.

column3: Oh My: IRS Admits Inappropriately" Targeting Conservative Groups in 2012"
column4: Agency officials found out about the practice last year and moved to correct it, the IRS said in a statement.

column3: Oh My: IRS Admits Inappropriately" Targeting Conservative Groups in 2012"
column4: The statement did not specify when officials found out.

column3: Oh My: IRS Admits Inappropriately" Targeting Conservative Groups in 2012"
column4: Let me see if I'm understanding this correctly.

column3: Oh My: IRS Admits Inappropriately" Targeting Conservative Groups in 2012"
column4: We're told that (a) "low level" IRS workers in Cincinnati established the practice of deliberately flagging "tea party" and "patriot" groups for further scrutiny, (b) this was somehow not "motivated by political bias," and (c) zero IRS higher-ups were aware that this was going on.

column3: Oh My: IRS Admits Inappropriately" Targeting Conservative Groups in 2012"
column4: What a tale.

column3: Oh My: IRS Admits Inappropriately" Targeting Conservative Groups in 2012"
column4: Did this become a national policy, or was it limited to southwest Ohio?

column3: Oh My: IRS Admits Inappropriately" Targeting Conservative Groups in 2012"
column4: The story linked above says that 75 different conservative groups were affected by this supposedly "grassroots" IRS procedure.

column3: Oh My: IRS Admits Inappropriately" Targeting Conservative Groups in 2012"
column4: Also, if the IRS brass discovered the malfeasance last year (coincidentally, an election year), why is the public just finding out about it now?

column3: Oh My: IRS Admits Inappropriately" Targeting Conservative Groups in 2012"
column4: And how can they make the "no political bias" claim with a straight face when it appears that only groups on the Right were ensnared by this?

column3: Oh My: IRS Admits Inappropriately" Targeting Conservative Groups in 2012"
column4: In any case, heads will have to roll over this, right?

column3: Oh My: IRS Admits Inappropriately" Targeting Conservative Groups in 2012"
column4: Wrong: IRS on conf call saying no disciplinary action against employees who targeted tea party groups for extra scrutiny.

column3: Oh My: IRS Admits Inappropriately" Targeting Conservative Groups in 2012"
column4: The senior IRS official briefing the press just said: "I'm not good at math."

column3: Benghazi Debate Focuses on Interpretation of Early E-Mail on Attackers
column4: WASHINGTON — House Republicans on Thursday intensified their criticism of the Obama administration for its handling of the assault on the diplomatic compound in Benghazi, with Speaker John A. Boehner calling for the release of an e-mail that he said showed that State Department officials believed from the start that “Islamic terrorists” were linked to the attack but have declined to say so publicly.

column3: Benghazi Debate Focuses on Interpretation of Early E-Mail on Attackers
column4: Mr. Boehner’s demand, delivered the day after a dramatic hearing by a House committee, signaled that Republican leaders intend to continue portraying the attack as a major failure by the administration as well as a potentially effective issue against former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton if she runs for president in 2016.

column3: Benghazi Debate Focuses on Interpretation of Early E-Mail on Attackers
column4: “The State Department would not allow our committees to keep copies of this e-mail when it was reviewed,” Mr. Boehner said.

column3: Benghazi Debate Focuses on Interpretation of Early E-Mail on Attackers
column4: “I would call on the president to order the State Department to release this e-mail so that the American people can see it.” During Wednesday’s hearing, Representative Trey Gowdy, Republican of South Carolina, read an excerpt from the e-mail, quoting what he said was a reference to the local militant group that carried out the attack, Ansar al-Shariah, as having links to “Islamic terrorists.” But a copy of the e-mail reviewed by The New York Times indicates that A. Elizabeth Jones, the senior State Department official who wrote it, referred to “Islamic extremists,” not terrorists.

column3: Benghazi Debate Focuses on Interpretation of Early E-Mail on Attackers
column4: The distinction is important, administration officials said, because while the White House did not initially characterize the attack as terrorism, senior officials, including Ambassador Susan E. Rice, acknowledged the possibility that extremists had been involved in the assault.

column3: Benghazi Debate Focuses on Interpretation of Early E-Mail on Attackers
column4: Mr. Gowdy and other Republicans dismissed that as a distinction without a difference, saying that the e-mail’s significance was in its timing — the day after the attack — and in its blunt description of what happened.

column3: Benghazi Debate Focuses on Interpretation of Early E-Mail on Attackers
column4: “The group that conducted the attacks — Ansar al-Shariah — is affiliated with Islamic extremists,” Ms. Jones, an acting assistant secretary of state for Near Eastern Affairs, wrote in the e-mail, which was distributed to nine senior State Department officials, though not to Mrs. Clinton directly.

column3: Benghazi Debate Focuses on Interpretation of Early E-Mail on Attackers
column4: The back and forth over a single word suggests the intensity of the political fight between the administration and Republicans over Benghazi.

column3: Benghazi Debate Focuses on Interpretation of Early E-Mail on Attackers
column4: It flared up anew on Wednesday after three State Department officials testified that they faced intimidation and punishment after questioning how the episode was handled.

column3: Benghazi Debate Focuses on Interpretation of Early E-Mail on Attackers
column4: “Four Americans lost their lives in this terrorist attack,” Mr. Boehner said, “and Congress is going to continue to investigate this issue using all the resources at our disposal.” For months, House Republicans have been pressing Mr. Boehner to take a more public stand on the matter, because it fires up the Republican base as lawmakers head into the midterm election cycle.

column3: Benghazi Debate Focuses on Interpretation of Early E-Mail on Attackers
column4: Voters in the most conservative districts often raise the issue, giving the lawmakers fuel to bring back to the Capitol after weekends at home.

column3: Benghazi Debate Focuses on Interpretation of Early E-Mail on Attackers
column4: Six weeks ago, Mr. Boehner convened the heads of all the committees investigating Benghazi for a strategy session on how to keep the pressure on.

column3: Benghazi Debate Focuses on Interpretation of Early E-Mail on Attackers
column4: Also invited was the House majority leader, Representative Eric Cantor of Virginia, as well as three Republican senators who have been outspoken on the attack: John McCain of Arizona, Lindsey Graham of South Carolina, and Kelly Ayotte of New Hampshire.

column3: Benghazi Debate Focuses on Interpretation of Early E-Mail on Attackers
column4: Mr. Boehner’s demand for the e-mail goes to one strand of the dispute: the talking points drafted by intelligence agencies for use by Ms. Rice and other administration officials in providing their initial account of what happened last Sept. 11, when the diplomatic compound came under attack and four Americans, including Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens, were killed.

column3: Benghazi Debate Focuses on Interpretation of Early E-Mail on Attackers
column4: The original talking points described “demonstrations” in Benghazi that were “spontaneously inspired” by an online video lampooning the Prophet Muhammad.

column3: Benghazi Debate Focuses on Interpretation of Early E-Mail on Attackers
column4: The draft identified the suspected attackers as Ansar al-Shariah, with links to Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb, an offshoot of Al Qaeda.

column3: Benghazi Debate Focuses on Interpretation of Early E-Mail on Attackers
column4: The reference to Ansar al-Shariah and Al Qaeda were later deleted from the talking points because, administration officials said, it might tip off the suspects and impede the criminal investigation.

column3: Benghazi Debate Focuses on Interpretation of Early E-Mail on Attackers
column4: The names were replaced with the term “extremists.” Ms. Rice, the ambassador to the United Nations, used the talking points in her appearance on five Sunday news programs the weekend after the attack.

column3: Benghazi Debate Focuses on Interpretation of Early E-Mail on Attackers
column4: She was harshly criticized by Republicans for misleading the public when the White House subsequently characterized the attack as a premeditated terrorist act, not a protest gone awry.

column3: Benghazi Debate Focuses on Interpretation of Early E-Mail on Attackers
column4: Republicans cited the e-mail as evidence that the administration believed this to be the case all along.

column3: Benghazi Debate Focuses on Interpretation of Early E-Mail on Attackers
column4: They noted that Ms. Jones had made no mention of a demonstration or a video featuring Muhammad.

column3: Benghazi Debate Focuses on Interpretation of Early E-Mail on Attackers
column4: The bulk of the e-mail was devoted to a call she had with the Libyan ambassador to Washington, Ali Aujali, over the treatment of the injured Americans and the public reaction of Libya’s leaders.

column3: Benghazi Debate Focuses on Interpretation of Early E-Mail on Attackers
column4: Democrats dismissed the e-mail as a Republican attempt to recycle an issue that Mrs. Clinton addressed last fall.

column3: Benghazi Debate Focuses on Interpretation of Early E-Mail on Attackers
column4: “ ‘Old news’ is an understatement — maybe Speaker Boehner just didn’t realize that this exact same issue was already addressed last October,” said Representative Elijah E. Cummings of Maryland, the ranking Democrat on the House Committee on Government Oversight and Reform, which held Wednesday’s hearing.

column3: Benghazi Debate Focuses on Interpretation of Early E-Mail on Attackers
column4: The State Department said it had expressed concerns to Mr. Boehner’s office about Republicans’ reading of the e-mail.

column3: Benghazi Debate Focuses on Interpretation of Early E-Mail on Attackers
column4: A spokesman, Patrick Ventrell, said, “One of the concerns is, the way the e-mail was read, there was a potential, inadvertent inaccuracy in the use of the word ‘terrorist.’ ” A spokesman for Mr. Boehner, Brendan Buck, said the speaker had not seen the e-mail; the State Department has allowed lawmakers to view it but has not publicly released it.

column3: Benghazi Debate Focuses on Interpretation of Early E-Mail on Attackers
column4: Mr. Boehner has cast that as a breach of Mr. Obama’s promise to cooperate with Congress.

column3: Benghazi Debate Focuses on Interpretation of Early E-Mail on Attackers
column4: Mr. Ventrell said the State Department had provided Congress with 25,000 pages of documents related to Benghazi.

column3: Benghazi Debate Focuses on Interpretation of Early E-Mail on Attackers
column4: Other officials pointed out that the e-mail, which is unclassified, was clearly available to members, given that they were quoting it in hearings.

column3: Benghazi Debate Focuses on Interpretation of Early E-Mail on Attackers
column4: None of this mollified Mr. Boehner.

column3: Benghazi Debate Focuses on Interpretation of Early E-Mail on Attackers
column4: “If there’s clear evidence that the administration knew this event was a terrorist attack immediately, yet told the world a different story for weeks, that document needs to be made public,” Mr. Buck said.

column4: We cannot rule out the individuals has previously surveilled the U.S. facilities, also contributing to the efficacy of the attacks.” In an email to officials at the White House and the intelligence agencies, State Department spokesman Victoria Nuland took issue with including that information because it “could be abused by members [of Congress] to beat up the State Department for not paying attention to warnings, so why would we want to feed that either?

column4: Concerned …” In a addition, a new report by the Weekly Standard says then-CIA director David Petraeus “was surprised when he read the freshly rewritten talking points an aide had emailed him in the early afternoon of Saturday, September 15”: Before circulating the talking points to administration policymakers in the early evening of Friday, September 14, CIA officials changed “Islamic extremists with ties to al Qaeda” to simply “Islamic extremists.” But elsewhere, they added new contextual references to radical Islamists.
