column4: The version Petraeus received in his inbox Saturday, however, had none.

column3: ABC Releases Big Benghazi Report: Talking Points Changed 12 Times, Dramatically Edited by Administration, and Scrubbed of Terror References
column4: The only remaining allusion to the bad guys noted that “extremists” might have participated in “violent demonstrations.” In an email at 2:44 p.m. to Chip Walter, head of the CIA’s legislative affairs office, Petraeus expressed frustration at the new, scrubbed talking points, noting that they had been stripped of much of the content his agency had provided.

column3: ABC Releases Big Benghazi Report: Talking Points Changed 12 Times, Dramatically Edited by Administration, and Scrubbed of Terror References
column4: Petraeus noted with evident disappointment that the policymakers had even taken out the line about the CIA’s warning on Cairo.

column3: ABC Releases Big Benghazi Report: Talking Points Changed 12 Times, Dramatically Edited by Administration, and Scrubbed of Terror References
column4: The CIA director, long regarded as a team player, declined to pick a fight with the White House and seemed resigned to the propagation of the administration’s preferred narrative.

column3: ABC Releases Big Benghazi Report: Talking Points Changed 12 Times, Dramatically Edited by Administration, and Scrubbed of Terror References
column4: The final decisions about what to tell the American people rest with the national security staff, he reminded Walter, and not with the CIA.

column3: ABC Releases Big Benghazi Report: Talking Points Changed 12 Times, Dramatically Edited by Administration, and Scrubbed of Terror References
column4: [Emphasis added] All of the information doesn’t seem to bode well for Press Secretary Jay Carney, who said back in November that only a “single adjustment” had been made.

column3: ABC Releases Big Benghazi Report: Talking Points Changed 12 Times, Dramatically Edited by Administration, and Scrubbed of Terror References
column4: “Those talking points originated from the intelligence community.

column3: ABC Releases Big Benghazi Report: Talking Points Changed 12 Times, Dramatically Edited by Administration, and Scrubbed of Terror References
column4: They reflect the IC’s best assessments of what they thought had happened,” Carney said on November 28, 2012.

column3: ABC Releases Big Benghazi Report: Talking Points Changed 12 Times, Dramatically Edited by Administration, and Scrubbed of Terror References
column4: “The White House and the State Department have made clear that the single adjustment that was made to those talking points by either of those two institutions were changing the word ‘consulate’ to ‘diplomatic facility’ because ‘consulate’ was inaccurate.” Still, Carney is standing by the remarks, and now seems to be carefully clarifying the difference between the White House and the “administration” and noting the CIA still signed off on them.

column3: ABC Releases Big Benghazi Report: Talking Points Changed 12 Times, Dramatically Edited by Administration, and Scrubbed of Terror References
column4: “The CIA drafted these talking points and redrafted these talking points,” Carney told ABC.

column3: ABC Releases Big Benghazi Report: Talking Points Changed 12 Times, Dramatically Edited by Administration, and Scrubbed of Terror References
column4: “The fact that there are inputs is always the case in a process like this, but the only edits made by anyone here at the White House were stylistic and nonsubstantive.

column3: ABC Releases Big Benghazi Report: Talking Points Changed 12 Times, Dramatically Edited by Administration, and Scrubbed of Terror References
column4: They corrected the description of the building or the facility in Benghazi from consulate to diplomatic facility and the like.

column3: ABC Releases Big Benghazi Report: Talking Points Changed 12 Times, Dramatically Edited by Administration, and Scrubbed of Terror References
column4: And ultimately, this all has been discussed and reviewed and provided in enormous levels of detail by the administration to Congressional investigators, and the attempt to politicize the talking points, again, is part of an effort to, you know, chase after what isn’t the substance here.”

column3: The Republicans' Benghazi Obsession
column4: Before Wednesday’s hearing on the attack in Benghazi, Libya, Republicans in Congress promised explosive new details about the administration’s mishandling of the episode.

column3: The Republicans' Benghazi Obsession
column4: Instead, the hearing showed, yet again, that sober fact-finding is not their mission.

column3: The Republicans' Benghazi Obsession
column4: Common sense and good judgment have long given way to conspiracy-mongering and a relentless effort to discredit President Obama and former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton.

column3: The Republicans' Benghazi Obsession
column4: The attack on the lightly protected consulate in Benghazi in September that killed Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens and three other Americans was a tragic event, and Americans should know the full story.

column3: The Republicans' Benghazi Obsession
column4: The most authoritative account, completed in December, came from an independent inquiry, led by two respected and now retired officials — Thomas Pickering, a former deputy secretary of state, and Adm. Mike Mullen, a former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

column3: The Republicans' Benghazi Obsession
column4: Their report was unsparing in concluding that “systemic failures and leadership and management deficiencies at senior levels” in the State Department’s bureaus of diplomatic security and near eastern affairs resulted in a “security posture that was inadequate for Benghazi and grossly inadequate to deal with the attack that took place.” Mrs. Clinton took responsibility for the security failures when she testified at a Congressional hearing in January.

column3: The Republicans' Benghazi Obsession
column4: Wednesday’s hearing, led by Representative Darrell Issa, a Republican of California who is chairman of the House oversight committee, featured three witnesses who testified about those failures.

column3: The Republicans' Benghazi Obsession
column4: One of them, Gregory Hicks, the No.

column3: The Republicans' Benghazi Obsession
column4: 2 official at the American Embassy in Tripoli, was at the embassy the night of the Benghazi attack.

column3: The Republicans' Benghazi Obsession
column4: He said he was later demoted for raising questions about how the incident was handled, a charge the State Department denied.

column3: The Republicans' Benghazi Obsession
column4: The hearing did not prove anything like an administration cover-up or other hysterical allegations of crimes equal to Watergate that some Republicans, such as Representative Steve King and Senator Lindsey Graham, have alleged.

column3: The Republicans' Benghazi Obsession
column4: Republicans have held numerous hearings and briefings on Benghazi and are threatening to hold even more.

column3: The Republicans' Benghazi Obsession
column4: It is a level of interest they did not show during George W. Bush’s administration when there were 64 attacks on American diplomatic targets or in the years they spent cutting back diplomatic security budgets.

column3: The Republicans' Benghazi Obsession
column4: The real scandal is that serious follow-up on security in Libya is going unaddressed.

column3: The Republicans' Benghazi Obsession
column4: Congress needs to make sure that State Department budgets for personnel and security improvements are sufficient and that security reforms are put in place as soon as possible.

column3: The Republicans' Benghazi Obsession
column4: The Senate should move quickly to confirm the ambassador, Deborah Jones, whose hearing was Tuesday.

column3: The Republicans' Benghazi Obsession
column4: Congress and the Obama administration also need to pay more attention to what’s happening in Libya in general.

column3: The Republicans' Benghazi Obsession
column4: After helping opposition forces oust Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the United States seems to have lost interest.

column3: The Republicans' Benghazi Obsession
column4: That is a huge mistake as militias threaten the country’s democratic transition and stability.

column3: The Republicans' Benghazi Obsession
column4: That surely is not an outcome that Ambassador Stevens would have wanted.

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: ANALYSIS/OPINION: When I took Hillary Rodham Clinton to task in January for the mishandling of security in Benghazi, Libya, I told her that if I had been president at the time, I would have relieved her of her post.

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: Some politicians and pundits took offense at my line of questioning.

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: During those hearings, I reminded Mrs. Clinton that multiple requests were sent to the State Department asking for increased security measures.

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: I asked if she had read the cables from Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens asking for increased security.

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: She replied that she was busy and had not read them.

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: I find that inexcusable.

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: Four months later, we are hearing that Mrs. Clinton allegedly withheld information from a counterterrorism bureau during the response.

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: We are hearing new allegations that Special Forces wanting to respond during the attacks were told, “You can’t go” by superiors.

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: Ambassador Stevens‘ deputy, Gregory Hicks, testified this week that he spoke with Mrs. Clinton on the night of the attack, when these orders were given.

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: We are hearing that Mr. Hicks was initially told by the State Department not to meet with congressional investigators.

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: We are, again, hearing allegations that contradict the White House’s story.

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: Benghazi security was a life-and-death matter that resulted in the latter.

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: The notion that high-ranking government officials are somehow beyond reproach, as some suggested during my criticism of Mrs. Clinton, is dangerous and wrong.

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: The secretary of state’s responsibility is to protect our diplomats.

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: Mrs. Clinton should have been relieved of her post for denying pleas for additional security.

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: Almost 20 years ago, President Clinton’s secretary of defense was relieved of his post for a similarly bad decision.

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: In early October 1993, a battle between U.S. forces and Somali militia in Mogadishu left 18 Americans soldiers dead, 80 wounded and two American helicopters shot down.

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: Today, this is remembered as the Battle of Mogadishu or more popularly, “Black Hawk Down,” thanks to a subsequent movie of the same name.

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: A month earlier in September, then-Chairman of the Joints Chief of Staff Colin L. Powell requested soldiers, tanks and armor-plated vehicles to reinforce the mission in Somalia.

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: Secretary of Defense Les Aspin denied these requests.

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: The Associated Press reported the following on Oct. 8, 1993, just days after the Battle of Mogadishu: “Defense Secretary Les Aspin today brushed aside calls for his resignation as ‘the politics of Capitol Hill,’ but conceded that in light of recent casualties, he shouldn’t have rejected a request to send more armor and troops to Somalia last month.” Two months later, after less than a year of service, Aspin resigned as secretary of defense.

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: Though Mr. Clinton cited personal reasons for Aspin’s resignation, it was reported widely that he had asked him to step down.

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: Aspin did ultimately accept responsibility for his decisions, saying, “The ultimate responsibility for the safety of our troops is mine.

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: I was aware of the request and could have directed that a deployment order be drawn up.

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: I did not, and I accept responsibility for the consequences.” By refusing to grant requests for weapons and reinforcement in Somalia in 1993, Aspin made a bad decision, admitted his bad decision, accepted responsibility and eventually left his position as a result of it.

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: When Ambassador Stevens, Libya’s site-security team commander Lt. Col. Andrew Wood and others made repeated requests for increased security and resources in Benghazi, those requests were ignored.

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: No one denies that these requests crossed Mrs. Clinton’s desk.

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: But virtually everyone involved has denied that they should accept responsibility for the tragedy in Benghazi.

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: Now there are new allegations, accusations that arguably bear more significance on how this tragedy unfolded.

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: It is imperative that we continue to ask: Who was responsible?

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: My job as a U.S. senator and as a member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee is to be part of the confirmation process for high-ranking national security positions as well as review the performance of officeholders.

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: When Aspin made bad decisions in 1993, he testified before the Senate, which examined his job performance, and many gave him a bad review.

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: Mrs. Clinton was never above a similar job-performance review.

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: When I asked her in January if her resignation meant that she was finally accepting responsibility, the answer never came.

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: Will the answers ever come?

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: Don’t the victims’ families deserve them?

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: Shouldn’t we do everything in our power to leave no rock unturned in order make sure such bad decision-making doesn’t happen again?

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: Aspin resigned over Black Hawk Down.

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: The same precedent should have applied apply to Mrs. Clinton.

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: To date, no one has ultimately taken responsibility for Benghazi.

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: My office is currently seeking out the witnesses and survivors of Benghazi to testify before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: To date, the Obama administration has refused to let them testify.

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: Too many questions remain unanswered.

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: Now, there are too many new questions.

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: The evidence we had in January already suggested that Mrs. Clinton ignored repeated requests for more security in Benghazi.

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: The new evidence we have today — and that continues to mount — suggests that at the very least, Mrs. Clinton should never hold high office again.

column3: PAUL: The moment of responsibility for Hillary Clinton
column4: Sen. Rand Paul, Kentucky Republican, is a member of the Senate Foreign Relations and Homeland Security committees.

column3: Here Are the 5 Key Things to Take Away From Wednesday's Benghazi Hearing
column4: Three Benghazi whistleblowers appeared before the House Oversight Committee on Wednesday to shed some light on the deadly terrorist attack that claimed the lives of four Americans, including U.S.

column3: Here Are the 5 Key Things to Take Away From Wednesday's Benghazi Hearing
column4: Ambassador Chris Stevens, State Department official Sean Smith and former Navy SEALs Glen Doherty and Tyrone Woods.

column3: Here Are the 5 Key Things to Take Away From Wednesday's Benghazi Hearing
column4: Several stunning revelations were made throughout the hearing, however, there were a few things that stood out.

column3: Here Are the 5 Key Things to Take Away From Wednesday's Benghazi Hearing
column4: Here are the five key things to take away from Wednesday’s Benghazi hearing: One of the biggest points of contention in the Benghazi investigation has been: Why did the Obama administration initially blame the terrorist attack on a YouTube video when there was no apparent evidence to support that theory?

column3: Here Are the 5 Key Things to Take Away From Wednesday's Benghazi Hearing
column4: During the House Oversight Committee hearing on the Benghazi attack, Rep. Trey Gowdy (R-S.C.) read from an email sent by Beth Jones, the acting assistant secretary for Middle Eastern affairs at the State Department, to Benghazi whistleblower Gregory Hicks and other top administration officials.

column3: Here Are the 5 Key Things to Take Away From Wednesday's Benghazi Hearing
column4: In it, she fingered Ansar al-Sharia, a radical Islamic terror group, as the perpetrator behind the attack after the Libyan government speculated that they might be ex-Gadhafi forces.

column3: Here Are the 5 Key Things to Take Away From Wednesday's Benghazi Hearing
column4: The email was sent the day after the attack on Sept. 12, 2012 — well before the Obama administration started pushing the YouTube video narrative.

column3: Here Are the 5 Key Things to Take Away From Wednesday's Benghazi Hearing
column4: “I spoke to the Libyan ambassador and emphasized the importance of Libyan leaders continuing to make strong statements,” the email read.

column3: Here Are the 5 Key Things to Take Away From Wednesday's Benghazi Hearing
column4: “When he said his government expected that former Ghadafi regime elements carried out the attacks, I told him that the group that conducted the attacks, Ansar al-Sharia, is affiliated with Islamic terrorists.” Gowdy said the email was previously unreleased, but not classified.

column3: Here Are the 5 Key Things to Take Away From Wednesday's Benghazi Hearing
column4: Benghazi whistleblower Gregory Hicks repeatedly brought up a man by the name of Lt. Col. Gibson.

column3: Here Are the 5 Key Things to Take Away From Wednesday's Benghazi Hearing
column4: Other than the fact that he was a Special Operations Command (SOC) Africa commander, we don’t know much else about him.

column3: Here Are the 5 Key Things to Take Away From Wednesday's Benghazi Hearing
column4: But more importantly, we don’t know what else he knows about the tragic events of Sept. 11, 2012.

column3: Here Are the 5 Key Things to Take Away From Wednesday's Benghazi Hearing
column4: On the night of the Benghazi attack, Gibson was “furious” when a stand down order was given, preventing Special Forces from intervening in Libya, Hicks testified.

column3: Here Are the 5 Key Things to Take Away From Wednesday's Benghazi Hearing
column4: Hicks said Gibson wanted to bring the Americans trapped in Benghazi home, but was unable to act.

column3: Here Are the 5 Key Things to Take Away From Wednesday's Benghazi Hearing
column4: Does Gibson know who personally issued the stand down order?

column3: Here Are the 5 Key Things to Take Away From Wednesday's Benghazi Hearing
column4: Does he know how far up the chain of command the order originated?

column3: Here Are the 5 Key Things to Take Away From Wednesday's Benghazi Hearing
column4: These are questions to keep in mind as the investigation proceeds.

column3: Here Are the 5 Key Things to Take Away From Wednesday's Benghazi Hearing
column4: Hicks on Wednesday also revealed that he was told by Obama administration officials not to talk with Rep. Jason Chaffetz (R-Utah) unsupervised.

column3: Here Are the 5 Key Things to Take Away From Wednesday's Benghazi Hearing
column4: A State Department lawyer accompanied the delegation and tried to be in every single meeting he was involved in, Hicks claimed.

column3: Here Are the 5 Key Things to Take Away From Wednesday's Benghazi Hearing
column4: Chaffetz, who traveled to Benghazi after the attack to investigate, also claimed back in October that the administration assigned a State Department attorney to follow him in his every “footstep” during his investigative trip.

column3: Here Are the 5 Key Things to Take Away From Wednesday's Benghazi Hearing
column4: Gregory Hicks told members of Congress that he has been “effectively demoted” from his position as deputy chief of mission shortly after he questioned United Nations Ambassador Susan Rice’s explanation that the Benghazi attack was the result of a spontaneous protest sparked by a YouTube video.

column3: Here Are the 5 Key Things to Take Away From Wednesday's Benghazi Hearing
column4: Hicks, the former deputy chief of mission under murdered U.S.

column3: Here Are the 5 Key Things to Take Away From Wednesday's Benghazi Hearing
column4: Ambassador Chris Stevens, now holds the title of foreign affairs officer in the Office of Global Intergovernmental Affairs.

column3: Here Are the 5 Key Things to Take Away From Wednesday's Benghazi Hearing
column4: “In hindsight I think it began after I asked a question about Ambassador Rice’s statement on the TV shows,” Hicks said, after being asked what the “seminal” moment had been in all of his new professional criticism.

column3: Here Are the 5 Key Things to Take Away From Wednesday's Benghazi Hearing
column4: Though some the details are still fuzzy, someone issued a stand down order that prevented Special Forces from traveling to Benghazi to intervene after the attack.

column3: Here Are the 5 Key Things to Take Away From Wednesday's Benghazi Hearing
column4: Hicks, the former deputy chief of mission for the U.S. in Libya and the highest ranking official in the country at the time of the Benghazi attacks, testified that either AFRICOMM or SOCAFRICA issued the stand down order, though he didn’t have a name or where the command originated.

column3: Here Are the 5 Key Things to Take Away From Wednesday's Benghazi Hearing
column4: Hicks said Lt. Col. Gibson, a Special Operations Command (SOC) Africa commander, was “furious” after receiving the stand down order.

column3: Here Are the 5 Key Things to Take Away From Wednesday's Benghazi Hearing
column4: “Lt.

column3: Here Are the 5 Key Things to Take Away From Wednesday's Benghazi Hearing
column4: Col. Gibson was furious.

column3: Here Are the 5 Key Things to Take Away From Wednesday's Benghazi Hearing
column4: I had told him to go bring our people home.

column3: Here Are the 5 Key Things to Take Away From Wednesday's Benghazi Hearing
column4: That’s what he wanted to do,” he said.

column3: Here Are the 5 Key Things to Take Away From Wednesday's Benghazi Hearing
column4: However, the burning question remains: Who, with the appropriate authority, actually gave the stand down order?

column3: Here Are the 5 Key Things to Take Away From Wednesday's Benghazi Hearing
column4: And why?

column3: Behind Mark Sanford's turnaround
column4: Updated 05/08/2013 11:01 PM EDT South Carolinians may not love former Gov.

column3: Behind Mark Sanford's turnaround
column4: Mark Sanford.

column3: Behind Mark Sanford's turnaround
column4: They may still have a bad taste in their mouths after his governorship.

column3: Behind Mark Sanford's turnaround
column4: They may even wonder whether they can entirely trust him.

column3: Behind Mark Sanford's turnaround
column4: But in the end, they decided he was as good as they were going to get.

column3: Behind Mark Sanford's turnaround
column4: Story Continued Below Sanford completed his return from the political graveyard Tuesday night, easily dispatching Democrat Elizabeth Colbert Busch in a deep red district that Mitt Romney won by nearly 20 percentage points.

column3: Behind Mark Sanford's turnaround
column4: ( PHOTOS: Mark Sanford’s career) With many voters expressing misgivings about the former governor, Sanford found a path to victory by turning the race into a referendum on the national Democratic Party instead of himself.

column3: Behind Mark Sanford's turnaround
column4: He put his political gifts to work, wooing skeptical voters in a relentless game of retail politics.

column3: Behind Mark Sanford's turnaround
column4: And he had the advantage of facing a political newcomer whose inexperience at times showed.

column3: Behind Mark Sanford's turnaround
column4: In the end, the nail-biter that late polls hinted at never materialized: Sanford crushed Colbert Busch, 54 percent to 45 percent.

column3: Behind Mark Sanford's turnaround
column4: A turning point in the race came two weeks ago, when Sanford held a mock debate with a cardboard cutout of House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, implying that the California Democrat — persona non grata in conservative South Carolina — was a stand-in for his Democratic opponent.

column3: Behind Mark Sanford's turnaround
column4: ( Also on POLITICO: Sanford defeats Colbert Busch) The former governor endured days of derision from the press for the move — Mark Sanford, once regarded as a viable potential presidential candidate, was debating a piece of cardboard.

column3: Behind Mark Sanford's turnaround
column4: But behind the scenes, Sanford’s aides grinned: Every time a reporter put “Pelosi” and “Colbert Busch” in the same sentence, the Republican was winning.

column3: Behind Mark Sanford's turnaround
column4: And some Democratic aides began to worry, too.

column3: Behind Mark Sanford's turnaround
column4: After months of relentless focus on his personal life — his upcoming marriage to his Argentine fiancée, the charges that he trespassed at his ex-wife’s house and more — the theatrics helped Sanford turn the race into a debate about issues.

column3: Behind Mark Sanford's turnaround
column4: Voters had to make a decision: Was Colbert Busch beholden to the Democratic Party?

column3: Behind Mark Sanford's turnaround
column4: And if so, was that worse than Sanford’s transgressions?

column3: Behind Mark Sanford's turnaround
column4: ( QUIZ: Do you know Mark Sanford?)

column3: Behind Mark Sanford's turnaround
column4: Over the ensuing days, Sanford – in TV ads, on the campaign trail, and in a debate — drove home his message.

column3: Behind Mark Sanford's turnaround
column4: He challenged Colbert Busch to say how she would differentiate herself from Pelosi.

column3: Behind Mark Sanford's turnaround
column4: And he hammered her for accepting campaign help from Washington-based groups like the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee and House Majority PAC, which combined to spend nearly $1 million on the TV airwaves against him.

column3: Behind Mark Sanford's turnaround
column4: As he greeted a lunchtime crowd in Charleston last week, Sanford told one supporter that his fight was against Washington Democrats who were “pouring acid on my head every day.” There was something else playing in Sanford’s favor — his political instincts.

column3: Behind Mark Sanford's turnaround
column4: For all his flaws, his fiercest critics concede, few are better at retail politics.

column3: Behind Mark Sanford's turnaround
column4: In 1994, Sanford — then a 34-year-old real estate investor and political newcomer — launched his first campaign for Congress, traveling up and down the South Carolina coastline in an exhausting push to introduce himself to voters.

column3: Behind Mark Sanford's turnaround
column4: This time, Sanford was, in a sense, running from scratch once again.

column3: Behind Mark Sanford's turnaround
column4: Without the trappings of the governorship, he hop-scotched the Lowcountry in a black van driven by an aide.

column3: Behind Mark Sanford's turnaround
column4: After spending a year in obscurity, he was reintroducing himself to voters — soothing the concerns of voters who still felt squeamish about what he had done.

column3: Behind Mark Sanford's turnaround
column4: CORRECTION: Corrected by: Nick Gass @ 05/07/2013 10:42 PM CORRECTION: Chad Walldorf’s position with Gov.

column3: Behind Mark Sanford's turnaround
column4: Sanford was misstated in an earlier version of this story.

column3: Former S.C. Gov. Sanford headed back to Congress after defeating Colbert Busch
column4: Former South Carolina Gov.

column3: Former S.C. Gov. Sanford headed back to Congress after defeating Colbert Busch
column4: Mark Sanford — once a rising star in the Republican Party whose career crashed four years ago after a bizarre extramarital affair — capped a remarkable political comeback Tuesday by winning a special election for the state’s open House seat.

column3: Former S.C. Gov. Sanford headed back to Congress after defeating Colbert Busch
column4: Political analysts this week had pegged the race between the Republican and Democrat Elizabeth Colbert Busch — sister of TV comedian and political satirist Stephen Colbert — as a dead heat.

column3: Former S.C. Gov. Sanford headed back to Congress after defeating Colbert Busch
column4: But Mr. Sanford won with ease, capturing 54 percent of the vote, compared with his opponent’s 45 percent.

column3: Former S.C. Gov. Sanford headed back to Congress after defeating Colbert Busch
column4: The South Carolina seat opened up after Gov.

column3: Former S.C. Gov. Sanford headed back to Congress after defeating Colbert Busch
column4: Nikki Haley appointed Rep. Tim Scott to the Senate seat vacated by Jim DeMint, a Republican who left to join the conservative Heritage Foundation, a Washington think tank.

column3: Former S.C. Gov. Sanford headed back to Congress after defeating Colbert Busch
column4: National Republican Congressional Committee Chairman Greg Walden of Oregon saw the result as a bellwether for elections next year.

column3: Former S.C. Gov. Sanford headed back to Congress after defeating Colbert Busch
column4: “These results demonstrate just how devastating the policies of Barack Obama and Nancy Pelosi are for House Democrats in 2014,” Mr. Walden said in a prepared statement.

column3: Former S.C. Gov. Sanford headed back to Congress after defeating Colbert Busch
column4: “Democrats spent more than $1 million trying to elect a candidate who was backed by the Democrat machine, but at the end of the day, running on the Obama-Pelosi ticket was just too toxic for Elizabeth Colbert Busch.” Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee Chairman Steve Israel had a different take, praising Mrs. Colbert Busch for pushing Mr. Sanford into a competitive contest in Republican-dominated district, saying it was a “testament to the strength of Elizabeth Colbert Busch as a candidate and the Republican habit of nominating flawed candidates.” Mr. Israel vowed that Democrats will be “aggressive and drive deep into Republican-held territory this [election] cycle to find districts with flawed Republican candidates where we can compete.” Mr. Sanford, who never has lost a political race, once was mentioned as a possible 2012 presidential candidate.

column3: Former S.C. Gov. Sanford headed back to Congress after defeating Colbert Busch
column4: But his reputation and career unraveled after he infamously disappeared in 2009, supposedly to “hike the Appalachian Trail,” but instead traveled to Argentina to visit his mistress.

column3: Former S.C. Gov. Sanford headed back to Congress after defeating Colbert Busch
column4: He quietly finished his second term as governor in early 2011 and kept a low profile until jumping into the House race this year.

column3: Former S.C. Gov. Sanford headed back to Congress after defeating Colbert Busch
column4: Mr. Sanford’s candidacy seemed to be in trouble last month when his ex-wife, Jenny, filed a complaint accusing him of trespassing on her property during the Super Bowl.

column3: Former S.C. Gov. Sanford headed back to Congress after defeating Colbert Busch
column4: His problems compounded when the National Republican Congressional Committee, the fundraising arm of House Republicans, pulled its financial support from the campaign weeks ago.

column3: Former S.C. Gov. Sanford headed back to Congress after defeating Colbert Busch
column4: But momentum in recent days shifted to Mr. Sanford when he got a boost from several high-profile Republican endorsements, including Mr. Scott, Sen. Lindsey Graham of South Carolina and Sen. Rand Paul of Kentucky, a tea party favorite who is considering a 2016 presidential run.

column3: Former S.C. Gov. Sanford headed back to Congress after defeating Colbert Busch
column4: By Sunday, a poll by Public Policy Polling showed the race had become a tossup, with Mr. Sanford ahead 47 percent to 46 percent.

column3: Former S.C. Gov. Sanford headed back to Congress after defeating Colbert Busch
column4: Two weeks earlier, a PPP survey had Mr. Sanford trailing by 9 percentage points.

column3: Senate Passes Bill to Widen Tax Collection on the Web
column4: WASHINGTON — A bipartisan coalition in the Senate easily passed legislation on Monday to force Internet retailers to collect sales taxes for state and local governments, sending the issue to the House, where antitax forces have vowed to kill it.

column3: Senate Passes Bill to Widen Tax Collection on the Web
column4: But the 69-to-27 vote in the Senate will give the measure significant momentum.

column3: Senate Passes Bill to Widen Tax Collection on the Web
column4: Hundreds of retailers are flying to Washington this week to pressure House lawmakers and counter the arguments of small-government groups, including Grover Norquist’s Americans for Tax Reform, which wields great influence in the House.

column3: Senate Passes Bill to Widen Tax Collection on the Web
column4: “After 20 years, there is finally light at the end of the tunnel for our brick-and-mortar businesses,” said Representative Steve Womack, Republican of Arkansas, and the bill’s House sponsor.

column3: Senate Passes Bill to Widen Tax Collection on the Web
column4: “Saving local retail business depends on it, and it’s now up to the House to act.” The Internet sales tax bill — called the Marketplace Fairness Act — is a rarity in Washington these days, a significant tax measure that has split antitax groups in Washington from reliably Republican Main Street businesses beyond the capital.

column3: Senate Passes Bill to Widen Tax Collection on the Web
column4: That divide has given the measure at least a chance to reach President Obama, who supports it.

column3: Senate Passes Bill to Widen Tax Collection on the Web
column4: With Republicans in Congress equally split, Senator Richard Durbin of Illinois, the Senate’s No.

column3: Senate Passes Bill to Widen Tax Collection on the Web
column4: 2 Democrat, joked Monday that C-Span watchers would see something “historic” and “precedent-setting:” “The Senate is actually going to vote for a bill.” The legislation would allow states to force online retailers with more than $1 million in annual out-of-state sales to collect sales taxes from all customers and remit those taxes back to state and local governments.

column3: Senate Passes Bill to Widen Tax Collection on the Web
column4: States would have to provide software to help calculate the taxes for thousands of jurisdictions.

column3: Senate Passes Bill to Widen Tax Collection on the Web
column4: Its sponsors intentionally kept the bill simple — just 11 pages in length — to ease passage.

column3: Senate Passes Bill to Widen Tax Collection on the Web
column4: In contrast, the Congressional Joint Committee on Taxation on Monday released a 568-page report to the House Ways and Means Committee on options for overhauling the tax code compiled by 11 bipartisan House working groups tackling that issue.

column3: Senate Passes Bill to Widen Tax Collection on the Web
column4: The release was intended to push forward comprehensive tax reform, but it only underscored how difficult a task that will be in a divided Congress.

column3: Senate Passes Bill to Widen Tax Collection on the Web
column4: The Senate Internet tax debate revolved around advocates’ arguments that applying sales taxes online is only fair, since traditional brick-and-mortar retailers must levy such taxes already.

column3: Senate Passes Bill to Widen Tax Collection on the Web
column4: Supporters said the bill was not a tax increase but a guarantee that taxes already owed would actually be paid.

column3: Senate Passes Bill to Widen Tax Collection on the Web
column4: The Senate, they said, was standing up for the right of states to collect taxes as they see fit.

column3: Senate Passes Bill to Widen Tax Collection on the Web
column4: “The first thing we have to make sure everybody understands is this isn’t a tax issue,” said Matthew Shay, chief executive of the National Retail Federation, which pushed for the legislation.

column3: Senate Passes Bill to Widen Tax Collection on the Web
column4: “States determine the level of sales taxes to be collected.

column3: Senate Passes Bill to Widen Tax Collection on the Web
column4: All we want to do is make sure the taxes are collected that are due.” But opponents say they will try to slow the process down in the House and shift the conversation to their issues: fears that the complexity of collecting the taxes will put many Internet retailers out of business or subject them to an avalanche of audits from state and local governments around the country.

column3: Senate Passes Bill to Widen Tax Collection on the Web
column4: In a “Memo for the Movement,” a coalition of 52 conservatives on Monday demanded that House Republican leaders not bring the Senate bill straight to the House floor and also said House conservatives “should reject any bill that expands the authority of out-of-state governments to regulate businesses with regard to online taxation.” Signers included Mr. Norquist, the keeper of the no-new-taxes pledge that almost every Republican in Washington has signed, conservative luminaries including Phyllis Schlafly and Richard Viguerie, and the heads of Heritage Action, the Heritage Foundation’s political arm, the Tea Party Patriots, Americans for Prosperity and FreedomWorks.

column3: Senate Passes Bill to Widen Tax Collection on the Web
column4: “We’re fairly confident that at the very least, we will slow this down,” said Dan Holler, a spokesman for Heritage Action.

column3: Senate Passes Bill to Widen Tax Collection on the Web
column4: “Then we have to make the arguments that can win.” With conservatives in Washington organizing against it, the bill faces an uphill climb in the House, but not a steep one.

column3: Senate Passes Bill to Widen Tax Collection on the Web
column4: The House bill already has 65 co-sponsors, almost half of them Republican, and those Republicans include veteran conservatives like Representatives Joe Barton of Texas and Spencer Bachus of Alabama.

column3: Senate Passes Bill to Widen Tax Collection on the Web
column4: Proponents point to their own conservative supporters, including Al Cardenas, chairman of the American Conservative Union, and Arthur Laffer, a conservative economist.

column3: Senate Passes Bill to Widen Tax Collection on the Web
column4: The House Judiciary Committee chairman, Bob Goodlatte of Virginia, has said he will at least consider the measure.

column3: Senate Passes Bill to Widen Tax Collection on the Web
column4: After the Senate’s passage, Mr. Goodlatte made it clear he would take his time with the legislation and would insist on significant changes.

column3: Senate Passes Bill to Widen Tax Collection on the Web
column4: He suggested he may force more uniformity in sales tax rates and add legal recourse for Internet retailers facing multiple audits.

column3: Senate Passes Bill to Widen Tax Collection on the Web
column4: But he did not indicate he planned to delay the issue in his committee.

column3: Senate Passes Bill to Widen Tax Collection on the Web
column4: Conservative voices in Washington are being countered by reliably Republican business voices from home.

column3: Senate Passes Bill to Widen Tax Collection on the Web
column4: Representative Tom Price, Republican of Georgia and a House conservative leader, said Monday that he was just starting to hear from both sides, including district retailers coming to his office.

column3: Senate Passes Bill to Widen Tax Collection on the Web
column4: Mr. Price said he was undecided on the issue, but he noted the bill would now go to the House Judiciary Committee, not the tax-writing House Ways and Means Committee.

column3: Senate Passes Bill to Widen Tax Collection on the Web
column4: That itself could ease the bill’s passage.

column3: Boehner: Internet Sales Tax Bill Likely DOA
column4: “Moving this bill where you’ve got 50 different sales tax codes, it’s a mess out there,” Boehner, an Ohio Republican, said in a Bloomberg Television interview in Washington.

column3: Boehner: Internet Sales Tax Bill Likely DOA
column4: “You’re going to make it much more difficult for online retailers to be able to comply.” The Senate passed the bill May 6 in a bipartisan vote of 69-27, with support from 21 Republicans.

column3: Boehner: Internet Sales Tax Bill Likely DOA
column4: Asked whether he could back it, Boehner said, “probably not.” A lack of support from the speaker emphasizes the difficulty the measure will have winning House passage, especially in its current form.

column3: Boehner: Internet Sales Tax Bill Likely DOA
column4: The House Judiciary Committee will consider the Senate bill, Boehner said.

column3: Boehner: Internet Sales Tax Bill Likely DOA
column4: “We’ll see what they think,” he said.

column3: Boehner: Internet Sales Tax Bill Likely DOA
column4: “You’re putting in a big burden on some very small businesses.” The measure is backed by Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and other retailers that say it’s unfair to allow many sales made over the Internet or through catalogs to be untaxed.

column3: Boehner: Internet Sales Tax Bill Likely DOA
column4: States lose an estimated $23 billion annually in forgone revenue from uncollected sales taxes.

column3: Boehner: Internet Sales Tax Bill Likely DOA
column4: Resolving Immigration Boehner also said he is “committed” to resolving the debate over curbing illegal immigration and fixing the “broken” system for legally entering the U.S. “We’re going to have votes,” the speaker said.

column3: Boehner: Internet Sales Tax Bill Likely DOA
column4: “We are going to deal with immigration in the House.” While he didn’t say what approach he supports on immigration policy, Boehner said “it’s time to deal honestly with a big challenge.” He said he expects a group of eight House Republicans and Democrats to present their immigration proposal “very soon.” “What I’ve been trying to do is to continue to foster the education and the discussion about how we resolve it,” Boehner said.

column3: Boehner: Internet Sales Tax Bill Likely DOA
column4: “It’s not going to be easy.” The Senate Judiciary Committee will begin considering a separate bipartisan immigration proposal this week.

column3: Boehner: Internet Sales Tax Bill Likely DOA
column4: Boehner reiterated his opposition to increasing tax revenue as part of any deficit-reduction bargain.

column3: Boehner: Internet Sales Tax Bill Likely DOA
column4: He said the focus should be on cutting spending and balancing the federal budget in 10 years.

column3: Boehner: Internet Sales Tax Bill Likely DOA
column4: President’s Role While he has previously said he won’t negotiate with President Barack Obama behind closed doors any more, the speaker said all sides need to have a role in working out an agreement.

column3: Boehner: Internet Sales Tax Bill Likely DOA
column4: “I’ll dance with whoever will dance to solve this problem,” Boehner said.

column3: Boehner: Internet Sales Tax Bill Likely DOA
column4: “So everybody needs to play a role if we’re going to solve this problem.” Boehner sought to deflect criticism from Democrats that by cutting spending the U.S. would risk the sort of damper on growth that European countries have seen after enacting austerity measures.

column3: Boehner: Internet Sales Tax Bill Likely DOA
column4: “We are not Europe, all right?” Boehner said.

column3: Boehner: Internet Sales Tax Bill Likely DOA
column4: “We’re talking about long-term spending problem.

column3: Boehner: Internet Sales Tax Bill Likely DOA
column4: It’s really not going to affect anything in the near future.” “The president wants to go out there and crow about the fact that the economy is growing -- barely,” Boehner said.

column3: Boehner: Internet Sales Tax Bill Likely DOA
column4: “This is not the kind of economic growth that’s going to help our country long term.

column3: Boehner: Internet Sales Tax Bill Likely DOA
column4: You got wages that are stagnant.

column3: Boehner: Internet Sales Tax Bill Likely DOA
column4: You have few opportunities of, if you will, walking up the economic ladder.”

column3: New Jersey Gov. Christie reportedly underwent stomach surgery to lose weight
column4: Chris Christie secretly underwent stomach surgery earlier this year to lose weight for the sake of his family, the New York Post reported Monday night.

column4: “I’ve struggled with this issue for 20 years,” he said.

column3: New Jersey Gov. Christie reportedly underwent stomach surgery to lose weight
column4: “For me, this is about turning 50 and looking at my children and wanting to be there for them.” Christie says he underwent the surgery on the morning of Feb. 16, and was home the same afternoon.

column3: New Jersey Gov. Christie reportedly underwent stomach surgery to lose weight
column4: The lap-band surgery restricts the stomach, causing patients to feel fuller faster.

column3: New Jersey Gov. Christie reportedly underwent stomach surgery to lose weight
column4: Christie declined to tell the Post how much weight he has lost so far, but sources estimate around 40 pounds.

column3: New Jersey Gov. Christie reportedly underwent stomach surgery to lose weight
column4: Christie says he is noticing changes in his appetite after the surgery.

column3: New Jersey Gov. Christie reportedly underwent stomach surgery to lose weight
column4: “A week or two ago, I went to a steakhouse and ordered a steak and ate about a third of it and I was full,” he told the paper.

column3: Can Obama's Jam and Slam Approach Work on Immigration?
column4: “Unfortunately you've grown up hearing voices that incessantly warn of government as nothing more than some separate, sinister entity that's the root of all our problems, even as they do their best to gum up the works; or that tyranny always lurks just around the corner.

column3: Can Obama's Jam and Slam Approach Work on Immigration?
column4: You should reject these voices.” \-- President Obama addressing graduates at The Ohio State University.

column3: Can Obama's Jam and Slam Approach Work on Immigration?
column4: A high-pressure vote on generally popular legislation that arouses deep passions among ideological activists and is doomed to failure in the House: Not a recipe for success in the U.S. Senate.

column3: Can Obama's Jam and Slam Approach Work on Immigration?
column4: But that’s where we’re headed this week as the bipartisan “Gang of Eight” gets ready to roll out the full version of their compromise immigration package, now almost six months in the making.

column3: Can Obama's Jam and Slam Approach Work on Immigration?
column4: Call it the “jam and slam.” First, jam the legislation through the Democrat-controlled Senate and then Slam House Republicans for resisting progress.

column3: Can Obama's Jam and Slam Approach Work on Immigration?
column4: But if you can’t jam, you sure can’t slam.

column3: Can Obama's Jam and Slam Approach Work on Immigration?
column4: America saw the result last month on a gun-control package backed by President Obama as ideology and political pragmatism teamed up to squelch the president’s second big policy push of his second term.

column3: Can Obama's Jam and Slam Approach Work on Immigration?
column4: Like they did on blocking the automatic reductions to increases in federal spending, Senate Democrats declined to fight for the president’s agenda when faced with their own political mortality.

column3: Can Obama's Jam and Slam Approach Work on Immigration?
column4: One might think that the approach would have fallen out of favor, but here we go again.

column3: Can Obama's Jam and Slam Approach Work on Immigration?
column4: If ever the approach was going to work, it would be on this subject.

column3: Can Obama's Jam and Slam Approach Work on Immigration?
column4: Americans generally support broad immigration reforms at the heart of the deal in which legalization for existing illegal immigrants is married with safeguards against new border jumpers.

column3: Can Obama's Jam and Slam Approach Work on Immigration?
column4: And Republican resistance to the idea of legalization is at a low ebb as the party faces demographic oblivion without the ability to attract non-white voters.

column3: Can Obama's Jam and Slam Approach Work on Immigration?
column4: Obama has established this legislation as a one-shot deal for Republicans.

column3: Can Obama's Jam and Slam Approach Work on Immigration?
column4: Either this comprehensive legislation will pass, or he will unveil his own, more-liberal bill, effectively ending any chance for compromise.

column3: Can Obama's Jam and Slam Approach Work on Immigration?
column4: The president says either Republicans will assent to this compromise or he will rally Hispanics and liberals around the banner of a more permissive, faster legalization and make sure Americans know it’s Republicans who are to blame.

column3: Can Obama's Jam and Slam Approach Work on Immigration?
column4: It’s now or never, says Obama.

column3: Can Obama's Jam and Slam Approach Work on Immigration?
column4: Many Republicans, led by Sen. Marco Rubio of Florida, are working to slow things down.

column3: Can Obama's Jam and Slam Approach Work on Immigration?
column4: Rubio, one of the eight, is proposing the legislation as a starting point for a deliberative Senate process resulting in final passage of a comprehensive bill that then would be merged with a version from House Republicans, setting off a final round of negotiations.

column3: Can Obama's Jam and Slam Approach Work on Immigration?
column4: The Democrats in the gang are looking for the more traditional (of late) approach to the legislation.

column3: Can Obama's Jam and Slam Approach Work on Immigration?
column4: This style brews up a bill behind closed doors and then offers it to the rest of the Senate like plea bargain to a criminal defendant on “Law and Order”: take it or leave it.

column3: Can Obama's Jam and Slam Approach Work on Immigration?
column4: What we’re seeing is the biggest collision yet between the old school of the Senate and the reform movement born with Obama’s 2010 health law.

column3: Can Obama's Jam and Slam Approach Work on Immigration?
column4: Conservative Republicans took offense at the means of passing what the president calls “Obamacare” almost as much as they dislike the ends.

column3: Can Obama's Jam and Slam Approach Work on Immigration?
column4: And “read the bill” still stands as one of the best rallying cries for the Tea Party movement.

column3: Can Obama's Jam and Slam Approach Work on Immigration?
column4: While Americans may disagree about how much to tax, how much to spend and how big the magazine on your rifle should be, it’s very hard to make a principled case against thoroughness and deliberation when it comes to major legislation.

column3: Can Obama's Jam and Slam Approach Work on Immigration?
column4: Obama, who shows increasing impatience with divided government, is strongly backing the Jack McCoy approach here.

column3: Can Obama's Jam and Slam Approach Work on Immigration?
column4: Either the Senate will swiftly pass the compromise bill, or he is going to send the GOP up the river with Hispanic voters.

column3: Can Obama's Jam and Slam Approach Work on Immigration?
column4: This is logical since following “regular order” on this legislation would help conservatives sink or shrink the legislation, with the most likely outcome being a lengthy battle that stretches into an election year.

column3: Can Obama's Jam and Slam Approach Work on Immigration?
column4: If that happens, Obama either gets no bill or a much-reduced version.

column3: Can Obama's Jam and Slam Approach Work on Immigration?
column4: And for Obama to make “jam and slam” work on immigration, he needs to get it done before the Senate has to take up the issue of a full-year federal budget.

column3: Can Obama's Jam and Slam Approach Work on Immigration?
column4: Once that starts, with all the talk about entitlements, taxes, etc.

column3: Can Obama's Jam and Slam Approach Work on Immigration?
column4: there’s not going to be room or appetite enough for anything else comprehensive and complicated.

column3: Can Obama's Jam and Slam Approach Work on Immigration?
column4: So can the Senate be done with immigration by July?

column3: Can Obama's Jam and Slam Approach Work on Immigration?
column4: If so, Obama has a chance to increase the pressure on House Republicans and get off the lame-duck pond.

column3: Can Obama's Jam and Slam Approach Work on Immigration?
column4: If his fellow Democrats in the Senate, though, can’t take care of the “jam” part of the strategy, Obama will have a tougher time on the budget and everything else that’s still left on his second-term wish list.

column3: Israeli airstrikes on Syria put Obama at the crossroads

column3: Israeli airstrikes on Syria put Obama at the crossroads
column4: Mr. Obama declined over the weekend to confirm or comment directly on the airstrikes, but he affirmed the right of Israel to defend itself.

column3: Israeli airstrikes on Syria put Obama at the crossroads
column4: “I continue to believe is that the Israelis justifiably have to guard against the transfer of advanced weaponry to terrorist organizations like Hezbollah,” Mr. Obama said in a televised interview with Telemundo.

John McCain, Arizona Republican, is among those criticizing Mr. Obama for his less-than-explicit response to recent reports that forces loyal to Syrian President Bashar Assad have used chemical weapons on their own people.

column3: Israeli airstrikes on Syria put Obama at the crossroads
column4: The Israel airstrikes complicate what was already a difficult spot for a president who promised to end two wars in the Middle East but now finds himself on the verge of being sucked into the Syrian civil war — in part because of comments he made at a news conference in August.

column3: Israeli airstrikes on Syria put Obama at the crossroads

column3: Israeli airstrikes on Syria put Obama at the crossroads
column4: But many in the White House are looking now to keep the president’s options open.

column3: Israeli airstrikes on Syria put Obama at the crossroads

column3: Israeli airstrikes on Syria put Obama at the crossroads

Tom Cotton, Arkansas Republican, told NBC’s “Meet the Press” that arming “reform minded, pro-Western rebels” is “something that should have been done many months ago.” He said a show of American force could include a no-fly zone and naval firepower, but no boots on the ground.

column3: Israeli airstrikes on Syria put Obama at the crossroads
column4: Summing up the situation, Mr. McCain told “Fox News Sunday,” “Never point a weapon at someone unless you’re ready to pull the trigger.” Syrian powder keg Developments in region may force Mr. Obama to act, political observers say.

column3: Israeli airstrikes on Syria put Obama at the crossroads

column3: Israeli airstrikes on Syria put Obama at the crossroads
column4: Syria’s government called the attacks against its territory a “flagrant violation of international law” that has made the Middle East “more dangerous.” It said “Israel should know that our people and state do not accept humiliation” and warned Syria has the right “to defend its people by all available means.” The generally muted response, read out by the information minister after an emergency government meeting, appeared to signal that Damascus did not want the situation to escalate.

column3: Israeli airstrikes on Syria put Obama at the crossroads
column4: Instead, it tried to use the strikes to taint the opposition, claiming the attacks were evidence of an alliance between Israel and Islamic extremist groups trying to overthrow Mr. Assad.

column3: Israeli airstrikes on Syria put Obama at the crossroads

Patrick J. Leahy, Vermont Democrat, said he also feels the United States is inching closer to providing lethal aid to rebels who are fighting pro-government Syrian forces, but it must be done carefully.

Jim DeMint, South Carolina Republican who left the Capitol at the start of the year to lead the Heritage Foundation, a conservative Washington think tank, accused the president of taking a passive role in the Syrian conflict.

column3: Democrats and Republicans think US closer to arming Syrian rebels, after Israeli strikes
column4: President Obama has said Assad’s use of chemical weapons would cross a red line, but has not taken action beyond giving humanitarian aid and money to rebel forces for defensive military equipment.

column3: Democrats and Republicans think US closer to arming Syrian rebels, after Israeli strikes

column3: Democrats and Republicans think US closer to arming Syrian rebels, after Israeli strikes

John McCain, the top Republican on the Senate Committee on Armed Services, told “Fox News Sunday.” “We need a game-changing action.” McCain suggested the U.S. establish a “safe zone” and give weapons to “the right people” but repeated that American soldiers should not enter the country.

Tom Cotton told NBC the U.S. should have started arming pro-Western rebel forces “months ago” and suggest the U.S. consider blocking Syrian air space.

column4: National Rifle Association Executive Vice President Wayne LaPierre on Saturday launched a blistering attack against the so-called Washington and media “elites” whom he said just don’t understand America.

column4: Speaking at the NRA national convention in Houston, the organization’s most visible figure acidly referred to “elites” more than a half-dozen times, painting them as hopelessly detached from the rest of the nation.

column3: Ã¢â‚¬ËœLet Them Be Damned!Ã¢â‚¬â„¢: Wayne LaPierre Savages Anti-Gun Ã¢â‚¬ËœElitesÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: “The media and the political elites, they denigrate us and they cringe at the sight of long lines at gun shows around this country.

column4: They mock Americans buying firearms at a record pace…they don’t get it because they don’t get America,” LaPierre said.

column3: Ã¢â‚¬ËœLet Them Be Damned!Ã¢â‚¬â„¢: Wayne LaPierre Savages Anti-Gun Ã¢â‚¬ËœElitesÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: After President Barack Obama said the NRA “willfully lied” to the American people about defeated gun legislation last month, LaPierre noted how Obama had tried to reassure gun owners during his re-election campaign.

column3: Ã¢â‚¬ËœLet Them Be Damned!Ã¢â‚¬â„¢: Wayne LaPierre Savages Anti-Gun Ã¢â‚¬ËœElitesÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: “Liars?

column3: Ã¢â‚¬ËœLet Them Be Damned!Ã¢â‚¬â„¢: Wayne LaPierre Savages Anti-Gun Ã¢â‚¬ËœElitesÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: Really?” LaPierre said.

column3: Ã¢â‚¬ËœLet Them Be Damned!Ã¢â‚¬â„¢: Wayne LaPierre Savages Anti-Gun Ã¢â‚¬ËœElitesÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: “This from a man who spent his entire re-election campaign saying he supported our Second Amendment rights and would never try to take anyone’s gun away.

column3: Ã¢â‚¬ËœLet Them Be Damned!Ã¢â‚¬â„¢: Wayne LaPierre Savages Anti-Gun Ã¢â‚¬ËœElitesÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: And he calls us liars?” LaPierre dismissed Obama’s calls for more gun legislation, pointing out that his hometown of Chicago has been suffering from a nearly unending wave of violence.

column3: Ã¢â‚¬ËœLet Them Be Damned!Ã¢â‚¬â„¢: Wayne LaPierre Savages Anti-Gun Ã¢â‚¬ËœElitesÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: “If the president had one clue about how to clean up violent crime, don’t you think he would do it in his own hometown?” LaPierre asked.

column3: Ã¢â‚¬ËœLet Them Be Damned!Ã¢â‚¬â„¢: Wayne LaPierre Savages Anti-Gun Ã¢â‚¬ËœElitesÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: He said Chicago ranks last in enforcement of federal gun laws, but that no journalist would dare question that, in part because they “still have Obama bumper stickers on their cars.” Bringing up the recent manhunt for the Boston bombing suspect when residents were told to remain in their homes, LaPierre asked, “how many Bostonian wished they had a gun two weeks ago?

column3: Ã¢â‚¬ËœLet Them Be Damned!Ã¢â‚¬â„¢: Wayne LaPierre Savages Anti-Gun Ã¢â‚¬ËœElitesÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: How many other Americans now ponder that life or death question?” “Lying in wait right now is a terrorist, a deranged serial killer, a kidnapper, a rapist, a murderer waiting and planning and plotting…no bill in Congress, no rose garden speech will ever change that inescapable reality.

column3: Ã¢â‚¬ËœLet Them Be Damned!Ã¢â‚¬â„¢: Wayne LaPierre Savages Anti-Gun Ã¢â‚¬ËœElitesÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: The only way to stop a bad guy with a gun is a good guy with a gun!” LaPierre thundered, earning some of his most sustained applause from the audience.

column4: LaPierre said the last few months have shown that the NRA is “truly at the heart of America’s heartland.” “Nowhere does freedom live anymore than in our Second Amendment right to defend ourselves, our families and our nation,” LaPierre said.

column3: Ã¢â‚¬ËœLet Them Be Damned!Ã¢â‚¬â„¢: Wayne LaPierre Savages Anti-Gun Ã¢â‚¬ËœElitesÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: “Without that freedom we really aren’t free at all.

column3: Ã¢â‚¬ËœLet Them Be Damned!Ã¢â‚¬â„¢: Wayne LaPierre Savages Anti-Gun Ã¢â‚¬ËœElitesÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: There is nothing more good or right or normal in America than an honest American citizen owning a firearm to protect himself or protect her family.” “They can try to blame us and shame us with all their might,” he continued.

column3: Ã¢â‚¬ËœLet Them Be Damned!Ã¢â‚¬â„¢: Wayne LaPierre Savages Anti-Gun Ã¢â‚¬ËœElitesÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: “We will never sacrifice our freedom on the altar of elitist acceptance.

column4: We will never surrender our guns, never!” LaPierre reminded the audience that Obama vowed that last month’s gun bill defeat was only “round one.” “They’re coming after us with a vengeance to destroy us — to destroy us and every ounce of our freedom…we need to meet them head-on,” he said.

column4: “We don’t care if it’s round one, round two or round 15.

column4: The NRA can go the distance.” “To the political and media elites who scorn us, we say, let them be damned!” he said.

column3: The NRA's no-compromise strategy
column4: HOUSTON — The National Rifle Association has become, more than ever, part and parcel of the Republican Party.

column3: The NRA's no-compromise strategy
column4: The officially nonpartisan group’s no-compromise strategy helped defeat the background check bill in the Senate last month and grow its membership ranks to 5 million.

column3: The NRA's no-compromise strategy
column4: Story Continued Below But it has also repelled many old Democratic allies and raised the hackles of liberal activists, which will make it harder for moderates to work with the NRA in the future and pave the way for new gun control laws in blue states.

column3: The NRA's no-compromise strategy
column4: ( PHOTOS: NRA annual meeting) Fueling the shift is a Democratic Party that has become more liberal on guns.

column3: The NRA's no-compromise strategy
column4: President Barack Obama, emboldened by his reelection, is less afraid to tackle the issue than a generation chastened by losing the House after the assault weapons ban in 1994.

column3: The NRA's no-compromise strategy
column4: New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg is spending money against Democrats in primaries who oppose gun control.

column3: The NRA's no-compromise strategy
column4: And the party has fewer members from southern states and rural districts.

column3: The NRA's no-compromise strategy
column4: The result is on display at this weekend’s NRA annual meeting here, where Democrats are glaringly absent from the roster of speakers.

column3: The NRA's no-compromise strategy
column4: It wasn’t always this way.

column3: The NRA's no-compromise strategy
column4: Sen. Joe Manchin (D-W.V.)

column3: The NRA's no-compromise strategy
column4: received a standing ovation two years ago at the NRA convention in Pittsburgh.

column3: The NRA's no-compromise strategy
column4: Former Rep. Heath Shuler (D-N.C.) attended in 2010.

column3: The NRA's no-compromise strategy
column4: Sen. Max Baucus (D-Mont.)

column3: The NRA's no-compromise strategy
column4: spoke in 2009.

column3: The NRA's no-compromise strategy
column4: This year, a host of potential 2016 Republican candidates pledged their fealty to the NRA.

column3: The NRA's no-compromise strategy
column4: The keynote speaker at a Saturday night rally is Glenn Beck.

column3: The NRA's no-compromise strategy
column4: ( Also on POLITICO: 2016ers to NRA: We'll stand firm) The trend began long before December’s massacre at Sandy Hook Elementary School.

column3: The NRA's no-compromise strategy
column4: Last cycle, the NRA spent $18.6 million on independent expenditures – $13.3 million against Democrats (including Obama) and $6.2 million for Republicans.

column3: The NRA's no-compromise strategy
column4: Only $41,506 went to boosting friendly Democrats, according to a tally from the Center for Responsive Politics.

column3: The NRA's no-compromise strategy
column4: In the 2012 cycle, the NRA cut checks to 26 House Democrats – down from 63 in the 2010 cycle.

column3: The NRA's no-compromise strategy
column4: Twenty years earlier, in 1992, the NRA gave money to 91 House Democrats.

column3: The NRA's no-compromise strategy
column4: One of the NRA’s 75 board members is former Democratic Rep. Dan Boren from Oklahoma.

column3: The NRA's no-compromise strategy
column4: But the board slants strongly to the right, from musician Ted Nugent to anti-tax crusader Grover Norquist and former Sen. Larry Craig (R-Idaho).

column3: The NRA's no-compromise strategy
column4: ( Also on POLITICO: NRA leaders: Watch out for Obama, liberals) Several former Democratic allies of the NRA complained that the group has marginalized itself.

column3: The NRA's no-compromise strategy
column4: Former Democratic National Committee Chairman Howard Dean was endorsed by the NRA in each of his six statewide runs for governor of Vermont, something he touted when he ran for president in 2004.

column3: The NRA's no-compromise strategy
column4: As a kid, he won NRA medals for marksmanship.

column3: The NRA's no-compromise strategy
column4: But he said the group lurched right in search of money and members, even as national Republicans realized after their losses last November that they need to work with Obama.

column3: Obama Blames Violence in Mexico on America's Lust for Drugs, Guns
column4: Speaking in Mexico on Friday, President Barack Obama blamed U.S. gun manufactures for the violence in the country, adding that much of it stems from the American demand for illegal drugs.

column3: Obama Blames Violence in Mexico on America's Lust for Drugs, Guns
column4: “Much of the root cause for violence that has been happening here in Mexico, for which so many Mexicans have suffered, is the demand for illegal drugs in the United States,” Obama said during a speech at Mexico’s Anthropology Museum He then turned his attention to U.S. gun owners and gun control.

column3: Obama Blames Violence in Mexico on America's Lust for Drugs, Guns
column4: “Most of the guns used to commit violence here in Mexico come from the United States,” Obama said.

column3: Obama Blames Violence in Mexico on America's Lust for Drugs, Guns
column4: “I think many of you know that in America, our Constitution guarantees our individual right to bear arms.

column3: Obama Blames Violence in Mexico on America's Lust for Drugs, Guns
column4: And as president, I swore an oath to uphold that right, and I always will.” “But at the same time, as I’ve said in the United States, I will continue to do everything in my power to pass common-sense reforms that keep guns out of the hands of criminals and dangerous people,” he added.

column3: Obama Blames Violence in Mexico on America's Lust for Drugs, Guns
column4: “That can save lives here in Mexico and back home in the United States.

column3: Obama Blames Violence in Mexico on America's Lust for Drugs, Guns
column4: It’s the right thing to do,” Obama said.

column3: Jobs report tempers 'spring swoon' worries
column4: Updated 05/04/2013 09:40 PM EDT A better than expected jobs report released Friday will most likely soothe worries that the economy has entered a “spring swoon,” but it continued to show that the pace of economic growth remains too slow to put a big dent in the unemployment number.

column3: Jobs report tempers 'spring swoon' worries
column4: The economy added 165,000 jobs in April while unemployment dropped modestly to 7.5 percent, the Labor Department reported.

column3: Jobs report tempers 'spring swoon' worries
column4: Story Continued Below The number beat expectations with analysts estimating that the economy added 145,000 jobs last month, according to a Reuters survey of economists.

column3: Jobs report tempers 'spring swoon' worries
column4: ( PHOTOS: What’s in Obama’s 2014 budget) “All things considered, 165,000 isn’t the biggest monthly gain in payrolls you’ll ever see, but it’s enough to assuage concerns that the economy had stalled again,” Paul Ashworth, chief U.S. economist for Capital Economics, said in a statement.

column3: Jobs report tempers 'spring swoon' worries
column4: The report contained good news about job growth in recent months.

column3: Jobs report tempers 'spring swoon' worries
column4: The number of jobs added for March was revised upward from 88,000 to 138,000 and February figures were also revised up from 268,000 to 332,000.

column3: Jobs report tempers 'spring swoon' worries
column4: Friday’s jobs numbers are certain to fuel ongoing concerns about the economic impact of across-the-board spending cuts known as the sequester.

column3: Jobs report tempers 'spring swoon' worries
column4: The cuts went into effect March 1 and the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office has projected they could lead to 750,000 fewer jobs this year and scale back economic growth by 0.6 percent.

column3: Jobs report tempers 'spring swoon' worries
column4: “Now is not the time for Washington to impose self-inflicted wounds on the economy,” Chairman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers Alan Krueger said in a statement.

column3: Jobs report tempers 'spring swoon' worries
column4: “The Administration continues to urge Congress to replace the sequester with balanced deficit reduction, while working to put in place measures to create middle-class jobs, such as by rebuilding our roads and bridges and promoting American manufacturing.” Both Democrats and Republicans have derided the blunt nature of the sequester cuts, which do not allow agencies to pick and choose where they can slash their budgets.

column3: Jobs report tempers 'spring swoon' worries
column4: But other than a recent effort to make sure the sequester did not lead to flight delays, there is little evidence there will be a deal to delay or greatly alter the way the cuts are being implemented.

column4: UPDATE — The White House in a prepared statement praised the unemployment report and urged U.S. lawmakers to do away with sequestration (the March 1 automatic budget cuts): While more work remains to be done, today’s employment report provides further evidence that the U.S. economy is continuing to recover from the worst downturn since the Great Depression.

column3: April's Unemployment Numbers Are in: Here?s What You Need to Know
column4: It is critical that we remain focused on pursuing policies to speed job creation and expand the middle class, as we continue to dig our way out of the deep hole that was caused by the severe recession that began in December 2007.
