column3: Commerce nominee tangled in massive bank collapse that cost depositors millions
column4: President Obama's nominee for Commerce secretary was embroiled in a massive bank failure more than a decade ago, in a collapse that cost depositors and federal insurers millions of dollars.

column3: Commerce nominee tangled in massive bank collapse that cost depositors millions
column4: The 2001 collapse of Superior Bank FSB now appears likely to re-emerge, more than a decade later, as Commerce nominee Penny Pritzker prepares for a confirmation hearing and Republicans already draw attention to the bank implosion.

column3: Commerce nominee tangled in massive bank collapse that cost depositors millions
column4: Pritzker's family, which founded Hyatt and is one of the wealthiest in the country, co-owned Superior Bank at the time of its collapse.

column3: Commerce nominee tangled in massive bank collapse that cost depositors millions
column4: The lawyer who represented depositors in the case told FoxNews.com on Thursday that the Pritzker family enjoyed a "special deal" while the "little guys" ended up "footing the bill."

column3: Commerce nominee tangled in massive bank collapse that cost depositors millions
column4: "The message of our Cabinet members should be people who do the right thing," attorney Clint Krislov said Thursday.

column3: Commerce nominee tangled in massive bank collapse that cost depositors millions
column4: "And it should not be a message of, if you're very wealthy you get a special deal and you get to sit on the Cabinet, too."

column3: Commerce nominee tangled in massive bank collapse that cost depositors millions
column4: Uninsured depositors at the Illinois bank are still owed roughly $10 million, according to federal records -- after a court challenge was rejected in 2007, those savings may never be recovered.

column3: Commerce nominee tangled in massive bank collapse that cost depositors millions
column4: The collapse also cost the FDIC, which insures banks, nearly $300 million.

column3: Commerce nominee tangled in massive bank collapse that cost depositors millions
column4: The failure, according to federal regulators, was triggered by a pattern of risky lending.

column3: Commerce nominee tangled in massive bank collapse that cost depositors millions
column4: The Office of Thrift Supervision took the rare step of shuttering the Hinsdale, Ill., bank on July 27, 2001.

column3: Commerce nominee tangled in massive bank collapse that cost depositors millions
column4: The office said at the time the bank "suffered as a result of its former high-risk business strategy," including "significant volumes of subprime" mortgage and auto loans.

column3: Commerce nominee tangled in massive bank collapse that cost depositors millions
column4: What happened after the collapse, though, is what triggered the lawsuit involving Krislov.

column3: Commerce nominee tangled in massive bank collapse that cost depositors millions
column4: The Pritzker family, as part of a settlement to shield itself from liability, agreed to pay $460 million to the federal government.

column3: Commerce nominee tangled in massive bank collapse that cost depositors millions
column4: But the family was subsequently able to claim part of a separate $125 million settlement from the bank's accounting firm.

column3: Commerce nominee tangled in massive bank collapse that cost depositors millions
column4: Krislov said the family was first in line for the money, followed by the depositors.

column3: Commerce nominee tangled in massive bank collapse that cost depositors millions
column4: "That is what is fundamentally troubling," he said.

column3: Commerce nominee tangled in massive bank collapse that cost depositors millions
column4: "They got a priority ahead of depositors while depositors were still short."

column3: Commerce nominee tangled in massive bank collapse that cost depositors millions
column4: An FDIC representative, though, suggested to the Chicago Tribune in 2004 that the sheer size of the $460 million settlement justified the trade-off.

column3: Commerce nominee tangled in massive bank collapse that cost depositors millions
column4: "If it means $30 million is turned over to the Pritzkers, I think it's hard to dispute that it's not advantageous for creditors of that failed institution," the spokesman said.

column3: Commerce nominee tangled in massive bank collapse that cost depositors millions
column4: Pritzker's involvement with the bank's questionable lending practices is unclear.

column3: Commerce nominee tangled in massive bank collapse that cost depositors millions
column4: She served as chairwoman of the bank from 1991 to 1994, after her uncle Jay went in with another wealthy family to buy Superior in the late '80s.

column3: Commerce nominee tangled in massive bank collapse that cost depositors millions
column4: Pritzker spokeswoman Susan Anderson stressed that Pritzker was not an officer or director at the time the bank failed.

column3: Commerce nominee tangled in massive bank collapse that cost depositors millions
column4: "She left its board in 1994, seven years before the bank failed.

column3: Commerce nominee tangled in massive bank collapse that cost depositors millions
column4: During her tenure, the bank received clean audits and regulators gave it high marks," she said in an email to FoxNews.com, calling her record as a manager "extraordinary."

column3: Commerce nominee tangled in massive bank collapse that cost depositors millions
column4: She also noted that despite the losses sustained by depositors, they did get 81 percent of their savings back, in addition to the $100,000 insured amount.

column3: Commerce nominee tangled in massive bank collapse that cost depositors millions
column4: "This is ... typical when a bank fails," she said.

column3: Commerce nominee tangled in massive bank collapse that cost depositors millions
column4: The FDIC insures depositors for up to $100,000.

column3: Commerce nominee tangled in massive bank collapse that cost depositors millions
column4: In the case of Superior, those with accounts above that amount were still repaid part -- but not all -- of their uninsured savings.

column3: Commerce nominee tangled in massive bank collapse that cost depositors millions
column4: Krislov said he wrote to Penny Pritzker after his clients lost their suit asking her to pay the remaining $10 million to the uninsured depositors.

column3: Commerce nominee tangled in massive bank collapse that cost depositors millions
column4: "I just figured it was the right thing to do," he said, adding that he never heard back.

column3: Obama Nominates Pritzker for Commerce Post
column4: WASHINGTON — President Obama rounded out his second-term cabinet choices on Thursday, nominating Penny Pritzker, his longtime financial backer and an heir to the Hyatt Hotel fortune, to be commerce secretary, and Michael Froman, a law school friend and White House adviser on international economics, as trade representative.

column3: Obama Nominates Pritzker for Commerce Post
column4: Mr. Obama introduced his two friends in a Rose Garden announcement just before departing for a three-day trip to Mexico and Costa Rica, along with Mr. Froman.

column3: Obama Nominates Pritzker for Commerce Post
column4: With Mr. Obama’s nomination on Monday of Anthony R. Foxx, the mayor of Charlotte, N.C., to be transportation secretary, he has now completed his selections for a cabinet depleted by departures after his first term.

column3: Obama Nominates Pritzker for Commerce Post
column4: Several nominees, including the new ones, still need Senate confirmation.

column3: Obama Nominates Pritzker for Commerce Post
column4: Republicans will closely scrutinize Ms. Pritzker’s financial record, as Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa made plain in a statement after the announcement.

column3: Obama Nominates Pritzker for Commerce Post
column4: “Every nominee’s offshore tax avoidance activities should be examined as part of the nomination process,” he said, suggesting that Ms. Pritzker is “associated with the kind of tax avoidance activity that the president dismisses as fat cat shenanigans for others.” Ms. Pritzker, a longtime Chicago donor and fund-raiser for Mr. Obama, had been expected to be his pick for the long-vacant Commerce Department post, but vetting of her substantial financial assets and ties delayed a formal announcement, administration aides have said.

column3: Obama Nominates Pritzker for Commerce Post
column4: She was a leading candidate for commerce secretary after Mr. Obama’s election in 2008, but withdrew from contention amid the public scrutiny at the time.

column3: Obama Nominates Pritzker for Commerce Post
column4: On Thursday the president signaled confidence that Ms. Pritzker would be confirmed by joking about it.

column3: Obama Nominates Pritzker for Commerce Post
column4: Noting that Ms. Pritzker’s nomination coincided with her 54th birthday, he quipped, “For your birthday present you get to go through confirmation.” After a comedic pause, he added with a chuckle, “It’s going to be great.” With Ms. Pritzker, Mr. Obama would bring a woman and a voice for business interests into a cabinet that has been criticized in the past as having too few of either.

column3: Obama Nominates Pritzker for Commerce Post
column4: Even so, the president of the National Organization for Women, Terry O’Neill, issued a statement immediately after the announcement saying that “the numbers are good, but not great,” since women are 51 percent of the population but about one-third of the cabinet.

column3: Obama Nominates Pritzker for Commerce Post
column4: “NOW is particularly concerned that the main group of advisers who have the president’s ear not just on occasion, but three, four, five times a day, is still overwhelmingly male,” she added.

column3: Obama Nominates Pritzker for Commerce Post
column4: Ms. Pritzker, a longtime business and civic leader in Chicago, would head perhaps the most eclectic department in the government, with wide-ranging responsibility that includes federal business programs, oceans policy, weather forecasting and travel and tourism.

column3: Obama Nominates Pritzker for Commerce Post
column4: In Democratic and Republican administrations, the commerce secretary is often best known as a president’s emissary to the business community and political donors.

column3: Obama Nominates Pritzker for Commerce Post
column4: The commerce post had been vacant for nearly a year, since the businessman John E. Bryson resigned for medical reasons in June; his deputy, Rebecca M. Blank, has been acting secretary since then.

column3: Obama Nominates Pritzker for Commerce Post
column4: Ms. Blank, an academic, is leaving to become chancellor of the University of Wisconsin, Madison.

column3: Obama Nominates Pritzker for Commerce Post
column4: Ms. Pritzker is chairwoman and chief executive of PSP Capital Partners and its affiliate, Pritzker Realty Group, and chairwoman of Artemis Real Estate Partners.

column3: Obama Nominates Pritzker for Commerce Post
column4: During Mr. Obama’s first term, she served on his Council on Jobs and Competitiveness and on his Economic Recovery Advisory Board.

column3: Obama Nominates Pritzker for Commerce Post
column4: Mr. Obama credited her on Thursday as “the driving force” behind his Skills for America’s Future initiative to connect businesses and community colleges to develop a work force with the skills employers need.

column3: Obama Nominates Pritzker for Commerce Post
column4: Mr. Froman, who is 50, has served in the White House as the deputy national security adviser for international economics since Mr. Obama first took office.

column3: Obama Nominates Pritzker for Commerce Post
column4: Although the post was not a cabinet position, Mr. Froman had proximity to the president and a portfolio thicker than that of the cabinet-rank trade representative, encompassing not only trade but also international development and climate change issues.

column3: Obama Nominates Pritzker for Commerce Post
column4: Mr. Froman had planned to keep his White House post in the second term, and Mr. Obama initially intended to nominate Jeffrey D. Zients, a businessman who had been the acting director of the Office of Management and Budget, to be trade representative.

column3: Obama Nominates Pritzker for Commerce Post
column4: But opposition to Mr. Zients from Senator Max Baucus of Montana, the Democratic chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, which would handle his nomination, scuttled it.

column3: Obama Nominates Pritzker for Commerce Post
column4: Mr. Baucus objected to Mr. Zients’s oversight of a government-reorganization study that recommended changes that would have affected the committee’s jurisdiction, according to administration and Congressional aides.

column3: Obama Nominates Pritzker for Commerce Post
column4: Mr. Froman’s inclusion with Mr. Obama for the trip to Mexico and Costa Rica reflects his current leading role in international economic affairs.

column3: Obama Nominates Pritzker for Commerce Post
column4: He has been the president’s “sherpa,” making preparations for past and coming global economic summit meetings.

column3: Obama Nominates Pritzker for Commerce Post
column4: He also oversees economic relations with Europe, Japan and the developing BRIC bloc — Brazil, Russia, India and China — and development policies for Africa and the Middle East.

column3: Obama Nominates Pritzker for Commerce Post
column4: Administration officials said Mr. Froman would retain some of those responsibilities.

column3: Obama Nominates Pritzker for Commerce Post
column4: On Thursday, Mr. Obama gave Mr. Froman credit, along with the man he would succeed as trade representative, Ron Kirk, for finishing free trade pacts with South Korea, Colombia and Panama, all of which were begun in the Bush administration.

column3: Obama Nominates Pritzker for Commerce Post
column4: The foremost issues for the new trade representative will be to negotiate trade liberalization deals with Europe and the Pacific Rim region.

column3: Obama Nominates Pritzker for Commerce Post
column4: “He has won the respect of our trading partners around the world,” Mr. Obama said of Mr. Froman.

column3: Obama Nominates Pritzker for Commerce Post
column4: “He has also won a reputation as being an extraordinarily tough negotiator while doing it.” Labor groups generally have had good if occasionally testy relations with Mr. Froman, but a liberal group, Public Citizen’s Global Trade Watch, assailed his “corporate agenda.” Business groups issued statements praising him and Ms. Pritzker.

column3: Federal Reserve Stands by Stimulus Policies, Blames U.S. Lawmakers For Sluggish Economy
column4: Economic stimulus is here to stay and U.S. lawmakers are to blame for sluggish economic growth, the Federal Reserve said in a statement released on Wednesday.

column3: Federal Reserve Stands by Stimulus Policies, Blames U.S. Lawmakers For Sluggish Economy

column3: Fix The Debt CEOs Bring $1 Billion From Tax Loopholes
column4: WASHINGTON -- Companies in the Fix the Debt coalition, which advocates for federal austerity policies, qualified for $1 billion or more in tax breaks tied to executive pay packages from 2009 to 2011, according to a new report by the liberal think tanks Institute for Policy Studies and Campaign for America's Future.

column3: Fix The Debt CEOs Bring $1 Billion From Tax Loopholes
column4: The four highest-paid executives at the firms received a total of $6.3 billion in pay over the period, according to the report.

column3: Fix The Debt CEOs Bring $1 Billion From Tax Loopholes
column4: Federal tax law allows companies to deduct executive pay based on performance from the firm's tax bill as a business expense.

column3: Fix The Debt CEOs Bring $1 Billion From Tax Loopholes
column4: This performance-based compensation includes stock options, stock awards and other types of incentive pay.

column3: Fix The Debt CEOs Bring $1 Billion From Tax Loopholes
column4: These 90 companies qualified for tax perks totaling between $1 billion and $1.5 billion over the course of three years, depending on how many types of pay firms actually deducted.

column3: Fix The Debt CEOs Bring $1 Billion From Tax Loopholes
column4: Companies can choose to be more or less aggressive about their tax deductions, and some types of incentive pay exist in a gray area where certain companies choose to claim deductions and others do not.

column3: Fix The Debt CEOs Bring $1 Billion From Tax Loopholes
column4: Firms do not make their tax filings public, although they release estimates of overall taxes paid in SEC filings.

column3: Fix The Debt CEOs Bring $1 Billion From Tax Loopholes
column4: The IPS-CAF study was based on actual payments to executives that were taxable in the years 2009, 2010 and 2011 that would have qualified for deductions, but whether firms chose to take them is not a matter of public record.

column3: Fix The Debt CEOs Bring $1 Billion From Tax Loopholes
column4: Fix the Debt is one of several austerity advocacy groups tied to Wall Street billionaire Peter Peterson, who started a think tank devoted to deficit reduction in 2008 and has bankrolled multiple public relations campaigns on the issue.

column3: Fix The Debt CEOs Bring $1 Billion From Tax Loopholes
column4: A total of 125 CEOs are officially members of the coalition, including CEOs of 90 public companies.

column3: Fix The Debt CEOs Bring $1 Billion From Tax Loopholes
column4: The IPS-CAF report only examined tax perks for public companies in the coalition.

column3: Fix The Debt CEOs Bring $1 Billion From Tax Loopholes
column4: The same CEO pay loophole is available to private companies, but private firms do not have to disclose executive pay to the SEC.

column3: Fix The Debt CEOs Bring $1 Billion From Tax Loopholes
column4: The coalition urges a host of spending cuts and tax reforms, including benefit cuts for Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid, as a means to reduce the federal budget deficit.

column3: Fix The Debt CEOs Bring $1 Billion From Tax Loopholes
column4: A spokesman for the group told HuffPost that while the group doesn't advocate for specific policies, it does insist that comprehensive tax reform be part of any debt deal.

column3: Fix The Debt CEOs Bring $1 Billion From Tax Loopholes
column4: "It's a lot easier for groups like this to sit on the sidelines and throw stones than to talk about the 4 million meals that are going to be eliminated for seniors because Congress wouldn't pass a debt deal," Fix the Debt spokesman Jon Romano said.

column3: Fix The Debt CEOs Bring $1 Billion From Tax Loopholes
column4: "All of our supporters understand that there is going to be pain associated with a comprehensive debt deal and that people are going to have to give something up to get a debt deal in place.

column3: Fix The Debt CEOs Bring $1 Billion From Tax Loopholes
column4: But everything has to be on the table.

column3: Fix The Debt CEOs Bring $1 Billion From Tax Loopholes
column4: We're a campaign about fixing the debt.

column3: Fix The Debt CEOs Bring $1 Billion From Tax Loopholes
column4: This is not about protecting special interests, this about what's in the best interest of the American people."

column3: Fix The Debt CEOs Bring $1 Billion From Tax Loopholes
column4: The group is currently airing an online video pushing to cut Social Security benefits by using a more conservative measure of inflation to calculate annual cost-of-living increases.

column3: Fix The Debt CEOs Bring $1 Billion From Tax Loopholes
column4: The CEO pay loophole being used by Fix the Debt companies is extremely popular in corporate America.

column3: Fix The Debt CEOs Bring $1 Billion From Tax Loopholes

column3: Fix The Debt CEOs Bring $1 Billion From Tax Loopholes

column3: Fix The Debt CEOs Bring $1 Billion From Tax Loopholes
column4: "The worst of it is that there is no 'cost' to a corporation that uses stock options to pay its executives, so there's no justification for allowing them to deduct it as an expense.

column4: It's not an expense."

column3: Fix The Debt CEOs Bring $1 Billion From Tax Loopholes
column4: Sen. Carl Levin (D-Mich.) has introduced legislation that would eliminate the loophole, but the plan is rarely included in deficit reduction talks on Capitol Hill.

column4: Seidenberg cashed in another $30 million in stock options from the period in 2011, and $25 million in 2010.

column3: Fix The Debt CEOs Bring $1 Billion From Tax Loopholes
column4: In addition, Seidenberg received $10,434 in non-equity performance compensation, including $3.5 million in 2011, $3.0 million in 2010 and $3.9 million in 2009.

column3: Fix The Debt CEOs Bring $1 Billion From Tax Loopholes
column4: Although the scope of the federal budget deficit has been a major political issue over the past four years, it has faded in recent months as Congress has considered gun legislation and immigration reform.

column3: Kelly Ayotte on defense over gun vote
column4: Updated 05/01/2013 09:48 AM EDT TILTON, N.H. — Sen. Kelly Ayotte’s town hall meeting here ended with scant discussion of gun control, an issue that consumed Washington for much of the past month.

column3: Kelly Ayotte on defense over gun vote
column4: Pro-gun control activists, who attended the meeting, were incensed.

column3: Kelly Ayotte on defense over gun vote
column4: Security brushed aside two women who approached Ayotte and demanded to speak with the first-term Republican about her vote against expanded background checks for commercial gun sales, underscoring the lingering controversy that continues to hover over the New Hampshire senator.

column3: Kelly Ayotte on defense over gun vote
column4: Story Continued Below “It’s a mixed reaction,” Ayotte told POLITICO as she rushed for the exits.

column3: Kelly Ayotte on defense over gun vote
column4: “Something both sides feel strongly about.” ( Also on POLITICO: Sandy Hook victim’s family presses Ayotte on guns) In the aftermath of the Senate’s failed vote two weeks ago to expand background checks, New Hampshire has suddenly emerged as ground zero in the national battle over gun control, with Ayotte now stuck at the center of the fight.

column3: Kelly Ayotte on defense over gun vote
column4: Powerful outside groups run by former Rep. Gabrielle Giffords and New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg are bankrolling ads and vowing to dump huge resources into the state to force Ayotte to reverse her opposition to the bill or pay the political consequences.

column3: Kelly Ayotte on defense over gun vote
column4: And after two years of projecting a profile as a foreign policy and deficit hawk, her critics in the state have spent the past two weeks trying to rebrand her as: “NRAyotte.” Meanwhile, the National Rifle Association is running radio ads thanking her for her support.

column3: Kelly Ayotte on defense over gun vote
column4: ( PHOTOS: Kelly Ayotte's career) The emotional fight threatens to transform Ayotte — a young conservative Republican woman whose star is on the rise — into a polarizing figure back home on a contentious issue.

column3: Kelly Ayotte on defense over gun vote
column4: Instead of taking up the banner of gun rights, Ayotte is seeking a lower profile on the subject in a state where she’s become the last Republican in the all-female congressional delegation.

column3: Kelly Ayotte on defense over gun vote
column4: “It hurts her,” said Kathy Sullivan, a longtime Democratic operative and former head of the state party here.

column3: Kelly Ayotte on defense over gun vote
column4: “Elections are won in New Hampshire with the vote of independents, particularly independent women.

column3: Kelly Ayotte on defense over gun vote
column4: Independent women will not favor a candidate who does not believe in background checks.

column3: Kelly Ayotte on defense over gun vote
column4: Will it be the only issue?

column3: Kelly Ayotte on defense over gun vote
column4: No, but it will be an issue.” ( PHOTOS: Pols speak out on gun control) Ayotte, for her part, seems to wish it would all go away, as she finds herself in the middle of a firestorm for the first time in her short Senate career.

column3: Kelly Ayotte on defense over gun vote
column4: The freshman Republican represents a libertarian-minded state that has been a stronghold for gun rights, but polls show strong support for expanded background checks.

column3: Daughter of Newtown Victim Confronts GOP Senator for Voting Against Gun Control Bill
column4: During a town hall event in Warren, N.H. on Tuesday, the daughter of slain Sandy Hook Elementary School principal Dawn Hochsprung went after Sen. Kelly Ayotte (R-N.H.) for voting against expanding background checks on all firearms sales.

column3: Daughter of Newtown Victim Confronts GOP Senator for Voting Against Gun Control Bill
column4: “You had mentioned that day the burden on owners of gun stores that the expanded background checks would cause,” Erica Lafferty said during the town hall.

column3: Daughter of Newtown Victim Confronts GOP Senator for Voting Against Gun Control Bill
column4: “I am just wondering why the burden of my mother being gunned down in the halls of her elementary school isn’t more important than that.” “Erica, certainly let me just say that I’m obviously so sorry, and as everyone here no matter what our views are, for what you have been through,” Ayotte replied, later adding that she wants to prevent that kind of mass shooting from ever occurring again.

column3: Daughter of Newtown Victim Confronts GOP Senator for Voting Against Gun Control Bill

column3: Drug Agency Lowers Age for Next-Day Birth Control
column4: The Food and Drug Administration said Tuesday that it would make the most widely known morning-after pill available without a prescription to girls and women ages 15 and older, and also make the pill available on drugstore shelves, instead of keeping it locked up behind pharmacy counters.

column3: Drug Agency Lowers Age for Next-Day Birth Control
column4: Until this decision the pill, Plan B One-Step, which is used after sexual intercourse to help prevent pregnancy, was available without a prescription only for ages 17 and older.

column3: Drug Agency Lowers Age for Next-Day Birth Control
column4: The decision did not address a federal judge’s ruling in early April that gave the drug agency 30 days to make the pill available for all ages without a prescription.

column3: Drug Agency Lowers Age for Next-Day Birth Control
column4: In a scathing opinion handed down three weeks ago, Judge Edward R. Korman in the Eastern District of New York said the Obama administration had put politics before science in restricting access to the drug.

column3: Drug Agency Lowers Age for Next-Day Birth Control
column4: The F.D.A.

column3: Drug Agency Lowers Age for Next-Day Birth Control
column4: and the White House said Tuesday that the Department of Justice was still deciding whether to appeal the ruling, something it can do independently of the drug agency’s decision on Tuesday.

column3: Drug Agency Lowers Age for Next-Day Birth Control
column4: That decision, which takes effect immediately, represents a compromise on the politically charged issue of access to emergency contraception, which has pitted conservative and anti-abortion groups against advocates for women’s health and reproductive rights.

column3: Drug Agency Lowers Age for Next-Day Birth Control
column4: The Justice Department is most likely weighing not only the substance of the judge’s ruling, but also the precedent the ruling would set in countermanding an order by a White House cabinet member, Kathleen Sebelius, the secretary of health and human services.

column3: Drug Agency Lowers Age for Next-Day Birth Control
column4: In 2011, she decided the pill would be available without prescription only to those 17 and older, despite the F.D.A.’s finding that it was safe and effective and should be available without any age restrictions.

column3: Drug Agency Lowers Age for Next-Day Birth Control

column3: Drug Agency Lowers Age for Next-Day Birth Control
column4: Besides lowering the age restriction, the new rule addresses concerns of women who were unable to get the pill if their drugstore’s pharmacy counter happened to be closed.

column3: Drug Agency Lowers Age for Next-Day Birth Control

column3: Drug Agency Lowers Age for Next-Day Birth Control

column3: Drug Agency Lowers Age for Next-Day Birth Control
column4: commissioner, said in a statement that data proved that 15-year-olds “were able to understand how Plan B One-Step works, how to use it properly, and that it does not prevent the transmission of a sexually transmitted disease.” The agency’s decision applies only to Plan B One-Step, which is a one-pill dose, not to the two-pill generic versions, because there is not enough data to show the two-dose versions can be used responsibly by younger teenagers without the intervention of a health provider, said an F.D.A.

column3: Drug Agency Lowers Age for Next-Day Birth Control

column3: President Obama defends second-term performance
column4: Updated 05/01/2013 06:24 AM EDT President Barack Obama defended the sluggish start to his second term Tuesday, arguing the United States needs more facts on Syria to guide his response and more cooperation from Congress to make progress on his domestic agenda.

column3: President Obama defends second-term performance
column4: Addressing Obamacare implementation, immigration reform and his inability to break the stalemate on the sequestration cuts aside from last week’s FAA carve out, Obama used a press conference marking the 100-day mark of his second term to bat back suggestions that the he’s falling short on all the big-ticket items in the agenda he laid out for himself at the beginning of the year.

column3: President Obama defends second-term performance
column4: Story Continued Below He started, though, by pushing back on the idea that he was dithering on crafting an American response to the situation in Syria, even after his administration announced proof of chemical weapons use — which Obama has previously called a “red line” that would be a “game-changer” if crossed, recalibrating how the international community deals with Syrian President Bashar al-Assad’s regime.

column3: President Obama defends second-term performance
column4: Pressed for explanation Tuesday, Obama said that the findings change the game in that his administration will have to “rethink the range of options that are available to us.” ( Also on POLITICO: Obama explains Syria 'game-changer') Though Obama never said the word “Iraq,” he drew a clear distinction between his approach of slowly gathering evidence and the prospect of rushing to war.

column3: President Obama defends second-term performance
column4: “What we now have is evidence that chemical weapons have been used inside of Syria, but we don’t know how they were used, when they were used, who used them.

column3: President Obama defends second-term performance
column4: We don’t have a chain of custody that establishes what exactly happened,” Obama said, explaining why he wouldn’t say definitively that a “red line” had been crossed.

column3: President Obama defends second-term performance
column4: “When I am making decisions about America’s national security and the potential for taking additional action in response to chemical weapon use, I’ve got to make sure I’ve got the facts,” he continued.

column3: President Obama defends second-term performance
column4: “That’s what the American people would expect.

column3: President Obama defends second-term performance
column4: And if we end up rushing to judgment without hard effective evidence, then we can find ourselves in a position where we can’t mobilize the international community.” ( Also on POLITICO: Obama says suspicions persist between U.S., Russian agencies) Though he hasn’t been successful on most of the issues he set to address at the start of his second term — especially to avert sequestration and to pass new gun laws — Obama denied that he’s lost his “juice” in Washington.

column3: President Obama defends second-term performance
column4: “Golly.

column3: President Obama defends second-term performance
column4: I think it’s a little, as Mark Twain said, ‘rumors of my demise may be exaggerated at this point,’” Obama said, paraphrasing the famous quote.

column3: President Obama defends second-term performance
column4: ( PHOTOS: Obama’s 24 international trips) Immigration reform has the best prospects of making it into law, with some Senate Republicans joining with Democrats in support of the bill drafted by the Gang of Eight.

column3: House Joins Senate in Passing Bill to Ease Flight Delays
column4: WASHINGTON — President Obama and Congressional Democrats on Friday abandoned their once-firm stand that growing airport bottlenecks would be addressed only in a broader fix to across-the-board spending cuts, accepting bipartisan legislation that would bring the nation’s air traffic control system back up to full strength.

column3: House Joins Senate in Passing Bill to Ease Flight Delays
column4: With remarkable speed, the House overwhelmingly approved legislation to give the secretary of transportation enough financial flexibility to shift as much as $253 million to the air traffic control system, less than a week after the onset of politically problematic flight delays driven by across-the-board spending cuts.

column3: House Joins Senate in Passing Bill to Ease Flight Delays
column4: The money will be shifted from airport improvement funds, and none would come from additional revenues, once a key demand of Mr. Obama and the Democrats.

column3: House Joins Senate in Passing Bill to Ease Flight Delays
column4: The 361-to-41 vote came less than 24 hours after the Senate rushed the measure through.

column3: House Joins Senate in Passing Bill to Ease Flight Delays

column4: “By last night, Senate Democrats were adopting our targeted ‘cut this, not that’ approach.

column3: On Beyond Fear
column4: The homeland security secretary, Janet Napolitano, testified on Tuesday before the Senate Judiciary Committee about the Senate’s bipartisan immigration bill.

column3: On Beyond Fear
column4: For hours, in a calm and methodical manner, she flipped each confrontational line of questioning on its head.

column3: On Beyond Fear
column4: No, the bill would not loosen security at borders and ports.

column3: On Beyond Fear
column4: It would tighten it.

column3: On Beyond Fear
column4: The bill would not weaken immigration enforcement, but strengthen it — adding resources and improving the government’s ability to keep unwanted people out and to catch fugitives, identify thieves and terrorists.

column3: On Beyond Fear
column4: Ms. Napolitano’s testimony filled the last of three days of hearings on the immigration bill, a marathon featuring more than two dozen witnesses from all corners of the country — sort of an immigration Woodstock.

column3: On Beyond Fear
column4: Within those three days and the bill’s 844 pages lay a dizzying blizzard of details, but after Ms. Napolitano wrapped things up, a clearer picture started to emerge.

column3: On Beyond Fear
column4: A veteran of the immigration battles could have watched her speak and still have been amazed at the vast sums of money and resources that have been sent to militarize America’s southern border, as if the people flowing across it were an existential threat rather than a problem and opportunity to be controlled and redirected.

column3: On Beyond Fear
column4: Ms. Napolitano’s testimony evoked a world of drones, radar and motion sensors, Border Patrol agents and National Guard troops, fencing and razor wire stretching for miles and miles.

column3: On Beyond Fear
column4: The bill calls for up to $6.5 billion in new spending, with expanded workplace-verification and entry-exit visa systems, and still more boots and fencing.

column3: On Beyond Fear
column4: What was especially striking was how much of this enforcement has already been accomplished, even as the country keeps waiting for the broader, once-in-a-generation immigration overhaul that this bill — and a companion bill being written in the House — is trying to achieve.

column3: On Beyond Fear
column4: The bill was only just filed and may not pass.

column3: On Beyond Fear
column4: The opponents of reform are intense in their desire to break it apart or stall it until it dies.

column3: On Beyond Fear
column4: Their arguments against the bill itself are unpersuasive — who could oppose making the system fairer and more efficient, clearing backlogs in legal immigration, or creating a more rational and streamlined visa process to supply the economy with the labor it needs, from Silicon Valley to dairy farms to citrus groves?

column3: On Beyond Fear
column4: What they do have is fear and anxiety, intensified by the Boston bombings.

column3: On Beyond Fear
column4: One witness on Monday, Kris Kobach, the Kansas secretary of state and an outsize figure in the nation’s anti-immigration battles, argued at length about how the bill might allow a hypothetical terrorist calling himself “Rumpelstiltskin” to get his papers and travel as freely as the Boston suspects did.

column3: On Beyond Fear
column4: As Senator Charles Schumer of New York correctly noted, the bill’s opposition grows from one root: restrictionist organizations that see no good in immigration short of mass deportation.

column3: On Beyond Fear
column4: They have profited immensely from fear, as the bristling southern border attests.

column3: On Beyond Fear
column4: But the flip side of fear is hope, exemplified by the host of witnesses on the other side — the growers, business owners, ministers, state officials, human-rights advocates and undocumented people themselves who have the better argument.

column3: Obama's Delicate Task at Bush Library Event
column4: DALLAS — President Obama has left little mystery about how he views his predecessor.

column3: Obama's Delicate Task at Bush Library Event
column4: “The failed policies of George W. Bush” wiped away a budget surplus and “squandered the legacy” of bipartisan foreign policy.

column3: Obama's Delicate Task at Bush Library Event
column4: Mr. Bush put two wars “on a credit card,” led the country away “from our values” and “crashed the economy.” But Mr. Obama will surely say none of that when he helps dedicate the George W. Bush Presidential Library and Museum on Thursday.

column3: Obama's Delicate Task at Bush Library Event
column4: Addressing a crowd of Bush supporters and administration veterans, the 44th president will no doubt extol the virtues of the 43rd and praise his years of service to the country.

column3: Obama's Delicate Task at Bush Library Event
column4: It has become an awkward ritual of the modern presidency that the current occupant of the Oval Office is called upon to deliver a generous historical judgment of the previous one.

column3: Obama's Delicate Task at Bush Library Event
column4: With the opening of each new presidential library, the members of the world’s most exclusive fraternity put aside partisan differences to honor the shared experience of running the nation in difficult times.

column3: Obama's Delicate Task at Bush Library Event
column4: The task in such moments is especially acute when, as with Mr. Obama and Mr. Bush, the current and previous presidents come from opposing parties and such different sensibilities.

column3: Obama's Delicate Task at Bush Library Event
column4: The incumbent must hit grace notes without appearing inconsistent with past criticism or, worse, hypocritical.

column3: Obama's Delicate Task at Bush Library Event
column4: Sometimes a president goes through the motions, dutifully reading what aides put before him.

column3: Obama's Delicate Task at Bush Library Event
column4: Other times, library dedications have become bonding moments when presidents genuinely grow closer.

column3: Obama's Delicate Task at Bush Library Event
column4: “When a president dedicates the library of someone he opposed politically, it’s interesting and a bit of a challenge,” said Michael Waldman, who was the chief speechwriter for President Bill Clinton when he helped President George Bush open his library in 1997.

column3: Obama's Delicate Task at Bush Library Event
column4: “The best thing to do is focus on something that you can really embrace and mean it.” Kenneth Khachigian, a chief speechwriter for President Ronald Reagan, said there was a formula: “If you’re a speechwriter, you can write a really nice speech about how Americans can fight and disagree and debate, but at the end of the day we’re all Americans and we have the same goals, and I’ve learned that anybody who sits in this office really at the end of the day has the best interest of everyone at heart.” That is a fair summation of what Reagan said in dedicating President Jimmy Carter’s library in October 1986.

column3: Obama's Delicate Task at Bush Library Event
column4: In that case, the dedication came in the midst of a midterm election campaign, so the moment of conciliation was followed just weeks later by fairly tough language on the campaign trail in which Reagan criticized Mr. Carter’s policies.

column3: Obama's Delicate Task at Bush Library Event
column4: With no election at hand, Mr. Obama has more latitude, not having to worry about alienating his base, which still loathes Mr. Bush.

column3: Obama's Delicate Task at Bush Library Event
column4: A gracious speech could also fit into his outreach to Congressional Republicans.

column3: Obama's Delicate Task at Bush Library Event
column4: The timing of the legislative calendar does give him some fodder for common ground with Mr. Bush.

column3: Obama's Delicate Task at Bush Library Event
column4: As he fights to liberalize the immigration system, Mr. Obama could use the speech to point out that he and Mr. Bush agree on the issue, implicitly pressuring other Republicans to join them.

column3: Obama's Delicate Task at Bush Library Event
column4: That is not to say that Mr. Obama is putting away his partisan hat altogether.

column3: Obama's Delicate Task at Bush Library Event
column4: He flew to Dallas on Wednesday, a day early, to appear at a Democratic fund-raiser.

column3: Obama's Delicate Task at Bush Library Event
column4: At the ceremony on Thursday at the new Bush center, on the campus of Southern Methodist University, he will be joined by the elder Mr. Bush, Mr. Carter and Mr. Clinton.

column3: Obama's Delicate Task at Bush Library Event
column4: At the event on Wednesday, Mr. Obama told donors: “I’m really looking forward to attending the Bush library opening tomorrow.

column3: Obama's Delicate Task at Bush Library Event
column4: One of the things I will insist upon is whatever our political differences, President Bush loves this country and loves its people and shares that same concern, and was concerned about all people in America, not just those who voted Republican.” But Mr. Bush’s circle is anticipating the encounter with a certain suspicion.

column3: Obama's Delicate Task at Bush Library Event
column4: While the former president retreated to Texas after leaving office and has refrained from criticizing his successor, Mr. Obama made Mr. Bush a foil on the campaign trail, attributing the country’s problems to the situation he inherited.

column3: Obama's Delicate Task at Bush Library Event
column4: “A huge part of his messaging platform for his presidency has been the contrast, laying it off on his predecessor,” said Dan Bartlett, who was the White House counselor under Mr. Bush.

column3: Obama's Delicate Task at Bush Library Event
column4: “He’s going to have to thread the needle.” Mr. Bush’s advisers bristled at Mr. Obama’s Inaugural Address in 2009, when the new president criticized “our collective failure to make hard choices” and assured the world “that we are ready to lead once more.” They also thought that Mr. Obama was grudging when he unveiled Mr. Bush’s portrait at the White House in 2012.

column3: Obama's Delicate Task at Bush Library Event
column4: Although Mr. Obama praised his predecessor’s “extraordinary strength and resolve” after the Sept. 11 attacks, he noted “just how breathtaking the financial crisis” he had left behind turned out to be.

column3: Obama's Delicate Task at Bush Library Event
column4: Marc Thiessen, a chief speechwriter in the Bush White House, said the test on Thursday would be whether Mr. Obama could be “substantively generous,” not just “personally generous.” In other words, would Mr. Obama acknowledge that despite their differences over Iraq, health care and other issues, Mr. Bush accomplished worthy things in office, like his fight against AIDS in Africa?

column3: Obama's Delicate Task at Bush Library Event
column4: “He’s never going to say this,” Mr. Thiessen said, “but if he’s being totally honest, he would say that except for interrogations, he adopted almost the entire Bush counterterrorism policy, some of it voluntarily, some of it involuntarily, but most of it voluntarily.” Mr. Obama and Mr. Bush have more in common than either might admit.

column3: Obama's Delicate Task at Bush Library Event
column4: They both value discipline and an orderly operation.

column3: Obama's Delicate Task at Bush Library Event
column4: They are both politicians intent on transformational presidencies.

column3: Obama's Delicate Task at Bush Library Event
column4: They both proved polarizing even though they arrived in Washington promising bipartisanship.

column3: Obama's Delicate Task at Bush Library Event
column4: But they have never connected in a meaningful way, leaving many in both camps to watch closely how they interact on Thursday.

column3: Obama's Delicate Task at Bush Library Event
column4: Past library openings have proved to be bonding moments: Mr. Clinton praised the elder Mr. Bush at his library opening in 1997, and both Bushes returned the favor at his dedication seven years later.

column3: Obama's Delicate Task at Bush Library Event
column4: Mr. Clinton was touched and has since become a virtual adopted member of the Bush family.

column3: Obama's Delicate Task at Bush Library Event
column4: “It was 2004 at the dedication of the Clinton library where the friendship was really renewed,” said James L. Rutherford III, known as Skip, a longtime friend of Mr. Clinton’s and the dean of the Clinton School of Public Service at the University of Arkansas.

column3: Obama's Delicate Task at Bush Library Event
column4: “That’s where they really bonded again and have remained good friends ever since.

column3: Obama's Delicate Task at Bush Library Event
column4: “That’s one of the beauties of the presidential library system,” he added.

column3: Obama's Delicate Task at Bush Library Event
column4: “That makes that possible.”

column4: "And if we do that it will be in large part thanks to the hard work of President George W.

column3: Democrat reveals 3 things liberals don't get about George W. Bush
column4: Thursday, April 25, on the Southern Methodist University campus in Dallas, Texas, four living presidents — Jimmy Carter, No.

column3: Democrat reveals 3 things liberals don't get about George W. Bush
column4: 39; George H.W.

column3: Democrat reveals 3 things liberals don't get about George W. Bush
column4: Bush, No.

column3: Democrat reveals 3 things liberals don't get about George W. Bush
column4: 41; Bill Clinton, No.

column3: Democrat reveals 3 things liberals don't get about George W. Bush
column4: 42, and Barack Obama, No.

column3: Democrat reveals 3 things liberals don't get about George W. Bush
column4: 44 — will honor one of their colleagues, George W. Bush, the 43rd president of the United States, at the dedication of his presidential library.

column3: Democrat reveals 3 things liberals don't get about George W. Bush
column4: So I take this occasion to remind my fellow liberal Democrats, many of whom continue to attack Bush in harsh and personal terms, of three things about him that I don’t think they understand or appreciate.

column3: Democrat reveals 3 things liberals don't get about George W. Bush
column4: First, while there were many polices under Bush with which liberal Democrats (myself included) disagreed — such as tax cuts, the Iraq War and not paying for either (as well as the Afghan war) with current revenues rather than borrowed money — there must be a distinction between disagreement and personal attack.

column3: Democrat reveals 3 things liberals don't get about George W. Bush
column4: [pullquote] For example, many Democrats still use the “lie” word in describing Bush’s rationale for the Iraq War — that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction.

column3: Democrat reveals 3 things liberals don't get about George W. Bush
column4: This turned out to be wrong.But Democrats in the Clinton administration also believed Saddam had WMDs, as did most experts in the U.S. intelligence community.

column3: Democrat reveals 3 things liberals don't get about George W. Bush
column4: Our politics have become so poisoned and our government so dysfunctional precisely because too many people — on both sides — can’t make a distinction between lies and being sincerely wrong.

column3: Democrat reveals 3 things liberals don't get about George W. Bush
column4: Second, Bush is known for his brilliant slogan when he first ran in 2000, describing himself as a “compassionate conservative.” But let’s not forget that on many issues, Bush was more “compassionate” than “conservative” — indeed, he was sometimes closer to Republican Theodore Roosevelt’s free-market progressivism than William Howard Taft’s laissez-faire conservatism.

column3: Democrat reveals 3 things liberals don't get about George W. Bush
column4: Examples include “No Child Left Behind” education reform, presented together at the White House by Bush and the liberal icon Sen. Edward Kennedy (D-Mass.)

column3: Democrat reveals 3 things liberals don't get about George W. Bush
column4: in the early days of the Bush presidency; support for broad immigration reform, very similar to the bipartisan legislation recently proposed in the Senate; and an extension of Medicare to include prescription drug benefits — the most far-reaching and generous Medicare reform since Lyndon Johnson.

column3: Democrat reveals 3 things liberals don't get about George W. Bush
column4: Third, it is important to remember what a good man with a good heart George W. Bush is.

column3: Democrat reveals 3 things liberals don't get about George W. Bush
column4: I know from personal experience.

column3: Democrat reveals 3 things liberals don't get about George W. Bush
column4: As I have written before, I remember sitting next to Bush when we were in the same residential college at Yale (Davenport — he graduated a year after me).

column3: Democrat reveals 3 things liberals don't get about George W. Bush
column4: I recall an evening when a group of us was sitting in the common room outside the college dining hall after dinner and a fellow Yale student walked by who was known to be gay, but in those days was not “out.” Someone said some ugly homophobic slurs.

column3: Democrat reveals 3 things liberals don't get about George W. Bush
column4: I didn’t like it, yet sat silently.

column3: Democrat reveals 3 things liberals don't get about George W. Bush
column4: But Bush snapped, saying something like “Hey, knock it off.

column3: Democrat reveals 3 things liberals don't get about George W. Bush
column4: Why don’t you walk in his shoes awhile and feel what he feels?” I remember thinking, “Whoa.

column3: Democrat reveals 3 things liberals don't get about George W. Bush
column4: This guy is much different inside than the fun-loving frat brother partying with me at Delta Kappa Epsilon.” As I watched him grow and evolve over the years, overcoming times of great personal pain and challenge to become a two-time governor of Texas and a two-term president of the United States, I only came to admire and like him even more than that evening at Yale.

column3: Democrat reveals 3 things liberals don't get about George W. Bush
column4: My late mother always used to say you can judge people on how they love and treat animals — good if they do, bad if they don’t.

column3: Democrat reveals 3 things liberals don't get about George W. Bush
column4: When Bush’s beloved dog, Barney, died recently, the statement he issued exemplified for me the inner core of goodness on my mother’s scale of judgment.

column3: Democrat reveals 3 things liberals don't get about George W. Bush
column4: “Barney never discussed politics,” he said in bidding Barney a sad farewell, “and he was always a faithful friend.

column3: Democrat reveals 3 things liberals don't get about George W. Bush
column4: Laura and I will miss our pal.” I know my mom in heaven, who would never have voted for George W. Bush for president, would have read that comment about Barney and insisted: “He is a good man.” I agree.

column3: Democrat reveals 3 things liberals don't get about George W. Bush
column4: Godspeed to you, George Bush, and blessings for your mom and dad and family on this great occasion.

column3: Democrat reveals 3 things liberals don't get about George W. Bush
column4: Lanny Davis is a regular weekly columnist for The Hill.

column3: Democrat reveals 3 things liberals don't get about George W. Bush
column4: In 1996-98, Davis served as special counsel to President Bill Clinton.

column3: Democrat reveals 3 things liberals don't get about George W. Bush
column4: He attended Yale Law School with Hillary Clinton in 1969-70 and has remained friends with her ever since.

column3: Democrat reveals 3 things liberals don't get about George W. Bush
column4: He is the author of the book, "Crisis Tales: Five Rules for Coping With Crises in Business, Politics, and Life," (Simon & Schuster March 2013).

column3: Democrat reveals 3 things liberals don't get about George W. Bush

column3: George W. Bush: A Disastrous President
column4: I wish the entire Bush family well and am pleased that the former presidents are sharing the opening of the Bush presidential library.

column3: George W. Bush: A Disastrous President
column4: But, as I wrote in my last column for The Hill calling for confirmation of all judicial nominations, it was President Bush and Karl Rove who corrupted American justice more than any president since Richard Nixon.

column3: George W. Bush: A Disastrous President
column4: The Bush presidency was a disastrous presidency which caused a range catastrophes including the Iraq war, the budget deficit, and the financial crash.

column3: George W. Bush: A Disastrous President
column4: The trouble began when Bush was warned in an intelligence briefing about the threat of terrorists flying planes into buildings in New York and treated these warnings with contempt.

column3: George W. Bush: A Disastrous President
column4: Bush did receive these warnings.

column3: George W. Bush: A Disastrous President
column4: He did treat them with contempt.

column3: George W. Bush: A Disastrous President
column4: He did not take action that was called for.

column3: George W. Bush: A Disastrous President
column4: The rest is history.

column3: George W. Bush: A Disastrous President
column4: Perhaps Republicans obsessed with Benghazi might convene hearings about this.

column3: George W. Bush: A Disastrous President
column4: After the attacks on September 11, 2001 Bush used those attacks to create fear and win votes and drive America to war in Iraq.

column3: George W. Bush: A Disastrous President
column4: It was an unwise war.

column3: George W. Bush: A Disastrous President
column4: As a result, when there was opportunity to kill Osama bin Laden that opportunity was missed because of the Iraq obsession.

column3: George W. Bush: A Disastrous President
column4: As a result, four things happened which continue to plague America today: First, the unwise Iraq war, a war which should never have been fought.

column3: George W. Bush: A Disastrous President
column4: The big winner of the Iraq war was Iran.

column3: George W. Bush: A Disastrous President
column4: Second, the war in Afghanistan was virtually won shortly after it was initiated, but that advantage was completely lost because resources were diverted away from Afghanistan to Iraq.

column3: George W. Bush: A Disastrous President
column4: Bush gave America an Iraq war that should never have been fought, and gave America an Afghanistan war that should have ended successfully 10 years ago.

column3: George W. Bush: A Disastrous President
column4: Third, because Bush pushed massive tax cuts, which disproportionately favored the wealthy, which cost the Treasury huge revenue, while he led America to war in Iraq, which created great costs, and prolonged the Afghanistan war, which created great costs, Bush was responsible for huge deficits.

column3: George W. Bush: A Disastrous President
column4: The prime reason the Clinton surplus became the Bush deficits was that Bush combined major wars with major tax cuts which created, inevitably, major deficits.

column3: George W. Bush: A Disastrous President
column4: Fourth, the deregulatory fever and crony capitalism of the Bush years contributed mightily to the financial crash that continues to plague America.

column3: George W. Bush: A Disastrous President
column4: Virtually all Republicans supported these gigantic and disastrous blunders stated above.

column3: George W. Bush: A Disastrous President
column4: I am sad to say, too many Democrats went along with them.

column3: George W. Bush: A Disastrous President
column4: Sound familiar?

column3: George W. Bush: A Disastrous President
column4: I wish George W. Bush, his wonderful wife Laura, his daughters and former President George H. W. Bush all the best.

column3: George W. Bush: A Disastrous President
column4: I believe it is perfectly appropriate for all living former presidents to join the Bush family in the opening of the Bush library.

column3: George W. Bush: A Disastrous President
column4: But make no mistake: the Bush presidency was a disaster.
