column3: No Room for Radicals
column4: JUST hours after the two suspects in the Boston Marathon bombing were identified as Muslims, Representative Peter T. King of New York, the Republican chairman of the House Subcommittee on Counterterrorism and Intelligence, called for an “increased surveillance” of Islamic communities in the United States.

column3: No Room for Radicals
column4: “I think we need more police and more surveillance in the communities where the threat is coming from,” he told National Review.

column3: No Room for Radicals
column4: “The new threat is definitely from within.” Mr. King’s hypothesis, and the widespread surveillance policies already in effect since 9/11, assume that the threat of radicalization has become a matter of local geography, that American Muslims are creating extremists in our mosques and community centers.

column3: No Room for Radicals
column4: But what we’re learning of the suspects, the brothers Tamerlan and Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, suggests a different story, and one that has itself become familiar: radicalization does not happen to young people with a strong grounding in the American Muslim mainstream; increasingly, it happens online, and sometimes abroad, among the isolated and disaffected.

column3: No Room for Radicals
column4: The YouTube page of Tamerlan Tsarnaev, for example, does not contain a single lecture from a scholar, imam or institution in America.

column3: No Room for Radicals
column4: One report suggests that he found the theology taught in a local Cambridge mosque, the Islamic Society of Boston, unpalatable: while attending a Friday service in which an imam praised the life and work of the Rev.

column3: No Room for Radicals
column4: Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Mr. Tsarnaev shouted that the imam was a “nonbeliever.” The younger Tsarnaev brother seems to have rarely attended a mosque at all.

column3: No Room for Radicals
column4: Representative King’s theories also fail to explain why, if young people are being radicalized within mainstream Islamic communities, there aren’t more attacks like the one in Boston.

column3: No Room for Radicals
column4: By some measures Islam is the fastest-growing religion in the United States, and the last decade has seen a rapid expansion of Muslim institutions across the country.

column3: No Room for Radicals
column4: Yet what’s most obvious to anyone who has spent time in these communities is that whether they are devotional or educational, focused on the arts or on interfaith cooperation and activism, this mediating set of American Muslim institutions is keeping impressionable young Muslims from becoming radicalized.

column3: No Room for Radicals
column4: Take the Islamic Society of Boston Cultural Center and its range of devotional, arts and educational programs, from preschool to a seminary.

column3: No Room for Radicals
column4: Or Chicago’s Inner-City Muslim Action Network, complete with a medical clinic, civic leadership education and a summer music festival that draws on the biggest names of Muslim hip-hop to promote peace through community organizing.

column3: No Room for Radicals
column4: Or Zaytuna College in Berkeley, Calif., the nation’s first four-year Islamic liberal arts school.

column3: No Room for Radicals
column4: These institutions and others have different aims, but they abide by a common idea: if the center of Judaism is the law, and the heart of Christianity is love, what Islam requires, above all else, is mercy.

column3: No Room for Radicals
column4: And whether on display in health care provided for the poor at South Los Angeles’s UMMA Community Clinic, or in a patiently handled Arabic lesson that will one day lead a new convert into the fullness of the tradition, Islamic mercy, preached and practiced within the community, allows no room for radicalization.

column3: No Room for Radicals
column4: Representative King and others have it exactly, completely wrong — the American Muslim community has actively and repeatedly, day in and day out, rejected such radicals on religious grounds: they do not know mercy.

column3: No Room for Radicals
column4: More than a decade since 9/11, this should no longer be any secret.

column3: No Room for Radicals
column4: Across the nation, the doors are open, and more are opening every day.

column3: No Room for Radicals
column4: And despite whatever misplaced fears the Boston bombings evoke about radical Islam and homegrown terror, we’ll all find ourselves increasingly secure as more Muslims heed the call — coming to Islam as it is in the United States, as a real, living community.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: New details are emerging about the religious motivations of Boston bombing suspects Tamerlan and Dzhokhar Tsarnaev and their recent interest in Chechnya, which experts say has become a hub for the extremist Saudi sect of Islam known as Wahhabism.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: The brothers are ethnically Chechen, though Dzhokhar was born in the Russian republic of Dagestan while his deceased older brother Tamerlan was born in the neighboring Russian republic of Kalmykia.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: Their parents confirmed that Tamerlan visited Dagestan and Chechnya last year, but denied reports that he did so to engage in militant Islamist training.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: University of Massachusetts-Dartmouth Professor Brian Glyn Williams, who mentored the younger Tsarnaev brother via email for his class on the War on Terror, noted the brothers’ growing sense of Chechen identity.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: Williams also posited that Tamerlan Tsarnaev became radicalized during his trip to Russia and also helped influence his younger brother.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: “That kid [Dzhokhar] and his brother identified with the Chechen struggle,” he said in an email to Steve Urbon of South Coast recently.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: “He was learning his Chechen identity, identifying with the diaspora and identifying with his homeland,” Williams said of Dzhokhar.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: “He wanted to learn more about Chechnya, who the fighters were, who the commanders were.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: I sort of gave him background.” Chechnya and Dagestan, separate Russian republics nestled in the North Caucasus, have majority Muslim populations that have long been influenced by Wahhabism, described by the U.S. Congressional Research Service as a “puritanical” form of Sunni Islam whose practice is centered in Saudi Arabia.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: U.S. officials maintain that the Tsarnaevs acted on their own and were not connected with any other groups — taking pains to affirm the innocence of two Saudi students questioned in Boston on the day of the bombings.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: One of those Saudi students, Abdul Rahman Ali Alharbi, was initially a person of interest in the bombings and Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano confirmed Tuesday that he was placed on a terror watch list after the attack.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: An event file created by federal law enforcement agents on April 16 called for his visa to be revoked, citing a terrorism threat, and indicated he was not properly vetted before being admitted to the U.S.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: While no current evidence links Alharbi to the Tsarnaev brothers, preliminary statements from the interrogation of Dzhokhar suggests the brothers were motivated by Islam.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: Additionally, the brothers appear to have been driven by a radical brand of Islam — although U.S. officials claimed they do not seem connected to any Muslim terrorist groups.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: That raises this question: Just how influential is Islam, and Saudi-Wahhabism in particular, in Chechnya and Dagestan?

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: Background on the region Chechnya and Dagestan lost their independence to Russia some 200 years ago at the hands of Tsar Nicholas I and have been, in some way shape or form, fighting ever since.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: In fact, Dr. Andrew Bostom, author of the scholarly volume, “The Legacy of Islamic Jihad,” told TheBlaze that Chechnya, which first adopted Islam in the 7th Century, is indeed “the hub” for all jihadist activity in the entire Caucasus region.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: What’s more, he also said it has also become a hub for the extremist sect of Sunni Islam known as Wahhabism.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: According to Ksenia Svetlova, an analyst for Israel’s Channel 9 who holds a doctorate in Middle Eastern Studies from the Hebrew University, Chechnya and Dagestan became a hotbed of Wahhabism from the early 1990s.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: “Mosques and madrasas were opened; training camps for young combatants were established to prepare them for the ‘jihad against the infidels,'” Svetlova wrote in an article explaining the region’s bent towards radical Islam.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: According to the scholar, the teachings of Wahhabist jihadi Said Buryatsky “are among the most downloaded files in Chechnya.” Svetlova also notes that Wahhabists “send money to religious institutions around the world, including in Chechnya and Dagestan.” By the late 1980s, Saudi Arabia also began sending clerics, scholars and “jihadist combatants” to the Caucasus, according to Svetlova.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: Also worth noting is that Saudi Arabia has, according to Bostom, long been known to fund projects as simple as providing language-translations of the Koran and Hadiths, ensuring that people of all walks can digest Islamic sacred texts regardless of their mother tongue.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: “That is often one of their most simple and legal forms of propaganda,” Bostom told TheBlaze.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: “To get Koran and Hadith into every population and I am sure they did this in Caucasus, just as I’m sure they funded the jihadists against the Soviets just as they did in Afghanistan.” Wahhabism in the North Caucasus Wahhabism, which originated in the Arabian peninsula during the 18th century, was meant as a return to a purer form of Islam by adopting a literal interpretation of the Koran and Hadiths.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: It is the predominant sect of Sunni Islam practiced in Saudi Arabia.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: “Wahhabism became an attractive alternative to the complicated mystic ideology of ‘normative’ Sufi Islam for a certain segment of Chechen believers,” noted Emil Souleimanov, author of “An Endless War: The Russian-Chechen Conflict In Perspective.” “It [Wahhabism] especially appealed to the militarized and–owing to the war–radicalized youth.” Souleimanov notes the irony in Chechen youths’ adoption of Wahhabism as a form of personal freedom, given the sects ultra-conservative restraints.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: “Yet in post-war Chechnya the egalitarian and militant spirit of Wahhabism seemed to be a desirable alternative to the rigid social structure.” The author goes on to note that despite the Wahhabists strict, extremist bent, Chechens by and large will not renounce the sect nor even openly criticize it.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: Rather, Chechens applaud young ideologues for being honorable enough to refrain from drugs, alcohol and for allowing themselves to be martyred for their cause.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: This, coupled with the fact that Wahhabi emissaries, according to the author, have often provided Chechens with charity, has gone a long way in creating a society that will likely refrain from acting out against the Wahhabi influence.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: What is perhaps most interesting about Chechnya, is that one would expect the republic’s current pro-Putin government, led by Sufi president Ramzan Kadyrov, to soften the Islamic influence in the North Caucasus.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: Rather, Kadyrov, while an opponent of Wahhabism, is no moderate and has been outspoken in his desire to implement Sharia law in Chechnya.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: This perhaps underscores the radical elements present even within the “moderate” sects of the North Caucasus.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: Wartime  and Wahhabism While the first and second Chechnya Wars of the 1990s were characterized by many as simply “nationalistic” struggles for independence against the Russian Federation, experts note it was more about the establishment of an Islamic caliphate some Chechens have been after.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: The first Chechnya War began before the collapse of the Soviet Union and lasted nearly two years, during which time thousands of civilians on both sides perished.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: The Soviets inevitably prevailed, but it was not before long an even more radicalized Chechen populace, under the banner of the Islamic International Brigade, challenged Moscow again, this time by invading Dagestan.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: The pretext for Islamists was that Chechnya would overtake Dagestan and declare the two republics as a single, unified, independent Islamic state.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: In 1997, ethnic Avar (the predominant tribe in Dagestan) and Wahhabist Bagauddin Magomedov, who served as “Emir of the Islamic Jamaat of Dagestan,” fled to Chechnya to woo neighboring Wahhabi-leaders.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: Soon, an “Islamic Legion” was formed and by the Spring of 1999, Magomedov, according to Souleimanov, made an appeal to the “Islamic patriots of the Caucasus” to “take part in the jihad” and help in “liberating Dagestan and the Caucasus from the Russian colonial yoke.” Needless to say, the Russians weren’t having any of it and, like the last time, they reigned victorious.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: What resulted was the installment of a pro-Moscow government in Chechnya (now led by President Ramzan Kadyrov) and a steady stream of low-level internal insurgencies coupled with more serious terror cell activity conducted by international jihadists who have used Chechnya as a base of operations.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: Jihadi links with Chechnya and Dagestan Chechnya has long been an outpost from which jihadists have operated.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: Consider the fact that 9/11 mastermind Osama bin Laden openly backed the Chechens in the 1990s during their wartime struggles against Russia, and 9/11 hijacker Zacarias Moussaoui was, according to the Wall Street Journal, “a recruiter for al-Qaeda-backed rebels in Chechnya.” Chechen militants fought with al-Qaeda and Taliban forces against the U.S.-backed Northern Alliance in late 2001.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: Even German al Qaeda operative Christian Ganczarski went on to Chechnya after becoming radicalized in Saudi Arabia, which has reportedly furnished thousands of international scholarships to young men in an effort to provide al Qaeda with a steady stream of new recruits.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: Other Chechen-related jihadist attacks include the 2002 incident in which 40 terrorists — mostly women in hijabs dubbed the “Black Widows” — took more than 700 hostages at a Moscow theater demanding Chechen independence.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: In the end they blew themselves up in a suicide mission, claiming 100 other movie-goers.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: Then, in 2004, jihadists demanding Chechen independence infamously set siege to a school in Beslan, North Ossetia, taking 1200 hostage.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: While they were defeated in the end, the Islamists killed 334 hostages, including 186 children.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: What’s more, Chechen jihadist Doku (Dokka) Umarov leads the Caucasus Emirate, a group designated by both the Russian Federation and the United States as a terrorist organization.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: Umarov, who fought in both Chechnyan wars against Russia, is known as the Chechen Osama bin Laden.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: He has claimed credit for ordering the Moscow airport bombing in January 2011 that killed 36 people and injured 180 others, and the March 2010 suicide bombings that targeted the Moscow subway system and killed 39 people.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: He also reportedly ordered the November 2009 bombing of a train to St. Petersburg from Moscow that killed 26 people, according to the BBC.

column4: The Caucasus Emirate, which was linked to on Tamerlan Tsarnaev’s reported YouTube page, is aligned ideologically and through its members, with al Qaeda and seeks the establishment of an Islamic State in the Caucasus.

column3: Details Emerge on Religious Motives of Boston Bomb Suspects and Recent Interest in Chechnya  - a Hub of Extremist Saudi Wahhabism
column4: Former CIA operative and senior fellow with the Center for Security Policy, Clare Lopez, told TheBlaze that there are many al Qaeda-Chechen ties.

column4: “It’s not all about Russia,” Lopez said in an email.

column4: The portrait investigators have begun to piece together of the two brothers suspected of the Boston Marathon bombings suggests that they were motivated by extremist Islamic beliefs but were not acting with known terrorist groups â and that they may have learned to build bombs simply by logging onto the online English-language magazine of the affiliate of Al Qaeda in Yemen, law enforcement officials said Tuesday.

column3: Boston Suspects Are Seen as Self-Taught and Fueled by Web
column4: The investigation into the bombings is still in its earliest stages, and federal authorities were still in the process of corroborating some of the admissions that law enforcement officials said were made by the surviving suspect in the attacks,Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, 19.

column3: Boston Suspects Are Seen as Self-Taught and Fueled by Web
column4: But they said some of his statements suggested that the two brothers could represent the kind of emerging threat that federal authorities have long feared: angry and alienated young men, apparently self-trained and unaffiliated with any particular terrorist group, able to use the Internet to learn their lethal craft.

column3: Boston Suspects Are Seen as Self-Taught and Fueled by Web

column3: Boston Suspects Are Seen as Self-Taught and Fueled by Web
column4: and intelligence officials Tuesday evening that the suspects were most likely radicalized over the Internet, but that investigators were still searching for possible sources of inspiration or support overseas.

column4: âThe increasing signals are that these were individuals who were radicalized, especially the older brother, over a period of time â radicalized by Islamist fundamentalist terrorists, basically using Internet sources to gain not just the types of philosophical beliefs that radicalized them, but also learning components of how to do these sorts of things,â Mr. Rubio told reporters.

column3: Boston Suspects Are Seen as Self-Taught and Fueled by Web
column4: âThis is a new element of terrorism that we have to face in our country,â Mr. Rubio said.

column3: Boston Suspects Are Seen as Self-Taught and Fueled by Web
column4: âWe need to be prepared for Boston-type attacks, not just 9/11-type attacks.â Dzhokhar Tsarnaev admitted to playing a role in the marathon bombings, which killed three people and wounded more than 260, and told federal agents that he and his brother were motivated by extremist Islamic beliefs, when he was interviewed Sunday at the hospital, law enforcement officials said.

column3: Boston Suspects Are Seen as Self-Taught and Fueled by Web

column3: Boston Suspects Are Seen as Self-Taught and Fueled by Web
column4: Now investigators will try to check Mr. Tsarnaevâs statements as they conduct a wide-ranging inquiry into the lives of the two brothers, speaking with people who knew them and looking at everything from items they left behind in their homes and, in the case of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, his dorm room, to the lengthy digital trail they left through their e-mails and posts on social media sites.

column3: Boston Suspects Are Seen as Self-Taught and Fueled by Web

DeLuca, also said that Ms. Russell, who grew up in North Kingstown, R.I., and met Mr. Tsarnaev when she was a student at Suffolk University, was âdoing everything she can to assist with the investigation.â

column3: Big news: Max Baucus to retire
column4: The first Senate casualty of ObamaCare?

column3: Big news: Max Baucus to retire
column4: First elected in 1978, Baucus has been the top Democrat on the powerful tax-writing committee for more than a dozen years.

column3: Big news: Max Baucus to retire
column4: At times infuriating his Democratic colleagues, he worked with Republicans to co-write the Bush-era tax cuts and the Medicare prescription drug plan, but he also served as the lead defender against George W. Bush’s 2005 effort to partially privatize Social Security and played a critical role in writing President Obama’s national health-care plan… Despite Obama’s double-digit defeat in Montana, Democrats intend to vigorously defend the seat.

column3: Big news: Max Baucus to retire
column4: The leading Democratic candidate is former governor Schweitzer, a popular figure who at times has feuded with Baucus over parochial political issues in the Big Sky state.

column3: Big news: Max Baucus to retire
column4: He made news twice last week, once for voting against the Democrats’ gun-control bills and the other for warning that ObamaCare, of which he was a lead architect, would be a “train wreck” if not implemented properly.

column3: Big news: Max Baucus to retire
column4: Maybe he hears the train whistle in the distance and figures he’ll get off the tracks now.

column3: Big news: Max Baucus to retire
column4: As for the gun-control votes, two theories.

column3: Big news: Max Baucus to retire
column4: One: He really does believe in gun rights.

column3: Big news: Max Baucus to retire
column4: He’s not just pandering to his red-state constituency.

column3: Big news: Max Baucus to retire
column4: Two: He was fully prepared to run again (he has millions in the bank to fund a campaign), but something happened between last Wednesday and today to make him suddenly reconsider.

column3: Big news: Max Baucus to retire
column4: Hmmm.

column3: Big news: Max Baucus to retire
column4: Normally the retirement of a six-term Democratic incumbent from a conservative state is cause for celebration, but I don’t know.

column3: Big news: Max Baucus to retire
column4: When PPP polled Montana two months ago, Baucus’s approval was underwater at 45/48.

column3: Big news: Max Baucus to retire
column4: Republicans will be out in force next year for the midterms, and Baucus hasn’t had to run a midterm campaign under a Democratic president since his first election in 1978.

column3: Big news: Max Baucus to retire
column4: With ObamaCare hanging over his head, he was beatable.

column3: Big news: Max Baucus to retire
column4: Brian Schweitzer, his likely replacement as Democratic nominee who once said he couldn’t run for Senate because he’s not “senile enough,” has huge name recognition as governor, a favorable rating of 56/37 per PPP, and none of Baucus’s Senate baggage (“Too tied to the Washington special interests, too aloof, too close to the Obama administration”).

column3: Big news: Max Baucus to retire
column4: Arguably the Democrats are trading up here, to the point where I’m tempted to wonder if maybe they pushed Baucus out somehow.

column3: Big news: Max Baucus to retire
column4: Is that even possible, though, with a six-term Senator who’s written most of the country’s tax laws?

column3: Big news: Max Baucus to retire
column4: They’d have to have some awfully grimy dirt on him.

column3: Big news: Max Baucus to retire
column4: And if they did, why not drop it on him before the gun votes so that he’d vote their way?

column3: Big news: Max Baucus to retire
column4: Exit question: What will the poor lobbyists do now?

column3: Big news: Max Baucus to retire
column4: Update: Via NRO’s Andrew Stiles, here’s Schweitzer four days ago checking the gun-rights box: Former Montana Gov.

column3: Big news: Max Baucus to retire
column4: Brian Schweitzer says his position on gun control is one reason he couldn’t step onto the national political stage.

column3: Big news: Max Baucus to retire
column4: Political pundits have mentioned Schweitzer as a possible candidate for the 2016 Democratic presidential nomination.

column3: Big news: Max Baucus to retire
column4: The Bozeman Daily Chronicle reports a bearded Schweitzer told some Montana State University students on Thursday that he couldn’t give an acceptable answer to voters in states like Iowa and Florida if they asked him about gun control.

column3: Big news: Max Baucus to retire
column4: He says his response would be something like: “You control yours, I’ll control mine.”

column3: Sen. Baucus Angers Dems by Retiring
column4: Senator Max Baucus, a Montana Democrat and chairman of the Finance Committee, has decided to not seek re-election in 2014, ABC News has learned, becoming the eighth senator to step down next year.

column3: Sen. Baucus Angers Dems by Retiring
column4: Baucus, who has served in the Senate for 36 years, intends to make his announcement this afternoon.

column3: Sen. Baucus Angers Dems by Retiring
column4: The decision surprised - and angered - some Democrats, given his vote last week against expanding background checks in the gun debate - a top priority of President Obama.

column3: Sen. Baucus Angers Dems by Retiring
column4: Related: Senate Rejects Background Checks Legislation The retirement of Baucus gives Republicans another opportunity in its quest to win control of the Senate.

column3: Sen. Baucus Angers Dems by Retiring
column4: But the race could still be intensely competitive for Democrats, particularly if former Gov.

column3: Sen. Baucus Angers Dems by Retiring
column4: Brian Schweitzer, one of the state's most popular figures, runs for the Senate seat.

column3: Sen. Baucus Angers Dems by Retiring
column4: Democrats are now defending open seats in Iowa, Michigan, Montana, New Jersey, South Dakota and West Virginia.

column3: Sen. Baucus Angers Dems by Retiring
column4: Republicans need to pick up six seats to win a majority in the Senate.

column3: Sen. Baucus Angers Dems by Retiring
column4: A friend of Baucus told ABC News today that he has been thinking about retiring "for a long time."

column3: Sen. Baucus Angers Dems by Retiring
column4: He has recently been remarried and "is finally happy," the friend said.

column3: Sen. Baucus Angers Dems by Retiring
column4: "At 72, he can still have a life," the friend said.

column3: Sen. Baucus Angers Dems by Retiring
column4: "It's harder to do that at 79."

column3: Sen. Baucus Angers Dems by Retiring
column4: But Baucus was clearly keeping his options open.

column3: Sen. Baucus Angers Dems by Retiring
column4: He has about $5 million in his campaign account and has been aggressively raising money and meeting with donors this year.

column3: Sen. Baucus Angers Dems by Retiring
column4: A week ago, he said the implementation of the nation?s new health care law had been a ?train wreck.?

column3: Sen. Baucus Angers Dems by Retiring
column4: That was among the conservative remarks and votes that had agitated many liberal Democrats.

column3: Sen. Baucus Angers Dems by Retiring
column4: Baucus has also been losing fights within his party.

column3: Sen. Baucus Angers Dems by Retiring
column4: The latest example is Internet sales tax legislation being considered this week in the Senate - over the fierce objections of Baucus, the chairman of the Finance Committee.

column3: Sen. Baucus Angers Dems by Retiring
column4: He disappointed many Democrats during the Obamacare debate when as a top negotiator he determined a public health insurance option should not be included in the bill.

column3: Sen. Baucus Angers Dems by Retiring
column4: And he helped former President George W. Bush enact Medicare Part D, the prescription drug benefit, as well as sweeping tax cuts.

column3: Sen. Baucus Angers Dems by Retiring
column4: But while Baucus may have not been as liberal as some in his party, he did get results.

column3: Sen. Baucus Angers Dems by Retiring
column4: Obamacare eventually passed.

column3: Sen. Baucus Angers Dems by Retiring
column4: The prescription drug benefit is an integral part of Medicare, and President Obama has protected the Bush era tax cuts for the majority of wage earners.

column3: Sen. Baucus Angers Dems by Retiring
column4: The face of the Senate is changing rapidly, with Baucus joining Democratic Senators Tom Harkin of Iowa, Jay Rockefeller of West Virginia, Carl Levin of Michigan, Frank Lautenberg of New Jersey and Tim Johnson of South Dakota in retirement.

column3: Sen. Baucus Angers Dems by Retiring
column4: Republican Senators Mike Johanns of Nebraska and Saxby Chambliss of Georgia also have announced their intention not to seek re-election.

column3: Boston Bombing Suspect Is Not Being Read His Miranda Rights - Why and What Does That Mean?
column4: Boston Marathon bombing suspect Dzhokhar Tsarnaev will not immediately be read his Miranda rights before he is questioned by investigators, U.S. government officials confirmed to multiple news networks.

column3: Boston Bombing Suspect Is Not Being Read His Miranda Rights - Why and What Does That Mean?
column4: Instead, the government is invoking the “public safety” exception that can be triggered when authorities believe there is a need to protect the public from immediate danger.

column3: Boston Bombing Suspect Is Not Being Read His Miranda Rights - Why and What Does That Mean?
column4: This means Tsarnaev can be questioned immediately without being officially warned of his right to remain silent, his right to an attorney, and the caution that anything he says can be used against him in trial.

column3: Boston Bombing Suspect Is Not Being Read His Miranda Rights - Why and What Does That Mean?
column4: “There is a public safety exemption in cases of national security and for acts of terrorism,” U.S. Attorney Carmen Ortiz told reporters Friday night.

column3: Boston Bombing Suspect Is Not Being Read His Miranda Rights - Why and What Does That Mean?
column4: The FBI has a full explainer of the public safety exception, but here’s the takeaway [emphasis added]: When police officers are confronted by a concern for public safety, Miranda warnings need not be provided prior to asking questions directed at neutralizing an imminent threat, and voluntary statements made in response to such narrowly tailored questions can be admitted at trial.

column3: Boston Bombing Suspect Is Not Being Read His Miranda Rights - Why and What Does That Mean?
column4: Once the questions turn from those designed to resolve the concern for safety to questions designed solely to elicit incriminating statements, the questioning falls outside the scope of the exception and within the traditional rules of Miranda.

column3: Boston Bombing Suspect Is Not Being Read His Miranda Rights - Why and What Does That Mean?

column3: Lindsey Graham Makes Controversial Call On 'Enemy Combatant'
column4: EARLIER: Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) suggested on Friday that the Obama administration should toss the court system and Constitution out the window when handling the missing suspect in the Boston Marathon bombings.

column3: Lindsey Graham Makes Controversial Call On 'Enemy Combatant'
column4: In a series of tweets that came hours after it was revealed that Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the suspect at large in the Boston marathon bombings, is a United States citizen, Graham urged the Obama administration to nevertheless consider treating him as an enemy combatant.

column3: Lindsey Graham Makes Controversial Call On 'Enemy Combatant'
column4: The legal status has been used largely for members of al Qaeda and associated forces held at the Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, military facility and elsewhere.

column3: Lindsey Graham Makes Controversial Call On 'Enemy Combatant'
column4: Graham also suggested that the Obama administration should use a drone to track any suspects in the case.

column3: Lindsey Graham Makes Controversial Call On 'Enemy Combatant'
column4: America is “a battlefield because the terrorists think it is,” Graham told The Washington Post.

column3: Lindsey Graham Makes Controversial Call On 'Enemy Combatant'
column4: “It sure would be nice to have a drone up there.” Graham's tweets were just as provocative: If captured, I hope Administration will at least consider holding the Boston suspect as enemy combatant for intelligence gathering purposes.

column3: Lindsey Graham Makes Controversial Call On 'Enemy Combatant'
column4: — Lindsey Graham (@GrahamBlog) April 19, 2013 If the #Boston suspect has ties to overseas terror organizations he could be treasure trove ofinformation.

column3: Lindsey Graham Makes Controversial Call On 'Enemy Combatant'
column4: — Lindsey Graham (@GrahamBlog) April 19, 2013 The last thing we may want to do is read Boston suspect Miranda Rights telling him to "remain silent."

column3: Lindsey Graham Makes Controversial Call On 'Enemy Combatant'
column4: — Lindsey Graham (@GrahamBlog) April 19, 2013 The Obama Administration needs to be contemplating these issues and should not rush into a bad decision.

column3: Lindsey Graham Makes Controversial Call On 'Enemy Combatant'
column4: — Lindsey Graham (@GrahamBlog) April 19, 2013 Tamerlan Tsarnaev, Dzhokhar's brother who also was a suspect in Monday's fatal attack, was killed Friday morning while on the run from police.

column3: Lindsey Graham Makes Controversial Call On 'Enemy Combatant'
column4: No one, so far, has offered any evidence of a direct connection between either brother and al Qaeda, and at least one legal expert said the Obama administration simply wouldn't consider the status change for Tsarnaev.

column3: Lindsey Graham Makes Controversial Call On 'Enemy Combatant'
column4: The administration has, however, maintained that it can delay reading a Miranda warning to terrorists in exceptional cases.

column3: Lindsey Graham Makes Controversial Call On 'Enemy Combatant'
column4: The Obama administration has repeatedly refused to hold recent high-profile terrorist captures under military law.

column3: Lindsey Graham Makes Controversial Call On 'Enemy Combatant'
column4: Both the so-called underwear bomber and Sept. 11 mastermind Osama bin Laden's son-in-law were charged under civilian law.

column3: Lindsey Graham Makes Controversial Call On 'Enemy Combatant'

column3: Lindsey Graham Makes Controversial Call On 'Enemy Combatant'
column4: The administration also has stated that it would waive the use of enemy combatant status as it is described in the National Defense Authorization Act of 2012 in a wide variety of circumstances.

column3: Lindsey Graham Makes Controversial Call On 'Enemy Combatant'
column4: "The current administration has a firm and publicly stated policy against using military detention for domestic captures or U.S. citizens.

column3: Lindsey Graham Makes Controversial Call On 'Enemy Combatant'
column4: So whatever the (National Defense Authorization Act) may theoretically authorize or tolerate, it doesn't affect this situation," wrote Benjamin Wittes, senior fellow and research director in public law at the Brookings Institution.

column3: Lindsey Graham Makes Controversial Call On 'Enemy Combatant'
column4: The Obama administration may nevertheless feel politically pressured to charge the remaining suspect under military law, just as it did after the underwear bomber's failed attempt to blow up a Detroit-bound plane.

column3: Lindsey Graham Makes Controversial Call On 'Enemy Combatant'
column4: Zeke Johnson, the director of Amnesty International USA's Security with Human Rights Campaign, said that would be a lamentable response to the Boston bombing.

column4: "Fear mongering is always the wrong response to tragedy.

column4: The right thing to do is fulfill the rights of victims and bring those responsible to justice through a fair trial," Johnson said.

column3: Bombing suspect in custody after standoff in Watertown
column4: WATERTOWN — Four days after two deadly explosions turned the finish line of the Boston Marathon into a scene of bloody chaos, the 19-year-old college student believed to be responsible for placing the bombs was taken into custody tonight, bringing a sense of relief and justice to a shaken region.

column3: Bombing suspect in custody after standoff in Watertown
column4: Dzhokhar A. Tsarnaev of Cambridge was pulled from his hiding place in a boat parked behind a house on Franklin Street shortly before 8:45 p.m. in this community just outside Boston.

column4: “We are eternally grateful for the outcome here tonight.

Davis said, citizens “can be confident that the threat has been removed.” President Obama, speaking at the White House tonight, said, “We’ve closed an important chapter in this tragedy.” But he also said there were “still many unanswered questions” and said the FBI would thoroughly investigate.

column3: Conservatives See a Turning Tide on Immigration
column4: WASHINGTON — Hours after a bipartisan group of eight senators introduced a sweeping overhaul of the nation’s immigration system, conservative radio talk show hosts took over two floors of a Capitol Hill hotel on Wednesday and denounced the proposal on the country’s drive-time airwaves as nothing more than a reward for lawbreakers.

column3: Conservatives See a Turning Tide on Immigration
column4: On a Florida station, WFTL, the host Joyce Kaufman called it “pure amnesty.” Jim Sharpe, a talk show host on KFYI in Phoenix, promised that “Arizonans are still not taking this sitting down.” On Denny Schaffer’s show in New Orleans, callers demanded deportations.

column3: Conservatives See a Turning Tide on Immigration
column4: “I see nothing wrong with putting them on a bus and shipping them back to wherever they came from,” a caller named Alan told Mr. Schaffer.

column3: Conservatives See a Turning Tide on Immigration
column4: “The law’s the law.” But even some of the talk show hosts most vehemently opposed to illegal immigration said they were worried that times have changed.

column3: Conservatives See a Turning Tide on Immigration
column4: They said their listeners seemed less agitated by the prospect that 11 million illegal immigrants might be granted legal status and concede that proponents of the legislation — who now include some conservative radio personalities — are better at promoting their message this time around.

column3: Conservatives See a Turning Tide on Immigration
column4: The senators filed their 844-page bill after 2 a.m. Wednesday, officially beginning what President Obama and other supporters hope will be a six-week effort to pass it in the Senate by early June.

column3: Conservatives See a Turning Tide on Immigration
column4: Hearings on the legislation, which tightens border security and offers an eventual path to citizenship, are set to begin on Friday.

column3: Conservatives See a Turning Tide on Immigration
column4: Opponents of the measure are eager to harness the conservative airwaves the way they did in 2007, when talk radio hosts helped whip up a fury of outrage that doomed similar legislation supported by President George W. Bush.

column3: Conservatives See a Turning Tide on Immigration
column4: This time there were 46 talk radio hosts sharing booths in the Phoenix Park Hotel, where they bent over their microphones and broadcast to places like Albany, Salt Lake City and Huntsville, Ala. “So far this has been an inside-the-Beltway echo chamber,” said Bob Dane, a spokesman for the Federation for American Immigration Reform, which organized the gathering.

column3: Conservatives See a Turning Tide on Immigration
column4: “What they have not had yet is a good, cold blast of air in the face from the rank-and-file conservative.

column3: Conservatives See a Turning Tide on Immigration
column4: We now have a bill.

column3: Conservatives See a Turning Tide on Immigration
column4: This is the game-changer where the American public is now starting to weigh in.” But how the public weighs in — and what they say when they call in to the shows — remains an open question.

column3: Conservatives See a Turning Tide on Immigration
column4: Sean Hannity, who in 2007 used his nationally syndicated radio program and perch at Fox News to rail against an immigration overhaul, now says that he has “evolved” and that it is time for Republicans to support some kind of major change in the nation’s immigration system.

column3: Conservatives See a Turning Tide on Immigration
column4: Opposition from some Republican lawmakers has softened since the 2012 presidential election, when Mr. Obama won the vast majority of Hispanic votes.

column3: Conservatives See a Turning Tide on Immigration
column4: Evangelical Christians, many of whom were opposed to an overhaul in 2007, are now among the biggest supporters.

column3: Conservatives See a Turning Tide on Immigration
column4: “There are some people who lost their will to fight this fight,” said Ms. Kaufman, who remains combative but admitted in an interview during a commercial break that she was worried the legislation might pass.

column3: Conservatives See a Turning Tide on Immigration
column4: “They think they’ve lost it already and they’ve sort of thrown in the towel, including my fellow radio hosts.” Or as Mr. Schaffer from New Orleans put it, “There is not that rage that was there.” From the beginning of this year’s immigration talks, senators from both parties braced for the reaction on conservative talk radio once the legislation was made public.

column3: Conservatives See a Turning Tide on Immigration
column4: Their memories were still fresh from six years ago, when activists at town hall meetings who had listened to talk radio harshly criticized Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, for his support of the 2007 proposed legislation.

column3: Conservatives See a Turning Tide on Immigration
column4: This time proponents are hoping that Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida and a member of the group of eight, will be able to mute the impact of the conservative chatter.

column3: Conservatives See a Turning Tide on Immigration
column4: Mr. Rubio, a Tea Party favorite, has spent much of his time in recent months talking about the proposals on conservative radio programs.

column3: Conservatives See a Turning Tide on Immigration
column4: That appears to have worked, at least a little.

column3: Conservatives See a Turning Tide on Immigration
column4: Michael Medved, one of the few conservative talk show hosts who has always supported an immigration overhaul, said he sensed a shift.

column3: Conservatives See a Turning Tide on Immigration
column4: “What you are not hearing as much, except from a handful of people, is ‘over my dead body,’ ” Mr. Medved said in an interview.

column3: Conservatives See a Turning Tide on Immigration
column4: “The level of apocalyptic hysteria is much less.” There are nonetheless plenty of talk show hosts who disagree with Mr. Hannity and Mr. Medved, as was clear at the Phoenix Park Hotel, where the hosts and activists sported “Border Security Now!” buttons.

column3: Conservatives See a Turning Tide on Immigration
column4: Many hosts and callers derided the “gang of eight” senators who drafted the legislation as the “eight gangsters.” But a few blocks away on the East Front of the Capitol, more than 300 evangelical Christian pastors gathered for what they billed as a national day of prayer to support the immigration legislation.

column3: Conservatives See a Turning Tide on Immigration
column4: Unlike 2007, this year evangelicals have mobilized some Christian radio hosts on behalf of immigration and are running saturation ad campaigns summoning evangelicals to obey biblical instructions that call for welcoming the stranger.

column3: Conservatives See a Turning Tide on Immigration
column4: In South Carolina, evangelical leaders ran radio commercials defending Senator Lindsey Graham, a Republican who is an author of the bipartisan bill, and Representative Trey Gowdy, also a Republican.

column3: Conservatives See a Turning Tide on Immigration
column4: The lawmakers were “inundated — very happily inundated” with calls from evangelicals, said Richard Land, president of the Southern Baptist Convention’s policy arm.

column3: Conservatives See a Turning Tide on Immigration
column4: “We’ve provided an example that when people like Lindsey Graham and Trey Gowdy get targeted, we’ve got their back,” Dr. Land said, “and we can activate a counternetwork.”

column3: Is Rejecting a Path to Citizenship for Illegal Immigrants Un-Christian?
column4: Immigration continues to be a contentious sociopolitical issue, with politicians, faith leaders and American citizens all weighing in on proposals to cope with the millions of illegals who are currently residing within the nation’s borders.

column3: Is Rejecting a Path to Citizenship for Illegal Immigrants Un-Christian?
column4: Due to its complexities, finding common ground can be difficult, however religious leaders like the Rev.

column3: Is Rejecting a Path to Citizenship for Illegal Immigrants Un-Christian?
column4: Samuel Rodriguez, president of the National Hispanic Christian Leadership Conference (NHCLC), believe that it is possible to reach viable — and faith-based — solutions to the domestic conundrum.

column3: Is Rejecting a Path to Citizenship for Illegal Immigrants Un-Christian?
column4: TheBlaze recently interviewed Rodriguez, a prominent evangelical leader, to learn more about how he is tackling this controversial issue.

column3: Is Rejecting a Path to Citizenship for Illegal Immigrants Un-Christian?
column4: Considering the role that preachers have in American communities and the work Rodriguez has been engaged in, his perspective on this front is important.

column3: Is Rejecting a Path to Citizenship for Illegal Immigrants Un-Christian?
column4: Among other observations, Rodriguez told TheBlaze that Christians’ views on immigration have changed dramatically over the past seven years, noting that progressive and conservative evangelicals, alike, are coming together like never before (we reported on a massive campaign bridging political divides earlier this year called “The Evangelical Immigration Table”).

column3: Is Rejecting a Path to Citizenship for Illegal Immigrants Un-Christian?
column4: “It’s important to that conservative evangelicals today, as in comparison to seven years ago, serve as probably one of the most significant supportive groups in favor of comprehensive immigration reform,” he said, noting that just a few years ago these same individuals and collectives were opposed.

column3: Is Rejecting a Path to Citizenship for Illegal Immigrants Un-Christian?
column4: “Today, because of groups like the Southern Baptists [and] Liberty Counsel…we are pushing immigration reform and we have a piece of legislation coming forth from Marco Rubio.” Rodriguez noted that he believes the previous stance against reform was rooted in “spiritual, cultural and political myopia.” Rather than a horizontal issue, the faith leader said that conservative evangelicals are now seeing the issue vertically and have woken up to the realities the nation is facing on the immigration front.

column3: Is Rejecting a Path to Citizenship for Illegal Immigrants Un-Christian?
column4: Also, outside of the political realm, Rodriguez noted that the most significant growth in Christianity is actually coming from these immigrants, making this as much a religious issue as it is one of policy.

column3: Is Rejecting a Path to Citizenship for Illegal Immigrants Un-Christian?
column4: “Before it was a political issue.

column3: Is Rejecting a Path to Citizenship for Illegal Immigrants Un-Christian?
column4: Now it’s a God and Christian issue,” he continued.

column3: Is Rejecting a Path to Citizenship for Illegal Immigrants Un-Christian?
column4: As for critics who might dismiss plans to provide a path to citizenship and other such proposals, TheBlaze asked how Rodriguez would react to those who believe that illegals broke the law and that, as a result, they shouldn’t be given amnesty.

column3: Is Rejecting a Path to Citizenship for Illegal Immigrants Un-Christian?
column4: “I agree they broke the law and they shouldn’t be given amnesty,” he responded.

column3: Is Rejecting a Path to Citizenship for Illegal Immigrants Un-Christian?
column4: “We have to ask ourselves what is the Biblical solution for those who are here.” Rather than deporting them — something Rodriguez said simply isn’t a viable option — he advocated a more compassionate and understanding approach.

column3: Is Rejecting a Path to Citizenship for Illegal Immigrants Un-Christian?
column4: He also claimed that many of the 11 million people (estimated) who are here actually came to the country legally at some point, but some “overstayed their VISAs” (a Wall Street Journal report corroborated that 40 percent of illegals did enter the nation legitimately at some point).

column3: Is Rejecting a Path to Citizenship for Illegal Immigrants Un-Christian?
column4: He said that there’s a fact-versus-fiction paradigm that shows that many of these individuals have actually contributed to their communities.

column3: Is Rejecting a Path to Citizenship for Illegal Immigrants Un-Christian?
column4: Rodriguez also highlighted his belief that it’s unfair to throw these individuals out when they have been living here for years.

column3: Is Rejecting a Path to Citizenship for Illegal Immigrants Un-Christian?
column4: “Ronald Reagan would agree with me on this.

column3: Is Rejecting a Path to Citizenship for Illegal Immigrants Un-Christian?
column4: He was the one who said that these immigrants really embody the future of America,” he added.

column3: Is Rejecting a Path to Citizenship for Illegal Immigrants Un-Christian?
column4: “True conservatism [means that] if we are to conserve the spirit of entrepreneurship, we want to welcome these immigrants.” It’s not as though the faith leader wants to open the floodgates.

column3: Is Rejecting a Path to Citizenship for Illegal Immigrants Un-Christian?
column4: Rodriguez is, in fact, calling for overarching reform.

column3: Is Rejecting a Path to Citizenship for Illegal Immigrants Un-Christian?
column4: And he’s fully on-board with making illegals go to the back of the line, pay fines, and learn the English language.

column3: Is Rejecting a Path to Citizenship for Illegal Immigrants Un-Christian?
column4: He noted that the process for becoming a citizen should include these benchmarks and that it could — and should — take someone 10 to 13 years to achieve this goal.

column3: Is Rejecting a Path to Citizenship for Illegal Immigrants Un-Christian?

column3: Key Amendments Fail In Gun Bill Votes
column4: WASHINGTON -- With shouts of "Shame on you!"

column3: Key Amendments Fail In Gun Bill Votes
column4: echoing in the chamber, the U.S. Senate failed to muster sufficient support Wednesday for a gun-buyer background check bill that's supported by nearly 90 percent of Americans.

column3: Key Amendments Fail In Gun Bill Votes
column4: It also voted down other key measures and counterproposals, defeating a string of amendments in a series of procedural votes that likely doomed any major legislation to curb gun violence.

column3: Key Amendments Fail In Gun Bill Votes
column4: The background check measure -- painstakingly crafted by the bipartisan duo of Sens.

column3: Key Amendments Fail In Gun Bill Votes
column4: Joe Manchin (D-W.Va.) and Pat Toomey (R-Pa.) -- was seen as the key to passing the first legislation in decades to address the sorts of mass slaughters that so recently horrified the country in Newtown, Conn., where 20 children and six educators were gunned down at an elementary school, and in Aurora, Colo., where 12 people were killed in a theater.

column3: Key Amendments Fail In Gun Bill Votes
column4: The amendment failed 54 to 46, falling short of the 60-vote threshold needed to break a filibuster.

column3: Key Amendments Fail In Gun Bill Votes
column4: That failure upset anew victims of the Sandy Hook shootings and other slaughters who watched from the Senate gallery.

column3: Key Amendments Fail In Gun Bill Votes
column4: "Shame on you!"

column3: Key Amendments Fail In Gun Bill Votes
column4: shouted two women in the gallery after the vote.

column3: Key Amendments Fail In Gun Bill Votes
column4: One was Patricia Maisch, who grabbed the third clip from the gunman who opened fired at then-Rep. Gabby Giffords in the Tuscon., Ariz., shooting in 2011.

column3: Key Amendments Fail In Gun Bill Votes
column4: The other was Lori Hass, whose daughter was injured in the Virginia Tech shootings six years and one day ago.

column3: Key Amendments Fail In Gun Bill Votes
column4: "I think we're going to continue to work for the right thing to be done.

column3: Key Amendments Fail In Gun Bill Votes
column4: I think the senators who voted against this will have to live with that vote, and I think they're going to have to account for themselves," said Peter Read, whose daughter, Mary, was among the 33 killed at Virginia Tech.

column3: Key Amendments Fail In Gun Bill Votes
column4: An angry and disappointed-looking President Barack Obama also hammered the vote in a Rose Garden speech on Wednesday.

column3: Key Amendments Fail In Gun Bill Votes
column4: "All in all, this is a pretty shameful day for Washington," Obama said.

column3: Key Amendments Fail In Gun Bill Votes
column4: "The American people are trying to figure out -- how can something that has 90 percent support not happen?"

column3: Key Amendments Fail In Gun Bill Votes
column4: Obama said.

column3: Key Amendments Fail In Gun Bill Votes
column4: He was echoed by other victims of mass shootings who watched the Senate vote.

column3: Key Amendments Fail In Gun Bill Votes
column4: "I was extremely disappointed," said retired Col. Bill Badger, one of the people who tackled Jared Lee Loughner in Tucson.

column3: Key Amendments Fail In Gun Bill Votes
column4: "When 90 percent of the people want something, and the senator votes against them, the next election, we're going to take care of those senators, because they're not representing the people."

column3: Key Amendments Fail In Gun Bill Votes
column4: Passage of the background check amendment had been seen as key because it represented a bipartisan agreement in a highly polarized debate.

column3: Key Amendments Fail In Gun Bill Votes
column4: It also would have preserved a major part of the overall bill that many advocates against gun violence saw as a minimum step toward stemming gun massacres.

column3: Key Amendments Fail In Gun Bill Votes
column4: Stronger measures up for a vote also failed, including a ban of assault weapons sponsored by Sen. Dianne Feinstein (D-Calif.) that went down 40 to 60, in spite of an impassioned plea from the senator.

column3: Key Amendments Fail In Gun Bill Votes
column4: "I know how this is going to end, and the despair and the dismay of the families standing out there whose safety we need to protect, and we don't do it.

column3: Key Amendments Fail In Gun Bill Votes
column4: I am really chagrined," said Feinstein, who argued that lawmakers with six-year terms should have the fortitude to take tough votes.

column3: Key Amendments Fail In Gun Bill Votes
column4: "Show some guts," Feinstein said.

column3: Key Amendments Fail In Gun Bill Votes
column4: The only significant steps that all sides agreed on were stemming illegal trafficking of weapons and improving mental health efforts, but even an amendment written with NRA input to crack down on trafficking failed 58 to 42.

column3: Key Amendments Fail In Gun Bill Votes
column4: A vote on improving mental health services was delayed until Thursday.

column3: Key Amendments Fail In Gun Bill Votes
column4: The background check measure would have expanded the current check system to cover sales of weapons on the Internet and at gun shows.

column3: Key Amendments Fail In Gun Bill Votes
column4: Democratic aides privately conceded that with the failure of background checks, the rest of the bill would likely go down.

column3: Key Amendments Fail In Gun Bill Votes
column4: One described it as a "pyrrhic victory," noting that a majority of the Senate backed the bill that is so popular outside the halls of Congress.

column3: Key Amendments Fail In Gun Bill Votes
column4: "It's the farthest we've come," said the aide, speaking on background to talk freely.

column3: Key Amendments Fail In Gun Bill Votes
column4: The aides saw little hope of it being resurrected, although leaders kept that option open.

column3: Key Amendments Fail In Gun Bill Votes
column4: Opponents, citing a National Institute of Justice study, argued that the expanded check system would have laid the groundwork for a national registry of gun owners, although the measure expressly forbid such a step, with a 15-year jail sentence for anyone who tried to do that.

column3: Key Amendments Fail In Gun Bill Votes
column4: They also called it a useless step that would achieve little.

column3: Key Amendments Fail In Gun Bill Votes
column4: "Expanded background checks would not have prevented Newtown," said Sen. Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa), who offered an alternative measure with Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas) lacking new background checks.

column3: Key Amendments Fail In Gun Bill Votes
column4: That measure also failed, 52 to 48.

column3: Key Amendments Fail In Gun Bill Votes
column4: But Toomey said his amendment would have at least been a modest step in the right direction.

column3: Key Amendments Fail In Gun Bill Votes
column4: "The goal was to see if we can find a way to make it a little bit more difficult for people who have no legal right to have a gun for them to obtain it," Toomey said.

column3: Key Amendments Fail In Gun Bill Votes
column4: "That was the goal."

column3: Key Amendments Fail In Gun Bill Votes
column4: The Senate failed to meet it.

column3: Conflicting reports over possible suspect in Boston Marathon bombing
column4: A federal law enforcement source told Fox News that investigators are looking for two men that are persons of interest in Monday's Boston Marathon terror attack and have distributed photos for “law enforcement eyes only.” The FBI is not sharing the photos with the public.

column3: Conflicting reports over possible suspect in Boston Marathon bombing
column4: A Fox News reporter has seen the photos and called them “clear.” According to the reporter, one of the men has a backpack that appears to match the bag believed to have been used in the attack.

column3: Conflicting reports over possible suspect in Boston Marathon bombing
column4: The other man also appears to have a bag of some kind.

column3: Conflicting reports over possible suspect in Boston Marathon bombing
column4: The source asked that the images not be made public for fear of jeopardizing the investigation.

column3: Conflicting reports over possible suspect in Boston Marathon bombing
column4: News of the images came as investigators spent Wednesday poring over photos and video footage and piecing together shredded remnants of bombs in an effort to zero in on suspects behind the attack.

column3: Conflicting reports over possible suspect in Boston Marathon bombing
column4: Even as amateur sleuths analyzed photos of the finish-line crowd and shared their own conclusions, FBI investigators were believed to be doing the same, and there were reports that they were interested in specific images of a person or persons with heavy backpacks.

column3: Conflicting reports over possible suspect in Boston Marathon bombing
column4: Investigators believe the bombs, at least one of which was likely a pressure cooker bomb laden with explosives and shrapnel, may have been concealed in such a bag.

column3: Conflicting reports over possible suspect in Boston Marathon bombing
column4: Monday's attack killed three and injured 176, many critically.

column3: Conflicting reports over possible suspect in Boston Marathon bombing
column4: A mangled pressure cooker lid found atop a nearby building is believed to have been part of one bomb, and it and other pieces were being analyzed at an FBI lab.

column3: Conflicting reports over possible suspect in Boston Marathon bombing
column4: A battery and several pieces of shrapnel were also recovered and undergoing analysis.

column3: Conflicting reports over possible suspect in Boston Marathon bombing
column4: Fox News learned that the circuit board suspected of being used to detonate at least one of the bombs has been recovered, and that FBI investigators were also analyzing cellphone tower records to identify positive hits for signs of calls that may have been placed to trigger both explosions remotely.

column3: Conflicting reports over possible suspect in Boston Marathon bombing

column3: Media Walks Back Arrest Reports
column4: CNN and other outlets found themselves with egg on their face when they reported that an arrest had been made in the Boston bombings and were then forced to walk that news back.

column3: Media Walks Back Arrest Reports
column4: Though it was not alone, CNN took the brunt of the blame for its faulty reporting.

column3: Media Walks Back Arrest Reports
column4: It was the first and most prominent outlet to tout its scoop.

column3: Media Walks Back Arrest Reports
column4: The network's John King, citing multiple sources, said that an arrest had been made.

column3: Media Walks Back Arrest Reports
column4: Fran Townsend, a contributor to the network, also said it had been made.

column3: Media Walks Back Arrest Reports
column4: The Boston Globe agreed.

column3: Media Walks Back Arrest Reports
column4: Fox News also reported an arrest.

column3: Media Walks Back Arrest Reports
column4: The Associated Press did so as well.

column3: Media Walks Back Arrest Reports
column4: Leading the way in its dispute of that story was NBC News.

column3: Media Walks Back Arrest Reports
column4: Citing multiple federal sources, the network's Pete Williams said, "No arrest has been made."

column3: Media Walks Back Arrest Reports
column4: "The FBI is looking for someone.

column3: Media Walks Back Arrest Reports
column4: They have a face.

column3: Media Walks Back Arrest Reports
column4: They don't know where he is," Williams said.

column3: Media Walks Back Arrest Reports
column4: CBS News also tweeted that no arrest had been made.

column3: Media Walks Back Arrest Reports
column4: Some minutes later, CNN suddenly appeared to be walking back its story: CNN starts walking it back: 'this may look very different in about an hour if we learn that there's been no arrest.'

column3: Media Walks Back Arrest Reports
column4: — HuffPost Media (@HuffPostMedia) April 17, 2013 CNN's John King: 'an arrest has been made.'

column3: Media Walks Back Arrest Reports
column4: CNN's Chris Cuomo: 'they could bring him in without an arrest.'

column3: Media Walks Back Arrest Reports
column4: — HuffPost Media (@HuffPostMedia) April 17, 2013 Eventually, Tom Fuentes, a former FBI agent, came on CNN.

column3: Media Walks Back Arrest Reports
column4: He reported that not only had no arrest been made, but that there was not even anyone in custody.

column3: Media Walks Back Arrest Reports
column4: "Initial reports, so often are wrong," Anderson Cooper said mournfully.

column3: Media Walks Back Arrest Reports
column4: The AP, Globe and Fox News eventually joined CNN in walking back their story.

column3: Media Walks Back Arrest Reports
column4: The Boston Police department then sealed the deal by tweeting that no arrest had been made.

column3: Media Walks Back Arrest Reports
column4: For CNN and Fox News, the botched reporting will be a painful reminder of their last high-profile failure, when they incorrectly said that the Supreme Court had overturned the Affordable Care Act.

column3: Media Walks Back Arrest Reports
column4: UPDATE: A CNN spokesperson defended the network's handling of the story in a statement sent to HuffPost's Michael Calderone: "CNN had three credible sources on both local and federal levels.

column3: Media Walks Back Arrest Reports
column4: Based on this information we reported our findings.

column3: Media Walks Back Arrest Reports
column4: As soon as our sources came to us with new information we adjusted our reporting."

column3: Senate to vote on gun bill amendments with background check plan in doubt
column4: As the Senate began voting Wednesday on nine proposed changes to a gun control bill, the centerpiece proposal on background checks quickly failed to win enough support, despite broad public backing.

column3: Downtown Boston Remains a Crime Scene
column4: BOSTON â The explosives that killed three people and injured more than 170 during the Boston Marathon on Monday were most likely rudimentary devices made from ordinary kitchen pressure cookers, except they were rigged to shoot sharp bits of shrapnel into anyone within reach of their blast and maim them severely, law enforcement officials said Tuesday.

column3: Downtown Boston Remains a Crime Scene
