column3: House Republicans Devise Plan To Weaken Gun Control Proposals
column4: WASHINGTON, April 15 (Reuters) - As the U.S. Senate prepares to debate a gun-control bill for the first time in two decades on Monday, Republicans in the House of Representatives are devising ways to delay and weaken gun legislation they see as limiting Americans' right to bear arms, congressional sources say.

column3: House Republicans Devise Plan To Weaken Gun Control Proposals
column4: Some Republican lawmakers and strategists are urging House Speaker John Boehner to kill any gun-control bill passed by the Senate by refusing to take action on it.

column3: House Republicans Devise Plan To Weaken Gun Control Proposals
column4: But the Republican speaker is planning what could be a months-long review of the bill that likely would involve chipping away at gun-related measures in the plan while pushing for proposals to identify and treat the mentally ill as the best hope for a compromise plan to reduce gun violence.

column3: House Republicans Devise Plan To Weaken Gun Control Proposals
column4: House Republicans' focus on mentally ill criminals has become sharper in recent days, as a bipartisan plan to expand background checks on prospective gun buyers gained momentum in the Democrat-led Senate - thanks in part to emotional calls for action in Washington by family members of victims of the Newtown, Connecticut, school shooting.

column3: House Republicans Devise Plan To Weaken Gun Control Proposals
column4: The Senate is expected to vote on Tuesday on that plan, which would expand background checks to include those who try to buy guns online and at gun shows.

column3: House Republicans Devise Plan To Weaken Gun Control Proposals
column4: Other Senate amendments would ban high-capacity ammunition magazines and military-style "assault" weapons - measures generally seen as having little chance of going anywhere.

column3: House Republicans Devise Plan To Weaken Gun Control Proposals
column4: The background checks proposal - probably Democratic President Barack Obama's best chance at getting a significant gun-control bill through Congress - is expected to wind up in the final Senate bill, along with plans to boost funding for school security and tighten restrictions on gun trafficking.

column3: House Republicans Devise Plan To Weaken Gun Control Proposals
column4: Boehner has pledged that the House will act on any gun bill that emerges from the Senate.

column3: House Republicans Devise Plan To Weaken Gun Control Proposals
column4: He has indicated that the House's review would allow a lengthy debate without many of the deadlines and restrictions that usually guide the chamber's work.

column3: House Republicans Devise Plan To Weaken Gun Control Proposals
column4: Many House Republicans saw that as a signal that conservatives who are staunch defenders of gun rights will have several weeks, or months, to come up with amendments that could make the gun bill unpalatable even to Senate Democrats who now support it.

column3: House Republicans Devise Plan To Weaken Gun Control Proposals
column4: For House Republicans, gun-control legislation is a political tightrope.

column3: House Republicans Devise Plan To Weaken Gun Control Proposals
column4: Like most Republicans in the Senate and a few Democrats from conservative, gun-friendly states, many House Republicans oppose the Senate plan to expand background checks and are under intense pressure from constituents and the gun lobby to resist such measures.

column3: House Republicans Devise Plan To Weaken Gun Control Proposals
column4: That level of opposition in one chamber of Congress typically would be enough to quash a bill without action.

column3: House Republicans Devise Plan To Weaken Gun Control Proposals
column4: But some House Republicans say they are wary of refusing to act on any gun bill passed by the Senate.

column3: House Republicans Devise Plan To Weaken Gun Control Proposals
column4: At a time when public opinion polls suggest that at least 80 percent of Americans favor expanded background checks - and as family members of the Newtown victims help Obama keep up the pressure on lawmakers - these Republicans worry about their party looking like an obstructionist if it does not allow at least an airing of the Senate bill.

column3: On Tax Day, Obama shows taxpayers where their money went
column4: President Obama marked Tax Day on Monday by directing taxpayers to an online tool that shows them how their tax dollars are being divided among broad categories of federal spending such as education and defense.

column3: On Tax Day, Obama shows taxpayers where their money went
column4: By using the link at www.Whitehouse.gov/2012-taxreceipt, taxpayers can enter the amount of taxes they paid in the past year, and the tool will calculate how much of those taxes went to various federal agencies and services.

column3: On Tax Day, Obama shows taxpayers where their money went
column4: For example, if a taxpayer paid $112,000 in income taxes in 2012, as did Mr. Obama and first lady Michelle Obama, they’d discover that $27,596 of their tax dollars went to the Defense Department and $5,073 funded veterans’ benefits.

column3: On Tax Day, Obama shows taxpayers where their money went
column4: The Obamas paid $8,971 for interest on the national debt, and $2,296 for immigration services, law enforcement and the administration of justice.

column3: On Tax Day, Obama shows taxpayers where their money went
column4: However, the online tool doesn’t get too specific.

column3: On Tax Day, Obama shows taxpayers where their money went
column4: For example, it doesn’t tell you how much of your taxes paid for loan guarantees for failed solar-energy companies, or for fraudulent Medicare payments, or for security for the now-canceled White House public tours that the president said his administration can no longer afford.

column3: On Tax Day, Obama shows taxpayers where their money went
column4: Mr. Obama unveiled the online taxpayer tool in 2011, fulfilling a promise he made in the State of the Union address that year.

column3: On Tax Day, Obama shows taxpayers where their money went
column4: “As long as he’s in office, every hardworking taxpayer will be able to jump online to see exactly how their tax dollars are being spent,” said Colleen Curtis, the White House director of digital content.

column3: On Tax Day, some will see how Obamacare will affect them
column4: Last Updated Apr 14, 2013 7:26 PM EDT For most lower- and middle-income taxpayers in need of health insurance, the most significant tax-related aspect of Obamacare starts this year: calculating subsidies.

column3: On Tax Day, some will see how Obamacare will affect them
column4: After filing his or her 2012 tax return, an uninsured taxpayer should find out whether they qualify for a government subsidy, and if so, how large it will be.

column3: On Tax Day, some will see how Obamacare will affect them
column4: That Tax Day development will help them make a key choice this fall: whether to take that subsidy and buy insurance coverage for 2014, or pay a fine to the IRS in 2015.

column3: On Tax Day, some will see how Obamacare will affect them
column4: In 2014 alone, the government is expected to spend $25 billion on subsidies to help people purchase coverage on the state-based health exchanges -- the online marketplaces where consumers can choose from various private insurance plans.

column3: On Tax Day, some will see how Obamacare will affect them
column4: The exchanges are expected to be ready for open enrollment by October of this year.

column3: On Tax Day, some will see how Obamacare will affect them
column4: Getting customers to join the exchange -- and thus expanding health care coverage, the Affordable Care Act's key objective -- requires the coordination of the Internal Revenue Service, Health and Human Services and other government agencies.

column3: On Tax Day, some will see how Obamacare will affect them
column4: The government is expected to collect more than $1 trillion in tax revenue over 10 years and dole out more than $1 trillion in subsidies.

column3: On Tax Day, some will see how Obamacare will affect them
column4: "This is a major new venture and like anything, no one can predict exactly how it's going to work," Paul Van de Water, a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, explained to CBSNews.com.

column3: On Tax Day, some will see how Obamacare will affect them
column4: "The HHS and the IRS and other agencies involved in this are working hard to implement it, but until the thing actually starts, no one's really going to know what features need to be modified to make them work better."

column3: On Tax Day, some will see how Obamacare will affect them
column4: Most of the tax-related elements of the Affordable Care Act don't impact taxpayers directly -- they instead impact business sectors like the medical device industry or health insurers.

column3: On Tax Day, some will see how Obamacare will affect them
column4: Still, some Americans will start noticing through their 2012 tax return how Obamacare impacts their lives.

column3: On Tax Day, some will see how Obamacare will affect them
column4: And starting this year, others will be paying extra taxes because of the law.

column3: On Tax Day, some will see how Obamacare will affect them
column4: Subsidies for the exchange will be available to individuals with household incomes between 100 and 400 percent of the Federal poverty level -- taking into account factors like family size.

column3: On Tax Day, some will see how Obamacare will affect them
column4: By 2022, according to the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office, an estimated 26 million people will get their insurance through state exchanges.

column3: On Tax Day, some will see how Obamacare will affect them
column4: Up to this point, however, most people don't understand how the health care law will impact them directly or what their taxes have to do with it.

column3: On Tax Day, some will see how Obamacare will affect them
column4: After finding in a survey that 77 percent of respondents were unaware their 2012 tax return could be used to determine their first year of subsidies, H&R Block started conducting customer outreach on the subject.

column3: On Tax Day, some will see how Obamacare will affect them
column4: When the company's tax preparers sit down with customers, "a lot of them are relieved and excited to the see the Affordable Care Act broken down into how it personally affects them," Meg Sutton, a senior advisor for tax and healthcare services at H&R Block, told CBSNews.com.

column3: On Tax Day, some will see how Obamacare will affect them
column4: Open enrollment for the exchanges is supposed to start in October of this year, with coverage starting in 2014.

column3: On Tax Day, some will see how Obamacare will affect them
column4: If a taxpayer qualifies for a subsidy, he'll enroll in a private health plan through the exchange, the government will pay the subsidy directly to the insurer and the taxpayer has to cover the remaining cost.

column3: On Tax Day, some will see how Obamacare will affect them
column4: If a taxpayer takes a subsidy, he's required by law to report that to the IRS the next year.

column3: On Tax Day, some will see how Obamacare will affect them
column4: The IRS will review it and decide, based on that person's income, whether he received too much or too little in subsidies.

column3: On Tax Day, some will see how Obamacare will affect them
column4: "If you got too much of a subsidy, consumers will see money coming out of their refund," Sutton explained.

Marco Rubio dismissed arguments Sunday that the Senate immigration bill offers amnesty for illegal immigrants and said border security is not the only key issue -- amid scrutiny from some fellow conservatives and the union that represents immigration enforcement agents.

column3: Rubio says immigration plan not amnesty, amid increasing conservative criticism

column4: But they have produced legislation ... that will give amnesty now, legalize everyone that's here effectively today.

column4: And then there's a promise of enforcement in the future."

column3: Rubio says immigration plan not amnesty, amid increasing conservative criticism
column4: Rubio also said Sunday that tracking illegal immigrants in and out of the U.S. and improving the employee-verification system, known as E-Verify, are equally important.

column4: “All three work together,” he told Fox.

column4: “All three have to happen.” Though Rubio made clear that securing the border is only part of the plan, he said a 90 percent border-apprehension rate within the next five years is a “trigger” for permanent residence.

column3: Rubio says immigration plan not amnesty, amid increasing conservative criticism
column4: “The Department of Homeland Security will have five years to meet that goal,” said Rubio, who appeared on all five major Sunday talk shows to garner support for the legislation.

column3: Obama's Budget Revives Benefits as Divisive Issue
column4: WASHINGTON — Whether or not Republicans ever agree to a budget deal with President Obama, one thing seems certain: now that he has officially put Social Security and Medicare benefits on the negotiating table, opponents on his party’s left will make that an issue for Democrats in the midterm elections next year — and perhaps in the 2016 presidential contest.

column3: Obama's Budget Revives Benefits as Divisive Issue
column4: In the midterm races already taking shape, Democrats who back Mr. Obama’s budget proposals to trim future benefits as part of a long-term deficit-reduction compromise could be attacked from the left and the right.

column3: Obama's Budget Revives Benefits as Divisive Issue
column4: Liberal groups and some union activists are threatening to recruit candidates to challenge these Democrats in their primaries.

column3: Obama's Budget Revives Benefits as Divisive Issue
column4: At the same time, the head of the House Republicans’ campaign committee gleefully signaled last week that he would use Mr. Obama’s “shocking attack on seniors” against Democrats in general-election races — though Republican Congressional leaders demanded the concessions from Mr. Obama.

column3: Obama's Budget Revives Benefits as Divisive Issue
column4: And while party leaders rebuked the campaign committee chief, Representative Greg Walden of Oregon, individual Republican candidates and “super PACs” would be free to wage their own attacks.

column3: Obama's Budget Revives Benefits as Divisive Issue
column4: For now, at least, the political warnings to Democrats are coming mostly from the left of their own party.

column3: Obama's Budget Revives Benefits as Divisive Issue
column4: “You cannot be a good Democrat and cut Social Security,” said Arshad Hasan, the executive director of Democracy for America, a liberal grass-roots group, which staged a small protest outside the White House last week even before Mr. Obama released his annual budget on Wednesday.

column3: Obama's Budget Revives Benefits as Divisive Issue
column4: “People would be looking to punish them,” said Robert Borosage, a co-founder of the Campaign for America’s Future, another liberal group, “and they would be looking for primary challengers.” Even if Democratic incumbents do not draw a primary challenger, liberal activists say, they might face a shortage of volunteers motivated enough to do the hard work of campaigning — just as Democrats did in the 2010 midterms, which resulted in big Republican gains.

column3: Obama's Budget Revives Benefits as Divisive Issue
column4: Looking further ahead, to 2016, some on the left have already begun talking about encouraging a liberal Democrat — the freshman Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts is the name most bandied — to take up the “don’t touch Social Security or Medicare” banner as part of a liberal bid for the party’s nomination to succeed Mr. Obama, even against Hillary Rodham Clinton or Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

column3: Obama's Budget Revives Benefits as Divisive Issue
column4: Such talk was stoked when Ms. Warren, within hours of the release of the president’s budget on Wednesday, sent supporters an e-mail sounding an alarm: “Our Social Security system is critical to protecting middle-class families, and we cannot allow it to be dismantled inch by inch.” She was not available for an interview, aides said on Friday.

column3: Obama's Budget Revives Benefits as Divisive Issue
column4: “If the major candidates running for the Democratic nomination hedge on important issues like Social Security, they will leave open a tremendous amount of space for an insurgent,” said Adam Green, a co-founder of the Progressive Change Campaign Committee, a group often critical of Mr. Obama.

column3: Obama's Budget Revives Benefits as Divisive Issue
column4: But, Mr. Green acknowledged, “I wouldn’t say anybody’s laying the groundwork yet.” At a minimum, Mr. Borosage said, all Democratic candidates in 2014 or 2016 “will be forced to take a stand.” That prospect could complicate the campaign strategies of establishment favorites.

column3: Obama's Budget Revives Benefits as Divisive Issue
column4: Mr. Biden is inevitably tied to Mr. Obama’s policies.

column3: Obama's Budget Revives Benefits as Divisive Issue
column4: And Mrs. Clinton, as a senator, was a fiscal moderate who extolled her husband’s budget-balancing record of compromise.

column3: Obama's Budget Revives Benefits as Divisive Issue
column4: President Bill Clinton negotiated Medicare savings with Congressional Republicans, and their 1997 deal nearly included the same proposal trimming Social Security cost-of-living increases that Mr. Obama has put in his budget to entice Republicans to compromise in turn.

column3: Obama's Budget Revives Benefits as Divisive Issue
column4: Ideological litmus tests have lately been more divisive for Republicans than for Democrats, over taxes and social issues like abortion, same-sex marriage and immigration.

column3: Obama's Budget Revives Benefits as Divisive Issue
column4: But the agitation on the left to defend Social Security and Medicare, the two programs that Democrats consider perhaps their party’s greatest legacy, did not begin last week with Mr. Obama’s new budget.

column3: Obama's Budget Revives Benefits as Divisive Issue
column4: It had been building since mid-2011, when the president, in private negotiations with Speaker John A. Boehner, tentatively agreed to the new formula for calculating cost-of-living adjustments in Social Security; economists recommend the formula as more accurate, but it would mean smaller increases for Social Security beneficiaries.

column3: Obama's Budget Revives Benefits as Divisive Issue
column4: Even so, Democrats in Congress and the White House agree that the party would have supported Mr. Obama back then if a compromise deal had come to a vote.

column3: Obama's Budget Revives Benefits as Divisive Issue
column4: But the 2011 talks, just like a second round of negotiations in December, collapsed after Mr. Boehner declined to agree to Mr. Obama’s counterdemands: new taxes on the wealthy and on some corporations, and job-creating investments in infrastructure projects, research and education.

column3: Obama's Budget Revives Benefits as Divisive Issue
column4: As his second term began, Mr. Obama used his annual budget proposal to make his most public overture toward compromise yet.

column3: Obama's Budget Revives Benefits as Divisive Issue
column4: The budget, incorporating the final December offer to Mr. Boehner, also proposed other cuts in spending for domestic programs and the military and $400 billion in savings over 10 years from Medicare.

column3: Obama's Budget Revives Benefits as Divisive Issue
column4: Those savings would come mostly from reducing payments to hospitals and pharmaceutical manufacturers, but also from trimming benefits and raising out-of-pocket costs for higher-income beneficiaries.

column3: Obama's Budget Revives Benefits as Divisive Issue
column4: Liberals found much to praise, like Mr. Obama’s proposed new spending for road construction, nationwide prekindergarten education and advanced manufacturing research; a higher federal minimum wage; and reduced tax breaks for the wealthy.

column3: Obama's Budget Revives Benefits as Divisive Issue
column4: But they were shocked that he proposed the new cost-of-living formula.

column3: Obama's Budget Revives Benefits as Divisive Issue
column4: With that as the kindling, their opposition movement intensified.

column3: Obama's Budget Revives Benefits as Divisive Issue
column4: More than two years away from Democrats’ presidential-nominating contest, however, it is hard to see who could or would become the left’s standard-bearer.

column3: Obama's Budget Revives Benefits as Divisive Issue
column4: Besides Ms. Warren, other party leaders mentioned include Gov.

column3: Obama's Budget Revives Benefits as Divisive Issue
column4: Andrew M. Cuomo of New York, Gov.

column3: Obama's Budget Revives Benefits as Divisive Issue
column4: Martin O’Malley of Maryland, Senator Kirsten Gillibrand of New York and Senator Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota.

column3: Obama's Budget Revives Benefits as Divisive Issue
column4: Certainly an unexpected candidate could emerge, as Mr. Obama did in the 2008 race.

column3: Obama's Budget Revives Benefits as Divisive Issue
column4: Three years ahead of that year’s nominating convention, few Democrats saw him as a likely candidate, much less one who could vanquish Mrs. Clinton.

column3: Obama's Budget Revives Benefits as Divisive Issue
column4: Now Mrs. Clinton is again seen as the nearly invincible front-runner, should she choose to run.

column3: Obama's Budget Revives Benefits as Divisive Issue
column4: Many potential aspirants, including Ms. Warren, are widely considered unlikely to challenge her as Mr. Obama did in 2008.

column3: Obama's Budget Revives Benefits as Divisive Issue
column4: Back then, the issue that he seized was opposition to the Iraq war.

column3: Obama's Budget Revives Benefits as Divisive Issue
column4: In 2004, Democrats’ disgust with that war had powered Howard Dean’s liberal challenge to Senator John Kerry, who ultimately defeated Mr. Dean for the nomination.

column3: Obama's Budget Revives Benefits as Divisive Issue
column4: Geoff Garin, a Democratic pollster, said that while the issue of protecting Social Security and Medicare could be potent in coming Congressional and presidential campaigns, it “will not be galvanizing in 2016 quite the way that voting for the Iraq war was.” “Certainly today, and presumably still at the time of the next election, President Obama has enormous credibility with Democratic voters, particularly liberal Democrats,” Mr. Garin said.

column3: Obama's Budget Revives Benefits as Divisive Issue
column4: That credibility extends, he added, to the president’s case for making changes that bolster the finances of the social-insurance programs for future generations.

column3: Obama's Budget Revives Benefits as Divisive Issue
column4: “While I have no doubt that there would be some Democratic voters who rally around a candidate who runs on a ‘don’t touch Social Security or Medicare’ platform,” Mr. Garin added, “there would not be enough to sustain a candidacy unless that candidate has a lot of other things going for him or her.”

column3: Senators Agree to Start Debate on Gun Safety Measures
column4: WASHINGTON — Pressed by shooting victims and relatives of Americans slain in gun violence, the Senate on Thursday voted to begin an emotionally and politically charged debate on gun safety proposals as advocates of new laws overcame a Republican filibuster threat.

column3: Senators Agree to Start Debate on Gun Safety Measures
column4: The strong majority in favor of considering legislation that would expand background checks and increase the penalties for illegal gun sales reflected the power of a lobbying campaign by parents of students killed in Newtown, Conn., and by others who persuaded reluctant lawmakers to back them in an initial fight that looked lost just last week.

column3: Senators Agree to Start Debate on Gun Safety Measures
column4: The vote was 68 to 31.

column3: Senators Agree to Start Debate on Gun Safety Measures
column4: “It’s remarkable,” said Senator Christopher S. Murphy, a Democrat from Connecticut whose nascent Senate career has been devoted to gun safety.

column3: Senators Agree to Start Debate on Gun Safety Measures
column4: “You can’t turn a corner in the Capitol this week without meeting a family of a gun violence victim.

column3: Senators Agree to Start Debate on Gun Safety Measures
column4: It’s hard to say no to these families.” But the victory could be short-lived.

column3: Senators Agree to Start Debate on Gun Safety Measures
column4: The vote in no way guaranteed passage of the gun measure; some Republicans and Democrats who voted for this initial step made clear they are not committed to supporting any final measure, even if they agreed to allow the debate.

column3: Senators Agree to Start Debate on Gun Safety Measures
column4: “I am not sure I could have the courage to do what they did,” said Senator Richard M. Burr, Republican of North Carolina, who met with family members of the Newtown victims on Wednesday.

column3: Senators Agree to Start Debate on Gun Safety Measures
column4: “It really does have an impact.” Mr. Burr voted to debate the bill, but said he was unlikely to go further.

column3: Senators Agree to Start Debate on Gun Safety Measures
column4: “Is there anything I’ve seen so far that would move me to vote for new gun laws?” he said.

column3: Senators Agree to Start Debate on Gun Safety Measures
column4: “No.” The coming weeks and even months will test both the resolve and the stamina of the families, who are both the best advocates for their cause and, in many ways, least equipped for its struggle.

column3: Senators Agree to Start Debate on Gun Safety Measures
column4: “Every day is hard for me,” said Mark Barden, the father of Daniel, who was killed at Sandy Hook Elementary School.

column3: Senators Agree to Start Debate on Gun Safety Measures
column4: “Making lunch for my kids is hard for me.

column3: Senators Agree to Start Debate on Gun Safety Measures
column4: Sleeping is hard.

column3: Senators Agree to Start Debate on Gun Safety Measures
column4: Waking up is hard.

column3: Senators Agree to Start Debate on Gun Safety Measures
column4: That being said, I just feel I need to be doing this.” The bill will again need 60 votes to end the debate after consideration of contentious amendments offered by both supporters and opponents of new laws.

column3: Senators Agree to Start Debate on Gun Safety Measures

column3: Senators Agree to Start Debate on Gun Safety Measures

column4: Twenty-nine Republicans opposed bringing the measure to the floor, along with two Democrats.

column3: Senators Agree to Start Debate on Gun Safety Measures
column4: Sixteen Republicans joined 50 Democrats and two independents in voting to proceed to consideration of the legislation.

column3: Senators Agree to Start Debate on Gun Safety Measures
column4: The two Democrats who voted against measure are both up for re-election in tough states in 2014: Senators Mark Begich of Alaska and Mark Pryor of Arkansas.

column3: Senators Agree to Start Debate on Gun Safety Measures
column4: Next week, the Senate is expected to begin reviewing the bill in earnest by voting on an amendment offered by Senators Joe Manchin III, Democrat of West Virginia and Patrick J. Toomey, Republican of Pennsylvania, that would expand background checks to cover unlicensed dealers at gun shows as well as all online sales.

column3: Senators Agree to Start Debate on Gun Safety Measures
column4: It would also maintain record-keeping provisions that law enforcement officials find essential in tracking guns used in crimes.

column4: This amendment would replace the background check provision of the original legislation, which would also create harsher penalties for the so-called straw purchasing of guns, in which people buy guns for others who are not able to legally.

column4: Subsequent amendments, dealing with mental health, a ban on assault weapons and other issues, are expected in the days ahead before a vote on the overall measure.

column3: Senators avert gun filibuster, setting up hard fight; 16 Republicans among 'no' votes
column4: Family members of the victims of December’s school shooting in Connecticut looked on as senators voted 68-31 to defeat the filibuster.

column3: Senators avert gun filibuster, setting up hard fight; 16 Republicans among 'no' votes

column3: Senators avert gun filibuster, setting up hard fight; 16 Republicans among 'no' votes

column4: Mark Begich of Alaska and Mark L. Pryor of Arkansas, both of whom are up for re-election in conservative-leaning states next year.

column4: Sens.

column4: Mike Lee of Utah, Ted Cruz of Texas and Rand Paul of Kentucky, who helped lead the filibuster attempt, said Democrats were trying to rush a bill through the chamber without giving senators enough time to be prepared.

column3: Senators avert gun filibuster, setting up hard fight; 16 Republicans among 'no' votes
column4: “Because the background-check measure is the centerpiece of this legislation, it is critical that we know what is in the bill before we vote on it.

column3: Senators avert gun filibuster, setting up hard fight; 16 Republicans among 'no' votes
column4: “We believe the abuse of the process is how the rights of Americans are systematically eroded and we will continue to do everything in our power to prevent it.” Under current law, checks are required only on guns sold by federally licensed dealers.

column4: Proponents of expanded checks say it will help keep criminals and the dangerously mentally ill from getting their hands on firearms, but gun rights supporters worry that expanding background checks to private transactions will be too burdensome for law-abiding gun owners.

column3: Senators avert gun filibuster, setting up hard fight; 16 Republicans among 'no' votes

column3: Conservatives Brace for Long Debate on Senate Gun Control Bill
column4: The Senate voted 68-31 to open debate on President Barack Obama's proposals to expand background checks for gun buyers, tighten restrictions on gun trafficking and increase funding for school security.

column3: Conservatives Brace for Long Debate on Senate Gun Control Bill
column4: The Senate easily cleared the 60-vote hurdle needed to break a Republican filibuster on a bill that has sparked intense lobbying on both sides, including families of the Connecticut victims as well as the powerful gun lobby the National Rifle Association.

column4: And if it clears the Senate, it would face a tough reception in the Republican-led House of Representatives.

column3: Conservatives Brace for Long Debate on Senate Gun Control Bill
column4: No major gun legislation has passed the U.S. Congress since 1994.

column4: That agreement to expand criminal background checks of gun buyers to include commercial sales made at gun shows and online was expected to boost bipartisan Senate support for the measure.

column3: Conservatives Brace for Long Debate on Senate Gun Control Bill
column4: The expanded background checks, a provision that polls show has the support of up to 90 percent of Americans, will be the first amendment offered in debate and appears to be Obama's best hope for achieving meaningful gun-control legislation.

column4: But Obama is unlikely to get some elements of gun control that he has advocated, including a ban on rapid-firing "assault" weapons like the one used in Connecticut and limits on the capacity of ammunition magazines.

column3: Conservatives Brace for Long Debate on Senate Gun Control Bill
column4: Amendments to add those provisions to the bill being considered by the Senate appear to have a slim chance of winning on the Senate floor.

column3: Conservatives Brace for Long Debate on Senate Gun Control Bill

column3: Senate gun control bill passes first test
column4: Updated 04/11/2013 11:50 PM EDT The Senate on Thursday ended a GOP filibuster on a new gun control bill, clearing the way for debate to begin on a hugely emotional issue that has dominated headlines since the tragic December shooting in Newtown, Conn.

column3: Senate gun control bill passes first test
column4: The vote was 68-31.

column3: Senate gun control bill passes first test
column4: Story Continued Below It’s a big win for Democrats in that 16 Republicans crossed the aisle to even consider the gun legislation, but the vote is only the opening move in what could be a drawn-out floor fight that will center on a deal unveiled Wednesday by Sens.

column3: Senate gun control bill passes first test
column4: Pat Toomey (R-Pa.), Mark Kirk (R-Ill.) and Joe Manchin (D-W.Va.) that would require background checks on all commercial gun sales and end the so-called “gun show loophole.” ( PHOTOS: Politicians speak out on gun control) Two Democrats - Sens.

column3: Senate gun control bill passes first test
column4: Mark Pryor of Arkansas and Mark Begich of Alaska sided with the Republicans and voted to continue the filibuster.

column3: Senate gun control bill passes first test
column4: Sixty votes were needed to end the GOP filibuster and start debate on the gun bill.

column3: Senate gun control bill passes first test
column4: Parents and family members of the victims of the Sandy Hook Elementary School Shooting watched from the gallery as the roll call vote was held.

column3: Senate gun control bill passes first test
column4: President Barack Obama spoke by phone with family members after the vote, the White House said.

column3: Senate gun control bill passes first test
column4: “The president congratulated the families on this important step forward, noting that the bipartisan progress would not have been be possible without their efforts,” said White House press secretary Jay Carney.

column3: Senate gun control bill passes first test
column4: “He reiterated that much work remains and pledged to continue fighting for the votes they deserved.” ( Also on POLITICO: Sandy Hook relative tweets senators) In the Senate, opening debate is not nearly the same as winning final passage on a bill.

column3: Senate gun control bill passes first test
column4: Republicans are expected to offer dozens — if not hundreds — of amendments and string out debate over the next few weeks.

column3: Senate gun control bill passes first test
column4: Technically, the Senate still must vote on motion to allow formal debate to begin.

column3: Senate gun control bill passes first test
column4: That vote is set for Friday at this point, but Democrats are hoping that Thursday’s big bipartisan vote will show that second vote to be a futile effort for delay.

column3: Senate gun control bill passes first test
column4: Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.) will offer a consent agreement to begin debate immediately, but any single Republican can object, forcing another temporary delay.

column3: Senate gun control bill passes first test

column3: Senate gun control bill passes first test

column3: Senate gun control bill passes first test
column4: Sen. Susan Collins (Maine), one of the few remaining Republican moderates, has her own bipartisan bill with Judiciary Committee Chairman Patrick Leahy (D-Vt.) to stiffen penalties for gun trafficking.

column3: Michelle Obama Compares Herself to Murdered Teenager in Chicago Speech
column4: Yesterday the First Lady gave a speech in Chicago about guns, obviously her forte.

column3: Michelle Obama Compares Herself to Murdered Teenager in Chicago Speech
column4: In the speech she compared herself to Hadiya Pendleton who was shot just a week after performing at the inauguration.

column3: Michelle Obama Compares Herself to Murdered Teenager in Chicago Speech
column4: Mrs. Obama said, “Hadiya Pendleton was me, and I was her”.

column3: Michelle Obama Compares Herself to Murdered Teenager in Chicago Speech
column4: The First Lady went on to say: "Thousands of children in this city live in neighborhoods where a funeral for a teenager is considered unfortunate, but not unusual; where wandering onto the wrong block or even just standing on your own front porch can mean putting yourself at risk," Michelle Obama told the Chicago crowd, according to a transcript provided by the White House.

column3: Michelle Obama Compares Herself to Murdered Teenager in Chicago Speech
column4: "Those are the odds that so many young people are facing in this city –- young people like Hadiya Pendleton, whose funeral I attended back in February.

column3: Michelle Obama Compares Herself to Murdered Teenager in Chicago Speech
column4: And we all know Hadiya’s story.

column3: Michelle Obama Compares Herself to Murdered Teenager in Chicago Speech
column4: She was 15 years old, an honor student at King College Prep.

column3: Michelle Obama Compares Herself to Murdered Teenager in Chicago Speech
column4: And she came from a good family -– two devoted parents, plenty of cousins, solid godparents and grandparents, an adoring little brother.

column3: Michelle Obama Compares Herself to Murdered Teenager in Chicago Speech
column4: The Pendletons are hardworking people.

column3: Michelle Obama Compares Herself to Murdered Teenager in Chicago Speech
column4: They’re churchgoing folks.

column3: Michelle Obama Compares Herself to Murdered Teenager in Chicago Speech
column4: And Hadiya’s mother did everything she could for her daughter.

column3: Michelle Obama Compares Herself to Murdered Teenager in Chicago Speech
column4: She enrolled her in every activity you could imagine -– cheerleading, majorettes, the praise dance ministry -– anything to keep her off the streets and keep her busy.

column3: Michelle Obama Compares Herself to Murdered Teenager in Chicago Speech
column4: "And as I visited with the Pendleton family at Hadiya’s funeral, I couldn’t get over how familiar they felt to me.

column3: Michelle Obama Compares Herself to Murdered Teenager in Chicago Speech
column4: Because what I realized was Hadiya’s family was just like my family.

column3: Michelle Obama Compares Herself to Murdered Teenager in Chicago Speech
column4: Hadiya Pendleton was me, and I was her.

column3: Michelle Obama Compares Herself to Murdered Teenager in Chicago Speech
column4: But I got to grow up, and go to Princeton and Harvard Law School, and have a career and a family and the most blessed life I could ever imagine.

column3: Michelle Obama Compares Herself to Murdered Teenager in Chicago Speech
column4: "And Hadiya?

column3: Michelle Obama Compares Herself to Murdered Teenager in Chicago Speech
column4: Oh, we know that story.

column3: Michelle Obama Compares Herself to Murdered Teenager in Chicago Speech
column4: Just a week after she performed at my husband’s inauguration, she went to a park with some friends and got shot in the back because some kid thought she was in a gang.

column3: Michelle Obama Compares Herself to Murdered Teenager in Chicago Speech
column4: Hadiya’s family did everything right, but she still didn’t have a chance.

column3: Michelle Obama Compares Herself to Murdered Teenager in Chicago Speech
column4: And that story -– the story of Hadiya’s life and death –- we read that story day after day, month after month, year after year in this city and around this country."

column3: Michelle Obama Compares Herself to Murdered Teenager in Chicago Speech
column4: Really Mrs. Obama?

column3: Michelle Obama Compares Herself to Murdered Teenager in Chicago Speech
column4: You really think that you are similar to a girl who was the victim of serious gun violence in a city, which you call home?

column3: Michelle Obama Compares Herself to Murdered Teenager in Chicago Speech
column4: How is it that you can feel comfortable standing on that stage, preaching those words, when you and your husband have done nothing but hurt that city.

column3: Michelle Obama Compares Herself to Murdered Teenager in Chicago Speech
column4: By supporting Rahm Emanuel you have doomed your hometown.

column3: Michelle Obama Compares Herself to Murdered Teenager in Chicago Speech
column4: The city with the highest gun control measures has some of the worst gun crime.

column3: Michelle Obama Compares Herself to Murdered Teenager in Chicago Speech
column4: Is it really working?

column3: Michelle Obama Compares Herself to Murdered Teenager in Chicago Speech
column4: Stop preaching gun control if it isn’t working.

column3: President Obama's budget targets smokers, wealthy - Reid J. Epstein and Darren Samuelsohn
column4: Updated 04/10/2013 05:48 PM EDT President Barack Obama presented a budget Wednesday that he called both a compromise and a final offer.

column3: President Obama's budget targets smokers, wealthy - Reid J. Epstein and Darren Samuelsohn
column4: But there’s a lot in the $3.77 trillion proposal — including $583 billion in new revenue from the wealthy and $78 billion over 10 years from new cigarette taxes, not to mention an assumption that a deal to reverse sequestration cuts can be struck — that drew an immediate rejection from Congressional Republican leaders.

column3: President Obama's budget targets smokers, wealthy - Reid J. Epstein and Darren Samuelsohn
column4: Story Continued Below Obama said he wasn’t interested in continuing to negotiate.

column3: President Obama's budget targets smokers, wealthy - Reid J. Epstein and Darren Samuelsohn
column4: Framing the budget as pitting the rich against the middle class, and smokers and the tobacco companies against preschool students, he asked Republicans to decide which side they’re on.

column3: President Obama's budget targets smokers, wealthy - Reid J. Epstein and Darren Samuelsohn
column4: ( Also on POLITICO: Obama budget squeezes $370B from Medicare) “When it comes to deficit reduction, I’ve already met Republicans more than halfway so in the coming days and weeks I hope that Republicans will come forward and demonstrate that they are really as serious about deficits and debt as they claim,” Obama said.

column3: President Obama's budget targets smokers, wealthy - Reid J. Epstein and Darren Samuelsohn
column4: “And I don’t believe that all these ideas are optimal, but I’m willing to accept them as part of a compromise — if, and only if, they contain protections for the most vulnerable Americans.” Obama’s counting $1.384 billion in savings from winding down the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan and $452 million in cuts to a program that provides funding for heating assistance for low-income households.

column3: President Obama's budget targets smokers, wealthy - Reid J. Epstein and Darren Samuelsohn
column4: The budget also includes major cuts to farm subsidies, cuts to the LIHEAP heating programs for the poor, lowering the budget for detaining illegal immigrants, new embassy security as recommended by the Benghazi Review Board and $222 million for gun control efforts.

column3: President Obama's budget targets smokers, wealthy - Reid J. Epstein and Darren Samuelsohn
column4: ( PHOTOS: What’s in Obama’s 2014 budget) The budget also raises the federal minimum wage from $7.25 to $9 per hour, lower than the hike Obama first promised during his 2008 campaign.

column3: President Obama's budget targets smokers, wealthy - Reid J. Epstein and Darren Samuelsohn
column4: And it assumes $230 billion in savings due to by implementing the reduction to the growth of Social Security spending known as “chained CPI” — though that proposal immediately fell flat with many Republicans and angered the president’s own base when news of it was leaked late last week.

column3: President Obama's budget targets smokers, wealthy - Reid J. Epstein and Darren Samuelsohn
column4: Obama’s budget comes months after its original due date, and weeks after the House and Senate passed their single chamber budget bills.

column3: President Obama's budget targets smokers, wealthy - Reid J. Epstein and Darren Samuelsohn
column4: During his Rose Garden statement, Obama made clear that his budget proposal already represents a compromise offer and said he will not allow spending cuts without the new tax increases he seeks.

column3: President Obama's budget targets smokers, wealthy - Reid J. Epstein and Darren Samuelsohn
column4: “When it comes to deficit reduction, I’ve already met Republicans more than halfway,” Obama said.

column3: President Obama's budget targets smokers, wealthy - Reid J. Epstein and Darren Samuelsohn
column4: “So in the coming days and weeks I hope that Republicans will come forward and demonstrate that they are really as serious about deficits and debt as they claim.” ( Also on POLITICO: Full coverage of Obama 2014 budget proposal) And Gene Sperling, the director Obama’s National Economic Council, on Wednesday afternoon emphasized that the proposal is”not an à la carte menu” for Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio) and congressional Republicans to choose what they like and discard the rest.

column3: President Obama's budget targets smokers, wealthy - Reid J. Epstein and Darren Samuelsohn
column4: “You can’t decide to only pick out the concessions the president has made and not include the concessions from the Republican side that need to be part of a bipartisan deal that can pass both houses,” Sperling said.

column3: President Obama's budget targets smokers, wealthy - Reid J. Epstein and Darren Samuelsohn
column4: Republicans are not impressed Republicans made clear Wednesday that they have no appetite for the new taxes Obama seeks.

column3: President Obama's budget targets smokers, wealthy - Reid J. Epstein and Darren Samuelsohn
column4: On a conference call with reporters in the afternoon, House Budget Chairman Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) called the budget “worse than the status quo,” but believed there was a silver lining.

column3: President Obama's budget targets smokers, wealthy - Reid J. Epstein and Darren Samuelsohn
column4: “A positive way of looking at this is at least everybody has put a plan on the table.

column3: President Obama's budget targets smokers, wealthy - Reid J. Epstein and Darren Samuelsohn
column4: At least the Senate has put it’s plan on the table, the president’s plan is on the table, so we can have a healthy budget debate,” he said.

column3: President Obama's budget targets smokers, wealthy - Reid J. Epstein and Darren Samuelsohn
column4: “My goal is to find common ground to where we can get a down payment on this problem.” He also identified the president’s willingness to means test pieces of Medicare as a “small instance of common ground.” “That gives me a glimmer of hope that we can get an agreement at the end of the day but we’re a long way from there right now,” he said.

column3: President Obama's budget targets smokers, wealthy - Reid J. Epstein and Darren Samuelsohn
column4: House Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio) said the White House should proceed with the “incremental entitlement reforms” the president offered without the tax hikes – the very proposal Obama explicitly ruled out.

column3: President Obama's budget targets smokers, wealthy - Reid J. Epstein and Darren Samuelsohn
column4: “I would hope that he would not hold hostage these modest reforms for his demand for bigger tax hikes.

column3: President Obama's budget targets smokers, wealthy - Reid J. Epstein and Darren Samuelsohn
column4: Listen, why don’t we do what we can agree to do?

column3: President Obama's budget targets smokers, wealthy - Reid J. Epstein and Darren Samuelsohn
column4: Why don’t we find the common ground that we do have and move on that?” Boehner told reporters at the Capitol.

column3: President Obama's budget targets smokers, wealthy - Reid J. Epstein and Darren Samuelsohn
column4: “The president got his tax hikes in January, we don’t need to be raising taxes on the American people.”

column3: Republicans rip 'unbalanced' budget proposal, bristle at proposed tax hikes
column4: Republicans ripped President Obama's long-awaited budget proposal Wednesday, describing it as a "reheated" plan that revives controversial tax hikes in the name of deficit reduction without ever balancing the budget.

column3: Republicans rip 'unbalanced' budget proposal, bristle at proposed tax hikes
column4: The 2014 plan, delivered to Congress Wednesday morning, was pitched by Obama as a compromise -- twinning tax increases, which Republicans dislike, with changes to Social Security, which liberal Democrats despise.

column3: Republicans rip 'unbalanced' budget proposal, bristle at proposed tax hikes
column4: "I have already met Republicans more than halfway," Obama said in the Rose Garden Wednesday.

column3: Republicans rip 'unbalanced' budget proposal, bristle at proposed tax hikes
column4: But Republican leaders, while praising the president for proposing a change to curb the growth of Social Security, said they had no interest in agreeing to new tax increases for a budget that wouldn't balance anyway.

column3: Republicans rip 'unbalanced' budget proposal, bristle at proposed tax hikes
column4: "We don't need an extreme unbalanced budget that won't balance in your lifetime or mine," Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell said on the floor Wednesday.

column3: Republicans rip 'unbalanced' budget proposal, bristle at proposed tax hikes
column4: The sentiment was echoed by GOP leaders in the House, who complained about the budget's abundant red ink -- which would run to nearly $5.3 trillion over 10 years.

column3: Republicans rip 'unbalanced' budget proposal, bristle at proposed tax hikes
column4: House Speaker John Boehner accused the White House of trying to hold "modest" changes to entitlements "hostage" to the call for more tax increases -- which Republicans argue they already conceded to during negotiations over the fiscal crisis late last year.

column3: Republicans rip 'unbalanced' budget proposal, bristle at proposed tax hikes
column4: House Republican Leader Eric Cantor urged Obama to drop the call for tax increases and work together with Republicans on entitlements.

column3: Republicans rip 'unbalanced' budget proposal, bristle at proposed tax hikes
column4: The budget claims to reduce the deficit by $1.8 trillion over 10 years.

column3: Republicans rip 'unbalanced' budget proposal, bristle at proposed tax hikes
column4: But annual deficits would never drop below $400 billion in that time, though they do mark an improvement over the $1 trillion deficits common during Obama's first four years in office.

column3: Republicans rip 'unbalanced' budget proposal, bristle at proposed tax hikes
column4: The budget projects a deficit for the current year of $973 billion, falling to $744 billion in 2014.

column3: Republicans rip 'unbalanced' budget proposal, bristle at proposed tax hikes
column4: The budget would also nearly double the federal tax on cigarettes to $1.95 per pack.

column3: Republicans rip 'unbalanced' budget proposal, bristle at proposed tax hikes
column4: That money would fund a new pre-school program for 4-year-olds.

column3: Republicans rip 'unbalanced' budget proposal, bristle at proposed tax hikes
column4: The president's proposed spending for the 2014 fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1, would rise 2.5 percent from this year.

column3: Republicans rip 'unbalanced' budget proposal, bristle at proposed tax hikes
column4: By including proposals to trim Social Security and Medicare, the government's two biggest benefit programs, Obama is hoping to entice Republicans to consider tax increases.

column3: Republicans rip 'unbalanced' budget proposal, bristle at proposed tax hikes
column4: Obama called his plan "a fiscally responsible blueprint for middle class jobs and growth," during remarks he made Wednesday morning in the White House Rose Garden.

column4: The president's plan to establish a program to offer preschool to all 4-year-olds from low- and moderate-income families would be financed by the higher tax on tobacco, which the administration said would raise $78 billion over a decade.

column4: The administration said its proposals to increase spending would not increase the deficit but rather would be paid for either by increasing taxes or making deeper cuts to other programs.

column4: Among the proposed cuts, the administration wants to trim defense spending by an additional $100 billion and domestic programs by an extra $100 billion over the next decade.

column3: Republicans rip 'unbalanced' budget proposal, bristle at proposed tax hikes
column4: The new method would take into account changes that occur when people substitute goods rising in price with less expensive products.

column3: Bipartisan Group of Senators Agrees on Outline of Immigration Bill
column4: WASHINGTON — A bipartisan group of senators has largely agreed on a broad immigration bill that would require tough border measures to be in place before illegal immigrants could take the first steps to become American citizens, according to several people familiar with drafts of the legislation.

column3: Bipartisan Group of Senators Agrees on Outline of Immigration Bill
column4: But in a delicate compromise worked out over weeks of negotiations, the bill does not impose any specific measurements of border enforcement results that, if they were not met, would stop the immigrants from proceeding toward citizenship.

column3: Bipartisan Group of Senators Agrees on Outline of Immigration Bill
column4: Instead, the bill allows a period of 10 years for the Department of Homeland Security to make plans and use resources to fortify enforcement at the borders and elsewhere within the country before it sets several broader hurdles that could derail the immigrants’ progress toward citizenship if they are not achieved.

column3: Bipartisan Group of Senators Agrees on Outline of Immigration Bill
column4: During the first decade after passage, the bill sets ambitious goals for border authorities — including continuous surveillance of 100 percent of the United States border and 90 percent effectiveness of enforcement in several high-risk sectors — and for other workplace and visa enforcement measures.

column3: Bipartisan Group of Senators Agrees on Outline of Immigration Bill
column4: It provides at least $3 billion for Homeland Security officials to meet those goals during the first five years, with a possibility of additional financing.

column3: Bipartisan Group of Senators Agrees on Outline of Immigration Bill
column4: The bill includes provisions, or “triggers,” during that decade that allow Congress at different points to ensure the enforcement goals are being met.

column3: Bipartisan Group of Senators Agrees on Outline of Immigration Bill
column4: As the group of eight senators continued on Wednesday to iron out final details of the legislation, several tens of thousands of immigrants, Latinos, labor union members, gay rights and other advocates held a rally on the lawn below the steps of the Capitol.

column3: Bipartisan Group of Senators Agrees on Outline of Immigration Bill
column4: With many waving American flags, they called for Congress to move quickly and demanded a direct path to citizenship for all 11 million illegal immigrants.

column3: Bipartisan Group of Senators Agrees on Outline of Immigration Bill
column4: “Families cannot continue to be torn apart,” Gustavo Torres, executive director of CASA de Maryland, an immigrant advocacy group, told the crowd.

column3: Bipartisan Group of Senators Agrees on Outline of Immigration Bill
column4: “Anything less than citizenship undermines American democracy,” he insisted.

column3: Bipartisan Group of Senators Agrees on Outline of Immigration Bill
column4: Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey, a Democrat who is one of the eight senators working to draft the legislation, told the crowd that the group was close to presenting a bill.

column3: Bipartisan Group of Senators Agrees on Outline of Immigration Bill
column4: “We have to get those who are in the shadows into the light to have an opportunity to earn their citizenship and be part of the dream,” said Mr. Menendez, who like many of the other speakers delivered his words in both English and Spanish.

column3: Bipartisan Group of Senators Agrees on Outline of Immigration Bill
column4: The senators’ compromise allows Republican lawmakers, including Senators John McCain of Arizona and Marco Rubio of Florida, to say that they achieved border enforcement advances in the bill as a condition before any illegal immigrants can apply for permanent-resident green cards, the first step toward citizenship.

column3: Bipartisan Group of Senators Agrees on Outline of Immigration Bill
column4: But it also allows Democrats to describe the border measures as goals that can be achieved with the resources provided, so they will not become roadblocks that could stop the immigrants from reaching the final stage of citizenship.

column3: Bipartisan Group of Senators Agrees on Outline of Immigration Bill
column4: President Obama, who has been largely silent during the negotiations, is strongly opposed to any hindrances on the immigrants’ path that could be the focus of political battles later on.

column3: Bipartisan Group of Senators Agrees on Outline of Immigration Bill
column4: As drafted, the legislation would provide as much as $3.5 billion for the Department of Homeland Security to set up a five-year border security plan.

column3: Bipartisan Group of Senators Agrees on Outline of Immigration Bill
column4: Officials must present the plan within six months, and no immigrants can gain any provisional legal status until the plan is in place.

column3: Bipartisan Group of Senators Agrees on Outline of Immigration Bill
column4: It would include a program to finish any border fencing that border agents deem necessary.

column3: Bipartisan Group of Senators Agrees on Outline of Immigration Bill
column4: The plan must also show how the authorities will move quickly to spread technology across the border to ensure that agents can have surveillance capability along its entire length.

column3: Bipartisan Group of Senators Agrees on Outline of Immigration Bill
column4: They will also have five years to reach 90 percent effectiveness in their operations, a measure based on calculations of what percentage of illegal crossers were caught or turned back without crossing.

column3: Bipartisan Group of Senators Agrees on Outline of Immigration Bill
column4: If, after five years, border officials have not reached the surveillance and enforcement goals, the bill establishes a border commission to advise the Department of Homeland Security on how to reach its goals, with additional financing of up to $2 billion.

column3: Bipartisan Group of Senators Agrees on Outline of Immigration Bill
column4: Homeland Security officials will also be required to expand a worker verification system, making it mandatory nationwide for all employers within five years.

column3: Bipartisan Group of Senators Agrees on Outline of Immigration Bill
column4: Within 10 years, they must also create an electronic exit system at all airports and seaports to help ensure that foreigners leave when their visas expire.

column3: Bipartisan Group of Senators Agrees on Outline of Immigration Bill
column4: Also, illegal immigrants who pass background checks and meet other requirements will have to wait in a provisional status for at least 10 years, before they could apply for green cards.

column3: Bipartisan Group of Senators Agrees on Outline of Immigration Bill
column4: Before those applications can begin, officials must show that the border security plan is operational, the fence is completed, and the worker verification and visa exits systems are operating.

column3: Bipartisan Group of Senators Agrees on Outline of Immigration Bill
column4: At the rally, the demonstrators filled the large lawns that sweep down from the Capitol, and overflowed into lawns on either side.

column3: Bipartisan Group of Senators Agrees on Outline of Immigration Bill
column4: Groups of demonstrators came mainly from Washington, Maryland and Virginia, while several hundred buses brought delegates from around the country.

column3: Bipartisan Group of Senators Agrees on Outline of Immigration Bill
column4: Rather than concentrate all their forces in one place, organizers also held more than 30 smaller events around the country on Wednesday, including marches, early morning candlelight vigils, and door knocking.

column3: Bipartisan Group of Senators Agrees on Outline of Immigration Bill
column4: In Orlando, Fla., farmworkers and immigrants held a picnic in front of the offices of Mr. Rubio.

column3: Bipartisan Group of Senators Agrees on Outline of Immigration Bill
column4: In Los Angeles and Fresno, Calif., advocates rallied outside the offices of Senator Dianne Feinstein, a Democrat who is leading negotiations over the agricultural provisions in the bill.

column3: Bipartisan Group of Senators Agrees on Outline of Immigration Bill
column4: Many events were organized by the Service Employees International Union and other unions, which have strongly supported the immigration effort.

column3: Bipartisan Group of Senators Agrees on Outline of Immigration Bill
column4: Many activists spent the morning on Capitol Hill lobbying lawmakers, including a contingent from Alabama who delivered 250 small red footballs to the office of Senator Jeff Sessions, a Republican from that state who is a staunch opponent of the proposed legislation.

column3: Bipartisan Group of Senators Agrees on Outline of Immigration Bill
column4: “Don’t drop the ball,” was the message they conveyed.

column3: Bipartisan Group of Senators Agrees on Outline of Immigration Bill
column4: At the rally, Representative Luis V. Gutierrez of Illinois, a Democrat who has been a tenacious proponent of the immigration overhaul, said, “You need to guarantee that you give me and my colleagues and the Congress of the United States no place to hide.

column3: Bipartisan Group of Senators Agrees on Outline of Immigration Bill
column4: “There are no acceptable excuses for failing to pass immigration reform this year,” Mr. Gutierrez said, “and no excuses will be accepted.” Many in the crowd said they were hoping that the coming debate in Congress would not divert or close their path to becoming Americans.

column3: Bipartisan Group of Senators Agrees on Outline of Immigration Bill
column4: “I believe this is a country of opportunity,” said Alonso Martinez, 30, an immigrant from Mexico who lives in Maryland, “and without citizenship we are not going to have the same opportunity as the other immigrants who came before us.”

column3: Katie Pavlich - Illegal Immigration Reform to Get Some Time for Debate
column4: According to POLITICO, the Gang of 8 is expected to release their illegal immigration reform plan as soon as Thursday with mark-ups beginning the first week of May.

column3: Katie Pavlich - Illegal Immigration Reform to Get Some Time for Debate
column4: This gives at least some time for debate on the issue, which has been in question since Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Patrick Leahy has indicated no plans to slow down the process.

column3: Katie Pavlich - Illegal Immigration Reform to Get Some Time for Debate
column4: Regardless, Leahy plans to hold just one hearing on the new legislation.

column3: Katie Pavlich - Illegal Immigration Reform to Get Some Time for Debate
column4: The Senate’s immigration Gang of Eight plans to announce a deal within a week but a committee markup is not expected until at least the week of May 6, providing a long period for debate and changes, Senate aides said Tuesday.

column3: Katie Pavlich - Illegal Immigration Reform to Get Some Time for Debate
column4: Aides said the legislative proposal could be released as soon as Thursday, but is more likely to be ready early next week.

column3: Katie Pavlich - Illegal Immigration Reform to Get Some Time for Debate
column4: The schedule outlined by the aides is meant to satisfy Sen. Marco Rubio (R-Fla.), who has said repeatedly that he wants a full debate and amendment process, to maximize the chances that the final vote is an overwhelming majority.

column3: Katie Pavlich - Illegal Immigration Reform to Get Some Time for Debate
column4: Earlier this week, it was speculated that the Gang of 8 would not allow for amendments to be added to the legislation.

column3: Katie Pavlich - Illegal Immigration Reform to Get Some Time for Debate
column4: Clearly that has changed.

column3: Katie Pavlich - Illegal Immigration Reform to Get Some Time for Debate
column4: As I've been mentioning, what we know of th Gang of 8 bill so far doesn't make clear how border security will be made a priority before amensty is granted to millions of illegal immigrants in the United States.

column3: Katie Pavlich - Illegal Immigration Reform to Get Some Time for Debate
column4: Yesterday, Texas Senator John Cornyn and Rep. Michael McCaul introduced legislation addressing border security on its own and separate from any path to citizenship or amnesty.

column3: Obama's budget faces bipartisan opposition
column4: Top congressional Republicans declared President Obama’s tax-laden budget for fiscal 2014 dead on arrival Wednesday, saying its failure to cut deficits destroys any hope of a “grand bargain” to fix the federal government’s fiscal crisis.

column3: Obama's budget faces bipartisan opposition
column4: The White House promoted the budget as an effort to restart negotiations on long-term deficit reduction with a mix of higher taxes on the wealthy and modest trims to entitlement programs.

column3: Obama's budget faces bipartisan opposition
column4: But House Budget Committee Chairman Paul Ryan, Wisconsin Republican, said the president’s proposals on Social Security and Medicare don’t come close to addressing the programs’ looming insolvency.

column3: Obama's budget faces bipartisan opposition
column4: “I don’t think we should be talking about a grand bargain, because that implies that the president and Senate Democrats are ready to embrace fundamental entitlement reform, which they have shown absolutely no indication of doing,” Mr. Ryan told reporters.

column3: Obama's budget faces bipartisan opposition
column4: SEE ALSO: Obama tax hikes ‘dead on arrival,’ GOP Rep. Kevin Brady says Mr. Obama introduced his fiscal 2014 budget to Congress on Wednesday, a $3.77 trillion spending plan that would raise hundreds of billions of dollars in taxes and commit his administration to entitlement reform for the first time by changing the way Social Security’s cost-of-living adjustments are calculated.

column3: Obama's budget faces bipartisan opposition
column4: Responding to Republican accusations that his budget doesn’t trim deficits as much as he claims, Mr. Obama insisted “the numbers work.” “There’s not a lot of smoke and mirrors in here,” Mr. Obama said in the White House Rose Garden as he presented the document with Jeffrey Zients, the acting budget director.

column3: Obama's budget faces bipartisan opposition
column4: SEE ALSO: Obama doubles estimated cost of health exchanges to $4.4B Adding up the numbers The budget proposal, which is nine weeks late, would replace the across-the-board “sequester” budget cuts that started March 1 with a mix of tax increases and more targeted program cuts.

column3: Obama's budget faces bipartisan opposition
column4: The blueprint also calls for more than $25 billion in specific spending cuts to 215 line items, slightly less than the $28 billion in individual program cuts that Mr. Obama sought last year.

column3: Obama's budget faces bipartisan opposition
column4: Mr. Obama said the budget would reduce deficits by $1.8 trillion over 10 years, partly by raising $580 billion in additional revenue through closing loopholes for wealthier taxpayers and limiting tax deductions, as well as eliminating tax breaks for oil and gas companies.

column3: Obama's budget faces bipartisan opposition
column4: It would include $400 billion in budget cuts divided evenly between defense and non-defense programs.

column3: Obama's budget faces bipartisan opposition
column4: “If you’re serious about deficit reduction, there’s no reason to keep these loopholes open,” Mr. Obama said.

column3: Obama's budget faces bipartisan opposition
column4: “When it comes to deficit reduction, I’ve already met the Republicans more than halfway.

column3: Obama's budget faces bipartisan opposition
column4: Our deficits are already falling.

column3: Obama's budget faces bipartisan opposition
column4: My budget will reduce deficits by nearly another $2 trillion … but it does so in a balanced and responsible way.” But in an indication of how far apart the two sides are, congressional Republicans immediately countered that the president’s plan reduces deficits by only $119 billion over 10 years, when the cost of replacing the sequester cuts is factored in and the administration’s fiscal “gimmicks” are exposed.

column3: Obama's budget faces bipartisan opposition
column4: Republican sources on the House and Senate budget committees said the administration’s own budget charts propose to trim deficits by $1.4 trillion, not $1.8 trillion.

column3: Obama's budget faces bipartisan opposition
column4: Mr. Ryan and Republican staffers said the administration is proposing largely bogus savings of $675 billion from ending the war in Afghanistan, as well as failing to offset a Medicare funding formula known as the “doc fix” ($250 billion), and failing to count the cost of extending certain refundable tax credits ($161 billion).

column3: Obama's budget faces bipartisan opposition
column4: Add up those gimmicks, Republicans said, and Mr. Obama is left with $119 billion in true deficit reductions over 10 years.

column3: Obama's budget faces bipartisan opposition
column4: Republican budget sources said Mr. Obama’s plan would raise taxes by $1 trillion over a decade, on top of the $600 billion in increased revenue he secured as part of the “fiscal cliff” deal Jan. 1.

column3: Obama's budget faces bipartisan opposition
column4: Mr. Obama’s budget never achieves balance, with a deficit projected at $439 billion in its 10th year.

column3: Obama's budget faces bipartisan opposition
column4: Mr. Obama also proposes to implement the “Buffett rule,” named for billionaire investor Warren Buffett, which would require households earning $1 million or more per year to pay at least 30 percent of their income in taxes.

column3: Obama's budget faces bipartisan opposition
column4: Spending proposals The spending plan will call for several initiatives that Mr. Obama previously outlined, including universal preschool to be funded by a cigarette tax, $50 billion more in infrastructure spending to create construction jobs, and tax credits for small businesses to hire more employees.

column3: Obama's budget faces bipartisan opposition
column4: The White House said all of the new spending proposals are paid for and would not add to the deficit, which in the current year is projected at about $850 billion.

column3: Obama's budget faces bipartisan opposition
column4: The White House estimates that the deficit in fiscal 2014 will be $744 billion.

column3: Obama's budget faces bipartisan opposition
column4: But even before Mr. Obama submitted the budget to Congress, the proposal was receiving more attention for its approach to reform of social welfare programs such as Social Security and Medicare than for any spending programs.

column3: Obama's budget faces bipartisan opposition
column4: The president is proposing to change the way Social Security benefits are calculated, moving from the current inflation measure to the “chained” consumer price index to slow the program’s cost growth by reducing payments over time to seniors and future retirees.

column3: Obama's budget faces bipartisan opposition
column4: The budget also will call for higher-income beneficiaries to pay more for Medicare coverage, and for $600 billion more in revenue — most of which would come from capping the tax deductions that those in the higher tax brackets can claim.

column3: Obama's budget faces bipartisan opposition
column4: The Social Security proposal would save about $230 billion over 10 years, according to administration estimates, and the health care reform would save $400 billion, mainly by cutting Medicare payments to providers.

column3: Obama's budget faces bipartisan opposition
column4: Pushback on the left “I don’t believe all these ideas are optimal, but I’m willing to accept them as part of a compromise,” Mr. Obama said.

column3: Obama's budget faces bipartisan opposition
column4: “They are reforms that keep our basic promise to our seniors.” As details of the entitlement reform have leaked, liberal lawmakers, unions and groups representing retired Americans have responded angrily.

column3: Obama's budget faces bipartisan opposition
column4: Some of them staged a protest outside the White House on Tuesday.

column3: Obama's budget faces bipartisan opposition
column4: Mr. Ryan said the president’s budget would add $8.2 trillion to the national debt over 10 years.

column3: Obama's budget faces bipartisan opposition
column4: “This is worse than a status quo budget,” he said.

column3: Obama's budget faces bipartisan opposition
column4: “It’s just more taxing, more spending and more of the same.” Even some of Mr. Obama’s strongest supporters objected to key parts of his proposed budget.

column3: Obama's budget faces bipartisan opposition
column4: Mary Kay Henry, president of the Service Employees International Union, backed Mr. Obama’s spending proposals to create more jobs but objected to his planned entitlement reforms.

column3: Obama's budget faces bipartisan opposition
column4: “Social Security has never been a contributing factor to the deficit and we cannot leave seniors out in the cold,” she said.

column4: Mr. Manchin, West Virginia Democrat, and Mr. Toomey, Pennsylvania Republican, both have “A” ratings from the National Rifle Association, potentially giving the the deal the kind of political weight needed to achieve a bipartisan vote capable of overcoming a filibuster.

column3: Background checks brokered: Sens. Toomey and Manchin reach gun deal

column3: Harry Reid sets showdown gun vote for Thursday

column3: Harry Reid sets showdown gun vote for Thursday

column3: Harry Reid sets showdown gun vote for Thursday

Chuck Grassley, Iowa Republican and ranking member of the Judiciary Committee, said Mr. Reid is forcing the Senate “to take a leap into the unknown” and that “we are being asked to vote to proceed to an uncertain bill.” “The world’s greatest deliberative body should not operate in this fashion,” he said.

column3: G.O.P. Senators Signal Possible Breakthrough in Gun Debate
column4: WASHINGTON — Several Senate Republicans said Tuesday that they would not participate in a filibuster of the first major gun control bill since 1993, as Democrats appeared on the verge of overcoming a blockade threatened by a group of conservatives before a word of debate on the measure was uttered.

column3: G.O.P. Senators Signal Possible Breakthrough in Gun Debate
column4: Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the majority leader, said he would schedule an initial showdown vote for Thursday.

column3: G.O.P. Senators Signal Possible Breakthrough in Gun Debate
column4: If backers of the measure can corral at least 60 votes, the Senate will begin consideration of a series of gun safety proposals — strongly supported by President Obama — that would still face a long and difficult journey across the Senate floor.

column3: G.O.P. Senators Signal Possible Breakthrough in Gun Debate
column4: The bill, which would increase penalties for illegal gun purchase and greatly expand background checks on gun buyers, would again need 60 votes to end the ensuing debate after consideration of contentious amendments, including a renewal of the assault weapons ban.

column3: G.O.P. Senators Signal Possible Breakthrough in Gun Debate
column4: Should it cross that very high hurdle, 51 votes would be needed to get to final passage.

column3: G.O.P. Senators Signal Possible Breakthrough in Gun Debate

Toomey, Republican of Pennsylvania were very near a deal that would most likely serve as an amendment replacing the background check piece of the measure that Mr. Reid is seeking a vote on.

column3: G.O.P. Senators Signal Possible Breakthrough in Gun Debate
column4: Their measure, which would almost certainly appeal to a broader base of members than the one now at the heart of the debate, would include fewer gun buyers in newly expanded checks, but allow for the record keeping that many Republicans have opposed.

column3: G.O.P. Senators Signal Possible Breakthrough in Gun Debate
column4: The two were expected to announce a deal Wednesday.

column3: G.O.P. Senators Signal Possible Breakthrough in Gun Debate
column4: Mr. Manchin briefed Mr. Reid late Tuesday.

column3: G.O.P. Senators Signal Possible Breakthrough in Gun Debate
column4: Still, eking out the first 60 votes would represent momentum for the bill’s supporters in the Senate, and an egg-on-the-face moment for those Republican senators, led by some younger conservatives, who chose to highlight their efforts to kill the bill before debate, a procedural move usually done more stealthily.

column3: G.O.P. Senators Signal Possible Breakthrough in Gun Debate
column4: “We’re moving forward on this bill,” said Mr. Reid, who earlier Tuesday invoked his own father’s suicide by gunshot to implore consideration of the legislation.

column3: G.O.P. Senators Signal Possible Breakthrough in Gun Debate
column4: “The American people deserve a vote on this legislation.” Senate Republicans began splintering Tuesday on whether the bill should be allowed full consideration on the floor, with nearly a dozen, including Kelly Ayotte of New Hampshire, Susan Collins of Maine, Johnny Isakson of Georgia and Tom Coburn of Oklahoma, saying they would support a procedural motion to take up the legislation formally for debate and amendments.

column3: G.O.P. Senators Signal Possible Breakthrough in Gun Debate
column4: “There’s not very much ambivalence on Capitol Hill about the gun issue,” Mr. Isakson said.

column3: G.O.P. Senators Signal Possible Breakthrough in Gun Debate
