column3: G.O.P. Senators Signal Possible Breakthrough in Gun Debate
column4: Many of those members are up for re-election next year and would rather not see the bill move forward.

column3: G.O.P. Senators Signal Possible Breakthrough in Gun Debate
column4: Mr. Reid’s decision to forge ahead came as lobbying on gun control stepped up on Capitol Hill, with the families of those killed in Newtown, Conn., four months ago fanning out across the Senate to appeal to lawmakers to vote for legislation to expand background checks for gun buyers and limit the size of magazines.

column3: G.O.P. Senators Signal Possible Breakthrough in Gun Debate
column4: “I think we bring a face to this tragedy,” said Mark Barden, whose son Daniel was among the 20 children killed at Newtown.

column3: G.O.P. Senators Signal Possible Breakthrough in Gun Debate
column4: The parents were reluctant to discuss whom they had met with, though according to several Senate Democrats, it was largely members from their party.

column3: G.O.P. Senators Signal Possible Breakthrough in Gun Debate
column4: “We’re encouraged and arranged meetings, whenever possible, with Republicans and Democrats,” said Senator Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut.

column3: G.O.P. Senators Signal Possible Breakthrough in Gun Debate
column4: “Some of my colleagues were more welcoming than others.” The decision by some Senate Republicans to abandon the filibuster on what is formally known as a motion to proceed came less than 24 hours after Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Republican leader, announced his support for the filibuster, resulting in a rare show of disunity among Senate Republicans.

column3: G.O.P. Senators Signal Possible Breakthrough in Gun Debate
column4: Thirteen senators, led by a core of younger conservatives, had vowed to try to block any legislation that they saw as infringing on the constitutional right to bear arms.

column3: G.O.P. Senators Signal Possible Breakthrough in Gun Debate
column4: “There’s an irony to the calls for ‘let’s have debate.’ We are having debate right now,” said Senator Ted Cruz, Republican of Texas and one of the original authors of the letter declaring an intent to filibuster.

column3: G.O.P. Senators Signal Possible Breakthrough in Gun Debate
column4: “And the reason why I and others have written to the majority leader and said we will insist on a 60-vote threshold is to safeguard the Bill of Rights.

column3: G.O.P. Senators Signal Possible Breakthrough in Gun Debate
column4: The Constitution is our founding document, and it protects the rights of Americans even when the passions of the moment intrude.” Republicans have voted to block debate on bills scores of times over the last few years.

column4: While advocates of the gun bill appeared on the edge of the 60 votes they will need to break a filibuster, the count remained close.

column3: North Korea urges foreigners to vacate South Korea
column4: PYONGYANG, North Korea (AP) — North Korea on Tuesday urged foreign companies and tourists in South Korea to evacuate, saying the two countries are on the verge of a nuclear war.

column3: North Korea urges foreigners to vacate South Korea
column4: The new warning appeared to be an attempt to scare foreigners into pressing their governments to pressure Washington and Seoul to act to avert a conflict.

column3: North Korea urges foreigners to vacate South Korea
column4: Analysts see a direct attack on Seoul as extremely unlikely, and there are no overt signs that North Korea's army is readying for war, let alone a nuclear one.

column3: North Korea urges foreigners to vacate South Korea
column4: Despite the warnings of an impending war, there was no sense of panic in North Korea's capital, Pyongyang, on Tuesday.

column3: North Korea urges foreigners to vacate South Korea
column4: Scores of people of all ages were armed with shovels, not guns, as they planted trees in a forestation campaign.

column3: North Korea urges foreigners to vacate South Korea
column4: The national flag fluttered across the city as North Korea marked the 20th anniversary of late leader Kim Jong Il's appointment as chairman of the National Defense Commission.

column3: North Korea urges foreigners to vacate South Korea
column4: In the evening, women donned traditional Korean dresses and danced in plazas across the country to celebrate.

column3: North Korea urges foreigners to vacate South Korea
column4: The call from the Asia-Pacific Peace Committee for foreigners to leave South Korea was the latest in a series of statements aimed at ramping up anxiety abroad about tensions on the peninsula.

column3: North Korea urges foreigners to vacate South Korea
column4: "The situation on the Korean Peninsula is inching close to a thermonuclear war due to the evermore undisguised hostile actions of the United States and the South Korean puppet warmongers and their moves for a war against" North Korea, the committee said in a statement carried by state media.

column3: North Korea urges foreigners to vacate South Korea
column4: White House spokesman Jay Carney called the statement "more unhelpful rhetoric."

column3: North Korea urges foreigners to vacate South Korea
column4: "It is unhelpful, it is concerning, it is provocative," he said.

column3: North Korea urges foreigners to vacate South Korea
column4: North Korea has been girding for a showdown with the U.S. and South Korea, its wartime foes, for months.

column3: North Korea urges foreigners to vacate South Korea
column4: The Korean War ended in 1953 with an armistice, not a peace treaty, leaving the peninsula still technically at war.

column3: North Korea urges foreigners to vacate South Korea

column3: North Korea urges foreigners to vacate South Korea

column3: North Korea urges foreigners to vacate South Korea

column3: North Korea urges foreigners to vacate South Korea
column4: Annual U.S.-South Korean military drills south of the border have further incensed Pyongyang, which sees them as practice for an invasion.

column3: North Korea urges foreigners to vacate South Korea

column4: North Korea also declared it would restart a mothballed nuclear complex.

column3: North Korea urges foreigners to vacate South Korea

column3: North Korea urges foreigners to vacate South Korea
column4: "The continued advancement of the North's nuclear and missile programs, its conventional force posture, and its willingness to resort to asymmetric actions as a tool of coercive diplomacy creates an environment marked by the potential for miscalculation," Locklear told the panel.

column3: North Korea urges foreigners to vacate South Korea
column4: He said the U.S. military and its allies would be ready if North Korea tries to strike.

column3: North Korea urges foreigners to vacate South Korea
column4: Heightening speculation about a provocation, foreign diplomats reported last week that they had been advised by North Korea to consider evacuating by Wednesday.

column3: North Korea urges foreigners to vacate South Korea
column4: However, Britain and others said they had no immediate plans to withdraw from Pyongyang.

column3: North Korea urges foreigners to vacate South Korea

column3: North Korea urges foreigners to vacate South Korea
column4: U.S. and South Korean defense officials have said they've seen nothing to indicate that Pyongyang is preparing for a major military action, and there was no sign of an exodus of foreign companies or tourists from South Korea.

column3: North Korea urges foreigners to vacate South Korea
column4: Still, the United States and South Korea have raised their defense postures, as has Japan, which deployed PAC-3 missile interceptors in key locations around Tokyo on Tuesday as a precaution against possible North Korean ballistic missile tests.

column3: North Korea urges foreigners to vacate South Korea
column4: In Rome, U.N. Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon described the tensions as "very dangerous" and said that "any small incident caused by miscalculation or misjudgment" may "create an uncontrollable situation."

column4: Also Tuesday, citing the tension, North Korea pulled out more than 50,000 workers from the Kaesong industrial park, which combines South Korean technology and know-how with cheap North Korean labor.

column4: "Everyone, including me, is determined to turn out as one to fight for national reunification ... if the enemies spark a war," he said, using nationalist rhetoric employed by many North Koreans when speaking to the media.

column3: President Obama's make-or-break week on guns
column4: President Barack Obama finds out this week whether he scratches out a narrow victory on gun control — or ends up with nothing at all.

column4: Four months after the mass shooting at a Newtown, Conn., elementary school reignited the national debate over gun control, the issue is finally headed to the Senate floor.

column3: Obama proposing Social Security change in exchange for taxes, drawing liberal ire

column3: Obama proposing Social Security change in exchange for taxes, drawing liberal ire

column3: Obama proposing Social Security change in exchange for taxes, drawing liberal ire

column3: Obama proposing Social Security change in exchange for taxes, drawing liberal ire
column4: That's no way to lead and move the country forward."

column3: Obama proposing Social Security change in exchange for taxes, drawing liberal ire

column3: Obama proposing Social Security change in exchange for taxes, drawing liberal ire

column3: Obama proposing Social Security change in exchange for taxes, drawing liberal ire

column3: Obama proposing Social Security change in exchange for taxes, drawing liberal ire

column3: Obama proposing Social Security change in exchange for taxes, drawing liberal ire

column3: Obama proposing Social Security change in exchange for taxes, drawing liberal ire

column3: 88,000 JOBS
column4: Austerity may be starting to squeeze the life out of the job market.

column3: 88,000 JOBS
column4: U.S. employers hired at the slowest pace in nearly a year in March, adding only 88,000 jobs to non-farm payrolls, with steep job cuts in the retail and government sectors, including 12,000 at the U.S.

column3: 88,000 JOBS
column4: Postal Service, according to a Labor Department report released Friday.

column3: 88,000 JOBS
column4: Economists predicted March's net gain to be somewhere closer to 190,000, according to a Bloomberg survey.

column3: 88,000 JOBS
column4: "This is a punch to the gut," Austan Goolsbee, former Chairman of the Council of Economic Advisors under President Obama, said on CNBC.

column3: 88,000 JOBS
column4: "This is not a good number."

column3: 88,000 JOBS
column4: (SCROLL DOWN FOR UPDATES AND ANALYSIS ON THE REPORT) Unemployment fell to 7.6 percent in March from 7.7 percent in February, the Bureau of Labor Statistics said.

column3: 88,000 JOBS
column4: But that was mainly due to 496,000 people leaving the labor force completely.

column3: 88,000 JOBS
column4: The labor-force participation rate -- the percentage of people eligible to be working or looking for work -- fell to 63.3 percent, the lowest since 1979.

column3: 88,000 JOBS
column4: Had that number simply held stable, the unemployment rate might have been higher.

column3: 88,000 JOBS
column4: Stocks, which have recently climbed to fresh record highs, sold off after the report.

column3: 88,000 JOBS
column4: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell about 150 points, or 1 percent, shortly after the market opened, while the S&P; 500 was down 1.1 percent.

column3: 88,000 JOBS
column4: Yields on 10-year Treasury notes tumbled below 1.7 percent, their lowest levels of the year, as investors rushed for safety.

column3: 88,000 JOBS
column4: Treasury yields fall as their prices rise.

column3: 88,000 JOBS
column4: Non-farm payrolls have grown by 504,000 jobs in the first three months of the year, or 168,000 per month, just enough to keep up with the natural growth of the labor force and keep unemployment from rising.

column3: 88,000 JOBS
column4: February's top-line number was revised up to 268,000.

column3: 88,000 JOBS
column4: Together, revisions to January and February added 61,000 jobs -- the one thin silver lining in an otherwise dismal report.

column3: 88,000 JOBS
column4: March's jobs numbers did not yet reflect much of the "sequester," the across-the-board federal budget cuts that will slowly take effect throughout the year, resulting in less hiring and fewer hours worked by government employees.

column3: 88,000 JOBS
column4: Nevertheless, austerity is already pinching job growth in other ways.

column3: 88,000 JOBS
column4: The federal government shed 14,000 jobs in March, almost all of which were accounted for by the U.S.

column3: 88,000 JOBS
column4: Postal Service.

column3: 88,000 JOBS
column4: Meanwhile, the retail sector shed 24,000 jobs, possibly an effect of the payroll-tax hike that was part of the "fiscal cliff" settlement at the beginning of the year.

column3: 88,000 JOBS
column4: A weak labor market meant that average hourly earnings for private-sector workers rose by just a penny in March, to $23.82 from $23.81.

column3: 88,000 JOBS
column4: Worker earnings have gained just 1.8 percent in the past year, not enough to keep up with inflation -- even as corporate profits and the stock market have soared to record highs.

column3: 88,000 JOBS
column4: With Congress focused on cutting the federal budget deficit, the Federal Reserve has been doing much of the heavy lifting in trying to stimulate the economy, buying $85 billion in bonds per month to keep longer-term interest rates low.

column3: 88,000 JOBS
column4: It has promised to keep doing that until it sees substantial improvement in the labor market.

column3: 88,000 JOBS
column4: The economy has added nearly 5.9 million jobs in total since the job market bottomed in February 2010, but it is still about 2.9 million jobs away from its peak level of non-farm employment in January 2008.

column3: 88,000 JOBS
column4: This grinding recovery has been the slowest since World War II.

column3: 88,000 JOBS
column4: One reason for the drag has been austerity in federal, state and local governments, which have cut 605,000 jobs since February 2010, a drag on the job market's growth, even as private-sector employers have added nearly 6.5 million jobs.

column3: 88,000 JOBS
column4: "Sharp cuts in government spending implemented March 1 are only beginning to show their ugly consequences," Heather Boushey, an economist with the liberal think-tank Center for American Progress, said in an email.

column3: 88,000 JOBS
column4: "While it’s too early to know what the full impact will be on the unemployment rate, government spending cuts are stealing wind from the sails of the recovery."

column3: Reagan?s daughter says he would not have opposed gay marriage
column4: The daughter of former President Ronald Reagan said this week that her father would not have stood in front of same-sex marriage, saying that opposing it would have clashed against his governing philosophy.

column3: Reagan?s daughter says he would not have opposed gay marriage
column4: “I think he would be puzzled on the one hand at why anyone would have a problem with people wanting to be married and wanting to be committed to one another and what difference does not make to anyone else’s life,” Patti Davis told the website Gwist TV, which bills itself as the “first online network that’s not about being gay but for being gay.” “I also think because he wanted government out of people’s lives that he would not understand the intrusion of government banning such a thing.

column3: Reagan?s daughter says he would not have opposed gay marriage
column4: This is not what he would have thought government should be doing,” Ms. Davis said.

column3: Reagan?s daughter says he would not have opposed gay marriage
column4: The youngest daughter of Mr. Reagan and his second wife, former first lady Nancy Reagan, Ms. Davis is an actress and author who has been dubbed the “black sheep” of the family.

column3: Reagan?s daughter says he would not have opposed gay marriage
column4: She made the comments while promoting her new e-book “Till Human Voices Wake Us,” which has been billed as a lesbian love story.

column3: Reagan?s daughter says he would not have opposed gay marriage
column4: The comments come as the Supreme Court weighs the constitutionality of California’s Proposition 8, a voter referendum that banned same-sex marriage, and the Defense of Marriage Act, or DOMA, which former President Bill Clinton signed into law in 1996.

column3: Reagan?s daughter says he would not have opposed gay marriage
column4: Republicans Sens.

column3: Reagan?s daughter says he would not have opposed gay marriage
column4: Rob Portman of Ohio and Mark Kirk of Illinois have come out in support of same-sex marriage in recent weeks.

column3: Reagan?s daughter says he would not have opposed gay marriage
column4: The Republican National Committee, meanwhile, has said the GOP must have bolster its outreach efforts to the gay community in the wake of the 2012 election, and Ed Gillespie, former RNC chief and ex-aid to former President George W. Bush, has said that it is possible the party will consider stripping calls for a federal marriage amendment — defining marriage between one man and one woman — from the party’s platform.

column3: Reagan?s daughter says he would not have opposed gay marriage
column4: In her interview, Ms. Davis said that many people have wrongly tried to claim the Reagan legacy.

column3: Reagan?s daughter says he would not have opposed gay marriage
column4: “I think people have chosen my father to chose and mold him into whatever they want him to be.

column3: Reagan?s daughter says he would not have opposed gay marriage
column4: He was a very tolerant person.

column3: Reagan?s daughter says he would not have opposed gay marriage
column4: He did not have prejudices against gay people,” she said.

column3: Reagan?s daughter says he would not have opposed gay marriage
column4: Meanwhile, Michael Reagan, the ex-president’s eldest son from a previous marriage, wrote an op-ed last week calling on churches to be more vocal in their opposition of same-sex marriage.

column3: Reagan?s daughter says he would not have opposed gay marriage
column4: “Churches should be in the vanguard of the fight to defend the culture against legalized gay marriage, not hiding in their pews,” he said.

column3: Public wants Constitution to decide same-sex marriage, not states
column4: Most voters say same-sex marriage should be decided by the U.S. Constitution, even as many pols have suggested that individual states should determine whether it ought to be legal.

column3: Public wants Constitution to decide same-sex marriage, not states
column4: In a new Quinnipiac University survey released Thursday, 56 percent said that same-sex marriage should be decided for all states on the basis of the Constitution.

column3: Public wants Constitution to decide same-sex marriage, not states
column4: Just 36 percent said states should make the call.

column3: Public wants Constitution to decide same-sex marriage, not states
column4: The survey’s findings reflect the data in a March Washington Post-ABC News poll.

column3: Public wants Constitution to decide same-sex marriage, not states
column4: Fully 64 percent of Americans and 62 percent of registered voters said the legality of same-sex marriage should be decided by the Constitution.

column3: Public wants Constitution to decide same-sex marriage, not states
column4: In the Quinnipiac poll, nearly seven in 10 Democrats support a constitutional decision.

column3: Public wants Constitution to decide same-sex marriage, not states
column4: Republicans are more divided, with 49 percent siding with the states and 45 percent preferring a constitutional mandate.

column3: Public wants Constitution to decide same-sex marriage, not states
column4: The Post-ABC poll also shows stronger support among Democrats for a federal directive, though a majority of Republicans (54 percent) also said they prefer a constitutional decision.

column3: Public wants Constitution to decide same-sex marriage, not states
column4: A constitutional preference doesn't necessarily mean someone is in favor of gay marriage, it’s important to note.

column3: Public wants Constitution to decide same-sex marriage, not states
column4: The Republican Party's platform calls for a constitutional amendment defining marriage as between a man and a woman, for example.

column3: Public wants Constitution to decide same-sex marriage, not states
column4: Despite the public’s preference for a federal decision, lawmakers in both parties continue to say that the issue should be decided by the states.

column3: Public wants Constitution to decide same-sex marriage, not states
column4: “Senator Heitkamp believes this should be decided on a state-by-state basis,” said a spokesperson for Democratic Sen. Heidi Heitkamp of North Dakota, one of only seven Senate Democrats who have not come out in support same-sex marriage.

column3: Public wants Constitution to decide same-sex marriage, not states
column4: "According to the U.S. Constitution, marriage and family law are reserved for the states," said Sen. Mary Landrieu (D-La.

column3: Public wants Constitution to decide same-sex marriage, not states
column4: ), another red state Democratic senator who hasn’t come out in favor of gay marriage.

column3: Public wants Constitution to decide same-sex marriage, not states
column4: Sen. Marco Rubio (R-Fla.) also believes states have the right to define marriage.

column3: Public wants Constitution to decide same-sex marriage, not states
column4: “Just because I believe states should have the right to define marriage in a traditional way does not make me a bigot,” he said in a speech last month.

column3: Public wants Constitution to decide same-sex marriage, not states
column4: While they are at odds with most voters, it’s not a total surprise that these and other pols continue to adopt a “let the states decide” posture.

column3: Public wants Constitution to decide same-sex marriage, not states
column4: Conservative rhetoric – especially coming from those outside of Washington – often involves a federalist argument that resonates heavily with with the political right.

column3: Public wants Constitution to decide same-sex marriage, not states
column4: If you're a Democrat in red state, it's politically perilous to part ways with conservatives, if you're hoping to win the crossover votes necessary for political survival.

column3: Public wants Constitution to decide same-sex marriage, not states
column4: What’s more, at a time when Washington is unpopular, it’s easier to rail against the federal government infringing on local territory on just about every issue.

column3: Public wants Constitution to decide same-sex marriage, not states
column4: Same-sex marriage has proven to be no exception.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: Republicans know that demographic realities leave them no choice but to embrace some sort of immigration reform.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: But the GOP base — egged along by leading conservative media figures — strongly opposes a path to citizenship for the nation’s undocumented immigrants.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: So many GOP officials have embraced reform as a general goal while stopping short of citizenship, essentially supporting a kind of second class legal status.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: The question is: Who does that position end up pleasing?

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: A new Quinnipiac poll out today offers an answer: Almost nobody.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: It finds that 59 percent of Americans support a path to citizenship, while 25 percent support deportation.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: The third option — staying without citizenship — is supported by only 11 percent.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: Among Republicans those numbers are even more interesting.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: It finds that a plurality of 47 percent supports citizenship, while 36 support deportation.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: Only 10 percent of Republicans support the staying-without-citizenship option — the very position that is designed to get them to accept reform.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: How can it be that more Republicans support citizenship than deportation?

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: A lot of this has to do with question wording.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: Yesterday’s Washington Post poll, for example, found that Republicans oppose citizenship by 60-35.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: But the Post poll only surveyed directly on citizenship, and didn’t offer the range of options that includes citizenship, staying without citizenship, and deportation.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: When that is offered, as the Quinnipiac poll did, the anti-citizenship camp of Republicans is split.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: This tells us something very important about the immigration debate.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: When all three positions are polled — and, in truth, the three options do represent the actual policy choice at the heart of the debate — the concocted “middle ground” position preferred by many GOP officials doesn’t really make anybody happy.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: It doesn’t even make Republicans happy.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: Only 10 percent of them support it.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: The problem is that Republicans know that they must be seen embracing some sort of immigration reform.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: Yet the base’s opposition to reform is such that not even the proposal to keep undocumented immigrants in a kind of sub-citizenship legal category is enough to get them to support it.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: And so, ultimately, Republicans are going to have to decide: Who is calling the shots here, the sizable chunk of Republican voters who do support citizenship, or the hard core anti-immigration reform-at-all-costs base?

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: Second class citizenship is not the answer to the GOP dilemma here.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: Ultimately, Republicans either must bravely cross the path-to-citizenship Rubicon and accept the consequences from the right, or we’re not getting reform.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: Another “gun rights” talking point crashes and burns: Glenn Kessler takes apart Lindsey Graham’s claim that out of thousands of people stopped from getting background checks, none were prosecuted.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: The larger point here, as Kessler demonstrates, is that the “gun rights” crowd is basing one of their chief arguments — that we need better enforcement of current laws, but no expansion — on cherry-picked data.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: Beyond this, it’s worth noting that the purpose of background checks is to stop transfers of guns to prohibited people, and each time that happens, it has succeeded.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: Overwhelming support for expanded background checks: Also from the new Quinnipiac poll: 91 percent of Americans, including 88 percent of Republicans and 88 percent of people from gun-owning households, support “requiring background checks for all gun buyers.” We keep hearing that public sentiment for action on guns has “waned,” but this poll finds that 53 percent support “stricter gun laws,” up one point from February.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: What’s more, support for the actual proposals has not “waned,” which should mean something.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: Public thinks marriage should be decided by Constitution: Also from the Quinnipiac poll, this is striking: Do you think each state should make its own law on whether same-sex marriage is legal or illegal there, or do you think this should be decided for all states on the basis of the U.S. Constitution?

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: State laws: 36 Constitution: 56 With the Supreme Court mulling a ruling on gay marriage cases that could have Constitutional implications, this suggests the public wants this settled already.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: Virtually all voter groups — Latinos, Independents, young voters — oppose having the states decide marriage rights, but Republicans support that by, 49-45, underscoring their isolation on the issue.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: The next battle in the immigration wars: Keep an eye on this one: A coalition of labor and faith leaders are joining to oppose any measure in the emerging immigration reform deal that would make it tougher for family members of citizens to join them in the United States.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: Republicans want this because it would lead to more skilled workers coming.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: What’s interesting here is that this could put Republicans at odds with the faith community.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: Gun control moves forward in Maryland and Connecticut: The Maryland House of Delegates has just passed one of the most sweeping gun control packages in the country, including universal background checks and required finger-printing of gun buyers.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: Gun control advocates are having success on the state level (also see Connecticut, where another sweeping law will be signed today) that’s eluding them in today’s Congress.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: Also, this is a reminder that the 2016 Dem presidential contenders are all scrambling to put their stamp on the gun issue (such as Maryland Governor Martin O’Malley), which is rising in importance to Dem voters.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: However, “gun rights” state laws are also on the march: A sobering point from the Wall Street Journal: This year, five states have passed seven laws that strengthen gun restrictions, while 10 states have passed 17 laws that weaken them.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: This isn’t to say that the gun control victories in Maryland and Connecticut aren’t significant; they are.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: But the relentless focus of the “gun rights” brigade on state legislatures is another reminder why we need federal gun law reform.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: The gun battle in Congress isn’t over yet: E.J.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: Dionne makes the case that rumors of the demise of expanded background checks are very much exaggerated.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: He sees hope in the Senate: Based on what they have said, a host of GOP senators just might find the daring to tell their party that gutting a background-check bill is foolish, substantively and politically.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: Their ranks include John McCain, who has been brave on this issue in the past, as well as Pat Toomey, Susan Collins, Lisa Murkowski, Jeff Flake, Mike Johanns, Dean Heller, Johnny Isakson, Saxby Chambliss, Lamar Alexander, Bob Corker and Rob Portman.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: They hold the key.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: It does look bleak.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: But the hope remains that if enough GOP Senators come on board (Dems will probably have to jettison record keeping to make that happened) it could conceivably force a vote in the House.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: And Senate GOPers once supported background checks: Indeed, Alex Seitz-Wald reminds us of an episode that in theory should be relevant today: A number of Senate Republicans voted to close the private seller loophole back in 1999, amid public outcry after the Columbine shooting.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: However, House Republicans killed it by dragging things out procedurally until public sentiment dissipated, a time tested “gun rights” tactic.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: I’d add, though, that a number of House Republicans did vote for the measure, even if it failed — meaning it’s not completely inconceivable that it could pass this time.

column3: The Morning Plum: The GOP dilemma on immigration
column4: What else?

column3: Connecticut lawmakers approve wide-ranging gun control law
column4: HARTFORD, Conn. –  Gov.

column3: Connecticut lawmakers approve wide-ranging gun control law
column4: Dannel P. Malloy, who four months ago broke the news to shocked parents that their children had been slaughtered in a Connecticut elementary school, signed into law Thursday sweeping new restrictions on weapons and large capacity ammunition magazines similar to the ones used by the man who gunned down 20 child and six educators in the massacre.

column3: Connecticut lawmakers approve wide-ranging gun control law
column4: Alongside family members of some of the victims of the shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School, Malloy signed the bill hours after the General Assembly approved the measure to give the state some of the toughest gun laws in the country.

column3: Connecticut lawmakers approve wide-ranging gun control law
column4: "This is a profoundly emotional day for everyone in this room," Malloy said.

column3: Connecticut lawmakers approve wide-ranging gun control law
column4: "We have come together in a way that few places in the nation have demonstrated the ability to do."

column3: Connecticut lawmakers approve wide-ranging gun control law
column4: In the hours after the shooting Dec. 14, as anxious family members gathered inside a firehouse and waited for news, Malloy told them their loved ones were not coming home.

column3: Connecticut lawmakers approve wide-ranging gun control law
column4: He said later that he didn't think it was right for the families to wait for the victims to be formally identified.

column3: Connecticut lawmakers approve wide-ranging gun control law
column4: Now, Connecticut joins states including California, New York, New Jersey and Massachusetts in having the country's strongest gun control laws, said Brian Malte, director of mobilization for the Brady Campaign to Prevent Gun Violence in Washington.

column3: Connecticut lawmakers approve wide-ranging gun control law
column4: "This would put Connecticut right at the top or near the top of the states with the strongest gun laws," Malte said.

column3: Connecticut lawmakers approve wide-ranging gun control law
column4: The legislation adds more than 100 firearms to the state's assault weapons ban and creates what officials have called the nation's first dangerous weapon offender registry as well as eligibility rules for buying ammunition.

column3: Connecticut lawmakers approve wide-ranging gun control law
column4: Some parts of the bill would take effect immediately after Malloy's signature, including background checks for all firearms sales.

column3: Connecticut lawmakers approve wide-ranging gun control law
column4: Following a total of more than 13 hours of respectful and at times somber debate, the House of Representatives and the Senate voted in favor of the 139-page bill crafted by leaders from both major parties in the Democratic-controlled General Assembly.

column3: Connecticut lawmakers approve wide-ranging gun control law
column4: Both were bipartisan votes.

column3: Connecticut lawmakers approve wide-ranging gun control law
column4: "I pray today's bill -- the most far-reaching gun safety legislation in the country -- will prevent other families from ever experiencing the dreadful loss that the 26 Sandy Hook families have felt," said House Majority Leader Joe Aresimowicz.

column3: Connecticut lawmakers approve wide-ranging gun control law
column4: Colorado and New York also passed new gun control requirements in the wake of the Newtown shooting, in which a 20-year-old gunman used a military-style semi-automatic rifle.

column3: Connecticut lawmakers approve wide-ranging gun control law
column4: Compared with Connecticut's legislation, which, for example, bans the sale or purchase of ammunition magazines holding more than 10 rounds, New York restricted magazines to seven bullets and gave owners of higher-capacity magazines a year to sell them elsewhere.

column3: Connecticut lawmakers approve wide-ranging gun control law

column3: Connecticut lawmakers approve wide-ranging gun control law

column4: Rep. Mitch Bolinsky, a freshman Republican lawmaker from Newtown, acknowledged the legislation "is not perfect" and he hoped would be "a beginning in addressing critical mental health needs."

column3: Connecticut lawmakers approve wide-ranging gun control law

column3: Connecticut lawmakers approve wide-ranging gun control law
column4: "I stand here as their voice, as their elected representative," he said, reciting the names of the 26 victims.

column3: Connecticut lawmakers approve wide-ranging gun control law
column4: Lawmakers appeared to still be stunned by the enormity of the massacre.

column3: Connecticut lawmakers approve wide-ranging gun control law
column4: "When a child is sent to school, their parents expect them to be safe.

column3: Connecticut lawmakers approve wide-ranging gun control law
column4: The Sandy Hook shooting rampage was a parent's, a school system's, a community's and the nation's worst nightmare," said Republican state Sen. Toni Boucher of Wilton.

column3: Connecticut lawmakers approve wide-ranging gun control law

column3: Connecticut lawmakers approve wide-ranging gun control law
column4: "What they're proposing will not stop anything."

column3: Connecticut lawmakers approve wide-ranging gun control law
column4: By the time the Senate voted around 6:30 p.m., many of the gun rights advocates had gone home, leaving behind proponents of the bill who applauded when the tally in the Senate was read.

column3: Connecticut lawmakers approve wide-ranging gun control law

column3: Connecticut lawmakers approve wide-ranging gun control law

column4: "We did our job.

column3: Connecticut Passes Nation's Strictest Gun Control Law
column4: WASHINGTON -- Both houses of the Connecticut legislature passed some of the strictest gun control laws in the nation Wednesday night and early Thursday morning, approximately 100 days after 26 students and educators were shot and killed at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown.

column3: Connecticut Passes Nation's Strictest Gun Control Law
column4: In a dramatic marathon legislative session that lasted well into the wee hours of Thursday morning, the state House of Representatives debated and passed gun control legislation by a bipartisan vote of 105 to 44.

column3: Connecticut Passes Nation's Strictest Gun Control Law
column4: A parallel bill was approved by the state Senate earlier Wednesday on a bipartisan 26-10 vote.

column3: Connecticut Passes Nation's Strictest Gun Control Law
column4: Following the House vote, the Senate and House versions of the bill will be reconciled, after which Connecticut Gov.

column3: Connecticut Passes Nation's Strictest Gun Control Law
column4: Dannel Malloy (D) has indicated his intent to sign the legislation as soon as possible.

column3: Connecticut Passes Nation's Strictest Gun Control Law
column4: In passing the sweeping set of laws, Connecticut joins Colorado, New York and Maryland, the three states that have passed major gun control legislation in the wake of the Sandy Hook tragedy.

column3: Connecticut Passes Nation's Strictest Gun Control Law
column4: A Maryland bill that includes fingerprinting gun buyers passed its House of Delegates on Wednesday.

column3: Connecticut Passes Nation's Strictest Gun Control Law
column4: But no state embodies the high costs and conflicting forces in America's gun debate more than Connecticut, home to some of the country's best-known gun manufacturers stretching back more than a century.

column3: Connecticut Passes Nation's Strictest Gun Control Law
column4: It also now grapples with a new distinction: It is home to Sandy Hook Elementary School, an international symbol of the mass shootings that occur too frequently in the United States.

column3: Connecticut Passes Nation's Strictest Gun Control Law
column4: Investigators in Newtown believe that Adam Lanza fired more than 155 bullets in under five minutes using a military-style assault rifle loaded with high capacity magazines.

column3: Connecticut Passes Nation's Strictest Gun Control Law
column4: The Connecticut legislation bans the sale of gun magazines with a capacity of more than 10 rounds and requires background checks for private gun sales, including those at gun shows.

column3: Connecticut Passes Nation's Strictest Gun Control Law
column4: It also expands the state's current assault weapons ban to include more than 100 gun models.

column3: Connecticut Passes Nation's Strictest Gun Control Law
column4: Additionally, the Connecticut bill allocates $15 million for expanded school safety and mental health programs, and includes new eligibility requirements for ammunition sales.

column3: Connecticut Passes Nation's Strictest Gun Control Law
column4: It also has a provision to create the nation's first registry of dangerous offenders, which will be accessible only to law enforcement officers.

column3: Connecticut Passes Nation's Strictest Gun Control Law
column4: The newly approved measures mark the culmination of a three-month process that began shortly after the Dec. 14 massacre, when a task force of legislators set out to determine ways to prevent future mass school shootings.

column3: Connecticut Passes Nation's Strictest Gun Control Law
column4: "Nobody will be able to say that this bill is absolutely perfect, but no one will also be able to say that this bill fails the test when it comes to being the strongest in the country and the most comprehensive bill in the country," Democratic state Senate President Don Williams, a member of the task force, told reporters on Wednesday.

column3: Connecticut Passes Nation's Strictest Gun Control Law
column4: Gun rights advocates protested the legislation on the grounds of the state Capitol Wednesday, waving signs that said, “N.R.A.

column3: Connecticut Passes Nation's Strictest Gun Control Law
column4: Stand and Fight” and “Connecticut the Un-Constitution State."

column3: Connecticut Passes Nation's Strictest Gun Control Law
column4: Protesters also occasionally shouted "No, no, no."

column3: Connecticut Passes Nation's Strictest Gun Control Law
column4: One gun rights advocate, Ron Pariseau, said the laws being proposed "will not stop anything," and he encouraged the legislature to "write laws that are sensible," instead of the ones being proposed.

column3: Connecticut Passes Nation's Strictest Gun Control Law
column4: But news of the law's passage was greeted with applause by gun control advocates like Dan Gross, president of the Brady Campaign to Prevent Gun Violence.

column3: Connecticut Passes Nation's Strictest Gun Control Law
column4: "The bills passed today will save lives, plain and simple," Gross said.

column3: Connecticut Passes Nation's Strictest Gun Control Law
column4: "The leaders in Connecticut are taking action because it is the right thing to do, but also because for them, Newtown didn’t just happen in some far off town ...

column3: Connecticut Passes Nation's Strictest Gun Control Law
column4: It was their friends and neighbors."

column3: Connecticut Passes Nation's Strictest Gun Control Law
column4: Gross also said he hoped Congress was watching the deliberations in Connecticut.

column3: Connecticut Passes Nation's Strictest Gun Control Law
column4: President Barack Obama plans to visit Connecticut Monday, part of his nationwide push to advance gun control legislation currently being considered by the U.S. Senate.

column3: Connecticut Passes Nation's Strictest Gun Control Law
column4: On Wednesday, he visited Denver, where he told an audience of law enforcement officers that his administration "will not just wait for the next Newtown" before passing stricter gun control laws.

column3: Connecticut Passes Nation's Strictest Gun Control Law
column4: In Washington, debate on gun control proposals is set to begin next week, when senators return from the Easter recess.

column3: Connecticut Passes Nation's Strictest Gun Control Law
column4: Republicans, including Kentucky Sen. Rand Paul and Florida Sen. Marco Rubio, have pledged to filibuster to block any gun control legislation from a Senate vote, setting the stage for what is likely to be a pitched with Senate Democrats.

column3: Connecticut Passes Nation's Strictest Gun Control Law
column4: Previously introduced provisions to ban high-capacity gun magazines and assault weapons appeared to have little bipartisan support in the Senate, largely due to vocal opposition led by the National Rifle Association.

column3: Connecticut Passes Nation's Strictest Gun Control Law
column4: Senate Democrats and the White House have zeroed in on expanded background checks and tougher penalties for gun trafficking, the two measures most likely to become federal law.

column3: Obama sequesters own salary, plans to give back 5 percent of pay
column4: President Obama will give back 5 percent of his salary to the U.S. Treasury in a show of solidarity with federal workers facing furloughs due to “sequester” budget cuts, the White House said Wednesday.

column3: Obama sequesters own salary, plans to give back 5 percent of pay
column4: The president’s salary is set by law at $400,000 a year, and he will give back about $20,000 this year.

column3: Obama sequesters own salary, plans to give back 5 percent of pay
column4: Mr. Obama will write a check to the Treasury Department each month, beginning this month.

column3: Obama sequesters own salary, plans to give back 5 percent of pay
column4: The 5 percent cut is the same percentage that non-defense federal agencies were trimmed when the sequester began March 1.

column3: Obama sequesters own salary, plans to give back 5 percent of pay
column4: The White House has said it will furlough nearly 500 employees in the Office of Management and Budget, but it has not outlined any budget cutbacks in the West Wing among the president’s top staff.

column3: Obama sequesters own salary, plans to give back 5 percent of pay
column4: Mr. Obama’s total income according in 2011 was $789,674, according to his tax returns.

column3: Obama sequesters own salary, plans to give back 5 percent of pay
column4: It included his investments and book sales.

column3: North Korea blocks South Koreans from entering jointly-run industrial park
column4: PAJU, South Korea –  North Korea on Wednesday barred South Korean workers from entering a jointly run factory park just over the heavily armed border in the North in the latest sign that Pyongyang's warlike stance toward South Korea and the United States is moving from words to action.

column3: North Korea blocks South Koreans from entering jointly-run industrial park
column4: The Kaesong move came a day after the North announced it would restart its long-shuttered plutonium reactor and a uranium enrichment plant, both of which could produce fuel for nuclear weapons that Pyongyang is developing and has threatened to hurl at the U.S. but which experts don't think it will be able to accomplish for years.

column3: North Korea blocks South Koreans from entering jointly-run industrial park
column4: The North's rising rhetoric over recent weeks has been met by a display of U.S. military strength, including flights of nuclear-capable bombers and stealth jets at the annual South Korean-U.S. military drills that the allies call routine but that North Korea claims are invasion preparations.

column3: North Korea blocks South Koreans from entering jointly-run industrial park
column4: The Kaesong industrial park started producing goods in 2004 and has been an unusual point of cooperation in an otherwise hostile relationship between the Koreas, whose three-year war ended in 1953 with an armistice.

column3: North Korea blocks South Koreans from entering jointly-run industrial park
column4: Its continued operation even through past episodes of high tension has reassured foreign multinationals that another Korean War is unlikely and their investments in prosperous dynamic South Korea are safe.

column3: North Korea blocks South Koreans from entering jointly-run industrial park
column4: "The Kaesong factory park has been the last stronghold of detente between the Koreas," said Hong Soon-jik, a North Korea researcher at the Seoul-based Hyundai Research Institute.

column3: North Korea blocks South Koreans from entering jointly-run industrial park
column4: He said tension between the Koreas could escalate further over Kaesong because Seoul may react with its own punitive response and Pyongyang will then hit back with another move.

column3: North Korea blocks South Koreans from entering jointly-run industrial park
column4: It is unclear how long North Korea will prevent South Koreans from entering the industrial park, which is located in the North Korean border city of Kaesong and provides jobs for more than 50,000 North Koreans.

column3: North Korea blocks South Koreans from entering jointly-run industrial park
column4: The last major disruption at the park amid tensions over U.S.-South Korean military drills in 2009 lasted just three days.

column3: North Korea blocks South Koreans from entering jointly-run industrial park
column4: Seoul's Unification Ministry spokesman Kim Hyung-suk said Pyongyang was allowing South Koreans to return home from Kaesong.

column3: North Korea blocks South Koreans from entering jointly-run industrial park
column4: Some 33 workers of about 860 South Koreans at Kaesong returned Wednesday.

column3: North Korea blocks South Koreans from entering jointly-run industrial park
column4: But Kim said about 480 South Koreans who had planned to travel to the park Wednesday were being refused entry.

column3: North Korea blocks South Koreans from entering jointly-run industrial park
column4: Trucks streamed back into South Korea through its Paju border checkpoint in the morning, just minutes after heading through it, after being refused entry into the North.

column3: North Korea blocks South Koreans from entering jointly-run industrial park
column4: Pyongyang threatened last week to shut down the park, which is run with North Korean labor and South Korean know-how.

column3: North Korea blocks South Koreans from entering jointly-run industrial park
column4: It expressed anger over South Korean media reports that said North Korea hadn't yet shut the park because it is a source of crucial hard currency for the impoverished country.

column3: North Korea blocks South Koreans from entering jointly-run industrial park
column4: About 120 South Korean companies operate factories in Kaesong which produced $470 million of goods such as clocks, clothing and shoes last year that are trucked back to the South for export to other countries.

column3: North Korea blocks South Koreans from entering jointly-run industrial park
column4: The industrial park is crucial for the small businesses that operate there to take advantage of North Korea's low wages but not important for the South Korean economy overall.

column3: North Korea blocks South Koreans from entering jointly-run industrial park
column4: It has more significance to cash-strapped North Korea since, according to the South Korean government, wages for North Korean workers totaled some $81 million last year.

column3: North Korea blocks South Koreans from entering jointly-run industrial park
column4: That has underlined the risks that North Korea's brinkmanship will result in a miscalculation that results in an even more dangerous polarization of the Korean peninsula.

column3: North Korea blocks South Koreans from entering jointly-run industrial park
column4: Barring entry to South Koreas is a "slap in the face" after the South Korean government recently extended medical aid to the North, said Lee Choon-kun, a North Korea researcher at the Korea Economic Research Institute, a Seoul-based think tank.

column3: North Korea blocks South Koreans from entering jointly-run industrial park
column4: "I see this as a start for more provocative actions," he said.

column3: North Korea blocks South Koreans from entering jointly-run industrial park
column4: "The North has made too many threats not to stop short of any real action."

column3: North Korea blocks South Koreans from entering jointly-run industrial park
column4: Kaesong, initially conceived as a test case for reunification and reconciliation, also provides an irksome reminder for Pyongyang that what it lacks, the South has in abundance — material prosperity.

column3: North Korea blocks South Koreans from entering jointly-run industrial park
column4: An enormous gap emerged between the two Koreas in the decades after the Korean War as the South embraced a form of state-directed capitalism while the North adhered to communist central planning.

column3: North Korea blocks South Koreans from entering jointly-run industrial park
column4: Every morning, North Korean workers commute to the complex on the edge of Kaesong on South Korean-made Hyundai buses.

column3: North Korea blocks South Koreans from entering jointly-run industrial park
column4: Once inside the gates of the complex, it's a world apart.

column3: North Korea blocks South Koreans from entering jointly-run industrial park
column4: The paved streets and sidewalks are marked with South Korean traffic signals and signs and the parking lots are filled with the Hyundai, Samsung and KIA cars driven by South Korean managers.

column3: North Korea blocks South Koreans from entering jointly-run industrial park
column4: Inside several factories visited by The Associated Press last year, the posters on the walls are not party slogans but safety warnings.

column3: North Korea blocks South Koreans from entering jointly-run industrial park
column4: "Beware of fires," read one; "Wash your hands" read another.

column3: North Korea blocks South Koreans from entering jointly-run industrial park
column4: While most factories in North Korea are drafty, and few have running water, the facilities in Kaesong are equipped with hot water, flush toilets and air conditioners.

column3: North Korea blocks South Koreans from entering jointly-run industrial park

column3: North Korea blocks South Koreans from entering jointly-run industrial park
column4: But inside Kaesong, North Korean workers work side by side with South Korean managers, discussing orders and mapping out production.

column3: North Korea blocks South Koreans from entering jointly-run industrial park
column4: However, they tend not to socialize with one another.

column3: North Korea blocks South Koreans from entering jointly-run industrial park
column4: At most factories, North Korean workers take their meals in cafeterias that serve basic stews and rice while the South Koreans dine separately.

column3: North Korea blocks South Koreans from entering jointly-run industrial park
column4: Park Yun-kyu, who heads a men's apparel maker that employs 700 North Korean workers in Kaesong, said he was worried he couldn't send fresh food to his eight South Korean workers in Kaesong.

column3: North Korea blocks South Koreans from entering jointly-run industrial park
column4: "The problem is food.

column3: North Korea blocks South Koreans from entering jointly-run industrial park
column4: I hope North Korea would at least let us send food.

column3: North Korea blocks South Koreans from entering jointly-run industrial park
column4: We have to send food and some materials for production every day."

column3: North Korea blocks South Koreans from entering jointly-run industrial park
column4: On Tuesday, a senior South Korean government official said Seoul has a contingency plan for its citizens in Kaesong.

column3: North Korea blocks South Koreans from entering jointly-run industrial park
column4: But he said the government hoped the tension would not lead to a shutdown of the complex.

column3: North Korea blocks South Koreans from entering jointly-run industrial park
column4: He spoke on condition of anonymity, saying he was not authorized to speak publicly to the media.

column4: SEOUL, South Korea — The United States announced Wednesday that it was speeding the deployment of an advanced missile defense system to Guam in the next few weeks, two years ahead of schedule in what the Pentagon said was “a precautionary move” to protect American naval and air forces from the threat of a North Korean missile attack.

column4: The North had threatened the move in reaction to taunts from the South Korean news media that the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, had cut hot lines and other communications across the border, but did not want to risk one of his most precious sources of hard currency.

column3: North Korea Blocks Workers From South at the Border

Rumsfeld, ordered the Army to prepare to intercept a long-range Taepodong missile from its antiballistic missile base in Alaska during a North Korean test.

column3: NRA School Safety Report Suggests, Yup, More Guns
column4: WASHINGTON -- Former Rep. Asa Hutchinson (R-Ark.)

column3: NRA School Safety Report Suggests, Yup, More Guns
column4: on Tuesday released a 225-page report on school safety funded by the National Rifle Association.

column3: NRA School Safety Report Suggests, Yup, More Guns
column4: The report, commissioned in the wake of the Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting, recommended properly trained armed employees to provide "an important layer of security in schools."

column3: NRA School Safety Report Suggests, Yup, More Guns
column4: The report was prepared by a 12-person task force, called the School Shield Program, led by Hutchinson.

column3: NRA School Safety Report Suggests, Yup, More Guns
column4: At Tuesday's press conference, he stated that its findings were independent of the nation's largest gun lobby.

column3: NRA School Safety Report Suggests, Yup, More Guns
column4: "Teachers should teach, but if there is personnel that has interest and is willing to go through 40 to 60 hours of [firearms] training, then schools should be willing to [arm them]," Hutchinson said.

column3: NRA School Safety Report Suggests, Yup, More Guns
column4: He added that the report found that "local school authorities are in the best position" to determine their own school security measures, "specifically whether an armed security guard is necessary and supported by the education and citizen community."

column3: NRA School Safety Report Suggests, Yup, More Guns
column4: The task force recommended that schools designate willing staff to be armed and trained, and it proposed a model training program, 40-60 hours per person, at what Hutchinson said would be a cost of about $800 to $1,000 per trained employee.

column3: NRA School Safety Report Suggests, Yup, More Guns
column4: Armed school personnel, called school resource officers, would also be required to undergo a "background investigation, testing, and [have] relevant experience."

column3: NRA School Safety Report Suggests, Yup, More Guns
column4: The committee didn't recommend any specific kind of firearm for school security, Hutchinson said, adding, "Everything from a sidearm, to a shotgun, to an AR-15" would work.

column3: NRA School Safety Report Suggests, Yup, More Guns
column4: The task force also suggested that states loosen current legal restrictions on who can carry a firearm on school property.

column3: NRA School Safety Report Suggests, Yup, More Guns
column4: Many states currently prohibit anyone but a law enforcement officer from possessing guns in a school.

column3: NRA School Safety Report Suggests, Yup, More Guns
column4: Other recommendations included creating threat assessment teams at schools, better coordinating state and federal funding for school security, and offering an online assessment tool, so that administrators can evaluate their schools' potential security gaps.

column3: NRA School Safety Report Suggests, Yup, More Guns
column4: Hutchinson's report and his press conference were both met with scathing criticism from the American Federation of Teachers, which supports broader gun control measures and strongly opposes arming educators.

column3: NRA School Safety Report Suggests, Yup, More Guns
column4: In a statement, union President Randi Weingarten called the report "a cruel hoax that will fail to keep our children and schools safe," adding that the findings "are simply designed to assist gun manufacturers flood the nation and our schools with more guns."

column3: NRA School Safety Report Suggests, Yup, More Guns
column4: The NRA also put out a statement on the report, over which the gun lobby insists it had no influence.

column3: NRA School Safety Report Suggests, Yup, More Guns
column4: The NRA said it needs "time to digest" the findings, but it commended Hutchinson and his team for contributions that "will go a long way to making America's schools safer."

column3: NRA School Safety Report Suggests, Yup, More Guns
column4: The report marks the culmination of a controversial process that began in December, when NRA CEO Wayne LaPierre held a press conference the week after the shooting in Newtown, Conn. At the time, LaPierre assailed the media and gun control advocates for their responses to the massacre, and he proposed that armed volunteers protect schools and that gun-free school zones be eliminated.

column3: NRA School Safety Report Suggests, Yup, More Guns
column4: The speech was widely considered a public relations disaster.

column3: NRA School Safety Report Suggests, Yup, More Guns
column4: Hutchinson said Tuesday that the idea of armed volunteers was scrapped after it was met with "great reluctance" from school employees.

column3: NRA School Safety Report Suggests, Yup, More Guns
column4: But the recommendation that states allow non-law enforcement officers, such as teachers and principals, to carry guns in schools would essentially eliminate gun-free school zones.

column3: NRA School Safety Report Suggests, Yup, More Guns
column4: Asked about the current debate in Congress over gun control legislation, Hutchinson said he had "not dealt with the separate debate" because he had been too busy considering school safety issues.

column3: NRA School Safety Report Suggests, Yup, More Guns
column4: He did, however, weigh in on state gun control efforts currently being debated in Connecticut, which include a ban on high-capacity magazines and a broader assault weapons ban.

column3: NRA School Safety Report Suggests, Yup, More Guns
column4: Hutchinson called them "totally inadequate."

column3: NRA School Safety Report Suggests, Yup, More Guns
column4: "You can address assault weapons, but it doesn't stop violence in schools.

column3: NRA School Safety Report Suggests, Yup, More Guns
column4: So if you're going to protect children, you have to do something about enhancing school safety," he said.

column3: NRA School Safety Report Suggests, Yup, More Guns
column4: Hutchinson also encouraged the NRA to continue funding pilot programs to train school employees to carry weapons.

column3: NRA School Safety Report Suggests, Yup, More Guns
column4: When he had finished introducing the report, Hutchinson called up Mark Mattioli, whose 6-year-old son, James Mattioli, was killed in December along with 19 other children at Sandy Hook Elementary School.

column3: NRA School Safety Report Suggests, Yup, More Guns
column4: Mattioli praised the NRA "for coming up and spending the time and resources on putting a program like this together."

column3: NRA School Safety Report Suggests, Yup, More Guns
column4: The story has been updated with comment from the American Federation of Teachers and the National Rifle Association.

column3: U.S. Stealth Jets Join South Korea Military Drills
column4: "(North Korea) will achieve nothing by threats or provocations, which will only further isolate North Korea and undermine international efforts to ensure peace and stability in Northeast Asia," the statement said.

column3: Supreme Court justices question DOMA's range, consider effect act has in states

column3: The Indefensible Marriage Act
column4: The discrimination embedded in the Defense of Marriage Act is precise yet sweeping.

column3: The Indefensible Marriage Act
column4: The 1996 statute defines marriage as the union of a man and a woman, and applies that definition to about 1,100 federal laws and programs.

column3: The Indefensible Marriage Act
column4: One of its many discriminatory results is that same-sex couples are prohibited from collecting many federal benefits available to other couples.

column3: The Indefensible Marriage Act
column4: That now includes people legally married in nine states and the District of Columbia, plus 18,000 couples who were legally married in California before 2008 when Proposition 8 banned same-sex marriage there.

column3: The Indefensible Marriage Act
column4: Solicitor General Donald Verrilli Jr., who is known for his reserve, was unhesitating before the Supreme Court on Wednesday when it heard the Defense of Marriage Act case: “I think it’s time for the court to recognize that this discrimination, excluding lawfully married gay and lesbian couples from federal benefits, cannot be reconciled with our fundamental commitment to equal treatment under law.” It appeared that a majority of the justices, including the likely swing vote, Justice Anthony Kennedy, had serious doubts as to whether the law served any legitimate purpose.

column3: The Indefensible Marriage Act
column4: Justice Kennedy, however, seemed primarily interested in questioning the law for the wrong reasons, concerned that the Defense of Marriage Act interferes in the primary right of states to regulate marriage and its benefits.

column3: The Indefensible Marriage Act
column4: Only the four more liberal justices appeared to focus on the reality that what is at stake here is not federalism but fairness.

column3: The Indefensible Marriage Act
column4: States can regulate marriage but they cannot discriminate while doing so, and leaving gay and lesbian couples out of the equation violates the Constitution’s guarantee of equal protection just as much as banning interracial marriage.

column3: The Indefensible Marriage Act
column4: Paul Clement, who was defending the act on behalf of the House of Representatives, said its only purpose was to ensure uniformity in distributing federal marriage benefits.

column3: The Indefensible Marriage Act
column4: But Justice Elena Kagan dismissed that notion, suggesting that Congress’s judgment in passing the act was “infected by dislike, by fear, by animus.” Quoting from the House’s legislative history, she said, “Congress decided to reflect an honor of collective moral judgment and to express moral disapproval of homosexuality.” That clear animus on the part of lawmakers explains why the court must strike down the law on equal-protection grounds, as a federal appeals court did last fall.

column3: The Indefensible Marriage Act
column4: The government needs to have an “exceptionally good” reason to justify treating gay men and lesbians differently, that court ruled, and Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg made a similar point today, saying that the law created “two kinds of marriage: the full marriage and then this sort of skim-milk marriage.” Still, no matter what grounds the court eventually uses to strike down the Defense of Marriage Act, getting rid of it would be a huge step forward in the national movement toward marriage equality.

column3: The Indefensible Marriage Act
column4: Once it is clear that the only thing standing between same-sex couples and federal benefits is an ideological state legislature, the pressure will accelerate on states to do the right thing, particularly in states like Virginia with large numbers of federal employees.

column3: The Indefensible Marriage Act
column4: The Supreme Court now has an opportunity to end the federal role in this discrimination — and to do so with a ringing affirmation of the importance of basic fairness.

column3: Report: Supreme Court '80% Likely' to Strike Defense of Marriage Act
column4: After an indecisive round of oral arguments Tuesday on the question of California’s controversial Proposition 8 gay marriage ban, the Supreme Court signaled today that it may be prepared to hand gay rights advocates a national victory over the course of two hours of oral arguments in the case U.S. vs Windsor.

column3: Report: Supreme Court '80% Likely' to Strike Defense of Marriage Act
column4: That case challenges section 3 of the federal Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA).

column3: Report: Supreme Court '80% Likely' to Strike Defense of Marriage Act
column4: Section 3 of DOMA bans the Federal government from extending marriage benefits to same sex couples, even in cases where an individual state has recognized those couples as married.

column3: Report: Supreme Court '80% Likely' to Strike Defense of Marriage Act
column4: Shortly after oral arguments concluded, the Peabody award winning Supreme Court watching blog SCOTUSblog posted the following Tweets: Final update: #scotus 80% likely to strike down #doma.

column3: Report: Supreme Court '80% Likely' to Strike Defense of Marriage Act
column4: J Kennedy suggests it violates states’ rights; 4 other Justices see as gay rights.

column3: Report: Supreme Court '80% Likely' to Strike Defense of Marriage Act
column4: — SCOTUSblog (@SCOTUSblog) March 27, 2013 @nprpolitics our 80% number accounts for Justice Kennedy not being completely decisive.

column3: Report: Supreme Court '80% Likely' to Strike Defense of Marriage Act
column4: — SCOTUSblog (@SCOTUSblog) March 27, 2013 Subsequently, SCOTUSblog’s main court reporter, Lyle Denniston, posted a longer recap of oral arguments suggesting that section 3o of DOMA had a very weak chance of surviving on the basis of the performance by swing vote Justice Kennedy, albeit for narrower reasons than gay rights advocates might like: Justice Kennedy told Clement that there was “a real risk” that DOMA would interfere with the traditional state authority to regulate marriage.

column3: Report: Supreme Court '80% Likely' to Strike Defense of Marriage Act
column4: Kennedy also seemed troubled about the sweeping breadth of DOMA’s Section 3, noting that its ban on benefits to already married same-sex couples under 1,100 laws and programs would mean that the federal government was “intertwined with citizens’ daily lives.”   He questioned Congress’s very authority to pass such a broad law.

column3: Report: Supreme Court '80% Likely' to Strike Defense of Marriage Act
column4: […] There did not appear to be a majority of Justices willing to strike down the 1996 law based on the argument that the Obama administration and gay rights advocates have been pressing: that is, the law violates the Fifth Amendment guarantee of legal equality in general.

column3: Report: Supreme Court '80% Likely' to Strike Defense of Marriage Act
column4: […] The Court, although it has been dealing with gay rights cases for years, has never spelled out a specific constitutional standard for judging laws that allegedly discriminate based on homosexuality.

column3: Report: Supreme Court '80% Likely' to Strike Defense of Marriage Act
column4: The indications on Wednesday that the DOMA case might be decided without supplying such a standard, since a decision based on interference with states’ prerogatives would not require the creation of a test based on equality principles.

column3: Report: Supreme Court '80% Likely' to Strike Defense of Marriage Act
column4: There was a third lawyer in the case to discuss the constitutional issue, New York attorney Roberta A. Kaplan, representing the New York City woman who had successfully challenged DOMA in this case — Edith Schlain Windsor, an eighty-three-year-old widow of a same-sex marriage, who sat in the second row of the audience to watch the Court deal with her case.

column3: Report: Supreme Court '80% Likely' to Strike Defense of Marriage Act
column4: Kaplan seemingly missed several opportunities, in answering the Justices’ questions, to the apparent consternation of gay rights lawyers in the attorney section.

column3: Report: Supreme Court '80% Likely' to Strike Defense of Marriage Act
column4: Talking Points Memo outlined the case in similarly stark terms for supporters of DOMA, describing the hearing as the law “taking a beating,” and pointing out that even the three Justices that seemed to support it (Chief Justice John Roberts and Justices Antonin Scalia and Samuel Alito) were more preoccupied with arguing over whether the case should be heard than with defending the law.

column3: Report: Supreme Court '80% Likely' to Strike Defense of Marriage Act
column4: Of course, as with any oral argument, it is necessary to note that often the Justices go in completely different direction than the questioning at oral argument indicates, as was the case last year with the Obamacare case HHS v. Florida.

column3: Report: Supreme Court '80% Likely' to Strike Defense of Marriage Act
column4: However, in the event that that happens in this case, it looks likely that the only way it could happen would be if Kennedy decided there was no standing by the court to hear the case, given the irregular appeals process that brought it up.

column3: Report: Supreme Court '80% Likely' to Strike Defense of Marriage Act
column4: A nationwide vindication of DOMA appears dramatically less likely.

column3: California gay marriage argument at high court Tuesday
column4: WASHINGTON (AP) — The Supreme Court dove into a historic debate on gay rights Tuesday that could soon lead to resumption of same-sex marriage in California, but the justices signaled they may not be ready for a major national ruling on whether America's gays and lesbians have a right to marry.

column3: California gay marriage argument at high court Tuesday
column4: The court's first major examination of gay rights in 10 years continues Wednesday, when the justices will consider the federal law that prevents legally married gay couples from receiving a range of benefits afforded straight married people.

column3: California gay marriage argument at high court Tuesday
column4: The issue before the court on Tuesday was more fundamental: Does the Constitution require that people be allowed to marry whom they choose, regardless of either partner's gender?

column3: California gay marriage argument at high court Tuesday
column4: The fact that the question was in front of the Supreme Court at all was startling, given that no state recognized same-sex unions before 2003 and 40 states still don't allow them.

column3: California gay marriage argument at high court Tuesday
column4: There is no questioning the emotions the issue stirs.

column3: California gay marriage argument at high court Tuesday
column4: Demonstrators on both sides crowded the grounds outside the court, waving signs, sometimes chanting their feelings.

column4: Inside, a skeptical Justice Samuel Alito cautioned against a broad ruling in favor of gay marriage precisely because the issue is so new.

column3: California gay marriage argument at high court Tuesday
column4: "You want us to step in and render a decision based on an assessment of the effects of this institution which is newer than cellphones or the Internet?

column3: California gay marriage argument at high court Tuesday
column4: I mean, we do not have the ability to see the future," Alito said.

column4: Indeed, it was clear from the start of the 80-minute argument in a packed courtroom, that the justices, including some liberals who seemed open to gay marriage, had doubts about whether they should even be hearing the challenge to California's Proposition 8, the state's voter-approved gay marriage ban.

column4: Justice Anthony Kennedy, the potentially decisive vote on a closely divided court, suggested the justices could dismiss the case with no ruling at all.

column3: California gay marriage argument at high court Tuesday
column4: Such an outcome would almost certainly allow gay marriages to resume in California but would have no impact elsewhere.
