column4: "Your Honor, even with respect to couples over the age of 55, it is very rare that both parties to the couple are infertile," Cooper said.

column3: California gay marriage argument at high court Tuesday
column4: Kagan cut in: "I can just assure you, if both the woman and the man are over the age of 55, there are not a lot of children coming out of that marriage."

column3: California gay marriage argument at high court Tuesday
column4: At another point, Justice Antonin Scalia, who has dissented in the court's previous gay rights cases, invoked the well-being of children to bolster Cooper's case.

column3: California gay marriage argument at high court Tuesday
column4: "If you redefine marriage to include same-sex couples, you must permit adoption by same-sex couples, and there's considerable disagreement among sociologists as to what the consequences of raising a child in a single-sex family, whether that is harmful to the child or not," Scalia said.

column3: California gay marriage argument at high court Tuesday
column4: The California case was argued 10 years to the day after the court took up a challenge to Texas' anti-sodomy statute.

column3: California gay marriage argument at high court Tuesday
column4: That case ended with a forceful ruling prohibiting states from criminalizing sexual relations between consenting adults.

column3: California gay marriage argument at high court Tuesday
column4: Kennedy was the author of the decision in Lawrence v. Texas in 2003, and he is being closely watched for how he might vote on the California ban.

column3: California gay marriage argument at high court Tuesday
column4: He cautioned in the Lawrence case that it had nothing to do with gay marriage, but dissenting Justice Scalia predicted the decision would lead to the invalidation of state laws against same-sex marriage.

column3: California gay marriage argument at high court Tuesday
column4: Kennedy's decision is widely cited in the briefs in support of same-sex unions.

column3: California gay marriage argument at high court Tuesday
column4: The California couples, Kris Perry and Sandy Stier of Berkeley and Paul Katami and Jeff Zarrillo of Burbank, filed their federal lawsuit in May 2009 to overturn the same-sex marriage ban that voters approved the previous November.

column3: California gay marriage argument at high court Tuesday
column4: The ballot measure halted same-sex unions in California, which began in June 2008 after a ruling from the California Supreme Court.

column3: California gay marriage argument at high court Tuesday
column4: Roughly 18,000 couples were wed in the nearly five months that same-sex marriage was legal and those marriages remain valid in California.

column3: California gay marriage argument at high court Tuesday
column4: The case is Hollingsworth v. Perry, 12-144.

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: A new Washington Post-ABC News poll last week showed support for gay marriage hitting an all-time high at 58 percent, with support having risen by 21 points over the last decade alone.

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: But some social conservatives say polls like this one are wrong, and that they over-sell the actual amount of support for gay marriage.

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: "I'm not worried about it, because the polls are skewed, " Gary Bauer, a leading social conservative and former presidential candidate, said on "Fox News Sunday."

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: "Just this past November, four states, very liberal states, voted on this issue and my side lost all four of those votes.

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: But my side had 45, 46 percent of the vote in all four of those liberal states."

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: Ralph Reed, the former head of the Christian Coalition, made a similar argument on NBC's "Meet the Press."

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: "It's clearly moved, but the idea that the American people are, you know, universally for same-sex marriage is just not backed (up)," Reed said.

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: He added: "They have, after all, voted in 31 state referenda and initiatives for traditional marriage.

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: Only three have they voted the other way.

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: So this thing tests very differently at the ballot box than it does in a poll."

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: So are they right?

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: Are the polls often wrong?

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: In a word, yes -- at least to some degree.

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: Polls on gay marriage ballot initiatives generally under-estimate the opposition to gay marriage by about seven percentage points, according to a 2010 study by New York University political science professor Patrick J. Egan.

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: "The share of voters in pre‐election surveys saying they will vote to ban same‐sex marriage is typically seven percentage points lower than the actual vote on election day," Egan wrote.

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: He also noted, however, that polls are generally accurate when it comes to the percentage of people supporting gay marriage.

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: The chart below, from Egan's study, illustrates this point.

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: Polls measuring opposition to gay marriage (denoted by the white dots) very often come in below the actual opposition to gay marriage on Election Day (denoted by the gray line).

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: The best example of the discrepancy between the polls and the actual vote may be the same gay marriage ban that comes before the Supreme Court this week -- California's Proposition 8.

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: While polling regularly showed more opposition to the ban (i.e.

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: support for gay marriage) than support for it, the measure passed on Election Day 2008 by four points, 52 percent to 48 percent.

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: The trend has continued, even as four states in November became the first in the country to have their citizens vote for gay marriage.

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: In Washington state, polls consistently showed more support for gay marriage than the final seven-point margin.

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: In Maryland, late polling showed support for gay marriage as high as nine or 10 points (including nine in a Washington Post poll) -- and even higher in some early polls -- but it passed by four points.

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: In Maine, late polls showed gay marriage ahead by double digits, but it passed by six points.

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: (The one exception is Minnesota, where the polling was pretty close but no late polls were conducted.

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: Voters overturned a constitutional ban on gay marriage by six points -- though it should be noted that they didn't effectively legalize gay marriage.)

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: There are a couple theories for this discrepancy, setting aside the notion that the pollsters themselves might be biased: 1) Polls under-sell opposition to gay marriage because people don't want to come off as intolerant of gay people, so they hide their true anti-gay marriage beliefs from pollsters.

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: A similar theory has been suggested for polls that over-sell support for black candidates -- something dubbed the "Bradley Effect."

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: A Washington state poll from last year, for example, tried to adjust for this so-called "social desirability" effect.

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: In addition to asking the gay marriage question, it moved undecided conservatives and religious voters into the "no" column, along with those who were uncomfortable with discussion about "sexual minorities."

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: While the first question showed gay marriage favored by a 58-37 margin, the latter adjustments showed the margin at 52-48 -- exactly the margin by which gay marriage passed.

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: Egan, though, argues that social desirability doesn't have much effect.

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: He noted that the amount of poll error remained similar even as support for gay marriage rose over time and was also consistent between states regardless of how many gay people they had -- the idea being that more tolerant places and times would lead to more error if the "Bradley Effect" applied to gay marriage.

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: In addition, until recently, gay marriage didn't have the support of a majority of Americans.

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: So the popular viewpoint was, in fact, against gay marriage, which suggests that would be the more socially desirable position.

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: 2) Opponents of gay marriage feel more strongly than supporters and thus are more apt to vote.

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: The evidence is also mixed on this one.

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: The latest Washington Post-ABC News poll showed 41 percent of Americans strongly support gay marriage, while 30 percent strongly oppose it.

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: In 2010, while gay marriage polled pretty evenly overall, 31 percent strongly favored it, while 42 percent strongly opposed it.

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: In both cases, though, the percentage of supporters who said their view was "strong" was lower than those who opposed gay marriage.

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: While 71 percent of supporters felt strongly in the most recent poll, 83 percent of opponents felt strongly.

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: The split was even wider in 2010, which suggests it could be something of a motivation issue.

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: In the end, both theories are plausible, if not necessarily proven.

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: Reed argued Sunday that several other recent polls have shown a much smaller pro-gay marriage margin than the Post-ABC poll.

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: That's true, as the chart below shows.

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: But it's also clear which way -- and how quickly -- the polls are headed.

column3: Is support for gay marriage over-sold?
column4: And if the current trajectory continues, it's going to simply be a matter of how big the majority of Americans who support gay marriage is, and how quickly it takes effect across the country.

column3: Supreme Court tackles gay marriage, as advocates line up for historic argument
column4: The front-lines of the gay marriage debate move this week to the Supreme Court, as it considers two cases which have the potential to redefine marriage on a national level.

column3: Supreme Court tackles gay marriage, as advocates line up for historic argument
column4: The arguments come at a time of changing views, with support for gay marriage becoming a mainstream Democratic position and the issue causing a sharp divide among Republicans.

column3: Supreme Court tackles gay marriage, as advocates line up for historic argument
column4: The first case the court will take up, on Tuesday, is California's Proposition 8 ban on same-sex marriage.

column3: Supreme Court tackles gay marriage, as advocates line up for historic argument
column4: The court on Wednesday weighs the Defense of Marriage Act, considering a provision that defines marriage as between a man and a woman for the purpose of deciding who can receive a range of federal benefits.

column3: Supreme Court tackles gay marriage, as advocates line up for historic argument
column4: It is the California case, though, that could have sweeping implications for the states.

column3: Supreme Court tackles gay marriage, as advocates line up for historic argument
column4: The judges could, if they choose to rule broadly, overturn every state constitutional provision and law banning same-sex marriages.

column3: Supreme Court tackles gay marriage, as advocates line up for historic argument
column4: Or, they could set back the gay marriage movement by upholding California's ban and continuing to leave the issue up to the states.

column3: Supreme Court tackles gay marriage, as advocates line up for historic argument
column4: Signaling the widespread interest in the rulings, spectators have been lining up all weekend outside the court, camping out in Washington for a chance to hear the arguments.

column3: Supreme Court tackles gay marriage, as advocates line up for historic argument
column4: The issue has created fault lines within the Republican Party, as some prominent members drop their opposition to same-sex marriage while others stiffen it.

column3: Supreme Court tackles gay marriage, as advocates line up for historic argument
column4: Gary Bauer, president of American Values, told "Fox News Sunday" that proponents of gay marriage are effectively asking "for unelected judges to deny the people of the states the right to decide what marriage is in their state."

column3: Supreme Court tackles gay marriage, as advocates line up for historic argument
column4: Bauer said he would prefer that every state bar gay marriage.

column3: Supreme Court tackles gay marriage, as advocates line up for historic argument
column4: But, acknowledging that's not likely, he said the court should let the states decide.

column3: Supreme Court tackles gay marriage, as advocates line up for historic argument
column4: Bauer said people are only changing their minds on the issue "because there's been a full-court blitz ... by the popular culture, by elites and all kinds of folks to intimidate and to cower people into no longer defending marriage between a man and a woman."

column3: Supreme Court tackles gay marriage, as advocates line up for historic argument
column4: But Nicolle Wallace, a former adviser to former President George W. Bush and to the 2008 McCain campaign, said those arguing against Prop 8 are in fact using a "conservative legal argument."

column3: Supreme Court tackles gay marriage, as advocates line up for historic argument
column4: "They will basically lay out the conservative case that there is not any place in the Constitution that allows for a different set of rules for a different class of people," she told "Fox News Sunday."

column3: Supreme Court tackles gay marriage, as advocates line up for historic argument
column4: "There's also a moral imperative here.

column3: Supreme Court tackles gay marriage, as advocates line up for historic argument
column4: If you believe, if you value and treasure and revere the institution of marriage, then you should want every family unit to be really wrapped in marriage."

column3: Supreme Court tackles gay marriage, as advocates line up for historic argument
column4: [summary] Top Democrats who previously opposed same-sex marriage -- and had taken the more moderate position of supporting civil unions -- have in recent months and years shifted course.

column3: Supreme Court tackles gay marriage, as advocates line up for historic argument
column4: President Obama announced his support for gay marriage in the months leading up to the presidential election.

column3: Supreme Court tackles gay marriage, as advocates line up for historic argument
column4: Hillary Clinton also recently followed suit.

column3: Supreme Court tackles gay marriage, as advocates line up for historic argument
column4: But Republicans have also been crossing to the pro-gay marriage side.

column3: Supreme Court tackles gay marriage, as advocates line up for historic argument
column4: Wallace is among dozens of Republicans who filed a brief in the Supreme Court case arguing for Prop 8 to be overturned.

column3: Supreme Court tackles gay marriage, as advocates line up for historic argument
column4: One of the lead lawyers arguing against Prop 8, Ted Olson, also is a prominent conservative who was solicitor general under George W. Bush.

column3: Supreme Court tackles gay marriage, as advocates line up for historic argument
column4: And Sen.

column3: Supreme Court tackles gay marriage, as advocates line up for historic argument
column4: Rob Portman, R-Ohio, publicly reversed his position on the issue after his son came out as gay.

column3: Supreme Court tackles gay marriage, as advocates line up for historic argument
column4: The position shifts, though, do not signal a party-wide change of heart.

column3: Supreme Court tackles gay marriage, as advocates line up for historic argument
column4: Many Republicans would still prefer the issue be left up to the states and are encouraging the high court justices to rule narrowly.

column3: Supreme Court tackles gay marriage, as advocates line up for historic argument
column4: "They would be far better off to decide these two cases on the narrowest possible grounds," former House Speaker Newt Gingrich said Sunday.

column3: Supreme Court tackles gay marriage, as advocates line up for historic argument
column4: A sweeping decision against gay marriage, he said, would be a "huge mistake" that would "undermine respect for the judiciary."

column3: Supreme Court tackles gay marriage, as advocates line up for historic argument
column4: Americans as a whole are likewise divided.

column3: Supreme Court tackles gay marriage, as advocates line up for historic argument
column4: A Fox News poll released Thursday showed 49 percent of voters favor legalizing gay marriage, while 46 percent oppose it.

column3: Supreme Court tackles gay marriage, as advocates line up for historic argument
column4: That marks a shift since the question was first asked in 2003 -- when 32 percent said gay marriage should be legal, and 58 percent opposed it.

column3: Supreme Court tackles gay marriage, as advocates line up for historic argument
column4: Support for gay marriage has grown the most among Democrats, and self-described moderates and independents.

column3: Supreme Court tackles gay marriage, as advocates line up for historic argument
column4: Still, support for gay marriage rose by 10 points among Republicans over the past decade, according to the Fox News polling.

column3: Supreme Court tackles gay marriage, as advocates line up for historic argument
column4: Gay marriage has been approved in nine states -- Connecticut, Iowa, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, New York, Vermont, Washington -- and the District of Columbia.

column3: Supreme Court tackles gay marriage, as advocates line up for historic argument
column4: But 31 states have amended their constitutions to prohibit same-sex marriage.

column3: Supreme Court tackles gay marriage, as advocates line up for historic argument
column4: North Carolina was the most recent example last May.

column3: Supreme Court tackles gay marriage, as advocates line up for historic argument
column4: The case being considered Tuesday concerns the constitutional ban on gay marriage that California voters adopted in 2008.

column3: Supreme Court tackles gay marriage, as advocates line up for historic argument
column4: One key question before the court is whether the Constitution's guarantee of equal protection means that the right to marriage cannot be limited to heterosexuals.

column3: Supreme Court tackles gay marriage, as advocates line up for historic argument
column4: The 9th Circuit Court of Appeals previously struck down Prop 8, without making any sweeping pronouncements.

column3: Supreme Court tackles gay marriage, as advocates line up for historic argument
column4: The larger constitutional issue almost certainly will be presented to the court, but the justices would not necessarily have to rule on it.

column3: Supreme Court tackles gay marriage, as advocates line up for historic argument
column4: The other issue the high court will take on involves the central provision of the Defense of Marriage Act, which defines marriage as between a man and woman.

column3: Supreme Court tackles gay marriage, as advocates line up for historic argument
column4: Four federal district courts and two appeals courts struck down the provision.

column3: Supreme Court tackles gay marriage, as advocates line up for historic argument
column4: Supreme Court rulings are expected in June.

column4: The Associated Press contributed to this report.

column3: Republicans see cash opportunity in gay marriage shift
column4: Updated 03/25/2013 01:56 PM EDT Republican fundraisers say the changing views of gay marriage in their party could unlock big money from GOP donors in places like New York, California and Florida — where some Republicans have kept their checkbooks closed over what they saw as misplaced priorities, at best, or intolerance, at worst, at the highest ranks of the party.

column3: Republicans see cash opportunity in gay marriage shift
column4: Several Republicans pointed to Sen.

column4: Rob Portman’s switch in support of gay marriage as a watershed moment for the party.

column4: And more than two dozen high-profile Republicans asked the Supreme Court to back gay rights.

column4: And even Foster Friess, Rick Santorum’s top benefactor, has softened his stance on domestic partnership.

column3: Republicans see cash opportunity in gay marriage shift
column4: Story Continued Below “Republicans’ intolerance to marriage equality has been detrimental to winning,” said Aaron McLear, a California Republican strategist.

column3: Long-awaited vote on Senate budget exposes cracks among Democrats
column4: Senate Democrats approved their first budget in four years early Saturday morning -- but just barely.

column3: Long-awaited vote on Senate budget exposes cracks among Democrats
column4: The final vote, which was held after the Senate worked well past midnight churning through dozens of amendments, exposed cracks in Democratic unity as lawmakers facing re-election peeled off, citing the proposal's failure to tackle the deficit.

column3: Long-awaited vote on Senate budget exposes cracks among Democrats
column4: In the end, the budget plan squeaked by on a razor-thin 50-49 vote.

column3: Long-awaited vote on Senate budget exposes cracks among Democrats
column4: Four Democrats opposed it, and one did not vote.

column3: Long-awaited vote on Senate budget exposes cracks among Democrats
column4: The defections, while amounting to only a handful, nevertheless could spell trouble for Democratic leaders as they head into the next phase of negotiations with House Republicans.

column3: Long-awaited vote on Senate budget exposes cracks among Democrats
column4: Leaders could be pressured by their more moderate members to make a bigger push to balance the budget, even if they don't want to make the kinds of major changes to entitlements that House Budget Committee Chairman Paul Ryan, R-Wis., prescribes.

column3: Long-awaited vote on Senate budget exposes cracks among Democrats
column4: Sen. Mark Begich, a moderate Democrat from Alaska, proudly announced Saturday that he opposed the Senate's plan because of its copious red ink.

column3: Long-awaited vote on Senate budget exposes cracks among Democrats
column4: "While I am happy that Congress is finally talking seriously about our fiscal crisis, this budget didn't go far enough," Begich said.

column3: Long-awaited vote on Senate budget exposes cracks among Democrats
column4: "Alaskans expect us to finish the job and make this staggering deficit manageable.

column3: Long-awaited vote on Senate budget exposes cracks among Democrats
column4: Passing this problem off to our children is not an option."

column3: Long-awaited vote on Senate budget exposes cracks among Democrats
column4: Though Democrats say Ryan is relying on unrealistic projections and changes, the House Republican budget aims to eliminate deficits over the next 10 years -- on paper, anyway.

column3: Long-awaited vote on Senate budget exposes cracks among Democrats
column4: The Senate Democrats' budget doesn't come close, despite raising taxes by $1 trillion.

column3: Long-awaited vote on Senate budget exposes cracks among Democrats
column4: Under their plan, the deficit over the next decade never dips below $400 billion and would hover at or near $600 billion by 2023.

column3: Long-awaited vote on Senate budget exposes cracks among Democrats
column4: This, as Republican Sen. Jeff Sessions repeatedly notes, would add $7.3 trillion to the national debt over that period.

column3: Long-awaited vote on Senate budget exposes cracks among Democrats
column4: "The content of the plan the majority has now approved demonstrates why they were unwilling to reveal it for so long: their proposal, once accurately understood, cannot be publicly defended," Sessions said in a statement.

column3: Long-awaited vote on Senate budget exposes cracks among Democrats
column4: House Republicans were not without defections of their own.

column3: Long-awaited vote on Senate budget exposes cracks among Democrats
column4: Ten Republicans opposed Ryan's 2014 plan earlier this week.

column3: Long-awaited vote on Senate budget exposes cracks among Democrats
column4: But the Republicans' budget resolution still passed by a more comfortable margin in the House than the Democrats' did in the Senate.

column3: Long-awaited vote on Senate budget exposes cracks among Democrats
column4: The four Senate Democrats who voted against the Democrats' bill were Kay Hagan, D-N.C.; Max Baucus, D-Mont.

column3: Long-awaited vote on Senate budget exposes cracks among Democrats
column4: ; Mark Pryor, D-Ark.

column3: Long-awaited vote on Senate budget exposes cracks among Democrats
column4: ; and Begich.

column3: Long-awaited vote on Senate budget exposes cracks among Democrats
column4: But there are more up for re-election in 2014 in moderate-to-conservative states where votes for a deficit-heavy budget plan would cause campaign problems.

column3: Long-awaited vote on Senate budget exposes cracks among Democrats
column4: President Obama plans to release his own 2014 budget next month, an unveiling that will be studied for whether it signals a willingness to engage Republicans in negotiations or play political hardball.

column3: Long-awaited vote on Senate budget exposes cracks among Democrats
column4: The Democratic budget's $975 billion in new taxes would be matched by an equal amount of spending reductions coming chiefly from health programs, defense and reduced interest payments as deficits get smaller than previously anticipated.

column3: Long-awaited vote on Senate budget exposes cracks among Democrats
column4: This year's projected deficit of nearly $900 billion would fall to around $700 billion next year and bottom out near $400 billion in 2016 before trending upward again.

column3: Long-awaited vote on Senate budget exposes cracks among Democrats
column4: Shoehorned into the package is $100 billion for public works projects and other programs aimed at creating jobs.

column3: Long-awaited vote on Senate budget exposes cracks among Democrats
column4: Neither the Democratic nor Republican plan will clear Congress in its current form -- plus each is just a blueprint which by itself does not appropriate money.

column3: Long-awaited vote on Senate budget exposes cracks among Democrats
column4: Democrats and Republicans will now launch into hard bargaining, and each make sacrifices if they are to settle on a bona fide budget, as opposed to passing stopgap spending bills to fund the government year after year.

column3: Long-awaited vote on Senate budget exposes cracks among Democrats
column4: The White House on Saturday again reiterated its displeasure with the House Republican plan, which does not call for tax hikes on anybody.

column3: Long-awaited vote on Senate budget exposes cracks among Democrats
column4: "The House Republican budget refuses to ask for a single dime of deficit reduction from closing tax loopholes for the wealthy and the well-connected but instead makes deep cuts to education and manufacturing while asking seniors and the middle class to pay more," White House Press Secretary Jay Carney said.

column3: Long-awaited vote on Senate budget exposes cracks among Democrats
column4: He said the Senate plan would "create jobs and cut the deficit in a balanced way."

column3: Long-awaited vote on Senate budget exposes cracks among Democrats

column4: It would take more than that to bring the budget into balance.

column4: It would also transform the health care program for older Americans into a voucher-like system for future recipients.

column3: Senate passes budget - first for four years
column4: In the early morning hours Saturday after almost 13 continuous hours of voting, the Senate passed a budget resolution for the first time in nearly four years.

column3: Senate passes budget - first for four years
column4: The proposal, which Democratic drafters say will reduce the deficit by $1.85 trillion between spending cuts and tax increases, passed narrowly 50-49 on a largely partisan vote at 4:56 a.m. Story Continued Below A handful of Democrats, all up for reelection next year and representing conservative states, voted against the measure: Sens.

column3: Senate passes budget - first for four years
column4: Kay Hagan (D-N.C.), Mark Pryor (D-Ark.

column3: Senate passes budget - first for four years
column4: ), Max Baucus (D-Mont.)

column3: Senate passes budget - first for four years
column4: and Mark Begich (D-Alaska).

column3: Senate passes budget - first for four years
column4: Sen. Frank Lautenberg (D-N.J.) was absent.

column3: Senate passes budget - first for four years
column4: ( Also on POLITICO: 'Vote-a-rama': The ones that matter) Nerves started to fray about 2 a.m., with Democrats pushing to end the voting and Republicans trying to continue to consider amendments.

column3: Senate passes budget - first for four years
column4: In total, they considered 101 amendments.

column3: Senate passes budget - first for four years
column4: The standoff brought leadership from both parties to hushed huddles on the floor as tired senators tried to intercede and speed the process.

column3: Senate passes budget - first for four years
column4: More than an hour of negotiations ensued until a deal was struck, more than 30 amendments would be passed without a vote as a package.

column3: Senate passes budget - first for four years
column4: Another 14 amendments would be voted on beginning just after 3 a.m. to allow them to finally be able to vote on the budget.

column3: Senate passes budget - first for four years
column4: ( Also on POLITICO: Congress averts shutdown) It was then that conservatives in the Senate were finally able to move on some of their more controversial amendments.

column3: Senate passes budget - first for four years
column4: Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas) offered amendments dealing with foreign relations in the Middle East and U.N. funding related to the legality of abortion, all of which were defeated.

column3: Senate passes budget - first for four years
column4: Sen. Mike Lee (R-Utah) offered an amendment reiterating the rights in the 2nd Amendment, which was shot down after being ruled unrelated to the budget.

column3: Senate passes budget - first for four years
column4: As part of a deal to move forward, the members agreed to remain seated and vote out loud as their names were called, an unusual event on the Senate floor.

column3: Senate passes budget - first for four years
column4: The 12-hour series of votes — more than 100 amendments were considered, breaking a previous “vote-a-rama” record — is mostly political theater and gives both sides the opportunity to force votes on pet issues.

column3: Senate passes budget - first for four years
column4: The budget is non-binding, therefore none of the passed amendments will likely carry the weight of law.

column3: Senate passes budget - first for four years
column4: But the votes are symbolic victories, demonstrating the ability of one side to rally enough senators to support a measure in hopes of using those votes for future bills.

column3: Senate passes budget - first for four years
column4: It also gives both sides a litany of roll calls to try to clobber their opponents during the next election.

column3: Senate passes budget - first for four years
column4: Republicans claimed victory on some key amendments, including passage of one to repeal the medical device tax included in Obamacare and one calling for the approval of the Keystone XL  Pipeline.

column3: Bipartisan House Majority Defeats Senate's Unbalanced Budget
column4: They'll debate and vote on the balanced, popular, pro-growth GOP alternative later today, but yesterday held an important moment of its own: The House on Wednesday rejected the Senate Democratic budget in a 154-261 vote, with 35 Democrats voting against the blueprint from their upper chamber colleagues.

column3: Bipartisan House Majority Defeats Senate's Unbalanced Budget
column4: House Democrats were instructed to vote for the Senate Democratic budget, but 35 of them defected...The House also rejected the budget from the Congressional Black Caucus (CBC) in a 105-305 vote...The Progressive Caucus budget was also rejected 84-327, but it managed to pick up a few more votes compared to last year.

column3: Bipartisan House Majority Defeats Senate's Unbalanced Budget
column4: Most Democrats voted against this bill, just as they did last year when it was rejected 78-346.

column3: Bipartisan House Majority Defeats Senate's Unbalanced Budget
column4: They would have voted on the president's budget as well, presumably, but it doesn't exist.

column3: Bipartisan House Majority Defeats Senate's Unbalanced Budget
column4: This executive abdication is unparalleled over the last 92 years of American presidents, dating back to the passage of the current law.

column3: Bipartisan House Majority Defeats Senate's Unbalanced Budget
column4: Here's a list of the Democrats who voted no on their own party's budget, perhaps because it raises taxes massively, punts on every major reform, and never, ever balances.

column3: Bipartisan House Majority Defeats Senate's Unbalanced Budget
column4: Coincidentally, many of the blue "no" votes were cast by vulnerable incumbents being targeted by the NRCC.

column3: Bipartisan House Majority Defeats Senate's Unbalanced Budget
column4: (2) The 'no' bloc "may be surprised to learn that they all hate old people and children, or whatever evil it is Democrat Budget Deniers are allegedly guilty of today."

column3: Bipartisan House Majority Defeats Senate's Unbalanced Budget
column4: Indeed.

column3: Three critical questions Obama needs to answer during his Israel trip
column4: To say that the pundits have low expectations for President Obama’s trip to Israel and Jordan this week would be putting it mildly.

column3: Three critical questions Obama needs to answer during his Israel trip
column4: Most expect a series of photo ops, but no serious progress on the three major issues: the Iran nuclear threat, the implosion of Syria, and the moribund Israeli-Palestinian peace process.

column3: Three critical questions Obama needs to answer during his Israel trip
column4: “It is hard for me to recall a less-anticipated trip to Israel by an American president,” noted Thomas L. Friedman in his recent column in the New York Times.

column3: Three critical questions Obama needs to answer during his Israel trip
column4: “But there is a message in that empty bottle: Little is expected from this trip — not only because little is possible, but because, from a narrow U.S. point of view, little is necessary.” [pullquote] Actually, much is necessary.

column3: Three critical questions Obama needs to answer during his Israel trip
column4: The president needs to “re-set” U.S.-Israeli relations in a positive way after a contentious relationship with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in the first term.

column3: Three critical questions Obama needs to answer during his Israel trip
column4: But that is the just the beginning.

column3: Three critical questions Obama needs to answer during his Israel trip
column4: There are three critical questions the president needs to answer on this trip: Unfortunately, the administration has sent mixed messages in recent days.

column3: Three critical questions Obama needs to answer during his Israel trip
column4: On March 4, Vice President Joe Biden told the AIPAC Policy Conference the president is committed to preventing Iran from getting the bomb, and pointedly noted that the “window is closing” for diplomacy and sanctions work.

column3: Three critical questions Obama needs to answer during his Israel trip
column4: “Let me make clear what that commitment is: It is to prevent Iran from acquiring a nuclear weapon,” said Biden.

column3: Three critical questions Obama needs to answer during his Israel trip
column4: “Period.

column3: Three critical questions Obama needs to answer during his Israel trip
column4: End of discussion.

column3: Three critical questions Obama needs to answer during his Israel trip
column4: Prevent — not contain —prevent….Big nations can’t bluff….And President Barack Obama is not bluffing.” The next day, however, Secretary of State John Kerry sent different signals.

column3: Three critical questions Obama needs to answer during his Israel trip
column4: He confirmed that Iran is getting closer to having nuclear weapons.

column3: Three critical questions Obama needs to answer during his Israel trip
column4: He conceded that “lines have been drawn before and they've been passed.

column3: Three critical questions Obama needs to answer during his Israel trip
column4: That's why the president has been so definitive this time.” But Kerry did not echo Biden’s hard line.

column3: Three critical questions Obama needs to answer during his Israel trip
column4: Rather, he said the president wants to “avoid any consideration of any kind of military action.” That same day, U.S. CENTCOM commander General James Mattis testified before the Senate Armed Services Committee.

column3: Three critical questions Obama needs to answer during his Israel trip
column4: He was asked, “In your professional opinion, are the current diplomatic and economic efforts to stop Iran from obtaining nuclear weapons capability -- are they working?” His answer was blunt.

column3: Three critical questions Obama needs to answer during his Israel trip
column4: “No, sir.” Then he said he was working on “other options” for the President.

column3: Three critical questions Obama needs to answer during his Israel trip
column4: Last week, President Obama was interviewed by Israel’s Channel 2.

column3: Three critical questions Obama needs to answer during his Israel trip
column4: He said there is still “a year or so” until Iran builds an operational nuclear bomb.

column3: Three critical questions Obama needs to answer during his Israel trip
column4: That confused the picture even more.

column3: Three critical questions Obama needs to answer during his Israel trip
column4: Was the president indicating time is running out and that military action might need to be taken soon, or that there is still plenty of time to keep trying diplomacy and sanctions?

column3: Three critical questions Obama needs to answer during his Israel trip
column4: Mr. Netanyahu famously told the U.N. General Assembly last fall that the “red line” – the point at which Israel would be forced to launch preemptive strikes or risk allowing Tehran to get The Bomb – would be reached by spring or summer 2013.

column3: Three critical questions Obama needs to answer during his Israel trip
column4: Today, senior Israeli officials confirm the red line is approaching.

column3: Three critical questions Obama needs to answer during his Israel trip
column4: “Iran’s nuclear program is advancing slower then they planned, but it is moving,” says Major General Aviv Kochavi, director of Israeli military intelligence.

column3: Three critical questions Obama needs to answer during his Israel trip
column4: “At their current pace of enrichment of 14 kilograms of uranium per month, Iran would be able to manufacture five to six nuclear bombs, if the order is given.” The problem, noted Kochavi, is that the military option that world leaders say is “on the table” is not being taken seriously by Tehran.

column3: Three critical questions Obama needs to answer during his Israel trip
column4: “Iran does not see a high likelihood of an attack on its nuclear facilities by the international community,” he noted at a recent security conference in Israel.

column3: Three critical questions Obama needs to answer during his Israel trip
column4: Netanyahu is ready to launch a massive preemptive military strike soon, and alone, if need be.

column3: Three critical questions Obama needs to answer during his Israel trip
column4: His new government is now in place.

column3: Three critical questions Obama needs to answer during his Israel trip
column4: This includes new Defense Minister Moshe Yaalon, a former chief of staff of the Israeli Defense Forces.

column3: Three critical questions Obama needs to answer during his Israel trip
column4: Neither man wants war.

column3: Three critical questions Obama needs to answer during his Israel trip
column4: They are looking for peaceful paths, and they would prefer the U.S. lead decisively.

column3: Three critical questions Obama needs to answer during his Israel trip
column4: But both are unsure if they can trust the American president, and both need clarity from Washington they have not yet received.

column3: Three critical questions Obama needs to answer during his Israel trip
column4: The pundits are wrong.

column3: Three critical questions Obama needs to answer during his Israel trip
column4: Much is at stake in the Mideast.

column3: Three critical questions Obama needs to answer during his Israel trip
column4: Thus, much is needed from President Obama on this week’s trip -- clear answers on three critical questions, most of all.

column3: Three critical questions Obama needs to answer during his Israel trip
column4: Joel C. Rosenberg, a dual U.S.-Israeli citizen, is a New York Times best-selling author and a founding member of the Alliance For The Peace of Jerusalem.

column4: Feinstein said she's "disappointed" with the decision, and is expected to nevertheless offer it as an amendment.

column3: Assault weapons ban dropped from Senate gun control bill
column4: But the move by Reid to cut it from the main bill signals a lack of congressional support for a proposal that would not only revive, but strengthen, the decade-long ban that expired in 2004.

column3: Assault weapons ban dropped from Senate gun control bill
column4: The proposed ban passed was passed last week by the Senate Judiciary Committee, along with three other measures.

column3: Assault weapons ban dropped from Senate gun control bill
column4: The others dealt with providing more school safety aid, expanding federal background checks on potential gun buyers and helping authorities prosecute illegal gun traffickers.

column3: Assault weapons ban dropped from Senate gun control bill
column4: Feinstein has led the gun-control charge since President Obama called for federal legislation in the wake of the Newtown and other mass shootings.

column3: Assault weapons ban dropped from Senate gun control bill
column4: The assault weapons ban was the most controversial of the major proposals to restrict guns that have been advanced by Obama and Senate Democrats.

column3: Assault weapons ban dropped from Senate gun control bill
column4: Because of that, it had been expected that the assault weapons measure would be left out of the initial package the Senate considers, with Democrats hoping the Senate could in turn amass the strongest possible vote for the overall legislation.

column3: Assault weapons ban dropped from Senate gun control bill
column4: There are 53 Democrats in the Senate, plus two independents who usually vote with them.

column3: Assault weapons ban dropped from Senate gun control bill
column4: Having a separate vote on assault weapons might free moderate Democratic senators facing re-election next year in Republican-leaning states to vote against the assault weapons measure, but then support the remaining overall package of gun curbs.

column3: Assault weapons ban dropped from Senate gun control bill
column4: Gun control supporters consider a strong Senate vote important because the Republican-run House has shown little enthusiasm for most of Obama's proposals.

column3: Assault weapons ban dropped from Senate gun control bill
column4: Feinstein said Reid told her there would be two additional votes.

column3: Assault weapons ban dropped from Senate gun control bill
column4: One would be on her assault weapons ban, which also includes a ban on ammunition magazines that carry more than 10 rounds.

column3: Assault weapons ban dropped from Senate gun control bill
column4: The second would just be on prohibiting the high-capacity magazine clips.

column3: Assault weapons ban dropped from Senate gun control bill
column4: Many Democrats think the ban on large-capacity magazines has a better chance of getting 60 votes than the assault weapons ban.

column3: Assault weapons ban dropped from Senate gun control bill
column4: The Associated Press contributed to this report.

column3: Joe Biden greets Pope Francis during pontiff's installation Mass
column4: It’s official: Pope Francis has started his ministry.

column3: Joe Biden greets Pope Francis during pontiff's installation Mass
column4: A cardinal gave the rite of inauguration to start the Mass: “The Good Shepherd charged Peter to feed his lambs and his sheep,” he said, as CBS reported.

column3: Joe Biden greets Pope Francis during pontiff's installation Mass
column4: “Today, you succeed him as the bishop of this church.” Vice President Joseph R. Biden, a Catholic, lead the U.S. delegation for the installation mass.

column3: Joe Biden greets Pope Francis during pontiff's installation Mass
column4: During a brief meeting, Biden shook the 76-year-old Argentinian pontiff’s hand, and swung his left hand on top of their clasp for extra emphasis as they quickly exchanged words.

column3: Joe Biden greets Pope Francis during pontiff's installation Mass
column4: Tens of thousands were on hand to witness the ceremony.

column3: Joe Biden greets Pope Francis during pontiff's installation Mass
column4: Pope Francis spent about a half-hour touring St. Peter’s Square, getting out of his Jeep at one point to bestow a blessing on a man in the crowd who sat in a wheelchair, CBS said.

column3: Joe Biden greets Pope Francis during pontiff's installation Mass
column4: The pope’s message was clear: Love all, be humble and sacrifice, as Jesus did.

column3: Joe Biden greets Pope Francis during pontiff's installation Mass
column4: We are here to protect each other, he said.

column3: Joe Biden greets Pope Francis during pontiff's installation Mass
column4: “I think he’ll revive the sentiments of Catholics who received the sacraments but don’t go to Mass anymore, and awaken the sentiments of people who don’t believe anymore in the church, for good reason,” said Judith Teloni, an Argentine tourist guide who attended the Mass, as quoted by CBS.

column3: Eyeing the Oval Office in 2016? Hillary Clinton makes an announcement: I support gay marriage
column4: Former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton says she now supports same-sex marriage — an announcement that could be seen as a political step toward a White House run.

column3: Eyeing the Oval Office in 2016? Hillary Clinton makes an announcement: I support gay marriage
column4: Gays are “full and equal citizens and deserve the rights of citizenship,” she said in a five-minute video released by the Human Rights Campaign on Monday morning.

column3: Eyeing the Oval Office in 2016? Hillary Clinton makes an announcement: I support gay marriage
column4: “That includes marriage.” Her husband, former President Bill Clinton, came out in support of gay marriage earlier this month.

column3: Eyeing the Oval Office in 2016? Hillary Clinton makes an announcement: I support gay marriage

column3: Eyeing the Oval Office in 2016? Hillary Clinton makes an announcement: I support gay marriage

column3: Republicans to spend millions to reach minorities
column4: The Republican Party, after holding up a mirror to itself and completing a lengthy analysis of what went wrong in the last election cycle, issued an extensive report Monday that formally endorsed immigration reform and outlined an ambitious drive to reach out to minority groups and build a winning coalition.

column3: Republicans to spend millions to reach minorities
column4: "When someone rolls their eyes at us, they are not likely to open their ears to us," the Republican National Committee's report said, asserting that "many minorities wrongly think that Republicans do not like them."

column3: Republicans to spend millions to reach minorities
column4: The RNC outlined a $10 million plan to reach out to minority groups in a bid to attract voters, whom the report acknowledged the party has been turning off.

column3: Republicans to spend millions to reach minorities
column4: "Public perception of the party is at record lows," the report said.

column3: Republicans to spend millions to reach minorities
column4: Leading off the set of recommendations was a call for the party to "stop talking to itself."

column3: Republicans to spend millions to reach minorities
column4: Click to read the report.

column3: Republicans to spend millions to reach minorities
column4: To broaden its appeal, the party must embrace immigration legislation, according to one recommendation in the report: "We must embrace and champion comprehensive immigration reform.

column3: Republicans to spend millions to reach minorities
column4: If we do not, our party's appeal will continue to shrink to its core constituencies only," it said.

column3: Republicans to spend millions to reach minorities
column4: The study also called for being more "inclusive and welcoming" when it comes to social issues.

column3: Republicans to spend millions to reach minorities
column4: The report, though, also described two different tracks for the GOP.

column3: Republicans to spend millions to reach minorities
column4: On one, state-level candidates are winning elections and re-defining the party.

column3: Republicans to spend millions to reach minorities
column4: On the other, the "federal wing" of Republicans is "increasingly marginalizing itself."

column3: Republicans to spend millions to reach minorities
column4: The report said "it is time for Republicans on the federal level to learn from successful Republicans on the state level."

column3: Republicans to spend millions to reach minorities
column4: The report calls on Republicans to take a harder line with corporate America, loosen political fundraising laws in Washington and in state capitals, and cut in half the number of candidate debates in a shortened 2016 presidential primary calendar.

column3: Republicans to spend millions to reach minorities
column4: "When Republicans lost in November, it was a wakeup call," RNC Chairman Reince Priebus said.

column3: Republicans to spend millions to reach minorities
column4: The Republican National Committee's shift on minority outreach may be the most visible change in the coming months.

column3: Republicans to spend millions to reach minorities
column4: Priebus plans to dispatch hundreds of paid workers into Hispanic, black and Asian communities across the nation by the end of the summer, a $10 million effort meant to rival President Obama's national political machine.

column3: Republicans to spend millions to reach minorities
column4: The RNC also will push for a tone of "tolerance and respect" in the immigration debate, create "senior level advisory councils" focused on minority groups, and establish "swearing-in citizenship teams" to connect with new voters immediately after swearing-in ceremonies.

column3: Republicans to spend millions to reach minorities
column4: "We need to go to communities where Republicans do not normally go to listen and make our case," the report says.

column3: Republicans to spend millions to reach minorities
column4: "We need to campaign among Hispanic, black, Asian and gay Americans and demonstrate that we care about them, too."

column3: Republicans to spend millions to reach minorities
column4: The recommendations will not be well received in all corners of the Republican Party.

column3: Republicans to spend millions to reach minorities
column4: Some Republicans, Florida Sen. Marco Rubio among them, are working toward bipartisan immigration reform that is likely to include a pathway to citizenship for illegal immigrants -- sometimes called "amnesty."

column3: Republicans to spend millions to reach minorities
column4: Conservative commentator Ann Coulter ripped the idea in a speech to the Conservative Political Action Conference over the weekend.

column3: Republicans to spend millions to reach minorities
column4: "If amnesty goes through, America becomes California and no Republican will ever win another national election," Coulter said.

column3: Republicans to spend millions to reach minorities
column4: The RNC's recommendations follow an extensive look at what went wrong in 2012.

column3: Republicans to spend millions to reach minorities
column4: Priebus tapped a handful of respected party leaders to examine how the GOP could better talk with voters, raise money from donors and learn from Democrats' tactics.

column3: Republicans to spend millions to reach minorities
column4: The report also suggests that party officials could lean more on independent groups such as super political action committees to fund television advertising campaigns, allowing the Republican National Committee to focus on strategy and contacting voters.

column3: Republicans to spend millions to reach minorities
column4: Ari Fleischer, White House press secretary under former President George W. Bush, and Bradshaw, a top adviser to former Florida Gov.

column3: Republicans to spend millions to reach minorities
column4: Jeb Bush, were among those leading the inquiry.

column3: Republicans to spend millions to reach minorities
column4: Republican National Committeeman Henry Barbour, a GOP strategist and nephew of former Mississippi Gov.

column3: Republicans to spend millions to reach minorities
column4: Haley Barbour, was also part of the group.

column3: Republicans to spend millions to reach minorities
column4: RNC members Zori Fonalledas of Puerto Rico and Glenn McCall of South Carolina rounded out the five-person committee that listened to Republicans' ideas and frustrations.

column3: Republicans to spend millions to reach minorities
column4: Those leaders heard from 50,000 rank-and-file members about how to respond to the nation's shifting demographics.

column3: Republicans to spend millions to reach minorities
column4: The proposals -- particularly those affecting the presidential primary calendar -- are far from a done deal.

column3: Republicans to spend millions to reach minorities
column4: They would have to win the approval of the 168-member RNC and then each state's election chief would have to abide by the party's proposed calendar.

column3: Republicans to spend millions to reach minorities
column4: The report recommends reducing the number of presidential primary debates to approximately 10 to 12, with the first scheduled no earlier than Sept. 1, 2015.

column3: Republicans to spend millions to reach minorities
column4: It calls for the primary calendar to begin with the traditional "carve out" states -- such as Iowa and New Hampshire -- before moving to a major reorganization, such as a "regional primary system" finished by mid-May.

column3: Republicans to spend millions to reach minorities
column4: The Associated Press contributed to this report.

column3: Paul Wins CPAC Straw Poll
column4: Sen. Rand Paul (R-Ky.) won the Conservative Political Action Conference straw poll on Saturday, marking an early indicator of conservative support ahead of the next presidential election in 2016.

column3: Paul Wins CPAC Straw Poll
column4: Paul topped the list and Sen. Marco Rubio (R-Fla.) came in second, according to Ian Bishop.

column3: Paul Wins CPAC Straw Poll
column4: Former Sen. Rick Santorum (R-Pa.) came in third place this year, with New Jersey Gov.

column3: Paul Wins CPAC Straw Poll
column4: Chris Christie -- who was notably not invited to this year's conference -- coming in fourth.

column3: Paul Wins CPAC Straw Poll
column4: Paul received 25 percent of the vote, with Rubio in a close second with 23 percent.

column3: Paul Wins CPAC Straw Poll
column4: Santorum received eight percent, and Christie took seven percent of the vote.

column3: Paul Wins CPAC Straw Poll
column4: The Hill's Alexandra Jaffe reports 2,930 registrants participated in the straw poll this year.

column3: Paul Wins CPAC Straw Poll
column4: The annual straw poll came at the conclusion of the high-profile conference, which featured dozens of notable conservative speakers over three days at National Harbor near Washington, D.C. Last year, Mitt Romney came out on top in the CPAC poll, foreshadowing his eventual nomination as Republican presidential candidate.

column3: Paul Wins CPAC Straw Poll
column4: Former Rep. Ron Paul (R-Texas), a Libertarian favorite, took home the title in 2010 and 2011.

column3: Rand Paul Edges out Marco Rubio to Win CPAC Straw Poll
column4: Sen. Rand Paul narrowly beat out Sen. Marco Rubio to win the Conservative Political Action Conference straw poll, offering an early glimpse of the potential 2016 Republican primary battle three years away.

column3: Rand Paul Edges out Marco Rubio to Win CPAC Straw Poll
column4: Paul (R-Ky.) won with 25 percent of the vote, closely followed by Rubio (R-Fla.) with 23 percent.

column3: Rand Paul Edges out Marco Rubio to Win CPAC Straw Poll
column4: Former Sen. Rick Santorum (R-Pa.) came in third place with 8 percent.

column3: Rand Paul Edges out Marco Rubio to Win CPAC Straw Poll
column4: New Jersey Gov.

column3: Rand Paul Edges out Marco Rubio to Win CPAC Straw Poll
column4: Chris Christie — not invited to speak at CPAC — was fourth with 7 percent of the vote, followed by Rep. Paul Ryan (R-Wis.), the 2012 GOP vice presidential nominee, with 6 percent.

column3: Rand Paul Edges out Marco Rubio to Win CPAC Straw Poll
column4: Nearly 3,000 CPAC registrants voted.

column3: Rand Paul Edges out Marco Rubio to Win CPAC Straw Poll
column4: The CPAC straw poll is in no way a predictor of who will win the White House: Mitt Romney won the straw poll last year, breaking two years of dominance by Rep. Ron Paul, father of Rand Paul.

column3: Wayne LaPierre Delivers Fiery Speech At CPAC
column4: -- National Rifle Association CEO Wayne LaPierre attempted to turn the tables Friday on those in the media and government who have recently characterized the gun lobbyist's talking points as "crazy."

column3: Wayne LaPierre Delivers Fiery Speech At CPAC
column4: In a speech at the Conservative Political Action Conference, LaPierre accused the federal government, the Department of Homeland Security, so-called "Washington elites" and Vice President Joe Biden of offering illogical solutions to the challenges of gun violence.

column3: Wayne LaPierre Delivers Fiery Speech At CPAC
column4: Entering the stage to a standing ovation and showing a video montage of his opponents' attacks, LaPierre delivered a fiery rebuttal that garnered a half-dozen standing ovations from the staunchly conservative, and generally young, crowd at CPAC.

column3: Wayne LaPierre Delivers Fiery Speech At CPAC
column4: Gun control advocates "insult [us], they denigrate, and they call us 'crazy' for holding fast to [our opposition to gun control].

column3: Wayne LaPierre Delivers Fiery Speech At CPAC
column4: In their distorted view of the world, they're smarter than we are; they're special; they're more worthy than we are; they know better than we do," he said.

column3: Wayne LaPierre Delivers Fiery Speech At CPAC
column4: "The liberal media can keep hating on me, but I'm still standing."

column3: Wayne LaPierre Delivers Fiery Speech At CPAC
column4: Much of LaPierre's speech covered familiar territory in the ongoing debate over gun violence, such as the argument that universal background checks on gun purchases will not work because criminals will evade them.

column3: Wayne LaPierre Delivers Fiery Speech At CPAC
column4: But LaPierre also launched attacks working off more recent news, such as Chinese Internet hackers and the across-the-board budget cuts known as sequestration.

column3: Wayne LaPierre Delivers Fiery Speech At CPAC
column4: "What's the point of registering lawful gun owners?"

column3: Wayne LaPierre Delivers Fiery Speech At CPAC
column4: LaPierre asked the crowd, jumping to the false conclusion that universal background checks will be used to create a federal registry of gun owners.

column3: Wayne LaPierre Delivers Fiery Speech At CPAC
column4: "So newspapers can print those names … so the list can be hacked by foreign entities like the Chinese?"

column3: Wayne LaPierre Delivers Fiery Speech At CPAC
column4: He also seized on the effects of sequestration.

column3: Wayne LaPierre Delivers Fiery Speech At CPAC
column4: "Instead of rational belt-tightening ... the first thing the government does is let criminal illegals out of jail," said LaPierre, referring to the February release of undocumented immigrants facing deportation by the Department of Homeland Security.

column3: Wayne LaPierre Delivers Fiery Speech At CPAC
column4: "It's as if insanity itself has been sequestered in Washington."

column3: Wayne LaPierre Delivers Fiery Speech At CPAC
column4: In addition to DHS Secretary Janet Napolitano, LaPierre directly addressed Vice President Biden, and in particular, Biden's recent suggestion that a shotgun would make a more effective weapon for personal defense than a military-style rifle like the one used in the Newtown, Conn., massacre.

column3: Wayne LaPierre Delivers Fiery Speech At CPAC
column4: Democrats support an assault weapons ban that would cover the latter guns.

column3: Wayne LaPierre Delivers Fiery Speech At CPAC
column4: "Have they lost their minds over at the White House?"

column3: Wayne LaPierre Delivers Fiery Speech At CPAC
column4: LaPierre asked mockingly.

column3: Wayne LaPierre Delivers Fiery Speech At CPAC
column4: "You keep your advice, we'll keep our guns."

column3: GOP Senator Reverses Stance On Gay Marriage After Son Comes Out
column4: Sen.

column3: GOP Senator Reverses Stance On Gay Marriage After Son Comes Out
column4: Rob Portman (R-Ohio) has reversed his stance on same-sex marriage two years after learning that his son is gay, several Ohio news outlets, including the Columbus Dispatch and the Cleveland Plain Dealer, reported Friday.

column3: GOP Senator Reverses Stance On Gay Marriage After Son Comes Out
column4: In an interview with Ohio reporters in his Senate office, Portman said that his son, Will, came out to the senator and his wife in February 2011.

column3: GOP Senator Reverses Stance On Gay Marriage After Son Comes Out
column4: "It allowed me to think of this issue from a new perspective, and that's of a Dad who loves his son a lot and wants him to have the same opportunities that his brother and sister would have -- to have a relationship like Jane and I have had for over 26 years," Portman said.

column3: GOP Senator Reverses Stance On Gay Marriage After Son Comes Out
column4: Portman said that his son, who is now a junior at Yale University, inspired him to reassess his position on same-sex unions.

column3: GOP Senator Reverses Stance On Gay Marriage After Son Comes Out
column4: The senator also consulted clergy on the matter, as well as friends such as former Vice President Dick Cheney, whose daughter Mary is openly gay.

column3: GOP Senator Reverses Stance On Gay Marriage After Son Comes Out
column4: According to Portman, Cheney told the senator to "follow [his] heart" on the matter.

column3: GOP Senator Reverses Stance On Gay Marriage After Son Comes Out
column4: "The overriding message of love and compassion that I take from the Bible, and certainly the Golden Rule, and the fact that I believe we are all created by our maker, that has all influenced me in terms of my change on this issue," Portman said.

column3: GOP Senator Reverses Stance On Gay Marriage After Son Comes Out
column4: Portman's announcement comes just days before the Supreme Court hears arguments on the Defense Of Marriage Act, the federal ban on same-sex marriage.

column3: GOP Senator Reverses Stance On Gay Marriage After Son Comes Out
column4: Portman co-sponsored the measure as a member of the U.S. House in 1996.

column3: GOP Senator Reverses Stance On Gay Marriage After Son Comes Out
column4: And in 1999, Portman voted for a measure prohibiting same-sex couples in Washington state from adopting children.

column3: GOP Senator Reverses Stance On Gay Marriage After Son Comes Out
column4: In 2011, Portman's "openly hostile" record on gay rights led to hundreds of students at the University of Michigan objecting to the senator speaking at the school's graduation ceremony.

column3: GOP Senator Reverses Stance On Gay Marriage After Son Comes Out
column4: "Rob believes marriage is a sacred bond between one man and one woman," a Portman spokesman told the Plain Dealer at the time of the protest.

column3: GOP Senator Reverses Stance On Gay Marriage After Son Comes Out
column4: Portman, who was considered by 2012 Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney as a potential running mate, says that he informed Romney about his son's sexual orientation.

column3: GOP Senator Reverses Stance On Gay Marriage After Son Comes Out
column4: "I told Mitt Romney everything," Portman told CNN.

column3: GOP Senator Reverses Stance On Gay Marriage After Son Comes Out
column4: "That process is, intrusive would be one way to put it.

column3: GOP Senator Reverses Stance On Gay Marriage After Son Comes Out
column4: But, no, yeah, I told him everything."

column3: GOP Senator Reverses Stance On Gay Marriage After Son Comes Out
column4: The senator also said that Romney's campaign told him that his son's sexuality was not part of the decision to select Rep. Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) over Portman.

column3: GOP Senator Reverses Stance On Gay Marriage After Son Comes Out
column4: UPDATE: 3/15 9:15 a.m. -- Portman has penned an column for the Columbus Dispatch explaining his reversal: "I have come to believe that if two people are prepared to make a lifetime commitment to love and care for each other in good times and in bad, the government shouldn’t deny them the opportunity to get married," he writes.

column3: GOP Senator Reverses Stance On Gay Marriage After Son Comes Out

column3: Which Republican Senator Is Offering a Shocking Endorsement of Gay Marriage After His Son Came Out?
column4: “I’ve come to the conclusion that for me, personally, I think this is something that we should allow people to do, to get married, and to have the joy and stability of marriage that I’ve had for over 26 years,” he said.

column4: “That I want all of my children to have, including our son, who is gay.” Watch a portion of his interview, below: This is a stark change from the past, when Portman, in 1996, voted in support of the Defense of Marriage Act.

column3: Which Republican Senator Is Offering a Shocking Endorsement of Gay Marriage After His Son Came Out?
column4: The controversial measure defined marriage as being strictly between a man and woman and it banned the federal government from recognizing gay marriage.

column3: Which Republican Senator Is Offering a Shocking Endorsement of Gay Marriage After His Son Came Out?
column4: He noted that his “faith tradition” had colored his views against gay marriage, but that his son’s revelation changed his position on the matter.

column3: Which Republican Senator Is Offering a Shocking Endorsement of Gay Marriage After His Son Came Out?
column4: Will, he says, blessed his decision to come forward and helped him process his thoughts before releasing his new-found stance.

column3: Which Republican Senator Is Offering a Shocking Endorsement of Gay Marriage After His Son Came Out?
column4: “I think he’s happy and, you know, proud that we’ve come to this point, but he let it be my decision just as you know, it’s going to be his decision as to the role he plays going forward in this whole issue,” Portman said of his son.

column3: Which Republican Senator Is Offering a Shocking Endorsement of Gay Marriage After His Son Came Out?
column4: Portman had previously discussed the issue with former Vice President Dick Cheney, his pastor and others.

column3: Confirmed: Senate Democrats' Budget Accelerates Spending, Never Balances
column4: It jacks up taxes by ~~one trillion~~ $1.5 trillion dollars(see update), passes on crucial entitlement reforms, relies on gimmicks for most of its spending cuts, and -- as we reported yesterday -- it actually  increases spending compared to the current unsustainable baseline.

column3: Confirmed: Senate Democrats' Budget Accelerates Spending, Never Balances

column3: Confirmed: Senate Democrats' Budget Accelerates Spending, Never Balances

column4: Democrats' plans will exceed even that rate of increase.

column3: Confirmed: Senate Democrats' Budget Accelerates Spending, Never Balances

column3: Confirmed: Senate Democrats' Budget Accelerates Spending, Never Balances
column4: As expected, Democrats try to hide this reality by leaning on accounting tricks, such as "savings" conjured from a fraudulent Afghanistan war baseline.

column3: Confirmed: Senate Democrats' Budget Accelerates Spending, Never Balances
column4: Even with all the (real) tax hikes and (fake) "cuts," the Democrat budget never even approaches balance.

column3: Confirmed: Senate Democrats' Budget Accelerates Spending, Never Balances
column4: Based on their own numbers, the closest Democrats say they'll come to balancing the budget over the next ten years is in 2016, when they project an annual deficit of $407 billion.

column3: Confirmed: Senate Democrats' Budget Accelerates Spending, Never Balances
column4: By contrast, Ryan's budget crosses into surplus in 2023, and pushes annual deficits below the $100 billion threshold seven times in ten years.

column3: Confirmed: Senate Democrats' Budget Accelerates Spending, Never Balances
column4: Another point of reference: President Bush's average annual deficit was $250 billion (although it can be fairly argued that he deserves a share of 2009's monster shortfall), so Senate Democrats' best expected deficit is still more than $150 billion higher than Bush's average.

column3: Confirmed: Senate Democrats' Budget Accelerates Spending, Never Balances
column4: Also, for the record, the last time a Republican Congress and a Republican president passed a budget (FY 2007), the deficit was $161 billion, even with two active wars at their peak.

column3: Confirmed: Senate Democrats' Budget Accelerates Spending, Never Balances
column4: Sen. Jeff Sessions, the ranking Republican on the budget committee, tees off: Four years have passed since the last time Senate’s Democrat majority attempted to pass a budget.

column3: Confirmed: Senate Democrats' Budget Accelerates Spending, Never Balances
column4: Four years of trillion-dollar deficits.

column3: Confirmed: Senate Democrats' Budget Accelerates Spending, Never Balances
column4: Yet, to my amazement and deep disappointment, the majority has come forward today with a proposal that does nothing to change our unsustainable debt course.

column3: Confirmed: Senate Democrats' Budget Accelerates Spending, Never Balances
column4: Next year alone, their budget increases spending $162 billion above what we are spending today.

column3: Confirmed: Senate Democrats' Budget Accelerates Spending, Never Balances
column4: That is astonishing.

column3: Confirmed: Senate Democrats' Budget Accelerates Spending, Never Balances
column4: They offer no plan—no proposal, no attempt—to reform taxes, grow the economy, reduce poverty, fix our entitlements, or that would create good-paying jobs and rising wages.

column4: We know from academic studies that our debt over 90 percent of GDP destroys jobs and wages—their proposal locks these dangerous debt levels in place.

column3: Confirmed: Senate Democrats' Budget Accelerates Spending, Never Balances
column4: Republicans believe we must balance the budget in 10 years, but the majority proposal never balances—ever.

column3: Confirmed: Senate Democrats' Budget Accelerates Spending, Never Balances
column4: ...In the majority’s plan as it now exists, debt increases $7 trillion from today’s levels, despite a massive tax hike.

column3: Confirmed: Senate Democrats' Budget Accelerates Spending, Never Balances
column4: Their proposal increases the federal budget from $3.6 trillion today to $5.7 trillion 10 years from now—an increase of 62 percent.

column3: Confirmed: Senate Democrats' Budget Accelerates Spending, Never Balances
column4: This represents a net increase of $208 billion above the projected surging spending growth in our existing baseline.

column3: Confirmed: Senate Democrats' Budget Accelerates Spending, Never Balances
column4: In other words: it’s a tax-and-spend budget.

column3: Confirmed: Senate Democrats' Budget Accelerates Spending, Never Balances
column4: Democrats are saying to the American people: you are the problem.

column3: Confirmed: Senate Democrats' Budget Accelerates Spending, Never Balances
column4: Washington doesn’t need to change.

column3: Confirmed: Senate Democrats' Budget Accelerates Spending, Never Balances
column4: You need to send us more money.

column3: Confirmed: Senate Democrats' Budget Accelerates Spending, Never Balances

column3: Confirmed: Senate Democrats' Budget Accelerates Spending, Never Balances
column4: The Democrat budget enriches the bureaucracy at the expense of the people.

column3: Confirmed: Senate Democrats' Budget Accelerates Spending, Never Balances
column4: He's exactly right.

column3: Confirmed: Senate Democrats' Budget Accelerates Spending, Never Balances
column4: When you hear the term "tax and spend liberal," these are the sorts of actions and priorities that are being referenced.

column3: Confirmed: Senate Democrats' Budget Accelerates Spending, Never Balances

column3: Confirmed: Senate Democrats' Budget Accelerates Spending, Never Balances
column4: But as we learned yesterday from our normally balance-obsessed president, balanced budgets aren't really that important.

column3: Confirmed: Senate Democrats' Budget Accelerates Spending, Never Balances

column3: Confirmed: Senate Democrats' Budget Accelerates Spending, Never Balances

column3: Confirmed: Senate Democrats' Budget Accelerates Spending, Never Balances

column3: Confirmed: Senate Democrats' Budget Accelerates Spending, Never Balances
