column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: Pope Francis held his first mass as leader of the Catholic Church Thursday, urging cardinals that the church should stick to its roots and avoid modern temptations.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: In his first homily at the Sistine Chapel, Jorge Mario Bergoglio, the 76-year-old Argentine cardinal who was elected pope by his peers on Wednesday, warned that the church risked becoming a "pitiful" non-governmental organization unless it goes through spiritual renewal and focuses on the message of Jesus Christ, Sky News reports.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: "If we do not confess to Christ what would we be?"

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: Francis said.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: "We would end up a pitiful NGO.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: What would happen would be like when children make sand castles and then it all falls down."

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: Francis and all the cardinals in attendance wore light yellow robes over their cassocks, while the new pope spoke in Italian without notes.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: Earlier Thursday, Francis stopped by his hotel to pick up his luggage and pay the bill himself and praying at Rome's main basilica dedicated to the Virgin Mary.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: He entered the St. Mary Major basilica through a side entrance just after 8 a.m. and left about 30 minutes later.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: "He spoke to us cordially, like a father," Father Ludovico Melo, a priest who prayed with Pope Francis, told Reuters.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: "We were given 10 minutes' advance notice that the pope was coming."

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: After becoming the first pontiff from the Americans, Francis had told a crowd of some 100,000 people packed in rain-soaked St. Peter's Square just after his election that he intended to pray Friday to the Madonna "that she may watch over all of Rome."

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: Bergoglio chose the name Francis, drawing connections to the humble 13th-century saint who saw his calling as trying to rebuild the church in a time of turmoil.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: Benedict's longtime aide, Monsignor Georg Gaenswein, accompanied Francis to the visit Thursday morning at St. Mary Major.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: In addition to being Benedict's secretary, Gaenswein is also the prefect of the papal household and will be arranging the new pope's schedule.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: Like many Latin American Catholics, Francis has a particular devotion to the Virgin Mary, and his visit to the basilica was a reflection of that.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: He prayed before a Byzantine icon of Mary and the infant Jesus, the Protectress of the Roman People.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: "He had a great devotion to this icon of Mary and every time he comes from Argentina he visits this basilica," said one of the priests at the basilica, the Rev.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: Elio Montenero.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: "We were surprised today because he did not announce his visit."

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: He then went into the main altar area of the basilica and prayed before relics of the manger in Bethlehem where Jesus is said to have been born — an important pilgrimage spot for Jesuits.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: Members of his flock were charmed Thursday when Francis stopped by the Vatican-owned residence where he routinely stays during visits to Rome.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: The Rev.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: Pawel Rytel-Andrianek, who teaches at the nearby Pontifical Holy Cross University and is staying at the residence, said he didn't just come to get his luggage, noting that anyone could have come to get his suitcases.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: "He wanted to come here because he wanted to thank the personnel, people who work in this house," he said.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: Francis met with the staff in the dining room.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: "He greeted them one by one, no rush, the whole staff, one by one," Rytel-Andrianek said, noting that the pope knew everyone by name.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: "People say that he never in these 20 years asked for a (Vatican) car," he said.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: "Even when he went for the conclave with a priest from his diocese, he just walked out to the main road, he picked up a taxi and went to the conclave.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: So very simple for a future pope."

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: Francis has also spoken by phone with Benedict, who became the first pope to resign in 600 years and has been living at the papal retreat in Castel Gandolfo.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: Francis was expected to visit him this week, but a Vatican spokesman, the Rev.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: Thomas Rosica, said Francis wouldn't make the trip to Castel Gandolfo on Thursday, and probably wouldn't go Friday, either.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: The visit is significant because Benedict's resignation has raised concerns about potential power conflicts emerging from the peculiar situation of having a reigning pope and a retired one.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: As the long-time archbishop of Buenos Aires, Francis has spent nearly his entire career at home in Argentina, overseeing churches and shoe-leather priests.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: In choosing a 76-year-old pope, the cardinals clearly decided that they didn't need a vigorous, young pope who would reign for decades but rather a seasoned, popular and humble pastor who would draw followers to the faith and help rebuild a church stained by scandal.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: Groups of supporters waved Argentine flags Wednesday night in St. Peter's Square as Francis, wearing simple white robes, made his first public appearance as pope.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: Chants of "Long live the pope!"

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: arose from the throngs of faithful, many with tears in their eyes.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: Crowds went wild as the Vatican and Italian military bands marched through the square and up the steps of the basilica, followed by Swiss Guards in silver helmets and full regalia.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: Francis appeared on the balcony of St. Peter's Basilica just after a church official announced "Habemus Papum" -- "We have a pope" -- and gave Bergoglio's name in Latin.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: "Ladies and Gentlemen, good evening," he said to wild cheers before making a reference to his roots in Latin America, which accounts for about 40 percent of the world's Roman Catholics.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: Francis asked for prayers for himself, and for retired Pope Emeritus Benedict XVI, whose resignation paved the way for the conclave that brought the first Jesuit to the papacy.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: "You know that the work of the conclave is to give a bishop to Rome," Francis said.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: "It seems as if my brother cardinals went to find him from the end of the earth.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: Thank you for the welcome."

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: Bergoglio has shown a keen political sensibility as well as the kind of self-effacing humility that fellow cardinals value highly, according to his official biographer, Sergio Rubin.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: He showed that humility on Wednesday, saying that before he blessed the crowd he wanted their prayers for him and bowed his head.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: "Good night, and have a good rest," he said before going back into the palace.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: In a lifetime of teaching and leading priests in Latin America, which has the largest share of the world's Catholics, Francis has been known for modernizing an Argentine church that had been among the most conservative in Latin America.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: Like other Jesuit intellectuals, Bergoglio has focused on social outreach.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: Catholics are still buzzing over his speech last year accusing fellow church officials of hypocrisy for forgetting that Jesus Christ bathed lepers and ate with prostitutes.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: Francis, the son of middle-class Italian immigrants, is known as a humble man who denied himself the luxuries that previous Buenos Aires cardinals enjoyed.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: Bergoglio often rode the bus to work, cooked his own meals and regularly visited the slums that ring Argentina's capital.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: He came close to becoming pope in 2005, reportedly gaining the second-highest vote total in several rounds of voting before he bowed out of the running in the conclave that elected Pope Benedict XVI.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: American Cardinal Timothy Dolan gave an inside glimpse into the drama of the conclave in his talk at the American seminary.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: When the tally reached the necessary 77 votes to make Bergoglio pope, Dolan said, the cardinals erupted in applause.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: And when he accepted the momentous responsibility thrust upon him -- ''there wasn't a dry eye in the place," Dolan recounted.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: After the princes of the church had congratulated the new pope one by one, other Vatican officials wanted to do the same, but Francis preferred to go outside and greet the throngs of faithful.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: ''Maybe we should go to the balcony first," Dolan recalled the pope as saying.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: Elected on the fifth ballot, Francis was chosen in one of the fastest conclaves in years, remarkable given there was no clear front-runner going into the vote and that the church had been in turmoil following the upheaval unleashed by Benedict's surprise resignation.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: For comparison's sake, Benedict was elected on the fourth ballot in 2005 -- but he was the clear front-runner going into the vote.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: Pope John Paul II was elected on the eighth ballot in 1978 to become the first non-Italian pope in 455 years.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: In choosing to call himself Francis, the new pope was linking himself with the much-loved Italian saint from Assisi associated with peace, poverty and simplicity.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: St. Francis was born to a wealthy family but later renounced his wealth and founded the Franciscan order of friars; he wandered about the countryside preaching to the people in very simple language.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: He was so famed for his sanctity that he was canonized just two years after his death in 1226.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: Francis will be installed officially as pope on Tuesday, on the feast of St. Joseph, patron saint of the universal church, according to Vatican spokesman Lombardi.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: Lombardi, also a Jesuit, said he was particularly stunned by the election given that Jesuits typically shun positions of authority in the church, instead offering their work in service to those in power.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: But Lombardi said that in accepting the election, Francis must have felt it "a strong call to service," an antidote to all those who speculated that the papacy was about a search for power.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: In an interesting twist the Jesuits were expelled from all of the Americas in the mid-18th century.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: Now, a Latin American Jesuit has been elected head of the 1.2-billion strong Catholic Church.

column3: Argentine Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio named new pope
column4: The Associated Press contributed to this report.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: ROME — The surprise selection on Wednesday of an Argentine, Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergoglio, as the new pope shifted the gravity of the Roman Catholic Church from Europe to Latin America in one fell swoop, and served as an emphatic salute to the growing power of Latinos across the Americas.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: The new pope took the name Francis and is the 266th pontiff of the church.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: He is the first pope from Latin America, and the first member of the Jesuit order to lead the church.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: “I would like to thank you for your embrace,” the new pope, dressed in white, said in Italian from the balcony on St. Peter’s Basilica as thousands cheered joyously below.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: “My brother cardinals have chosen one who is from far away, but here I am.” The selection electrified Latinos from Los Angeles to Buenos Aires, and raised the hopes especially of those in Latin America, where 4 of every 10 of the world’s Catholics now live.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: But the choice also may provide a strategic boost to the church in the United States, where its following would have lost ground in recent decades were it not for the influx of Latino immigrants, who have increasingly asserted themselves as a cultural and political force, and played a critical role in President Obama’s re-election.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: The significance of the choice was not lost on church leaders.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: “It’s been more than 500 years since the first evangelization, and this is the first time that there is a pope from Latin America,” said Archbishop Jose Gomez of Los Angeles, who is originally from Mexico.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: “It’s a huge role that we never had before,” he said.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: The new pope, known for his simple, pastoral ways and his connection to the poor, is in some ways a contrast to his predecessor, Benedict XVI, an aloof theologian who resigned the office — the first pope to do so in 598 years — saying he no longer felt up to the rigors of the job.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: But Francis shares Benedict’s core doctrinal positions and is not considered likely to push changes in positions like the church’s ban on the ordination of women as priests or its strict opposition to abortion and gay marriage.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: The choice of Francis, who is 76, also defied some predictions that the 115 cardinals would opt for a young pope who could energize the church at a time when it faces a shortage of priests, growing competition from evangelical churches in the Southern Hemisphere, a sexual abuse crisis that has undermined the church’s moral authority in the West and difficulties governing the Vatican itself.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: Pope Francis spoke by telephone with Benedict, now known as pope emeritus, on Wednesday evening, said a Vatican spokesman, the Rev.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: Federico Lombardi.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: He called it, “an act of great significance and pastorality” that Francis’ first act as pope was to offer a prayer for his predecessor.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: Cardinal Timothy Dolan of New York told reporters he had heard that Francis would visit Benedict soon, although the Vatican did not include the visit on the new pope’s schedule for this week.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: Italian news media reported that the visit would take place in the next few days and would be televised.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: Mr. Obama was among the first world leaders to congratulate Francis in a message that emphasized the pope’s humble roots and New World origins.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: “As the first pope from the Americas,” the president said, “his selection also speaks to the strength and vitality of a region that is increasingly shaping our world, and alongside millions of Hispanic Americans, those of us in the United States share the joy of this historic day.” The cardinals could have chosen a pope from a country in Africa or Asia where Catholic converts are plentiful and the church is vibrant.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: Instead, they selected a cardinal from Argentina, to the surprise of even those who had hoped for a non-European.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: “An Argentine!

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: I can’t believe it,” said Gaston Aquino, a seminarian from Argentina standing in the packed crowd in St. Peter’s Square in Rome as the name of the new pope was announced from the balcony above.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: “Bergoglio, pope!” he marveled.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: “I think it will mean great joy” for Argentina.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: Catholics in the United States are holding steady at about a quarter of the population, and about one-third of those are Latinos.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: In Latin America, the church is confronting many of the same cultural and political battles as it is in Europe and the United States: a rise in acceptance of gay relationships, abortion and birth control, and a growing tide of people abandoning the church and professing no religion.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: The Rev.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: Luis Calero, a Jesuit priest and professor of anthropology at Santa Clara University in California who studies the church in Central and South America said: “A lot of Catholics are leaving the Catholic church in Latin America to go to evangelical and Pentecostal churches.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: They no longer find a home in Catholic Christianity.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: “Going to a traditional parish is no longer fulfilling to them because the parish is impersonal,” he said.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: “It tends to not have a sense of community that is uplifting.” Father Calero said the next pope might be able to turn the situation around if he could respond to what he said were the most pressing problems: poverty, pluralism and the shortage of priests because of the church’s requirement of clerical celibacy.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: The choice of Cardinal Bergoglio at least initially appeared to be celebrated across the continent.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: There had been faint hope in Mexico that the next pope would be Cardinal José Francisco Robles Ortega, the archbishop of Guadalajara, who was mentioned in Italian newspapers in the past week as a candidate gaining steam.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: But many Mexican were joyous nonetheless, with newspapers playing up the historical turn of a Latin American assuming the throne of Peter.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: “It fills us with joy because he is close to the Latin American people,” Msgr.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: Eugenio Lira, the secretary general of the Mexican Conference of Bishops, told reporters.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: “He could be sensitive to economic conditions and the suffering, joys and hope of people in these lands.” The choice also points to challenges faced by the church in some parts of Latin America, like Portuguese-speaking Brazil, the country with the world’s largest concentration of Catholics, where evangelical churches have made big inroads in recent decades.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: In Argentina itself, a nation historically seen as more Europeanized than its neighbors, the church is grappling with a declining number of Catholics who regularly attend mass.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: Cardinal Dolan said in an interview after the conclave that “Catholic is part of their DNA” in Argentina.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: With Cardinal Bergoglio as pope, he said, “think of the electricity that is going to send.” But he said that country of origin was not the main factor for the cardinals who elected him.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: “Most cardinals just want to choose the right man,” he said.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: The pope should be a good pastor, governor and communicator.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: “He fills those bills.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: Where he comes from is gravy.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: And we’ve got a lot of good gravy.” Enrique Krauze, a Mexican historian and political analyst, said there would be an expectation in Latin America for a pope from the region to promote democracy and human rights.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: “If the church plays a role in favor of democracy and human rights as it played in Chile during the Pinochet regime, then the pope will be a factor in civic progress in these countries,” he said.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: “If the church takes up the banner of freedom it would be a great benefit in this continent that is the reservoir of Catholicism in the world.” Outside St. Matthew Catholic School in West Phoenix, where she had gone to pick up her children, Deana Silva, 27, said, “I didn’t really connect with the other pope,” but “Papa Francisco,” or Pope Francis, “is different.” He is “more like us, you know, Latino,” Ms. Silva said.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: Her mother, Donna Reyes, 46, said she was “very excited.” “We had been watching and waiting,” said Ms. Reyes, whose parents were immigrants from Mexico.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: “There are a lot of us Latinos in the Catholic Church.

column3: New Pope Shifts Church's Center of Gravity Away From Europe
column4: It was nice that the Church finally recognized it.” As the children lined up to leave school, someone said a prayer and made an announcement about Lent over the loudspeakers, then, in Spanish, greeted the new pope, “el primer Papa de las Americas,” the first pope from the Americas.

column3: Obama meets with House Republicans, downplays 'immediate' debt crisis
column4: President Obama met Wednesday with House Republicans in an apparent bid to find consensus on fiscal policy, even as he seemed to antagonize the other side by claiming there's no "immediate crisis in terms of debt."

column3: Obama meets with House Republicans, downplays 'immediate' debt crisis
column4: His statement would be sharply at odds with a core Republican principle that the debt must be addressed soon -- and which underpinned the cost-cutting GOP budget released Tuesday.

column3: Obama meets with House Republicans, downplays 'immediate' debt crisis
column4: The president also acknowledged, in an interview aired earlier in the day, that differences with the GOP might be "too wide" to bridge.

column3: Obama meets with House Republicans, downplays 'immediate' debt crisis
column4: Still, the president made the rare visit with House Republicans on Capitol Hill as part of what some are calling his charm offensive.

column3: Obama meets with House Republicans, downplays 'immediate' debt crisis
column4: The president is making a renewed effort to meet with Republican leaders and rank-and-file lawmakers amid overlapping budget battles and a series of deadlines on the horizon.

column3: Obama meets with House Republicans, downplays 'immediate' debt crisis
column4: The president is trying to find common ground with Congress in order to halt the sequester spending cuts, which have already taken effect -- as well as pass a stopgap budget bill in order to avert an end-of-the-month government shutdown, pass a bona fide budget for next year and once again raise the debt ceiling.

column3: Obama meets with House Republicans, downplays 'immediate' debt crisis
column4: A source in the room during the meeting with Republicans told Fox News that Obama told them he's looking for bipartisanship on a range of issues, including fiscal matters, immigration, gun regulation and foreign policy.

column3: Obama meets with House Republicans, downplays 'immediate' debt crisis
column4: One skeptical source told Fox News, "we shall see."

column3: Obama meets with House Republicans, downplays 'immediate' debt crisis
column4: Rep. Paul Ryan, R-Wis., though, later emerged saying the president "did himself some good."

column3: Obama meets with House Republicans, downplays 'immediate' debt crisis
column4: Obama went into the meeting with his aides and allies ripping House Republicans for their newly introduced budget, which aims to balance the country's finances in 10 years.

column3: Obama meets with House Republicans, downplays 'immediate' debt crisis
column4: In an interview with ABC News, the president declared that there is no "immediate" debt crisis and that "for the next 10 years, it's going to be in a sustainable place."

column3: Obama meets with House Republicans, downplays 'immediate' debt crisis
column4: That message is likely to rile Republicans, who cite widespread economic warnings in saying the debt -- which is nearing $17 trillion -- must be addressed.

column3: Obama meets with House Republicans, downplays 'immediate' debt crisis
column4: "We are addressing the most predictable debt crisis in this country's history," Ryan, chairman of the House Budget Committee, said Tuesday while introducing his budget plan, which was approved by the House panel by a 22-17 party-line vote.

column3: Obama meets with House Republicans, downplays 'immediate' debt crisis
column4: White House Press Secretary Jay Carney said Wednesday that "everybody" recognizes there is a "long-term debt challenge."

column3: Obama meets with House Republicans, downplays 'immediate' debt crisis
column4: And he said the president "believes that bipartisan cooperation is possible."

column3: Obama meets with House Republicans, downplays 'immediate' debt crisis
column4: Senate Democrats were unveiling their budget proposal Wednesday afternoon, in response to the House Republican plan introduced Tuesday.

column3: Obama meets with House Republicans, downplays 'immediate' debt crisis
column4: The plan calls for $975 billion in new tax revenue through closing loopholes and ending deductions and credits benefiting corporations and the country’s highest wage earners.

column3: Obama meets with House Republicans, downplays 'immediate' debt crisis
column4: It also calls for $100 billion in new stimulus spending while cutting $1.85 trillion from the deficit over 10 years.

column3: Obama meets with House Republicans, downplays 'immediate' debt crisis
column4: The rest of the savings would come through spending cuts.

column3: Obama meets with House Republicans, downplays 'immediate' debt crisis
column4: Senate Budget Committee members will begin voting and submitting amendments Thursday, with a full Senate vote expected by next week.

column3: Obama meets with House Republicans, downplays 'immediate' debt crisis
column4: The Republican plan touts longstanding party proposals to cut funding for domestic programs, repeal Obama's health care reform law and overhaul the Medicare health care program for the elderly.

column3: Obama meets with House Republicans, downplays 'immediate' debt crisis
column4: It would balance the federal budget in 10 years with steep spending cuts alone -- a nonstarter with Democrats.

column3: Obama meets with House Republicans, downplays 'immediate' debt crisis
column4: "Ultimately, it may be that the differences are just too wide," Obama said in the interview broadcast Wednesday.

column3: Obama meets with House Republicans, downplays 'immediate' debt crisis
column4: If Republicans insist that their only solution is to avoid tax hikes and "gut" entitlement programs, "then we're probably not going to be able to get a deal," he said.

column3: Obama meets with House Republicans, downplays 'immediate' debt crisis
column4: Obama has continued reaching out to lawmakers in hopes that he can somehow reach a "grand bargain" that reins in deficit spending without hurting the economy and stops Washington from lurching from one self-induced fiscal crisis to another.

column3: Obama meets with House Republicans, downplays 'immediate' debt crisis
column4: The fence-mending campaign started with an unusual dinner Obama hosted last week at a hotel near the White House for a dozen Senate Republicans and continues Wednesday with his meeting with House Republicans.

column3: Obama meets with House Republicans, downplays 'immediate' debt crisis
column4: Obama, who also will meet with Senate Republicans and House Democrats on Thursday, has shown a willingness to reduce spending on big entitlement programs but has not agreed to the kinds of changes Ryan and other Republicans have sought.

column3: Obama meets with House Republicans, downplays 'immediate' debt crisis
column4: Republicans, however, object to any more tax increases, insisting that Obama got his way with tax hikes on top earners in the New Year's Day deal that averted the "fiscal cliff."

column3: Obama meets with House Republicans, downplays 'immediate' debt crisis
column4: That last-minute deal prevented automatic tax hikes for all federal income tax payers, but merely delayed $85 billion in across-the-board spending cuts.

column3: Obama meets with House Republicans, downplays 'immediate' debt crisis
column4: The parties were unable to reach a compromise on a deficit-cutting plan, so the automatic spending cuts began taking effect March 1 and are set to continue through the decade.

column3: Obama meets with House Republicans, downplays 'immediate' debt crisis
column4: The Associated Press contributed to this report.

column3: Official worried about cyber attacks on US nuclear command and control
column4: Air Force Gen. C. Robert Kehler said during a hearing of the Senate Armed Services Committee that nuclear weapons and the communications used to control them are older and thus less vulnerable to disruption by computer network attacks.

column3: Official worried about cyber attacks on US nuclear command and control
column4: "However, we are very concerned with the potential of a cyber related attack on our nuclear command and control and on the weapons systems themselves," Kehler said.

column3: Official worried about cyber attacks on US nuclear command and control
column4: "We do evaluate that."

column3: Official worried about cyber attacks on US nuclear command and control
column4: The four-star general was responding to questions about the security of nuclear controls outlined in a Defense Science Board report.

column3: Official worried about cyber attacks on US nuclear command and control
column4: The report from January stated that U.S. nuclear forces are regularly assessed for their reliability and readiness but said "most of the systems have not been assessed against a sophisticated cyberattack to understand possible weak spots."

column3: Official worried about cyber attacks on US nuclear command and control
column4: Click for more from The Washington Free Beacon.

column3: Obama to Dems: Trade entitlements for taxes
column4: Updated 03/13/2013 06:28 AM EDT President Barack Obama told Senate Democrats on Tuesday that his budget to be released in April would align closely with their priorities.

column3: Obama to Dems: Trade entitlements for taxes
column4: He also warned that Democrats need to embrace at least some changes to unsustainable entitlement programs in order to achieve their long-term priorities.

column3: Obama to Dems: Trade entitlements for taxes
column4: Story Continued Below The president made the case, senators attending the luncheon said, to protect entitlements for future generations — a key Democratic priority in negotiations with Republicans over a deficit reduction deal known as a grand bargain.

column3: Obama to Dems: Trade entitlements for taxes
column4: ( Also on POLITICO: Paul Ryan budget: Challenge to White House, DOA in Senate) But Obama acknowledged that Social Security and Medicare — big drivers of federal spending — wouldn’t survive without some changes to save money.

column3: Obama to Dems: Trade entitlements for taxes
column4: Obama added that Republicans must first agree to more revenue hikes before the White House would concede on changes to entitlement programs, senators attending the luncheon said.

column3: Obama to Dems: Trade entitlements for taxes
column4: Obama seemed to be opening the door a crack toward a way forward: if the White House is seen as willing to put entitlements on the table, some Republicans may reconsider their staunch opposition to new revenue.

column3: Obama to Dems: Trade entitlements for taxes
column4: Obama told Senate Democrats that he sees his framework — a mix of new revenues and spending cuts — as a big enough compromise.

column3: Obama to Dems: Trade entitlements for taxes
column4: He said Republicans will need to move toward him to obtain a grand bargain, which he sees as the way out of the sequester, Sen. Tom Harkin (D-Iowa) said.

column3: Obama to Dems: Trade entitlements for taxes
column4: Obama also reiterated that he isn’t going to negotiate over the next debt ceiling increase, slated to come up this summer.

column3: Obama to Dems: Trade entitlements for taxes
column4: “I think the president made it clear he understands the framework of a major [budget] agreement,” Sen. Ron Wyden (D-Ore.) said.

column3: Obama to Dems: Trade entitlements for taxes
column4: “It’s got to be this idea of common ground… That’s [the] basis of his outreach to senators and [House members].

column3: Obama to Dems: Trade entitlements for taxes
column4: He’s going to be doing a lot of eating on the Hill this week.” Whether both sides can reach a deal that includes entitlement changes and new tax dollars may become clearer on Wednesday, as the president meets with House Republicans.

column3: Obama to Dems: Trade entitlements for taxes
column4: Obama completes his Hill tour on Thursday with meetings with House Democrats and Senate Republicans.

column3: Obama to Dems: Trade entitlements for taxes
column4: Obama’s blunt talk on entitlements doesn’t mean that Senate Democrats are on board.

column3: Obama to Dems: Trade entitlements for taxes
column4: Several members in the meeting spoke up about the concerns that changes to the programs would be part of a deal, attendees said.

column3: Obama to Dems: Trade entitlements for taxes
column4: “He said he hoped we can reach some sort of grand bargain,” Harkin said.

column3: Obama to Dems: Trade entitlements for taxes
column4: “Of course some of us responded by say, ‘Yes, but what is in that grand bargain?’ We don’t want to start whacking away at Social Security or Medicare.” According to Harkin, Sen. Carl Levin (D-Mich.) asked the president about his plans to switch to a “chained-CPI,” which would lower the rate at which Social Security benefits are increased and cut the cost of the program in the long run.

column3: Obama to Dems: Trade entitlements for taxes
column4: “We’re not going to go so far as to negotiate away our principals and what we think is best,” Harkin said.

column3: Obama to Dems: Trade entitlements for taxes
column4: “When you’re talking about entitlements, Social Security, Medicaid, Medicare, there is more than one way to solve that problem.” ( Also on POLITICO: Patty Murray budget: $1 trillion in new revenue) Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.) said that House Republicans have never gone beyond broad discussions about entitlement programs and that their talk has been used to argue Obama would agree to changes.

column3: Obama to Dems: Trade entitlements for taxes
column4: “Here’s the issue — the president in the past in personal negotiations with Boehner, Biden, in personal negotiations with Cantor has indicated that they would be willing to do certain things,” Reid told reporters after the meeting.

column3: Obama to Dems: Trade entitlements for taxes
column4: “The Republicans never get further than that.”

column3: Jeb Bush: Not much daylight between immigration plans
column4: Former Florida Gov.

column3: Jeb Bush: Not much daylight between immigration plans
column4: Jeb Bush, blanketing the Sunday talk shows, vigorously denied charges leveled at him in the past week that he’s shifted his views on immigration reform as other Republicans eyeing potential 2016 presidential bids jockey for position on the issue.

column3: Jeb Bush: Not much daylight between immigration plans
column4: Mr. Bush said he still favors a pathway to citizenship for illegal immigrants and is on the same page with a bipartisan group of senators crafting such a bill after his new book outlining a “pathway to residency” for those in the country illegally drew fire from both the right and the left last week.

column3: Jeb Bush: Not much daylight between immigration plans
column4: “I … think that a path to citizenship, so long as the ability of someone to come legally is easier and less costly than coming illegally, then a path to citizenship is appropriate, and I applaud the work of the senators and others in the Congress that are working to try to craft a consensus and a compromise on this issue,” Mr. Bush said on “Fox News Sunday.” SPECIAL COVERAGE: Immigration Reform But in his new book, “Immigration Wars: Forging an American Solution,” Mr. Bush writes that he favors a path to residency, rather than citizenship, for the estimated 11 million illegal immigrants already in the country, and that they should have to leave the country and reapply if they truly want to get U.S. citizenship.

column3: Jeb Bush: Not much daylight between immigration plans
column4: Sen. Lindsey Graham, South Carolina Republican and a member of the “Gang of Eight,” said last week that such a stance “undercuts” what the senators are trying to accomplish.

column3: Jeb Bush: Not much daylight between immigration plans
column4: But Mr. Bush said he had talked with Mr. Graham and they are on the same page — and that his views on the issue have been consistent despite backing a pathway to citizenship earlier in his career.

column3: Jeb Bush: Not much daylight between immigration plans
column4: “I haven’t changed,” he said on CBS’ “Face the Nation.” “I support a path to legalization or citizenship so long as the path for people that have been waiting patiently is easier and costs less, the legal entrance to our country, than illegal entrance.” Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, Nevada Democrat, disagreed.

column3: Jeb Bush: Not much daylight between immigration plans
column4: “Let’s wait for a few minutes and see how Jeb Bush changes his mind, again,” Mr. Reid told reporters last week.

column3: Jeb Bush: Not much daylight between immigration plans
column4: “His opinion on immigration is not evolving; it’s devolving.

column3: Jeb Bush: Not much daylight between immigration plans
column4: He keeps going backwards.” President Obama, who had pledged to pass comprehensive immigration reform in his first term, has made the issue one of his top priorities for his second.

column3: Jeb Bush: Not much daylight between immigration plans
column4: But Republicans working on the issue have a tricky needle to thread between distancing themselves from the president and potentially alienating Latino voters.

column3: Jeb Bush: Not much daylight between immigration plans
column4: Republican Sens.

column3: Jeb Bush: Not much daylight between immigration plans
column4: Marco Rubio of Florida and Rand Paul of Kentucky immediately blasted a framework for immigration reform leaked by the White House last month that included a path to citizenship as part of the plan.

column3: Jeb Bush: Not much daylight between immigration plans
column4: Mr. Rubio has been widely viewed as a potential 2016 nominee, and Mr. Paul’s stock rose tremendously in that regard after waging a filibuster that lasted nearly 13 hours last week and ended up as a scathing critique of the White House’s policy on drone aircraft.

column3: Jeb Bush: Not much daylight between immigration plans
column4: Mr. Rubio, whose parents emigrated to the United States from Cuba, favors a pathway to citizenship for those currently in the country illegally, and Mr. Bush said his views “absolutely” coincide with those.

column3: Jeb Bush: Not much daylight between immigration plans
column4: “I applaud what Senator Rubio’s doing, the other members of the so-called Gang of Eight — they’re making a major contribution,” Mr. Bush said on “Face the Nation.” “And there’s also efforts in the House of Representatives as well.

column3: Jeb Bush: Not much daylight between immigration plans
column4: This is a very encouraging time, because if we can get immigration right, imagine, there’s possibilities of cats and dogs living with one another in other policy areas as well.” But Mr. Bush flatly dismissed the notion that the events of the past week or his book had anything to do with political maneuvering for the 2016 Republican presidential nomination.

column3: Jeb Bush: Not much daylight between immigration plans
column4: “Yeah, see, that’s the Washington world, the world of everything has to have a personal political ambition, motive,” he said.

column3: Jeb Bush: Not much daylight between immigration plans
column4: “That’s not the case.

column3: Jeb Bush: Not much daylight between immigration plans
column4: The book was written last year at a time when the tenor of the debate on immigration was dramatically different than it is today.”

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: BERKELEY, Calif. NEARLY 700 miles of walls now separate the United States and Mexico.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: Would-be migrants still find ways over, under, through and around them.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: As a tool for controlling immigration to the United States, the border fortifications have been remarkably ill suited to the task.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: And yet these barriers are having a significant and lasting effect nonetheless: they are harming communities on both sides of the border.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: We should tear them down before the damage becomes irreparable.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: After Sept. 11, 2001, President George W. Bush instructed the Department of Homeland Security to prioritize the construction of fortifications along the Mexican border.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: The result has been an astonishing array of barriers across America’s southern frontier.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: The number of Border Patrol agents doubled in seven years to more than 21,000.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: And interior enforcement was expanded to identify, detain, prosecute and deport undocumented migrants.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: From the numbers, it might seem as if such efforts have worked to stem illegal immigration.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: Today, Border Patrol apprehensions have fallen to levels seen in the mid-1970s.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: But evidence suggests this decline has less to do with tightened enforcement than with economic factors: the reductions have been driven largely by weak job prospects in the United States and a resurgent economy in Mexico, which have kept more would-be migrants at home.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: Even so, President Obama has continued most of Mr. Bush’s programs — and, in fact, increased deportations to nearly 410,000 in 2012, the highest number ever.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: The vast majority of these deportations were to Mexico.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: Two principal agencies, Immigration and Customs Enforcement and Customs and Border Protection, spent nearly $18 billion in 2012 — enforcing what Janet Napolitano, the secretary of Homeland Security, calls a no-nonsense approach to immigration.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: Such an effort is necessary, she said, in order for voters to support comprehensive immigration reform, including a pathway to citizenship for some 11 million undocumented immigrants.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: But rather than no-nonsense, America’s approach to building walls has been nonsensical.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: Along the river boundary, the wide meanders of the Rio Grande made it impossible to build a continuous, straight-line fence.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: So the barriers were constructed north of the river — slicing off part of a nature reserve here, a few holes of a golf course there and cutting a university campus in two.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: United States citizens stranded on the “Mexican side” of the interior divide wonder if they now live in Mexico.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: Barriers in Texas, moreover, are disproportionately located in poor and minority communities — a pattern that is so clear that it sometimes becomes farcical: plans for one fence, for instance, show it ending abruptly at the edge of a billionaire’s property.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: Inside Arizona, checkpoints have been established on major freeways.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: Posted signs report the number of arrests made and kilos of narcotics seized, but many commuters are just plain irritated by the delays.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: Government agencies have arrived to enforce immigration law, and some Arizonans have taken to welcoming visitors to their “police state.” Many locals lost patience with a pilot project to build nine surveillance towers north of the borderline, complaining that the cameras were pointed at them, not toward Mexico.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: Members of the Tohono O’odham Nation, whose territory is bisected by the international boundary, have felt especially aggrieved by what they view as a reoccupation of their land by federal agents.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: In California, during the fence-building frenzy of 2009, I met a Border Patrol agent and project engineer at Smuggler’s Gulch — a deep canyon near the Pacific Ocean where the Department of Homeland Security had dumped in an estimated 2 million cubic yards of dirt and then fenced in the landfill to prevent access from Mexico.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: The canyon stream still flowed across the border, so engineers built a tunnel under the landfill to permit the water’s passage.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: The tunnel entrance and exit were gated, but the agent predicted that migrants would soon use the tunnel to cross.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: “Ninety percent of this is politics,” said the engineer.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: Borderlanders have done their best to adjust to this increasingly bizarre world.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: Crossing times at the border first doubled, then tripled, from what they had been before the fences, but people learned to factor the holdups into their commute times.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: Television news programs even began reporting crossing delays along with the weather report.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: Such adjustments, though, barely mitigate the outrage that many Americans feel toward the encroachment of hideous barriers into their once open land.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: Nor do these daily adjustments change the fact that the border fence is harming an ancient human ecosystem.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: Mutual interdependence has always been a hallmark of cross-border lives.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: Residents on both sides of the line regard parts of Mexico and the United States as their home.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: For them, the border is a connective membrane, not a line of demarcation.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: Often describing themselves as “transborder citizens,” they have more in common with one another than with their host nations.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: Besides sentiments of belonging and shared destiny, this “third nation,” as it is known, is bolstered by synergistic local economies.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: Border states are among the fastest-growing regions in both countries.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: Ciudad Juárez, once a city of 1.5 million, lost about a quarter-million inhabitants who fled from drug cartel-related violence to various destinations across Mexico.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: Yet the city’s industries continue to add jobs, fostering some $80 billion in trade between Juárez and neighboring El Paso in 2011, a $10 billion increase from the previous year.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: In El Paso, the arrival of 30,000 sanctuary seekers from Juárez created a boom in real estate and restaurant businesses.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: Cross-border institutions also reinforce binational ties.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: For more than a century, the International Boundary and Water Commission, with representatives from the United States and Mexico, has overseen water issues along the border and supported joint development projects.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: The border fence, however, undermines this cooperation and cohesion, as it splinters lives and scars landscapes.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: Likewise, to many who live here, the border patrols, with their ever watching drones, feel more like an occupying army.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: Add to this the enormous expense of maintaining the fortifications — estimated to be $6.5 billion over the next 20 years — and it’s clear that the costs of these structures far outweigh any benefit they offer in deterring illegal immigration.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: We can prevent further waste by just demolishing the Mexico-United States Barrier today.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: Of course, whether we act boldly now or not, it will eventually come down, just as other barriers have fallen.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: The Berlin Wall was demolished virtually overnight, its fragments sold as souvenirs of a bygone cold war.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: When it is finally recognized for what it is — a manifestation of a failed immigration policy — our border fence will fall to angry residents, avid recyclers and souvenir hunters.

column3: Mr. President, Tear Down This Wall
column4: When that happens, someone ought to preserve a few sections for the Smithsonian, to mark the moment when America’s national identity is again defined by something more durable than a strip of steel.

column4: President Obama ramped up his GOP charm offensive last week with lunch and dinner dates with congressional Republicans.

column4: But really, it was all just the appetizer.

column4: now."

column3: Why President ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s charm offensive is headed for pressure testing Ã¢â‚¬â€ right away
column4: That's because this week could well reveal more than any period since the president was reelected about whether the White House and congressional Republicans can even begin to talk about working toward a landmark deal to rein in the nation's deficit or whether efforts will, once again, fall short.

column3: Why President ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s charm offensive is headed for pressure testing Ã¢â‚¬â€ right away
column4: And given both what's happened before and what's coming up, there are plenty of reasons to have more faith in the latter scenario -- at least for now.

column4: Let's start with what's coming up this week.

column4: Obama is slated to meet with congressional Republicans and Democrats on Capitol Hill, following up on the more informal meetings he hosted last week.

column3: Why President ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s charm offensive is headed for pressure testing Ã¢â‚¬â€ right away
column4: Given the extent to which relations between GOP leaders and Obama have deteriorated over the years, this is a rare occasion.

column4: And it's one that could mark the last best chance to kick-start talks.

column3: Why President ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s charm offensive is headed for pressure testing Ã¢â‚¬â€ right away
column4: If post-meeting chatter is positive from both sides, it will bode well for bipartisanship.

column3: Why President ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s charm offensive is headed for pressure testing Ã¢â‚¬â€ right away
column4: If not, the ship could be sunk before it leaves port.

column3: Why President ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s charm offensive is headed for pressure testing Ã¢â‚¬â€ right away
column4: In the House, Rep. Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) will release his latest budget blueprint, which he previewed on Sunday.

column3: Why President ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s charm offensive is headed for pressure testing Ã¢â‚¬â€ right away
column4: The plan will propose revamping Medicare and Medicaid and will aim to balance the budget in 10 years, a more ambitious benchmark than previous versions introduced by the House Budget Committee chairman.

column3: Why President ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s charm offensive is headed for pressure testing Ã¢â‚¬â€ right away
column4: And it will propose to repeal Obama's health-care law, basically a futile aim given Democratic control of the Senate and White House.

column3: Why President ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s charm offensive is headed for pressure testing Ã¢â‚¬â€ right away
column4: What that all means is a proposal that is likely to reignite the Democratic pushback against Ryan's ideas that was ubiquitous in the 2012 campaign.

column3: Why President ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s charm offensive is headed for pressure testing Ã¢â‚¬â€ right away
column4: Senate Democrats are also set to release their budget blueprint, and a key question is whether their pitch can be reconciled with the House GOP plan in an agreement that is acceptable to both parties.

column3: Why President ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s charm offensive is headed for pressure testing Ã¢â‚¬â€ right away
column4: But given how far apart the two proposals will likely begin -- a commitment to repeal the health-care law that the Supreme Court has upheld doesn't exactly scream bipartisanship -- that could be a very tall order.

column3: Why President ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s charm offensive is headed for pressure testing Ã¢â‚¬â€ right away
column4: Finally, Senate Democrats will introduce their own continuing resolution to fund the government through the rest of the fiscal year.

column3: Why President ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s charm offensive is headed for pressure testing Ã¢â‚¬â€ right away
column4: The House passed its version last week.

column3: Why President ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s charm offensive is headed for pressure testing Ã¢â‚¬â€ right away
column4: Congress has until late this month to come to terms on a funding agreement.

column3: Why President ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s charm offensive is headed for pressure testing Ã¢â‚¬â€ right away
column4: And if they can't even do that, then, well, it goes without saying what it would suggest about the prospects of a longer-term budget deal.

column3: Why President ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s charm offensive is headed for pressure testing Ã¢â‚¬â€ right away
column4: All of which is enough reason for skepticism that real bipartisan accord can be reached.

column3: Why President ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s charm offensive is headed for pressure testing Ã¢â‚¬â€ right away
column4: But there's more.

column3: Why President ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s charm offensive is headed for pressure testing Ã¢â‚¬â€ right away
column4: Just look at what has -- or what hasn't -- happened in the past.

column3: Why President ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s charm offensive is headed for pressure testing Ã¢â‚¬â€ right away
column4: “I think he’s genuinely reaching out,” Sen. Tom Coburn (R-Okla.) said Sunday of Obama's outreach on NBC's “Meet The Press.” “But you know, you’ve got a lot of scabs and sores on people, and it’s going to take a while for that to heal.” He wasn't kidding.

column3: Why President ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s charm offensive is headed for pressure testing Ã¢â‚¬â€ right away
column4: Rewind to 2011, and you'll find a previous attempt at a "grand bargain" over the deficit that Obama and House Speaker John A. Boehner (R-Ohio) failed to reach.

column3: Why President ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s charm offensive is headed for pressure testing Ã¢â‚¬â€ right away
column4: Rewind to early 2013, and you'll find an agreement to avert the fiscal cliff that involved raising tax rates for the wealthiest Americans.

column3: Why President ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s charm offensive is headed for pressure testing Ã¢â‚¬â€ right away
column4: But since that deal, Republican leaders have stood firm against any new attempts to raise taxes, while Democrats haven't let up on their call to raise new tax revenue.

column3: Why President ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s charm offensive is headed for pressure testing Ã¢â‚¬â€ right away
column4: And on entitlements, a similar impasse can be found.

column3: Why President ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s charm offensive is headed for pressure testing Ã¢â‚¬â€ right away
column4: Ultimately, anything resembling a renewed "grand bargain" looks like it would require a "grand gesture" or "grand gestures" from one or both sides.

column3: Why President ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s charm offensive is headed for pressure testing Ã¢â‚¬â€ right away
column4: A concession on entitlements from Democrats, a willingness to accept new tax revenue from Republicans -- these are the types of big moves we're talking about.

column3: Why President ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s charm offensive is headed for pressure testing Ã¢â‚¬â€ right away
column4: To be clear, these aren't impossibilities.

column3: Why President ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s charm offensive is headed for pressure testing Ã¢â‚¬â€ right away
column4: But they are a long way from being realities, until further progress is made.

column3: Why President ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s charm offensive is headed for pressure testing Ã¢â‚¬â€ right away
column4: But that's why this week matters so much in the grand scheme of things.

column3: Why President ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s charm offensive is headed for pressure testing Ã¢â‚¬â€ right away
column4: If the two parties are going to defy the odds, it will have to begin ... now.

column3: As budget battles resume, Republicans hope Obama 'sincere' in compromise efforts
column4: Rep.Kevin McCarthy, R-Calif.,  (AP) After a week of President Obama extending lunch and dinner invites to congressional Republicans, ahead of the next budget battle, party leaders are expressing cautious optimism about the president being sincere – not just leading a so-called charm offensive.

column3: As budget battles resume, Republicans hope Obama 'sincere' in compromise efforts
column4: The invitations appear to be a change in political tactics for Obama, who since elected in 2008 has largely avoided courting Congress, preferring as of late to instead make his case to the public with campaign-style events.

column3: As budget battles resume, Republicans hope Obama 'sincere' in compromise efforts
column4: He also plans to keep up the effort this week with three scheduled trips to Capitol Hill to visit Democrats and Republicans in both chambers, a likely effort to broker a “grand bargain” on tax and spending instead of another short-term fix.

column3: As budget battles resume, Republicans hope Obama 'sincere' in compromise efforts
column4: "I hope that this is sincere," Republican Rep. Paul Ryan, chairman of the House Budget Committee, who had lunch Thursday with Obama at the White House, told “Fox News Sunday.” “We had a very good, frank exchange.

column3: As budget battles resume, Republicans hope Obama 'sincere' in compromise efforts
column4: But the proof will be in the coming weeks as to whether or not it's a real, sincere outreach to find common ground."

column3: As budget battles resume, Republicans hope Obama 'sincere' in compromise efforts
column4: Obama’s apparent courtship follows $85 billion in spending cuts this year that kicked in March 1 and before the next deadline, March 27, when the current short-term budget extension expires and a government shutdown looms.

column3: As budget battles resume, Republicans hope Obama 'sincere' in compromise efforts
column4: Ryan, R-Wis., also told Fox his proposal for 2014 would balance the federal budget in 10 years, but is based in part on repeal of the president’s Affordable Care Act, which appears unlikely.

column3: As budget battles resume, Republicans hope Obama 'sincere' in compromise efforts
column4: Though Republicans appeared optimistic, they also expressed concern that the president’s second-term efforts might be too late.

column3: As budget battles resume, Republicans hope Obama 'sincere' in compromise efforts
column4: “I think he is sincere,” said Oklahoma Sen. Tom Coburn, who attended the hotel dinner with 11 other Republican senators Wednesday night.

column3: As budget battles resume, Republicans hope Obama 'sincere' in compromise efforts
column4: “But you know, you’ve got a lot of scabs and sores on people,” Coburn told NBC’s “Meet the Press.” “And it’s going to take a while for that to heal.” The president will have to work quickly to achieve even a shorter-term deal, considering Congress is scheduled to leave town March 22.

column3: As budget battles resume, Republicans hope Obama 'sincere' in compromise efforts
column4: Senate Democrats said they already have a spending measure ready for passage that would pay for day-to-day federal operations through September.

column3: As budget battles resume, Republicans hope Obama 'sincere' in compromise efforts
column4: The measure would impose automatic cuts of 5 percent to domestic agencies and 7.8 percent to the Pentagon.

column3: As budget battles resume, Republicans hope Obama 'sincere' in compromise efforts
column4: Virginia Democratic Sen. Tim Kaine said Sunday that leaders of the Democrat-controlled Senate also are working on full budget for passage, the first in four years.

column3: As budget battles resume, Republicans hope Obama 'sincere' in compromise efforts
column4: And he expressed optimism about an eventual Hill deal.

column3: As budget battles resume, Republicans hope Obama 'sincere' in compromise efforts
column4: “The two (chambers’) budgets will be different,” he told NBC’s “Meet the Press.” “We're going to have to find a balanced solution, and it will involve all elements.

column3: As budget battles resume, Republicans hope Obama 'sincere' in compromise efforts
column4: It will involve talking about revenues, talking about expenses, talking about entitlements.

column3: As budget battles resume, Republicans hope Obama 'sincere' in compromise efforts
column4: We have to do that.” Still, some Republicans seem unconvinced about the president's recent efforts.

column3: As budget battles resume, Republicans hope Obama 'sincere' in compromise efforts
column4: "I hope that he's genuine,” Rep. Cory Gardner, R-Colo., told NBC.

column3: As budget battles resume, Republicans hope Obama 'sincere' in compromise efforts
column4: “But I don't think we're going to be doing the Harlem Shake any time soon together."

column3: As budget battles resume, Republicans hope Obama 'sincere' in compromise efforts
column4: Republican Whip Kevin McCarthy question whether Obama’s efforts were about winning over the Republican-controlled House or “governing for all of America.” “Only time will tell,” the California congressman told CNN’s “State of the Union.” The Associated Press contributed to this story.

column3: Ryan: New House Republican budget includes ObamaCare repeal
column4: Wisconsin Rep. Paul Ryan, chairman of the House Budget Committee, said Sunday that his new budget includes the repeal of President Obama’s health-care reform law known as ObamaCare.

column3: Ryan: New House Republican budget includes ObamaCare repeal
column4: Ryan told “Fox News Sunday” that the new proposal will make enough cuts to balance the federal budget in 10 years, compared to his previous one that tried to achieve that goal in 25 years.

column3: Ryan: New House Republican budget includes ObamaCare repeal
column4: “We think we owe the American people a balanced budget,” the Republican congressman said.

column3: Ryan: New House Republican budget includes ObamaCare repeal
column4: Ryan said the focus of the ObamaCare repeal would be to stop the expansion of Medicaid, the federal program that provides medical services to low-income U.S. families.

column3: Ryan: New House Republican budget includes ObamaCare repeal
column4: “Our budget does promote repealing ObamaCare and replacing it with a better system,” said Ryan, who did not say whether his 2014 budget is based on a full repeal.

column3: Ryan: New House Republican budget includes ObamaCare repeal
column4: Ryan, the Republican 2012 vice presidential nominee, said he wants states to run Medicaid through federal block grants.

column3: Ryan: New House Republican budget includes ObamaCare repeal
column4: Ryan said his proposal attempts to reach a balanced budget, in part, by slowing the rate of federal spending from 4.9 percent to 3.4 percent.

column3: Ryan: New House Republican budget includes ObamaCare repeal
column4: Other parts include consolidating federal job-training programs and reforming the federal Food Stamps program to ensure only qualified applicants receive the benefits.

column3: Ryan: New House Republican budget includes ObamaCare repeal
column4: “I’ve very confident this is the way to go,” said Ryan, whose budget would have a better chance of passing the Republican-controlled House than the Democrat-controlled Senate.

column3: Paul Ryan: Budget blueprint will promote repealing health care law
column4: Rep. Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) said Sunday that the budget blueprint he plans to unveil later this week will promote repealing President Obama's signature health care law.

column3: Paul Ryan: Budget blueprint will promote repealing health care law
column4: "Yes, our budget does promote repealing Obamacare and replacing it with a better system," Ryan, the chairman of the House Budget Committee, said on "Fox News Sunday."

column3: Paul Ryan: Budget blueprint will promote repealing health care law
column4: Past House Republican efforts to repeal the president's health care law have failed and the Supreme Court upheld the constitutionality of law last year.

column3: Paul Ryan: Budget blueprint will promote repealing health care law
column4: On Thursday, Ryan lunched at the White House with Obama and Rep. Chris Van Hollen (D-Md.

column3: Paul Ryan: Budget blueprint will promote repealing health care law
column4: ), the ranking Democrat on the House Budget Committee.

column3: Paul Ryan: Budget blueprint will promote repealing health care law
column4: Ryan said Sunday that only time will tell how effective the president's recent outreach to him and other congressional Republicans will be.

column3: Paul Ryan: Budget blueprint will promote repealing health care law
column4: "The proof will be in the coming weeks as to whether or not it is a real sincere outreach to find common ground," Ryan said.

column3: Bin Laden son-in-law pleads not guilty, lawmakers blast move to use civilian courts
column4: A top Al Qaeda spokesman, who is the son-in-law of Usama bin Laden, pleaded not guilty Friday in federal court to charges of conspiracy to kill Americans, touching off what could be lengthy legal proceedings as Republicans complained that such terror suspects don't belong in the civilian judicial system.

column3: Bin Laden son-in-law pleads not guilty, lawmakers blast move to use civilian courts
column4: Sulaiman Abu Ghaith was hit with the charges in an indictment unsealed by the Justice Department late Thursday.

column3: Bin Laden son-in-law pleads not guilty, lawmakers blast move to use civilian courts
column4: The terror suspect's capture and prosecution in federal court -- all of which was first revealed to the public Thursday -- caught lawmakers by surprise.

column3: Bin Laden son-in-law pleads not guilty, lawmakers blast move to use civilian courts
column4: Republican Sens.

column3: Bin Laden son-in-law pleads not guilty, lawmakers blast move to use civilian courts
column4: Lindsey Graham and Kelly Ayotte, said Thursday the Obama administration's decision to bring Abu Ghaith to court in New York City is wrong, "sneaky" and against the will of Congress.

column3: Bin Laden son-in-law pleads not guilty, lawmakers blast move to use civilian courts
column4: While foes of using Guantanamo to hold suspects say detainees there are afforded fewer legal rights, supporters say they can yield more information while held in the military facility.

column3: Bin Laden son-in-law pleads not guilty, lawmakers blast move to use civilian courts
column4: Graham says Abu Ghaith is clearly an enemy combatant and should have been sent straight to the Guantanamo Bay detainee facility for extended questioning.

column3: Bin Laden son-in-law pleads not guilty, lawmakers blast move to use civilian courts
column4: "The Obama administration’s lack of a war-time detention policy for foreign members of al Qaeda, as well as its refusal to detain and interrogate these individuals at Guantanamo, makes our nation less safe," Graham and Ayotte said in a joint written statement.

column3: Bin Laden son-in-law pleads not guilty, lawmakers blast move to use civilian courts
column4: “We are at war with Al Qaeda and its affiliated groups, and America’s detention policy must reflect that reality."

column3: Bin Laden son-in-law pleads not guilty, lawmakers blast move to use civilian courts
column4: On Friday, Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell also questioned whether the U.S. was losing valuable intelligence by going through the civilian court system.

column3: Bin Laden son-in-law pleads not guilty, lawmakers blast move to use civilian courts
column4: "From public reports it is clear that Abu Ghaith possesses valuable knowledge of al Qaeda's activities within Iran.

column3: Bin Laden son-in-law pleads not guilty, lawmakers blast move to use civilian courts
column4: Abu Ghaith has sworn to kill Americans, and he likely possesses information that could prevent harm to America and its allies.

column3: Bin Laden son-in-law pleads not guilty, lawmakers blast move to use civilian courts
column4: He is an enemy combatant and should be held in military custody," he said.

column3: Bin Laden son-in-law pleads not guilty, lawmakers blast move to use civilian courts
column4: But the White House argues that the civilian courts are a more effective avenue for justice.

column3: Bin Laden son-in-law pleads not guilty, lawmakers blast move to use civilian courts
column4: "Article 3 courts have shown that they are, in many ways, a more efficient way for us to deliver justice to those who seek to harm the United States of America and that is the consensus view of the president's national security team and of agencies all across the federal government -- that this is the best way to handle bringing Abu Ghaith to justice," Deputy Press Secretary Josh Earnest said Friday.

column3: Bin Laden son-in-law pleads not guilty, lawmakers blast move to use civilian courts
column4: Fox News has learned that the suspect was arrested Feb. 28 overseas and arrived March 1.

column3: Bin Laden son-in-law pleads not guilty, lawmakers blast move to use civilian courts
column4: His next court appearance is set for April 8.

column3: Bin Laden son-in-law pleads not guilty, lawmakers blast move to use civilian courts
column4: He has at least three court-appointed lawyers; he does not have the resources to pay for them.

column3: Bin Laden son-in-law pleads not guilty, lawmakers blast move to use civilian courts
column4: The case reflects the Obama administration priority of prosecuting terror suspects in U.S. federal courts instead of holding them at Guantanamo Bay, which the administration has so far been unable to close.

column3: Bin Laden son-in-law pleads not guilty, lawmakers blast move to use civilian courts
column4: The capture of Abu Ghaith drew praise from Republican Rep. Peter King of New York, the former chairman of the House Homeland Security Committee, who called it a "very significant victory" in U.S. efforts against Al Qaeda.

column3: Bin Laden son-in-law pleads not guilty, lawmakers blast move to use civilian courts
column4: The Justice Department touted the capture of Abu Ghaith as significant.

column3: Bin Laden son-in-law pleads not guilty, lawmakers blast move to use civilian courts
column4: "It has been 13 years since Abu Ghaith allegedly worked alongside Usama Bin Laden in his campaign of terror, and 13 years since he allegedly took to the public airwaves, exhorting others to embrace Al Qaeda's cause and warning of more terrorist attacks like the mass murder of 9/11," U.S. Attorney Bharara said in a news release announcing Abu Ghaith's arrest.

column3: Bin Laden son-in-law pleads not guilty, lawmakers blast move to use civilian courts
column4: "The memory of those attacks is indelibly etched on the American psyche, and today's action is the latest example of our commitment to capturing and punishing enemies of the United States, no matter how long it takes."

column3: Bin Laden son-in-law pleads not guilty, lawmakers blast move to use civilian courts
column4: Attorney General Eric Holder added, "No amount of distance or time will weaken our resolve to bring America's enemies to justice."

column3: Bin Laden son-in-law pleads not guilty, lawmakers blast move to use civilian courts
column4: Abu Ghaith became an international name in late 2001 when he appeared on pan-Arab satellite television urging Muslims everywhere to fight the United States and warning of more attacks similar to those of Sept. 11.

column3: Bin Laden son-in-law pleads not guilty, lawmakers blast move to use civilian courts

column3: Bin Laden son-in-law pleads not guilty, lawmakers blast move to use civilian courts
