column4: "The propaganda statements in which Abu Ghaith and his late father-in-law, Usama bin Laden, praised the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001 are alone enough to merit the most serious punishment," King said The Obama administration's attempts to move many of the detainees held at Guantanamo into facilities in the United States to stand trial domestically were halted during Obama's first term after Congress passed a measure with bipartisan majorities opposing such transfers.

column3: Bin Laden son-in-law pleads not guilty, lawmakers blast move to use civilian courts
column4: Fox News' Mike Levine and The Associated Press contributed to this report.

column3: Unemployment Hits 4-Year Low
column4: Despite constant budget fights in Washington, the U.S. economy managed one of the best months for job gains in the past year in February, driving the unemployment rate to its lowest level in more than four years.

column3: Unemployment Hits 4-Year Low
column4: But the job market would be even better, and the unemployment rate even lower, had not the government spent most of the recovery cutting spending and jobs.

column3: Unemployment Hits 4-Year Low
column4: And though Wall Street may cheer February's jobs report, the pain of government cutbacks looks to get worse as the year goes on.

column3: Unemployment Hits 4-Year Low
column4: U.S. employers added 236,000 jobs to non-farm payrolls in February, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported on Friday, up from 119,000 in January.

column3: Unemployment Hits 4-Year Low
column4: That was the best payroll growth since 247,000 jobs last November and the second-best month for job growth of the past 12 months.

column3: Unemployment Hits 4-Year Low
column4: The unemployment rate dropped to 7.7 percent from 7.9 percent in January, with 12 million people looking for work.

column3: Unemployment Hits 4-Year Low
column4: That is the lowest unemployment rate since December 2008, when the rate was 7.3 percent.

column3: Unemployment Hits 4-Year Low
column4: "The recovery is gathering momentum," Paul Ashworth, chief U.S. economist at Capital Economics, wrote in a note.

column3: Unemployment Hits 4-Year Low
column4: But U.S. non-farm payrolls are still 3 million jobs shy of their pre-recession highs, and the jobless rate is still too high to convince the Federal Reserve to stop pumping cash into the economy.

column3: Unemployment Hits 4-Year Low
column4: (SCROLL DOWN FOR UPDATES AND ANALYSIS ON THE REPORT) Meanwhile, a higher payroll tax rate, the harsh budget cuts of the "sequester" and other effects of Washington's endless budget wars could carve 1.5 percent from economic growth this year and cut at least 700,000 jobs in the next two years, according to recent studies by the private forecasting firm Macroeconomic Advisers.

column3: Unemployment Hits 4-Year Low
column4: "There really is the potential for trouble ahead," Ian Shepherdson, chief economist at Pantheon Macroeconomic Advisors, wrote in a note.

column3: Unemployment Hits 4-Year Low

column4: And the unemployment rate fell in large part because the labor force shrank by 130,000 workers.

column3: Unemployment Hits 4-Year Low

column3: Unemployment Hits 4-Year Low

column3: Unemployment Hits 4-Year Low

column3: Unemployment Hits 4-Year Low

column3: Unemployment Hits 4-Year Low
column4: Including February's jobs, the U.S. economy has added 5.7 million jobs since the labor market bottomed in February 2010, but non-farm employment is still 3 million jobs lower than before the start of the recession in December 2007, making this the slowest labor-market recovery since World War II.

column3: Unemployment Hits 4-Year Low
column4: After peaking at 10 percent in October 2009, the unemployment rate has been grinding lower, but far too slowly.

column3: Unemployment Hits 4-Year Low
column4: As a result, the Federal Reserve has kept short-term interest rates near zero for more than four years and has launched a series of unprecedented bond-buying programs to further bolster the economy.

column3: U.S. UNEMPLOYMENT FALLS TO LOWEST RATE IN FOUR YEARS
column4: The unemployment rate fell to 7.7 percent from 7.9 percent in February, the lowest it has been since President Barack Obama took office, the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics reported Friday.

column3: U.S. UNEMPLOYMENT FALLS TO LOWEST RATE IN FOUR YEARS
column4: The report — compiled before sequestration took effect — notes that the private economy added 236,000 jobs.

column3: U.S. UNEMPLOYMENT FALLS TO LOWEST RATE IN FOUR YEARS
column4: Increases were seen in professional and business services, construction, and health care.

column3: U.S. UNEMPLOYMENT FALLS TO LOWEST RATE IN FOUR YEARS
column4: “The unemployment rate edged down to 7.7 percent in February but has shown little movement, on net, since September 2012.

column3: U.S. UNEMPLOYMENT FALLS TO LOWEST RATE IN FOUR YEARS
column4: The number of unemployed persons, at 12.0 million, also edged lower in February,” the report reads.

column3: U.S. UNEMPLOYMENT FALLS TO LOWEST RATE IN FOUR YEARS
column4: Here’s unemployment broken up by group: The number of people on long-term unemployment (i.e those who have been out of work for 27 weeks or more) in February was about 4.8 million.

column3: U.S. UNEMPLOYMENT FALLS TO LOWEST RATE IN FOUR YEARS
column4: This accounts for 40.2 of total unemployment, which is an increase from last month’s 38.1 percent.

column3: U.S. UNEMPLOYMENT FALLS TO LOWEST RATE IN FOUR YEARS
column4: The civilian labor force participation rate and the number of people employed part-time were both essentially unchanged from January: The former coming in at about 63.5 percent and the latter at about 8.0 million.

column3: U.S. UNEMPLOYMENT FALLS TO LOWEST RATE IN FOUR YEARS
column4: “In February, 2.6 million persons were marginally attached to the labor force, the same as a year earlier,” the report notes.

column3: U.S. UNEMPLOYMENT FALLS TO LOWEST RATE IN FOUR YEARS
column4: “These individuals were not in the labor force, wanted and were available for work, and had looked for a job sometime in the prior 12 months.” “They were not counted as unemployed because they had not searched for work in the 4 weeks preceding the survey,” it adds.

column3: U.S. UNEMPLOYMENT FALLS TO LOWEST RATE IN FOUR YEARS
column4: It continues: Among the marginally attached, there were 885,000 discouraged workers in February, down slightly from a year earlier … Discouraged workers are persons not currently looking for work because they believe no jobs are available for them.

column3: U.S. UNEMPLOYMENT FALLS TO LOWEST RATE IN FOUR YEARS
column4: The remaining 1.7 million persons marginally attached to the labor force in February had not searched for work in the 4 weeks preceding the survey for reasons such as school attendance or family responsibilities.

column3: Arkansas Becomes Biggest Advocate for Life
column4: Well Arkansas has officially become the state with the most restrictive abortion law and has made a case for life.

column3: Arkansas Becomes Biggest Advocate for Life
column4: The new law is a near-ban on abortion after the 12th week of pregnancy.

column3: Arkansas Becomes Biggest Advocate for Life
column4: Unless a lawsuit or court action intervenes before it takes effect this summer, it looks like Arkansas will become the toughest state to get an abortion after the 3 month mark.

column3: Arkansas Becomes Biggest Advocate for Life
column4: Lawmakers in the Republican-dominated Legislature defied Gov.

column3: Arkansas Becomes Biggest Advocate for Life
column4: Mike Beebe, overriding the Democrat's veto.

column3: Arkansas Becomes Biggest Advocate for Life
column4: The House voted 56-33 on Wednesday to override Beebe's veto, a day after the Senate voted to do the same.

column3: Arkansas Becomes Biggest Advocate for Life
column4: The votes come less than a week after the Legislature overrode a veto of a separate bill banning most abortions starting in the 20th week of pregnancy.

column3: Arkansas Becomes Biggest Advocate for Life
column4: That bill took effect immediately after the final override vote, whereas the 12-week ban won't take effect until this summer.

column3: Arkansas Becomes Biggest Advocate for Life
column4: Abortion rights advocates say they will sue over this vote, but those who advocated and voted for this law are not scared of this challenge.

column3: Arkansas Becomes Biggest Advocate for Life
column4: The governor, who has continually stated that these laws are unconstitutional due to the Roe v. Wade decision, will face opponents from the Right.

column3: Arkansas Becomes Biggest Advocate for Life
column4: "Not the governor, nor anyone else other than the courts, can determine if something is constitutional or unconstitutional," Rep. Bruce Westerman, a Republican from Hot Springs, said in urging his colleagues to override Beebe.

column3: Arkansas Becomes Biggest Advocate for Life
column4: Bill sponsor Sen. Jason Rapert, a Republican from Conway, watched the vote from the House gallery and said a number of law firms have offered to help the state defend the laws in court, if it comes to that.

column3: Arkansas Becomes Biggest Advocate for Life
column4: "I'm just grateful that this body has continued to stand up for the bills that have passed.

column3: Arkansas Becomes Biggest Advocate for Life
column4: The eyes of the entire nation were on the Arkansas House of Representatives today," he said.

column3: Arkansas Becomes Biggest Advocate for Life
column4: This 12-week ban will prohibit abortions from the point when a baby’s heart rate can be heard through an abdominal ultrasound.

column3: Arkansas Becomes Biggest Advocate for Life
column4: “It includes exemptions for rape, incest, the life of the mother and highly lethal fetal disorders.

column3: Arkansas Becomes Biggest Advocate for Life
column4: The 20-week prohibition, which is based on the disputed claim that a fetus can feel pain by the 20th week and therefore deserves protection from abortion, includes all of the same exemptions except for fetal disorders.” And 6 Democrats even crossed the aisle to join Republicans on this vote.

column3: Arkansas Becomes Biggest Advocate for Life
column4: So if you can hear the heartbeat at 12 weeks, how is it that anti-abortion advocates can claim it is not a live being in there?

column3: Arkansas Becomes Biggest Advocate for Life
column4: Thank you to Arkansas for standing with the women and children of your state and protecting their lives.

column3: Chavez Dies, Leaving Sharp Divisions in Venezuela

column3: Cuba's coup de grace in Venezuela
column4: For two long years, Venezuelan leader Hugo Chávez’s Cuban medical team perpetrated a colossal deception of the Venezuelan people and the world about his bout with terminal cancer.

column3: Cuba's coup de grace in Venezuela
column4: According to knowledgeable sources, Cuban doctors botched the initial treatment that doomed Chavez, manipulated his anxiety and paranoia so he would settle for substandard medical care in Havana, and pushed him back on to the campaign trail despite the impact on his health.

column3: Cuba's coup de grace in Venezuela
column4: Quite plainly, the Cuban regime traded Chávez’s life for its own survival – knowing that its bankrupt economy depends on Venezuelan generosity.

column3: Cuba's coup de grace in Venezuela
column4: Unfortunately, the Cubans are not done administering to Venezuela – putting that country’s constitution under the knife.

column3: Cuba's coup de grace in Venezuela
column4: Article 233 of that charter says, in part, “When an elected president becomes permanently unavailable to serve prior to his inauguration, a new election by universal suffrage and direct ballot shall be held within 30 consecutive days.

column3: Cuba's coup de grace in Venezuela
column4: Pending election and inauguration of the new president, the president of the National Assembly shall take charge of the presidency of the Republic.” [Emphasis added] [pullquote] Today, Chávez is as “permanently unavailable to serve” as president of Venezuela as anyone can be.

column3: Cuba's coup de grace in Venezuela
column4: He was out of the country and unable to take the oath of office on Jan. 10, when his new term should have commenced; the cronies on his supreme court pushed back his inauguration to a time convenient to the president.

column3: Cuba's coup de grace in Venezuela
column4: So, he was never inaugurated and never will be.

column3: Cuba's coup de grace in Venezuela
column4: A plain reading of Article 233 makes National Assembly chief Diosdado Cabello the custodian of the presidency until new elections can be held.

column3: Cuba's coup de grace in Venezuela
column4: But Havana does not like Cabello, and the feeling is mutual.

column3: Cuba's coup de grace in Venezuela
column4: Havana favors Nicolas Maduro, whom Chávez named late last year as vice president.

column3: Cuba's coup de grace in Venezuela
column4: If Chávez had taken the oath of office and initiated his new term, Maduro might have some claim to succession.

column3: Cuba's coup de grace in Venezuela
column4: However, Chávez’s term was never inaugurated, so there is no mandate for Maduro to claim.

column3: Cuba's coup de grace in Venezuela
column4: Indeed, the moment Chávez died, Maduro became no one’s vice president.

column3: Cuba's coup de grace in Venezuela
column4: The Cubans have no choice but to run the risk of awakening Venezuelan nationalism.

column3: Cuba's coup de grace in Venezuela
column4: Not only did they essentially sequester another country’s president for the last 90 days, they even summoned Venezuelan ministers to Havana to hold imaginary cabinet meetings.

column3: Cuba's coup de grace in Venezuela
column4: In recent weeks, university students have protested Cuban interference in Venezuela’s internal affairs.

column3: Cuba's coup de grace in Venezuela
column4: Nationalistic military officers – most of whom favor the veteran Cabello and were trained to oppose Cuban communism – have grumbled about Havana’s heavy-handed stage-managing of a succession that favors Havana’s selfish interests.

column3: Cuba's coup de grace in Venezuela
column4: According to sources in Venezuela, the country’s security forces are divided – with most of the military muscle lining up behind Cabello.

column3: Cuba's coup de grace in Venezuela
column4: However, with 30,000 Cubans – including disciplined mobile hit squads – roaming the streets and monitoring the movements of every Venezuelan military officer, Havana will put up a fight.

column3: Cuba's coup de grace in Venezuela
column4: If that sparks a civil war in which thousands of Venezuelans might die, so be it.

column3: Cuba's coup de grace in Venezuela
column4: After years of ignoring Chávez’s authoritarianism, the international community might finally muster the courage to speak up to prevent bloodshed.

column3: Cuba's coup de grace in Venezuela
column4: The solution appears to be fairly straightforward:  a constitutional succession and new elections to choose a president.

column3: Cuba's coup de grace in Venezuela
column4: If Maduro wants to be president and defender of the Venezuelan Constitution, he can play by the rules and compete for the job.

column3: Cuba's coup de grace in Venezuela
column4: Of course, before the democratic opposition hits the campaign trail yet again, they are insisting on simple but profound reforms to ensure a level playing field and a fair process in which all the votes are counted.

column3: Cuba's coup de grace in Venezuela
column4: These concepts might be alien to a bunch of thugs from Cuba, but Venezuelans have gotten fairly used to elections of one sort or another.

column3: Cuba's coup de grace in Venezuela
column4: If Havana gets its way on interpreting the Venezuelan Constitution in a manner that hands power to its puppet, who can object when Cuba vetoes new elections?

column3: Cuba's coup de grace in Venezuela
column4: And if new elections are held, does anyone expect the Castro brothers to risk holding a freer or fairer process?

column3: Cuba's coup de grace in Venezuela
column4: In recent months, the U.S. State Department has found itself in the awkward position of favoring Havana’s hand-picked candidate, holding secret talks with Maduro beginning last November aimed at normalizing bilateral relations.

column3: Cuba's coup de grace in Venezuela
column4: Yesterday, Maduro rewarded the naïveté of U.S. diplomats by expelling two military officers assigned to the U.S. Embassy for allegedly destabilizing Venezuela; he also suggested that Chávez might have been poisoned.

column3: Cuba's coup de grace in Venezuela
column4: As of this morning, it is not too late for Washington to be as effective as Havana when it comes to defending our values and interests.

column3: Cuba's coup de grace in Venezuela
column4: By this afternoon, the Cubans’ coup de grâce against Venezuela’s constitution may be irreversible.

column3: Now Dems worry: Did President Obama cry wolf?
column4: President Barack Obama hopes to spark a pitchfork revolt against Republicans over sequester-induced budget cuts — but many Democrats fret that he’s undermined that effort with an early strategy marred by hype, poor planning and muddled messaging.

column3: Now Dems worry: Did President Obama cry wolf?
column4: The stakes in the sequester debate aren’t quite as high as they were during the debt ceiling battle of 2011, but Democratic veterans of the Obama-Republican wars of 2009 and 2010 are getting a creepy sense of déjà vu from a White House messaging shop they believe fumbled the rollouts of the stimulus and health care initiatives.

column3: Now Dems worry: Did President Obama cry wolf?
column4: Story Continued Below Over the past few days, Obama and his team have pulled back from a kick-off strategy that portrayed the $84 billion in automatic cuts this year as a parade of instant horrors — hellish waits at airports, a quick cascade of private job losses resulting from voided federal contracts, teachers immediately sacked.

column3: Now Dems worry: Did President Obama cry wolf?
column4: ( Also on POLITICO: Wall Street blows off the sequester) That’s part of a “recalibration,” according to one Obama insider, intended to take the focus off the veracity of the administration’s claims — and back on congressional Republicans who have refused to give ground on new tax revenue demanded by Obama as a condition of any long-term budget deal.

column3: Now Dems worry: Did President Obama cry wolf?
column4: “I think they probably went over the top in terms of saying that the consequences were going to be horrible, especially because it’s happened and the lines in the airports aren’t long, the world hasn’t changed overnight,” says former Pennsylvania Gov.

column3: Now Dems worry: Did President Obama cry wolf?
column4: Ed Rendell, an on-again, off-again Obama critic who supports the broad outlines of Obama’s $4 trillion “grand bargain” proposal.

column3: Now Dems worry: Did President Obama cry wolf?
column4: “Some of this is going to kick in eventually — government workers will be furloughed, contractors will lose their jobs, people will start feeling this for sure — but it will take some time … and it probably wasn’t the best strategic path for the White House to follow.” One top Democratic Congressional aide offered this bit of advice to Obama: “Don’t accentuate a fight you don’t intend to wage [and] can’t win.

column3: Now Dems worry: Did President Obama cry wolf?
column4: … They spent two weeks building up sequester as a horror show and then got fact-checked a dozen times and were forced to back off their own claims of it being a disaster once they were forced to acquiesce to the cuts happening.” ( Also on POLITICO: Koch-backed group says Obama’s hyping) The cuts are coming, many after a one-month delay — and local media around the country were busily reporting details of tower closures at 173 small- to medium-sized airports by April 7.

column3: Now Dems worry: Did President Obama cry wolf?
column4: Republicans claim the administration could opt for less onerous cuts, but the Obama administration says the indiscriminate austerity of the sequester means unavoidable pain.

column3: Now Dems worry: Did President Obama cry wolf?
column4: Obama himself seemed to acknowledge the need to lower the temperature when he strode into the White House briefing room last Friday to make a significant messaging adjustment: It’s going to be bad, but not the end of the world.

column3: Now Dems worry: Did President Obama cry wolf?
column4: “We will get through this.

column3: Now Dems worry: Did President Obama cry wolf?
column4: This is not going to be an apocalypse, I think as some people have said,” Obama said after exiting a perfunctory 52-minute meeting at the White House with House Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio), Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.), Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.) and House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.).

column3: Now Dems worry: Did President Obama cry wolf?
column4: ( Also on POLITICO: Right-wing blogs: The world isn’t ending) “It’s just dumb.

column3: Now Dems worry: Did President Obama cry wolf?
column4: And it’s going to hurt.

column3: Now Dems worry: Did President Obama cry wolf?
column4: It’s going to hurt individual people, and it’s going to hurt the economy over all,” he said, in a tone that was considerably less alarmist than the messaging emanating from his team the prior week.

column3: Leaked email adds fuel to claims White House playing politics over impact of cuts
column4: A leaked email from an Agriculture Department field officer adds fuel to claims President Obama's political strategy is to make the billions in recent federal budget cuts as painful as possible to win the public opinion battle against Republicans.

column3: Leaked email adds fuel to claims White House playing politics over impact of cuts
column4: The email, circulated around Capitol Hill, was sent Monday by Charles Brown, a director at the agency’s Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service office in Raleigh, N.C.

column3: Leaked email adds fuel to claims White House playing politics over impact of cuts
column4: He appears to tell his regional team about a response to his recent question on the amount of latitude he has in making cuts.

column3: Leaked email adds fuel to claims White House playing politics over impact of cuts
column4: According to the partially redacted email, the response came from the Agriculture Department’s budget office and in part states: “However you manage that reduction, you need to make sure you are not contradicting what we said the impact would be.” The response noted that the administration had already told Congress that the APHIS would “eliminate assistance to producers in 24 states in managing wildlife damage to the aquaculture industry” without additional funds.

column3: Leaked email adds fuel to claims White House playing politics over impact of cuts
column4: Arkansas Republican Rep. Tim Griffin said the administration’s response to Brown’s email shows a bid to undermine efforts to replace the cuts, known as sequester, with less onerous ones.

column3: Leaked email adds fuel to claims White House playing politics over impact of cuts
column4: “This email confirms what many Americans have suspected: The Obama administration is doing everything they can to make sure their worst predictions come true and to maximize the pain of the sequester cuts for political gain,” Griffin said in a statement.

column3: Leaked email adds fuel to claims White House playing politics over impact of cuts
column4: Griffin told Fox News on Wednesday that the bosses effectively said, “You can’t do anything that is inconsistent with the negative impact that we’ve told everybody these cuts are going to have.” An Agriculture Department spokesperson told Fox on Wednesday that the email "has been completely taken out of context.

column3: Leaked email adds fuel to claims White House playing politics over impact of cuts
column4: The spokesperson said it references "cuts and impacts communicated to Congress as part of the FY2013 budget, not as part of a sequester plan."

column3: Leaked email adds fuel to claims White House playing politics over impact of cuts
column4: Under the 2011 deal reached by Obama and Congress, the cuts are supposed to be across the board, meaning government officials have limited flexibility in moving around money.

column3: Leaked email adds fuel to claims White House playing politics over impact of cuts
column4: The administration in recent weeks has made doomsday predictions about the impact of the cuts.

column3: Leaked email adds fuel to claims White House playing politics over impact of cuts
column4: And the White House so far has appeared unwilling to accept a Republican offer to give the president more autonomy in making the cuts, covering $85 billion this fiscal year, to help reduce the impact on some of the most essential or hardest-hit programs or agencies.

column3: Leaked email adds fuel to claims White House playing politics over impact of cuts
column4: Some political strategists say the president hopes the cuts hurt enough to compel Republican lawmakers seeking re-election next year to end them by agreeing to more tax increases.

column3: Leaked email adds fuel to claims White House playing politics over impact of cuts
column4: On Sunday, Gene Sperling, the White House’s top economic adviser, suggested Republicans would indeed make this decision.

column3: Leaked email adds fuel to claims White House playing politics over impact of cuts
column4: “Our hope is, as more Republicans start to see this pain in their own districts, they will choose bipartisan compromise over this absolutist position,” he said.

column3: Leaked email adds fuel to claims White House playing politics over impact of cuts
column4: Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack, during a House hearing Tuesday, was asked by South Dakota Republican Rep. Kristi Noem about the Brown email.

column3: Leaked email adds fuel to claims White House playing politics over impact of cuts
column4: Vilsack said he was unaware of the email, but denied the administration has a policy of being inflexible and maximizing the cuts’ impact.

column3: Leaked email adds fuel to claims White House playing politics over impact of cuts

column4: Some people said, ‘Oh, look, if this number here comes in, why, you could win.’ But you know, by 8 or 9 o’clock, it was pretty clear that we were not going to win.” Romney called his inability to win black and Hispanic votes “a real weakness” and said future GOP candidates must do better.

column3: Mitt Romney: 'It kills me' not to be president
column4: He blamed himself for the infamous “47 percent” comments and said he should have been more careful when speaking privately — as he thought he was at the fundraiser in Boca Raton, Fla. “The weakness that our campaign had and that I had is we weren’t effective in — in taking my message primarily to minority voters, to Hispanic-Americans, African-Americans, other minorities,” he said.

column3: Mitt Romney: 'It kills me' not to be president
column4: “That was a real weakness.

column3: Mitt Romney: 'It kills me' not to be president
column4: Uh, we did very well with the majority population, but not with minority populations.

column3: Mitt Romney: 'It kills me' not to be president
column4: And — and that was a — that was a failing.

column3: Mitt Romney: 'It kills me' not to be president
column4: That was a real mistake.”

column3: Romney relays disappointment over loss, admits mistakes, in first sitdown since 2012 election
column4: Mitt Romney, the 2012 Republican presidential nominee, gave an unflinching review Sunday of his unsuccessful campaign, admitting his shortcomings and disappointments but vowing to remain a force in American politics.

column3: Romney relays disappointment over loss, admits mistakes, in first sitdown since 2012 election
column4: “It kills me not to be there, not to be in the White House doing what needs to be done,” Romney told “Fox News Sunday” in his first interview with wife Ann after the election.

column3: Romney relays disappointment over loss, admits mistakes, in first sitdown since 2012 election
column4: “It’s hard.” In the wide-ranging interview, Romney and his wife also talked about everything from campaign missteps to heartbreaking Election night results to how President Obama has led the country so far in his second term.

column3: Romney relays disappointment over loss, admits mistakes, in first sitdown since 2012 election
column4: “The president is out campaigning to the American people, doing rallies around the country, flying around the country and berating Republicans and blaming and pointing,” Romney said.

column3: Romney relays disappointment over loss, admits mistakes, in first sitdown since 2012 election
column4: “That causes the Republicans to retrench and to put up a wall and to fight back.” Romney told Fox that Obama appears to be failing in his handling of the $85 billion in spending cuts this year that automatically kicked in this weekend, in part because he failed to broker a less drastic option between Democrats and Republicans.

column3: Romney relays disappointment over loss, admits mistakes, in first sitdown since 2012 election
column4: “No one can think that that's been a success for the president,” he said.

column3: Romney relays disappointment over loss, admits mistakes, in first sitdown since 2012 election
column4: Romney, a former Massachusetts governor, spoke in detail about remarks he made during a private event, regarding not being able to reach 47 percent of voters, which critics exploited late in the campaign.

column3: Romney relays disappointment over loss, admits mistakes, in first sitdown since 2012 election
column4: “It was a very unfortunate statement,” Romney told Fox.

column3: Romney relays disappointment over loss, admits mistakes, in first sitdown since 2012 election
column4: “It's not what I meant.

column3: Romney relays disappointment over loss, admits mistakes, in first sitdown since 2012 election
column4: I didn't express myself as I wished I would have.

column3: Romney relays disappointment over loss, admits mistakes, in first sitdown since 2012 election
column4: You know, when you speak in private, uh, you don't spend as much time thinking about how something could be twisted and distorted.

column3: Romney relays disappointment over loss, admits mistakes, in first sitdown since 2012 election
column4: And it could come out wrong.

column3: Romney relays disappointment over loss, admits mistakes, in first sitdown since 2012 election
column4: … There's no question that hurt and did real damage to my campaign.

column3: Romney relays disappointment over loss, admits mistakes, in first sitdown since 2012 election
column4: He also acknowledges he and his campaign failed to reach out to minorities as well as the Obama campaign.

column3: Romney relays disappointment over loss, admits mistakes, in first sitdown since 2012 election
column4: “We weren't effective in my message primarily to minority voters, to Hispanic-Americans, African-Americans, other minorities,” Romney said.

column3: Romney relays disappointment over loss, admits mistakes, in first sitdown since 2012 election
column4: “That was a real mistake.” In the interview, which was taped Thursday and aired Sunday, Romney also said he and his campaign underestimated the appeal of Obama's new health care law to low-income voters.

column3: Romney relays disappointment over loss, admits mistakes, in first sitdown since 2012 election
column4: Romney said he is finished will elected office, but will continue to try to help the Republican Party, despite having a less powerful voice.

column3: Romney relays disappointment over loss, admits mistakes, in first sitdown since 2012 election
column4: “I lost and so I'm not going to be telling the Republican Party, ‘Come listen to me, the guy who lost,’ ” Romney said.

column3: Romney relays disappointment over loss, admits mistakes, in first sitdown since 2012 election
column4: “I'm not going to disappear.

column3: Romney relays disappointment over loss, admits mistakes, in first sitdown since 2012 election
column4: … I care about America.

column3: Romney relays disappointment over loss, admits mistakes, in first sitdown since 2012 election
column4: I care about the people that can't find jobs.

column3: Romney relays disappointment over loss, admits mistakes, in first sitdown since 2012 election
column4: I care about the fact that we're racking up larger deficits and putting the peril of the future generation very much in play.”

column3: YOUNG: Washington still doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t get it
column4: ANALYSIS/OPINION: Washington’s fiscal problem can be succinctly summarized: It’s the spending, Stupid.

column3: YOUNG: Washington still doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t get it
column4: For anyone still doubting, you need look no further than the Congressional Budget Office’s just-released estimates for the next decade.

column3: YOUNG: Washington still doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t get it
column4: The verdict: Federal outlays spiked with the recession, remained high and will rise from there – even with their recent hike, revenues simply cannot keep pace.

column3: YOUNG: Washington still doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t get it
column4: Like a connect-the-dot picture, CBO’s “The Budget and Economic Outlook: Fiscal Years 2013 to 2023” lays out the salient points of Washington’s fiscal dilemma.

column3: YOUNG: Washington still doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t get it
column4: The image is not pretty.

column3: YOUNG: Washington still doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t get it
column4: What passes for good news comes this year.

column3: YOUNG: Washington still doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t get it
column4: The federal deficit is projected to fall below $1 trillion for the first time in five years.

column3: YOUNG: Washington still doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t get it
column4: It is expected to remain a staggering $845 billion – roughly $400 billion more than the amount for which the Bush administration was assailed in 2008.

column3: YOUNG: Washington still doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t get it
column4: Then the bad news really begins: “Deficits are projected to increase later in the coming decade, however, because of the pressures of an aging population, rising health care costs, an expansion of federal subsidies for health insurance, and growing interest payments on federal debt.” The key point from that fearsome foursome is that all of these are due to growing spending.

column3: YOUNG: Washington still doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t get it
column4: Yet could not falling revenues, as occurred during the recession and subsequent “slow recovery seen since the recession ended in mid-2009” still be a culprit?

column3: YOUNG: Washington still doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t get it
column4: According to CBO estimates, the New Year’s tax hike has addressed that issue – but good.

column3: YOUNG: Washington still doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t get it
column4: “Federal revenues will increase by roughly 25 percent between 2013 and 2015…[and] revenues are projected to grow from 15.8 percent of GDP in 2012 to 19.1 percent of GDP in 2015 – compared with an average of 17.9 percent of GDP over the past 40 years.” Washington’s fiscal problem is that spending will also be above its past levels – only more so.

column3: YOUNG: Washington still doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t get it
column4: “Although outlays are projected to decline from 22.8 percent of GDP in 2012 to 21.5 percent of GDP by 2017, they will still exceed their 4-year average of 21 percent.” They also resume growing – reaching 22.9 percent of GDP by decade’s end – while revenues on the other hand stay at their current GDP ratio.

column3: YOUNG: Washington still doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t get it
column4: To underscore that spending, not falling revenues, is driving the deficit: “Under CBO’s baseline projections, most of the decline in the deficit in the next two years is the result of a projected significant rise in revenues, which are estimated to increase by 25 percent between 2013 and 2015.” OK, that’s “then,” but isn’t the present deficit the fault of revenues?

column3: YOUNG: Washington still doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t get it
column4: Actually, “federal revenues increased by $147 billion (or 6 percent) in 2012, and they are projected to grow by $259 billion (or 11 percent) in 2013.” In comparison, had it not been for a federal payment shift, “outlays in fiscal year 2012 would have been about the same as in fiscal year 2011.” So revenues increased – at almost three times the economy’s growth rate – while spending stayed flat.

column3: YOUNG: Washington still doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t get it
column4: Flat is decidedly not what federal spending has been during the recession.

column3: YOUNG: Washington still doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t get it
column4: It increased $535 billion from 2008 to 2009, an 18 percent jump.

column3: YOUNG: Washington still doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t get it
column4: Simultaneously, the deficit increased by almost $1 trillion – from $459 billion to $1.413 trillion.

column3: YOUNG: Washington still doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t get it
column4: Spending peaked at $3.6 trillion in 2011, and there it has pretty much stayed – $3.5 trillion in 2012 and an estimated $3.6 trillion again this year.

column3: YOUNG: Washington still doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t get it
column4: The verdict on what happened to the federal budget is clear.

column3: YOUNG: Washington still doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t get it
column4: During the recession, spending spiked; there it stayed for three years, and soon it will begin to soar…again.

column3: YOUNG: Washington still doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t get it
column4: There is no way for revenues to keep up with it and for the economy to keep growing at the same time.

column3: YOUNG: Washington still doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t get it
column4: Precisely identifying Washington’s spending dynamic, CBO sums up: Not only are an aging population, increased health care cost and subsidies, Social Security spending and debt service costs the spending problem, but “spending on all other programs – in the aggregate – is projected to decline relative to GDP between 2014 and 2023.” The spending problem is real, it is not new, it is not going away, it is going to get worse, and it is due to the four areas identified.

column3: YOUNG: Washington still doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t get it
column4: To address it, Washington must not only reach the heretofore elusive “grand bargain,” but that agreement must be centered on entitlement reform, putting these programs on a sustainable course.

column3: YOUNG: Washington still doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t get it
column4: This needs to be done before interest rate increases spur debt service costs, and entitlements really begin their explosion.

column3: YOUNG: Washington still doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t get it
column4: If this spending threat sounds all too familiar – you need only look to Europe to see why.

column3: YOUNG: Washington still doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t get it
column4: It is past time for Washington finally to recognize that the unaffordable is not unavoidable.

column3: Spending Cuts Imposed; U.S. Starts to Trim Its Budget
column4: WASHINGTON — University officials, city managers, day care providers and others spent Saturday assessing how they would absorb their part of the across-the-board cuts in federal spending that began taking effect over the weekend.

column3: Spending Cuts Imposed; U.S. Starts to Trim Its Budget
column4: But even as the institutions that depend on federal money nervously took stock, most Americans were largely unaffected by the cuts, at least for now.

column3: Spending Cuts Imposed; U.S. Starts to Trim Its Budget
column4: At Los Angeles International Airport, John Konopka, 45, suffered no delays as he arrived from Atlanta.

column3: Spending Cuts Imposed; U.S. Starts to Trim Its Budget
column4: “This is just another travel day,” Mr. Konopka said.

column3: Spending Cuts Imposed; U.S. Starts to Trim Its Budget
column4: “I think all of it’s been talked up a bit, way too politically, to make it seem a lot worse than it is.

column3: Spending Cuts Imposed; U.S. Starts to Trim Its Budget
column4: I don’t think it’s going to be the gloom and doom that some people are saying it would be.” Others were less sanguine.

column3: Spending Cuts Imposed; U.S. Starts to Trim Its Budget
column4: Joel Silver, 63, a retiree from the Bronx, said he feared the cuts would affect the most vulnerable.

column3: Spending Cuts Imposed; U.S. Starts to Trim Its Budget
column4: He said he was angry that President Obama and lawmakers had not prevented what he called “an invented crisis.” “What’s the point of a Congress?” he asked.

column3: Spending Cuts Imposed; U.S. Starts to Trim Its Budget
column4: “Aren’t they supposed to sit down and talk about things and figure them out?

column3: Spending Cuts Imposed; U.S. Starts to Trim Its Budget
column4: The economy was just recovering and now it’s going to slide back.” Across the country, the impact of sequestration, as the cuts are known, appeared to be as varied as the thousands of federal programs, big and small, that now have shrunken pots of money from which to draw.

column3: Spending Cuts Imposed; U.S. Starts to Trim Its Budget
column4: In Baltimore, the mayor called for an emergency cabinet meeting to discuss the reductions in federal money and their impact on a city that already has a projected deficit of $750 million over the next decade.

column3: Spending Cuts Imposed; U.S. Starts to Trim Its Budget
column4: At research universities, administrators sent e-mails to faculty members and students warning that changes were coming.

column3: Spending Cuts Imposed; U.S. Starts to Trim Its Budget
column4: Samuel L. Stanley Jr., the president of Stony Brook University, said the institution would lose $7.6 million in “vital federal funding” for research grants and other programs.

column3: Spending Cuts Imposed; U.S. Starts to Trim Its Budget
column4: The University of California, Berkeley, warned that “as sequestration translates into fewer federal grants, the campus will be forced to hire fewer researchers.” The Air Force Thunderbirds, the elite team of F-16 pilots who perform flight maneuvers at air shows around the country, announced on their Web site that all of their shows had been canceled starting April 1.

column3: Spending Cuts Imposed; U.S. Starts to Trim Its Budget
column4: Federal officials began sending letters to governors, informing them of smaller grants.

column3: Spending Cuts Imposed; U.S. Starts to Trim Its Budget
column4: Shaun Donovan, the secretary of housing and urban development, wrote to Gov.

column3: Spending Cuts Imposed; U.S. Starts to Trim Its Budget
column4: John R. Kasich of Ohio, “You can expect reductions totaling approximately $35 million.” In a 70-page report to Congress accompanying the sequestration order and detailing the reductions — agency by agency and program by program — Jeffrey D. Zients, Mr. Obama’s budget director, called them “deeply destructive to national security, domestic investments and core government functions.” Among the $85 billion in cuts for the fiscal year ending Sept. 30: $3 million less for Pacific coastal salmon recovery; $148 million less for the patent office; a $1 million cut in support by the Defense Department for international sporting competitions; $289 million less for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention; a $1 million cut in the Interior Department’s helium fund; and $16 million less for the Sept. 11 victim compensation fund.

column3: Spending Cuts Imposed; U.S. Starts to Trim Its Budget
column4: But even as the reductions became official, the result of a stalemate between Mr. Obama and Congressional Republicans over increasing taxes, some of the immediate impact was difficult to see.

column3: Spending Cuts Imposed; U.S. Starts to Trim Its Budget
column4: The process of trimming government budgets is slow and cumbersome, involving notifications to unions about temporary furloughs, reductions in overtime pay and cuts in grant financing to state and local programs.

column3: Spending Cuts Imposed; U.S. Starts to Trim Its Budget
column4: Less federal money will, over time, mean fewer government contracts with private companies.

column3: Spending Cuts Imposed; U.S. Starts to Trim Its Budget
column4: Reduced overtime pay for airport security checkpoint officers will make lines longer, eventually.

column3: Spending Cuts Imposed; U.S. Starts to Trim Its Budget
column4: And so as the first weekend began for the new, slimmer government, little of that was evident yet.

column3: Spending Cuts Imposed; U.S. Starts to Trim Its Budget
column4: At Kennedy International Airport in New York, travelers who arrived extra early were greeted by short lines, not the drastic delays that federal transportation officials have said could emerge as security officers are furloughed to save money.

column3: Spending Cuts Imposed; U.S. Starts to Trim Its Budget
column4: “The check-in was fine, at least for now.

column3: Spending Cuts Imposed; U.S. Starts to Trim Its Budget
column4: I’m surprised,” said Chris Achilefu, 45, who arrived at the airport four hours before his flight to Lagos, Nigeria.

column3: Spending Cuts Imposed; U.S. Starts to Trim Its Budget
column4: Normally Mr. Achilefu, an automotive exporter who lives in Upper Darby, Pa., would arrive two hours early, but he said he was concerned about lines.

column3: Spending Cuts Imposed; U.S. Starts to Trim Its Budget
column4: “I was listening to what the president said yesterday, that it won’t kick in right away,” he said.

column3: Spending Cuts Imposed; U.S. Starts to Trim Its Budget
column4: “Hopefully the two parties will come together, hopefully they will resolve it before another month.” At the main San Ysidro port of entry between Mexico and San Diego, traffic moved smoothly late Friday night, just hours after the sequestration began, and border lines had only a few dozen vehicles in each lane.

column3: Spending Cuts Imposed; U.S. Starts to Trim Its Budget
column4: Vendors who line the street where cars sometimes idle for hours waiting to enter the United States perked up when they heard about the cuts.

column3: Spending Cuts Imposed; U.S. Starts to Trim Its Budget
column4: “That’s good for business,” said Emilio Gomez, an employee at a stand selling rugs, china figurines and soda.

column3: Spending Cuts Imposed; U.S. Starts to Trim Its Budget
column4: “When people are waiting, they get bored and they buy more stuff.” In his weekly address on Saturday, Mr. Obama acknowledged that not everyone would be affected equally.

column3: Spending Cuts Imposed; U.S. Starts to Trim Its Budget
column4: “While not everyone will feel the pain of these cuts right away, the pain will be real,” he said.

column3: Spending Cuts Imposed; U.S. Starts to Trim Its Budget
column4: “Many middle-class families will have their lives disrupted in a significant way.” In the Republican response to Mr. Obama’s address, Representative Cathy McMorris Rodgers of Washington also called the cuts “devastating,” but said that Republicans in the House would not yield on taxes.

column3: Spending Cuts Imposed; U.S. Starts to Trim Its Budget
column4: “Spending is the problem, which means cutting spending is the solution,” she said.

column3: Spending Cuts Imposed; U.S. Starts to Trim Its Budget
column4: “It’s that simple.”

column3: Sequestration: So now what?
column4: Here’s the good news for the first day of the sequester: The world won’t end.

column3: Sequestration: So now what?
column4: For all the hype, spin and blame exchanged over the across-the-board cuts, the reality is they don’t mean the sudden economic collapse of America.

column3: Sequestration: So now what?
column4: So it’s understandable that Main Street hasn’t been tuning into this distinctly Not-Made-for-TV crisis: Polls show Americans aren’t paying close attention to the fight even though a slight majority says sequestration will hurt the economy.

column3: Sequestration: So now what?
column4: Story Continued Below But tell that to the people who will be affected.

column3: Sequestration: So now what?
column4: More than 1 million federal employees could get furlough notices.

column3: Sequestration: So now what?
column4: Programs for the poor could be cut.

column3: Sequestration: So now what?
column4: Fishermen from California to Alaska could miss the start of halibut season on March 23.

column3: Sequestration: So now what?
column4: ( PHOTOS: How sequestration could affect you) President Barack Obama will meet with House and Senate leaders Friday morning, but nobody expects a last-minute solution.

column3: Sequestration: So now what?
column4: More likely — a month of tense and complicated negotiations with Congress and the White House trying to address the $85 billion in domestic cuts at the same time they try to fund the government through the rest of the fiscal year before money runs out March 27.

column3: Sequestration: So now what?
column4: And if the cuts aren’t addressed?

column3: Sequestration: So now what?
column4: There’s more pain for everyone: Furlough notices could turn into office closures, federal tax returns could take longer to process and hurricane season could see fewer forecasters tracking storms.

column3: Sequestration: So now what?
column4: “It won’t be like a shutdown, where it’s like turning off the light switch,” Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano told reporters at the White House on Monday.

column3: Sequestration: So now what?
column4: “But all I can say for folks is these are the effects that will accrue.” Many of the agencies contacted by POLITICO this week said they still don’t know for sure when exactly the cuts will ripple through their ranks.

column3: Sequestration: So now what?
column4: But here’s a look ahead at what to expect: Friday Sequestration officially starts Friday — most likely at 11:59 p.m., though Obama could act sooner — when the Office of Management and Budget issues a notice ordering agencies to make cuts of about 9 percent for most nondefense programs and about 13 percent for defense programs.

column3: Sequestration: So now what?
column4: ( Also on POLITICO: Senate fails in last-chance bid to avoid sequester) OMB will simultaneously transmit a report to Congress with those same details.

column3: Sequestration: So now what?
column4: “That’s an important symbolic moment,” said OMB Controller Danny Werfel.

column3: Sequestration: So now what?
column4: “The reality is I think it becomes extraordinarily problematic and serious once we hit March 1 because then it’s real and then a lot of these things come to fruition in a much more exponential way.” Negotiations between agencies and union officials — already ongoing — will reach fever pitch Friday ahead of the release of the agency furlough notices.

column3: Sequestration: So now what?
column4: Talks center on how the furloughs will be implemented, who’s covered, mandatory days off around holidays and whether to go in phases over the next seven months so budget officials can re-evaluate whether more or less time off is needed.

column3: Sequestration: So now what?
column4: ( Also on POLITICO: When does sequestration start?)

column3: Sequestration: So now what?
column4: Programs that dole out funding as an intermediary — like public rent assistance, farm loans and food programs — will see immediate cuts.

column3: Sequestration: So now what?
column4: The same goes for the Farm Service Agency’s loans, particularly those for small, family-owned farms, which face a cut of $5.4 million, resulting in 890 fewer direct farm aid loans.

column3: White House to enact sequester cuts Friday, amid questions over impact
column4: WASHINGTON –  President Obama signed an order authorizing the government to begin cutting $85 billion from federal accounts, officially enacting across-the-board spending reductions.

column3: White House to enact sequester cuts Friday, amid questions over impact
column4: Obama acted Friday, the deadline for the president and Congress to avoid the steep, one-year cuts.

column3: White House to enact sequester cuts Friday, amid questions over impact
column4: The president placed blame squarely on Republican lawmakers at a Friday press conference for failing to stop automatic spending cuts that were to begin kicking in later in the day, calling the cuts "dumb, arbitrary."

column3: White House to enact sequester cuts Friday, amid questions over impact
column4: Republicans, for their part, said the fault was his, for insisting that increased taxes be part of the resolution The president said the impact of the cuts won't immediately be felt, but middle class families will begin to "have their lives disrupted in significant ways."

column3: White House to enact sequester cuts Friday, amid questions over impact
column4: He said that as long as the cuts stay in effect, Americans will know that the economy could have been better had they been averted.

column3: White House to enact sequester cuts Friday, amid questions over impact
column4: "The pain, though, will be real," Obama said.

column3: White House to enact sequester cuts Friday, amid questions over impact
column4: He said he still believed the cuts could be replaced but he wanted a deal that includes more tax revenue.

column3: White House to enact sequester cuts Friday, amid questions over impact

column3: White House to enact sequester cuts Friday, amid questions over impact
column4: "It's happening because of a choice that Republicans in Congress have made.

column3: White House to enact sequester cuts Friday, amid questions over impact
column4: We shouldn't be making a series of dumb, arbitrary cuts to things."

column3: White House to enact sequester cuts Friday, amid questions over impact

column3: White House to enact sequester cuts Friday, amid questions over impact

column3: White House to enact sequester cuts Friday, amid questions over impact

column3: White House to enact sequester cuts Friday, amid questions over impact

column3: White House to enact sequester cuts Friday, amid questions over impact
column4: "The discussion about revenue in my view is over.

column3: White House to enact sequester cuts Friday, amid questions over impact
column4: It's about taking on the spending problem here in Washington."

column3: White House to enact sequester cuts Friday, amid questions over impact

column3: White House to enact sequester cuts Friday, amid questions over impact

column3: White House to enact sequester cuts Friday, amid questions over impact

column3: White House to enact sequester cuts Friday, amid questions over impact
column4: In the days leading up to the deadline, there were few signs that either party had much progress on how to cut the federal debt that now tops $16.5 trillion.

column3: White House to enact sequester cuts Friday, amid questions over impact

column3: White House to enact sequester cuts Friday, amid questions over impact

column3: White House to enact sequester cuts Friday, amid questions over impact

column4: Administration officials say the impact of this and other cuts will build up over time; Obama describes the effect on the economy as a “tumble downward.” But some fiscal hawks see a silver lining, in that the sequester will force the government to trim the waste in order to shield higher-priority items.

column3: White House to enact sequester cuts Friday, amid questions over impact
column4: Already, the White House budget office is recommending agencies take a skeptical eye toward costly conferences and training programs.

column4: The two sides remain deadlocked over the issue of raising taxes.

column4: Republicans want to replace the current regime of cuts with different, more sensible, cuts.

column4: Democrats want to blend in a set of tax increases, closing loopholes for top earners and some corporations.

column4: The effects of the 2013 sequestration will be rolled out over the next several months.

column3: White House to enact sequester cuts Friday, amid questions over impact
column4: It won’t be a government shutdown but it will be a government slowdown.

column3: White House to enact sequester cuts Friday, amid questions over impact
column4: “The impact of this policy won’t be felt overnight but it will be real,” Obama said.

column3: White House to enact sequester cuts Friday, amid questions over impact
column4: “The longer these cuts are in place, the greater the damage.” The predicted impact of the spending cuts could come in flight delays, limited hours at national parks, longer wait times at border crossings and furloughs of civilian Pentagon employees – and workers at several other agencies.

column3: White House to enact sequester cuts Friday, amid questions over impact
column4: Some officials say the administration has the leeway, or should be given the leeway, to spread around the budget pain.

column3: White House to enact sequester cuts Friday, amid questions over impact
column4: “There is so much hype on this, it’s ridiculous,” David Walker, former U.S. comptroller general, told Fox News.

column3: White House to enact sequester cuts Friday, amid questions over impact
column4: “We spend as much money as the next 15 countries put together and some of the people who are hyping this big time are going to be really embarrassed.” How the public reacts to the cuts will have an effect on how Congress addresses the issue.

column3: White House to enact sequester cuts Friday, amid questions over impact
column4: If voters react with a shrug, the GOP may be less compelled to agree to the kinds of tax increases Obama wants.

column3: White House to enact sequester cuts Friday, amid questions over impact
column4: If there’s a big backlash, the Obama administration may take it as vindication that the public won’t stand for big cuts to federally funded programs.

column3: White House to enact sequester cuts Friday, amid questions over impact
column4: Still, Republicans point out that the sequester idea originated at the White House.

column3: White House to enact sequester cuts Friday, amid questions over impact
column4: “The sky is not going to fall but things will get progressively worse,” Maryland Democrat Rep. Chris Van Hollen said.

column3: White House to enact sequester cuts Friday, amid questions over impact
column4: White House spokesman Jay Carney said Friday’s talks are designed to be a “constructive discussion” about how to keep the deep spending cuts from having harmful consequences.

column3: White House to enact sequester cuts Friday, amid questions over impact
column4: The meeting, the first face-to-face since Obama was sworn in for his second term in January, will essentially look past the current $85 billion in cuts to the next looming fiscal crisis – a possible government shutdown.

column3: White House to enact sequester cuts Friday, amid questions over impact
column4: On March 27, the fiscal 2013 continuing appropriations resolution expires, cutting off the ability of most agencies and programs to operate.

column3: White House to enact sequester cuts Friday, amid questions over impact
column4: A new spending bill will be needed to keep the government from shutting down.

column3: White House to enact sequester cuts Friday, amid questions over impact
column4: Following March Madness – budget style – Congress will have two months to decide on the debt limit.

column3: White House to enact sequester cuts Friday, amid questions over impact
column4: Congress has suspended enforcement of the $16.4 trillion limit on federal borrowing until May 18.

column3: White House to enact sequester cuts Friday, amid questions over impact
column4: The short-term debt limit deal will then raise the borrowing limit the following day, on May 19, to the debt accumulated up through May 18.

column3: White House to enact sequester cuts Friday, amid questions over impact
column4: The short-term extension, approved in January, will allow what budget experts project will be $450 billion in additional borrowing before the debt limit is raised to a new, higher level.

column3: White House to enact sequester cuts Friday, amid questions over impact
column4: And then, even if no increase in granted by May 19, the Treasury Department will be able to stave off a final day of reckoning until late July or early August by redeploying cash management measures which would allow it to claw back about $220 billion worth of borrowing capacity.

column3: White House to enact sequester cuts Friday, amid questions over impact
