column3: Brief Supporting Same-Sex Marriage Gets More Republican Support
column4: More than two dozen Republicans — including a top adviser to Mitt Romney, the 2012 Republican presidential nominee — have added their names to a legal brief urging the Supreme Court to declare that gay couples have a constitutional right to wed.

column3: Brief Supporting Same-Sex Marriage Gets More Republican Support
column4: The brief comes as the White House is considering whether to weigh in on the same-sex marriage case; at this point, the Republicans who signed the document are taking a more expansive stance than President Obama, who favors same-sex marriage but has said he would leave it to the states, as opposed to making it a constitutional right.

column3: Brief Supporting Same-Sex Marriage Gets More Republican Support
column4: The list of Republicans on the brief now tallies more than 100, organizers say.

column3: Brief Supporting Same-Sex Marriage Gets More Republican Support
column4: It now includes Beth Myers, who ran Mr. Romney’s 2008 campaign and was a senior adviser to him in 2012; Charles Bass, a former member of Congress from New Hampshire; and Douglas Holtz-Eakin, an economist who advised Senator John McCain’s 2008 presidential campaign.

column3: Brief Supporting Same-Sex Marriage Gets More Republican Support
column4: Also on the list is B. J. Nikkel, who made national news last year when she became the only Republican on the Colorado House Judiciary Committee to vote in favor of same-sex civil unions.

column3: Brief Supporting Same-Sex Marriage Gets More Republican Support
column4: She previously worked as district director for Representative Marilyn Musgrave, a former congresswoman whose signature issue in Washington was banning same-sex marriage.

column3: Brief Supporting Same-Sex Marriage Gets More Republican Support
column4: The brief, organized by Ken Mehlman, a former chairman of the Republican National Committee who is gay, will be filed on Thursday as a friend-of-the-court, or amicus, brief to a lawsuit that seeks to overturn Proposition 8, a California ballot initiative that forbids same-sex marriage, and all similar bans.

column3: Brief Supporting Same-Sex Marriage Gets More Republican Support
column4: The landmark case will be heard alongside a request that the court overturn the 1996 federal Defense of Marriage Act, which defines marriage for the purposes of federal law as the union between a man and a woman.

column3: Brief Supporting Same-Sex Marriage Gets More Republican Support
column4: Mr. Obama strongly supports the repeal of the defense of marriage law, and has instructed his Justice Department not to defend it in court.

column3: Brief Supporting Same-Sex Marriage Gets More Republican Support
column4: His move prompted the House speaker, John A. Boehner, and the House Republican leadership to authorize the expenditure of tax dollars to defend the law; Mr. Boehner, who is personally opposed to same-sex marriage, has said he believes it is up to the Supreme Court, not the Obama administration, to determine the constitutionality of the measure.

column3: Brief Supporting Same-Sex Marriage Gets More Republican Support
column4: Last week, the administration filed its brief in the Defense of Marriage case, asking the court to declare the measure unconstitutional.

column3: Brief Supporting Same-Sex Marriage Gets More Republican Support
column4: The brief notes that same-sex couples may already legally marry in some states and argues that singling them out is “a harsh form of discrimination that bears no relation to their ability to contribute to society.” But the administration has been far more cautious in the Proposition 8 case.

column3: Brief Supporting Same-Sex Marriage Gets More Republican Support
column4: A White House official said Tuesday morning that no decision had been made on whether to file an amicus brief; the deadline is Thursday.

column3: Brief Supporting Same-Sex Marriage Gets More Republican Support
column4: The Wall Street Journal, citing unnamed sources, reported Tuesday evening that the administration was still weighing its decision, and was “looking at options that fall short of embracing a constitutional right'’ to same-sex marriage.

column3: Brief Supporting Same-Sex Marriage Gets More Republican Support
column4: Mr. Obama has made supporting same-sex marriage a central theme in his recent speeches, including his second inaugural address, and has often stated that Americans ought to have equal rights, “no matter who you love.” He announced during his re-election campaign last year that, after months of saying his views were “evolving,” he had concluded that gay couples ought to be allowed to marry.

column3: Brief Supporting Same-Sex Marriage Gets More Republican Support
column4: But in announcing that decision, Mr. Obama said he believed the issue would be “worked out at the local level,” because marriage has traditionally been the province of the states, not the federal government.

column3: Brief Supporting Same-Sex Marriage Gets More Republican Support
column4: That position enrages many gay rights activists, who view it as immoral and note that it was the same explanation opponents of interracial marriage once used to prevent couples like Mr. Obama’s own parents from marrying.

column3: Brief Supporting Same-Sex Marriage Gets More Republican Support
column4: The elder Obamas married in 1961 in Hawaii, which permitted interracial unions.

column3: Brief Supporting Same-Sex Marriage Gets More Republican Support
column4: But it was not until the landmark Loving v. Virginia case — decided in 1967, when Mr. Obama was 6 — that the Supreme Court declared interracial marriage a constitutional right and overturned a Virginia ban.

column3: Obama nears deadline on gay marriage decision
column4: WASHINGTON (AP) — In a historic argument for gay rights, President Barack Obama on Thursday urged the Supreme Court to overturn California's same-sex marriage ban and turn a skeptical eye on similar prohibitions across the country.

column3: Obama nears deadline on gay marriage decision
column4: The Obama administration's friend-of-the-court brief marked the first time a U.S. president has urged the high court to expand the right of gays and lesbians to wed.

column3: Obama nears deadline on gay marriage decision
column4: The filing unequivocally calls on the justices to strike down California's Proposition 8 ballot measure, although it stops short of the soaring rhetoric on marriage equality Obama expressed in his inaugural address in January.

column3: Obama nears deadline on gay marriage decision
column4: California is one of eight states that give gay couples all the benefits of marriage through civil unions or domestic partnership, but don't allow them to wed.

column3: Obama nears deadline on gay marriage decision
column4: The brief argues that in granting same-sex couples those rights, California has already acknowledged that gay relationships bear the same hallmarks as straight ones.

column3: Obama nears deadline on gay marriage decision
column4: "They establish homes and lives together, support each other financially, share the joys and burdens of raising children, and provide care through illness and comfort at the moment of death," the administration wrote.

column3: Obama nears deadline on gay marriage decision
column4: The brief marks the president's most expansive view of gay marriage and signals that he is moving away from his previous assertion that states should determine their own marriage laws.

column3: Obama nears deadline on gay marriage decision
column4: Obama, a former constitutional law professor, signed off on the administration's legal argument last week following lengthy discussions with Attorney General Eric Holder and Solicitor General Donald Verrilli.

column3: Obama nears deadline on gay marriage decision
column4: In a statement following the filing, Holder said "the government seeks to vindicate the defining constitutional ideal of equal treatment under the law."

column3: Obama nears deadline on gay marriage decision
column4: Obama's position, if adopted by the court, would likely result in gay marriage becoming legal in the seven other states: Delaware, Hawaii, Illinois, Nevada, New Jersey, Oregon and Rhode Island.

column3: Obama nears deadline on gay marriage decision
column4: In the longer term, the administration urges the justices to subject laws that discriminate on sexual orientation to more rigorous review than usual, as is the case for claims that laws discriminate on the basis of race, sex and other factors.

column3: Obama nears deadline on gay marriage decision
column4: The Supreme Court has never given gay Americans the special protection it has afforded women and minorities.

column3: Obama nears deadline on gay marriage decision
column4: If it endorses such an approach in the gay marriage cases, same-sex marriage bans around the country could be imperiled.

column3: Obama nears deadline on gay marriage decision
column4: Friend-of-the-court briefs are not legally binding.

column3: Obama nears deadline on gay marriage decision
column4: But the government's opinion in particular could carry some weight with the justices when they hear oral arguments in the case on March 26.

column3: Obama nears deadline on gay marriage decision
column4: Despite the potentially wide-ranging implications of the administration's brief, it still falls short of what gay rights advocates and the attorneys who will argue against Proposition 8 had hoped for.

column3: Obama nears deadline on gay marriage decision
column4: Those parties had pressed the president to urge the Supreme Court to not only overturn California's ban, but also declare all gay marriage bans unconstitutional.

column3: Obama nears deadline on gay marriage decision
column4: Still, marriage equality advocates publicly welcomed the president's legal positioning.

column3: Obama nears deadline on gay marriage decision
column4: "President Obama and the solicitor general have taken another historic step forward consistent with the great civil rights battles of our nation's history," said Chad Griffin, president of the Human Rights Campaign and co-founder of the American Foundation for Equal Rights, which brought the legal challenge to Proposition 8.

column3: Obama nears deadline on gay marriage decision
column4: The president raised expectations that he would back a broad brief during his inauguration address on Jan. 21.

column3: Obama nears deadline on gay marriage decision
column4: He said the nation's journey "is not complete until our gay brothers and sisters are treated like anyone else under the law."

column3: Obama nears deadline on gay marriage decision
column4: "For if we are truly created equal, than surely the love we commit to one another must be equal as well," he added.

column3: Obama nears deadline on gay marriage decision
column4: Obama has a complicated history on gay marriage.

column3: Obama nears deadline on gay marriage decision
column4: As a presidential candidate in 2008, he opposed the California ban but didn't endorse gay marriage.

column3: Obama nears deadline on gay marriage decision
column4: He later said his personal views on gay marriage were "evolving."

column3: Obama nears deadline on gay marriage decision
column4: When he ran for re-election last year, Obama announced his personal support for same-sex marriage, but said marriage was an issue that states, not the federal government, should decide.

column3: Obama nears deadline on gay marriage decision
column4: Public opinion has shifted in support of gay marriage in recent years.

column3: Obama nears deadline on gay marriage decision
column4: In May 2008, Gallup found that 56 percent of Americans felt same-sex marriages should not be recognized by the law as valid.

column3: Obama nears deadline on gay marriage decision
column4: By last November, 53 percent felt they should be legally recognized.

column3: Obama nears deadline on gay marriage decision
column4: Gay marriage supporters see the Supreme Court's hearing of Proposition 8, as well as a related case on the Defense of Marriage Act, as a potential watershed moment for same-sex unions.

column3: Obama nears deadline on gay marriage decision
column4: In a well-coordinated effort, opponents of the California ban flooded the justices with friend-of-the-court briefs in recent days.

column3: Obama nears deadline on gay marriage decision
column4: Among those filing briefs were 13 states, including four that do not now permit gay couples to wed, and more than 100 prominent Republicans, such as GOP presidential candidate Jon Huntsman and Florida Rep. Ileana Ros-Lehtinen.

column3: Obama nears deadline on gay marriage decision
column4: Two professional football players who have been outspoken gay rights advocates also filed a brief in the California case.

column3: Obama nears deadline on gay marriage decision
column4: Minnesota Vikings punter Chris Kluwe and Baltimore Ravens linebacker Brendon Ayanbadejo urged the court to rule in favor of same-sex marriage.

column3: Obama nears deadline on gay marriage decision
column4: The Supreme Court has several options to decide the case that would be narrower than what the administration is asking.

column3: Obama nears deadline on gay marriage decision
column4: The justices also could uphold the California provision, as opponents of gay marriage are urging.

column3: Obama nears deadline on gay marriage decision
column4: One group, the National Organization for Marriage, expects the Supreme Court to uphold the votes of over 7 million Californians to protect marriage, spokesman Thomas Peters said.

column3: Obama nears deadline on gay marriage decision
column4: One day after the Supreme Court hears the California case, the justices will hear arguments on provisions of the federal Defense of Marriage Act, which defines marriage as between a man and a woman for the purpose of deciding who can receive a range of federal benefits.

column3: Obama nears deadline on gay marriage decision
column4: The administration abandoned its defense of the act in 2011, but the measure will continue to be federal law unless it is struck down or repealed.

column3: Obama nears deadline on gay marriage decision
column4: In a brief filed last week, the government said Section 3 of the act "violates the fundamental constitutional guarantee of equal protection" because it denies legally married same-sex couples many federal benefits that are available only to legally married heterosexual couples.

column3: Obama nears deadline on gay marriage decision
column4: ___ Follow Julie Pace at http://twitter.com/jpaceDC and Mark Sherman at http://twitter.com/shermancourt

column3: White House denies staffer threatened Watergate journalist Woodward
column4: Another member of the Washington political media stepped forward Thursday to claim he was threatened by the Obama White House, shortly after the White House denied reports that an adviser threatened famed Watergate journalist Bob Woodward.

column3: White House denies staffer threatened Watergate journalist Woodward
column4: The latest claim comes from Lanny Davis, who served as counsel to former President Bill Clinton and later went on to write a column for The Washington Times.

column3: White House denies staffer threatened Watergate journalist Woodward
column4: In a radio interview on WMAL, Davis said that a "senior Obama White House official" once called his editor at the Times and said that if the paper continued to run his columns, "his reporters would lose their credentials."

column3: White House denies staffer threatened Watergate journalist Woodward
column4: Davis said he "couldn't imagine why this call was made" since he's an Obama supporter.

column3: White House denies staffer threatened Watergate journalist Woodward
column4: But he called the alleged threat "unfortunate."

column3: White House denies staffer threatened Watergate journalist Woodward
column4: The account comes after Woodward claimed Wednesday night that a White House aide sent him an email saying he would "regret" his recent reporting on the sequester battle.

column3: White House denies staffer threatened Watergate journalist Woodward
column4: The aide was not identified, but an official familiar with the exchange told Fox News it was National Economic Council Director Gene Sperling -- the tone of the email was rather mixed, as it also included an apology.

column3: White House denies staffer threatened Watergate journalist Woodward
column4: That was after Woodward wrote a column this past weekend claiming Obama was trying to re-write history -- regarding not only whose idea the sequester was, but also how it would take effect.

column3: White House denies staffer threatened Watergate journalist Woodward
column4: Woodward wrote that based on his reporting earlier in the budget battle, the president was trying to move the goalposts by trying to replace the sequester with a mix of tax hikes and spending cuts -- instead of solely spending cuts.

column3: White House denies staffer threatened Watergate journalist Woodward
column4: After Politico reported late Wednesday that Woodward was coming forward to claim he was threatened, a White House aide denied the claim.

column3: White House denies staffer threatened Watergate journalist Woodward
column4: "Of course no threat was intended," wrote the White House aide.

column3: White House denies staffer threatened Watergate journalist Woodward
column4: "As Mr. Woodward noted, the email from the aide was sent to apologize for voices being raised in their previous conversation.

column3: White House denies staffer threatened Watergate journalist Woodward
column4: The note suggested that Mr. Woodward would regret the observation he made regarding the sequester because that observation was inaccurate, nothing more.

column3: White House denies staffer threatened Watergate journalist Woodward
column4: And Mr. Woodward responded to this aide's email in a friendly manner."

column3: White House denies staffer threatened Watergate journalist Woodward
column4: White House Press Secretary Jay Carney said Thursday that Woodward and Obama's advisers merely "had a factual disagreement that I think we stand by."

column3: White House denies staffer threatened Watergate journalist Woodward
column4: He stressed that it's clear nobody was threatening anybody, and that the tone was "respectful."

column3: White House denies staffer threatened Watergate journalist Woodward
column4: According to Politico, Woodward said he was "yelled at" by an Obama aide over his weekend column in the Post.

column3: White House denies staffer threatened Watergate journalist Woodward
column4: Then, he said he received a page-long email from the aide -- apparently Sperling -- that said: "I apologize for raising my voice in our conversation today.

column3: White House denies staffer threatened Watergate journalist Woodward
column4: ... You're focusing on a few specific trees that give a very wrong impression of the forest.

column3: White House denies staffer threatened Watergate journalist Woodward
column4: But perhaps we will just not see eye to eye here.

column3: White House denies staffer threatened Watergate journalist Woodward
White House denies staffer threatened Watergate journalist Woodward
column4: I think you will regret staking out that claim."

column3: White House denies staffer threatened Watergate journalist Woodward
column4: Animosity between Woodward and the Obama team is rising, as the journalist has repeatedly needled the administration on its sequester talking points.

column3: White House denies staffer threatened Watergate journalist Woodward
column4: His reporting bolstered claims that the sequester idea originated at the White House.

column3: White House denies staffer threatened Watergate journalist Woodward
column4: And this week, he called the administration's handling of the cuts "madness."

column3: White House denies staffer threatened Watergate journalist Woodward
column4: Former Obama adviser David Plouffe tweeted Wednesday: "Watching Woodward last 2 days is like imagining my idol Mike Schmidt facing live pitching again.

column3: White House denies staffer threatened Watergate journalist Woodward
column4: Perfection gained once is rarely repeated."

column3: White House denies staffer threatened Watergate journalist Woodward
column4: Fox News' Ed Henry contributed to this report.

column3: Exclusive: The Woodward, Sperling emails revealed
column4: POLITICO’s “Behind the Curtain” column last night quoted Bob Woodward as saying that a senior White House official has told him in an email he would “regret” questioning White House statements on the origins of sequestration.

column4: The official in question is Gene Sperling, economic adviser to the president.

column3: Exclusive: The Woodward, Sperling emails revealed
column4: The White House has since pushed back, saying the exchange was far more innocuous than Woodward claims.

column3: Exclusive: The Woodward, Sperling emails revealed
column4: We have obtained, exclusively, the exchange.

column3: Exclusive: The Woodward, Sperling emails revealed
column4: Here it is: Story Continued Below From Gene Sperling to Bob Woodward on Feb. 22, 2013 Bob: I apologize for raising my voice in our conversation today.

column4: My bad.

column3: Exclusive: The Woodward, Sperling emails revealed
column4: I do understand your problems with a couple of our statements in the fall — but feel on the other hand that you focus on a few specific trees that gives a very wrong perception of the forest.

column3: Exclusive: The Woodward, Sperling emails revealed
column4: But I do truly believe you should rethink your comment about saying saying that Potus asking for revenues is moving the goal post.

column4: The idea that the sequester was to force both sides to go back to try at a big or grand barain with a mix of entitlements and revenues (even if there were serious disagreements on composition) was part of the DNA of the thing from the start.

column4: It was an accepted part of the understanding — from the start.

column3: Exclusive: The Woodward, Sperling emails revealed
column4: Really.

column3: Exclusive: The Woodward, Sperling emails revealed
column4: It was assumed by the Rs on the Supercommittee that came right after: it was assumed in the November-December 2012 negotiations.

column3: Exclusive: The Woodward, Sperling emails revealed
column4: There may have been big disagreements over rates and ratios — but that it was supposed to be replaced by entitlements and revenues of some form is not controversial.

column3: Exclusive: The Woodward, Sperling emails revealed
column4: (Indeed, the discretionary savings amount from the Boehner-Obama negotiations were locked in in BCA: the sequester was just designed to force all back to table on entitlements and revenues.)

column3: Exclusive: The Woodward, Sperling emails revealed
column4: I agree there are more than one side to our first disagreement, but again think this latter issue is diffferent.

column3: Exclusive: The Woodward, Sperling emails revealed
column4: Not out to argue and argue on this latter point.

column3: Exclusive: The Woodward, Sperling emails revealed
column4: Just my sincere advice.

column3: Exclusive: The Woodward, Sperling emails revealed
column4: Your call obviously.

column3: Exclusive: The Woodward, Sperling emails revealed
column4: My apologies again for raising my voice on the call with you.

column3: Exclusive: The Woodward, Sperling emails revealed
column4: Feel bad about that and truly apologize.

column3: Exclusive: The Woodward, Sperling emails revealed
column4: Gene From Woodward to Sperling on Feb. 23, 2013 Gene: You do not ever have to apologize to me.

column3: Exclusive: The Woodward, Sperling emails revealed
column4: You get wound up because you are making your points and you believe them.

column4: This is all part of a serious discussion.

column3: Exclusive: The Woodward, Sperling emails revealed
column4: I am listening.

column3: Exclusive: The Woodward, Sperling emails revealed
column4: I know you lived all this.

column3: Exclusive: The Woodward, Sperling emails revealed
column4: My partial advantage is that I talked extensively with all involved.

column3: Exclusive: The Woodward, Sperling emails revealed

column3: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Rule Against Key Provision of Voting Rights Act
column4: Conservative Supreme Court Justices expressed strong reservations today about a key provision of the Voting Rights Act that is intended to protect the rights of minorities and suggested it could be in danger.

column3: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Rule Against Key Provision of Voting Rights Act
column4: That section of the landmark 1965 law says that certain states, mostly in the South, must get any changes to voting regulations precleared by federal officials in Washington, D.C. RELATED: Challenge to the Voting Rights Act Reaches Supreme Court Solicitor General Donald B. Verrilli Jr. began arguments at the Court Wednesday by saying that the Voting Rights Act "made a huge difference in transforming the culture of blatantly racist vote suppression that characterized parts of this country for a century.

column3: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Rule Against Key Provision of Voting Rights Act
column4: Section 5 preclearance was the principal engine of that progress."

column3: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Rule Against Key Provision of Voting Rights Act
column4: But Chief Justice John Roberts expressed concern that Congress, when reauthorizing the law in 2006 for 25 more years, used an outdated "coverage formula" that singled out only a few states, mostly in the South.

column3: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Rule Against Key Provision of Voting Rights Act
column4: He asked Verrilli: "Is it the government's submission that the citizens in the South are more racist than citizens in the North?"

column3: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Rule Against Key Provision of Voting Rights Act
column4: The jurisdictions covered under the law include Alabama, Alaska, Arizona, Georgia, Louisiana, Mississippi, South Carolina, Texas and Virginia, as well as portions of California, Florida, Michigan, New Hampshire, New York, North Carolina and South Dakota.

column3: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Rule Against Key Provision of Voting Rights Act
column4: Justice Samuel Alito said, "There's no question that the Voting Rights Act has done enormous good."

column3: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Rule Against Key Provision of Voting Rights Act
column4: But he said that when Congress reauthorized it, it should have considered a new determination of which states should be covered.

column3: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Rule Against Key Provision of Voting Rights Act
column4: "Maybe the whole country should be covered.

column3: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Rule Against Key Provision of Voting Rights Act
column4: Or maybe certain parts of the country should be covered based on a formula that is grounded in up-to-date statistics, " he said.

column3: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Rule Against Key Provision of Voting Rights Act
column4: Justice Antonin Scalia spoke at length about the fact that the 2006 congressional vote to reauthorized the act was nearly unanimous.

column3: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Rule Against Key Provision of Voting Rights Act
column4: "I think it is attributable, very likely attributable, to a phenomenon that is called perpetuation of racial entitlement.

column3: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Rule Against Key Provision of Voting Rights Act
column4: It's been written about.

column3: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Rule Against Key Provision of Voting Rights Act
column4: Whenever a society adopts racial entitlements, it is very difficult to get out of them through the normal political processes.

column3: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Rule Against Key Provision of Voting Rights Act
column4: "And I am fairly confident it will be re-enacted in perpetuity unless a court can say it does not comport with the Constitution," he continued.

column3: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Rule Against Key Provision of Voting Rights Act
column4: "You have to show, when you are treating different states differently, that there's a good reason for it. "

column3: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Rule Against Key Provision of Voting Rights Act
column4: Scalia said, "That's the concern that those of us who have some questions about this statute have.

column3: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Rule Against Key Provision of Voting Rights Act
column4: It's a concern that this is not the kind of a question you can leave to Congress."

column3: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Rule Against Key Provision of Voting Rights Act
column4: After the dialogue, Roberts gave Verrilli an extra five minutes.

column3: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Rule Against Key Provision of Voting Rights Act
column4: "Thank you," Verrilli said, smiling.

column3: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Rule Against Key Provision of Voting Rights Act
column4: "I may need it for that question."

column3: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Rule Against Key Provision of Voting Rights Act
column4: "We are talking about the enforcement power that the Constitution gives to the Congress to make these judgments to ensure protection of fundamental rights," said Verrilli.

column3: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Rule Against Key Provision of Voting Rights Act
column4: He added that he thought it would be "extraordinary" to look behind the judgment of Congress on the basis of "that sort of motive analysis."

column3: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Rule Against Key Provision of Voting Rights Act
column4: Scalia's question bothered Justice Sonia Sotomayor who later asked a lawyer for Shelby County, Ala., "Do you think Section 5 was voted for because it was a racial entitlement?"

column4: And she also said, "Do you think that racial discrimination in voting has ended and there is none anywhere? "

column3: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Rule Against Key Provision of Voting Rights Act
column4: Sotomayor, one of the four liberals on the court, emerged as one of the most vocal defenders of the law.

column3: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Rule Against Key Provision of Voting Rights Act
column4: Bert W. Rein, the attorney challenging Section 5, said that the South had changed and that the coverage formula should not have been reauthorized.

column3: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Rule Against Key Provision of Voting Rights Act
column4: But Sotomayor cut him off.

column3: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Rule Against Key Provision of Voting Rights Act
column4: She said that even if some portions of the South had changed, "your county pretty much hasn't."

column3: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Rule Against Key Provision of Voting Rights Act
column4: "Why would we vote in favor of a county whose record is the epitome of what caused the passage of this law to start with," she asked.

column3: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Rule Against Key Provision of Voting Rights Act
column4: Justice Anthony Kennedy, who could be a crucial vote, asked a question that showed skepticism of Rein's position.

column3: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Rule Against Key Provision of Voting Rights Act
column4: He referred to Alabama's history of discrimination and noted that the state might be considered under any coverage formula.

column3: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Rule Against Key Provision of Voting Rights Act

column3: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Rule Against Key Provision of Voting Rights Act
column4: But as he had previously stated in a related case in 2009, Kennedy seemed concerned about the federalist implications of the law on the states.

column3: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Rule Against Key Provision of Voting Rights Act
column4: At one point he compared Alabama's sovereignty with the "trusteeship of the United States government."

column3: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Rule Against Key Provision of Voting Rights Act
column4: Justice Elena Kagan defended the 15,000-page legislative record Congress developed after holding 21 hearings.

column3: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Rule Against Key Provision of Voting Rights Act
column4: "It's hard to see how Congress could have developed a better and more thorough legislative record than it did," she said.

column3: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Rule Against Key Provision of Voting Rights Act
column4: Justice Clarence Thomas said nothing during arguments, but in 2009 he said he believed Section 5 " exceeded Congress' power to enforce the 15th Amendment."

column3: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Rule Against Key Provision of Voting Rights Act
column4: Protesters gathered on the steps outside the court before arguments began.

column3: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Rule Against Key Provision of Voting Rights Act

column3: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Rule Against Key Provision of Voting Rights Act
column4: Demonstrators from the Alliance for Justice lined up in front of the Supreme Court steps.

column3: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Rule Against Key Provision of Voting Rights Act
column4: Jackson, Sharpton and Lewis spoke for the group, and were joined by Rep. Marcia Fudge, D-Ohio, House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, Rep. Judy Chu, D-Calif., and Ruben Hinojos, D-Texas, among others.

column3: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Rule Against Key Provision of Voting Rights Act
column4: Fudge, chairwoman of the Congressional Black Caucus, had a clear retort to the arguments against Section 5: "You will not win.

column3: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Rule Against Key Provision of Voting Rights Act
column4: You will not win this battle."

column3: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Rule Against Key Provision of Voting Rights Act
column4: Sharpton ended his remarks with: "They don't use white sheets anymore, they use black robes."

column3: Supreme Court May Roll Back '65 Voting Rights Act
column4: Hearing arguments today in Washington, the court’s Republican-appointed justices expressed skepticism about the law’s requirement that all or parts of 16 states get federal clearance before changing their voting rules.

column3: Supreme Court May Roll Back '65 Voting Rights Act
column4: The court’s Democratic appointees voiced support for the law.

column3: Supreme Court May Roll Back '65 Voting Rights Act
column4: The case threatens one of the signature achievements of the civil rights movement, a law aimed at the discrimination that had kept generations of Southern blacks from voting.

column3: Supreme Court May Roll Back '65 Voting Rights Act
column4: Together with a separate fight over university affirmative action, the voting case may make the current Supreme Court term a watershed for the legal rules governing race, rolling back decades-old protections.

column3: Supreme Court May Roll Back '65 Voting Rights Act
column4: The court will rule in both cases by June.

column3: Supreme Court May Roll Back '65 Voting Rights Act
column4: The skeptics today included the likely swing vote, Justice Anthony Kennedy, who faulted Congress for relying on a decades- old formula for determining which states were covered.

column3: Supreme Court May Roll Back '65 Voting Rights Act
column4: Kennedy said if Congress is going to “single out” some states, “it should do it by name.” Preclearance Requirement At issue is the law’s so-called preclearance requirement, also known as Section 5.

column3: Supreme Court May Roll Back '65 Voting Rights Act
column4: The provision requires all or parts of 16 states, including virtually the entire South, to get federal approval before changing election districts, voting rules or even polling locations.

column3: Supreme Court May Roll Back '65 Voting Rights Act
column4: A separate section of the law bars voting discrimination nationwide and isn’t affected by the high court case.

column3: Supreme Court May Roll Back '65 Voting Rights Act
column4: The Justice Department has used the requirement to object to more than 2,400 state and local voting changes since 1982.

column3: Supreme Court May Roll Back '65 Voting Rights Act
column4: The Obama administration last year invoked Section 5 in stopping Republican-backed voter-identification laws in Texas and South Carolina from going into effect.

column3: Supreme Court May Roll Back '65 Voting Rights Act
column4: Congress reauthorized the law’s preclearance requirement in 2006, extending it for 25 years on lopsided votes: 98-0 in the Senate and 390-33 in the House.

column3: Supreme Court May Roll Back '65 Voting Rights Act
column4: Then-President George W. Bush, a Republican, signed the measure into law.

column3: Supreme Court May Roll Back '65 Voting Rights Act
column4: Civil rights leaders Al Sharpton and Jesse Jackson listened to the argument today in the packed courtroom, as other supporters of the Voting Rights Act rallied on the sidewalk in front of the court.

column3: Voting Rights Act under fire at Supreme Court
column4: Updated 02/27/2013 09:04 PM EST A key provision in one of the U.S.’s best known civil rights laws, the Voting Rights Act, received a highly skeptical and sometimes downright hostile response from the conservative justices at the Supreme Court on Wednesday.

column3: Voting Rights Act under fire at Supreme Court
column4: During contentious oral arguments, several liberal justices argued vigorously in favor of preserving a portion of the 1965 law which requires parts or all of 16 states to get permission from the Justice Department or a court before changing voting requirements or redrawing election districts.

column3: Voting Rights Act under fire at Supreme Court
column4: Story Continued Below However, the court’s conservatives seemed persuaded that when Congress renewed the Voting Rights Act for another 25 years in 2006, lawmakers lacked a sufficient basis for essentially keeping as is the list of states subject to the unusual pre-approval rule, known as Section 5.

column3: Voting Rights Act under fire at Supreme Court
column4: Justice Antonin Scalia argued that the court needed to step in because the overwhelming, bipartisan vote in favor of renewing the law in 2006 showed that lawmakers were reluctant to disturb what amounted to a “racial entitlement.” “I think it is attributable, very likely attributable, to a phenomenon that is called perpetuation of racial entitlement,” Scalia said.

column3: Voting Rights Act under fire at Supreme Court
column4: “Whenever a society adopts racial entitlements, it is very difficult to get out of them through the normal political processes….This is not the kind of a question you can leave to Congress.

column3: Voting Rights Act under fire at Supreme Court
column4: There are certain districts in the House that are black districts by law just about now.” The conservative justices seemed to have the votes to strike the provision down.

column3: Voting Rights Act under fire at Supreme Court
column4: Scalia suggested that regardless of the facts, lawmakers were very reluctant to disturb the law for fear for being accused of racism.

column3: Voting Rights Act under fire at Supreme Court
column4: “Even the name of it is wonderful: the Voting Rights Act,” he said sarcastically.

column3: Voting Rights Act under fire at Supreme Court
column4: “Who is going to vote against that in the future?” No other justice responded immediately to Scalia’s comments, but Justice Sonia Sotomayor made clear a few minutes later that she was irked by Scalia’s language.

column3: Voting Rights Act under fire at Supreme Court
column4: “Do you think that the right to vote is a racial entitlement in Section 5?…Do you think Section 5 was voted for because it was a racial entitlement?” she asked lawyer Bert Rein, who argued for Alabama’s Shelby County that the provision should be struck down.

column3: Voting Rights Act under fire at Supreme Court
column4: “No,” said Rein, who said the measure was Congress’s response “to a problem of race discrimination which it thought was prevalent in certain jurisdictions.” Earlier, Rein began his argument by arguing that there had been “unmistakable” change in the South in the nearly half-century since the the law was passed.

column3: Voting Rights Act under fire at Supreme Court
column4: That assertion, too, provoked Sotomayor.

column3: Voting Rights Act under fire at Supreme Court
column4: “Assuming some portions of the South have changed, your county pretty much hasn’t,” she interjected.

column3: Voting Rights Act under fire at Supreme Court
column4: She said Rein was arguing for “a county whose record is the epitome of what caused the passage of the [law] in the first place.” “You may be the wrong party bringing this,” Sotomayor said .

column3: Voting Rights Act under fire at Supreme Court
column4: Justice Elena Kagan noted that Alabama has no statewide officials who are black.

column3: Voting Rights Act under fire at Supreme Court
column4: “You’re objecting to a [coverage] formula, but any formula Congress could devise would capture Alabama,” she said.

column3: Hagel survives; opponents make nice
column4: They beat him up for months — in TV ads, in op-ed pages and in Congress, with delay after delay before his confirmation on Tuesday.

column3: Hagel survives; opponents make nice
column4: But now that Chuck Hagel is set to take the top job at the Pentagon on Wednesday, many of his Senate opponents seemed ready to mend fences just hours after trying to derail him.

column3: Hagel survives; opponents make nice
column4: As Hagel’s confirmation cleared the Senate floor 58 to 41, key Republican opponents who tried to wreck his nomination were already engaged in the Washington ritual of trying to make nice with their opponent after spending weeks opposing him.

column3: Hagel survives; opponents make nice
column4: Story Continued Below “I like Chuck,” said Sen. Jeff Sessions of Alabama — who once said he had “dramatic concern” about Hagel’s opposition to nuclear weapons and voted against him on Tuesday.

column3: Hagel survives; opponents make nice
column4: “I’ve been reluctant to criticize him, but I did disagree with some of his policy positions.

column3: Hagel survives; opponents make nice
column4: He went through a tough confirmation, was asked appropriate questions … I would think that personalities won’t be a problem.” ( Also on POLITICO: Senate confirms Chuck Hagel 58-41) Sen. Kelly Ayotte of New Hampshire, a member of the Armed Services Committee who voted against Hagel in committee and then in the full Senate, said she looked forward to meeting with the new defense secretary to tackle what she called common challenges.

column3: Hagel survives; opponents make nice
column4: “It is my hope … that he will sit down with everyone on the committee, and that we do what’s best for our Department of Defense going forward,” Ayotte said.

column3: Hagel survives; opponents make nice
column4: ( WATCH: Top 5 controversial Chuck Hagel positions) And Sen. Lindsey Graham of South Carolina, who signed a letter urging Hagel to withdraw, and said Hagel might embolden Iran and endanger the U.S.’s relationship with Israel, said he hoped Hagel would prove him wrong.

column3: Hagel survives; opponents make nice
column4: “I hope he exceeds expectations,” Graham said.

column3: Hagel survives; opponents make nice
column4: “It would be great for the country.

column3: Hagel survives; opponents make nice
column4: Sen. Hagel has a challenge to prove to people that he’s up for the job.” ( Also on POLITICO: Schumer plays role of deal-maker) For his part, Hagel pledged cooperation after his grueling battle for confirmation.

column3: Hagel survives; opponents make nice
column4: “I will work closely with Congress to ensure that we maintain the strongest military in the world and continue to protect this great nation,” he said in a statement.

column3: Hagel survives; opponents make nice
column4: Still, not everyone was eager to bury the hatchet.

column3: Hagel survives; opponents make nice
column4: Arizona Sen. John McCain, who faulted Hagel and joined his Republican colleagues in their delay tactics, said the responsibility for mending fences belongs solely with Hagel.

column3: Hagel survives; opponents make nice
column4: Asked about whether the relationship across the Potomac would improve, McCain answered, “It depends on what he does.” And freshman Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas) said the end of the Hagel battle is not necessarily a happy ending for the country.

column3: Hagel survives; opponents make nice
column4: “Chuck Hagel will be confirmed because Senate Democrats stood united behind President [Barack] Obama’s nomination of the most controversial secretary of defense in modern times,” Cruz said.

column3: Hagel survives; opponents make nice
column4: “I fervently hope that this confirmation does not embolden Iran to accelerate their nuclear weapons development; I fervently hope that this confirmation does not undermine our vital alliance with Israel.” ( PHOTOS: Chuck Hagel’s confirmation hearing) McCain and Cruz appeared to be outliers in their unwillingness to begin building a relationship now that Hagel will run the Pentagon.

column3: Hagel survives; opponents make nice
column4: Hagel’s opponents outside Congress — led by Bill Kristol, the conservative editor of The Weekly Standard and the chairman of the Emergency Committee for Israel — framed the drawn-out process as a success for their cause.

column3: Hagel survives; opponents make nice
column4: “We are heartened that the overwhelming majority of senators from one of the two major parties voted against confirming Mr. Hagel,” Kristol said in a statement after the vote.

column3: Hagel survives; opponents make nice
column4: “[We] do believe that, as a result of this battle, Mr. Hagel will be less free to pursue dangerous policies at the Defense Department and less inclined to advocate them within the administration.”

column3: Senate approves Hagel for Defense secretary after historic nomination fight
column4: The Senate approved Chuck Hagel's nomination for Defense secretary Tuesday, ending a contentious battle that exposed deep divisions over the president's Pentagon pick.

column3: Senate approves Hagel for Defense secretary after historic nomination fight
column4: After Republicans blocked the nomination earlier this month, they ultimately allowed for an up-or-down vote on Tuesday.

column3: Senate approves Hagel for Defense secretary after historic nomination fight
column4: The margin was historically close, with 58 senators supporting him and 41 opposing in the end.

column3: Senate approves Hagel for Defense secretary after historic nomination fight
column4: Though Hagel is himself a former Republican senator, the resistance to his nomination showed an unusual level of distrust among many senators toward the man chosen to lead the Defense Department -- at a time when the country is trying to wind down the Afghanistan war, while assessing emerging threats from Iran, Syria and elsewhere in the turbulent Middle East and North Africa.

column3: Senate approves Hagel for Defense secretary after historic nomination fight
column4: Republicans had earlier held up the nomination largely over demands for more information from the Obama administration on the Sept. 11 Libya attacks.

column3: Senate approves Hagel for Defense secretary after historic nomination fight
column4: But they also raised serious and recurring concerns about Hagel's record of past statements and votes on everything from Israel to Iran to nuclear weapons.

column3: Senate approves Hagel for Defense secretary after historic nomination fight
column4: Sen. John McCain, a leading Republican, clashed with his onetime friend over his opposition to President George W. Bush's decision to send an extra 30,000 troops to Iraq in 2007 at a point when the war seemed in danger of being lost.

column3: Senate approves Hagel for Defense secretary after historic nomination fight
column4: Hagel, who voted to authorize military force in Iraq, later opposed the conflict, comparing it to Vietnam and arguing that it shifted the focus from Afghanistan.

column3: Senate approves Hagel for Defense secretary after historic nomination fight
column4: McCain called Hagel unqualified for the Pentagon job even though he once described him as fit for a Cabinet post.

column3: Senate approves Hagel for Defense secretary after historic nomination fight
column4: Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid asked what the delaying tactics had done for "my Republican colleagues."

column3: Senate approves Hagel for Defense secretary after historic nomination fight
column4: "Twelve days later, nothing.

column3: Senate approves Hagel for Defense secretary after historic nomination fight
column4: Nothing has changed," the Democrat said on the Senate floor.

column3: Senate approves Hagel for Defense secretary after historic nomination fight
column4: "Sen. Hagel's exemplary record of service to his country remains untarnished."

column3: Senate approves Hagel for Defense secretary after historic nomination fight
column4: Reid blamed partisanship over Obama's second-term national security team for the delay.

column3: Senate approves Hagel for Defense secretary after historic nomination fight
column4: Both Reid and Senate Armed Services Committee Chairman Carl Levin, a Democrat, warned that it was imperative to act just days before automatic, across-the-board budget cuts hit the Pentagon.

column3: Senate approves Hagel for Defense secretary after historic nomination fight
column4: Hagel will succeed Defense Secretary Leon Panetta and join Obama's retooled national security team.

column3: Senate approves Hagel for Defense secretary after historic nomination fight
column4: Hagel's nomination bitterly split the Senate, with Republicans turning on their former party colleague and Democrats standing by Obama's nominee.

column3: Senate approves Hagel for Defense secretary after historic nomination fight
column4: Republicans also challenged Hagel about a May 2012 study that he co-authored for the advocacy group Global Zero, which called for an 80 percent reduction of U.S. nuclear weapons and the eventual elimination of all the world's nuclear arms.

column3: Senate approves Hagel for Defense secretary after historic nomination fight
column4: The group argued that with the Cold War over, the United States can reduce its total nuclear arsenal to 900 without sacrificing security.

column3: Senate approves Hagel for Defense secretary after historic nomination fight
column4: Currently, the U.S. and Russia have about 5,000 warheads each, either deployed or in reserve.

column3: Senate approves Hagel for Defense secretary after historic nomination fight
column4: Both countries are on track to reduce their deployed strategic warheads to 1,550 by 2018, the number set in the New START treaty that the Senate ratified in December 2010.

column3: Senate approves Hagel for Defense secretary after historic nomination fight
column4: In an echo of the 2012 presidential campaign, Hagel faced an onslaught of criticism by well-funded, Republican-leaning outside groups that labeled the former senator "anti-Israel" and pressured senators to oppose the nomination.

column3: Senate approves Hagel for Defense secretary after historic nomination fight
column4: The groups ran television and print ads criticizing Hagel.

column3: Senate approves Hagel for Defense secretary after historic nomination fight
column4: Opponents were particularly incensed by Hagel's use of the term "Jewish lobby" to refer to pro-Israel groups.

column3: Senate approves Hagel for Defense secretary after historic nomination fight
column4: He apologized, saying he should have used another term and should not have said those groups have intimidated members of the Senate into favoring actions contrary to U.S. interests.

column3: Senate approves Hagel for Defense secretary after historic nomination fight
column4: The nominee spent weeks reaching out to members of the Senate, meeting individually with lawmakers to address their concerns and seeking to reassure them about his policies.

column3: Senate approves Hagel for Defense secretary after historic nomination fight
column4: Hagel's halting and inconsistent performance during some eight hours of testimony at this confirmation hearing last month undercut his cause, but it wasn't a fatal blow.

column3: Senate approves Hagel for Defense secretary after historic nomination fight
column4: There was no erosion in Democratic support for the president's choice and Hagel already had the backing of three Republicans -- Sens.

column3: Senate approves Hagel for Defense secretary after historic nomination fight
column4: Thad Cochran, Mike Johanns and Richard Shelby.

column3: Senate approves Hagel for Defense secretary after historic nomination fight
column4: Sen. Rand Paul, R-Ky., also switched to support Hagel in the final vote.

column3: Senate approves Hagel for Defense secretary after historic nomination fight
column4: The Associated Press contributed to this report.

column3: The sequester? Never heard of it.
column4: Just one in four Americans are following very closely the debate over the $1.2 trillion in automatic spending cuts set to kick in on Friday, according to a new Washington Post-Pew poll, numbers that serve as a reminder that although talk of the sequester is dominating the nation's capital, it has yet to permeate the public at large.

column3: The sequester? Never heard of it.
column4: Not only are most people paying very little attention to the sequester, they also have only the faintest sense of what it would do.

column3: The sequester? Never heard of it.
column4: Less than one in five (18 percent) in the Post-Pew poll say they understand "very well" what would happen if the sequester went into effect.

column3: The sequester? Never heard of it.
column4: Those remarkably low numbers come despite the fact that the debate over the sequester has dominated Washington for much of the last month and, in the past week or so, President Obama has cranked up the direness of his warnings about what it could do to the economy.

column3: The sequester? Never heard of it.
column4: The lack of interest and knowledge about the sequester stands in contrast to the level of engagement the public showed in the last crisis -- the fiscal cliff.

column3: The sequester? Never heard of it.
column4: In Pew polling done in the run-up to the cliff, 40 percent of people said they were following the negotiations "very" closely, while roughly three in 10 said they had a very strong understanding of what it would mean for themselves and the country if we went off the cliff.

column3: The sequester? Never heard of it.
column4: What explains the difference between sequester and the cliff?

column3: The sequester? Never heard of it.
column4: At first glance, it appears to be the fact that, without tax increases included in the sequester, most people don't think it will really affect them.

column3: The sequester? Never heard of it.
column4: Just 30 percent of those tested say sequestration would have a "major effect" on their own financial situation -- a contrast to 43 percent who said the same about the fiscal cliff.

column3: The sequester? Never heard of it.
column4: The lack of a tax increase component in sequestration (Democrats do want some increases in revenue, but mostly through closing loopholes) is seen most clearly among Republicans -- with just one in five following news about the automatic cuts "very closely."

column3: The sequester? Never heard of it.
column4: Twice as many Republicans followed the fiscal cliff battle in December very closely.

column3: The sequester? Never heard of it.
column4: (While it is impossible to document via polling, we believe strongly that people have less of a sense for sequestration than they did for the fiscal cliff because it lacks a catchy name.

column3: The sequester? Never heard of it.
column4: Never underestimate the shallowness of the American public's news consumption habits.)

column3: The sequester? Never heard of it.
column4: The sea of numbers above should serve as a reminder that, for most Americans, the sequester doesn't exist.

column3: The sequester? Never heard of it.
column4: All of the talk about it coming out of Washington about whom to blame is lost on these people -- another fight in the nation's capital that they don't believe will have any actual impact in their lives.

column3: The sequester? Never heard of it.
column4: (For what it's worth, the poll shows that 45 percent say Republicans in Congress should be blamed for the sequester, while 32 percent blame President Obama.

column3: The sequester? Never heard of it.
column4: That's a far less sizable edge than the 26-point blame-game advantage that Obama enjoyed over congressional GOPers on the fiscal cliff.)

column3: The sequester? Never heard of it.
column4: Whether the lack of interest and knowledge regarding the sequester will change once it actually hits later this week remains to be seen, although these numbers suggest it's got a long way to go to even be a relevant issue for most people in the country.

column3: The sequester? Never heard of it.
column4: A very long way.

column3: The sequester: A tea party victory
column4: View Photo Gallery —The 2010 election brought scores of tea party-backed candidates into Washington.

column3: The sequester: A tea party victory
column4: Since the day they were swept to power more than two years ago, the tea party’s legions in Washington have made dramatic federal spending cuts the centerpiece of an economic message that has dominated the national debate.

column3: The sequester: A tea party victory

column3: WSJ: Dems Caving on Sequestration, Moving to Continuing Resolution Battle?
column4: Although the president is still out on the campaign trail sounding the hysterical alarm over proportionally miniscule sequester cuts, the Wall Street Journal reports that Beltway Democrats are already shifting their focus to the next manufactured crisis of their own making: Already looking past the current budget impasse gripping the capital, congressional leaders are quietly considering a deal to avert a government shutdown next month—but at the cost of prolonging across-the-board spending cuts.

column3: WSJ: Dems Caving on Sequestration, Moving to Continuing Resolution Battle?
column4: Attention is beginning to shift from Friday, when the broad cuts known as the sequester kick in, to the next budget deadline: Congress must pass a so-called continuing resolution by the end of March to keep funding government operations.

column3: WSJ: Dems Caving on Sequestration, Moving to Continuing Resolution Battle?
column4: Senior aides to House Speaker John Boehner (R., Ohio) and Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D., Nev.) have begun discussing a bill being prepared by House Republicans to fund government operations through September.

column3: WSJ: Dems Caving on Sequestration, Moving to Continuing Resolution Battle?
column4: Republicans want the bill to extend operating funds at the lower levels set to kick in Friday and to give more flexibility to the Pentagon to manage its cuts.

column3: WSJ: Dems Caving on Sequestration, Moving to Continuing Resolution Battle?
column4: Given the current balance of power in Washington, this comes close to a best-case-scenario outcome for the GOP.

column3: WSJ: Dems Caving on Sequestration, Moving to Continuing Resolution Battle?
column4: They'd help ease some of the sequester's defense cuts while steering the next six months of federal spending, based on the lower baseline that kicks in on Friday.

column3: WSJ: Dems Caving on Sequestration, Moving to Continuing Resolution Battle?
column4: The White House isn't happy about the reduced level of spending increases (remember, the sequester doesn't actually cut year-over-year spending in 2013; it slows the rate of growth), but some Democrats are acknowledging that Republicans may have the upper hand in shaping the next Continuing Resolution: A White House official said the administration wouldn’t go along with such a plan to extend the lower spending levels.

column3: WSJ: Dems Caving on Sequestration, Moving to Continuing Resolution Battle?
column4: And Democrats are insisting that the House GOP bill also give new latitude to domestic agencies as well as the Pentagon.

column3: WSJ: Dems Caving on Sequestration, Moving to Continuing Resolution Battle?
column4: But an aide to Senate Democratic leaders said such a measure might be politically difficult for the lawmakers to oppose, lest they bear the blame for shutting down the government.

column3: WSJ: Dems Caving on Sequestration, Moving to Continuing Resolution Battle?
column4: “There’s an emerging consensus that it would be a difficult battle to have,” said the Senate leadership aide.

column3: WSJ: Dems Caving on Sequestration, Moving to Continuing Resolution Battle?
column4: “I don’t think we could force a shutdown.” Last month, I urged Congressional Republicans to avert an ugly brawl over the debt limit, leave sequestration intact, then insist on lower spending in the Continuing Resolution.

column3: WSJ: Dems Caving on Sequestration, Moving to Continuing Resolution Battle?
column4: It appears as though they're prepared to do exactly that.

column3: WSJ: Dems Caving on Sequestration, Moving to Continuing Resolution Battle?
column4: GOP lawmakers gave the president a clean, temporary debt limit increase to strip away his "full faith and credit" scare tactics, they're poised to maintain current law and allow the president's sequester to go into effect, and they're gearing up to use that reduced baseline to hold down spending through the end of the fiscal year.

column3: WSJ: Dems Caving on Sequestration, Moving to Continuing Resolution Battle?
column4: Eighty-five billion dollars isn't much in the scheme of things, but it's something.

column3: WSJ: Dems Caving on Sequestration, Moving to Continuing Resolution Battle?
column4: Republicans will pass an acceptable CR out of the House, then it will be incumbent upon Senate Democrats to act.

column3: WSJ: Dems Caving on Sequestration, Moving to Continuing Resolution Battle?
column4: If the leadership aide quoted in the Journal is representative of his conference's mentality, Democrats are worried about losing the blame game over causing a government shut down.

column3: WSJ: Dems Caving on Sequestration, Moving to Continuing Resolution Battle?
column4: Republicans could accurately argue that they've passed legislation to keep the federal government open for business for the rest of the year, based on the lower output threshold established by the president's own sequester proposal.

column3: WSJ: Dems Caving on Sequestration, Moving to Continuing Resolution Battle?
column4: How would Democrats justify a shut down based on a demand for more spending?

column3: WSJ: Dems Caving on Sequestration, Moving to Continuing Resolution Battle?
column4: Contributing to the Left's jitters is a nagging concern that the sequester cuts will arrive at the end of the week, and few voters will notice or care: “The good news is, the world doesn’t end March 2.

column3: WSJ: Dems Caving on Sequestration, Moving to Continuing Resolution Battle?
column4: The bad news is, the world doesn’t end March 2,” said Emily Holubowich, a Washington health-care lobbyist who leads a coalition of 3,000 nonprofit groups fighting the cuts.

column3: WSJ: Dems Caving on Sequestration, Moving to Continuing Resolution Battle?
column4: “The worst-case scenario for us is the sequester hits and nothing bad really happens.

column3: WSJ: Dems Caving on Sequestration, Moving to Continuing Resolution Battle?
column4: And Republicans say: See, that wasn’t so bad.” In the long partisan conflict over government spending, the sequester is where the rubber meets the road.

column3: WSJ: Dems Caving on Sequestration, Moving to Continuing Resolution Battle?
column4: Obama is betting Americans will be outraged by the abrupt and substantial cuts to a wide range of government services, from law enforcement to food safety to public schools.

column3: WSJ: Dems Caving on Sequestration, Moving to Continuing Resolution Battle?
column4: And he is hoping they will rise up to demand what he calls a “balanced approach” to deficit reduction that replaces some cuts with higher taxes.

column3: WSJ: Dems Caving on Sequestration, Moving to Continuing Resolution Battle?
column4: But if voters react with a shrug, congressional Republicans will have won a major victory in their campaign to shrink the size of government.

column3: WSJ: Dems Caving on Sequestration, Moving to Continuing Resolution Battle?
column4: Instead of cancelling the sequester, the GOP will likely push for more.

column3: WSJ: Dems Caving on Sequestration, Moving to Continuing Resolution Battle?
column4: It wouldn't be a "major victory" in terms of real dollars -- we've already established that.

column3: WSJ: Dems Caving on Sequestration, Moving to Continuing Resolution Battle?
column4: But it could be a significant messaging boon to Republicans, and may also whet the public's professed appetite for across-the-board spending reductions (this disheartening caveat notwithstanding).

column3: WSJ: Dems Caving on Sequestration, Moving to Continuing Resolution Battle?
column4: Obama also runs the risk of falling victim to 'boy who cried wolf' syndrome, wherein Americans become more skeptical of future predictions of impending cut-related doom.

column3: WSJ: Dems Caving on Sequestration, Moving to Continuing Resolution Battle?
column4: Which brings us to the next stanza in this tug of war: The upcoming budget season.

column3: WSJ: Dems Caving on Sequestration, Moving to Continuing Resolution Battle?
column4: All of the irritating cliff-style showdowns over the last few years are directly attributable to the piecemeal, crisis-to-crisis governance spawned by the government refusal to pass budgets.

column3: WSJ: Dems Caving on Sequestration, Moving to Continuing Resolution Battle?
column4: House Republicans will again adhere to the law and pass a budget this spring (and House Budget Committee Chairman Paul Ryan says it will reflect the lower sequester baseline over the full budget window).

column3: WSJ: Dems Caving on Sequestration, Moving to Continuing Resolution Battle?
column4: The GOP has also ramped up public pressure on Senate Democrats to offer a budget for the first time in four years, introducing the "No Budget, No Pay" maneuver last month.

column3: WSJ: Dems Caving on Sequestration, Moving to Continuing Resolution Battle?
column4: Harry Reid's clan might be sensing that their budget abdication strategy is finally reaping diminishing returns; they claim they'll finally do their job for FY 2014.

column3: WSJ: Dems Caving on Sequestration, Moving to Continuing Resolution Battle?
column4: If and when that happens, the GOP can finally compare and contrast the two parties' competing visions and priorities based on actual proposals -- which is precisely what Democrats have been deliberately avoiding since 2009.

column3: WSJ: Dems Caving on Sequestration, Moving to Continuing Resolution Battle?
column4: Should Republicans manage to hold firm on Obama's sequester cuts, adhere to the new baseline through September in the subsequent CR, then force Democrats back into normal budgetary order, those accomplishments would amount to be a fine piece of political jujiusu.

column3: WSJ: Dems Caving on Sequestration, Moving to Continuing Resolution Battle?
column4: It's pretty pathetic that simply preventing minor spending reductions from being reversed and getting the ruling party to follow the law counts as 'achievements' these days, but such is life in year five of the Obama presidency.

column3: WSJ: Dems Caving on Sequestration, Moving to Continuing Resolution Battle?
