column3: White House ups rhetoric on dangers of sequester
column4: The Obama administration amped up its offensive Sunday with Republicans over the $85 billion in across-the-board federal spending cuts scheduled to kick in Friday, releasing fresh warnings of a “real impact on people’s lives” despite GOP claims the White House is exaggerating the potential ill effects.

column3: White House ups rhetoric on dangers of sequester
column4: A new administration report shows the effects of the so-called sequester cuts seeping far beyond just nonessential government workers and programs.

column3: White House ups rhetoric on dangers of sequester
column4: For example, the cuts would threaten 350 teaching jobs in Ohio, result in 4,180 fewer children in Georgia receiving vaccines, and cancel maintenance on 11 Navy ships docked in Norfolk, Va., says a new administration report.

column3: White House ups rhetoric on dangers of sequester
column4: “This will have macroeconomic consequences, cost hundreds of thousands of jobs across the country and jobs throughout the private sector from contractors,” Jason Furman, principal deputy director of the White House’s National Economic Council, told reporters during a conference call.

column3: White House ups rhetoric on dangers of sequester
column4: “This will have serious programmatic consequences for all 50 states and the District of Columbia.” SEE ALSO: White House sequester warnings fall on deaf ears The administration says federal agencies are drafting plans ahead of Friday’s deadline on how to best carry out the cuts, such as stopping contracts with private-sector vendors, employee layoffs, cutting grants or scaling back programs — or some combination of these and other cost-saving measures.

column3: White House ups rhetoric on dangers of sequester
column4: But Republicans accused the president of hypocrisy, saying he has chosen to go on a nationwide public relations tour in an attempt to shame them instead of staying in Washington to work on a deal.

column3: White House ups rhetoric on dangers of sequester
column4: “The White House needs to spend less time explaining to the press how bad the sequester will be and more time actually working to stop it,” said Michael Steel, a spokesman for House Speaker John A. Boehner, Ohio Republican.

column3: White House ups rhetoric on dangers of sequester
column4: SEE ALSO: Transportation Secretary LaHood: Sequester means furloughs Republicans also say the GOP-controlled House twice last year passed bills to replace the sequester with spending cuts, only to have the measures die in the Democrat-controlled Senate.

column3: White House ups rhetoric on dangers of sequester
column4: “What we still don’t know is whether the president has a plan for smarter, more common-sense cuts to the waste and endless growth in Washington,” Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, Kentucky Republican, said Sunday.

column3: White House ups rhetoric on dangers of sequester
column4: “Rather than issuing last-minute press releases on cuts to first responders or troop training or airport security, he should propose smarter ways to cut Washington spending.” The administration and Democrats counter that only a “balanced approach” that includes tax increases has a chance of passing both chambers.

column3: White House ups rhetoric on dangers of sequester
column4: They add the House bills died with the new Congress convened in January, and complain House leaders haven’t pushed new legislation this year to end the sequester.

column3: White House ups rhetoric on dangers of sequester
column4: Even before Sunday’s conference call, administration proxies had fanned out throughout the morning talk shows, warning of catastrophes that would result if $85 billion in spending cuts are imposed on a federal government that spends more than $3,000 billion annually and is more than $16,000 billion in debt.

column3: White House ups rhetoric on dangers of sequester
column4: Secretary of Transportation Ray LaHood, for example, warned Sunday that furloughs — including for air-traffic controllers — will be imminent in his department if the spending cuts kick in Friday, as scheduled.

column3: White House ups rhetoric on dangers of sequester
column4: “We’re going to look at everything we possibly can to get to where we need to be, which is about $600 million in cuts.

column3: White House ups rhetoric on dangers of sequester
column4: But we can’t do it without also furloughing people,” Mr. LaHood told CNN’s “State of the Union.” Education Secretary Arne Duncan said Sunday he will be powerless to avoid the sequester’s harmful effects to programs ranging from preschool to college.

column3: White House ups rhetoric on dangers of sequester
column4: “We don’t have any ability with dumb cuts like this to figure out what the right thing to do is,” he said on CBS’ “Face the Nation.” “It just means a lot more children will not get the kinds of services and opportunities they need and as many as 40,000 teachers could lose their jobs.” The administration also kept up its sequester blame game with congressional Republicans, accusing them of refusing to negotiate in good faith to avoid the cuts.

column3: White House ups rhetoric on dangers of sequester
column4: “Let’s be very clear; Democrats in the House are trying to resolve it, Democrats in the Senate are trying to resolve it, President Obama is trying to resolve it and the Republicans are making a policy choice that these cuts are better for the economy than eliminating loopholes and benefits for the wealthy,” White House senior adviser Dan Pfeiffer said Sunday during the conference call with reporters.

column3: White House ups rhetoric on dangers of sequester
column4: “It should be easy for Republicans to do, but they are so focused on not giving the president a win.” Mr. LaHood, a former Republican congressman from Illinois, also called on GOP members of Congress to put partisan politics aside and work with Mr. Obama to get a deal down to avoid the cuts.

column3: White House ups rhetoric on dangers of sequester
column4: “My audience is trying to persuade my former [congressional] colleagues that they need to come to the table with a proposal,” he said.

column3: White House ups rhetoric on dangers of sequester
column4: “While the president has, the Republicans haven’t.” The series of federal spending cuts — set into motion by the 2011 debt deal and delayed two months as part of the New Year’s Eve deal to avoid the “fiscal cliff” — would reduce the discretionary budgets of most agencies and programs by up to about 10 percent.

column3: White House ups rhetoric on dangers of sequester
column4: A few notable exemptions apply, such as Social Security, veterans programs and education Pell Grants.

column3: White House ups rhetoric on dangers of sequester
column4: And the sequester spared Medicare from a 2 percent cut to medical providers.

column3: White House ups rhetoric on dangers of sequester
column4: The sequesters never were intended to be implemented.

column3: White House ups rhetoric on dangers of sequester
column4: Rather, they were meant to be so onerous that all sides involved would be inspired to find other, more palatable ways to lower the debt and deficit.

column3: White House ups rhetoric on dangers of sequester
column4: Republicans, who initially balked at the pending Pentagon cuts, have concluded the sequesters offer their best immediate chances for real spending cuts.

column3: White House ups rhetoric on dangers of sequester
column4: Sen. Tom Coburn on Sunday accused the administration of “absolutely” exaggerating the potential adverse effects of the sequesters.

column3: White House ups rhetoric on dangers of sequester
column4: “You see the typical setup, a straw man,” he said on “Fox News Sunday.” The Oklahoma Republican, who said he doesn’t think a deal will be reached in time to avoid the cuts, added federal agencies such as the Homeland Security and Transportation departments have “plenty of flexibility” to find ways to implement the cuts in ways that don’t compromise safety or national security.

column3: White House ups rhetoric on dangers of sequester
column4: “There’s easy ways to cut this money that the American people will never feel,” he said.

column3: White House ups rhetoric on dangers of sequester
column4: “What you hear is an outrage because nobody wants to cut spending.

column3: White House ups rhetoric on dangers of sequester
column4: … It will be somewhat painful, but not cutting spending is going to be disastrous for our country.” But Danny Werfel, controller of the White House’s Office of Management and Budget, said federal agency heads have “limited flexibility” in how to impose the cuts.

column3: White House ups rhetoric on dangers of sequester
column4: “All of these various disruptions and harmful impacts — they’re going to occur,” he told reporters on the conference call.

column3: White House ups rhetoric on dangers of sequester
column4: “We can try to mitigate some of them, and we are to the best of our ability.

column3: White House ups rhetoric on dangers of sequester
column4: … [But] when you’re taking an $85 billion cut over a seven-month period, there is no road map of flexibility that allows you to eliminate many, many of the disruptions that are going to occur.”

column3: Sequester Impact On States Detailed In New White House Reports
column4: WASHINGTON -- It's looking increasingly like the government is about to impose on itself $85 billion in across-the-board spending cuts.

column3: Sequester Impact On States Detailed In New White House Reports
column4: So as part of its strategy to pressure Republicans into accepting new revenues as part of a deal to prevent the sequester from taking effect, the White House released new reports on Sunday that outline the ugly effects those cuts would have in individual states.

column3: Sequester Impact On States Detailed In New White House Reports
column4: Each state's report is linked below.

column3: Sequester Impact On States Detailed In New White House Reports
column4: But Jason Furman, principal deputy director of the White House's National Economic Council, pulled out some state-specific examples of the ways the cuts will hurt education, national defense, public health and the economy.

column3: Sequester Impact On States Detailed In New White House Reports
column4: In Ohio, 350 teacher and teacher-aide jobs are at risk, which means 43,000 fewer students will be served, Furman said on a Sunday conference call with reporters.

column3: Sequester Impact On States Detailed In New White House Reports
column4: In Virginia, 90,000 civilian Department of Defense employees would be furloughed.

column3: Sequester Impact On States Detailed In New White House Reports
column4: About 4,180 fewer children in Georgia would get vaccines and, in Kentucky, 400 fewer victims of domestic violence would end up being served.

column3: Sequester Impact On States Detailed In New White House Reports
column4: Recently approved aid for Hurricane Sandy relief efforts will also be at risk, officials said, and commuters should expect more delays in airports.

column3: Sequester Impact On States Detailed In New White House Reports
column4: President Barack Obama's deficit reduction plan, which includes new revenues in addition to spending cuts, would be a "much better course, economically and substantively" than the sequester, Furman said.

column3: Sequester Impact On States Detailed In New White House Reports
column4: The president's proposal would achieve $1.8 trillion in deficit reduction, made up of roughly $1.1 trillion in spending cuts and $680 billion in new revenues drawn from limiting deductions and closing tax loopholes for the wealthiest Americans.

column3: Sequester Impact On States Detailed In New White House Reports
column4: White House senior advisor Dan Pfeiffer said the blame will fall squarely on House Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio) and Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) if the sequester kicks in, since they aren't budging in accepting new revenues that stem from higher taxes on the wealthy.

column3: Sequester Impact On States Detailed In New White House Reports
column4: "Republicans are making a policy choice that these are cuts are better for the economy than closing loopholes that benefit the wealthy," Pfeiffer said on the same call Sunday.

column3: Sequester Impact On States Detailed In New White House Reports
column4: The American people, he said, "overwhelmingly disagree with that choice."

column3: Sequester Impact On States Detailed In New White House Reports
column4: Despite saying it will be Republicans' fault if the sequester takes effect, Pfeiffer said it "misses the point" to try to place blame for coming up with the sequester idea at all.

column3: Sequester Impact On States Detailed In New White House Reports
column4: It was never intended to take effect; Obama and Congress signed off on it during the 2011 debt fight purely as a way to put more pressure on themselves to come up with something better than sweeping, across-the-board cuts that total $1 trillion over ten years.

column3: Sequester Impact On States Detailed In New White House Reports
column4: But they failed to do so, and now that sequestration may become a reality, partisan finger-pointing has escalated in recent weeks over whose great idea that was in the first place.

column3: Sequester Impact On States Detailed In New White House Reports
column4: "You should ask House Republicans why they think this is such an important debate," Pfeiffer said.

column3: Sequester Impact On States Detailed In New White House Reports
column4: "It's a fairly stupid one."

column3: Sequester Impact On States Detailed In New White House Reports
column4: GOP leaders issued statements later Sunday trashing Obama for not doing enough on overall deficit reduction.

column3: Sequester Impact On States Detailed In New White House Reports
column4: “Rather than issuing last-minute press releases on cuts to first responders or troop training or airport security, he should propose smarter ways to cut Washington spending.

column3: Sequester Impact On States Detailed In New White House Reports
column4: After all, Washington spending, even with the sequester, is bigger than it was when he got here,” McConnell said.

column3: Sequester Impact On States Detailed In New White House Reports
column4: “Republicans in the House have voted -- twice -- to replace President Obama's sequester with smarter spending cuts,” said Boehner spokesman Michael Steel.

column3: Sequester Impact On States Detailed In New White House Reports
column4: “The White House needs to spend less time explaining to the press how bad the sequester will be and more time actually working to stop it."

column3: Sequester Impact On States Detailed In New White House Reports
column4: Some governors bracing for the effects of the sequester are emphasizing the need for flexibility in making those cuts in their states.

column3: Sequester Impact On States Detailed In New White House Reports
column4: "We are budget balancers.

column3: Sequester Impact On States Detailed In New White House Reports
column4: There is an art to it," said North Dakota Gov.

column3: Sequester Impact On States Detailed In New White House Reports
column4: Jack Dalrymple (R), talking to HuffPost at the National Governors Association meeting in Washington, D.C. this weekend.

column3: Sequester Impact On States Detailed In New White House Reports
column4: "The worst thing is to have no flexibility."

column3: Sequester Impact On States Detailed In New White House Reports
column4: Dalrymple said governors were briefed at the meeting that the cuts would come from individual federal line items that would flow down to the states, a plan he said he feared wouldn't give state officials enough control over how their states were impacted.

column4: New Hampshire Gov.

column3: Sequester Impact On States Detailed In New White House Reports
column4: Maggie Hassan (D), meanwhile, told HuffPost the real focus should be on passing Obama's proposal, not on how states should be preparing for cuts that will hurt the middle class.

column3: Sequester Impact On States Detailed In New White House Reports
column4: The sequester "is going to stop our economic recovery in its tracks," Hassan said.

column3: Sequester Impact On States Detailed In New White House Reports
column4: It's not surprising that some Democratic governors are criticizing GOP lawmakers for the sequester stalemate.

column3: Sequester Impact On States Detailed In New White House Reports
column4: But now even some conservative Republican governors are saying it's time for lawmakers in their party to stop drawing a hard line at including new revenues in a fiscal deal.

column4: "We don’t like taxes.

column3: Sequester Impact On States Detailed In New White House Reports
column4: "But we know we have to be pragmatic.

column4: We know there has to be some kind of compromise, but dang it, they need to get the job done.

column3: Obama urges Supreme Court to strike down federal Defense of Marriage Act
column4: The Obama administration is asking the Supreme Court to strike down the federal law defining marriage as a union between only a man and a woman.

column3: Obama urges Supreme Court to strike down federal Defense of Marriage Act
column4: The request regarding the 1996 Defense of Marriage Act was made Friday in a brief by Solicitor General Donald Verrilli that argues the law is unconstitutional because it violates "the fundamental guarantee of equal protection."

column3: Obama urges Supreme Court to strike down federal Defense of Marriage Act
column4: The high court is set to hear two cases next month on the issue: the constitutional challenge on Proposition 8, the 2008 California that allowed same-sex marriages in the state that two years later was overturned, and United States v. Windsor, which challenges DOMA.

column3: Obama urges Supreme Court to strike down federal Defense of Marriage Act
column4: Edith Windsor, a California resident, was married to her female partner in Canada in 2007 but was required to pay roughly $360,000 in federal estate taxes because the marriage is not recognized under DOMA.

column3: Obama urges Supreme Court to strike down federal Defense of Marriage Act
column4: The law "denies to tens of thousands of same-sex couples who are legally married under state law an array of important federal benefits that are available to legally married opposite-sex couples," Verrilli’s brief in part states.

column3: Obama urges Supreme Court to strike down federal Defense of Marriage Act
column4: House Republicans also purportedly filed a brief Friday, arguing for the right to defend DOMA.

column3: Obama urges Supreme Court to strike down federal Defense of Marriage Act
column4: Obama’s move comes as no surprise, considering he said during his first term that he personally is in favor of gay marriage.

column3: Obama urges Supreme Court to strike down federal Defense of Marriage Act
column4: And he ended the U.S. military’s “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy, opening the way for gays to serve openly.

column3: Obama urges Supreme Court to strike down federal Defense of Marriage Act
column4: More recently, during Obama’s second inaugural address, he hinted at further action.

column3: Obama urges Supreme Court to strike down federal Defense of Marriage Act
column4: "Our journey is not complete until our gay brothers and sisters are treated like anyone else under the law, for if we are truly created equal," he said.

column3: Obama urges Supreme Court to strike down federal Defense of Marriage Act
column4: The court is taking up the California case March 26 and has several options.

column3: Obama urges Supreme Court to strike down federal Defense of Marriage Act
column4: Among them are upholding the state ban on gay marriage and saying residents of a state have the right to make that call.

column3: Obama urges Supreme Court to strike down federal Defense of Marriage Act
column4: The nine justices also could endorse an appeals court ruling that would make same-sex marriage legal in California, but it would apply only to that state.

column3: Obama urges Supreme Court to strike down federal Defense of Marriage Act
column4: Twenty-nine other states have constitutional amendments banning gay marriage, while nine states and Washington, D.C., recognize same-sex marriage.

column3: Obama urges Supreme Court to strike down federal Defense of Marriage Act
column4: Public opinion has shifted in support of gay marriage in recent years.

column3: Obama urges Supreme Court to strike down federal Defense of Marriage Act
column4: In May 2008, Gallup found that 56 percent of Americans felt same-sex marriages should not be recognized by the law as valid.

column3: Obama urges Supreme Court to strike down federal Defense of Marriage Act
column4: By November 2012, some 53 percent felt they should be legally recognized.

column3: Obama urges Supreme Court to strike down federal Defense of Marriage Act
column4: The Associated Press contributed to this report.

column3: Obama brief fuels gay marriage speculation
column4: A legal brief the Justice Department filed with the Supreme Court Friday asking the justices to strike down a key part of the Defense of Marriage Act is raising hopes among gay rights advocates that President Barack Obama is on the verge of embracing a federal constitutional right to same-sex marriage.

column3: Obama brief fuels gay marriage speculation
column4: The brief formally urges the court to declare unconstitutional the portion of the 1996 law barring recognition of same-sex marriages by the federal government for income tax purposes, federal employee benefits, immigration and myriad other programs.

column3: Obama brief fuels gay marriage speculation
column4: Story Continued Below ( FULL TEXT: The White House's brief) The portion of DOMA barring federal benefits for same-sex spouses “targets the many gay and lesbian people legally married under state law for a harsh form of discrimination that bears no relation to their ability to contribute to society,” Solicitor General Donald Verrilli and other government lawyers write in the brief.

column3: Obama brief fuels gay marriage speculation
column4: “It is abundantly clear that this discrimination does not substantially advance an interest in protecting marriage, or any other important interest.

column3: Obama brief fuels gay marriage speculation
column4: The statute simply cannot be reconciled with the Fifth Amendment’s guarantee of equal protection.

column3: Obama brief fuels gay marriage speculation
column4: The Constitution therefore requires that Section 3 [of DOMA] be invalidated.” The brief pulls few punches in its effort to knock out DOMA, using sweeping language about the history of discrimination against gays and finding no legitimacy in the reasons some have offered for rejecting same-sex marriages.

column3: Obama brief fuels gay marriage speculation
column4: The unsparing tone of the government’s brief led some observers to suspect that the Justice Department is laying the groundwork to endorse a federal constitutional right to same-sex marriage in another pending case that addresses that question more directly.

column3: Obama brief fuels gay marriage speculation
column4: ( Also on POLITICO: New gay marriage ad won't use Laura Bush) The Obama administration must decide by next week whether to join with those urging the court to strike down California’s voter-approved ban on gay marriage, Proposition 8.

column3: Obama brief fuels gay marriage speculation
column4: The federal government is not required to file any brief in the Prop.

column3: Obama brief fuels gay marriage speculation
column4: 8 case, but those arguing against the measure and in favor of a constitutional right to gay marriage have until Thursday to weigh in with the high court.

column3: Obama brief fuels gay marriage speculation
column4: “There is nothing at all tentative about the government’s embrace of gay equality in this brief.

column3: Obama brief fuels gay marriage speculation
column4: And next week I think we will see the government urging the same standard of review be used to overturn Prop.

column3: Obama brief fuels gay marriage speculation
column4: 8, and with it, all anti-gay-marriage laws,” said Richard Socarides, a gay rights advocate and White House adviser to President Bill Clinton.

column3: Obama brief fuels gay marriage speculation
column4: “It’s clear from the administration’s DOMA brief that they understand and now embrace its connection to the Prop.

column3: Obama brief fuels gay marriage speculation
column4: 8 case.

column3: Obama brief fuels gay marriage speculation
column4: The discrimination evidenced by Prop.

column3: Obama brief fuels gay marriage speculation
column4: 8 itself is cited to support the standard of review urged by the government to strike down DOMA.”

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: “The president’s sequester is the wrong way to reduce the deficit, but it is here to stay until Washington Democrats get serious about cutting spending.” \-- House Speaker John Boehner in a Wall Street Journal Op-Ed on Wednesday.

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: Is sequestration better than nothing?

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: The inability of Republicans to plainly answer that question is giving President Obama the upper hand in the ongoing spat over automatic decreases to automatic increases in federal spending due to kick in a week from Friday.

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: Republicans, especially Defense Department stalwarts, have spent 19 months doomsaying the reductions.

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: The cuts have been described in apocalyptic terms over and over and over again.

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: “Harsh.” “Brutal.” “Devastating.” Did they suppose that Obama would be on the other side of this issue?

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: Did they think that the greatest enthusiast for federal spending since Lyndon Johnson would suddenly become a deficit hawk?

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: Did they think that the master of the perpetual campaign would grimly and stoically oversee the imposition of the cuts?

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: The answer to almost any riddle about Obama – the presidential response to almost any problem – involves three things: Campaigning, calls for more taxes and spending and blaming Republicans.

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: Millions out of work?

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: Head to Ohio to call for tax increases on rich people to finance stimulus spending blocked by Republicans who are beholden to “millionaires and billionaires.” Gas prices too high?

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: Head to Virginia to call for tax increases on energy companies to finance solar-panel subsidies blocked by Republicans beholden to “big oil.” Illegal immigrants driving down wages?

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: Head to Nevada to call for tax increases on top earners to finance new education programs to help train workers for the “jobs of tomorrow” blocked by Republicans beholden to xenophobic rural voters.

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: Obama repeats this so often that if he were to run out of Rice Krispies at the breakfast table, one would almost expect him to hop Air Force One for Battle Creek, Mich. and call for a tax hike to finance research into renewable cereal technology blocked by Republicans in the thrall of “big breakfast.” So how is it that even with nearly two years to prepare for this moment, Republicans are letting themselves get rope-a-doped again?

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: The biggest part is the GOP’s long-standing support for a mighty military.

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: Their party was forged in its current form by Ronald Reagan and annealed in the 9/11 era, so many Republicans see keeping up Pentagon spending on an ideological par with low taxes and small government.

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: Deficits, as Republicans argued in the Reagan and George W. Bush military buildups, were certainly secondary to a strong national defense.

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: Hawkish Republicans never liked making the military part of the cuts plan, preferring to hold the line that not cutting spending at all was better than having any cuts at the Pentagon.

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: But their argument for maintaining military sacrosanctity lost out to the case made by deficit hawks who said that without the sequestration, Obama would end up getting a debt limit increase without ever making any real cuts.

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: This split produced a bizarre strategy to try to shame the president into agreeing to cut welfare and domestic programs he likes in order to spare the military.

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: [pullquote] But why would he do that?

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: Obama has been trying to hike domestic spending and lower military spending his whole career.

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: Did Republican members of Congress, who are mostly either unknown or disliked, believe that they could convince a war-weary public to push a re-elected president into doing the opposite of what he has always done?

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: C’mon, dude.

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: After months of Republicans screaming about the damage and danger of the automatic reductions, they now are somehow surprised to see the president joining the chorus.

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: “Yes!” he hollers.

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: “Those guys are right.

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: This thing is a doomsday machine!

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: We have to stop it!” And the Republican response to this?

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: Complain that it was actually Obama’s idea.

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: It was.

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: So what?

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: It was his idea for placating Republicans into giving him a debt bump, not something that he wanted or liked.

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: And now, he’s using his celebrity and media megaphone to try to undo it.

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: That would mean that he would get nearly his original demand in the 2011 debt fight: an unconditional increase.

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: So here sit Republicans, teeth clenched, gripping their desks, waiting for the “devastating” cuts to explode the economy and just hoping that Obama will get some of the blame for having invented the thing.

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: They are assuming that $85 billion less spent by the government will cause devastation in an economy of some $16 trillion.

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: What a bunch of Keynesians.

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: If the cuts are so bad, why not just stop them?

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: Quit the puffery about offsets versus tax hikes and just kill the monster they helped make.

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: The Senate would surely go along and the president would only too happily sign.

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: As it is, Republicans and Obama look like two firemen standing outside of a burning building arguing about whether to use water from the hydrant or the truck to put it out.

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: “Wait until you see my press release blaming you!” screams one.

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: “Oh yeah, well I’m going to hit you with the snarkiest Tweets ever!” screams the other.

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: Republicans have rhetorically contorted themselves into what Obama has long accused them of being: politicians who would harm the American economy and people in order to win a political fight with him.

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: Their message is that they could stop the terrible thing, but won’t until Obama gives in.

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: What they have never really done is make an argument that having the cuts go into place is better than not.

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: And Now, A Word From Charles “They are doing it because it's the only hope of a dollar worth of cuts out of this administration.

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: This is in law.

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: It's an amount that at least you can get by doing nothing.

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: And unless they allow this to go ahead Obama will give you no cuts in an entire term and we're going to go over a Greek cliff.” \-- Charles Krauthammer on “Special Report with Bret Baier.” Chris Stirewalt is digital politics editor for Fox News, and his POWER PLAY column appears Monday-Friday on FoxNews.com.

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: Catch Chris Live online daily at 11:30amET  at  http:live.foxnews.com.

column3: Do Republicans Really Like Lower Spending or Not?
column4: Chris Stirewalt joined Fox News Channel (FNC) in July of 2010 and serves as politics editor based in Washington, D.C.

column3: Pentagon notifies Congress of likely civilian furloughs over budget cuts
column4: Defense Secretary Leon Panetta told Congress on Wednesday that if automatic government spending cuts kick in on March 1 he may have to shorten the workweek for the "vast majority" of the Defense Department's 800,000 civilian workers.

column3: Pentagon notifies Congress of likely civilian furloughs over budget cuts
column4: They would lose one day of work per week, or 20 percent of their pay, for up to 22 weeks, probably starting in late April.

column3: Pentagon notifies Congress of likely civilian furloughs over budget cuts
column4: To dispel the notion that this is mainly a problem for the nation's capital, the Pentagon's budget chief, Robert Hale, told reporters that the economic impact would be felt nationwide.

column3: Pentagon notifies Congress of likely civilian furloughs over budget cuts
column4: The biggest potential losses, in term of total civilian payroll dollars, would be in Virginia, California, Maryland, Texas and Georgia, according to figures provided by the Pentagon.

column3: Pentagon notifies Congress of likely civilian furloughs over budget cuts
column4: Hale said the unpaid leaves for civilian workers would begin in late April and would save $4 billion to $5 billion if extended through the end of the budget year, Sept. 30.

column3: Pentagon notifies Congress of likely civilian furloughs over budget cuts
column4: That is only a fraction of the $46 billion the Pentagon would have to cut this budget year unless a deficit-reduction deal is reached.

column3: Pentagon notifies Congress of likely civilian furloughs over budget cuts
column4: Panetta also said the across-the-board spending reductions would "put us on a path toward a hollow force," meaning a military incapable of fulfilling all of its missions.

column3: Pentagon notifies Congress of likely civilian furloughs over budget cuts
column4: In a written message to employees, Panetta said that he notified members of Congress Wednesday that if the White House and Congress cannot strike a deficit reduction deal before March 1 to avoid the furloughs, all affected workers will get at least 30 days' advance notice.

column3: Pentagon notifies Congress of likely civilian furloughs over budget cuts
column4: "In the event of sequestration we will do everything we can to be able to continue to perform our core mission of providing for the security of the United States, but there is no mistaking that the rigid nature of the cuts forced upon this department, and their scale, will result in a serious erosion of readiness across the force," Panetta wrote.

column3: Pentagon notifies Congress of likely civilian furloughs over budget cuts
column4: Adding his voice to the budget debate, Secretary of State John Kerry said the fiscal impasse is a serious threat to American credibility around the world.

column3: Pentagon notifies Congress of likely civilian furloughs over budget cuts
column4: "Think about it: It is hard to tell the leadership of any number of countries that they have to resolve their economic issues if we don't resolve our own," Kerry said Wednesday at the University of Virginia.

column3: Pentagon notifies Congress of likely civilian furloughs over budget cuts
column4: House Speaker John Boehner put the blame on Obama and said he agrees with Panetta that automatic spending cuts would devastate the military.

column3: Pentagon notifies Congress of likely civilian furloughs over budget cuts
column4: Boehner released a copy of Panetta's letter formally notifying Congress that the Pentagon will have to consider furloughing a large portion of its civilian workforce if sequestration kicks in.

column3: Pentagon notifies Congress of likely civilian furloughs over budget cuts
column4: "The furloughs contemplated by this notice will do real harm to our national security," Panetta wrote in his congressional notification letter, adding that it would make troops less ready for combat and slow the acquisition of important weapons.

column3: Pentagon notifies Congress of likely civilian furloughs over budget cuts
column4: "Overall, sequestration will put us on a path toward a hollow force and inflict serious damage on our national security," Panetta wrote.

column3: Pentagon notifies Congress of likely civilian furloughs over budget cuts
column4: Panetta was flying Wednesday to Brussels to attend a NATO defense ministers meeting.

column3: Pentagon notifies Congress of likely civilian furloughs over budget cuts
column4: Spokesman George Little told reporters en route that Panetta would tell his counterparts that across-the-board budget cuts will hurt not only the U.S. military but also the ability of NATO to respond to crises.

column3: Pentagon notifies Congress of likely civilian furloughs over budget cuts
column4: Little said the Pentagon is also discussing the possibility of not being able to send military units on planned rotations to various places around the world.

column3: Pentagon notifies Congress of likely civilian furloughs over budget cuts
column4: In anticipation of cuts, the Pentagon has already decided not to send one aircraft carrier back to the Persian Gulf, reducing the U.S. presence there to one carrier.

column3: Pentagon notifies Congress of likely civilian furloughs over budget cuts
column4: The Pentagon has begun discussing details of the furloughs with defense worker union officials.

column3: Pentagon notifies Congress of likely civilian furloughs over budget cuts
column4: President Barack Obama has exempted military personnel from furloughs.

column3: Pentagon notifies Congress of likely civilian furloughs over budget cuts
column4: Obama was continuing to pressure Republican lawmakers to avert the automatic cuts by supporting a Senate Democratic plan that would replace the immediate cuts with a mix of spending reductions and tax increases.

column3: Pentagon notifies Congress of likely civilian furloughs over budget cuts
column4: He was conducting interviews with local television in eight markets: Boston, Charleston, S.C., Baltimore, Oklahoma City, Okla., Wichita, Kan., San Antonio, Texas, San Francisco, and Honolulu.

column3: Pentagon notifies Congress of likely civilian furloughs over budget cuts
column4: "I don't know why it is in this town folks leave stuff to the last minute.

column3: Pentagon notifies Congress of likely civilian furloughs over budget cuts
column4: You know, there's no other profession, no other industry, where people wait until the 11th hour to solve these big problems," Obama told WJZ, the CBS affiliate in Baltimore.

column3: Pentagon notifies Congress of likely civilian furloughs over budget cuts
column4: The only civilian Pentagon workers who would be exempt from furloughs would be Senate-confirmed political appointees such as the defense secretary and deputy defense secretary, as well as a relatively small number of workers deemed essential to protect the safety of defense property and personnel.

column3: Pentagon notifies Congress of likely civilian furloughs over budget cuts
column4: Panetta said the administration is still working with Congress to avoid automatic budget cuts by reaching agreement on a deficit reduction plan.

column3: Cash-Strapped U.S. Postal Service Hopes You Will Buy Some Of Their Dope All-Weather Gear
column4: As you've no doubt heard, there are big changes afoot for your U.S.

column3: Cash-Strapped U.S. Postal Service Hopes You Will Buy Some Of Their Dope All-Weather Gear
column4: Postal Service.

column3: Cash-Strapped U.S. Postal Service Hopes You Will Buy Some Of Their Dope All-Weather Gear
column4: The perennially cash-strapped movers of mail recently announced that they will soon discontinue most Saturday delivery in order to save $2 billion, against a $15.9 billion shortfall last year.

column3: Cash-Strapped U.S. Postal Service Hopes You Will Buy Some Of Their Dope All-Weather Gear
column4: As Postmaster General Patrick R. Donahoe put it, "Our financial situation is urgent."

column3: Cash-Strapped U.S. Postal Service Hopes You Will Buy Some Of Their Dope All-Weather Gear
column4: And so they are acting, because Congress won't -- as the Associated Press reported, most of the Postal Service's "red ink comes from a 2006 law forcing it to pay about $5.5 billion a year into future retiree health benefits, something no other agency does."

column3: Cash-Strapped U.S. Postal Service Hopes You Will Buy Some Of Their Dope All-Weather Gear
column4: Congress has also "stymied the service's efforts to close some post offices in small towns," another move the Postal Service could have made to save on costs.

column3: Cash-Strapped U.S. Postal Service Hopes You Will Buy Some Of Their Dope All-Weather Gear
column4: But the agency is bent on raising as many ducats as it can in as many ways as possible, it seems, because it has also announced that it will sally forth on a plan to create and sell a clothing line.

column3: Cash-Strapped U.S. Postal Service Hopes You Will Buy Some Of Their Dope All-Weather Gear
column4: Just let me make sure I am reading this report from the Washington Post's Josh Hicks correctly...okay, yes, that's the deal: a Postal Service clothing line.

column3: Cash-Strapped U.S. Postal Service Hopes You Will Buy Some Of Their Dope All-Weather Gear
column4: I've double-checked that now.

column3: Cash-Strapped U.S. Postal Service Hopes You Will Buy Some Of Their Dope All-Weather Gear
column4: The basic idea is that the Postal Service wants to leverage its famous "neither snow nor rain nor heat nor gloom of night et cetera" brand identity in the service of making "a new line of all-weather apparel and accessories," and so it is partnering with an apparel manufacturer, The Waconah Group, to "produce Rain Heat & Snow apparel and accessories using technology to create ‘smart apparel’ — also known as wearable electronics."

column3: Cash-Strapped U.S. Postal Service Hopes You Will Buy Some Of Their Dope All-Weather Gear
column4: A men's line will be launched initially, followed by a women's line, and it's all to be sold "in premium department stores and specialty stores, but not at post offices" -- presumably to avoid having to scale up existing post offices to include fitting rooms or Gap-style greeters.

column3: Cash-Strapped U.S. Postal Service Hopes You Will Buy Some Of Their Dope All-Weather Gear
column4: If you are wondering if this has been tried before, well, Hicks has the answer to your question: The Postal Service introduced a limited retail line in the 1980s that included items such as T-shirts, mugs and neckties, all sold exclusively in post offices.

column3: Cash-Strapped U.S. Postal Service Hopes You Will Buy Some Of Their Dope All-Weather Gear
column4: Betts said the agency discontinued those products after lobbyists complained to Congress that the organization was directly competing with private businesses and that it was not established to sell merchandise.

column3: Cash-Strapped U.S. Postal Service Hopes You Will Buy Some Of Their Dope All-Weather Gear
column4: It's always the lobbyists.

column3: Cash-Strapped U.S. Postal Service Hopes You Will Buy Some Of Their Dope All-Weather Gear
column4: At any rate, I suppose you should look for The Postal Service's gear in stores near you, starting in 2014.

column3: Cash-Strapped U.S. Postal Service Hopes You Will Buy Some Of Their Dope All-Weather Gear
column4: One potential conflict that I can see with this is that the other The Postal Service has reformed and embark on a world tour in support of a deluxe, 10th anniversary edition of their 2003 record, "Give Up," and will obviously be selling "The Postal Service" branded merchandise of their own.

column3: Cash-Strapped U.S. Postal Service Hopes You Will Buy Some Of Their Dope All-Weather Gear
column4: The band and the mail carriers have famously reached peaceable accords over their identical names before, but one has to imagine that those bonds were a bit frayed when the band licensed their song "Such Great Heights" to the United Parcel Service to use in their famous "Whiteboard" commercials: We'll see if tensions reignite after every indie-rock nostalgist is wearing a newly topically ironic t-shirt that reads "The Postal Service: Give Up" at the same time the agency is trying to sell anoraks.

column3: Cash-Strapped U.S. Postal Service Hopes You Will Buy Some Of Their Dope All-Weather Gear
column4: [Would you like to follow me on Twitter?

column3: Cash-Strapped U.S. Postal Service Hopes You Will Buy Some Of Their Dope All-Weather Gear
column4: Because why not?]

column3: Cash-strapped Postal Service to launch new clothing line
column4: On the heels of announcing the end of Saturday mail delivery, the U.S.

column3: Cash-strapped Postal Service to launch new clothing line
column4: Postal Service said Tuesday it plans to launch a new line of clothing and accessories next year.

column3: Cash-strapped Postal Service to launch new clothing line
column4: The cash-strapped agency has signed a license agreement with Wahconah Group, a Cleveland-based fashion apparel company, to support its new "Rain Heat & Snow" brand, Postal Service corporate licensing manager Steven Mills said in a news release.

column3: Cash-strapped Postal Service to launch new clothing line
column4: “This agreement will put the Postal Service on the cutting edge of functional fashion,” Mills said.

column3: Cash-strapped Postal Service to launch new clothing line
column4: “The main focus will be to produce Rain Heat & Snow apparel and accessories using technology to create ‘smart apparel’ — also known as wearable electronics.” The Postal Service plans to establish a showroom in New York City's garment district to showcase its new products, which will be available initially only for men, the news release states.

column3: Cash-strapped Postal Service to launch new clothing line
column4: The goal of the new product line, according to Mills, is to eventually sell Rain Heat & Snow products "in premier department and specialty stores."

column3: Cash-strapped Postal Service to launch new clothing line
column4: The Postal Service is in the midst of a major restructuring throughout its retail, delivery and mail processing operations.

column3: Cash-strapped Postal Service to launch new clothing line
column4: Since 2006, it has cut annual costs by about $15 billion, reduced the size of its career workforce by 193,000 or by 28 percent, and has consolidated more than 200 mail processing locations, officials say.

column3: Cash-strapped Postal Service to launch new clothing line
column4: The agency in November reported an annual loss of a record $15.9 billion for the last budget year and forecast more red ink in 2013, capping a tumultuous year in which it was forced to default on billions in retiree health benefit prepayments to avert bankruptcy.

column3: Cash-strapped Postal Service to launch new clothing line
column4: The financial losses for the fiscal year ending Sept. 30 were more than triple the $5.1 billion loss in the previous year.

column3: Cash-strapped Postal Service to launch new clothing line
column4: Having reached its borrowing limit, the mail agency is operating with little cash on hand.

column3: Cash-strapped Postal Service to launch new clothing line
column4: The Associated Press contributed to this report.

column3: Obama administration reportedly considering fines, trade penalties for cybertheft
column4: WASHINGTON –  The White House is reportedly considering fines and other trade penalties against China or any other country guilty of cyberattacks amid evidence of an unrelenting cyber espionage campaign linked to the Chinese government.

column4: The Associated Press reported Wednesday that the actions are being considered as part of the Obama administration's response to a report that claimed the Chinese Army is behind a series of cyberattacks on U.S. companies.

column3: Obama administration reportedly considering fines, trade penalties for cybertheft
column4: Officials familiar with the administration's plans spoke on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to speak publicly about the threatened action.

column3: Obama administration reportedly considering fines, trade penalties for cybertheft

column3: Obama administration reportedly considering fines, trade penalties for cybertheft

column3: Obama administration reportedly considering fines, trade penalties for cybertheft

column3: Obama administration reportedly considering fines, trade penalties for cybertheft

column3: Obama administration reportedly considering fines, trade penalties for cybertheft

column3: Obama administration reportedly considering fines, trade penalties for cybertheft

column3: Obama administration reportedly considering fines, trade penalties for cybertheft
column4: But they said the U.S. is bulking up its cyber-defenses while stressing a new -- albeit controversial -- White House executive order aimed at improving the nation's ability to defend against cyberattacks.

column3: Obama administration reportedly considering fines, trade penalties for cybertheft
column4: "It is a major challenge for us in the national security arena," Carney said Monday, adding that it is known that foreign countries and companies "swipe" sensitive U.S. information.

column3: Obama administration reportedly considering fines, trade penalties for cybertheft
column4: The release of the Mandiant report, complete with details on three of the alleged hackers and photographs of one of the military unit's buildings in Shanghai, makes public what U.S. authorities have said less publicly for years.

column3: Obama administration reportedly considering fines, trade penalties for cybertheft
column4: But it also increases the pressure on the U.S. to take more forceful action against the Chinese for what experts say has been years of systematic espionage.

column3: Obama administration reportedly considering fines, trade penalties for cybertheft
column4: "If the Chinese government flew planes into our airspace, our planes would escort them away.

column3: Obama administration reportedly considering fines, trade penalties for cybertheft
column4: If it happened two, three or four times, the president would be on the phone and there would be threats of retaliation," said Shawn Henry, former FBI executive assistant director.

column3: Obama administration reportedly considering fines, trade penalties for cybertheft
column4: "This is happening thousands of times a day.

column3: Obama administration reportedly considering fines, trade penalties for cybertheft
column4: There needs to be some definition of where the red line is and what the repercussions would be."

column3: Obama administration reportedly considering fines, trade penalties for cybertheft
column4: Henry, the president of the security firm CrowdStrike, said that rather than tell companies to increase their cybersecurity, the government needs to focus more on how to deter the hackers and the nations that are backing them.

column3: Obama administration reportedly considering fines, trade penalties for cybertheft
column4: James Lewis, a cybersecurity expert at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, said that in the past year the White House has been taking a serious look at responding to China.

column3: Obama administration reportedly considering fines, trade penalties for cybertheft
column4: "This will be the year they will put more pressure on, even while realizing it will be hard for the Chinese to change.

column3: Obama administration reportedly considering fines, trade penalties for cybertheft
column4: There's not an on-off switch," Lewis said.

column3: Obama administration reportedly considering fines, trade penalties for cybertheft
column4: In denying involvement in the cyberattacks tracked by Mandiant, China's Foreign Ministry said China, too, has been a victim of hacking, some of it traced to the United States.

column3: Obama administration reportedly considering fines, trade penalties for cybertheft
column4: Foreign Ministry spokesman Hong Lei cited a report by an agency under the Ministry of Information Technology and Industry that said in 2012 alone foreign hackers used viruses and other malicious software to seize control of 1,400 computers in China and 38,000 websites.

column3: Obama administration reportedly considering fines, trade penalties for cybertheft
column4: "Among the above attacks, those from the U.S. numbered the most," Hong said at a daily media briefing, lodging the most specific allegations the Chinese government has made about foreign hacking.

column3: Obama administration reportedly considering fines, trade penalties for cybertheft
column4: Cybersecurity experts say U.S. authorities do not conduct similar attacks or steal data from Chinese companies, but acknowledge that intelligence agencies routinely spy on other countries.

column3: Obama administration reportedly considering fines, trade penalties for cybertheft
column4: China is clearly a target of interest, said Lewis, noting that the U.S. would be interested in Beijing's military policies, such as any plans for action against Taiwan or Japan.

column3: Obama administration reportedly considering fines, trade penalties for cybertheft
column4: In its report, Mandiant said it traced the hacking back to a neighborhood in the outskirts of Shanghai that includes a white 12-story office building run by the army's Unit 61398.

column3: Obama administration reportedly considering fines, trade penalties for cybertheft
column4: Mandiant said there are only two viable conclusions about the involvement of the Chinese military in the cyberattacks: Either Unit 61398 is responsible for the persistent attacks, or they are being done by a secret organization of Chinese speakers, with direct access to the Shanghai telecommunications infrastructure, who are engaged in a multi-year espionage campaign being run right outside the military unit's gates.

column3: Obama administration reportedly considering fines, trade penalties for cybertheft
column4: "In a state that rigorously monitors Internet use, it is highly unlikely that the Chinese government is unaware of an attack group that operates from the Pudong New Area of Shanghai," the Mandiant report said, concluding that the only way the group could function is with the "full knowledge and cooperation" of the Beijing government.

column3: Obama administration reportedly considering fines, trade penalties for cybertheft
column4: The unit "has systematically stolen hundreds of terabytes of data from at least 141 organizations," Mandiant wrote.

column3: Obama administration reportedly considering fines, trade penalties for cybertheft
column4: A terabyte is 1,000 gigabytes.

column3: Obama administration reportedly considering fines, trade penalties for cybertheft
column4: The most popular version of the new iPhone 5, for example, has 16 gigabytes of space, while the more expensive iPads have as much as 64 gigabytes of space.

column3: Obama administration reportedly considering fines, trade penalties for cybertheft
column4: The U.S. Library of Congress' 2006-10 Twitter archive of about 170 billion tweets totals 133.2 terabytes.

column3: Obama administration reportedly considering fines, trade penalties for cybertheft
column4: The Associated Press and Fox News' Barnini Chakraborty contributed to this report.

column3: Obama decries 'meat cleaver' sequestration
column4: Updated 02/19/2013 07:03 PM EST President Barack Obama on Tuesday used the threat of cuts to emergency services as his latest attempt to increase pressure on Congress to avert the automatic spending cuts looming to take effect in just 10 days.

column3: Obama decries 'meat cleaver' sequestration
column4: The “meat cleaver approach” of the sequester, Obama said, would “jeopardize our military readiness, it will eviscerate job creating investments in education and energy and medical research.” Story Continued Below Back in Washington from a long weekend of golfing in Florida, Obama accused Republicans of favoring deficit reduction measures that he argued benefit the rich and hurt most Americans.

column3: Obama decries 'meat cleaver' sequestration
column4: He pushed again for an agreement that would replace $85 billion in cuts by the end of the current fiscal year with a $110 billion package that would cut spending and end some tax loopholes.

column3: Obama decries 'meat cleaver' sequestration
column4: An agreement on a larger deal has remained elusive with less than two weeks to go until the deadline, and Obama is looking to push Republicans to a deal.

column3: Obama decries 'meat cleaver' sequestration
column4: “Are you willing to see a bunch of first responders lose their jobs because you want to protect a special interest tax loophole?

column3: Obama decries 'meat cleaver' sequestration
column4: Are you willing to have teachers laid off or kids not have access to Head Start?

column3: Obama decries 'meat cleaver' sequestration
column4: Or deeper cuts in student loan programs?” he asked, appearing in the Eisenhower Executive Office Building with a group of first responders lined up behind him.

column3: Obama decries 'meat cleaver' sequestration
column4: He plans to ratchet up the pressure on Republicans with more events at the White House and travel ahead of the March 1 deadline.

column3: Obama decries 'meat cleaver' sequestration
column4: ( PHOTOS: 13 people to watch in 2013) It’s “troubling that just 10 days from now, Congress just might allow a series of automatic, severe budget cuts to take place,” Obama said.

column3: Obama decries 'meat cleaver' sequestration
column4: “This is not an abstraction: people will lose their jobs.” The sequester cuts, totaling $1.2 trillion over the course of a decade, were agreed to in the summer of 2011 in a deal to raise the debt ceiling and were intended to be so unpalatable that the White House and Congress would find a way to avert them by developing an alternate long-term deficit reduction plan.

column3: Obama decries 'meat cleaver' sequestration
column4: Half the cuts would be to non-combat military spending while the other half would be to domestic discretionary spending.

column3: Obama decries 'meat cleaver' sequestration
column4: The cuts were originally set to begin on Jan. 1, but the White House and congressional Republicans agreed then to a deal that postponed the cuts for two months in hopes that a longer-term agreement could be reached by the end of February.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: President Obama pinned the blame on Republicans Tuesday for looming spending cuts that may be triggered by what was originally a White House proposal -- while a former leader of the president's deficit commission said it's Obama who's on the path to a "failed presidency" if he can't tackle the debt.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: The president spoke Tuesday at the White House, urging Congress to come up with a short-term fix to cancel sweeping cuts to defense and other programs set to hit March 1.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: "These cuts are not smart.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: They are not fair.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: They will hurt our economy.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: They will add hundreds of thousands of Americans to the unemployment rolls," Obama said.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: "This is not an abstraction -- people will lose their jobs."

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: The president ticked off a host of expected repercussions should the $85 billion in cuts for this year take effect.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: He said Border Patrol, emergency responders, FBI agents, airport controllers and others would all face cutbacks.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: He said teachers would be laid off by the thousands and America's military would be degraded.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: As he has before, Obama urged Congress to pass a stopgap to allow for more time to pass a bigger package.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: But, with Congress out this week and many lawmakers resisting another attempt to kick the can on the cuts, Obama tried to cast Republicans as the ones responsible.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: Obama suggested their resistance to his calls to pass a "balanced" package -- by closing tax loopholes for top earners and big corporations -- is the hold-up.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: He asked whether Republicans are willing to let hundreds of thousands of people lose their jobs "just to protect a few special-interest tax loopholes."

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: He blamed the current stalemate on "partisan recklessness and ideological rigidity."

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: House Speaker John Boehner, after Obama talked, claimed Obama was merely reinforcing what Republicans have been saying -- "his sequester is the wrong way to cut spending."

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: Boehner and others note the so-called sequester -- which set up more than $1 trillion in sweeping spending cuts if Congress failed, as it did, to reach a compromise on deficit reduction -- originated in the White House.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: "But once again, the president offered no credible plan that can pass Congress -- only more calls for higher taxes," Boehner said.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: White House Press Secretary Jay Carney acknowledged that the idea was originally "put forward" by the White House.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: But he said the White House only pitched it as an "absolute necessity" in 2011 to avoid default over the debt ceiling, and noted Republicans "embraced" it at the time.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: Shortly before he spoke, Obama was also dealt a blunt warning by former Republican Sen. Alan Simpson, who co-chaired the president's deficit-reduction commission.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: Simpson warned that Obama "will have a failed presidency" unless he deals "honestly" with entitlements, saying programs like Medicare and Social Security must be dealt with in order to get the country on a sustainable path.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: "If he wants to leave it alone and not deal with those two biggies, forget the rest of the stuff -- he'll have a failed presidency," Simpson told Fox News.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: While Obama says opposition to tax hikes is holding up a deal, Republicans say Democrats' resistance to major changes to entitlements are a big part of the problem.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: Simpson and Erskine Bowles, the former co-chairmen of the president's deficit-reduction commission who for years have been urging Washington to stop kicking the can, got in front of the president early Tuesday morning to push a plan of their own.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: "Over the medium and long-term, our debt is projected to continue growing faster than the economy.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: It is simply on an unsustainable path," they said in a statement.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: The two fiscal hawks pitched a plan to avert the looming spending cuts -- heavy cuts to defense and other programs that they describe as "abrupt" and "mindless" -- and instead enact a $2.4 trillion deficit reduction plan over 10 years.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: A quarter would come from changes to health care spending, a quarter would come from closing tax loopholes and the rest would come from spending reductions including a stingier adjustment of Social Security's cost of living increases.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: On tax reform, the plan presents a middle ground -- by using the savings from closing loopholes to both lower rates and bring down the deficit.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: By contrast, Obama has pushed to use that savings mostly to reduce the deficit, while Republicans have pushed to use it to bring down rates.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: Simpson and Bowles cast their plan as building on the proposal from the president's deficit commission -- a plan that Congress never adopted and Obama never fully endorsed.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: Obama, fresh off a three-day Florida golfing trip, pressed his own case during the event at the White House Tuesday morning.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: Emergency responders, a group of workers the White House says could be affected if state and local governments lose federal money as a result of the cuts, joined him.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: The $85 billion in cuts, known as the sequester, will start taking effect on March 1 unless Congress acts.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: The White House says the sequester could derail an economy still suffering from high unemployment and sluggish growth.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: Obama wants to offset the sequester through a combination of targeted spending cuts and increased tax revenue.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: The White House is backing a proposal unveiled last week by Senate Democrats that is in line with the president's principles.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: But that plan was met with an icy reception by Republicans, who oppose raising more tax revenue in order to offset the cuts.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: GOP leaders say the president got the tax increases he wanted at the beginning of the year when Congress agreed to raise taxes on family income exceeding $450,000 a year.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: A senior administration official later insisted the White House is not looking to raise tax rates for top earners, but does want to close deductions.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: The official indicated the White House expects Republicans to eventually allow this despite statements to the contrary.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: Still, the White House sees the March 1 cuts as a real possibility, warning that the economic impact will be ugly.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: The Democrats propose to generate revenue by plugging some tax loopholes.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: Those include tax breaks for the oil and natural gas industry and businesses that have sent jobs overseas, and by taxing millionaires at a rate of at least 30 percent.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: Some Republicans, including House Budget Committee Chairman Paul Ryan, R-Wis., have advocated plugging loopholes, but as part of a discussion on a tax overhaul, not sequestration.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: "Loopholes are necessary for tax reform," Ryan said Sunday on ABC's "This Week."

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: `'If you take them for spending, you're blocking tax reform and you're really not getting the deficit under control."

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: The sequester was first set to begin taking effect on Jan. 1.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: But as part of the "fiscal cliff" negotiations, the White House and lawmakers agreed to push it off for two months in order to create space to work on a larger budget deal.

column3: Obama pins blame on Republicans for looming cuts...
column4: The Associated Press contributed to this report.

column3: White House seeks 'balanced way' to budget fix
column4: WASHINGTON (AP) — President Barack Obama is concerned about the effect that looming, drastic across-the-board budget cuts will have on the middle class, his new chief of staff said Sunday.

column3: White House seeks 'balanced way' to budget fix
column4: Congressional Republicans predicted the cuts would start as scheduled next month and blamed Obama not only for doing little to stop them but for the idea itself.

column3: White House seeks 'balanced way' to budget fix
column4: The cuts, called the sequester, would drain $85 billion from the government's budget over the coming seven months.

column3: White House seeks 'balanced way' to budget fix
column4: Actual cuts may be around 13 percent for defense and 9 percent for other programs because lawmakers delayed their impact, requiring savings over a shorter period of time.

column3: White House seeks 'balanced way' to budget fix
column4: The White House last week let loose a list of ways Americans would feel the trims, from longer waits at airport security to as many as 13,000 teachers being laid off.

column3: White House seeks 'balanced way' to budget fix
column4: Outgoing Secretary of Defense Leon Panetta told a congressional panel the sequester would hollow the U.S. military because it would give the Pentagon little leeway in deciding how best to spend the money.

column3: White House seeks 'balanced way' to budget fix
column4: Denis McDonough, the president's chief of staff, warned the cuts would come as the stock market is coming back, the housing market has improved and the number of jobs has grown, and urged Congress to consider a balanced approach that would further strengthen the economy and, in turn, the middle class.

column3: White House seeks 'balanced way' to budget fix
column4: "This isn't a spending fight for us," McDonough told NBC's "Meet the Press."

column3: White House seeks 'balanced way' to budget fix
column4: ''This is a fight about whether we're going to make the investments in middle class families in this country, in education, in science and technology, in food inspection, and those kinds of things."

column3: White House seeks 'balanced way' to budget fix
column4: Senate Democrats last week offered a plan they say is a balanced approach of more revenue and budget cuts.

column3: White House seeks 'balanced way' to budget fix
column4: The White House supports the proposal, but it drew an icy reception from Republicans, who say the president got the tax increases he wanted during the agreement to avoid the "fiscal cliff."

column3: White House seeks 'balanced way' to budget fix
column4: "The question isn't whether we're going to insist on some position because that's the ideologically right position," McDonough said.

column3: White House seeks 'balanced way' to budget fix
column4: "This should not be a social science experiment.

column3: White House seeks 'balanced way' to budget fix
column4: This should be a question where we ask ourselves, what is most important to the economy, what is most important to the middle class families of this country, and that's the way the president is going to do this."

column3: White House seeks 'balanced way' to budget fix
column4: South Carolina's Sen. Lindsay Graham was among the Republicans on Sunday who recalled the president's position on the sequester in the fall.

column3: White House seeks 'balanced way' to budget fix
column4: "The president promised in the campaign sequestration would not happen.

column3: White House seeks 'balanced way' to budget fix
column4: Now, he is allowing it to happen," Graham said on "Fox News Sunday."

column3: White House seeks 'balanced way' to budget fix
column4: "He's the commander-in-chief and on his watch, we're going to begin to unravel the finest military in the history of the world, at a time when we need it most," Graham, a member of the Armed Services Committee added.

column3: White House seeks 'balanced way' to budget fix
column4: "If you want to look at ways to find $1.2 trillion in savings over the next decade, let's look at Obamacare.

column3: White House seeks 'balanced way' to budget fix
column4: Let's don't destroy the military and just cut blindly across the board.

column3: White House seeks 'balanced way' to budget fix
column4: There are many ways to do this."

column3: White House seeks 'balanced way' to budget fix
column4: However, Graham offered no specifics.

column3: White House seeks 'balanced way' to budget fix
column4: The Democrats propose generating revenue from plugging some tax loopholes.

column3: White House seeks 'balanced way' to budget fix
column4: Those include tax breaks for the oil and gas industry and businesses that have sent jobs overseas and taxing millionaires at a rate of at least 30 percent.

column3: White House seeks 'balanced way' to budget fix
column4: Rep. Paul Ryan, who chairs the Budget Committee, advocates for plugging loopholes, but as part of a discussion on tax reform, not sequestration.

column3: White House seeks 'balanced way' to budget fix
column4: "Loopholes are necessary for tax reform," Ryan said on ABC's "This Week."

column3: White House seeks 'balanced way' to budget fix
column4: ''If you take them for spending, you're blocking tax reform and you're really not getting the deficit under control."

column3: White House seeks 'balanced way' to budget fix
column4: With the March 1 deadline fast approaching, Sen. Chuck Schumer, a New York Democrat and close ally of the White House, predicted that Republicans will eventually join Democrats to avoid the cuts.

column3: White House seeks 'balanced way' to budget fix
column4: "They have no choice," Schumer said on CNN's "State of the Union."

column3: White House seeks 'balanced way' to budget fix
column4: ''Their arguments are untenable and don't meet the favor of hardly anyone other than themselves and the special interests they're protecting."

column4: White House Chief of Staff Denis McDonough said Sunday that Presiden Obama has not given up on the prospect of averting the looming across-the-board spending cuts known as the sequester.
