column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: WASHINGTON -- House Speaker John Boehner (R-Ohio) only needed a single night's sleep before throwing cold water on one of the most significant proposals put forth by President Barack Obama in his State of the Union address Tuesday night: raising the federal minimum wage to $9 per hour and pegging it to inflation.

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: "When you raise the price of employment, guess what happens?

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: You get less of it," Boehner told reporters Wednesday morning.

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: "At a time when Americans are still asking the question, ‘Where are the jobs?’ why would we want to make it harder for small employers to hire people?"

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: Obama's proposal to raise the minimum wage by $1.75 over the course of three years is hardly radical.

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: The minimum wage, after all, only goes up over time, and even Republican President George W. Bush signed a similarly incremental minimum wage hike into law during his second term.

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: What probably concerns House Republicans, as well as the business lobby, most about Obama's proposal is not the nominal minimum wage hike.

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: It's the inclusion of a cost-of-living adjustment, which would tweak the minimum wage each year to adjust for inflation.

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: This would guarantee that workers on the lowest rung of the economic ladder don't lose purchasing power, but it would also mean fast-food companies and other low-wage employers would have to pay higher wages just about every year, except in rare cases of deflation.

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: On Capitol Hill, it means lawmakers wouldn't have to legislate a new minimum wage every few years.

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: The cost-of-living provision would give members of Congress less to squabble about -- and it would basically wipe out a bargaining chip for those who oppose higher minimum wages.

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: The president's proposal is only a day old, and the battle lines on the issue have barely been drawn.

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: But given the significance of the indexing portion, Republicans may try to give Democrats some kind of nominal increase in the minimum wage while jettisoning the cost-of-living piece of the package.

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: Whether or not Democrats hold strong to the inflation measure may determine if they produce a truly progressive piece of legislation.

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: Without it, the proposal isn't much different from previous minimum wage increases, both Democratic and Republican.

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: HuffPost readers: Are you working for minimum wage?

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: Tell us about it.

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: Email dave.jamieson@huffingtonpost.com.

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: "Indexing the minimum wage to inflation would help working families make ends meet as costs rise," said Allison Preiss, a spokeswoman for Sen. Tom Harkin (D-Iowa), one of the foremost backers of a higher minimum wage.

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: "Sen. Harkin believes that the ability of these families to afford basic necessities shouldn’t be used as a political football by those in Congress."

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: Aaron Albright, a spokesman for Rep. George Miller (D-Calif.), said it was critical that the nominal raise and the cost-of-living adjustment come together in a package.

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: "It is crucial that these two proposals are paired," he said.

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: "It takes the politics out of keeping the minimum wage up with the cost of living, as long as you begin at a fair minimum floor.

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: It gives certainty to working families and businesses."

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: Jen Kern, minimum wage campaign coordinator at the National Employment Law Project, a worker advocacy group, was more blunt.

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: "Any proposal that doesn't include indexing is a proposal that will erode the minimum wage," she said.

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: The federal minimum wage has remained at $7.25 per hour since 2009, when the last of a series of increases signed by Bush went into effect.

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: The $7.25 rate translates into a salary of about $14,500, well below a living wage in most areas.

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: The federal rate prevails in 31 states that do not mandate a higher one.

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: Ten states have already put cost-of-living adjustments on their books, meaning minimum-wage workers in those states see a raise just about every year.

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: A handful of congressional Democrats, led by Harkin and Miller, have pushed for raising the minimum wage in recent sessions.

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: Their bills have gone virtually nowhere, as even many progressives have seemed loath to put much weight behind a minimum wage hike in a down economy.

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: But with the president making just such a proposal on the largest of stages, the legislative environment will now likely change.

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: On Wednesday, Harkin and Miller announced in a statement that they will roll out a joint legislative proposal to hike the minimum wage higher than Obama has suggested -- to $10.10 per hour -- and raise it with the cost of living.

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: (If the minimum wage had kept pace with inflation since its real-value high in the late 1960s, it would be roughly $10 now.)

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: Obama once proposed raising the minimum wage to $9.50, back in 2008.

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: Harkin and Miller said the proposal in the president's State of the Union address was "lower than what is needed," though they added that "there is no question that last night he threw the door open for a robust discussion on the importance of raising the minimum wage."

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: Although indexing is championed mostly by advocates for low-wage workers, the idea has found some conservative adherents as well, given that it provides employers with predictability.

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: Former GOP presidential candidate Mitt Romney, most notably, said on the campaign trail last year that he supported tying the minimum wage to inflation.

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: (He later qualified his remarks, saying the minimum wage shouldn't be raised in a weak economy.)

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: Obama, in his address, jokingly referred to indexing as "an idea that Governor Romney and I actually agreed on last year."

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: The idea is apparently less popular with House Republicans, however.

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: Rep. Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) was asked by CNN's Jake Tapper after the address if he agreed with his former running-mate on the matter of indexing.

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: "I have never been a fan of that idea," Ryan responded.

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: "I think it is inflationary.

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: I think it actually is counterproductive in many ways.

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: You end up costing jobs from people who are at the bottom rung of the economic ladder."

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: "Look," Ryan added, "I wish we could just pass a law saying everybody should make more money without any adverse consequences."

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: But even given the sluggish economic recovery, Republicans who vehemently oppose the proposal run the risk of looking callous at a time when millions of Americans work but remain poor.

column3: Why Obama's Minimum Wage Plan Really Worries The GOP And Business Lobby
column4: After all, minimum wage hikes poll very well with the general public.

column3: Republicans vow to hold out for data before vote on Hagel
column4: Democrats pressed ahead Wednesday with Chuck Hagel’s nomination to be secretary of defense, scheduling a showdown vote for Friday even as top Republicans signaled that they need more information before confirming him for the Pentagon’s top civilian post.

column3: Republicans vow to hold out for data before vote on Hagel
column4: He is one of several top administration nominees facing roadblocks as Republicans demand to know more from President Obama on various topics, such as the Sept. 11 attacks on the U.S. Consulate in Benghazi, Libya, and threaten to hold up his appointments as leverage.

column3: Republicans vow to hold out for data before vote on Hagel
column4: Sen. Rand Paul, Kentucky Republican, said Wednesday that he would hold up Mr. Obama’s pick to head the CIA, John O. Brennan, until the White House releases more information about the secret drone execution program.

column3: Republicans vow to hold out for data before vote on Hagel
column4: Democrats bristled at the delay over Mr. Hagel, accusing the Republicans of unprecedented obstructions.

column3: Republicans vow to hold out for data before vote on Hagel
column4: “This is the first time in the history of our country that a presidential nominee for secretary of defense has been filibustered,” Majority Leader Harry Reid of Nevada said Wednesday on the Senate floor.

column3: Republicans vow to hold out for data before vote on Hagel
column4: “What a shame.

column3: Republicans vow to hold out for data before vote on Hagel
column4: But that’s the way it is.” Republicans said Mr. Reid was rushing Mr. Hagel’s nomination through the chamber and that there is a long history of filibustering nominations as a way to try to pry information loose.

column3: Republicans vow to hold out for data before vote on Hagel
column4: “We haven’t gotten the information that we want,” said Sen. James M. Inhofe of Oklahoma, the ranking Republican on the Armed Services Committee.

column3: Republicans vow to hold out for data before vote on Hagel
column4: Mr. Hagel, a former Republican senator whom Mr. Obama tapped to be his independent voice at the Defense Department, will need to muster 60 votes Friday or else his confirmation will be delayed until later this month.

column3: Republicans vow to hold out for data before vote on Hagel
column4: He suffered through a rocky confirmation hearing two weeks ago, and Republicans said he has not disclosed all of the foreign clients for whom he has worked in the four years since he left the Senate.

column3: Republicans vow to hold out for data before vote on Hagel
column4: Freshman Sen. Ted Cruz, Texas Republican, made a plea for that information, wondering at Tuesday’s committee meeting whether Mr. Hagel might have taken money from governments that aren’t friendly to the U.S. “We do not know, for example if he received compensation for giving paid speeches at extreme or radical groups,” he said Tuesday.

column3: Republicans vow to hold out for data before vote on Hagel
column4: Sen. David Vitter, Louisiana Republican, said he needs more time to pore over Mr. Hagel’s recent speeches.

column3: Republicans vow to hold out for data before vote on Hagel
column4: Sen. John McCain, an influential Republican from Arizona, signaled Wednesday that he is among those seeking more answers from Mr. Obama about the White House’s response to the attack in Benghazi.

column3: Republicans vow to hold out for data before vote on Hagel
column4: “I’m looking for an answer,” Mr. McCain said, specifically on “where the president was that night and what he did.” Mr. McCain would not disclose whether he plans to block a vote on the nomination if Mr. Obama does not supply the information he wants.

column3: Republicans vow to hold out for data before vote on Hagel
column4: “I’ll cross that bridge when I come to it,” he told reporters outside the Senate chamber.

column3: Republicans vow to hold out for data before vote on Hagel
column4: “My position right now is I want answers to the questions.” Chairman Carl Levin, Michigan Democrat, said Mr. Hagel has cooperated with the committee’s rules and is qualified for the job.

column3: Republicans vow to hold out for data before vote on Hagel
column4: “The president needs to have a secretary of defense in whom he has trust, who will give him unvarnished advice, a person of integrity and one who has a personal understanding of the consequences of decisions relative to the use of military force,” Mr. Levin said on the Senate floor.

column3: Republicans vow to hold out for data before vote on Hagel
column4: Mr. Levin said Mr. Hagel has the full support of five previous defense secretaries and that he served courageously in the Vietnam War.

column3: Republicans vow to hold out for data before vote on Hagel
column4: Mr. Hagel would be the first former enlisted man to serve as defense secretary.

column3: Republicans vow to hold out for data before vote on Hagel
column4: Although they may seem arcane, document requests can be powerful weapons against nominees.

column3: Republicans vow to hold out for data before vote on Hagel
column4: Americans for a Strong Defense, a group that opposes Mr. Hagel’s nomination, accused Senate Democrats of hypocrisy Wednesday for insulating the nominee from Republicans’ request for records, noting the party employed a wide range of delay tactics to thwart some of President George W. Bush’s nominees.

column3: Republicans vow to hold out for data before vote on Hagel
column4: They pointed to successful efforts to block John R. Bolton as ambassador of the United Nations, after Mr. Bush submitted his name to keep him on the job in 2006.

column3: Republicans vow to hold out for data before vote on Hagel
column4: Miguel A. Estrada, an accomplished lawyer known to possess conservative views, withdrew his name from consideration for the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia after senators stirred controversy from 2001 to 2003 by calling for legal memos that Mr. Estrada composed during his time at the Department of Justice.

column3: Republicans vow to hold out for data before vote on Hagel
column4: “There’s certainly a history of calling for disclosure for nominees that have gone before the Senate,” said Ryan Williams, the organization’s spokesman.

column3: Republicans vow to hold out for data before vote on Hagel
column4: Despite these precedents, “it’s very unusual to do this with a major nomination,” said Thomas E. Mann, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution.

column3: Republicans vow to hold out for data before vote on Hagel
column4: As of now, Mr. Hagel and Mr. Brennan face roadblocks — and Jacob “Jack” Lew, Mr. Obama’s nominee to be the Treasury Department secretary, could also may have to overcome obstacles if he doesn’t provide more information about his investment history.

column3: Republicans vow to hold out for data before vote on Hagel
column4: Mr. Hagel’s nomination was cleared through the Armed Services Committee on Tuesday on a party-line vote.

column3: Republicans vow to hold out for data before vote on Hagel
column4: Two Republicans have said they would support his nomination, while others have said they would vote against him but wouldn’t take part in a filibuster.

column3: Republicans vow to hold out for data before vote on Hagel
column4: “I wish that President Obama had made a different choice for this critical position, but he is entitled to have this nominee receive a direct vote on the Senate floor,” said Sen. Susan M. Collins, Maine Republican.

column3: Harry Reid sets the stage for Chuck Hagel showdown
column4: Updated 02/14/2013 10:40 AM EST Senate Republicans see the writing on the wall: Chuck Hagel will get his job at the Pentagon, and John Brennan will soon be headed to Langley.

column3: Harry Reid sets the stage for Chuck Hagel showdown
column4: But that doesn’t mean they won’t drag out the proceedings to extract every possible concession they can get and weaken the nominees and the White House in the process.

column3: Harry Reid sets the stage for Chuck Hagel showdown
column4: Story Continued Below Harry Reid knows this and has had enough.

column3: Harry Reid sets the stage for Chuck Hagel showdown
column4: In an attempt to get Hagel installed as secretary of defense before next week’s recess, the majority leader set up a Friday vote to cut off debate, setting up a crucial 60-vote test.

column3: Harry Reid sets the stage for Chuck Hagel showdown
column4: If Reid can find five Republicans to join the 55 members of the Democratic Caucus, the Senate could approve Hagel quickly — possibly Saturday or earlier.

column3: Harry Reid sets the stage for Chuck Hagel showdown
column4: ( Also on POLITICO: Senate to vote Friday on Hagel) But if he can’t, the White House could be forced to recalibrate its strategy as the nomination drags out into late February.

column3: Harry Reid sets the stage for Chuck Hagel showdown
column4: And that could give the GOP more time to mount opposition to Hagel’s nomination, which has been targeted because of the former Nebraska senator’s past comments on Iran, Iraq and Israel and his shaky performance at his confirmation hearings.

column3: Harry Reid sets the stage for Chuck Hagel showdown
column4: Sen. John McCain (R-Ariz.), who previously opposed a filibuster on a defense secretary nominee, is now among those Republicans warning they may block Hagel until the White House coughs up more information over last September’s Benghazi attacks.

column3: Harry Reid sets the stage for Chuck Hagel showdown
column4: ( PHOTOS: Chuck Hagel's confirmation hearing) Sen. John Thune, No.

column3: Harry Reid sets the stage for Chuck Hagel showdown
column4: 3 in Senate GOP leadership, said his colleagues are prepared to unite to block the nomination if the White House doesn’t adequately respond to their demands for information.

column3: Harry Reid sets the stage for Chuck Hagel showdown
column4: “I think we will hold the line if there’s a vote this week,” Thune said before a caucus lunch.

column3: Harry Reid sets the stage for Chuck Hagel showdown
column4: “Because there are enough of our members on the committee and some who aren’t that they aren’t being responsive and are not getting the information they had asked for.” Asked about the precedent his party is setting, Thune demurred: “I don’t think it influences the ultimate outcome.

column3: Harry Reid sets the stage for Chuck Hagel showdown
column4: I think in the end, ultimately he’ll get his vote.” Democrats are warning Republicans that the precedent they set by forcing a cloture vote on the national security nominees — particularly on Hagel — would come back to haunt them when a GOP president eventually returns to the White House.

column3: Harry Reid sets the stage for Chuck Hagel showdown
column4: “This is the first time in the history of our country that a presidential nominee for secretary of defense has been filibustered,” Reid said on the floor.

column3: Harry Reid sets the stage for Chuck Hagel showdown
column4: “What a shame, but that’s the way it is.” Republicans are trying to make the case that their decision to force a cloture vote is really not all that unusual.

column3: Harry Reid sets the stage for Chuck Hagel showdown
column4: They say they are simply delaying a final vote, which they promise will eventually come, just as minority parties typically do to exert their leverage over the White House.

column3: Harry Reid sets the stage for Chuck Hagel showdown
column4: And they say it’s not uncommon for the two parties to agree that 60 votes are needed to confirm presidential nominations, even if it’s not technically called a filibuster.

column3: Harry Reid sets the stage for Chuck Hagel showdown
column4: CORRECTION: Corrected by: Nick Gass @ 02/13/2013 10:53 PM CORRECTION: An earlier version of this story omitted words from a Harry Reid quote.

column3: What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
column4: President Obama set the tone for his second term Tuesday, going through a litany of policy proposals that he will pursue in the months and years ahead.

column3: What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
column4: And polls suggest most of his big proposals have broad public support.

column3: What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
column4: That doesn't mean, of course, that Congress will pass the bills, but it does suggest that the president is pushing ideas that the American public is broadly receptive to.

column3: What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
column4: Below, we detail some of the major items Obama talked about Tuesday, alongside what the polls say about them and how that bodes for congressional action.

column3: What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
column4: Increasing the minimum wage Obama is pushing for a gradual increase to $9 an hour, from the current $7.25.

column3: What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
column4: This is not new for Obama, who previously said he wanted to up the minimum wage to $9.50 by 2011.

column3: What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
column4: Polling routinely shows Americans are overwhelmingly in favor of increasing the minimum wage.

column3: What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
column4: In fact, a Public Religion Research Institute poll in 2010 showed that two-thirds of Americans would like to see the minimum wage at $10 an hour — including 51 percent of Republicans.

column3: What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
column4: What's more, about two-fifths of states have increased their minimum wages beyond the federal level.

column3: What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
column4: Of course, that doesn't mean raising the minimum wage will be easy.

column3: What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
column4: Businesses say that forcing them to pay a higher minimum wage will make them to scale back hiring, and Republicans in particular will be sensitive to that complaint.

column3: What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
column4: A path to citizenship and tougher border security Obama called for a path to citizenship for illegal immigrants that includes a penalty and for going to the end of the line, behind immigrants that have begun the process legally.

column3: What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
column4: He also called for increasingly tough border security.

column3: What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
column4: Both are popular, but stricter border security is basically a no-brainer, with 83 percent in a recent Washington Post-ABC News poll in favor.

column3: What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
column4: The path to citizenship also has clear majority support, with 55 percent of people supporting it in the same poll.

column3: What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
column4: A recent CBS News poll that gave a third option — allowing immigrant to stay as guest workers — showed 51 percent supported a path to citizenship and 20 percent favored a guest worker program, while just 24 percent favored deportation.

column3: What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
column4: Only "modest" Medicare and Social Security reforms The president said the cost of the looming sequester should not be shifted to the nation's entitlement programs, and Americans tend to agree.

column3: What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
column4: As we noted in Morning Fix today, poll after poll shows Americans don't like basically any changes that could scale back their Medicare and Social Security benefits, with more than 80 percent opposing such changes to both programs.

column3: What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
column4: In addition, Obama suggested that the poor and middle class shouldn't shoulder the burden of such changes.

column3: What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
column4: That's another message that resonates.

column3: What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
column4: In fact, a significant majority of people say they are just fine with cutting Social Security and Medicare benefits — as long as they are being cut only for the wealthiest Americans.

column3: What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
column4: Increased gun control Obama name-checked increased background checks — which are hugely popular, even among gun rights supporters — but didn't push specifically for the assault weapons ban, which is also a part of the White House's gun proposals in the aftermath of the tragedy in Newtown, Conn. (Obama instead mentioned "weapons of war" and the more broad desire to get them off the streets.)

column3: What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
column4: Polling has repeatedly shown that the assault weapons ban has around 50 percent support (45 percent in a Post-ABC poll, higher in others), but it appears very unlikely to pass in Congress, and thus the administration has been emphasizing that background checks are the key piece here.

column3: What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
column4: But despite what happened in Newtown, guns are not a huge priority for Americans right now, ranking behind economic issues and on par with reining in spending on Social Security and Medicare.

column3: What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
column4: Ending the war in Afghanistan Before Obama's speech came news that the United States would draw down 34,000 troops from Afghanistan this year and that the war will be over by the end of 2014.

column3: What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
column4: Americans love this; polls show more than 70 percent of Americans favor ending the war.

column3: What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
column4: Increased infrastructure spending This is an old standard for Obama, and the American people support it.

column3: What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
column4: A Post-Kaiser Family Foundation poll last year showed 63 percent thought increased spending on roads, bridges and other public works projects would help create jobs.

column3: What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
column4: That's not quite the same as asking whether it would be good for the economy overall, of course.

column3: What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
column4: And in fact, infrastructure ranks relatively low on the list of priorities.

column3: What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
column4: A CBS News/New York Times poll in 2011 showed people would choose to cut infrastructure spending over cutting science and research, aid to the unemployed and education.

column3: What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
column4: Addressing climate change This also has majority support, with 51 percent in a recent WaPo-ABC poll saying they favor "new federal policies to address climate change."

column3: What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
column4: Of course, the devil is in the details, and Democrats failed to pass a so-called "cap and trade" energy bill even when they had total control of Washington, as Democrats from coal country and conservative districts balked.

column3: What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
column4: It's not clear exactly what Obama will press for here, but the fact that only a bare majority of Americans support broadly defined "federal policies to address climate change" suggests it will be tough to do.

column3: What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
column4: Increasing sharing of information to prevent cyber attacks Obama wants Congress to pass legislation that would increase the flow of information between U.S. companies and the government in the name of preventing increasing cyber-attacks.

column3: What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
column4: But some are worried that such an arrangement would violate Americans' privacy by sharing their personal information and e-mails with the government.

column3: What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
column4: A June 2012 Washington Post poll showed Americans are very much divided: 46 percent of people said such an information exchange was "justified," while 43 percent said it "goes too far."

column3: What the polls say about ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s proposals
column4: Scott Clement contributed to this report.

column3: OPINION: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s agenda is simple Ã¢â‚¬â€ take more of your money

column3: OPINION: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s agenda is simple Ã¢â‚¬â€ take more of your money
column4: And this president could not imagine an agenda that didn’t cost a fortune of your money.

column3: OPINION: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s agenda is simple Ã¢â‚¬â€ take more of your money
column4: So he ticked off his list of projects to tackle in his second term from gun control to global warming to immigration to raising the minimum wage.

column3: OPINION: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s agenda is simple Ã¢â‚¬â€ take more of your money
column4: In case you are one of those mathy types out there wondering how much further into debt Mr. Obama will fling us to accomplish all this — well, don’t you worry your silly little heads.

column3: OPINION: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s agenda is simple Ã¢â‚¬â€ take more of your money
column4: “Nothing I’m proposing tonight should increase our deficit by a single dime,” Mr. Obama explained.

column3: OPINION: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s agenda is simple Ã¢â‚¬â€ take more of your money
column4: “It’s not a bigger government we need, but a smarter government that sets priorities and invests in broad-based growth.” So, there you have it.

column3: OPINION: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s agenda is simple Ã¢â‚¬â€ take more of your money
column4: Of course, when it comes to math, you got to watch what Mr. Obama says.

column3: OPINION: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s agenda is simple Ã¢â‚¬â€ take more of your money
column4: Especially when it is your money he is playing with.

column3: OPINION: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s agenda is simple Ã¢â‚¬â€ take more of your money
column4: Remember four years ago when he promised that his plans would cut the deficit in half during his first term?

column3: OPINION: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s agenda is simple Ã¢â‚¬â€ take more of your money
column4: “This will not be easy,” he warned at the time.

column3: OPINION: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s agenda is simple Ã¢â‚¬â€ take more of your money
column4: “It will require us to make difficult decisions and face challenges we’ve long neglected.

column3: OPINION: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s agenda is simple Ã¢â‚¬â€ take more of your money
column4: But I refuse to leave our children with a debt that they cannot repay – and that means taking responsibility right now, in this administration, for getting our spending under control.” So, instead of cutting the deficit in half, he grew the debt by more than half.

column3: OPINION: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s agenda is simple Ã¢â‚¬â€ take more of your money
column4: Which is why it now stands at about $16 trillion as opposed to the roughly $10 trillion when he took office.

column4: Like I said, your money.

column3: OPINION: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s agenda is simple Ã¢â‚¬â€ take more of your money
column4: Not his concern.

column3: OPINION: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s agenda is simple Ã¢â‚¬â€ take more of your money
column4: Now he’s got yet another big new plan for the government to create jobs.

column3: OPINION: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s agenda is simple Ã¢â‚¬â€ take more of your money
column4: It must, he told Congress during his State of the Union address, “be the North Star that guides our efforts.” This guy is so delusion, he still thinks the North Star is following him around.

column4: It got so thick in the chamber that even Mr. Obama’s vice president had a hard time keeping it together.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: WASHINGTON –  President Barack Obama did some cherry-picking Tuesday night in defense of his record on jobs and laid out a conditional path to citizenship for illegal immigrants that may be less onerous than he made it sound.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: A look at some of the claims in his State of the Union speech, a glance at the Republican counterargument and how they fit with the facts: OBAMA: "After years of grueling recession, our businesses have created over 6 million new jobs."

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: THE FACTS: That's in the ballpark, as far as it goes.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: But Obama starts his count not when he took office, but from the point in his first term when job losses were the highest.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: In doing so, he ignores the 5 million or so jobs that were lost on his watch, up to that point.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: Private sector jobs have grown by 6.1 million since February 2010.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: But since he became president, the gain is a more modest 1.9 million.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: And when losses in public sector employment are added to the mix, his overall jobs record is a gain of 1.2 million.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: \------ OBAMA: "We have doubled the distance our cars will go on a gallon of gas."

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: THE FACTS: Not so fast.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: That's expected to happen in 12 more years.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: Under a deal the Obama administration reached with automakers in 2011, vehicles will have a corporate average fuel economy of 54.5 miles per gallon by 2025, twice the 27 miles per gallon, on average, that cars and trucks get today.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: Automobile manufacturers won't start making changes to achieve the new fuel economy standards until model year 2017.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: Not all cars will double their gas mileage, since the standard is based on an average of a manufacturers' fleet.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: \------ OBAMA: "Already the Affordable Care Act is helping to reduce the growth of health care costs."

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: THE FACTS: The jury is still out on whether Obama's health care overhaul will reduce the growth of health care costs.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: It's true that cost increases have eased, but many experts say that's due to the sluggish economy, not to the health care law, whose main provisions are not yet fully in effect.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: \------ OBAMA: "Real reform means establishing a responsible pathway to earned citizenship -- a path that includes passing a background check, paying taxes and a meaningful penalty, learning English and going to the back of the line behind the folks trying to come here legally."

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: THE FACTS: The seemingly stern admonition that illegal immigrants must go to the back of the line, often heard from the president, doesn't appear to have much practical effect except in the most obvious sense.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: Everyone who joins a line, whether for a movie, a coffee or citizenship, starts at the back of that particular line.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: It's not clear he is saying anything more than that illegal immigrants won't get to cut in line for citizenship once they've obtained provisional legal status.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: Like those living abroad who have applied to come to the U.S. legally, illegal immigrants who qualify for Obama's proposed path to citizenship will surely face long waits to be processed.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: But during that time, they are already in the U.S. and will get to stay, work and travel in the country under their new status as provisional immigrants, while those outside the U.S. simply have to wait.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: Sending illegal immigrants to the "back of the line" is something of a distinction without a difference for some legal immigrants who dutifully followed all the rules before coming to the United States.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: For instance, some legal immigrants who are in the U.S. on an employer-sponsored visa can't easily change jobs, or in some cases take a promotion, without jeopardizing their place in line to get a green card.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: In other cases, would-be legal immigrants in other countries wait for years to be able to settle in the U.S. Obama is using "back of the line" somewhat figuratively, because there are multiple lines depending on the applicant's relationship with family already in the U.S. or with an employer.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: Generally, a foreign-born spouse of a U.S. citizen or someone with needed skills and a job offer will be accepted more quickly than many others.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: But even as a figurative point, his assertion may cloak the fact that people who came to the U.S. illegally and win provisional status have the great advantage over applicants abroad of already being where they all want to go.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: \------ OBAMA: "Study after study shows that the sooner a child begins learning, the better he or she does down the road.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: ... And for poor kids who need help the most, this lack of access to preschool education can shadow them for the rest of their lives.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: ... Every dollar we invest in high-quality early education can save more than $7 later on -- by boosting graduation rates, reducing teen pregnancy, even reducing violent crime."

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: THE FACTS: Dozens of studies have shown Head Start graduates are more likely to complete high school than their at-risk peers who don't participate in the program.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: But a study last year by the Department of Health and Human Services that found big vocabulary and social development gains for at-risk students in pre-kindergarten programs also found those effects largely faded by the time pupils reached third grade.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: The report didn't explain why the kids saw a drop-off in performance or predict how they would fare as they aged.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: \------ OBAMA: "I urge this Congress to pursue a bipartisan, market-based solution to climate change, like the one John McCain and Joe Lieberman worked on together a few years ago.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: But if Congress won't act soon to protect future generations, I will.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: I will direct my Cabinet to come up with executive actions we can take, now and in the future, to reduce pollution, prepare our communities for the consequences of climate change and speed the transition to more sustainable sources of energy."

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: THE FACTS: Obama failed to get a global warming bill through Congress when both Houses were controlled by Democrats in 2010.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: With Republicans in control of the House, the chances of a bill to limit the gases blamed for global warming and to create a market for businesses to trade pollution credits are close to zero.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: The Obama administration has already acted to control greenhouse gases through existing law.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: It has boosted fuel-efficiency standards and proposed rules to control heat-trapping emissions from new power plants.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: And while there are still other ways to address climate change without Congress, it's questionable regulation alone can achieve the reductions needed to start curbing global warming.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: \------ FLORIDA SEN. MARCO RUBIO, in the Republican response: "The real cause of our debt is that our government has been spending $1 trillion more than it takes in every year.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: That's why we need a balanced-budget amendment."

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: THE FACTS: That statement may reflect the math behind recent debt, but it doesn't get directly to the cause -- the worst recession since the Depression and its aftereffects.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: The deficit is not only caused by spending, but by reduced tax revenues.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: And during the recession, revenues from both individual and corporate taxes fell markedly.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: The steep increases in debt and the measures that should be taken to ease the burden are central to the debate in Washington.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: But there is no serious move afoot to amend the Constitution to prohibit deficit spending.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: The ability to take on debt has been used by governments worldwide and through U.S. history to shelter people from the ravages of a down economy, wage war and achieve many other ends.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: An effort to amend the Constitution for any purpose faces daunting odds; this would be no exception.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: Most state constitutions demand a balanced budget, but states lack some big obligations of the federal government, including national defense.

column3: Fact check on Obama's State of the Union address
column4: And Washington's ability to go deeper into debt provides states with at least a minimal safety net in times of high unemployment.

column3: Senate Armed Services Committee endorses Chuck Hagel 14-11
column4: Updated 02/12/2013 05:38 PM EST Splitting along party lines, the Senate Armed Services Committee voted 14-11 on Tuesday to advance Chuck Hagel’s nomination after a tense two-hour meeting that closed the latest chapter in a weeks-long political saga.

column3: Senate Armed Services Committee endorses Chuck Hagel 14-11
column4: The nomination heads to the full Senate, where Republicans may demand a 60-vote threshold in a vote expected later this week.

column3: Senate Armed Services Committee endorses Chuck Hagel 14-11
column4: Story Continued Below ( PHOTOS: Chuck Hagel’s confirmation hearing) Democrats and Republicans broke sharply over whether the former Republican senator from Nebraska is the right man to run the Pentagon.

column3: Senate Armed Services Committee endorses Chuck Hagel 14-11
column4: Supporters cited Hagel’s experience as an enlisted soldier in Vietnam and his service in the Senate and elsewhere as reasons he should succeed Defense Secretary Leon Panetta while opponents stuck with their criticisms about Hagel’s past positions on Iran, Israel and the defense budget.

column3: Senate Armed Services Committee endorses Chuck Hagel 14-11
column4: A few Republicans kept up their bid to stop Hagel’s nomination from moving ahead, arguing he has kept some information from the committee, but Democrats insisted that he has satisfied its disclosure requirements and accused Republicans of tarring Hagel unfairly.

column3: Senate Armed Services Committee endorses Chuck Hagel 14-11
column4: Sen. Bill Nelson (D-Fla.) said Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas) had "gone over the line" and "basically ... impugned the patriotism of the nominee” by pointing out that the Iranian Foreign Ministry had praised Hagel.

column3: Senate Armed Services Committee endorses Chuck Hagel 14-11
column4: The top Republican on the committee, Sen. Jim Inhofe (R-Okla.), shot back later in defense of Cruz, "You don't get any cozier than that."

column3: Senate Armed Services Committee endorses Chuck Hagel 14-11
column4: Former ranking member Sen. John McCain (R-Ariz.) interjected soon thereafter with a message for his colleagues: "Sen. Hagel is an honorable man who has served his country, and no one on this committee at any time should impugn his character," McCain said.

column3: Senate Armed Services Committee endorses Chuck Hagel 14-11
column4: ( PHOTOS: Chuck Hagel’s career) But for most of the meeting, senators referred to Hagel’s late January confirmation hearing.

column3: Senate Armed Services Committee endorses Chuck Hagel 14-11
column4: McCain slammed Hagel’s performance as “the worst I have seen of any nomination for office” and said it was “disturbing” that Hagel would not directly respond to his question about whether the Iraq surge was a success.

column3: Senate Armed Services Committee endorses Chuck Hagel 14-11
column4: Democrats said the criticism of Hagel’s day in the spotlight was unfair, and they defended his description of a policy of “containment” for a nuclear Iran — which the White House does not support – as a simple slip of the tongue.

column3: Senate Armed Services Committee endorses Chuck Hagel 14-11
column4: Apart from the politics involved with Hagel himself, Senate Armed Services Committee Chairman Carl Levin (D-Mich.) had warned senators that rejecting him would endanger the Pentagon at a time it could ill afford another complication.

column3: Senate panel endorses Hagel for Pentagon in rare party-line vote
column4: A Senate panel narrowly endorsed Chuck Hagel to lead the Pentagon Tuesday, in a rare party-line vote that underscored intense Republican opposition to his nomination while nevertheless advancing Hagel to the floor for a final verdict.

column3: Senate panel endorses Hagel for Pentagon in rare party-line vote
column4: The Senate Armed Services Committee voted 14-11 to advance Hagel's nomination.

column3: Senate panel endorses Hagel for Pentagon in rare party-line vote
column4: All Republicans present voted against Hagel, himself a Republican and former Nebraska senator.

column3: Senate panel endorses Hagel for Pentagon in rare party-line vote
column4: Supporters lauded his service in the Vietnam War, and claimed the nominee had been forthcoming throughout his confirmation process.

column3: Senate panel endorses Hagel for Pentagon in rare party-line vote
column4: But critics pointed to Hagel's history of controversial votes and statements regarding Iran, Israel, terror groups, the Iraq war and other issues.

column3: Senate panel endorses Hagel for Pentagon in rare party-line vote
column4: Further, they panned what was widely regarded as a rocky performance by Hagel during his recent confirmation hearing.

column3: Senate panel endorses Hagel for Pentagon in rare party-line vote
column4: It is rare for the Senate to be this divided on a Cabinet nomination of this magnitude.

column3: Senate panel endorses Hagel for Pentagon in rare party-line vote
column4: "His performance before this committee was the worst that I have seen for any nominee for office," Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz., said, before voting against Hagel.

column3: Senate panel endorses Hagel for Pentagon in rare party-line vote
column4: Sen. Lindsey Graham, R-S.C., another senator opposing Hagel, said "there are very few people who have been this wrong about so many things."

column3: Senate panel endorses Hagel for Pentagon in rare party-line vote
column4: Saying the next secretary of Defense will deal with "a world on fire," Graham said Hagel's testimony was "not reassuring."

column3: Senate panel endorses Hagel for Pentagon in rare party-line vote
column4: Republican lawmakers had various reasons for opposing Hagel or trying to hold up his nomination.

column3: Senate panel endorses Hagel for Pentagon in rare party-line vote
column4: Some wanted him to provide more financial background information.

column3: Senate panel endorses Hagel for Pentagon in rare party-line vote
column4: Others voiced interest in holding up the nomination until the administration provides more information about the Benghazi terror attack, while voicing concerns about Hagel's background as well.

column3: Senate panel endorses Hagel for Pentagon in rare party-line vote
column4: Democratic Chairman Carl Levin, though, pushed forward on a vote just hours before President Obama was set to deliver his State of the Union address.

column3: Senate panel endorses Hagel for Pentagon in rare party-line vote
column4: "The time has come for the committee to act on this nomination," Levin said.

column3: Senate panel endorses Hagel for Pentagon in rare party-line vote
column4: Obama tapped Hagel, 66, a former Republican senator and twice-wounded Vietnam War combat veteran to succeed Defense Secretary Leon Panetta, who is stepping down after four years as CIA director and Pentagon chief.

column3: Senate panel endorses Hagel for Pentagon in rare party-line vote
column4: Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, a Democrat, is pressing for a full Senate vote later this week, most likely on Thursday.

column3: Senate panel endorses Hagel for Pentagon in rare party-line vote
column4: McCain cited Hagel's opposition to an increase in U.S. forces in Iraq that McCain backed in 2007, as well as Hagel's halting performance at his confirmation hearing.

column3: Senate panel endorses Hagel for Pentagon in rare party-line vote
column4: During the final committee meeting Tuesday, a dispute broke out between Sen. Ted Cruz, R-Texas, and Democrats over complaints Cruz had about Hagel not revealing certain personal compensation -- Cruz questioned whether Hagel had gotten paid at any point by radical groups.

column3: Senate panel endorses Hagel for Pentagon in rare party-line vote
column4: Sen. Bill Nelson, D-Fla., said Cruz had "gone over the line" and "impugned the patriotism" of Hagel, a claim Cruz denied.

column3: Senate panel endorses Hagel for Pentagon in rare party-line vote
column4: Committee Republicans had forced a delay in the expected vote last week when they pressed Hagel for further data on his personal finances.

column3: Senate panel endorses Hagel for Pentagon in rare party-line vote
column4: Levin said the Republican demands were beyond the scope of those traditionally asked of previous nominees, Republican and Democrat -- a point echoed by McCain.

column3: Senate panel endorses Hagel for Pentagon in rare party-line vote
column4: Hagel now faces Republican delaying tactics in the full Senate, with the panel's top Republican, Sen. Jim Inhofe, insisting that any confirmation be based on 60 votes rather than a majority of the 100-member Senate.

column3: Senate panel endorses Hagel for Pentagon in rare party-line vote
column4: But that effort has divided Republicans, with several longtime members opposed to the unprecedented step of stalling, or filibustering, a president's Cabinet nominee for Defense secretary.

column3: Senate panel endorses Hagel for Pentagon in rare party-line vote
column4: Late Monday, McCain met privately with several committee Republicans and urged them not to filibuster the Hagel nomination, pointing out that the roles could be reversed someday with a Republican president and Republican-controlled Senate.

column3: Senate panel endorses Hagel for Pentagon in rare party-line vote
column4: "I'm encouraging my colleagues if they want to vote against Sen. Hagel that's one thing and that's a principled stand," McCain told a group of reporters.

column3: Senate panel endorses Hagel for Pentagon in rare party-line vote
column4: "We do not want to filibuster.

column3: Senate panel endorses Hagel for Pentagon in rare party-line vote
column4: We have not filibustered a Cabinet appointee in the past and I believe that we should move forward with his nomination, bring it to the floor and vote up or down."

column3: Senate panel endorses Hagel for Pentagon in rare party-line vote
column4: All 55 Democrats are expected to back Hagel, and two Republicans -- Sens.

column3: Senate panel endorses Hagel for Pentagon in rare party-line vote
column4: Thad Cochran and Mike Johanns -- have said they will vote for the nominee.

column3: Senate panel endorses Hagel for Pentagon in rare party-line vote
column4: At least five Republicans, including McCain, have said they oppose a filibuster despite their reservations or opposition toward the nominee.

column3: Senate panel endorses Hagel for Pentagon in rare party-line vote
column4: More than a dozen Republicans have said they will oppose their former colleague, and several others have indicated they are likely to vote no.

column3: Senate panel endorses Hagel for Pentagon in rare party-line vote
column4: Sen. Kelly Ayotte, a Republican member of the Armed Services Committee, said Tuesday she would vote against the nominee, citing his performance at his confirmation hearing.

column3: Senate panel endorses Hagel for Pentagon in rare party-line vote
column4: Hagel seemed ill-prepared under withering cross-examination from committee Republicans in nearly eight hours of testimony on Jan. 31.

column3: Senate panel endorses Hagel for Pentagon in rare party-line vote
column4: He was repeatedly pressed about past statements and votes on Israel, Iran and nuclear weapons, with Republican lawmakers suggesting he wasn't sufficiently supportive of Israel or anti-Iran.

column3: Senate panel endorses Hagel for Pentagon in rare party-line vote
column4: The Associated Press contributed to this report.

column3: 5 things to watch for in the State of the Union
column4: President Barack Obama on Tuesday gets his second high-profile opportunity in less than a month to set the agenda for his second term.

column3: 5 things to watch for in the State of the Union
column4: The president views the speech as finishing a thought that began with the Inauguration, aides say, with a deeper focus on job creation and the economy but no shortage of attention to the controversial social issues that top his to-do list.

column3: 5 things to watch for in the State of the Union
column4: Story Continued Below Here’s POLITICO’s list of five things to watch in the State of the Union: 1\.

column3: 5 things to watch for in the State of the Union
column4: Soft, strident or somewhere in between?

column3: 5 things to watch for in the State of the Union
column4: Obama irritated Republicans with his unapologetically liberal inaugural address — and the lack of any perceived olive branch quickly became the news.

column3: 5 things to watch for in the State of the Union
column4: ( PHOTOS: State of the Union history: 10 famous lines) But as Obama prepares to move his agenda into legislation, he’ll need congressional — and at least some Republican — support.

column3: 5 things to watch for in the State of the Union
column4: So he has to find a way to do both: Make a robust case for limiting guns, overhauling immigration and protecting entitlement programs but without alienating the party that controls the House and the ability to filibuster in the Senate.

column3: 5 things to watch for in the State of the Union
column4: Finding that balance is nearly impossible.

column3: 5 things to watch for in the State of the Union
column4: The West Wing would no doubt prefer to use the speech to remind Republicans that elections have consequences — and, by the way, Obama won.

column3: 5 things to watch for in the State of the Union
column4: His aides question whether any of his past bipartisan gestures really got him anywhere.

column3: 5 things to watch for in the State of the Union
column4: And Obama hasn’t exactly moved out of campaign mode.

column3: 5 things to watch for in the State of the Union
column4: He’s been traveling the country on immigration and guns and hammering Republicans for more than a week on the across-the-board spending cuts known as the sequester.

column3: 5 things to watch for in the State of the Union
column4: He’s accusing them of wanting automatic cuts “on seniors and middle-class families” to avoid closing “even a single tax loophole that benefits the wealthy.” ( PHOTOS: Memorable guests at the State of the Union) But Republicans will be looking for an overture that they felt was missing from the Inauguration — though they really don’t want him to get too close.

column3: 5 things to watch for in the State of the Union
column4: For example, Obama name-checking the Republicans who are working with Democrats on guns and immigration may look like a magnanimous act to the world outside Washington but here, it could be fatal to the delicate talks.

column3: 5 things to watch for in the State of the Union
column4: Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) put the president on notice, saying Obama needs to soften his rhetoric on the sequester and work with Congress.

column3: 5 things to watch for in the State of the Union
column4: ( Full coverage: State of the Union 2013) “Let’s be clear about something: If the President does choose to strike fear into the hearts of folks he should be reassuring, then that decision will be his alone,” McConnell said Monday.

column3: 5 things to watch for in the State of the Union
column4: “And that’s why the next time the president delivers some over-the-top speech flanked by some pollster-approved voter group, I hope someone on the stage taps him on the shoulder and asks: Mr. President, if you’re truly worried about this issue, why aren’t you working with the Congress we elected to prevent it?” 2\.

column3: 5 things to watch for in the State of the Union
column4: Will there be a breakthrough jobs plan?

column3: 5 things to watch for in the State of the Union
column4: It would be déjà vu, at this point, for Obama to use a high-profile speech to talk about jobs, the economy and the middle class — he’s been doing that for four years.

column3: 5 things to watch for in the State of the Union
column4: ( POLITICO’s White House team previews State of the Union 2013) With the Commerce Department reporting last month that the economy shrank in the final quarter of 2012, surprising experts who expected some growth, there’s political and practical urgency.

column3: 5 things to watch for in the State of the Union
column4: But the challenge for Obama is to come up with fresh job proposals that stand any chance of passing a deeply divided Congress.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s State of the Union a wish list for liberals
column4: The first State of the Union address of President Obama’s second term is shaping up as a conservative’s nightmare come true.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s State of the Union a wish list for liberals
column4: In his speech to Congress on Tuesday night, Mr. Obama is certain to demand more tax revenue, part of his “balanced” approach to deficit reduction, even though he won a battle with Congress last month for a tax increase on wealthier households.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s State of the Union a wish list for liberals
column4: He also will push for more spending to fund his job-creation proposals and education plans.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s State of the Union a wish list for liberals
column4: The nationally televised address will begin at 9 p.m. (SEE RELATED: Ted Nugent to be a guest at State of the Union address) “He will focus on the proposals that are necessary to help the middle class grow and help the economy grow,” White House press secretary Jay Carney said Monday.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s State of the Union a wish list for liberals
column4: “We need more investment that helps the key industries of the 21st century take root here in the United States.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s State of the Union a wish list for liberals
column4: We are not done, not even close.” Along with higher taxes and bigger government, Mr. Obama will renew his call for gun-control measures and immigration reform that includes a pathway to citizenship.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s State of the Union a wish list for liberals
column4: Many Democrats expect the president to call attention again to climate change as part of his clean-energy agenda.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s State of the Union a wish list for liberals
column4: As for Republicans’ goals of cutting spending, curbing the growth of entitlement programs and reducing the size of government?

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s State of the Union a wish list for liberals
column4: Most observers don’t expect the president to give those subjects more than the briefest of lip service.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s State of the Union a wish list for liberals
column4: “Don’t hold your breath,” said Ron Haskins, a senior fellow in economic studies at the left-leaning Brookings Institution.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s State of the Union a wish list for liberals
column4: “Why would he?

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s State of the Union a wish list for liberals
column4: He’s in great political shape.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s State of the Union a wish list for liberals
column4: I don’t think he’s going to do anything serious [on spending].

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s State of the Union a wish list for liberals
column4: He has every reason to sit tight and play to his base.” (SEE RELATED: State of Union response carries risk for Marco Rubio) The day after delivering his agenda, Mr. Obama will begin a series of trips to sell his initiatives to the public in North Carolina, Georgia and Illinois.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s State of the Union a wish list for liberals
column4: The danger in failing to reach out to Republicans on deficit reduction, some analysts say, is that the Republicans have the power to block Mr. Obama’s top priorities such as immigration reform.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s State of the Union a wish list for liberals
column4: If the president takes too combative a posture with Republicans, it will “doom” much of his agenda, said Alice Rivlin, another senior fellow at Brookings who served on Mr. Obama’s debt commission.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s State of the Union a wish list for liberals
column4: “We have a long-run problem, and if he’s seen as not addressing it by much of the country and by the Republican opposition, he will doom his other agenda to bickering,” she said.

column4: Progressive policies are great: That’s the gist of what President Obama will suggest during Tuesday’s State of the Union speech, according to various leaks, analyses and outright guesses.

column4: By comparison, Mr. Obama highlighted in his last major speech — January’s inaugural address — on social policy and equal rights for gays.
