column3: Pope Benedict to become first pontiff in 600 years to resign
column4: The 85-year-old pontiff made the announcement Monday, saying he no longer had the strength to carry out his papal duties.

column3: Pope Benedict to become first pontiff in 600 years to resign
column4: "After having repeatedly examined my conscience before God, I have come to the certainty that my strengths, due to an advanced age, are no longer suited to an adequate exercise of the Petrine ministry," the pope said according to a statement released by the Vatican.

column3: Pope Benedict to become first pontiff in 600 years to resign
column4: [pullquote] He said he is aware of the "seriousness" of his resignation, but that he did so in "full freedom."

column3: Pope Benedict to become first pontiff in 600 years to resign
column4: He will live out his days on Vatican grounds, according to officials.

column3: Pope Benedict to become first pontiff in 600 years to resign
column4: The last pope to resign was Pope Gregory XII, who stepped down in 1415 in a deal to end the Great Western Schism among competing papal claimants.

column3: Pope Benedict to become first pontiff in 600 years to resign
column4: The sudden announcement sets the stage for the Vatican to hold a conclave to elect a new pope by mid-March, since the traditional mourning time that would follow the death of a pope doesn't have to be observed.

column3: Pope Benedict to become first pontiff in 600 years to resign
column4: There are several papal contenders in the wings, but no obvious front-runner, according to Vatican watchers.

column3: Pope Benedict to become first pontiff in 600 years to resign
column4: A Vatican spokesperson told "Fox & Friends" that Pope Benedict "will not take part in conclave" to choose his successor.

column3: Pope Benedict to become first pontiff in 600 years to resign
column4: Officials hope to have a new pope in place in time for the start of Holy Week, on March 14.

column3: Pope Benedict to become first pontiff in 600 years to resign
column4: Although there has been much speculation about Pope Benedict's health, a Vatican spokesman said he is not in any immediate danger.

column3: Pope Benedict to become first pontiff in 600 years to resign
column4: "There's nothing immediately serious or grave," the Vatican spokesman told ABC.

column3: Pope Benedict to become first pontiff in 600 years to resign
column4: The pope's 89-year-old brother, Georg Ratzinger, told a German news agency that the pope has had difficulty walking recently and has considered stepping down for months.

column3: Pope Benedict to become first pontiff in 600 years to resign
column4: “His age is weighing on him,” Georg Ratzinger said.

column3: Pope Benedict to become first pontiff in 600 years to resign
column4: “At this age my brother wants more rest.” Fox News Executive Vice President John Moody, former Vatican bureau chief for Time magazine, told Fox News Channel that Pope Benedict showed courage by accepting that the rigors of the papacy had become too much for him.

column3: Pope Benedict to become first pontiff in 600 years to resign
column4: "I think it is one of the bravest things I’ve ever heard of," said Moody, who is author of a 1996 biography of Pope John Paul II.

column3: Pope Benedict to become first pontiff in 600 years to resign
column4: "Nobody gives up power willingly.

column3: Pope Benedict to become first pontiff in 600 years to resign
column4: Nobody gives up power without forethought.

column3: Pope Benedict to become first pontiff in 600 years to resign
column4: For this man, who really the world hasn’t gotten to know very well, despite the fact that he’s been around as pope for seven years, to do this speaks volumes about the kind of man he is and the kind of leader of the church that he insisted on being."

column3: Pope Benedict to become first pontiff in 600 years to resign
column4: Born Joseph Aloisius Ratzinger, Pope Benedict became the 265th pope after being elected by his fellow cardinals on April 19, 2005, at the age of 78 following the death of the popular John Paul II.

column3: Pope Benedict to become first pontiff in 600 years to resign
column4: The ninth German pope and first in nearly 500 years, Benedict was ordained in 1951 and was a major figure at the Vatican stage for decades before his ascension.

column3: Pope Benedict to become first pontiff in 600 years to resign
column4: Ratzinger chose the name Benedict, which comes from the Latin word meaning "the blessed," in homage to Pope Benedict XV, who was pope during World War I, and Saint Benedict of Nursia, who established the Benedictine monasteries.

column3: Pope Benedict to become first pontiff in 600 years to resign
column4: During his papacy and in the years prior, Benedict was a key figure in the church's efforts to address widespread instances of sexual abuse of children by priests.

column3: Pope Benedict to become first pontiff in 600 years to resign
column4: In 2001, then-Cardinal Ratzinger convinced John Paul II to put the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith, which he led, in charge of investigating cases and setting policy regarding what he termed "filth" in the church.

column3: Pope Benedict to become first pontiff in 600 years to resign
column4: As a cardinal, Ratzinger pushed through important reforms, including making Internet offenses against children a violation covered by canon law, extending child abuse offenses to include the sexual abuse of all under 18, waiving of the statute of limitation and speeding the process of dismissing guilty priests.

column3: Pope Benedict to become first pontiff in 600 years to resign
column4: Even before becoming pope, Ratzinger had experienced health problems and attempted to resign from his role as prefect of the Congregation for the Doctrine of Faith several times, only to stay on at the behest of Pope John Paul II.

column3: Pope Benedict to become first pontiff in 600 years to resign
column4: In 1991, Ratzinger suffered a stroke, according to reports.

column3: Pope Benedict to become first pontiff in 600 years to resign
column4: After becoming pope, Benedict, who predicted a short tenure for himself, suffered another stroke in May 2005, according to the Vatican.

column3: Pope Benedict to become first pontiff in 600 years to resign
column4: He is also believed to suffer from a heart condition.

column3: Pope Benedict to become first pontiff in 600 years to resign
column4: As pope, Benedict embraced technology.

column3: Pope Benedict to become first pontiff in 600 years to resign
column4: In December, he began using Twitter, where he has 1.5 million followers.

column3: Pope Benedict to become first pontiff in 600 years to resign
column4: "We must trust in the mighty power of God’s mercy," read his most recent tweet, posted yesterday.

column3: Pope Benedict to become first pontiff in 600 years to resign
column4: "We are all sinners, but His grace transforms us and makes us new."

column3: Pope Benedict to become first pontiff in 600 years to resign
column4: The Associated Press contributed to this report.

column3: Prayer Breakfast Speech: Doctor Attacks Political Correctness, National Debt in Front of Obama
column4: — UPDATE: Dr. Carson Reveals Why He Spoke Out Against Obama’s Policies at Prayer Breakfast — Plus, Would He Ever Run for President?

column3: Prayer Breakfast Speech: Doctor Attacks Political Correctness, National Debt in Front of Obama
column4: — One of the more unique speeches delivered at this morning’s National Prayer Breakfast came from Dr. Benjamin S. Carson, a world-renowned pediatric neurosurgeon at Johns Hopkins Hospital.

column3: Prayer Breakfast Speech: Doctor Attacks Political Correctness, National Debt in Front of Obama
column4: Taking the stage before President Barack Obama’s faith-filled address, Carson spoke for more than 25 minutes, tackling issues ranging from education to personal responsibility.

column3: Prayer Breakfast Speech: Doctor Attacks Political Correctness, National Debt in Front of Obama
column4: His keynote, while predicated upon the theme of Jesus Christ as his ultimate role model, also took a starkly political tone, advocating against some of the very policies the president has implemented.

column3: Prayer Breakfast Speech: Doctor Attacks Political Correctness, National Debt in Front of Obama
column4: At the beginning of his speech, Carson shared an intense disdain for political correctness.

column3: Prayer Breakfast Speech: Doctor Attacks Political Correctness, National Debt in Front of Obama
column4: Without getting too specific on the issue front, he said that Americans should stop being afraid to speak up and defend their beliefs; he also encouraged people to respect the individuals they disagree with.

column3: Prayer Breakfast Speech: Doctor Attacks Political Correctness, National Debt in Front of Obama
column4: Carson held little back, condemning political correctness as “a horrible thing” that is “dangerous,” as it hampers freedom of thought and expression.

column3: Prayer Breakfast Speech: Doctor Attacks Political Correctness, National Debt in Front of Obama
column4: “We’ve reached a point where people are actually afraid to talk about what they want to say, because somebody might be offended,” Carson said, noting the example of people refraining from saying “Merry Christmas.” “We’ve got to get over this sensitivity and it keeps people from saying what they really believe.” [ooyala code=”hpM202OTp0vuiuIW_xDAWCaz-4MrM4dN”] Carson encouraged discussion about societal issues, also pointing out education as an essential conundrum the country needs to confront.

column3: Prayer Breakfast Speech: Doctor Attacks Political Correctness, National Debt in Front of Obama
column4: He highlighted his own path from poverty to success, sharing very personal details about his parents and early family life and subsequently described the importance of helping students seeking to advance academically through his Carson Scholars Fund.

column3: Prayer Breakfast Speech: Doctor Attacks Political Correctness, National Debt in Front of Obama
column4: The speech took an interesting turn when the doctor cautioned that moral decay and fiscal irresponsibility can have dire consequences — even for powerful countries like America.

column3: Prayer Breakfast Speech: Doctor Attacks Political Correctness, National Debt in Front of Obama
column4: Here, he became even more pointed and impassioned.

column3: Prayer Breakfast Speech: Doctor Attacks Political Correctness, National Debt in Front of Obama
column4: “I think particularly about ancient Rome.

column3: Prayer Breakfast Speech: Doctor Attacks Political Correctness, National Debt in Front of Obama
column4: Very powerful — nobody could even challenge them militarily…they destroyed themselves from within,” Carson continued.

column3: Prayer Breakfast Speech: Doctor Attacks Political Correctness, National Debt in Front of Obama
column4: “Moral decay.

column3: Prayer Breakfast Speech: Doctor Attacks Political Correctness, National Debt in Front of Obama
column4: Fiscal irresponsibility.” While he said America’s issues are dire, he was positive that the nation can fix its ways, as there are bright and innovative people who simply need to come together to address the problems at hand.

column3: Prayer Breakfast Speech: Doctor Attacks Political Correctness, National Debt in Front of Obama
column4: “And one of our big problems right now…our deficit is a big problem,” he said, as Obama watched him intently.

column3: Prayer Breakfast Speech: Doctor Attacks Political Correctness, National Debt in Front of Obama
column4: “Think about it — and our national debt — $16 and a half trillion dollars.” To illustrate just how massive the debt is, Carson told the audience that if they counted one number per second, it would take them 507,000 years to get to the sum total.

column3: Prayer Breakfast Speech: Doctor Attacks Political Correctness, National Debt in Front of Obama
column4: The doctor said that the massive fiscal blunder is something that the nation must contend with.

column3: Prayer Breakfast Speech: Doctor Attacks Political Correctness, National Debt in Front of Obama
column4: From there, he moved on to taxation, seemingly taking a stance in direct opposition to Obama’s.

column3: Prayer Breakfast Speech: Doctor Attacks Political Correctness, National Debt in Front of Obama
column4: “What about our taxation system — so complex there is no one that can possibly comply with every jot and tittle,” he noted, going on to call for a simpler (i.e.

column3: Prayer Breakfast Speech: Doctor Attacks Political Correctness, National Debt in Front of Obama
column4: flat tax) system.

column3: Prayer Breakfast Speech: Doctor Attacks Political Correctness, National Debt in Front of Obama
column4: “When I pick up my Bible, you know what I see — I see the fairest individual in the universe — God — and he’s given us a system.

column3: Prayer Breakfast Speech: Doctor Attacks Political Correctness, National Debt in Front of Obama
column4: It’s called tithe.” [ooyala code=”85Nm02OTpkDb6O80wV0Xbw4-T2Dtv9ho”] Carson progressed, seemingly comparing the tithe, at least in principal, to the flat tax system.

column3: Prayer Breakfast Speech: Doctor Attacks Political Correctness, National Debt in Front of Obama
column4: Rather than continuing to tier taxes owed, he argued that everyone should pay the same proportion and that, through this fairer system, money sent by wealthier Americans for protection abroad should be brought back to America to help build infrastructure and create additional jobs.

column3: Prayer Breakfast Speech: Doctor Attacks Political Correctness, National Debt in Front of Obama
column4: The doctor also addressed medical care, advocating for health savings accounts and railing against the notion that Americans should be sending money into a large bureaucratic system.

column3: Prayer Breakfast Speech: Doctor Attacks Political Correctness, National Debt in Front of Obama
column4: You can watch the entire, 26-minute speech below: Editor’s note: The Ben Carson speech post is one of most popular and viral in the two-year history of TheBlaze.

column3: White House outlines deep cuts that could be coming soon
column4: They include layoffs or furloughs of "hundreds of thousands" of federal workers, including FBI agents, U.S. prosecutors, food safety inspectors and air traffic controllers, said White House budget officials at a briefing and in a fact sheet that included these examples of what the cuts would mean: -- 70,000 young children would be kicked off Head Start, 10,000 teacher jobs would be put at risk and up to 2,100 food safety inspections might have to be cancelled.

column3: White House outlines deep cuts that could be coming soon
column4: --Up to 373,000 "seriously mentally ill adults and seriously emotionally disturbed children" would go untreated, up to 1,000 fewer National Science Foundation research grants and effecting some 12,000 scientists and students could be threatened, many small business loans denied, workplace safety inspections curtailed, federally assisted programs like "Meals on Wheels" slashed and 125,000 low-income renters put at risk of losing government-subsidized housing.

column3: White House outlines deep cuts that could be coming soon
column4: -- Approximately 424,000 fewer HIV tests could be conducted by state agencies working with the Centers for Disease Control and some 100,000 formerly homeless people, including veterans, would be removed from their current housing and emergency shelter programs.

column3: White House outlines deep cuts that could be coming soon
column4: The so-called mandatory sequester cuts are a "serious threat to national security, domestic programs and the economy," Office of Budget and Management official Danny Werfel told a White House briefing.

column3: White House outlines deep cuts that could be coming soon
column4: The spending cuts were originally to take place beginning Jan. 1, but were put off until March 1 in a last-minute deal between President Obama and Congress to avert a New Year's Day "fiscal cliff" of tax hikes and spending cuts.

column3: White House outlines deep cuts that could be coming soon
column4: At issue are $1.2 trillion of additional spending cuts over the next 10 years, including about $85 billion this year.

column3: White House outlines deep cuts that could be coming soon
column4: Obama has called for a small package of spending cuts and measures to close tax loopholes and put off the deadline again.

column3: White House outlines deep cuts that could be coming soon

column3: White House outlines deep cuts that could be coming soon

column3: White House outlines deep cuts that could be coming soon

Ideas for increasing tax revenue include a minimum tax rate for millionaires, eliminating a tax perk on corporate jets and closing a loophole that allows wealthy people to avoid paying Social Security and Medicare taxes on some of their income.

column3: White House outlines deep cuts that could be coming soon

column3: White House outlines deep cuts that could be coming soon

column3: White House Delivers Dire Warning About Automatic Cuts
column4: 5:12 p.m. | Updated With a real blizzard bearing down on New England, the policy wonks in the White House tried every which way they could on Friday to warn of the dangers of a different kind of storm.

column3: White House Delivers Dire Warning About Automatic Cuts
column4: The officials gathered reporters to describe what they believe will be the effects of sequestration, the automatic, across-the-board cuts to defense and domestic spending that will kick in on March 1 unless Congress and President Obama agree on a plan to put them off.

column3: White House Delivers Dire Warning About Automatic Cuts
column4: The string of adjectives was meant to be chilling: “large and arbitrary,” “severe,” “significant and harmful,” “very significant,” “blunt,” “mindless” and “extraordinarily troublesome.” They didn’t stop with just adjectives, though.

column3: White House Delivers Dire Warning About Automatic Cuts
column4: In their effort to pressure Republican lawmakers to agree to tax increases as well as spending cuts, White House officials predicted specific consequences that Americans might not like.

column3: White House Delivers Dire Warning About Automatic Cuts
column4: Among them, they said: 70,000 young children will be kicked off Head Start early education programs; hundreds of federal prosecutors will be furloughed; food safety inspections will be cut back; 600,000 women and children will lose nutritional benefits; and small-business loans will be cut by about $500 million.

column3: White House Delivers Dire Warning About Automatic Cuts
column4: “The cuts would cause very significant disruptions that would be felt far and wide across the country,” said Danny Werfel, the federal controller of the Office of Management and Budget.

column3: White House Delivers Dire Warning About Automatic Cuts
column4: “This is just the tip of the iceberg.

column3: White House Delivers Dire Warning About Automatic Cuts
column4: We can’t plan our way out of these consequences or take steps to soften the blow.” The briefing was the latest attempt by Mr. Obama’s White House to try and make sure that Republicans receive the blame for the consequences of the automatic cuts — if they happen.

column3: White House Delivers Dire Warning About Automatic Cuts
column4: Brendan Buck, a spokesman for the House speaker, John A. Boehner, tried to deflect that blame, noting that the House has already proposed alternative spending cuts as a way of avoiding the automatic ones.

column3: White House Delivers Dire Warning About Automatic Cuts
column4: Mr. Obama has said he wants a mix of spending cuts and tax increases.

column3: White House Delivers Dire Warning About Automatic Cuts
column4: And a news release from the speaker’s office had the headline: “White House Outlines Devastating Consequences of President Obamaâs Sequester.” “The president is out of excuses,” Mr. Buck said in a statement e-mailed to reporters.

column3: White House Delivers Dire Warning About Automatic Cuts
column4: “We’re glad they’re laying out the devastating consequences of the presidentâs sequester, but the question remains: what are they willing to do to prevent it?” A spokesman for Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Republican leader, said in a message on Twitter after the White House briefing: “Words not used at WH briefing to describe sequestered budget cuts: ‘Here’s our plan.’ ” At the White House, the economic officials conducting the briefing lamented the lack of flexibility in the sequestration law, which they noted was intentional.

column3: White House Delivers Dire Warning About Automatic Cuts
column4: “It was intended to drive Democrats and Republicans in Congress to compromise,” Mr. Werfel said.

column3: White House Delivers Dire Warning About Automatic Cuts
column4: “It does not represent a responsible way to achieve deficit reduction.” White House officials are quick to point out that Republicans in the House embraced the idea of the automatic cuts as a way to force deficit discipline.

column3: White House Delivers Dire Warning About Automatic Cuts
column4: They point out that 174 House Republicans voted for sequestration, including Mr. Boehner, who proclaimed himself pleased when it passed.

column3: White House Delivers Dire Warning About Automatic Cuts
column4: Jay Carney, the president’s press secretary, said the idea that the automatic cuts were all the president’s idea is a “fanciful confection” invented by Republicans.

column3: White House Delivers Dire Warning About Automatic Cuts
column4: And yet, none of Mr. Obama’s aides were willing to say that the president regretted signing the law that put the sequestration plan into effect.

column3: White House Delivers Dire Warning About Automatic Cuts
column4: Mr. Carney said that because of Republican opposition to tax increases, the automatic cuts became the only way to avoid a default on the national debt in the summer of 2011.

column3: White House Delivers Dire Warning About Automatic Cuts
column4: “He could not let the country default for the first time, thus the sequester,” Mr. Carney said.

column3: White House Delivers Dire Warning About Automatic Cuts
column4: “The whole point in its design was that it would never come to pass.”

column3: Defiant John Brennan: No recourse except drone strikes to kill suspected terrorists""
column4: John O. Brennan, President Obama’s pick to lead the CIA, defended the administration’s drone execution program before Congress on Thursday, saying that in war the commander in chief has the right to order a targeted killing — but agreeing that Congress should be more involved in knowing what is happening.

column3: Defiant John Brennan: No recourse except drone strikes to kill suspected terrorists""
column4: Mr. Brennan, who is Mr. Obama’s homeland security adviser and is considered one of the key architects of the war on terrorism in recent years, also said he is not sure whether interrogation techniques such as waterboarding produced any valuable information from suspected terrorist detainees.

column3: Defiant John Brennan: No recourse except drone strikes to kill suspected terrorists""
column4: In a hearing interrupted repeatedly by anti-war protesters, Mr. Brennan denied he had leaked classified information to reporters and told the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence that he will try to work with Capitol Hill so that lawmakers are aware of the administration’s operations in the war on terrorism.

column3: Defiant John Brennan: No recourse except drone strikes to kill suspected terrorists""
column4: Senators homed in on targeted killings by armed unmanned aerial vehicles, begun under President George W. Bush and dramatically expanded by Mr. Obama.

column3: Defiant John Brennan: No recourse except drone strikes to kill suspected terrorists""
column4: The drone program has come under scrutiny after the Obama administration used it to kill an American citizen living in Yemen.

column3: Defiant John Brennan: No recourse except drone strikes to kill suspected terrorists""
column4: “I understand you can’t have co-commanders in chief, but having the executive being the prosecutor, the judge, the jury and the executioner all in one is very contrary to the traditions and the laws of this country,” said Sen. Angus S. King Jr., Maine independent.

column3: Defiant John Brennan: No recourse except drone strikes to kill suspected terrorists""
column4: Mr. Brennan replied that this was not a judicial proceeding.

column3: Defiant John Brennan: No recourse except drone strikes to kill suspected terrorists""
column4: “The actions that we take on the counterterrorism front, again, are to take actions against individuals where we believe that the intelligence base is so strong and the nature of the threat is so grave and serious, as well as imminent, that we have no recourse except to take this action that may involve a lethal strike,” he said.

column3: Defiant John Brennan: No recourse except drone strikes to kill suspected terrorists""
column4: With some senators threatening to delay Mr. Brennan’s nomination to be CIA director until more information is disclosed, the White House late Wednesday said it would provide to the committee legal memos detailing advice about the drone program.

column3: Defiant John Brennan: No recourse except drone strikes to kill suspected terrorists""
column4: NBC News this week obtained and released a 16-page Justice Department memo laying out the legal justification for the program.

column3: Defiant John Brennan: No recourse except drone strikes to kill suspected terrorists""
column4: Three Americans are known to have been killed by the program — all of them in Yemen and all by missile strikes from drones.

column3: Defiant John Brennan: No recourse except drone strikes to kill suspected terrorists""
column4: The three are radical Islamic preacher Anwar al-Awlaki, a senior leader in al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP); his 16-year-old son, Abdulrahman al-Awlaki; and AQAP propagandist Samir Khan.

column3: Defiant John Brennan: No recourse except drone strikes to kill suspected terrorists""
column4: U.S. officials have said that al-Awlaki was targeted directly only because he had an “operational role” in recruiting and training suicide terrorists including the Nigerian would-be “underwear bomber” Umar Farouk Abdulmutallab.

column3: Defiant John Brennan: No recourse except drone strikes to kill suspected terrorists""
column4: The other two were killed in strikes targeting other AQAP leaders.

column3: Defiant John Brennan: No recourse except drone strikes to kill suspected terrorists""
column4: Several Republicans closely questioned Mr. Brennan about leaks to the news media regarding Obama administration national security successes.

column3: Defiant John Brennan: No recourse except drone strikes to kill suspected terrorists""
column4: Mr. Brennan denied that he was the source of any of them.

column3: Defiant John Brennan: No recourse except drone strikes to kill suspected terrorists""
column4: “I never provided classified information to reporters,” Mr. Brennan said.

column3: Defiant John Brennan: No recourse except drone strikes to kill suspected terrorists""
column4: He added that his contacts with the news media were arranged by the White House press office and aimed at explaining administration policy.

column3: Defiant John Brennan: No recourse except drone strikes to kill suspected terrorists""
column4: Sen. Ron Wyden, Oregon Democrat, told the hearing that Congress, and eventually the American public, needed to see the documents outlining the legal basis for the targeted-killing program.

column3: Defiant John Brennan: No recourse except drone strikes to kill suspected terrorists""
column4: “We’ve got to see any and all opinions before the vote” on the nomination, Mr. Wyden said.

column3: Defiant John Brennan: No recourse except drone strikes to kill suspected terrorists""
column4: He also called for the legal opinions to be made public so that Americans could judge for themselves the exact extent of the authority President Obama asserts to kill U.S. citizens without charge or trial if they are senior al Qaeda leaders who cannot be captured.

column3: Defiant John Brennan: No recourse except drone strikes to kill suspected terrorists""
column4: “What it really goes to is the issue of checks and balances,” he said.

column3: Defiant John Brennan: No recourse except drone strikes to kill suspected terrorists""
column4: Mr. King asked Mr. Brennan to allow the judicial branch to oversee targeted killings of U.S. citizens, as it authorized intelligence surveillance against Americans, through the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA) court — a secret tribunal that grants warrants for the electronic and physical surveillance of Americans suspected of espionage or terrorism.

column3: Defiant John Brennan: No recourse except drone strikes to kill suspected terrorists""
column4: “I would like to suggest to you that you consider a FISA court-type process, where an American citizen is going to be targeted for a lethal strike,” Mr. King told Mr. Brennan.

column3: Defiant John Brennan: No recourse except drone strikes to kill suspected terrorists""
column4: “At least that would be some check,” Mr. King said.

column3: Defiant John Brennan: No recourse except drone strikes to kill suspected terrorists""
column4: “I have great confidence in you.

column3: Defiant John Brennan: No recourse except drone strikes to kill suspected terrorists""
column4: I have great confidence in President Obama.

column3: Defiant John Brennan: No recourse except drone strikes to kill suspected terrorists""
column4: But all the lessons of history are, it shouldn’t matter who’s in charge, because we should have procedures and processes in place that will protect us.” Some Republicans asked Mr. Brennan whether the administration’s expanded use of the lethal strikes by remotely piloted drone aircraft grew from its decision to abjure the capture, detention and harsh interrogation techniques employed by the Bush administration.

column3: Defiant John Brennan: No recourse except drone strikes to kill suspected terrorists""
column4: “Is your testimony today that the huge increase in the number of lethal strikes has no connection to the change in the Obama administration’s detention policy?” said Sen. Susan M. Collins, Maine Republican.

column3: Defiant John Brennan: No recourse except drone strikes to kill suspected terrorists""
column4: “Because obviously, if we’re capturing a terrorist, we have the opportunity to interrogate that individual and perhaps learn of ongoing plots.

column3: Defiant John Brennan: No recourse except drone strikes to kill suspected terrorists""
column4: But if the strike is done, that opportunity is lost.” “There’s never been occasion that I’m aware of where we had the opportunity to capture a terrorist and we didn’t and we decided to take a lethal strike,” replied Mr. Brennan.

column3: Defiant John Brennan: No recourse except drone strikes to kill suspected terrorists""
column4: “So certainly there is no correlation there.” He added that the expanding use of drones was in part a result of “the maturation of capabilities and insights into [al Qaeda] plots as a result of the investment that was made in the previous administration.” Other Republicans focused on questioning Mr. Brennan about administration leaks to the media.

column3: Defiant John Brennan: No recourse except drone strikes to kill suspected terrorists""
column4: “I engaged in discussions with reporters about classified issues that they might have had access to because of unfortunate leaks of classified information, and I frequently work with reporters, if not editors of newspapers, to keep out of the public domain some of this country’s most important secrets,” Mr. Brennan said.

column3: Defiant John Brennan: No recourse except drone strikes to kill suspected terrorists""
column4: “Whenever I deal with reporters, I do so at the request of the White House press office and they set the ground rules,” he said.

column3: Defiant John Brennan: No recourse except drone strikes to kill suspected terrorists""
column4: He said that he voluntary cooperated with the Department of Justice investigation into the leak of information about a double agent inside al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) who helped U.S. and allied agencies foil an underwear bomb plot.

column3: Defiant John Brennan: No recourse except drone strikes to kill suspected terrorists""
column4: Mr. Brennan said he had “been interviewed on it” and his office turned over “all relevant materials,” including any notes of the conference call.

column3: Defiant John Brennan: No recourse except drone strikes to kill suspected terrorists""
column4: He denied that a statement he made in a conference call with former officials last year about the plot had compromised intelligence sources and methods.

column3: Defiant John Brennan: No recourse except drone strikes to kill suspected terrorists""
column4: The call had been arranged because the former officials were all going on news programs to discuss the foiling of the plot, which targeted U.S. aviation.

column3: Defiant John Brennan: No recourse except drone strikes to kill suspected terrorists""
column4: Mr. Brennan said, in a statement later repeated publicly by several of the former officials, that the United States had “inside control” of the plot and that the underwear bomb was never a threat to American aviation.

column3: Defiant John Brennan: No recourse except drone strikes to kill suspected terrorists""
column4: Later that day, news agencies broke the story that an a U.S. allied agency had an agent inside the AQAP cell planning the bombing.

column3: Defiant John Brennan: No recourse except drone strikes to kill suspected terrorists""
column4: Mr. Brennan said he needed to explain that the U.S. had “inside control,” because during the time of the plot — around the first anniversary of the Navy SEAL raid on Osama bin Laden’s compound in Pakistan — he and other officials had reassured that there was no specific actionable intelligence about threats or plots.

column3: Defiant John Brennan: No recourse except drone strikes to kill suspected terrorists""
column4: “We had said publicly that there was no active plot at the time of the bin Laden anniversary,” he said.

column3: Defiant John Brennan: No recourse except drone strikes to kill suspected terrorists""
column4: Mr. Brennan is a 25-year career intelligence officer who served in the Bush administration as the first head of the National Counterterrorism Center.

column3: Defiant John Brennan: No recourse except drone strikes to kill suspected terrorists""
column4: In 2008, he was a close adviser to Mr. Obama in the Senate.

column3: 4 takeaways from John Brennan's grilling
column4: Bipartisan agreement isn’t common on Capitol Hill these days, but John Brennan brought senators together at his CIA director confirmation hearing — to express their anger at years of intelligence stonewalling from presidents of both parties.

column3: 4 takeaways from John Brennan's grilling
column4: Twelve years into the war on terror, a largely complacent Congress and its Senate Intelligence Committee finally seemed to have found its voice.

column3: 4 takeaways from John Brennan's grilling
column4: Brennan had the misfortune of being the one on the other side of the table when they did.

column3: 4 takeaways from John Brennan's grilling
column4: Story Continued Below ( PHOTOS: John Brennan’s confirmation hearing) It seemed clear by the end of the session that Brennan had the support to be confirmed, but it was equally clear that senators are so angry with the Obama administration over questions of access to information about drone policies, Benghazi and other topics that the CIA nominee may have to wait for some of the questions to be sorted before being confirmed by the full Senate.

column3: 4 takeaways from John Brennan's grilling
column4: Here’s POLITICO’s top takeaways from Brennan’s grilling: Senators were looking for a piñata For hours, Brennan was battered by senators with long-standing grievances with the CIA or the Obama administration, even though many of the complaints had little or nothing to do with him.

column3: 4 takeaways from John Brennan's grilling
column4: ( Also on POLITICO: Senate pounds Brennan on CIA ‘trust-deficit’) Brennan tried to head off some of the complaints by saying in his opening statement that he’d learned there was a “trust deficit” between the CIA and the Senate.

column3: 4 takeaways from John Brennan's grilling
column4: He called that “wholly unacceptable.” “I like to think that my candor and bluntness will reassure you that you will get straight answers from me, maybe not always the ones you like but you will get answers and they will reflect my honest views,” he said.

column3: 4 takeaways from John Brennan's grilling
column4: Sen. Barbara Mikulski (D-Md.)

column3: 4 takeaways from John Brennan's grilling
column4: made clear that there was a lot of work to do after decades of directors she said misled her or obstructed her requests.

column3: 4 takeaways from John Brennan's grilling
column4: “With the exception of Mr. Panetta, I feel I’ve been jerked around by every CIA director,” Mikulski said, a list that would include not just Bush-era directors like Porter Goss and George Tenet but also perhaps Obama appointee David Petraeus.

column3: 4 takeaways from John Brennan's grilling
column4: If White House officials thought President Barack Obama’s belated decision Wednesday to allow intelligence committees access to classified Justice Department legal memos that justified drone strikes against American terror suspects abroad would appease the committee, that was clearly a miscalculation.

column3: 4 takeaways from John Brennan's grilling
column4: Instead, it seemed to have provoked them.

column3: 4 takeaways from John Brennan's grilling
column4: Senators opened the session with a flurry of complaints.

column3: 4 takeaways from John Brennan's grilling
column4: They challenged Brennan about why senators’ staff couldn’t look at the documents.

column3: 4 takeaways from John Brennan's grilling
column4: “Our staff was banned from seeing it … this is upsetting to a number of members,” an irritated Chairman Dianne Feinstein (D-Calif.) declared.

column3: Congress to See Memo Backing Drone Attacks on Americans
column4: WASHINGTON — The White House on Wednesday directed the Justice Department to release to the two Congressional Intelligence Committees classified documents discussing the legal justification for killing, by drone strikes and other means, American citizens abroad who are considered terrorists.

column3: Congress to See Memo Backing Drone Attacks on Americans
column4: The White House announcement appears to refer to a long, detailed 2010 memo from the Justice Department’s Office of Legal Counsel justifying the killing of Anwar al-Awlaki, an American-born cleric who had joined Al Qaeda in Yemen.

column3: Congress to See Memo Backing Drone Attacks on Americans
column4: He was killed in a C.I.A.

column3: Congress to See Memo Backing Drone Attacks on Americans
column4: drone strike in September 2011.

column3: Congress to See Memo Backing Drone Attacks on Americans
column4: Members of Congress have long demanded access to the legal memorandum.

column3: Congress to See Memo Backing Drone Attacks on Americans
column4: The decision to release the legal memo to the Intelligence Committees came under pressure, two days after a bipartisan group of 11 senators joined a growing chorus asking for more information about the legal justification for targeted killings, especially of Americans.

column3: Congress to See Memo Backing Drone Attacks on Americans
column4: The announcement also came on the eve of the confirmation hearing scheduled for Thursday afternoon for John O. Brennan, President Obama’s choice to be director of the C.I.A., who has been the chief architect of the drone program as Mr. Obama’s counterterrorism adviser.

column3: Congress to See Memo Backing Drone Attacks on Americans
column4: Critics accused Mr. Obama of hypocrisy for keeping the legal opinions on targeted killing secret, noting that in 2009 he had ordered the public release of the classified memos governing C.I.A.

column3: Congress to See Memo Backing Drone Attacks on Americans
column4: interrogations under President George W. Bush.

column3: Congress to See Memo Backing Drone Attacks on Americans
column4: Administration officials replied that the so-called enhanced interrogations had been stopped, while drone strikes continue.

column3: Congress to See Memo Backing Drone Attacks on Americans
column4: Until Wednesday, the administration had refused to even officially acknowledge the existence of the documents, which have been reported about in the press.

column3: Congress to See Memo Backing Drone Attacks on Americans
column4: This week, NBC News obtained an unclassified, shorter “white paper” that detailed some of the legal analysis about killing a citizen and was apparently derived from the classified Awlaki memorandum.

column3: Congress to See Memo Backing Drone Attacks on Americans
column4: The paper said the United States could target a citizen if he was a senior operational leader of Al Qaeda involved in plots against the country and if his capture was not feasible.

column3: Congress to See Memo Backing Drone Attacks on Americans

column3: Skip the drone debate, just kill the terrorists before they kill us
column4: We no longer have to transport ourselves to a magical alternate reality to ponder what a love child between Richard Nixon and Dick Cheney would look like.

column3: Skip the drone debate, just kill the terrorists before they kill us
column4: Given a Justice Department memo obtained by NBC News, we can conclude that child would look like none other than President Barack Obama.

column3: Skip the drone debate, just kill the terrorists before they kill us
column4: David Frost, in his conversation with President Nixon, asked him if the president could do something illegal.

column3: Skip the drone debate, just kill the terrorists before they kill us
column4: Nixon responded, “I'm saying that when the president does it, it's not illegal.” Vice President Cheney, in the War on Terror, took the strong position that citizenship did not necessarily matter when it came to targeting our enemies.

column3: Skip the drone debate, just kill the terrorists before they kill us
column4: Though Senator and presidential candidate Barack Obama was squeamish about such things, President Obama has taken on a very Nixonian-Cheneyesque view of such things.

column3: Skip the drone debate, just kill the terrorists before they kill us
column4: Now, NBC News has uncovered a Justice Department memo making clear what President Obama’s evolved view on terrorists is — kill ‘em regardless of citizenship and do not worry about such small things as constitutional due process.

column3: Skip the drone debate, just kill the terrorists before they kill us
column4: According to the Justice Department memo, if intelligence confirms an American is involved in a terrorist plot as a ranking member of Al Qaeda and extraction of that American is not possible without putting military lives in jeopardy, the United States should have no hesitation in killing him without making an attempt to arrest him and give him his due process.

column3: Skip the drone debate, just kill the terrorists before they kill us
column4: [pullquote] Civil libertarians on the left and right are aghast.

column3: Skip the drone debate, just kill the terrorists before they kill us
column4: Conservatives who long thought the president was softening on his commitment against terrorists have cheered.

column3: Skip the drone debate, just kill the terrorists before they kill us
column4: Roles have been reversed.

column3: Skip the drone debate, just kill the terrorists before they kill us
column4: More importantly, this news exposes partisans who have surrendered intellectual consistency for party cheerleading.

column3: Skip the drone debate, just kill the terrorists before they kill us
column4: Some Republicans who would have been happy with President Bush doing this are now upset.

column3: Skip the drone debate, just kill the terrorists before they kill us
column4: Some Democrats who denounced Bush are now cheering on Barack Obama.

column3: Skip the drone debate, just kill the terrorists before they kill us
column4: Perhaps, they should all pay attention to one key part of the newly uncovered memo.

column3: Skip the drone debate, just kill the terrorists before they kill us
column4: As my friend Moe Lane, writing at RedState.com, noticed, the memo includes this fascinating portion: “…the condition that an operation leader present an “imminent” threat of violent attack against the United States does not require the United States to have clear evidence that a specific attack on U.S. persons and interests will take place in the immediate future.

column3: Skip the drone debate, just kill the terrorists before they kill us
column4: Given the nature of, for example, the terrorist attacks on September 11, in which civilian airliners were hijacked to strike the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, this definition of imminence, which would require the United States to refrain from action until preparations for an attack are concluded, would not allow the United States sufficient time to defend itself.” In other words, there need not be immediacy in the definition of “imminent.”  As long as a plan is in continuation, the United States could proceed.

column3: Skip the drone debate, just kill the terrorists before they kill us
column4: Hypothetically, a world leader — let us call him Saddam — invites Al Qaeda operatives into his country, which we will call Iraq for purposes of this hypothetical, to design and structure terrorist attacks on the United States.

column3: Skip the drone debate, just kill the terrorists before they kill us
column4: While everyone is focusing on drones and American targets, this memo also begins to justify military and intelligence forces going beyond that in order to stop terrorist attacks.

column3: Skip the drone debate, just kill the terrorists before they kill us
column4: This memo gives a foundation for invasion to stop imminent attacks that are not imminent, in the common sense of the word, but are in active planning.

column3: Skip the drone debate, just kill the terrorists before they kill us
column4: The battlefield has shifted over the past two decades.

column3: Skip the drone debate, just kill the terrorists before they kill us
column4: The president has already killed one American on a battlefield with a drone.

column3: Skip the drone debate, just kill the terrorists before they kill us
column4: His chief role is to keep the nation safe.

column3: Skip the drone debate, just kill the terrorists before they kill us
column4: In the twenty-first century, in the remote caves of Afghanistan and deserts of the Middle East, it is both impractical and unnecessary to strap a speaker to a drone in order to shout down to an American Al Qaeda operative, read him his Miranda rights, then caution him to step back a quarter mile to wait for his arrest while the drone unleashes hell on all his terrorist friends.

column3: Skip the drone debate, just kill the terrorists before they kill us
column4: Just kill them before they kill us.

column3: Skip the drone debate, just kill the terrorists before they kill us
column4: At some point, we must trust that the president and his advisers, when they see a gathering of Al Qaeda from the watchful eye of a drone, are going to make the right call and use appropriate restraint and appropriate force to keep us safe.

column3: Skip the drone debate, just kill the terrorists before they kill us
column4: Frankly, it should be American policy that any American collaborating with Al Qaeda is better off dead than alive.

column3: Skip the drone debate, just kill the terrorists before they kill us
column4: Richard Nixon and Dick Cheney should be proud.

column3: Obama Administration Rejected FOIA Before Touting Drone White Paper
column4: WASHINGTON -- The Obama administration rejected a Freedom of Information Act request for the "white paper" outlining the legal justification for the targeted killing of suspected terrorists less than two weeks before a White House spokesman pointed to a leaked version of the memo as evidence the administration was enabling a public discussion about the legal principles behind targeted drone strikes.

column3: Obama Administration Rejected FOIA Before Touting Drone White Paper
column4: The New York Times reports that the Justice Department declined to disclose the white paper in a letter on Jan. 23, telling the newspaper the document was a "draft" and was exempted from FOIA because it was part of the "deliberative process."

column3: Obama Administration Rejected FOIA Before Touting Drone White Paper
column4: But White House spokesman Jay Carney touted the release of the white paper as evidence the administration was enabling a public conversation about the principles behind the government's targeted killing program, stating at one point on Tuesday that the white paper had been "released" rather than leaked.

column3: Obama Administration Rejected FOIA Before Touting Drone White Paper
column4: "The President has made clear, as reflected in the statements by and speeches by senior administration officials, that we need to inform the public and explain to the public and to you the process that we're undertaking and the reasoning behind it," Carney said, according to a White House transcript.

column3: Obama Administration Rejected FOIA Before Touting Drone White Paper
column4: "And the white paper that was provided to some members of Congress -- it is unclassified, it's been released -- is part of that process.

column3: Obama Administration Rejected FOIA Before Touting Drone White Paper
column4: And since it is out there, you should read it.

column3: Obama Administration Rejected FOIA Before Touting Drone White Paper
