column3: Obama ramps up pressure to resolve sequester
column4: Warning of serious repercussions for the economy and the military if Congress fails to halt the next round of $85 billion in budget cuts next month, President Obama on Tuesday called for replacing the automatic spending “sequesters” with a vague mix of smaller cuts and more tax increases.

column3: Obama ramps up pressure to resolve sequester
column4: At a time when many top Republicans have said the cuts should take effect, Mr. Obama’s call renews the battle over spending that has dominated Washington for the past two years, but which seemed to cool after the January deal that raised taxes across the board.

column3: Obama ramps up pressure to resolve sequester
column4: The president said he would like another big tax reform that targets the wealthy, cutting deductions and loopholes, but said at the very least Congress should avert the sequester, which he called an avoidable self-inflicted economic wound.

column3: Obama ramps up pressure to resolve sequester
column4: “If they can’t get a bigger package done by the time the sequester is scheduled to go into effect, then I believe they should at least pass a smaller package,” he said.

column3: Obama ramps up pressure to resolve sequester
column4: “There is no reason that the jobs of thousands of Americans who work in national security or education or clean energy — not to mention the growth of the entire economy — should be put in jeopardy.” His offer is a rehash of proposals he has made to end tax breaks and lower projected increases in health care spending, though the White House has yet to lay out a full list of deductions it wants Congress to target.

column3: Obama ramps up pressure to resolve sequester
column4: Even before Mr. Obama spoke, Republicans were rejecting his offer.

column3: Obama ramps up pressure to resolve sequester
column4: House Speaker John A. Boehner, Ohio Republican, issued a statement saying it was the president who came up with the sequester idea.

column3: Obama ramps up pressure to resolve sequester
column4: He also said House Republicans have passed two bills to avert the sequesters, so Mr. Obama must lay out his own specific plan.

column3: Obama ramps up pressure to resolve sequester
column4: Still smarting from his “fiscal cliff” deal with Democrats in which Republicans agreed to increase taxes without spending cuts, the speaker made it clear that he was ruling out any need to increase taxes further.

column3: Obama ramps up pressure to resolve sequester
column4: “President Obama first proposed the sequester and insisted it become law.

column3: Obama ramps up pressure to resolve sequester
column4: Republicans have twice voted to replace these arbitrary cuts with common-sense cuts and reforms that protect our national defense,” he said.

column3: Obama ramps up pressure to resolve sequester
column4: “We believe there is a better way to reduce the deficit, but Americans do not support sacrificing real spending cuts for more tax hikes.

column3: Obama ramps up pressure to resolve sequester
column4: “The president’s sequester should be replaced with spending cuts and reforms that will start us on the path to balancing the budget in 10 years,” he said.

column3: Obama ramps up pressure to resolve sequester
column4: Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, Kentucky Republican, rebuked Mr. Obama for lecturing Congress about the need to avoid the cuts he proposed.

column3: Obama ramps up pressure to resolve sequester
column4: “If Democrats have ideas for smarter cuts, they should bring them up for debate,” he said.

column3: Obama ramps up pressure to resolve sequester
column4: “But the American people will not support more tax hikes in place of the meaningful spending reductions both parties already agreed to and the president signed into law.” Mr. McConnell also criticized Mr. Obama for failing to submit a budget by the statutory deadline this year.

column3: Obama ramps up pressure to resolve sequester
column4: “The clock is ticking.

column3: Obama ramps up pressure to resolve sequester
column4: It’s time to get serious,” he added.

column3: Obama ramps up pressure to resolve sequester
column4: The White House first came up with the idea of the arbitrary, across-the-board spending cuts during budget talks in summer 2011 as a way to pressure Democrats and Republicans in Congress into coming up with their own spending cut plan to reduce the deficit over the next decade.

column3: Obama ramps up pressure to resolve sequester
column4: But partisan Washington gridlock quickly took hold and a supercommittee of lawmakers tasked with coming up with a plan to find alternative spending cuts to replace the sequester failed to reach a deal after negotiating for months.

column3: Obama ramps up pressure to resolve sequester
column4: As the country braced for the cuts to kick in and Washington to tumble off the fiscal cliff Jan. 1, lawmakers struck a last-minute deal that shifted the first two months of cuts into future spending bills and replaced the rest with an increase in the way retirement accounts are taxed.

column3: Obama ramps up pressure to resolve sequester
column4: Still, the deal postponed another $85 billion in cuts to March 1 — a way to buy more time to find alternative sources of revenue.

column3: Obama ramps up pressure to resolve sequester
column4: The Pentagon in recent weeks has grown increasingly pessimistic about the chances of avoiding the cuts, and the branches of the military have issued memos outlining what programs and sections would be hit hardest.

column3: Obama ramps up pressure to resolve sequester
column4: Washington think tanks and policy centers have warned repeatedly of the havoc that the cuts could wreak on the economy.

column3: Obama ramps up pressure to resolve sequester
column4: The Bipartisan Policy Center has estimated that 1 million jobs could be lost this year and next as a direct result of the spending cuts, and defense industry analysts say that number could rise to 2 million this year alone.

column3: Obama ramps up pressure to resolve sequester
column4: The president made his plea as Senate Democrats were meeting in Annapolis for their annual retreat.

column3: Obama ramps up pressure to resolve sequester
column4: Mr. Obama is scheduled to address the group Wednesday.

column3: Obama Urges Congress to Act to Stave Off Cuts
column4: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Tuesday called on Congress to quickly pass a new package of limited spending cuts and tax increases to head off substantial across-the-board reductions to domestic and military spending set to begin on March 1, but his appeal for more revenue was dismissed by Republicans.

column3: Obama Urges Congress to Act to Stave Off Cuts
column4: Trying to gain the upper hand in the latest fiscal clash, Mr. Obama said Congress should delay the reductions for at least a few months to give lawmakers a chance to negotiate a full deficit reduction package that permanently resolves the threat of a so-called sequester.

column3: Obama Urges Congress to Act to Stave Off Cuts
column4: “They should at least pass a smaller package of spending cuts and tax reforms that would delay the economically damaging effects of the sequester for a few more months,” Mr. Obama said Tuesday afternoon in the White House briefing room.

column3: Obama Urges Congress to Act to Stave Off Cuts
column4: He said there was no reason to put at risk “the jobs of thousands of Americans.” The president said the economy, which unexpectedly contracted at the end of last year, had begun to recover slowly.

column3: Obama Urges Congress to Act to Stave Off Cuts
column4: But he warned that continuing fights over taxes and spending threaten to delay or derail that improvement.

column3: Obama Urges Congress to Act to Stave Off Cuts
column4: “We’ve also seen the effects that political dysfunction can have,” Mr. Obama said.

column3: Obama Urges Congress to Act to Stave Off Cuts
column4: “We’ve made progress.

column3: Obama Urges Congress to Act to Stave Off Cuts
column4: And I still believe we can finish the job with a balanced mix of spending cuts and more tax reform.” Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Republican leader, mocked the president’s demands to close tax loopholes, calling them “gimmicky tax hikes” and said, “It’s time for Washington Democrats to get real.” House Republicans noted that they had already passed their own plans to avoid the sequester.

column3: Obama Urges Congress to Act to Stave Off Cuts
column4: With the deadline looming, each party is eager to blame the other for consequences that could include thousands of layoffs at military contractors, service reductions in programs for the needy and a new economic slump.

column3: Obama Urges Congress to Act to Stave Off Cuts
column4: Mr. Obama, who missed a deadline this week to submit his annual budget to Congress, acknowledged on Tuesday that a broader deficit agreement is unlikely to be reached by the March deadline.

column3: Obama Urges Congress to Act to Stave Off Cuts
column4: He provided no details about the tens of billion of dollars in spending cuts and tax adjustments that he wants Congress to pass quickly.

column3: Obama Urges Congress to Act to Stave Off Cuts
column4: More specifics could come when he delivers his State of the Union address next Tuesday.

column3: Obama Urges Congress to Act to Stave Off Cuts
column4: “While it’s critical for us to cut wasteful spending, we can’t just cut our way to prosperity,” the president said, returning to fiscal issues after several weeks focused on gun control and immigration.

column3: Obama Urges Congress to Act to Stave Off Cuts
column4: “I still believe that we can finish the job with a balanced mix of spending cuts and more tax reform.” Without action in the next three weeks, federal law will set off automatic cuts worth about $1.2 trillion over the next decade.

column3: Obama Urges Congress to Act to Stave Off Cuts
column4: Mr. Obama and Republicans in Congress designed the cuts in 2011 to be devastating as a way to prod passage of a more thoughtful deficit reduction approach, but no agreement has been reached.

column3: Obama Urges Congress to Act to Stave Off Cuts
column4: Mr. Obama spoke as the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Officereleased its annual economic report with the latest 10-year projections for the annual federal budget deficits.

column3: Obama Urges Congress to Act to Stave Off Cuts
column4: It provided some fodder to critics on the left and some economists who say that Washington’s continued emphasis on immediate deficit reduction is constraining economic growth, though the budget office said lower deficits would help the economy starting in 2014.

column3: Obama Urges Congress to Act to Stave Off Cuts
column4: “The federal fiscal policy specified by current law will represent a drag on economic activity” this year and through 2017, the report said.

column3: Obama Urges Congress to Act to Stave Off Cuts
column4: It said that growth in 2013 “would be roughly 1 ½ percentage points faster than the agency now projects if not for the fiscal tightening.” Conservative House Republicans, as a price for their vote to suspend the debt ceiling, last month demanded that their leaders allow the automatic cuts to go into force as scheduled unless alternatives could be found on time.

column3: Obama Urges Congress to Act to Stave Off Cuts
column4: So far, Republican leaders have held firm to that promise even with some Republicans expressing anxiety about the cuts to the Pentagon.

column3: Obama Urges Congress to Act to Stave Off Cuts
column4: House Republicans last year passed two bills that would reduce domestic spending enough to avoid the automatic military cuts, although those bills expired with the last Congress.

column3: Obama Urges Congress to Act to Stave Off Cuts
column4: Speaker John A. Boehner on Tuesday called their proposals “common-sense cuts and reforms” that the president and his Democratic allies in the Senate could immediately accept.

column3: Obama Urges Congress to Act to Stave Off Cuts
column4: Democrats say the cuts favored by House Republicans would unfairly target domestic programs, and Mr. Obama again insisted on Tuesday that any short-term action in the next several weeks must meet his demands for a balanced approach that also closes tax loopholes for wealthy citizens and industries.

column3: Obama Urges Congress to Act to Stave Off Cuts
column4: Democrats in the Senate are divided on how to proceed in the coming fiscal negotiations with Republicans.

column3: Obama Urges Congress to Act to Stave Off Cuts
column4: Like Mr. Obama, Senate Democratic leaders want a three-month replacement bill, just long enough to move the showdown past other budget deadlines like March 27, when the current stopgap law financing the government expires, and April 15, when the Senate and House must produce budgets.

column3: Obama Urges Congress to Act to Stave Off Cuts
column4: Senator Barbara A. Mikulski of Maryland, chairwoman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, favors a yearlong agreement.

column3: Obama Urges Congress to Act to Stave Off Cuts
column4: Senator Carl Levin of Michigan, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, has a broader, $200 billion plan to shut down offshore tax havens and other loopholes.

column3: Obama Urges Congress to Act to Stave Off Cuts
column4: And Senator Max Baucus of Montana, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, wants to defer any action on closing tax loopholes for the broader fight over taxes and spending.

column3: Obama Urges Congress to Act to Stave Off Cuts
column4: “We are not going to have multiple bites at this apple,” Mr. Baucus said Tuesday.

column3: Obama Urges Congress to Act to Stave Off Cuts
column4: The report from the Congressional Budget Office was its first fiscal analysis since the year-end deal between the White House and Congress that raised taxes on high incomes, and it projected that the deficit for this fiscal year that ends Sept. 30 would be $845 billion.

column3: Obama Urges Congress to Act to Stave Off Cuts
column4: That would be the first deficit below $1 trillion in five years, since the financial crisis of 2008.

column3: Obama Urges Congress to Act to Stave Off Cuts
column4: It would be equal to 5.3 percent of the nation’s total output, or gross domestic product — about half of what the deficit was relative to the size of the weaker economy in fiscal year 2009 when Mr. Obama took office, but still higher than the roughly 3 percent level that many economists consider the maximum that is sustainable in a growing economy.

column3: Obama Urges Congress to Act to Stave Off Cuts
column4: While the budget office forecast that annual deficits will decline significantly as the economy recovers, the budget office once again emphasized that the deficit will rise later in the decade, beginning in 2016, and continue do to so as the population ages and health care prices rise.

column3: Obama seeks another short-term fix to looming defense cuts
column4: President Obama is urging another short-term fix to avoid automatic spending cuts set to hit March 1, calling on Congress to come up with an alternative package containing tens of billions of dollars in spending cuts and tax revenue.

column3: Obama seeks another short-term fix to looming defense cuts
column4: Republican leaders, though, quickly raised concern that the president was setting the stage for another round of tax hikes.

column3: Obama seeks another short-term fix to looming defense cuts
column4: "There is no reason that the jobs of thousands of Americans ... not to mention the growth of the entire economy, should be put in jeopardy just because folks in Washington couldn't come together," Obama said Tuesday, during a brief statement at the White House.

column3: Obama seeks another short-term fix to looming defense cuts
column4: The call is the latest effort to kick the can on a deadline set by Congress in the summer of 2011.

column3: Obama seeks another short-term fix to looming defense cuts
column4: As part of the debt-ceiling deal, Congress set in motion more than $1 trillion in defense and other spending cuts unless lawmakers found an alternative that achieved similar deficit reduction.

column3: Obama seeks another short-term fix to looming defense cuts
column4: They didn't.

column3: Obama seeks another short-term fix to looming defense cuts
column4: Lawmakers, as part of the fiscal crisis deal at the end of 2012, delayed the automatic budget cuts for two months.

column3: Obama seeks another short-term fix to looming defense cuts
column4: But with less than a month left until the next deadline, Obama on Tuesday urged Congress -- if they can't enact a bigger package by then -- to draft a short-term package of "spending cuts and tax reforms" that would push off the deadline for a "few more months."

column3: Obama seeks another short-term fix to looming defense cuts
column4: Noting that Congress is currently working on a broader package, Obama said "at the very least we should give them a chance to come up with this budget instead of making indiscriminate cuts now that would cost us jobs and significantly slow down our economy."

column3: Obama seeks another short-term fix to looming defense cuts
column4: The move, though, underscores how little progress has been made toward a comprehensive solution.

column3: Obama seeks another short-term fix to looming defense cuts
column4: It also raised renewed concerns among Republicans that Obama, after winning tax hikes on top earners during the fiscal-crisis talks, would push anew for more tax increases.

column3: Obama seeks another short-term fix to looming defense cuts
column4: "We believe there is a better way to reduce the deficit, but Americans do not support sacrificing real spending cuts for more tax hikes," House Speaker John Boehner said in a statement.

column3: Obama seeks another short-term fix to looming defense cuts
column4: Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell accused Obama of wanting to "delay" the cuts "for a few months with more permanent tax hikes at a time when American families are already feeling the pinch of the Obama economy."

column3: Obama seeks another short-term fix to looming defense cuts
column4: He called on the president to propose "significant spending reforms."

column3: Obama seeks another short-term fix to looming defense cuts
column4: "The clock is ticking.

column3: Obama seeks another short-term fix to looming defense cuts
column4: It's time to get serious," McConnell said.

column3: Obama seeks another short-term fix to looming defense cuts
column4: Obama said in an interview with CBS before the Super Bowl on Sunday that he doesn't think tax rates will need to be raised again.

column3: Obama seeks another short-term fix to looming defense cuts
column4: But he indicated he wants to raise revenue by closing loopholes.

column3: Obama seeks another short-term fix to looming defense cuts
column4: "There is no doubt we need additional revenue, coupled with smart spending reductions, in order to bring down our deficit," he said.

column3: Obama seeks another short-term fix to looming defense cuts
column4: The automatic cuts, if they are allowed to proceed, could require widespread layoffs and indiscriminately affect defense programs and domestic spending accounts.

column3: Obama seeks another short-term fix to looming defense cuts
column4: Obama is asking for a targeted way to reduce the deficit in the short term, perhaps several months.

column3: Obama seeks another short-term fix to looming defense cuts
column4: White House officials said that Congress needs more time to work out a 10-year plan worth more than $1 trillion in deficit reduction.

column3: Obama seeks another short-term fix to looming defense cuts
column4: Obama is not placing a time span or a dollar amount on the short-term plan.

column3: Obama seeks another short-term fix to looming defense cuts
column4: Officials said he will leave that to Congress.

column3: Obama seeks another short-term fix to looming defense cuts
column4: Finding deficit reductions of up to $85 billion would put off the automatic cuts, known as a "sequester" in government budget language, until the start of the new fiscal year.

column3: Obama seeks another short-term fix to looming defense cuts
column4: The White House cited as part of its rationale that the annual budget process in Congress won't even be complete by March 1 -- Obama, though, came under fire Monday for missing the deadline for submitting his own budget proposal for the next fiscal year.

column3: Obama seeks another short-term fix to looming defense cuts
column4: White House officials say the delay will give Congress and the administration time to negotiate a long-term deal through the regular legislative budget process.

column3: Obama seeks another short-term fix to looming defense cuts
column4: The automatic cuts are part of a 10-year, $1 trillion deficit reduction plan that was supposed to spur Congress and the administration to act on long-term fiscal policies that would stabilize the nation's debt.

column3: Obama seeks another short-term fix to looming defense cuts
column4: Though Congress and the White House have agreed on about $2.6 trillion in cuts and higher taxes since the beginning of 2011, they have been unable to close the deal on their goal of reducing deficits by about $4 trillion over a decade.

column3: Obama seeks another short-term fix to looming defense cuts
column4: If the automatic cuts are allowed to kick in, they would reduce Pentagon spending by 7 percent and domestic programs by 5 percent.

column3: Obama seeks another short-term fix to looming defense cuts
column4: Food stamps and Medicaid would be exempt, but Medicare could take up to a 2 percent reduction, under the plan.

column3: Obama seeks another short-term fix to looming defense cuts
column4: The Associated Press contributed to this report.

column3: Talks over immigration reform, guest worker program ramp up in Washington
column4: House Republicans on Tuesday kicked off one of Washington’s most active and intense rounds of debate over the illegal immigration issue, holding a hearing in which witnesses largely appealed to Congress to pass reform legislation to help families and improve the country’s struggling economy.

column3: Talks over immigration reform, guest worker program ramp up in Washington
column4: While some on Capitol Hill are pushing for a comprehensive immigration reform package, several House Republicans homed in Tuesday on a handful of policy changes they argued should take priority -- including improving the visa system for immigrants who graduate from American schools and dealing with illegal immigrants who came to the U.S. as children.

column3: Talks over immigration reform, guest worker program ramp up in Washington
column4: House Republican Leader Eric Cantor, during a policy speech Tuesday at the American Enterprise Institute, called for helping the youngest illegal immigrants while saying the debate must balance “respect for the rule of law and respect for those waiting to enter this country legally.” “A good place to start is with the kids,” the Virginia congressman said.

column3: Talks over immigration reform, guest worker program ramp up in Washington
column4: “One of the great founding principles of our country was that children would not be punished for the mistakes of their parents.” Cantor also said he supports the Senate plan to make border security, employment verification and a workable guest-worker program part of the reform legislation.

column3: Talks over immigration reform, guest worker program ramp up in Washington
column4: Meanwhile, the House Judiciary Committee held a lengthy hearing, marking Congress’ first public debate on the issue since President Obama’s re-election and his second-term pledge to make comprehensive immigration reform a top priority.

column3: Talks over immigration reform, guest worker program ramp up in Washington
column4: “We can save the economy, and immigration is one of the ways to make it happen,” said Vivek Wadhwa, director of research at Duke University’s Pratt School of Engineering, during the hearing.

column3: Talks over immigration reform, guest worker program ramp up in Washington
column4: While the House held its hearing, Obama held separate White House meetings with labor and business leaders to discuss a wide range of issues, including immigration reform and how it fits into the broader economic picture.

column3: Talks over immigration reform, guest worker program ramp up in Washington
column4: “We had a great conversation with the president about immigration,” said Arne Sorenson, president of Marriott International.

column3: Talks over immigration reform, guest worker program ramp up in Washington
column4: “We've got 11 million people in this country who are not sufficiently documented.

column3: Talks over immigration reform, guest worker program ramp up in Washington
column4: They are not going home.

column3: Talks over immigration reform, guest worker program ramp up in Washington
column4: We have got to do what we can quickly to make them contributing members of our economy and our society.

column3: Talks over immigration reform, guest worker program ramp up in Washington
column4: It'll be good for our economy.

column3: Talks over immigration reform, guest worker program ramp up in Washington
column4: … It will be good for their lives.” Among the most high-profile speakers at the House hearing was Julian Castro, the Democratic mayor of San Antonio, Texas.

column3: Talks over immigration reform, guest worker program ramp up in Washington
column4: He urged Congress to help those brought to the United States illegally by their parents and businesses that are helping train highly skilled immigrants, only to see them deported.

column3: Talks over immigration reform, guest worker program ramp up in Washington
column4: “The reforms that you have on the table are … pro-family and pro-business,” Castro testified.

column3: Talks over immigration reform, guest worker program ramp up in Washington
column4: “Every year as competition increases, American companies throw up their hands, watch those trained in American universities leave in frustration.” He also said visa laws that separate husbands and wives for years are “outdated” and “make no sense.” While Obama and other Democrats have called for expedient and comprehensive reform, Republicans on Tuesday cautioned against passing legislation without a thorough debate.

column3: Talks over immigration reform, guest worker program ramp up in Washington
column4: “We all agree that our nation’s immigration system is in desperate need of repair,” said committee Chairman Bob Goodlatte, R-Va. “But before we rush to judgment, we need to carefully look at the current laws on the books to see what is and isn’t working.

column3: Talks over immigration reform, guest worker program ramp up in Washington
column4: Reforming our nation’s immigration laws is a massive undertaking and is too important to not examine each piece in detail.” His comments were followed those of Alabama Republican Rep. Spencer Bachus, who suggested passing separate legislation, instead of one comprehensive bill, that would first deal with getting high-skilled people working legally in this country.

column3: Talks over immigration reform, guest worker program ramp up in Washington
column4: “It’s going to be a much easier lift to solve the problem of high-skilled workers,” said Bachus, a subcommittee chairman.

column3: Talks over immigration reform, guest worker program ramp up in Washington
column4: “We could pass a bill that would take that off the table.

column3: Talks over immigration reform, guest worker program ramp up in Washington
column4: When you take compressive, full citizenship, that’s a more toxic contentious issue.

column3: Talks over immigration reform, guest worker program ramp up in Washington
column4: ... Let’s not let the more contentious issue prevent us from this year, this month, passing something to address what is a horrible situation -- training people to go back to their countries and compete against us.” At the same time, House Speaker John Boehner told reporters he was pleased with the bipartisan Senate effort on immigration, but the reform effort is “not a race.

column3: Talks over immigration reform, guest worker program ramp up in Washington
column4: It's about trying to get it right.” While the president and Senate panel each appear to want legislation that includes a path to citizenship, the congressional plan is more closely tied to tightening border security.

column3: Talks over immigration reform, guest worker program ramp up in Washington
column4: California Republican Rep. Darrell Issa complained Tuesday that the president’s plan  calls for a path to citizenship without first securing borders.

column3: Talks over immigration reform, guest worker program ramp up in Washington
column4: “The president’s trying to go to the left of a bipartisan Senate deal,” he said.

column3: Talks over immigration reform, guest worker program ramp up in Washington
column4: “And I think Republicans in the House are trying to figure what we can do on a bipartisan basis, or a partisan basis if necessary, that will help fix this problem, help people who want to be here and who can add to our economy.” Meanwhile, New York Democratic Sen. Chuck Schumer has asked the U.S. Chamber of Commerce and the AFL-CIO to promptly reach an agreement on immigration that he and other members of the bipartisan Senate group can incorporate into their legislation.

column3: Talks over immigration reform, guest worker program ramp up in Washington
column4: The possibility of a guest-worker program has traditionally divided labor and business.

column3: Talks over immigration reform, guest worker program ramp up in Washington
column4: Labor groups have looked askance on bringing in numerous low-wage workers, while that's an outcome businesses have favored.

column3: Talks over immigration reform, guest worker program ramp up in Washington
column4: Both sides appear hopeful, although Schumer and others say the issue scuttled the last attempt at a comprehensive overhaul of immigration law in 2007.

column3: Talks over immigration reform, guest worker program ramp up in Washington
column4: This time around, officials involved hope for a better result, in part because all involved see the clear necessity of addressing what's called "future flow" -- the influx of migrants to the U.S. that's sure to come whether or not Congress passes an immigration bill.

column3: Talks over immigration reform, guest worker program ramp up in Washington
column4: While Congress acts to provide a pathway to citizenship for the estimated 11 million illegal immigrants already in this country, it's just as important to deal with future immigration, advocates say.

column3: Talks over immigration reform, guest worker program ramp up in Washington
column4: Otherwise, some time from now the country will once again find itself home to many more illegal immigrants.

column3: Talks over immigration reform, guest worker program ramp up in Washington
column4: "We're at a point where we have to take that issue really seriously and think about what kind of a system do we want to have in place so that 10 years from now, 15 years from now, we're not in the same situation," said Ana Avendano, assistant to the AFL-CIO president for immigration and community action.

column3: Talks over immigration reform, guest worker program ramp up in Washington
column4: The Chamber of Commerce "views the existence of a temporary worker program as vital to a comprehensive immigration bill," spokeswoman Blair Latoff Holmes said in a statement.

column3: Talks over immigration reform, guest worker program ramp up in Washington
column4: The U.S. does have several temporary worker programs already, but they're viewed as cumbersome and outdated, and experts say the majority of migrant workers in agricultural and other low-skill fields like landscaping or housekeeping are illegal.

column3: Talks over immigration reform, guest worker program ramp up in Washington
column4: For business and labor, the question is how to come to an agreement on how many workers to let in and under what circumstances, how much they would be paid, and whether and how they would be able to attain eventual permanent residency, the critical step toward citizenship.

column3: Talks over immigration reform, guest worker program ramp up in Washington
column4: "Few aspects of immigration law are so divisive in terms of where the two sides stand," said Demetrios Papademetriou, head of the nonpartisan Migration Policy Institute.

column3: Talks over immigration reform, guest worker program ramp up in Washington
column4: The Associated Press contributed to this report.

column3: Lindsey Graham goes all-in on immigration
column4: A red-state Republican senator up for reelection and seen as vulnerable to a primary challenge from the right embraces a plan to allow illegal immigrants to gain U.S. citizenship — a lightning rod for GOP primary voters if there ever was one.

column3: Lindsey Graham goes all-in on immigration
column4: Seems unthinkable on its face.

column3: Lindsey Graham goes all-in on immigration
column4: Yet that’s precisely what Lindsey Graham did last week.

column3: Lindsey Graham goes all-in on immigration
column4: And the remarkable thing is, there’s no sign of a backlash in his home state, South Carolina — at least not yet.

column3: Lindsey Graham goes all-in on immigration
column4: Story Continued Below ( PHOTOS: Pols react to immigration deal) It’s a reflection of both Graham’s political strength and his party’s rapid evolution on immigration since its November licking among Latinos.

column3: Lindsey Graham goes all-in on immigration
column4: Long viewed with suspicion among the right wing — in no small part because of his 2007 endorsement of the Kennedy-McCain immigration reform bill — Graham apparently feels safe enough heading into 2014 to stick his neck out again on a politically perilous debate he obviously cares about deeply.

column3: Lindsey Graham goes all-in on immigration
column4: ( Also on POLITICO: Graham: 'Hillary Clinton got away with murder') The two-term senator is also convinced the dynamic has changed since 2007.

column3: Lindsey Graham goes all-in on immigration
column4: Immediately after the November election, Graham called Sen. Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) and told him he wanted to try to cut a sweeping bipartisan deal on the issue, which few Republicans have wanted to touch in recent years.

column3: Lindsey Graham goes all-in on immigration
column4: Back then, Graham was booed at town halls for supporting reform pushed by President George W. Bush.

column3: Lindsey Graham goes all-in on immigration
column4: County parties censured him.

column3: Lindsey Graham goes all-in on immigration
column4: Rush Limbaugh described his proposal as “Grahamnesty.” “There are going to be people who are upset, I understand that,” Graham told POLITICO last week.

column3: Lindsey Graham goes all-in on immigration
column4: “I do believe that people in the Republican Party are beginning to understand the politics of immigration.

column3: Lindsey Graham goes all-in on immigration
column4: But people do want the borders secured; they want to get this issue behind us; and I think I’m in a good spot to go back home and tell people that now is the time to get this done.” ( PHOTOS: At a glance: The Senate immigration deal) Florida Sen. Marco Rubio, a member, along with Graham, of the Gang of Eight, provides the South Carolina senator some cover on his right flank.

column3: Lindsey Graham goes all-in on immigration
column4: And the 2012 electoral thumping that the GOP took, driven partly by Mitt Romney’s 27 percent showing with Hispanics, has prompted many Republicans to rethink the party’s opposition to a comprehensive overhaul.

column3: Lindsey Graham goes all-in on immigration
column4: One of them is Randy Page, chairman of the GOP committee in South Carolina’s 2nd Congressional District.

column3: Lindsey Graham goes all-in on immigration
column4: He voted last summer to include tough language in the GOP national platform as South Carolina’s representative on the committee that drafted its contents.

column3: Lindsey Graham goes all-in on immigration
column4: “A number of us, myself included, have looked at the message that the Republican Party has been sending and looking at the message that the Hispanic community sent us in November, and we’ve started to listen to what Sen. Rubio and Sen. Graham have been saying,” he said.

column3: Lindsey Graham goes all-in on immigration
column4: “Looking specifically at Hispanics, most of them support us on other issues — whether social issues or fiscal issues,” he added.

column3: Lindsey Graham goes all-in on immigration
column4: “They’re saying, ‘We agree with you on life and school choice and so many other things,’ but yet we’re saying, ‘You’re not welcome.

column3: Lindsey Graham goes all-in on immigration
column4: And we want you to go back and self-deport yourself’?

column3: Lindsey Graham goes all-in on immigration
column4: That’s the wrong rhetoric, and it’s, frankly, the wrong solution.” What’s happening in South Carolina mirrors what’s happened among conservative thought leaders nationally.

column3: Lindsey Graham goes all-in on immigration
column4: Television host Sean Hannity, columnist Charles Krauthammer and others have announced changes in heart on immigration reform since the election.

column3: Change of strategy for immigration: Reform bill faces full gantlet in the Senate
column4: Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid’s vow last week to put the immigration bill through the regular Senate process of committee hearings and floor amendments may sound inconsequential, but it marks a major shift for the Nevada Democrat.

column3: Change of strategy for immigration: Reform bill faces full gantlet in the Senate
column4: In 2007, the last time the chamber took up immigration, Mr. Reid twice tried to shoehorn a bill through the chamber under tightly controlled rules that locked out most debate.

column3: Change of strategy for immigration: Reform bill faces full gantlet in the Senate
column4: He was rebuffed both times, and the measure ultimately imploded under the weight of a bipartisan filibuster.

column3: Change of strategy for immigration: Reform bill faces full gantlet in the Senate
column4: “I look back in retrospect and say it was a mistake not to go through the committee process last time,” Sen. Charles E. Schumer, one of Mr. Reid’s top lieutenants, told reporters.

column3: Change of strategy for immigration: Reform bill faces full gantlet in the Senate
column4: One week after a bipartisan group of eight senators announced that they had settled on a framework for an immigration bill, the issue has all but consumed Washington.

column3: Change of strategy for immigration: Reform bill faces full gantlet in the Senate
column4: President Obama traveled to Las Vegas to give a speech blessing the framework and, most notably, did not draw any lines in the sand, which gives lawmakers some room to negotiate.

column3: Change of strategy for immigration: Reform bill faces full gantlet in the Senate
column4: Instead, Mr. Obama is putting his effort into one of his strengths by giving interviews to Spanish-language networks to try to drum up support.

column3: Change of strategy for immigration: Reform bill faces full gantlet in the Senate
column4: Creating consensus On Capitol Hill, though, the first cracks have started to show in the gang over issues such as how to handle gay partners in the legal-immigration system, and how to decide when the border is secure enough to give illegal immigrants green cards, which is the key step on the path to citizenship.

column3: Change of strategy for immigration: Reform bill faces full gantlet in the Senate
column4: Mr. Reid said that is part of the reason he will send the bill through the regular legislative order of committee work and full floor amendments.

column3: Change of strategy for immigration: Reform bill faces full gantlet in the Senate
column4: In 2007, Mr. Reid kept a much tighter leash on the debate.

column3: Change of strategy for immigration: Reform bill faces full gantlet in the Senate
column4: Each time, he was met with a bipartisan filibuster from senators angered at the legislation itself and at the process being used.

column3: Change of strategy for immigration: Reform bill faces full gantlet in the Senate
column4: This time, the Nevada Democrat wants to eliminate that procedural excuse.

column3: Change of strategy for immigration: Reform bill faces full gantlet in the Senate
column4: “Once it gets to the floor, I have made a commitment — and I’m telling everyone here — we’re going to have an amendment process.

column3: Change of strategy for immigration: Reform bill faces full gantlet in the Senate
column4: I don’t know how long it will take, but we’ll take a lot of time, because there will be a lot of important issues brought up,” Mr. Reid told reporters.

column3: Change of strategy for immigration: Reform bill faces full gantlet in the Senate
column4: “We may have to have a number of votes on different amendments in a different number of procedural ways, but we’re going to have legislation done in the Senate the way that it’s supposed to be done.” Backing the move An open process was welcomed by those who have been waiting for a bill to pass.

column3: Change of strategy for immigration: Reform bill faces full gantlet in the Senate
column4: “It’s a good sign, and it hardly ever happens these days,” said Frank Sharry, executive director at America’s Voice, an advocacy group.

column3: Change of strategy for immigration: Reform bill faces full gantlet in the Senate
column4: “This is going to be wild and wide open legislating.

column3: Change of strategy for immigration: Reform bill faces full gantlet in the Senate
column4: Bring your six-shooter and a lot of bullets, because this thing is going to be crazy.” More than any other bill in recent years, the immigration debate will be colored by the previous fight in 2007.

column3: Change of strategy for immigration: Reform bill faces full gantlet in the Senate
column4: Back then, the bill was another grand bargain struck by what Sen. Jeff Sessions, Alabama Republican and ardent opponent, called “the Masters of the Universe.” Led by Sen. Jon Kyl, Arizona Republican, and Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, Massachusetts Democrat, they tried to fend off all amendments to preserve the core agreement of stiffer border security and a new legal-immigration system in exchange for legalization of illegal immigrants.

column3: Change of strategy for immigration: Reform bill faces full gantlet in the Senate
column4: Mr. Kyl retired last year, and Kennedy passed away, leaving matters to Sens.

column3: Change of strategy for immigration: Reform bill faces full gantlet in the Senate
column4: John McCain, Marco Rubio, Lindsey Graham and Jeff Flake (who won Mr. Kyl’s seat) from the GOP, and Mr. Schumer, joined by Sens.

column3: Change of strategy for immigration: Reform bill faces full gantlet in the Senate
column4: Richard J. Durbin, Robert Menendez and Michael F. Bennet on the Democratic side.

column3: Change of strategy for immigration: Reform bill faces full gantlet in the Senate
column4: History’s lessons The 2007 bill had just enough for everyone to dislike, which helped prompt the bipartisan filibuster that blocked it.

column3: Change of strategy for immigration: Reform bill faces full gantlet in the Senate
column4: It’s unclear what this year’s bill will look like because the “Gang of Eight” has produced only a five-page framework.

column3: Change of strategy for immigration: Reform bill faces full gantlet in the Senate
column4: One key question is whether the Gang of Eight will feel obliged to stand together in defending its grand bargain against all amendments, or whether the lawmakers instead will be free to vote their consciences.

column3: Change of strategy for immigration: Reform bill faces full gantlet in the Senate
column4: The last time, defending the bargain led to striking votes in which Mr. Kennedy, a labor union defender, voted against labor’s wishes, and in which Mr. Kyl voted against stiffer enforcement provisions.

column3: Change of strategy for immigration: Reform bill faces full gantlet in the Senate
column4: Mr. Sharry said he expects Mr.

column3: Change of strategy for immigration: Reform bill faces full gantlet in the Senate
column4: Sessions, who informally led the opposition in 2007, to try to offer some of those same enforcement amendments to try to divide supporters of the bill.

column3: Change of strategy for immigration: Reform bill faces full gantlet in the Senate
column4: Indeed, a Republican Senate aide told The Washington Times that the Republicans will home in on security and enforcement amendments and said the bill “faces an uphill climb.” One of the groups that rallied voters to make phone calls, shutting down the Senate switchboard, has panned the latest effort.

column3: President Obama taking gun violence plan on the road
column4: President Obama took his first trip outside Washington on Monday to promote his far-reaching plan to curb the nation’s gun violence, meeting with law enforcement leaders in Minneapolis, which has dramatically reduced gun violence in recent years.

column3: President Obama taking gun violence plan on the road
column4: Obama visited the Minneapolis Police Department’s Special Operations Center, where he delivered remarks about what the White House calls his “comprehensive set of common-sense ideas to reduce gun violence.” "Universal background checks are almost universally supported," Obama said, "by gun owners."

column3: President Obama taking gun violence plan on the road
column4: He asked people in the audience to keep pressure up on their representatives in Congress to do something about gun violence.

column3: President Obama taking gun violence plan on the road
column4: "Tell them now is the time for action.

column3: President Obama taking gun violence plan on the road
column4: That we're not going to wait until the next Newtown.

column3: President Obama taking gun violence plan on the road
column4: The next Aurora."

column3: President Obama taking gun violence plan on the road
column4: The president also met with the area’s elected leaders to highlight Minneapolis, a city that the White House says already has taken “important steps to reduce gun violence and foster a conversation in the community about what further action is needed.” Obama has proposed universal background checks for all gun buyers, which is considered the most likely of his legislative proposals to win bipartisan support in Congress.

column3: President Obama taking gun violence plan on the road
column4: He also has called for stricter laws against gun trafficking, and press secretary Jay Carney said Monday that Obama remains committed to a ban on assault weapons, although the ban is considered the most difficult to pass.

column3: President Obama taking gun violence plan on the road
column4: Minneapolis, once known as “Murder-apolis,” has made significant progress over the past few years in reducing gun violence after its homicide rate rivaled New York City’s in the 1990s, during the crack and gang wars, according to a report in USA Today.

column3: President Obama taking gun violence plan on the road
column4: Last week, Obama met at the White House with law enforcement leaders from around the country -- including Minneapolis Police Chief Janeé Harteau and Hennepin County (Minn.) Sheriff Richard Stanek -- to urge them to help him build support in Congress to pass his proposals to toughen gun laws.

column3: President Obama taking gun violence plan on the road
column4: The president told the law enforcement leaders that they are “where the rubber hits the road” and represent the most important group in the contentious debate over gun laws.

column3: President Obama taking gun violence plan on the road
column4: “Hopefully, if law enforcement officials who are dealing with this stuff every single day can come to some consensus in terms of steps that we need to take, Congress is going to be paying attention to them, and we’ll be able to make progress,” Obama said at last week’s meeting.

column3: First stop: Democrat-leaning Minnesota, for gun-control campaign
column4: President Obama is taking his gun-control message on the road, with a planned first stop in Democrat-leading Minnesota, at the Minneapolis Police Department’s Special Operations Center, according to media reports.

column3: First stop: Democrat-leaning Minnesota, for gun-control campaign
column4: There, Mr. Obama is expected to call for a ban on assault weapons and a mandate for national background checks on all gun buyers, Newsmax reports.

column3: First stop: Democrat-leaning Minnesota, for gun-control campaign
column4: This is the first stop on a planned national public relations campaign for Congress to enact more gun control laws, Newsmax said.

column3: First stop: Democrat-leaning Minnesota, for gun-control campaign
column4: Minnesota officials have been seeking ways to tighten gun laws for years, Newsmax reported.

column3: Senate approves bill to suspend debt limit, sends to Obama
column4: WASHINGTON –  Congress passed must-do legislation Thursday to permit the government to borrow hundreds of billions of dollars more to meet its obligations, averting a first-ever government default that had loomed as early as mid-February.

column3: Senate approves bill to suspend debt limit, sends to Obama
column4: The 64-34 vote in the Democratic-controlled Senate sent the measure to President Obama, who has said he will sign it.

column3: Senate approves bill to suspend debt limit, sends to Obama
column4: The Republican-led House passed the legislation last week.

column3: Senate approves bill to suspend debt limit, sends to Obama
column4: The legislation would temporarily suspend the $16.4 trillion limit on federal borrowing, which experts say would allow the government to borrow about $450 billion to meet interest payments and obligations like Social Security benefits and government salaries.

column3: Senate approves bill to suspend debt limit, sends to Obama
column4: The deadline for Congress to act again to prevent default would likely not come until August, according to calculations by the Bipartisan Policy Center, a Washington-based think tank.

column3: Senate approves bill to suspend debt limit, sends to Obama
column4: Without the bill, the Treasury Department says, the government would default on its obligations by as early as mid-February.

column3: Senate approves bill to suspend debt limit, sends to Obama
column4: "Failure to pass this bill will set off an unpredictable financial panic that would plunge not only the United States, but much of the world, back into recession," said Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont.

column3: Senate approves bill to suspend debt limit, sends to Obama
column4: Those cuts -- postponed by the recent "fiscal cliff" deal -- are the punishment for the failure of a 2011 deficit supercommittee to reach an agreement.

column3: Senate approves bill to suspend debt limit, sends to Obama
column4: The panel was itself established by the hard-fought 2011 increase in the debt limit.

column3: Senate approves bill to suspend debt limit, sends to Obama

column3: Senate approves bill to suspend debt limit, sends to Obama
column4: Senate Republicans offered several amendments, but all failed on party-line votes.

column3: Senate approves bill to suspend debt limit, sends to Obama
column4: Any amendments to the bill would have required the House to vote again.

column4: Sen.

column3: Senate approves bill to suspend debt limit, sends to Obama
column4: Rob Portman, R-Ohio, sought to require that any immediate increase in the debt limit be paired with commensurate cuts to spending, which could be spread out over 10 years.

column3: Senate approves bill to suspend debt limit, sends to Obama

column3: Senate approves bill to suspend debt limit, sends to Obama
column4: That was a slap at the Democratic-controlled Senate, which hasn't passed a budget blueprint since 2009.

column3: Senate approves bill to suspend debt limit, sends to Obama

column3: Senate approves bill to suspend debt limit, sends to Obama
column4: For starters, it made members of the minority party dependent on the ability of the majority party to advance a budget if they all were to be paid.

column3: Senate approves bill to suspend debt limit, sends to Obama

column3: Senate approves bill to suspend debt limit, sends to Obama
column4: Lawmakers have already shifted their focus to the across-the-board cuts, which would pare $85 billion from this year's budget after being delayed from Jan. 1 until March 1 and reduced by $24 billion by the recently enacted tax bill.

column4: Defense hawks are particularly upset, saying the Pentagon cuts would devastate military readiness and cause havoc in defense contracting.
