column3: Fiscal fights ding economy
column4: Updated 01/30/2013 04:05 PM EST No one is predicting a "double-dip recession" yet — but Wednesday's negative-growth GDP reading put to rest the question of whether Washington’s budget wars can damage the economy.

column3: Fiscal fights ding economy
column4: They just did.

column3: Fiscal fights ding economy
column4: Story Continued Below And with two major fiscal fights looming early this year, it's got policymakers worried there could be more grim news on the horizon for an economy already barely pulling itself out of the doldrums.

column3: Fiscal fights ding economy
column4: ( Also on POLITICO: Obama's GDP nightmare) On its face, the 0.1 percent fourth quarter GDP contraction — the first negative growth since the middle of 2009 — announced by the Commerce Department drew mixed reactions from economists, many of whom saw positive news beneath the headlines, so long as Washington doesn’t keep getting in the way.

column3: Fiscal fights ding economy
column4: Analysts had expected GDP growth to be 1 percent to 1.2 percent.

column3: Fiscal fights ding economy
column4: Still, investors appeared to shrug off the GDP number, as the Dow Jones Industrial Average was down slightly in morning trading.

column3: Fiscal fights ding economy
column4: While federal, state and local government spending, private inventory investment and exports were down, personal spending was up by 2.2 percent, more than its 1.6 percent increase in the third quarter.

column3: Fiscal fights ding economy
column4: Nonresidential fixed investments also increased 8.4 percent, reversing a decline in the previous quarter.

column3: Fiscal fights ding economy
column4: But the fourth quarter ended just as lawmakers and the White House were battling over the fiscal cliff.

column3: Fiscal fights ding economy
column4: And Congress and the White House are now wrangling over what to do with a round of spending cuts, including major curbs on Pentagon spending, set to take place on March 1 — and a possible government shutdown in late March — that some economists have warned could further slow economic growth.

column3: Fiscal fights ding economy
column4: ( Also on POLITICO: Krugman: U.S. has 'running room') Noting that “federal defense spending declined precipitously, likely due to uncertainty stemming from the sequester,” Alan B. Krueger, chairman of the White House’s Council of Economic Advisers, downplayed the report in a blog post.

column3: Fiscal fights ding economy
column4: Instead, he said that “today’s report is a reminder of the importance of the need for Congress to act to avoid self-inflicted wounds to the economy.

column3: Fiscal fights ding economy
column4: The administration continues to urge Congress to move toward a sustainable federal budget in a responsible way that balances revenue and spending, and replaces the sequester, while making critical investments in the economy that promote growth and job creation and protect our most vulnerable citizens.” Nonetheless, the number comes at an inopportune time for the White House as it tries to move beyond fights with Republicans over the economy and focus on new policy pushes on immigration reform and gun control.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: Influential figures on both sides of the gun control debate tangled Wednesday over the effectiveness of background checks, with the husband of wounded former Rep. Gabrielle Giffords urging an overhaul and a top National Rifle Association official saying "homicidal maniacs" will skirt the system no matter what.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: NRA Executive Vice President Wayne LaPierre was the final witness to testify before the Senate Judiciary Committee as the panel begins to consider new legislation.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: He argued that more security and more enforcement, but not new laws, is the answer to gun violence.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: He specifically knocked down a call by President Obama and others for "universal" background checks, particularly at gun shows.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: "When it comes to background checks, let's be honest -- background checks will never be universal because criminals will never submit to them," LaPierre said.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: But Giffords' husband Mark Kelly argued that improving the background check system should be a priority.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: He said holes in the law "make a mockery" of the system -- echoing Obama's recent proposal, he called for submitting private sales to background checks as well.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: He further argued that stronger background checks could have prevented the mass shooting in January 2011 where his wife was shot in the head.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: LaPierre later got into an argument over the issue with Sen. Dick Durbin, D-Ill., after LaPierre argued that more background checks would merely subject "law-abiding people" to more taxes and fees and hassle without going after "bad guys."

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: "Mr. LaPierre that's the point," Durbin said.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: "The criminals won't get to purchase the guns because there'll be a background check.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: We'll stop them from the original purchase -- you missed that point completely.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: I think it's basic."

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: Raising his voice, LaPierre said: "Senator, I think you missed the point!"

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: Chairman Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., then banged the gavel and called for order.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: The disagreement was one of several sticking points as the Senate Judiciary Committee held the first gun control hearing since Obama released a comprehensive gun control plan earlier this month.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: LaPierre pressed for enforcing existing laws over creating new ones.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: "Prosecuting criminals who misuse firearms works," LaPierre testified.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: "Unfortunately, we've seen a dramatic collapse in federal gun prosecutions in recent years."

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: He continued: "Proposing more gun control laws, while failing to enforce the thousands we already have -- it's not a serious solution for reducing crime."

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: The panel was stacked with high-profile witnesses on both sides of the debate.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: Giffords, who was shot while meeting with constituents outside an Arizona supermarket in January 2011, made a surprise appearance at the start of the hearing Wednesday morning to urge Congress to act.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: "We must do something," Giffords said, speaking slowly but clearly.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: "It will be hard, but the time is now.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: ... You must act."

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: Giffords urged lawmakers to "be bold, be courageous."

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: She later met with President Obama at the White House.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: "Violence is a big problem.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: Too many children are dying," the former congresswoman said.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: Six people were killed, and 12 were wounded, in the Arizona attack.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: The fatal shooting at an elementary school in Newtown, Conn., last month brought the issue of gun control back to the fore of the congressional agenda.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: Kelly, speaking after his wife, called for a "careful and civil conversation" about limitations on firearms.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: He noted that he and Giffords own guns, but are "anti-gun violence."

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: He said a "matrix" of failures contributes to the country's gun violence problem, including mental illness and poverty, but also gun laws.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: He said the complexity is "not an excuse for inaction."

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: Kelly said weapons designed to inflict maximum damage have turned corners of America "into places of carnage and gross human loss."

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: Kelly briefly described how the 2011 shooting affected his family, leaving his wife partially blind and struggling to walk.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: Kelly and Giffords have formed a political action committee called Americans for Responsible Solutions to back lawmakers who support tighter gun restrictions and counter the influence of the NRA.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: LaPierre, though, argued that prosecution for federal weapons violations in 2011 was essentially down 35 percent, compared to previous administrations, which he says means violent felons, gang members and the mentally ill who possess firearms are not being prosecuted.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: "That is completely and totally unacceptable," said LaPierre, who suggested fixing the country's "broken" mental-health system become part of the solution to gun violence -- including making patient records part of the National Instant Criminal Background Check System.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: The hearing, titled "What Should America Do about Gun Violence," takes place roughly seven weeks after a lone gunman with psychological problems used an assault weapon to kill 20 first-graders and six adults inside a Connecticut elementary school, prompting renewed calls for more gun control.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: The NRA, with 4.5 million active members, remains the most powerful gun-rights advocacy group in the country.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: Obama is calling for a renewed ban on semi-automatic weapons and high-capacity magazines, along with more extensive background checks.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: LaPierre said the group is willing to work with Congress and the president in curbing gun violence, but "law-abiding gun owners will not accept blame for the acts of violent or deranged criminals.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: Nor do we believe the government should dictate what we can lawfully own and use to protect our families."

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: Under questioning from Sen. Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y., Baltimore County Police Chief James Johnson said Wednesday that the current background check system has already stopped nearly 2 million "prohibited purchases" between 1994 and 2009.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: Sen. Dianne Feinstein, D-Calif., has already introduced legislation taking similar steps to Obama's proposals.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: The California Democrat on Tuesday said she will hold her own hearing on gun control because she was unhappy that three of the five witnesses testifying Wednesday are "skewed against us."

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: Feinstein is a member of the Judiciary Committee.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: Despite the momentum gun control advocates have gained since the massacre in Newtown, Conn, it will be difficult for them to prevail in Congress this year because of the popularity of guns in many states -- including several represented by Democratic senators -- and the formidable muscle of the NRA on Capitol Hill, lawmakers and others say.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: Among other obstacles, the Republican-run House has shown little immediate interest in making dramatic changes in the laws.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: At the Senate hearing, Leahy, D-Vt., said lawmakers were not trying to take away Americans' guns.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: "They're not at risk.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: ... what is at risk are lives," he said.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: The committee's top Republican, Sen. Charles Grassley, said he welcomed the "renewed discussion" on gun violence.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: But he voiced skepticism about a renewed ban on assault weapons and high-capacity magazines.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: "Those can be circumvented by carrying multiple guns," Grassley said.

column3: NRA's LaPierre to tell Congress more gun laws 'not a serious solution'
column4: The Associated Press contributed to this report.

column3: Congress Takes Up Gun Violence
column4: Senate hearings on stronger gun controls are scheduled to begin on Wednesday before a divided Congress and a nation agonizing over how to prevent more of the carnage that killed 20 schoolchildren and six adults last month at a Newtown, Conn., elementary school.

column3: Congress Takes Up Gun Violence
column4: The gun lobby’s opposition to reasonable controls is already fierce, and political courage is, as ever, wavering in Congress.

column3: Congress Takes Up Gun Violence
column4: But this singular opportunity to curb the gun violence must not be wasted in more of the posturing in Washington that tolerates 30,000 gun deaths a year.

column3: Congress Takes Up Gun Violence
column4: The Senate Judiciary Committee is scheduled to hear a raft of proposals, including a vitally needed ban on fast-firing semiautomatic weapons, like the military-style Bushmaster assault rifle the Newtown gunman used in his killing spree at Sandy Hook Elementary School.

column3: Congress Takes Up Gun Violence
column4: The measure would also ban ammunition magazines that can hold more than 10 bullets, which have facilitated battlefield-scale killing of the innocent in the Newtown school, the movie theater in Aurora, Colo., and dozens of similar tragedies.

column3: Congress Takes Up Gun Violence
column4: Making federal background checks universal, instead of limiting them to sales by licensed gun dealers, is no less vital, closing a loophole that lets 40 percent of firearm sales take place with no oversight.

column3: Congress Takes Up Gun Violence
column4: This proposal is the chief goal of many gun-control groups and has a different aim than the assault weapons ban: the proliferation of handguns that are used in most gun violence, particularly in cities.

column3: Congress Takes Up Gun Violence
column4: Another measure would create a separate criminal offense for gun trafficking and toughen penalties on those involved, including the “straw buyers” who purchase weapons later funneled into criminal hands.

column3: Congress Takes Up Gun Violence
column4: This should be accompanied by tighter restrictions on high-risk gun dealers who sell a disproportionate number of the guns traced to crimes, as well as new resources for more frequent inspection of all gun stores.

column3: Congress Takes Up Gun Violence
column4: Congressional corridors and committee evasions are not the way to advance these bills.

column3: Congress Takes Up Gun Violence
column4: They should be debated and voted on in public view so each lawmaker can be tallied on these major issues.

column3: Congress Takes Up Gun Violence
column4: The Second Amendment is nowhere at stake.

column3: Congress Takes Up Gun Violence
column4: The fight will not be easy.

column3: Congress Takes Up Gun Violence
column4: A bill introduced by Senator Dianne Feinstein of California would, for example, ban 157 of the worst assault weapons while leaving 2,200 guns untouched in the sportsmen’s marketplace.

column3: Congress Takes Up Gun Violence
column4: “I understand how difficult this is,” Ms. Feinstein said.

column3: Congress Takes Up Gun Violence
column4: “That doesn’t mean we shouldn’t try.” The reform effort will require an unprecedented outpouring of public support and pressure on Congress — a national drive that President Obama needs to make unrelenting and well-organized.

column3: Congress Takes Up Gun Violence
column4: The sponsor of the assault weapons ban in the House, Representative Carolyn McCarthy of New York, wisely says nothing will come of the reform effort unless the president is “out there selling it.” Mr. Obama is supposed to follow Vice President Joseph Biden Jr. in leaving Washington for drumbeating rounds with community leaders.

column3: Congress Takes Up Gun Violence
column4: Mr. Biden is already emphasizing his mantra for audiences: “Tell your congressman.” Republicans and wobbly Democrats in the House are waiting on results from the Senate, where the Democratic majority leader, Harry Reid, will play a crucial role.

column3: Congress Takes Up Gun Violence
column4: He is skeptical of an assault weapons ban and wary of losing Senate Democrats in next year’s elections.

column3: Congress Takes Up Gun Violence
column4: But he admits, “We need to accept the reality that we are not doing enough to protect our citizens.” Mr. Reid aims to have legislation shaped by the Judiciary Committee for floor debate that will be freely open to amendment.

column3: Congress Takes Up Gun Violence
column4: This unusual process has the virtue of putting senators on the record for each major proposal, but could weaken a measure as much as strengthen it.

column3: Congress Takes Up Gun Violence
column4: Nothing is settled in Congress.

column3: Congress Takes Up Gun Violence
column4: The outcome depends to a great degree on how demanding the public is for credible action against the gun violence ravaging the nation.

column3: Congress Takes Up Gun Violence
column4:  This is part of a continuing series on the epidemic of gun violence and possible solutions.

column3: Congress Takes Up Gun Violence
column4: Other editorials are at nytimes.com/gunchallenge.

column3: Obama's Immigration Plan: Expedite 11 Million Illegal Immigrants to Citizenship
column4: President Obama has wrapped up his $1.6 million ~~campaign event~~ immigration reform speech in Las Vegas, Nevada.

column3: Obama's Immigration Plan: Expedite 11 Million Illegal Immigrants to Citizenship
column4: "Now is the time for common sense, comprehensive immigration reform," Obama said.

column3: Obama's Immigration Plan: Expedite 11 Million Illegal Immigrants to Citizenship
column4: Piggybacking off of a bipartisan immigration reform plan presented by eight Senators yesterday, Obama called on Congress to quickly come up with legislation.

column3: Obama's Immigration Plan: Expedite 11 Million Illegal Immigrants to Citizenship
column4: "We can't allow immigration reform to get bogged down in endless debate," Obama said.

column3: Obama's Immigration Plan: Expedite 11 Million Illegal Immigrants to Citizenship
column4: "For the first time in years, Republicans and Democrats seem ready to attack this problem together."

column3: Obama's Immigration Plan: Expedite 11 Million Illegal Immigrants to Citizenship
column4: Although Obama focused on further enforcement as a top priority for reform, he stressed the need to expedite 11 million illegal immigrants away from the shadows and into American society as citizens, a position bound to put the country into another  post-1986 amnesty situation.

column3: Obama's Immigration Plan: Expedite 11 Million Illegal Immigrants to Citizenship
column4: Obama wants to study the fine print of legislation once it is written, but administration officials were quick to say the president objects to linking an earned pathway to citizenship to enforcement or border security triggers, a contingency concept included in the bipartisan “principles” outlined Monday by pro-reform senators who have been dubbed the “immigration eight.” Immigration enforcement goals have already been met by the administration, the officials said, and any new triggers or thresholds set by law would create unnecessary obstacles to those seeking legal status.

column3: Obama's Immigration Plan: Expedite 11 Million Illegal Immigrants to Citizenship
column4: Obama warned if Congress fails to enact its own immigration reform, he'll send up his own bill "and insist they vote on it right away," while cautioning against the emotion of ongoing debate and an "us vs. them" mentality.

column3: Obama's Immigration Plan: Expedite 11 Million Illegal Immigrants to Citizenship
column4: "The closer we get, the more emotional this debate is going to become," Obama said.

column3: Obama's Immigration Plan: Expedite 11 Million Illegal Immigrants to Citizenship
column4: "Immigration has always been an issue that inflames passions."

column3: Obama's Immigration Plan: Expedite 11 Million Illegal Immigrants to Citizenship
column4: Republican Senator Marco Rubio has said he will oppose legislation that puts the Green Card process before border enforcement and security.

column3: President Obama, John McCain, Marco Rubio begin immigration dance
column4: LAS VEGAS — The immigration reform plan President Barack Obama outlined Tuesday sounds a lot like the new bipartisan proposal from the Senate — and on the broad points, it is.

column3: President Obama, John McCain, Marco Rubio begin immigration dance
column4: But the differences are in the details.

column3: President Obama, John McCain, Marco Rubio begin immigration dance
column4: And those details, with the liberal stamp Obama put on his approach here, could be the difference between a deal and another failed effort on an issue that Washington has struggled with for years.

column3: President Obama, John McCain, Marco Rubio begin immigration dance
column4: Story Continued Below ( PHOTOS: Pols react on immigration) Obama’s speech launched a campaign for legislation built on several overarching principles: provide a path to citizenship for the country’s approximately 11 million undocumented immigrants, streamline legal immigration, crack down on employers who hire undocumented workers and strengthen border security.

column3: President Obama, John McCain, Marco Rubio begin immigration dance
column4: That’s all in the blueprint offered Monday by a group of eight senators, led by Republican John McCain and Democrat Chuck Schumer.

column3: President Obama, John McCain, Marco Rubio begin immigration dance
column4: That’s where things get tricky.

column3: President Obama, John McCain, Marco Rubio begin immigration dance
column4: ( Also on POLITICO: Pitfalls that could stop immigration deal) Senior administration officials said the contrasts and omissions aren’t red lines for the president.

column3: President Obama, John McCain, Marco Rubio begin immigration dance
column4: But they do foreshadow the points of tension in the upcoming legislative negotiations.

column3: President Obama, John McCain, Marco Rubio begin immigration dance
column4: Perhaps the biggest hurdle is a trigger for citizenship that Republicans such as Florida Sen. Marco Rubio describe as a must-have.

column3: President Obama, John McCain, Marco Rubio begin immigration dance
column4: Obama wouldn’t make citizenship for undocumented immigrants contingent upon a declaration that the U.S.-Mexico border has been secured.

column3: President Obama, John McCain, Marco Rubio begin immigration dance
column4: And he highlighted that difference with the Senate plan in his speech Tuesday, saying “it must be clear from the outset that there is a pathway to citizenship.” The president didn’t explicitly endorse the need for a temporary worker program, as he did in his 2011 immigration blueprint.

column3: President Obama, John McCain, Marco Rubio begin immigration dance
column4: The Senate proposal would set up a process for American companies to hire low-skilled labor under certain circumstances — a concept that’s divided labor and business — but the White House doesn’t view such a program as essential, given the current economic conditions.

column3: President Obama, John McCain, Marco Rubio begin immigration dance
column4: Obama also didn’t embrace a proposal from the Senate group that would set up an expedited citizenship process for agricultural workers who commit to working in the industry.

column3: President Obama, John McCain, Marco Rubio begin immigration dance
column4: And although he didn’t mention it in his speech, his plan explicitly includes protections for gay couples.

column3: President Obama, John McCain, Marco Rubio begin immigration dance
column4: Unlike the Senate blueprint, Obama’s plan “treats same-sex families as families by giving U.S. citizens and lawful permanent residents the ability to seek a visa on the basis of a permanent relationship with a same-sex partner.”

column3: Obama presses immigration agenda as senators draft new overhaul
column4: President Obama said Tuesday that "now's the time" for immigration reform, using an address in Las Vegas to try and energize renewed talks in Congress toward comprehensive legislation.

column3: Obama presses immigration agenda as senators draft new overhaul
column4: "I'm here today because the time has come for common-sense comprehensive immigration reform," Obama said.

column3: Obama presses immigration agenda as senators draft new overhaul
column4: The president, setting out to achieve an immigration overhaul where many before him have failed, was running into trouble even before he gave his address.

column3: Obama presses immigration agenda as senators draft new overhaul
column4: Sen. Marco Rubio, R-Fla., one of four Republican senators involved in a bipartisan effort to craft immigration legislation, earlier in the day blasted Obama for opposing a requirement to shore up border security before legalizing up to 11 million illegal immigrants.

column3: Obama presses immigration agenda as senators draft new overhaul
column4: Obama's speech, and a separate fact sheet handed out by the White House, made clear that the administration does not want to link the path to citizenship to border enforcement.

column3: Obama presses immigration agenda as senators draft new overhaul
column4: The president said Tuesday that in order for immigration reform to work, "It must be clear from the outset that there is a pathway to citizenship."

column3: Obama presses immigration agenda as senators draft new overhaul
column4: The comment, albeit subtle, was an apparent reference to a provision in the Senate blueprint that would not let illegal immigrants seek citizenship until border security is strengthened.

column3: Obama presses immigration agenda as senators draft new overhaul
column4: Obama said that his conditions would only involve the illegal immigrants themselves -- he said that they would have to submit to a background check, pay back taxes and fines, learn English and get in the back of the line in order to apply.

column3: Obama presses immigration agenda as senators draft new overhaul
column4: The president described his plan as "earned citizenship."

column3: Obama presses immigration agenda as senators draft new overhaul
column4: Obama claimed a "broad consensus" was emerging on the issue itself, calling the plan outlined by Rubio and others "very much in line" with his own -- aside from the path-to-citizenship provision.

column3: Obama presses immigration agenda as senators draft new overhaul
column4: "For the first time in many years, Republicans and Democrats seem ready to tackle this problem together," he said, calling legislation "within our grasp."

column3: Obama presses immigration agenda as senators draft new overhaul
column4: He said any plan should include the path to citizenship, but also a crackdown on employers who knowingly hire undocumented workers -- and a better system for verifying the status of those workers.

column3: Obama presses immigration agenda as senators draft new overhaul
column4: He also called for streamlining the legal immigration system, providing visas for foreign entrepreneurs and retaining sought-after science and math graduate students.

column3: Obama presses immigration agenda as senators draft new overhaul
column4: The president has run into complaints from conservatives that his plan is tantamount to "amnesty."

column3: Obama presses immigration agenda as senators draft new overhaul
column4: But the most problematic objection so far has come from Rubio -- a prominent Hispanic conservative who is vital to the bipartisan effort on Capitol Hill.

column3: Obama presses immigration agenda as senators draft new overhaul
column4: Speaking on Fox News on Tuesday, Rubio insisted that illegal immigrants not be allowed to obtain green cards -- let alone citizenship -- "until the enforcement stuff is in place."

column3: Obama presses immigration agenda as senators draft new overhaul
column4: "I think that would be a terrible mistake," Rubio told Fox News.

column3: Obama presses immigration agenda as senators draft new overhaul
column4: "We have a bipartisan group of senators that have agreed to that.

column3: Obama presses immigration agenda as senators draft new overhaul
column4: For the president to try to move the goalposts on that specific requirement, as an example, does not bode well in terms of what his role's going to be in this or the outcome."

column3: Obama presses immigration agenda as senators draft new overhaul
column4: He said: "If that's not in the bill, I won't support it."

column3: Obama presses immigration agenda as senators draft new overhaul
column4: Obama stressed Tuesday that if Congress cannot move forward "in a timely fashion," he will submit a proposal drafted by the White House.

column3: Obama presses immigration agenda as senators draft new overhaul
column4: Amid the exchanges, Republicans congressional leaders expressed a willingness to debate the issue while cautioning against Obama getting too involved.

column3: Obama presses immigration agenda as senators draft new overhaul
column4: "There are a lot of ideas about how best to fix our broken immigration system," House Speaker John Boehner said in a statement.

column3: Obama presses immigration agenda as senators draft new overhaul
column4: "Any solution should be a bipartisan one, and we hope the president is careful not to drag the debate to the left and ultimately disrupt the difficult work that is ahead in the House and Senate."

column3: Obama presses immigration agenda as senators draft new overhaul
column4: The issue of immigration reform was put on the back burner during Obama's first term -- overtaken by debate over health care legislation and economic measures.

column3: Obama presses immigration agenda as senators draft new overhaul
column4: But along with gun control, it is one of the top items on his second-term domestic agenda.

column3: Obama presses immigration agenda as senators draft new overhaul
column4: The eight U.S. senators got ahead of him Monday, unveiling a blueprint that calls for, among other things, a path to citizenship for the 11 million illegal immigrants already in the United States.

column3: Obama presses immigration agenda as senators draft new overhaul
column4: But White House Press Secretary Jay Carney said the president "welcomes" the proposal, saying it represents the "bipartisan support coalescing" behind certain principles of immigration reform.

column3: Obama presses immigration agenda as senators draft new overhaul
column4: Despite the difference over the path to legal status, an Obama administration official told Fox News the senators' plan is on a trajectory that mirrors Obama's immigration plan in many ways, and that the White House is willing to let the group take the lead.

column3: Obama presses immigration agenda as senators draft new overhaul
column4: Sen. Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y., one of the eight senators, called the new proposal a "major breakthrough" and said he hopes to turn it into legislation by March -- with the goal of passing something out of the Senate "by late spring or summer."

column3: Obama presses immigration agenda as senators draft new overhaul
column4: Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz., standing beside him, claimed 2013 is the "best chance" lawmakers will have to tackle immigration for years.

column3: Obama presses immigration agenda as senators draft new overhaul
column4: Even so, the proposed pathway to citizenship for illegal immigrants drew immediate criticism from others on Capitol Hill.

column3: Obama presses immigration agenda as senators draft new overhaul
column4: "No one should be surprised that individuals who have supported amnesty in the past still support amnesty," Rep. Lamar Smith, R-Texas, said.

column3: Obama presses immigration agenda as senators draft new overhaul
column4: "By granting amnesty, the Senate proposal actually compounds the problem by encouraging more illegal immigration."

column3: Obama presses immigration agenda as senators draft new overhaul
column4: The eight senators who unveiled the new principles are Democrats Schumer, Dick Durbin of Illinois, Robert Menendez of New Jersey and Michael Bennet of Colorado; and Republicans McCain, Lindsey Graham of South Carolina, Rubio of Florida and Jeff Flake of Arizona.

column3: Obama presses immigration agenda as senators draft new overhaul
column4: The Senate framework would also require those here illegally to pass background checks and pay fines and taxes in order to qualify for a "probationary legal status" that would allow them to live and work here -- but not qualify for federal benefits -- before being able to apply for permanent residency, a critical step toward citizenship.

column3: Obama presses immigration agenda as senators draft new overhaul
column4: Once they are allowed to apply they would do so behind everyone else already waiting for a green card within the current immigration system.

column3: Obama presses immigration agenda as senators draft new overhaul
column4: Senators also want to reform the legal immigration system, including awarding green cards to immigrants who obtain advanced degrees in science, math, technology or engineering from an American university.

column3: Obama presses immigration agenda as senators draft new overhaul
column4: The principles released Monday are outlined on just over four pages, leaving plenty of details to fill in.

column3: Obama presses immigration agenda as senators draft new overhaul
column4: The Associated Press contributed to this report.

column3: Fox News, Palin part ways
column4: NEW YORK –  Fox News Channel is parting ways with former Republican vice presidential candidate Sarah Palin, ending her three-year tenure as a contributor on the network.

column3: Fox News, Palin part ways
column4: While Palin's time at Fox was occasionally rocky, the network's news executive, Bill Shine, said Friday that "we have thoroughly enjoyed our association" with her.

column3: Fox News, Palin part ways
column4: "We wish her the best in her future endeavors," said Shine, Fox's executive vice president for programming.

column3: Fox News, Palin part ways
column4: A person familiar with discussions between Fox and Palin described the parting as amicable, saying that Fox and Palin had discussed renewing her contract but she decided to do other things.

column3: Fox News, Palin part ways
column4: The person spoke on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to speak on the record.

column3: Fox News, Palin part ways
column4: Palin's lawyer in Alaska, John Tiemessen, had no immediate comment on her exit.

column3: Fox News, Palin part ways
column4: Palin's last appearance on Fox News was Dec. 19 on Greta Van Susteren's show.

column3: Fox News, Palin part ways
column4: Palin signed to deliver commentary on Fox in January 2010, reportedly for $1 million a year.

column3: Fox News, Palin part ways
column4: It was a coup for both sides at the time; the former Alaska governor was a little more than a year removed from her attention-getting run for the vice presidency and was considered one of the leading contenders for the 2012 presidential nomination.

column3: Fox News, Palin part ways
column4: At Fox, she had a platform on the most popular network for conservative viewers.

column3: Fox News, Palin part ways
column4: Fox installed equipment in Palin's Wasilla, Alaska, home to make her regular appearances easier.

column3: Fox News, Palin part ways
column4: But there were some indications of tension between her and Fox News Chairman Roger Ailes, who was quoted in a 2011 story by The Associated Press saying, "I hired Sarah Palin because she was hot and got ratings."

column3: Fox News, Palin part ways
column4: When Palin announced she would not be a candidate in 2012, she said it on a conservative radio show, which didn't sit well with the company paying her to be a contributor.

column3: Fox News, Palin part ways
column4: Palin took to her Facebook page late last summer to complain that Fox had cancelled her appearances one night at the GOP national convention; Fox said it was simply because the GOP had to condense its speaker schedule due to a hurricane.

column3: Fox News, Palin part ways
column4: Four years removed from her vice presidential candidacy, Palin's influence had waned and she was somewhat overshadowed as a contributor at Fox by Karl Rove, former President George W. Bush's top political aide.

column3: Fox News, Palin part ways
column4: Rove recently renewed his contract at Fox through the 2016 election.

column3: Fox News, Palin part ways
column4: With four more years of a Barack Obama administration in power, Fox recently hired former Democratic presidential candidate Dennis Kucinich as a contributor.

column3: Sarah Palin's Fox Exit Marks End Of An Era
column4: The news that Sarah Palin will no longer be a paid contributor to Fox News puts an exclamation point on the end of an era, or at least a chapter, in U.S. political history.

column3: Sarah Palin's Fox Exit Marks End Of An Era
column4: She could land somewhere else, and she still has her Facebook friends, but it’s hard to imagine she’ll find a more visible or influential platform than Fox.

column3: Bipartisan Group Of Senators To Introduce Immigration Plan, Preempt Obama
column4: WASHINGTON -- A bipartisan group of four Democratic senators and four Republican senators will announce the framework for a comprehensive immigration reform plan on Monday, seeking to jump out in front of President Obama's planned Tuesday speech on immigration.

column3: Bipartisan Group Of Senators To Introduce Immigration Plan, Preempt Obama
column4: Senate Majority Whip Dick Durbin (D-Ill.), Sen. Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.), Sen. Bob Menendez (D-N.J.) and Sen. Michael Bennet (D-Colo.) will join with Sen. Marco Rubio (R-Fla.), Sen. John McCain (R-Ariz.), Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) and Sen. Jeff Flake (R-Ariz.) to promote the plan.

column3: Bipartisan Group Of Senators To Introduce Immigration Plan, Preempt Obama
column4: Senators will unveil their plan (read the full five-page memo below) at a Monday afternoon press conference in Washington.

column3: Bipartisan Group Of Senators To Introduce Immigration Plan, Preempt Obama
column4: The senators were expected to make an announcement this week, but after news broke last Thursday that Obama would speak Tuesday in Las Vegas about what he wants in immigration legislation, the lawmakers agreed quickly last Friday to hold the event at the beginning of this week.

column3: Bipartisan Group Of Senators To Introduce Immigration Plan, Preempt Obama
column4: Both Democratic and Republican senators were eager to go before Obama to try to wrest control of the process from the White House, according to Senate aides.

column3: Bipartisan Group Of Senators To Introduce Immigration Plan, Preempt Obama
column4: The group is notable in that it includes leading Senate Democrats like Durbin and Schumer, veteran Republican senators like McCain and Graham, and then Rubio, who was reported to have first joined the bipartisan working group last week, but according to a Rubio aide, was first approached by the others in December and has worked with them since.

column3: Bipartisan Group Of Senators To Introduce Immigration Plan, Preempt Obama
column4: "He's met with them several times since then.

column3: Bipartisan Group Of Senators To Introduce Immigration Plan, Preempt Obama
column4: Our staffs have shared a lot of paper," the aide said, describing the principles as "consistent with everything that Senator Rubio's been talking about."

column3: Bipartisan Group Of Senators To Introduce Immigration Plan, Preempt Obama
column4: Durbin and Menendez have been insistent that a path to citizenship for the estimated 11 million undocumented immigrants in the U.S. is a core part of their approach.

column3: Bipartisan Group Of Senators To Introduce Immigration Plan, Preempt Obama
column4: "Very clearly, having a pathway to earned legalization is an essential element.

column3: Bipartisan Group Of Senators To Introduce Immigration Plan, Preempt Obama
column4: And I think that we are largely moving in that direction as an agreement," Menendez said on ABC News' "This Week."

column3: Bipartisan Group Of Senators To Introduce Immigration Plan, Preempt Obama
column4: But the bipartisan group has also agreed that before a pathway to citizenship is made available, thresholds must be met on border security and workplace enforcement.

column3: Bipartisan Group Of Senators To Introduce Immigration Plan, Preempt Obama
column4: The draft agreement reads: "Once the enforcement measures have been completed, individuals with probationary legal status will be required to go to the back of the line of prospective immigrants, pass an additional background check, pay taxes, learn English and civics, demonstrate a history of work in the United States, and current employment, among other requirements, in order to earn the opportunity to apply for lawful permanent residency.

column3: Bipartisan Group Of Senators To Introduce Immigration Plan, Preempt Obama
column4: Those individuals who successfully complete these requirements can eventually earn a green card."

column3: Bipartisan Group Of Senators To Introduce Immigration Plan, Preempt Obama
column4: The border component will include a commission to verify that the border is secure, made up of governors and attorneys general from border states.

column3: Bipartisan Group Of Senators To Introduce Immigration Plan, Preempt Obama
column4: In response to a report in The Hill last week that undocumented immigrants might become eligible for taxpayer-subsidized health care under immigration reform, the Rubio aide also said that the bipartisan group is agreed that undocumented immigrants who might be given a temporary work visa under a new legal framework will not be eligible to receive federal aid.

column3: Bipartisan Group Of Senators To Introduce Immigration Plan, Preempt Obama
column4: The draft language backs this up.

column3: Bipartisan Group Of Senators To Introduce Immigration Plan, Preempt Obama
column4: "Current restrictions preventing non-immigrants from accessing federal public benefits will also apply to lawful probationary immigrants," it says.

column3: Bipartisan Group Of Senators To Introduce Immigration Plan, Preempt Obama
column4: McCain, also appearing on "This Week," said that the group's proposal is "not that much different from what we tried to do in 2007," when then-President George W. Bush tried to push a set of reforms through Congress.

column3: Bipartisan Group Of Senators To Introduce Immigration Plan, Preempt Obama
column4: Bush's initiative was met with hostility by the conservative wing of the Republican party, who howled about amnesty and brought the initiative down to defeat.

column3: Bipartisan Group Of Senators To Introduce Immigration Plan, Preempt Obama
column4: McCain said that Republican Mitt Romney's loss in the 2012 presidential election, and the fact that McCain in 2008 and Romney in 2012 lost increasingly large numbers of Latino voters, has altered the politics of the immigration debate.

column3: Bipartisan Group Of Senators To Introduce Immigration Plan, Preempt Obama
column4: "What's changed is -- honestly, is that there is a new, I think, appreciation on both sides of the aisle -- including maybe more importantly on the Republican side of the aisle -- that we have to enact a comprehensive immigration reform bill," McCain said.

column3: Bipartisan Group Of Senators To Introduce Immigration Plan, Preempt Obama
column4: "Look at the last election.

column3: Bipartisan Group Of Senators To Introduce Immigration Plan, Preempt Obama
column4: Look at the last election," McCain said.

column3: Bipartisan Group Of Senators To Introduce Immigration Plan, Preempt Obama
column4: "We are losing dramatically the Hispanic vote, which we think should be ours, for a variety of reasons, and we've got to understand that."

column3: Bipartisan Group Of Senators To Introduce Immigration Plan, Preempt Obama
column4: In the past, figures like McCain -- who is viewed suspiciously by many conservatives –- have been unable to convince the GOP base or the media influencers like conservative talk radio that their approach to immigration is not "amnesty."

column3: Bipartisan Group Of Senators To Introduce Immigration Plan, Preempt Obama
column4: But Rubio –- who is the son of Cuban immigrants –- has had success in ways that other Republicans never have.

column3: Bipartisan Group Of Senators To Introduce Immigration Plan, Preempt Obama
column4: Just last week he got high praise for his ideas on immigration from talk radio host Mark Levin and Fox News' Lou Dobbs, who both in the past have been outspoken opponents of legalizing undocumented immigrants.

column3: Bipartisan Group Of Senators To Introduce Immigration Plan, Preempt Obama
column4: "He's talking intelligently about a rational, effective, humane response to the issue, and the idea's going to be whether the Republican party has the ability, the capacity and the will to put him in a position so that he can represent the party on the issue," Dobbs said.

column3: Bipartisan Group Of Senators To Introduce Immigration Plan, Preempt Obama
column4: Bipartisan immigration plan

column3: Bipartisan group of 8 senators reaches deal on immigration changes
column4: President Obama, just days into his second term, is pressing ahead on the explosive issue of immigration reform -- boosted Monday by a bipartisan group of senators drafting a proposal of their own while running into early criticism that the blueprint amounts to "amnesty."

column3: Bipartisan group of 8 senators reaches deal on immigration changes
column4: The president is traveling Tuesday to Las Vegas, where he will outline his immigration reform goals, said to be similar to those he championed during the campaign.

column3: Bipartisan group of 8 senators reaches deal on immigration changes
column4: The issue was put on the back burner during his first term -- overtaken by debate over health care legislation and economic measures.

column3: Bipartisan group of 8 senators reaches deal on immigration changes
column4: But along with gun control, it is one of the top items on his second-term domestic agenda.

column3: Bipartisan group of 8 senators reaches deal on immigration changes
column4: Eight U.S. senators got ahead of him Monday, unveiling a blueprint that calls for, among other things, a path to citizenship for the 11 million illegal immigrants already in the United States.

column3: Bipartisan group of 8 senators reaches deal on immigration changes
column4: But White House Press Secretary Jay Carney said the president "welcomes" the proposal, saying it represents the "bipartisan support coalescing" behind certain principles of immigration reform.

column3: Bipartisan group of 8 senators reaches deal on immigration changes
column4: "This is an important first step.

column3: Bipartisan group of 8 senators reaches deal on immigration changes
column4: ... We need to continue the movement," Carney said.

column3: Bipartisan group of 8 senators reaches deal on immigration changes
column4: An Obama administration official tells Fox News the senators' plan is on a trajectory that mirrors Obama’s immigration plan almost exactly, and that the White House is willing to let the group take the lead.

column3: Bipartisan group of 8 senators reaches deal on immigration changes
column4: The aide says requiring illegal immigrants to pay back taxes and a fine and ensuring they would be at the back of the line after would-be legal immigrants have always been part of the president's immigration proposal.

column3: Bipartisan group of 8 senators reaches deal on immigration changes
column4: The president has also advocated for a path to citizenship.

column3: Bipartisan group of 8 senators reaches deal on immigration changes
column4: Sen. Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y., one of the eight senators  called the new proposal a "major breakthrough" and said he hopes to turn it into legislation by March -- with the goal of passing something out of the Senate "by late spring or summer."

column3: Bipartisan group of 8 senators reaches deal on immigration changes
column4: Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz., standing beside him, claimed 2013 is the "best chance" lawmakers will have to tackle immigration for years.

column3: Bipartisan group of 8 senators reaches deal on immigration changes
column4: Even so, the proposed pathway to citizenship for illegal immigrants drew immediate criticism from others on Capitol Hill.

column3: Bipartisan group of 8 senators reaches deal on immigration changes
column4: "No one should be surprised that individuals who have supported amnesty in the past still support amnesty," Rep. Lamar Smith, R-Texas, said.

column3: Bipartisan group of 8 senators reaches deal on immigration changes
column4: "By granting amnesty, the Senate proposal actually compounds the problem by encouraging more illegal immigration."

column3: Bipartisan group of 8 senators reaches deal on immigration changes
column4: The eight senators who unveiled the new principles are Democrats Schumer, Dick Durbin of Illinois, Robert Menendez of New Jersey and Michael Bennet of Colorado; and Republicans McCain, Lindsey Graham of South Carolina, Marco Rubio of Florida and Jeff Flake of Arizona.

column3: Bipartisan group of 8 senators reaches deal on immigration changes
column4: According to documents released early Monday, the senators will call for accomplishing four main goals: \--Creating a path to citizenship for the estimated illegal immigrants already in the U.S., contingent upon securing the border and better tracking of people here on visas.

column3: Bipartisan group of 8 senators reaches deal on immigration changes
column4: \--Reforming the legal immigration system, including awarding green cards to immigrants who obtain advanced degrees in science, math, technology or engineering from an American university.

column3: Bipartisan group of 8 senators reaches deal on immigration changes
column4: \--Creating an effective employment verification system to ensure that employers do not hire illegal immigrants.

column3: Bipartisan group of 8 senators reaches deal on immigration changes
column4: \--Allowing more low-skill workers into the country and allowing employers to hire immigrants if they can demonstrate they couldn't recruit a U.S. citizen; and establishing an agricultural worker program.

column3: Bipartisan group of 8 senators reaches deal on immigration changes
column4: The principles being released Monday are outlined on just over four pages, leaving plenty of details left to fill in.

column3: Bipartisan group of 8 senators reaches deal on immigration changes
column4: A Senate aide tells Fox News the group's principles say important security triggers must be met before a pathway for citizenship is created for illegal immigrants.

column3: Bipartisan group of 8 senators reaches deal on immigration changes
column4: Even then, the principles explicitly state that illegal immigrants must go to the back of the line behind would-be legal immigrants, and they will not be eligible for federal benefits while in the temporary legal status.

column3: Bipartisan group of 8 senators reaches deal on immigration changes
column4: The aide tells Fox News that although many of the details of the bill still need to be worked out, those involved are encouraged by their progress and the support of senior senators.

column3: Bipartisan group of 8 senators reaches deal on immigration changes
column4: Members of the group on Sunday said they are seeking to craft a one-step, all-encompassing bill based on the shared principles.

column3: Bipartisan group of 8 senators reaches deal on immigration changes
column4: "We are committed to a comprehensive approach to immigration that we can live with," Durbin told "Fox News Sunday."

column3: Bipartisan group of 8 senators reaches deal on immigration changes
column4: Citizenship has been a sticking point in previous efforts, particularly among Capitol Hill Republicans.

column3: Bipartisan group of 8 senators reaches deal on immigration changes
column4: However, they appear willing to accept the path to citizenship, in part, so long as the legislation also includes tighter border security.

column3: Bipartisan group of 8 senators reaches deal on immigration changes
column4: Tennessee Republican Sen. Bob Corker told Fox News he is optimistic but "details matter."

column3: Bipartisan group of 8 senators reaches deal on immigration changes
column4: "We're at the talking points stage," he said.

column3: Bipartisan group of 8 senators reaches deal on immigration changes
column4: "We need to get to the legislation."

column3: Bipartisan group of 8 senators reaches deal on immigration changes
column4: McCain said more work is needed on the legislation.

column3: Bipartisan group of 8 senators reaches deal on immigration changes
column4: "I'm quietly optimistic we can get it done," he told ABC's "This Week."

column3: Bipartisan group of 8 senators reaches deal on immigration changes
column4: McCain, a key player in the 2007 effort on immigration reform, also acknowledged that Obama's overwhelming support among Hispanics in the November elections was a wakeup call to Republicans that they need to do more to reach out to that growing part of the population.

column3: Bipartisan group of 8 senators reaches deal on immigration changes
column4: The group has been working since the November elections on the legislation and is expected to have a complete bill by March or April.

column3: Bipartisan group of 8 senators reaches deal on immigration changes
column4: Several of these lawmakers have worked for years on the issue.

column3: Bipartisan group of 8 senators reaches deal on immigration changes
column4: McCain collaborated with the late Democratic Sen. Edward M. Kennedy on comprehensive immigration legislation pushed by then-President George W. Bush in 2007, only to see it collapse in the Senate when it couldn't get enough GOP support.

column3: Bipartisan group of 8 senators reaches deal on immigration changes
column4: Fox News' Mike Emanuel and The Associated Press contributed to this report.

column3: Gun Control Advocates Need to Listen to Gun Owners, Obama Says
column4: WASHINGTON – President Obama said that he and his guests go skeet shooting at Camp David “all the time” and that gun control advocates need “to do a little more listening” to understand why so many Americans are wary of government limits on firearms.

column3: Gun Control Advocates Need to Listen to Gun Owners, Obama Says
column4: In an interview released Sunday morning, Mr. Obama acknowledged that getting his package of gun proposals through Congress could be tough, and he expressed empathy for the strong sentiments of gun owners.

column3: Gun Control Advocates Need to Listen to Gun Owners, Obama Says
column4: Like Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., who has mentioned that he owns two shotguns, Mr. Obama tried to associate himself with those who enjoy firing guns.

column3: Gun Control Advocates Need to Listen to Gun Owners, Obama Says
column4: “Up at Camp David, we do skeet shooting all the time,” he told The New Republic in the interview, conducted Jan. 16, just after he unveiled his gun proposals.

column3: Gun Control Advocates Need to Listen to Gun Owners, Obama Says
column4: Asked about his family, he said, “Not the girls, but oftentimes guests of mine go up there.

column3: Gun Control Advocates Need to Listen to Gun Owners, Obama Says
column4: And I have a profound respect for the traditions of hunting that trace back in this country for generations.

column3: Gun Control Advocates Need to Listen to Gun Owners, Obama Says
column4: And I think those who dismiss that out of hand make a big mistake.” He added that the experience with guns in rural America differed dramatically from that in urban America.

column3: Gun Control Advocates Need to Listen to Gun Owners, Obama Says
column4: “If you grew up and your dad gave you a hunting rifle when you were 10, and you went out and spent the day with him and your uncles, and that became part of your family’s traditions, you can see why you’d be pretty protective of that,” he said.

column3: Gun Control Advocates Need to Listen to Gun Owners, Obama Says
column4: “So it’s trying to bridge those gaps that I think is going to be part of the biggest task over the next several months,” he added.

column3: Gun Control Advocates Need to Listen to Gun Owners, Obama Says
column4: “And that means that advocates of gun control have to do a little more listening than they do sometimes.” Mr. Obama has proposed reinstating and strengthening an expired ban on new assault weapons and high-capacity magazines, expanding criminal background checks for nearly all gun sales except those within families, and cracking down on straw purchasers who buy firearms for others who would not be able to pass a background check.

column3: Gun Control Advocates Need to Listen to Gun Owners, Obama Says
column4: He also used his executive authority to try to improve the background check database and to revive government research into gun violence.

column3: Gun Control Advocates Need to Listen to Gun Owners, Obama Says
column4: In the interview, Mr. Obama also expressed concern for the state of football in America, particularly at the college level, where there is no union to represent the interests of players.

column3: Gun Control Advocates Need to Listen to Gun Owners, Obama Says
column4: “I’m a big football fan,” he said, “but I have to tell you, if I had a son, I’d have to think long and hard before I let him play football.

column3: Gun Control Advocates Need to Listen to Gun Owners, Obama Says
column4: And I think those of us who love the sport are going to have to wrestle with the fact that it will probably change gradually to reduce some of the violence.” Asked about the continuing rebellion in Syria that has led to tens of thousands of deaths, Mr. Obama made clear that he has declined to intervene because he is haunted by a series of questions that he cannot answer satisfactorily.

column3: Gun Control Advocates Need to Listen to Gun Owners, Obama Says
column4: “In a situation like Syria,” he said, “I have to ask, can we make a difference in that situation?

column3: Gun Control Advocates Need to Listen to Gun Owners, Obama Says
column4: Would a military intervention have an impact?

column3: Gun Control Advocates Need to Listen to Gun Owners, Obama Says
column4: How would it affect our ability to support troops who are still in Afghanistan?

column3: Gun Control Advocates Need to Listen to Gun Owners, Obama Says
column4: What would be the aftermath of our involvement on the ground?

column3: Gun Control Advocates Need to Listen to Gun Owners, Obama Says
column4: Could it trigger even worse violence or the use of chemical weapons?

column3: Ryan says GOP needs to pick its fights with Obama
column4: WASHINGTON (AP) — Rep. Paul Ryan has a message for fellow Republicans: Let's stick together and carefully pick our fights with President Barack Obama.

column3: Ryan says GOP needs to pick its fights with Obama
column4: In a speech Saturday to conservatives, the Wisconsin congressman and 2012 vice presidential nominee outlined a pragmatic approach for dealing with a second Obama administration.

column3: Ryan says GOP needs to pick its fights with Obama
column4: Saying that Obama would attempt to divide Republicans, Ryan urged them to avoid internal squabbles.

column3: Ryan says GOP needs to pick its fights with Obama
column4: "We can't get rattled.

column3: Ryan says GOP needs to pick its fights with Obama
column4: We won't play the villain in his morality plays.

column3: Ryan says GOP needs to pick its fights with Obama
column4: We have to stay united," Ryan said at the National Review Institute's weekend conference on the future of conservatism.

column3: Ryan says GOP needs to pick its fights with Obama
column4: "We have to show that if given the chance, we can govern.

column3: Ryan says GOP needs to pick its fights with Obama
column4: We have better ideas."

column3: Ryan says GOP needs to pick its fights with Obama
column4: The GOP is reeling from back-to-back presidential defeats and trying to determine whether to oppose Obama at every turn or shape his proposals with conservative principles.

column3: Ryan says GOP needs to pick its fights with Obama
column4: How the party rebounds was a major theme of the three-day meeting of conservative activists, a dominant voice in the GOP.

column3: Ryan says GOP needs to pick its fights with Obama
column4: A similar theme dominated the Republican National Committee's winter meeting, which ended Friday in Charlotte, N.C. With a surging minority population altering the electorate, Republican leaders have discussed the need to attract more women and Hispanics while at the same time standing firm on the values that unite conservatives.

column3: Ryan says GOP needs to pick its fights with Obama
column4: Republicans said despite the losses, the party could return to power by projecting optimism and attracting new voters with a message of economic opportunity.

column3: Ryan says GOP needs to pick its fights with Obama
column4: Wisconsin Gov.

column3: Ryan says GOP needs to pick its fights with Obama
column4: Scott Walker, a star among conservatives after surviving a union-led campaign to recall him from office, said government needed "brown-bag common sense," a reference to his frugal practice of packing his own lunch of ham-and-cheese sandwiches every day.

column3: Ryan says GOP needs to pick its fights with Obama
column4: Qualities like optimism, staying relevant to voters and showing courage in tackling big problems would be rewarded at the voting booth, he said.

column3: Ryan says GOP needs to pick its fights with Obama
column4: "We've got to learn to be more optimistic.

column3: Ryan says GOP needs to pick its fights with Obama
column4: We've got to learn to give a viable alternative to the voters," Walker said.

column3: Ryan says GOP needs to pick its fights with Obama
column4: Sen. Ted Cruz of Texas said Republicans needed to use upcoming fights over the budget and the deficit as "leverage points" to tame long-term spending and debt.

column3: Ryan says GOP needs to pick its fights with Obama
column4: Projecting an upbeat outlook for the party, he said Obama's policies would drive many voters to Republicans just as many Americans turned to Ronald Reagan after the economic turmoil of the late 1970s.

column3: Ryan says GOP needs to pick its fights with Obama
column4: "We're on the verge of a rebirth of conservativism," Cruz said.

column3: Ryan says GOP needs to pick its fights with Obama
column4: Looking ahead, Ryan rejected the notion that Republicans were "in the wilderness," noting that the party controls the House and most statehouses.

column3: Ryan says GOP needs to pick its fights with Obama
column4: But he said Obama's victory over Romney meant that Republicans would need to recalibrate their approach to deal with the new political realities.

column3: Ryan says GOP needs to pick its fights with Obama
column4: "If we want to promote conservatism, we'll need to use every tool at our disposal," Ryan said.

column3: Ryan says GOP needs to pick its fights with Obama
column4: "Sometimes, we will have to reject the president's proposals — that time may come more than once.

column3: Ryan says GOP needs to pick its fights with Obama
column4: And sometimes we'll have to make them better."

column3: Ryan says GOP needs to pick its fights with Obama
column4: He said Republicans should have two main goals for the next four years, namely "to mitigate bad policies" and "to advance good policy wherever we can."

column3: Ryan says GOP needs to pick its fights with Obama
column4: Ryan acknowledged that "we all didn't see eye to eye" on the recent "fiscal cliff" vote to deal with a combination of spending cuts and higher taxes that were set to take effect at the start of the year.

column3: Ryan says GOP needs to pick its fights with Obama

column3: Ryan says GOP needs to pick its fights with Obama
column4: As chairman of the House Budget Committee, Ryan said Republicans needed to guard against a debt crisis for the country that would undermine the economy.

column3: Ryan says GOP needs to pick its fights with Obama
column4: He said he would promote changes to Medicare and Medicaid and would propose a budget "that will balance and pay down the debt."

column3: Ryan says GOP needs to pick its fights with Obama
column4: But November's election results still linger.

column3: Ryan says GOP needs to pick its fights with Obama

column3: GOP leaders insist no overhaul needed
