column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: WASHINGTON (AP) — The tradition-laden Senate voted Thursday to modestly curb filibusters, using a bipartisan consensus rare in today's hyper-partisan climate to make it a bit harder but not impossible for outnumbered senators to sink bills and nominations.

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: The rules changes would reduce yet not eliminate the number of times opponents — usually minority-party Republicans these days — can use filibusters, procedural tactics which can derail legislation and which can be stopped only by the votes of 60 of the 100 senators.

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: In return, the majority party — Democrats today — would have to allow two minority amendments on bills, a response to Republican complaints that Democrats often prevent them from offering any amendments at all.

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: The new procedures also would limit the time spent debating some bills and nominations, allowing some to be completed in hours that could otherwise take a day or more.

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: The changes were broken into two pieces and approved by votes of 78-16 and 86-9.

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: In both roll calls, Republican opponents were joined by Sen. Bernie Sanders, a Vermont independent who usually sides with Democrats.

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: Many of the GOP "no" votes came from tea party-backed senators like Sens.

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: Mike Lee, R-Utah; Rand Paul, R-Ky.; and Marco Rubio, R-Fla.

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: The two votes and a brief debate took less than an hour, impressively quick for the Senate.

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: They came after a more typical day that featured a sprinkling of senators' speeches and long periods when the Senate chamber idled with no one talking, while private negotiations off the floor nailed down final details.

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: President Barack Obama said the Senate action would help his agenda in Congress.

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: "At a time when we face critical decisions on a whole range of issues — from preventing further gun violence, to reforming our broken immigration system, to getting our fiscal house in order and creating good paying jobs — we cannot afford unnecessary obstruction.

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: And I am hopeful that today's bipartisan agreement will pave the way for the Senate to take meaningful action in the days and weeks ahead," Obama said in a written statement.

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: The pact leaves the Senate's minority party with far more power than it has in the House, where rules let a united majority party easily muscle through its priorities.

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: It also falls short of changes Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid, D-Nev., had been threatening to ram through using the 55 votes Democrats have, a technique nicknamed the "nuclear option" because it is considered likely to produce harsh GOP retaliation that could grind work to a virtual halt.

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: "I'm glad cooler heads have prevailed here once again, and those who were clamoring for the nuclear option, most of whom have never served a day of their lives in the minority, didn't prevail," said McConnell, who worked out the agreement with Reid.

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: He added that Republicans felt rules changes were not needed, merely a willingness by both parties to allow "vigorous debate and a robust amendment process."

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: Reid said the changes would increase Senate efficiency while protecting lawmakers in the minority party, warning that he would consider future changes if Thursday's package didn't do enough.

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: "We were elected to get things done for the middle class — not waste time with endless stalling tactics that cause even bills with broad bipartisan support to languish for weeks," Reid said.

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: Democrats say Republican use of filibusters has become almost routine and far too frequent.

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: Republicans say they use it because Reid often blocks them from offering amendments.

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: The rules also don't go nearly as far as restrictions championed by a group of newer Democratic senators, such as requiring filibustering senators to physically debate on the Senate floor, as portrayed by the actor Jimmy Stewart in the classic 1939 film, "Mr. Smith Goes to Washington."

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: Such filibusters have been rare for decades.

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: Democrats said this week that they lacked the votes to force that proposal through the Senate.

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: Even so, the agreement was remarkable in a period of bitter partisan clashes over Obama's budgetary, tax and social initiatives and GOP efforts to block them.

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: It will streamline some of the Senate's work and avoid what could have been prolonged, nasty battling between the two parties if Democrats — frustrated by the GOP's growing reliance on the delays — tried forcing more decisive changes.

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: The deal gave each side something it wanted: Quicker action for Democrats, guaranteed amendments for Republicans.

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: And it avoided clamping tight limits on filibusters that would alienate veteran lawmakers wary that their party could fall into the minority after any election.

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: Months ago, Reid said he favored completely banning filibusters when the Senate tries to begin debating a measure, a tactic Republicans have been using more in recent years.

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: He threatened to use Democrats' strength in the Senate to enact that change and perhaps others by a simple majority vote, instead of the two-thirds majority most rules changes require.

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: Tight restraints on filibusters were championed by less-senior Democrats like Sens.

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: Jeff Merkley, D-Ore., and Tom Udall, D-N.M.

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: They are frustrated with the chamber's often glacial debates and the ability of the minority — these days Republicans — to kill bills with less than majority support.

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: "Are they everything I want?

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: Of course not," Udall said in an interview.

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: But he said the Senate is "moving in the right direction.

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: With these changes, it will make this a more efficient institution."

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: The liberal group Common Cause, which has filed a lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of the filibuster, criticized Reid for the agreement, saying the senator "has gone missing in the fight for filibuster reform."

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: As part of the agreement, filibusters could be avoided when the Senate tries beginning debate on legislation.

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: In return, the majority leader would have to allow each party to offer at least two amendments — addressing a major complaint of Republicans that their amendments are often shut out.

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: In addition, once the Senate votes to limit debate on certain nominations — district court judges and administration posts below Cabinet level — the debate would be limited to two hours, far below the 30 hours now allowed.

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: The proposal was aimed at speeding the time spent on such nominations.

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: In addition, instead of three separate opportunities for opponents of a bill to wage filibusters to block a Senate vote allowing the chamber to try writing compromise legislation with the House, there would only be one such filibuster allowed.

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: According to the Senate Historian's Office, there were 73 "cloture" votes to end filibusters in the two-year Congress that ended earlier this month.

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: There were 91 such votes in the Congress that served in the two previous years, and 112 in the two-year Congress before that.

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: Republicans were the Senate minority party in each of those Congresses.

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: Those are the three highest number of cloture votes in any Congress since the Senate started allowing such votes to end filibusters nearly 100 years ago.

column3: Senate OKs modest restrictions on filibusters
column4: ___ Associated Press writers Jim Abrams, Stephen Ohlemacher, Andrew Taylor and David Espo contributed to this report.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: WASHINGTON -- Progressive senators working to dramatically alter Senate rules were defeated on Thursday, with Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.) and his counterpart, Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.), set to announce a series of compromise reforms on the Senate floor that fall far short of the demands.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: The language of the deal was obtained by HuffPost and can be read here and here.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: The pressure from the liberal senators, led by Oregon Democrat Jeff Merkley and backed by a major coalition of progressive groups, created the political space for Reid to cut the deal with McConnell, which includes changes to how the Senate operates but leaves a fundamental feature, the silent filibuster, in place.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: The deal will address the filibuster on the motion to proceed by changing the amount of debate time that would follow a cloture vote from 30 hours to four, speeding up Senate business and allowing more legislation to reach the floor.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: But the deal still requires Democrats to muster 60 votes to invoke cloture on that motion, despite Reid's earlier suggestion that he would bar a filibuster on that motion entirely.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: An alternate route to get past the motion to proceed will be implemented as a change to the rules, and a filibuster on the motion would be barred if the majority can find eight members of the minority, including the minority leader, to sign a petition.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: But Democrats already have 55 members in their caucus, five short of the 60 needed to end a filibuster, so it's unclear what the purpose of getting three additional Republicans would be.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: Under the agreement, the minority party will be able to offer two amendments on each bill, a major concession to Republicans.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: This change is made only as a standing order, not a rules change, and expires at the end of the term.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: The new rules will also make it easier for the majority to appoint conferees once a bill has passed, but leaves in place the minority's ability to filibuster that motion once -- meaning that even after the Senate and House have passed a bill, the minority can still mount a filibuster one more time.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: Reid won concessions on district court nominations as well.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: Under the old rules, after a filibuster had been beaten, 30 more hours were required to pass before a nominee could finally be confirmed.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: That delay threatened to tie the chamber in knots.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: The new rules will only allow two hours to pass after cloture is invoked before a nominee is confirmed.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: The two leaders agreed that they will make some changes in how the Senate carries out filibusters under the existing rules, reminiscent of the handshake agreement last term, which quickly fell apart.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: First, senators who wish to object or threaten a filibuster must actually come to the floor to do so.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: And second, the two leaders will make sure that debate time post-cloture is actually used in debate.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: If senators seeking to slow down business simply put in quorum calls to delay action, the Senate will go live, force votes to produce a quorum, and otherwise work to make sure senators actually show up and debate.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: The arrangement between Reid and McConnell means that the majority leader will not resort to his controversial threat, known as the "nuclear option," to change the rules via 51 votes on the first day of the congressional session.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: Reid may have been able to achieve greater reforms that way, but several members of his own party were uncomfortable with the precedent it would have set.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: And Reid himself, an institutionalist, wanted a bipartisan deal for the long-term health of the institution.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: Reid presented McConnell with two offers -- one bipartisan accord consisting of weaker reforms, and a stronger package Reid was willing to ram through on a partisan vote.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: McConnell chose the bipartisan route.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: Supporters of the deal insist that even without using the "nuclear option," Reid was able to secure tangible changes on the pace and conduct of Senate business.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: The deal, said one top Democratic aide, is "not everything Reid wanted but there are significant changes.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: Everybody was so focused on the filibuster, but as you know there were a lot of Dems who really felt uncomfortable going there.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: Let's face it, if not for 60 then Roe v. Wade might be dead and Social Security would be private accounts.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: But, Reid gets the power to get on bills without having to file cloture.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: That's a big deal.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: Also, post cloture time for non appellate judges will be cut from 30 hours to 2.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: That's huge because now Reid can stack nominations, which forces the Repubs' hands."

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: Added another supportive Democratic Senate aide: "We are now a more efficient Senate; we'll be able to get on bills without having 60 votes and without having to spend a week to do it.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: We are getting the ability to confirm certain nominees who have objections against them.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: Instead of taking a week to confirm them, it'll take a few hours.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: That's all Reid ever really wanted."

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: The compromise is a blow to Merkley, who had been the most outspoken proponent of what he called the "talking filibuster," which would change current rules so that the minority couldn't filibuster a bill by simply objecting and sitting down or leaving the chamber.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: Once that provision looked to be faded, reformers gravitated toward a proposal from Reid that would flip the onus onto the minority by requiring Republicans to affirmatively come up with 41 votes to sustain a filibuster, rather than requiring Democrats to find 60 to end it.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: Reid was only willing to go forward with such a move if McConnell had rejected his offer.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: At Tuesday's closed-door caucus meeting, Merkley was upbraided by Reid for breaking unspoken Senate rules and naming specific senators in a conference call with Democratic activists last week, according to sources familiar with the exchange.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: "He's pissed off so many in the caucus," said one Democratic aide piqued at Merkley.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: "He has been having conference calls with progressive donors and activists trying to get them energized.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: He's named specific Dem Senators.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: Many are furious.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: He was called out on Tuesday in caucus and very well could be again today."

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: A Reid staffer was on the conference call with the activists and donors, and Merkley's move was reported the next day by Politico: On a private call with the Bay Area Democrats on Wednesday, Merkley identified Reid as the key person in the talks, and he urged activists to target members of Reid’s leadership team ahead of their meetings next week, according to people on the call.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: ), Patrick Leahy (Vt.), Dianne Feinstein (Calif.), Barbara Boxer (Calif.), Joe Manchin (West.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: Fix the Senate Now, a coalition of over 50 progressive and labor organizations that has been tirelessly advocating for an end to the silent filibuster, called the emerging deal a "missed opportunity."

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: "While the provisions included in the likely agreement may help with streamlining certain nominations, potentially a significant step forward, the agreement avoids measures that would actually raise the costs of Senate obstruction," the group said in a statement.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: "Neither the talking filibuster provision nor the shifting the burden provision is expected to be included in the final package.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: While certain details remain important and unresolved, such as potential conditions attached to the elimination of filibusters on the motion to proceed, we know enough to sum up the agreement as follows: a missed opportunity to provide meaningful filibuster reform, while advancing some decent procedural improvements."

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: In its statement, Fix the Senate Now also praised the "tireless advocacy" of Merkley and fellow Sens.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: Tom Harkin (D-Iowa) and Tom Udall (D-N.M.).

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: The coalition had been pushing for the Senate to adopt Merkley's talking filibuster proposal, and also called on Reid to implement other far-reaching reforms, such as requiring the minority to find 41 votes to maintain a filibuster.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: If the agreement proceeds as expected, the group said, the Senate "will have missed an opportunity to restore accountability and deliberation to the Senate, while not raising the costs of obstruction."

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: CREDO, another group that had been pressuring the Senate to pass strong filibuster reform, criticized the deal in a statement.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: "In 2010, Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid sold out Senate Democrats by striking a 'gentleman's agreement' with Republican Minority Leader McConnell instead of pushing for strong filibuster reform," said Becky Bond, CREDO's political director.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: "And now he's done the exact same thing, again.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: When will Democratic Leadership learn the lesson that Republicans will not negotiate in good faith?"

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: "The bipartisan deal Sen. Reid struck is a compromised bait and switch deal which he and Sen. McConnell call filibuster reform, but we know will do next to nothing to actually fix the filibuster."

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: UPDATE: 4:00 p.m. -- As Senate Democrats trickled out of their caucus meeting, where Reid presented his deal with McConnell, the consensus appeared to be that while the reforms were not as far-reaching as they had hoped, compromise was better than taking matters into their own hands.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: "It's a compromise, and I'm big on that," said Sen. Claire McCaskill (D-Mo.).

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: "I think it's progress, and we're starting on the right foot.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: And if we would have started with blowing everything up, I think it would have been months before we could get back to a place where we could hope to try to really get back to regular order."

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: Sen. Dick Durbin (D-Ill.) said the deal was a real agreement between both leaders.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: "That is a very positive environment to start this session," he said.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: Asked about complaints from filibuster reform advocates who were seeking an end to the silent filibuster, Durbin essentially said that life isn't always fair.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: "Let me tell you, that's how this world works," he said.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: "People start aspiring at very high levels, then you get a negotiation, then you reach something called compromise.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: And I think we are at that point."

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: Durbin said there was overwhelming support for the deal among Senate Democrats, though he conceded that he was uncertain whether it would make it easier to pass bills.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: "It can," he said.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: "It requires good will [and] good faith."

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: Durbin also backed up Reid's claim that he had the 51 votes necessary to use the so-called nuclear, or constitutional, option, but he said the goal was always to avoid using extreme measures and instead reach a compromise that both the majority and minority would be comfortable with.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: McCaskill, too, hinted that more could have been done had Reid gone forth without Republicans -- but she remained enthusiastic about the deal's prospects.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: "Will it work as well as some of us want to?

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: That remains to be seen," she said.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: "But it's going to be better."

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: Sen. Carl Levin (D-Mich.), who cosponsored the bipartisan bill that the final deal most closely resembles, had no complaints.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: "It'll give great momentum to working on a bipartisan basis in the Senate," Levin said.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: "What we've avoided in a bipartisan approach is the use of this nuclear option or constitutional option, which Democrats strongly opposed when the Republicans threatened it a few years ago."

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: "If it were used, if it had to be used, it would have turned a gridlock into a meltdown," he added.

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal
column4: "The Senate would have had a meltdown."

column3: Harry Reid, Mitch McConnell Reach Filibuster Reform Deal

column3: Louisiana Gov. Jindal calls on GOP to 'recalibrate' at RNC's winter meeting
column4: CHARLOTTE, North Carolina –  Louisiana Gov.

column3: Louisiana Gov. Jindal calls on GOP to 'recalibrate' at RNC's winter meeting
column4: Bobby Jindal called on the Republican Party to "stop being the stupid party" on Thursday as GOP leaders promised fundamental changes to help stave off future losses.

column3: Louisiana Gov. Jindal calls on GOP to 'recalibrate' at RNC's winter meeting
column4: In the keynote address at the Republican National Committee's winter meeting, Jindal said the GOP doesn't need to change its values but "might need to change just about everything else we are doing."

column3: Louisiana Gov. Jindal calls on GOP to 'recalibrate' at RNC's winter meeting
column4: "We've got to stop being the stupid party.

column3: Louisiana Gov. Jindal calls on GOP to 'recalibrate' at RNC's winter meeting
column4: It's time for a new Republican Party that talks like adults," he said.

column3: Louisiana Gov. Jindal calls on GOP to 'recalibrate' at RNC's winter meeting
column4: "We had a number of Republicans damage the brand this year with offensive and bizarre comments.

column3: Louisiana Gov. Jindal calls on GOP to 'recalibrate' at RNC's winter meeting
column4: I'm here to say we've had enough of that."

column3: Louisiana Gov. Jindal calls on GOP to 'recalibrate' at RNC's winter meeting
column4: Jindal, thought to be a potential 2016 presidential contender, offered little detail in the 25-minute address.

column3: Louisiana Gov. Jindal calls on GOP to 'recalibrate' at RNC's winter meeting
column4: He called on conservatives to shift their focus from Capitol Hill number crunching to "the place where conservatism thrives -- in the real world beyond the Washington Beltway."

column3: Louisiana Gov. Jindal calls on GOP to 'recalibrate' at RNC's winter meeting
column4: Hours before the speech, Republican leaders promised to release in March a report, dubbed the "Growth and Opportunity Project," outlining recommendations on party rules and messaging designed to appeal to a rapidly changing American electorate.

column3: Louisiana Gov. Jindal calls on GOP to 'recalibrate' at RNC's winter meeting
column4: President Barack Obama's November victory was fueled, in part, by overwhelming support from the nation's Hispanic, Asian and African-American communities.

column3: Louisiana Gov. Jindal calls on GOP to 'recalibrate' at RNC's winter meeting
column4: "Losing is not fun.

column3: Louisiana Gov. Jindal calls on GOP to 'recalibrate' at RNC's winter meeting
column4: We want to win," said GOP strategist Sally Bradshaw, who is among five people appointed by RNC Chairman Reince Priebus to craft the report.

column3: Louisiana Gov. Jindal calls on GOP to 'recalibrate' at RNC's winter meeting
column4: "I think you're going to see a very renewed, aggressive effort by this party to put on a different face," Bradshaw said.

column3: Louisiana Gov. Jindal calls on GOP to 'recalibrate' at RNC's winter meeting
column4: "We are going to go into areas that we do not go into and see folks that we do not see."

column3: Louisiana Gov. Jindal calls on GOP to 'recalibrate' at RNC's winter meeting
column4: Republicans presidential nominee Mitt Romney struggled last fall to win over women and minorities, who overwhelmingly favored President Barack Obama's re-election bid.

column3: Louisiana Gov. Jindal calls on GOP to 'recalibrate' at RNC's winter meeting
column4: GOP officials conceded this week that they must change their tone and message, if not their policies, if they hope to expand their appeal in the coming years.

column3: Louisiana Gov. Jindal calls on GOP to 'recalibrate' at RNC's winter meeting
column4: Romney alienated many Hispanic voters by highlighting his support for a fence along the Mexican border and "self-deportation" of illegal immigrants.

column3: Louisiana Gov. Jindal calls on GOP to 'recalibrate' at RNC's winter meeting
column4: Down-ticket Republican candidates alienated female voters by backing new abortion laws in a handful of swing states like Virginia and New Hampshire, while Senate candidate Todd Akin of Missouri hurt himself and his party by declaring that women's bodies could prevent pregnancy in cases of "legitimate rape."

column3: Louisiana Gov. Jindal calls on GOP to 'recalibrate' at RNC's winter meeting
column4: GOP strategist Ari Fleischer suggested that his party could learn an important lesson from Democrats on messaging: "Republicans talk policy and Democrats talk people.

column3: Louisiana Gov. Jindal calls on GOP to 'recalibrate' at RNC's winter meeting
column4: Republicans can learn a little bit from Democrats on how to make those people connections with our policies."

column3: Louisiana Gov. Jindal calls on GOP to 'recalibrate' at RNC's winter meeting
column4: Asked whether he was considering a presidential bid in 2016, Jindal brushed aside the question.

column3: Louisiana Gov. Jindal calls on GOP to 'recalibrate' at RNC's winter meeting
column4: "Any Republican that's thinking about talking about running for president in 2016 needs to get his head examined," he said.

column3: Louisiana Gov. Jindal calls on GOP to 'recalibrate' at RNC's winter meeting
column4: "We've got a lot of work to do."

column3: Louisiana Gov. Jindal calls on GOP to 'recalibrate' at RNC's winter meeting
column4: He called on conservatives to stop fighting with Democrats on their terms about the size of government in Washington and focus instead on connecting with voters across the nation.

column3: Louisiana Gov. Jindal calls on GOP to 'recalibrate' at RNC's winter meeting
column4: "Today's conservatism is completely wrapped up in solving the hideous mess that is the federal budget, the burgeoning deficits, the mammoth federal debt, the shortfall in our entitlement programs," he said.

column3: Louisiana Gov. Jindal calls on GOP to 'recalibrate' at RNC's winter meeting
column4: "We seem to have an obsession with government bookkeeping.

column3: Louisiana Gov. Jindal calls on GOP to 'recalibrate' at RNC's winter meeting
column4: This is a rigged game, and it is the wrong game for us to play."

column3: Louisiana Gov. Jindal calls on GOP to 'recalibrate' at RNC's winter meeting
column4: Jindal's comments come a day after the House passed a bill to permit the government to borrow enough money to avoid a first-time default for at least four months, defusing a looming crisis setting up a springtime debate over taxes, spending and the deficit.

column3: Louisiana Gov. Jindal calls on GOP to 'recalibrate' at RNC's winter meeting
column4: The House passed the measure on a bipartisan basis as majority Republicans back away from their previous demand that any increase in the government's borrowing cap be paired with an equivalent level of spending cuts.

column3: Louisiana Gov. Jindal calls on GOP to 'recalibrate' at RNC's winter meeting
column4: The Louisiana governor's blunt remarks follow criticism from another high-profile Republican based outside Washington who publicly blasted GOP leadership on Capitol Hill: New Jersey Gov.

column3: Louisiana Gov. Jindal calls on GOP to 'recalibrate' at RNC's winter meeting
column4: Chris Christie.

column3: Louisiana Gov. Jindal calls on GOP to 'recalibrate' at RNC's winter meeting
column4: One of the party's most popular voices, Christie earlier in the month criticized his party's `'toxic internal politics" after House Republicans initially declined to approve disaster relief for victims of Superstorm Sandy.

column3: Louisiana Gov. Jindal calls on GOP to 'recalibrate' at RNC's winter meeting
column4: He said it was `'disgusting to watch" their actions and he faulted the GOP's most powerful elected official, House Speaker John Boehner, R-Ohio.

column3: Louisiana Gov. Jindal calls on GOP to 'recalibrate' at RNC's winter meeting
column4: Former House Speaker Newt Gingrich, R-Ga., told reporters on the sidelines of the meeting Thursday that Republicans also need to develop a sound strategy for confronting the Obama administration, suggesting House Republicans could use hearings to expose waste and promote better ideas.

column3: Louisiana Gov. Jindal calls on GOP to 'recalibrate' at RNC's winter meeting

column3: Louisiana Gov. Jindal calls on GOP to 'recalibrate' at RNC's winter meeting

column3: Louisiana Gov. Jindal calls on GOP to 'recalibrate' at RNC's winter meeting

column3: GOP Considers Strategy from Obama's Playbook
column4: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — As Republican leaders gathered here on Thursday to consider how to rebuild their party, President Obama was at the center of the conversation.

column3: GOP Considers Strategy from Obama's Playbook
column4: But the sharp criticism directed at him was replaced by something new: envy over his campaign.

column3: GOP Considers Strategy from Obama's Playbook
column4: The Republican National Committee is reviewing the party’s deficiencies, particularly in technology and grass-roots organizing, that contributed to Mitt Romney’s sound defeat last year.

column3: GOP Considers Strategy from Obama's Playbook
column4: The excuses and grievances that several top Republicans offered up after the election have been supplanted by pledges to strengthen the party.

column3: GOP Considers Strategy from Obama's Playbook
column4: “We need to get people organized and learn from what Obama did,” said Mike Duncan, a former national party chairman who now represents Kentucky on the committee.

column3: GOP Considers Strategy from Obama's Playbook
column4: “We’ve got to reverse engineer what they did and leapfrog to the next cycle.” As Republicans look for a path to victory, party officials from all 50 states convened here at the winter meeting of the Republican National Committee.

column3: GOP Considers Strategy from Obama's Playbook
column4: There was less finger-pointing than soul-searching, and Republican leaders acknowledged the urgent need to make the party more welcoming to a broader cross-section of Americans, particularly women, Hispanics and blacks.

column3: GOP Considers Strategy from Obama's Playbook
column4: “The Republican Party does not need to change our principles, but we might need to change just about everything else we are doing,” said Gov.

column3: GOP Considers Strategy from Obama's Playbook
column4: Bobby Jindal of Louisiana.

column3: GOP Considers Strategy from Obama's Playbook
column4: It was time, he said, “to recalibrate the compass of conservatism.” There was more discussion about the challenges facing Republicans than the solutions.

column3: GOP Considers Strategy from Obama's Playbook
column4: But in interviews, Republican officials from across the country said a new tone is needed, and they called on the party to take cues from its 30 governors rather than become consumed by Republicans’ differences in Washington.

column3: GOP Considers Strategy from Obama's Playbook
column4: Tensions remain high among the Tea Party movement, the Republican establishment and other segments of the party, who are at odds over fiscal issues and taxes in Congress.

column3: GOP Considers Strategy from Obama's Playbook
column4: Immigration policy and other measures also threaten to divide the party in the 2014 midterm elections, when Republicans are seeking to keep their House majority and win back the Senate.

column3: GOP Considers Strategy from Obama's Playbook
column4: “The tone does have to change,” said Gov.

column3: GOP Considers Strategy from Obama's Playbook
column4: Pat McCrory of North Carolina, who called for “a tone of respecting the other side’s opinion.” He said Republicans also should not bow to all viewpoints inside the party, declaring, “When you try to appease everyone, you satisfy no one.” A five-member panel of the Republican National Committee, known as the Growth and Opportunity Project, is scheduled to release a report in March outlining recommendations for strengthening the party, with the primary goal to win the White House in 2016.

column3: GOP Considers Strategy from Obama's Playbook
column4: The group is reviewing how Republicans fell short last year and how the Republican primaries might have weakened Mr. Romney.

column3: GOP Considers Strategy from Obama's Playbook
column4: Sally Bradshaw, a party strategist in Florida who is an adviser to former Gov.

column3: GOP Considers Strategy from Obama's Playbook
column4: Jeb Bush, said Republicans needed to recruit stronger and more diverse candidates to win races.

column3: GOP Considers Strategy from Obama's Playbook
column4: Her assignment on the panel includes a review of how Republicans and their get-out-the-vote operation were overwhelmed by the Obama campaign.

column3: GOP Considers Strategy from Obama's Playbook
column4: “I think you’re going to see a very renewed, aggressive effort by this party to put on a different face,” Ms. Bradshaw said.

column3: GOP Considers Strategy from Obama's Playbook
column4: “We are going to go into areas that we do not go into and see folks that we do not see.” Henry Barbour, a member of the Republican National Committee from Mississippi who is also on the panel, said the party should not dilute its conservative values, but it needed to broaden its appeal to compete with Democrats.

column3: GOP Considers Strategy from Obama's Playbook
column4: “We did get whipped in the presidential election, and that’s not something that is taken lightly,” Mr. Barbour said.

column3: GOP Considers Strategy from Obama's Playbook
column4: “The demographic changes in America are real, and they are a wake-up call to the Republican Party.” Newt Gingrich, the former House speaker, who competed with Mr. Romney for the Republican presidential nomination, said that the party had been “outmaneuvered” by the Obama campaign and that its ideas were not creative enough.

column3: GOP Considers Strategy from Obama's Playbook
column4: He held court with committee members — and reporters — here on Thursday and said Republicans were responsible for their own fate.

column3: GOP Considers Strategy from Obama's Playbook
column4: “A lot of Republicans, frankly, spent the last two years saying, ‘Oh, gee, we don’t have to do much because after Obama loses we’ll work with the new Republican president,’ ” Mr. Gingrich said.

column3: GOP Considers Strategy from Obama's Playbook
column4: “Well, that world ain’t there, so now they have to make adjustments.

column3: GOP Considers Strategy from Obama's Playbook
column4: They’ve got to understand that this is a different game.” Despite the party’s divisions and its disappointment about losing the White House and seats in both the House and Senate, the 168-member committee is poised to re-elect its chairman, Reince Priebus, to a second term on Friday.

column3: GOP Considers Strategy from Obama's Playbook
column4: In 2011, Mr. Priebus inherited a party that was deeply in debt, but he has turned around the committee’s finances, which members said explained why he had no serious opposition.

column3: GOP Considers Strategy from Obama's Playbook
column4: Mr. Priebus said he would lead a Republican rebuilding effort in all 50 states rather than simply focus on battleground states.

column3: GOP Considers Strategy from Obama's Playbook
column4: In Congressional races next year, he said, the party would try to improve its standing with voters who have shied away from Republicans.

column3: GOP Considers Strategy from Obama's Playbook
column4: “To those who have left the party, we want to earn your trust again,” Mr. Priebus will say in his acceptance speech on Friday, according to excerpts released by his aides.

column3: GOP Considers Strategy from Obama's Playbook
column4: “To those who have yet to join us, we welcome you, with open doors and open arms.”

column3: Hillary Clinton's last trip to the Hill?
column4: It was probably not the way she would have chosen to go out.

column3: Hillary Clinton's last trip to the Hill?
column4: Wednesday’s combative Senate hearing on the Benghazi attacks was one of Secretary of State Hillary Clinton’s last, most high-profile public appearances of her time at Foggy Bottom.

column3: Hillary Clinton's last trip to the Hill?
column4: Story Continued Below (PHOTOS: Hillary Clinton's many expressions at the Benghazi hearing) In a few days, one of the most famous women on the planet will step off the public stage for the first time in 30 years — and she’s not going quietly.

column3: Hillary Clinton's last trip to the Hill?
column4: She choked up, she raised her voice, she took full responsibility for the death of U.S.

column3: Hillary Clinton's last trip to the Hill?
column4: Ambassador Chris Stevens and three others, and she was defiant.

column3: Hillary Clinton's last trip to the Hill?
column4: When Sen. Ron Johnson (R-Wis.) pressed her on who knew what when, she slapped him down with a raised voice: “With all due respect, four Americans were dead.

column3: Hillary Clinton's last trip to the Hill?
column4: What difference at this point does it make?” ( PHOTOS: Clinton’s best Benghazi hearing lines) This was no gauzy farewell tour, no clubby appearance before her former Senate colleagues, although most thanked her for her service.

column3: Hillary Clinton's last trip to the Hill?
column4: She will be back Thursday to introduce her likely successor, Sen. John Kerry (D-Mass.

column3: Hillary Clinton's last trip to the Hill?
column4: ), before the committee.

column3: Hillary Clinton's last trip to the Hill?
column4: Left unsaid, however: this is likely not her ultimate act.

column3: Hillary Clinton's last trip to the Hill?
column4: Already, the question — will she run for president?

column3: Hillary Clinton's last trip to the Hill?
column4: — follows her around relentlessly.

column3: Hillary Clinton's last trip to the Hill?
column4: And if there were any consolation for Clinton on Wednesday, it doesn’t seem that the American public is holding the former first lady responsible for the death of four Americans in Libya, even as some Republican senators tried their level best to pin it on her.

column3: Hillary Clinton's last trip to the Hill?
column4: ( Also on POLITICO: McCain, Paul take on Clinton on Benghazi) She’s leaving with the highest approval ratings of her political career — 67 percent of all Americans, and 91 percent of Democrats approve of her, according to a new Washington Post/ABC News poll, while only 26 percent disapprove.

column3: Hillary Clinton's last trip to the Hill?
column4: Despite a health scare last month, she showed up and came out swinging for a pair of Hill hearings this week.

column3: Hillary Clinton's last trip to the Hill?
column4: “The world is at her doorstep.

column3: Hillary Clinton's last trip to the Hill?
column4: She can ride into the sunset, write books, broker international events and certainly run for president in 2016 if she chooses,” said former Democratic campaign operative Steve Jarding, a lecturer in Public Policy at Harvard’s Center for Public Leadership.

column3: Hillary Clinton's last trip to the Hill?
column4: For most of Clinton’s adult life, there has always been another mountain to climb: Yale lawyer, first lady, U.S. senator, first serious female presidential candidate and secretary of state.

column3: Hillary Clinton's last trip to the Hill?
column4: But as she leaves her secretary of state post, her path is not at all clear.

column3: Hillary Clinton's last trip to the Hill?
column4: ( Also on POLITICO: Pol: Clinton evaded with ‘theatrics’) As Vice President Joe Biden ricochets around town this week like a roadrunner on Red Bull, leaving little doubt he’s eyeing 2016, Clinton is approaching her future with caution and equanimity — and if we take her at face value — without a real plan.

column3: Hillary Clinton's last hurrah? A lasting image while explaining Benghazi
column4: ANALYSIS/OPINION: ANALYSIS/OPINION: The “old” Hillary Rodham Clinton emerged yesterday in the congressional hearings about what happened in Benghazi, and it’s the Hillary image that’s likely to last.

column3: Hillary Clinton's last hurrah? A lasting image while explaining Benghazi
column4: Pressed for the first time to answer sharp public questioning about her part in the episode, she grew angry and combative, more like the Hillary who screamed vulgarities and threw lamps at her husband at the White House than a smooth and accommodating secretary of state.

column3: Hillary Clinton's last hurrah? A lasting image while explaining Benghazi
column4: Occasionally raising her voice to a shout and scream, with her face contorted by something little short of rage, she could barely hold back tears only minutes later.

column3: Hillary Clinton's last hurrah? A lasting image while explaining Benghazi
column4: She told the senators that it was the labyrinthine bureaucracy of the State Department — “the fudge factory,” as her predecessors have called it — that was at fault for the evasion, invention and confusion in the several stories put out by the Obama administration in the immediate aftermath of Benghazi.

column3: Hillary Clinton's last hurrah? A lasting image while explaining Benghazi
column4: She reminded the senators that a board of both Republicans and Democrats investigated the attack on the U.S. Consulate at Benghazi and the board “made it very clear that the level of responsibility for the failures that they outlined were set by the assistant secretary of state and below.

column3: Hillary Clinton's last hurrah? A lasting image while explaining Benghazi
column4: These requests don’t ordinarily come to the secretary of state.” This was not good enough for Sen. Rand Paul, the freshman Republican senator from Kentucky.

column3: Hillary Clinton's last hurrah? A lasting image while explaining Benghazi
column4: “I think ultimately with your leaving [the State Department] you accept culpability for the worst tragedy since Sept. 11, [2001],” he told her.

column3: Hillary Clinton's last hurrah? A lasting image while explaining Benghazi
column4: “If I’d been president at the time and I’d found that you did not read the cables from Benghazi, that you did not read the cables from Ambassador [J. Christopher] Stevens, I would have relieved you of your post.

column3: Hillary Clinton's last hurrah? A lasting image while explaining Benghazi
column4: Not to know of the requests for security, really, I think cost these people their lives.” When Sen. Ron Johnson, Wisconsin Republican, asked why someone hadn’t interviewed survivors of Benghazi before Susan E. Rice, the U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, was sent out to deliberately offer a false account of what happened, Mrs. Clinton exploded with sarcasm.

column3: Hillary Clinton's last hurrah? A lasting image while explaining Benghazi
column4: “With all due respect,” she replied, in a voice that didn’t sound overflowing with respect, “Was it because of a protest or was it because of guys out for a walk one night who decided they’d go kill some Americans, what difference at this point does it make?” This was truly tough stuff, to be held responsible for four people losing their lives.

column3: Hillary Clinton's last hurrah? A lasting image while explaining Benghazi
column4: Mrs. Clinton was unsettled for the rest of the day.

column3: Hillary Clinton's last hurrah? A lasting image while explaining Benghazi
column4: She repeated several times the assertion that she accepted responsibility for the mistakes her department made on Sept. 11, 2012, but was told in official proceedings for the first time that the fault, as well as the responsibility, was hers.

column3: Hillary Clinton's last hurrah? A lasting image while explaining Benghazi
column4: Hillary Clinton has lived in a soap opera since she first arrived from Arkansas as the wife of a credible candidate for president of the United States.

column3: Hillary Clinton's last hurrah? A lasting image while explaining Benghazi
column4: Over the years, she cast several images of herself, some flattering and some not.

column3: Hillary Clinton's last hurrah? A lasting image while explaining Benghazi
column4: She was the emotionally abused wife, standing at her husband’s side in the 1992 New Hampshire primary but not, she famously said, willing to take the advice of country-music singer Tammy Wynette to “stand by your man.” But when her husband introduced millions of Americans to their first public discussion of oral sex and was accused of sexual dalliance by a White House intern less than half his age, she not only stood by her man but cast herself as his avenging angel, accusing the critics of her man of working together in “a vast right-wing conspiracy.” With the White House years behind her, she moved to New York and, having never lived in New York and neither knowing the way to Schenectady nor the shuffle to Buffalo, succeeded as a celebrity senator.

column3: Hillary Clinton's last hurrah? A lasting image while explaining Benghazi
column4: She cast herself, with considerable help from her husband’s genius for politics, as the inevitable president in 2008, only to see her candidacy evaporate in the cool shadow of Barack Obama.

column3: Hillary Clinton's last hurrah? A lasting image while explaining Benghazi
column4: She drew praise from both friend and old foe as secretary of state, performing flawlessly as the president’s voice abroad.

column3: Hillary Clinton's last hurrah? A lasting image while explaining Benghazi
column4: Until Benghazi.

column3: Hillary Clinton's last hurrah? A lasting image while explaining Benghazi
column4: Nothing about Benghazi makes anyone in the Obama government look good.

column3: Hillary Clinton's last hurrah? A lasting image while explaining Benghazi
column4: The hearings Wednesday in Congress were in all likelihood Hillary’s last hurrah.

column3: Hillary Clinton's last hurrah? A lasting image while explaining Benghazi
column4: There was little to hurrah about.

column3: Hillary Clinton's last hurrah? A lasting image while explaining Benghazi
column4: It’s how Washington will remember her.

column3: Hillary Clinton's last hurrah? A lasting image while explaining Benghazi

column3: Last Hoorah: Panetta Lifts Ban on Women in Combat
column4: On his way out the door as Defense Secretary, Leon Panetta has lifted the ban on women serving in combat roles on the front lines of our wars.

column3: Last Hoorah: Panetta Lifts Ban on Women in Combat
column4: More from AP: Senior defense officials say Pentagon chief Leon Panetta is removing the military's ban on women serving in combat, opening hundreds of thousands of front-line positions and potentially elite commando jobs after more than a decade at war.

column3: Last Hoorah: Panetta Lifts Ban on Women in Combat
column4: The groundbreaking move recommended by the Joint Chiefs of Staff overturns a 1994 rule banning women from being assigned to smaller ground combat units.

column3: Last Hoorah: Panetta Lifts Ban on Women in Combat
column4: Panetta's decision gives the military services until January 2016 to seek special exceptions if they believe any positions must remain closed to women.

column3: Last Hoorah: Panetta Lifts Ban on Women in Combat
column4: Question: Does this mean women will now be required by law to sign up for the draft at the age of 18?

column3: Last Hoorah: Panetta Lifts Ban on Women in Combat
column4: Equal rights, equal fights.

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: Secretary of State Hillary Clinton began her long-awaited testimony Wednesday on the Benghazi terror attack by taking "responsibility" -- but she used the full day of hearings to repeatedly deny involvement in key controversies and pointedly reject the allegations of Republican lawmakers.

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: The at times heated testimony before House and Senate committees, likely to be the outgoing secretary's last, elicited praise from Democrats and frustration from Republicans.

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: Far from putting the issue to rest, the testimony further fueled a debate that has raged on Capitol Hill for four months.

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: Though she said officials are following some "very promising leads" on the terrorists, Clinton herself acknowledged there are still several open questions about what prompted the attack that night.

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: The secretary battled tough criticism from lawmakers throughout the day.

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: In one of the final jabs of the session, Rep. Jeff Duncan, R-S.C., told her, "Madame Secretary, you let the consulate become a death trap."

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: He was referring to the administration's initial claim that the attack sprung out of a protest.

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: It was later determined there was no protest on the ground in Benghazi.

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: "We were misled that there were supposedly protests and something sprang out of that," Johnson said.

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: "The American people could have known that (there was no protest) within days, and they didn't know that."

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: At that point, Clinton began to raise her voice.

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: "With all due respect, the fact is we had four dead Americans," she said.

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: "I understand," Johnson said.

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: Clinton continued to speak, raising her voice and gesturing: "Was it because of a protest or is it because of guys out for a walk one night and they decide they go kill some Americans?

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: "What difference, at this point, does it make?"

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: Clinton, lowering her voice, then said it is the administration's job to "figure out what happened" and prevent it from happening again.

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: Later in the testimony before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Clinton acknowledged the administration did not have a "clear picture" of what happened in the immediate aftermath.

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: She said perhaps officials didn't do a good enough job explaining that they "didn't have a clear picture."

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: But Clinton still said the motivations of the attackers, to this day, are not clear.

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: "Even today there are questions being raised," she said, referring to findings in the classified version of a recent report that she could not describe in detail.

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: Clinton, throughout the hearing, walked a fine line between taking responsibility generally for what went wrong and challenging specific allegations against her department and the administration.

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: During the opening of the hearing, Clinton said she has "no higher priority" than the security of her department's staff, and that she is committed to making the department "safer, stronger and more secure."

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: "As I have said many times, I take responsibility, and nobody is more committed to getting this right," Clinton said, later choking up when describing how she greeted the families of the victims when the caskets were returned.

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: Clinton went on to deny having ever seen the requests for more security from the Libya team that were denied by officials within the State Department.

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: "I didn't see those requests, they didn't come to me," Clinton said, adding those kinds of requests wouldn't normally come to the secretary.

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: Sen. Rand Paul, R-Ky., later suggested lives could have been saved if Clinton were more involved in reviewing security requests.

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: He said that if he were president, "I would have relieved you from your post."

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: Clinton, while pushing back against Johnson, also said she was not involved in crafting the controversial statements that U.S.

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: Then there is the decision by Clinton and State Department Undersecretary of Management Patrick Kennedy not to mobilize the Counterterrorism Security Group, which is composed of experts on terrorism from across government agencies and makes recommendations on the response to crises involving terrorism.

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: Further, there are questions about the perceived delays CIA officials -- stationed in Benghazi -- encountered that night and their frustration that air support was not sent from nearby Sigonella air base.

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: In recent weeks, Fox News has learned that the rescue unit that left Tripoli was told that air support would be above when they landed in Benghazi.

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: It wasn't.

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: During the hearing on the House side Wednesday afternoon, Clinton was also pressed on why she was never interviewed by the State Department-sponsored board that investigated the incident.

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: Rep. Ileana Ros-Lehtinen, R-Fla., said that was "outrageous."

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: Clinton said the board thought she was not "relevant" to their investigation because they were focusing on security officials.

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: She said she "gladly" would have spoken with them.

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: She also addressed concerns about the four State Department officials who were removed from their jobs in the fallout from the attack - but were not removed from the department.

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: She suggested federal law restricts what disciplinary measures could be taken against them.

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: The hearing Wednesday comes amid a broadening threat to U.S. interests across North Africa.

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: There are reports that some of the attackers who took hostages in the deadly raid on an Algeria gas plant may have also participated in the Libya attack.

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: "Benghazi did not happen in a vacuum," Clinton said Wednesday, while saying later she could not verify that specific claim.

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: She said instability has created an "expanding safe haven for terrorists" who plot into Algeria and other countries.

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: Sen. Bob Corker, R-Tenn., top Republican on the Senate committee, lamented "the spiking of the ball and the thinking that when Usama bin Laden was gone that was the end of Al Qaeda."

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: "We know nothing could be further from the truth," he said.

column3: Clinton denies 'delay' in Benghazi response, despite accounts
column4: Clinton appeared to agree that the terrorist threat is far from diminished, saying Al Qaeda "wannabes" and "affiliates" continue to pose a challenge.

column3: Hillary Clinton takes blame for Benghazi
column4: Secretary of State Hillary Clinton engaged in six hours of sometimes aggressive questioning from both sides of Capitol Hill on Wednesday over the deaths of four Americans in the attack on U.S. diplomatic outposts in Benghazi, Libya.

column3: Hillary Clinton takes blame for Benghazi
column4: Clinton — whose testimony was delayed for more than a month because of health reasons — stood her ground in a tenser hearing before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee in the morning and wasn’t rattled in an afternoon outing before the GOP-controlled House Foreign Affairs Committee, where boosterism ran high over a possible 2016 presidential bid.
