column3: Obama would sign short debt ceiling extension
column4: The White House praised House Republicans for deciding to forgo a fight over raising the nation’s borrowing limit and said President Obama would likely sign a three-month extension of the debt ceiling even though he would prefer a longer-term deal.

column3: Obama would sign short debt ceiling extension
column4: House Republicans are set to vote on the three-month extension Wednesday, and White House spokesman Jay Carney said the president “would not stand in the way” if Congress approves the deal and it reaches his desk.

column3: Obama would sign short debt ceiling extension
column4: “What we saw happen last week was significant,” Mr. Carney said.

column3: Obama would sign short debt ceiling extension
column4: “House Republicans made a decision to back away from the kind of brinksmanship that was very concerning to the markets, very concerning to business, very concerning to the American people …The fact that House Republicans made this decision is certainly something that we welcome.” At a House GOP retreat last week, Republican leaders suggested the three-month extension as a way to de-escalate a number of budget issues all coming to a head in the next few months.

column3: Obama would sign short debt ceiling extension
column4: Mr. Obama has repeatedly insisted he would not bargain over the debt ceiling rise, as he did in an earlier showdown in the summer of 2011 that contributed to a downgrading of the country’s AAA credit rating.

column3: Obama would sign short debt ceiling extension
column4: Mr. Obama would prefer a long-term debt extension, but Mr. Carney said the president believes the three-month proposal could be constructive because it “de-escalates the sense of conflict.” The Treasury Department said the country already hit the $16.4 trillion debt ceiling at the end of the year and has since been using a series of budget gimmicks to buy time.

column3: Obama would sign short debt ceiling extension
column4: After mid-February, however, the department said it will start running out of ways to keep the government from defaulting on its bills.

column3: Obama would sign short debt ceiling extension
column4: Several prominent Republicans, including Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell of Kentucky have pushed for the party to use the debt-ceiling limit as way to extract spending cuts from Democrats by threatening to let the country go into default.

column3: Obama would sign short debt ceiling extension
column4: Mr. Obama last week warned that any GOP attempt to leverage the nation’s borrowing limit for spending cuts as “irresponsible” and “absurd” because he said it would likely rock stock markets and could derail any chances for a fuller economic recovery this year.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: WASHINGTON — Barack Hussein Obama ceremonially opened his second term on Monday with an assertive Inaugural Address that offered a robust articulation of modern liberalism in America, arguing that “preserving our individual freedoms ultimately requires collective action.” On a day that echoed with refrains from the civil rights era and tributes to the Rev.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Mr. Obama dispensed with the post-partisan appeals of four years ago to lay out a forceful vision of advancing gay rights, showing more tolerance toward illegal immigrants, preserving the social welfare safety net and acting to stop climate change.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: At times he used his speech, delivered from the West Front of the Capitol, to reprise arguments from the fall campaign, rebutting the notion expressed by conservative opponents that America risks becoming “a nation of takers” and extolling the value of proactive government in society.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: Instead of declaring the end of “petty grievances,” as he did taking the oath as the 44th president in 2009, he challenged Republicans to step back from their staunch opposition to his agenda.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: “Progress does not compel us to settle centuries-old debates about the role of government for all time — but it does require us to act in our time,” he said in the 18-minute address.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: “For now decisions are upon us, and we cannot afford delay.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: We cannot mistake absolutism for principle or substitute spectacle for politics or treat name-calling as reasoned debate.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: We must act.” Mr. Obama used Abraham Lincoln’s Bible, as he did four years ago, but this time added Dr. King’s Bible as well to mark the holiday honoring the civil rights leader.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: He became the first president ever to mention the word “gay” in an Inaugural Address as he equated the drive for same-sex marriage to the quests for racial and gender equality.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: The festivities at the Capitol came a day after Mr. Obama officially took the oath in a quiet ceremony with his family at the White House on the date set by the Constitution.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: With Inauguration Day falling on a Sunday, the swearing-in was then repeated for an energized mass audience a day later, accompanied by the pomp and parade that typically surround the quadrennial tradition.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: Hundreds of thousands of people gathered on a brisk but bright day, a huge crowd by any measure, though far less than the record turnout four years ago.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: If the day felt restrained compared with the historic mood the last time, it reflected a more restrained moment in the life of the country.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: The hopes and expectations that loomed so large with Mr. Obama’s taking the office in 2009, even amid economic crisis, have long since faded into a starker sense of the limits of his presidency.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: Now 51 and noticeably grayer, Mr. Obama appeared alternately upbeat and reflective.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: When he re-entered the Capitol at the conclusion of the ceremony, he stopped his entourage to turn back toward the cheering crowds on the National Mall.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: “I want to take a look, one more time,” he said.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: “I’m not going to see this again.” If the president was wistful, his message was firm.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: He largely eschewed foreign policy except to recommend engagement over war, and instead focused on addressing poverty and injustice at home.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: He did little to adopt the language of the opposition, as he has done at moments in the past, and instead directly confronted conservative philosophy.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: “The commitments we make to each other — through Medicare and Medicaid and Social Security — these things do not sap our initiative; they strengthen us,” he said.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: “They do not make us a nation of takers; they free us to take the risks that make this country great.” The phrase, “nation of takers,” was a direct rebuke to Republicans like Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin, last year’s vice-presidential nominee, and several opposition lawmakers took umbrage at the president’s tone.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: “I would have liked to see a little more on outreach and working together,” said Senator John McCain of Arizona, the Republican who lost to Mr. Obama four years ago.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: “There was not, as I’ve seen in other inaugural speeches, ‘I want to work with my colleagues.’ ” Representative Pete Sessions of Texas, a member of the Republican leadership, said that from the opening prayer to the closing benediction, “It was apparent our country’s in chaos and what our great president has brought us is upheaval.” He added, “We’re now managing America’s demise, not America’s great future.” Mr. Obama struck a more conciliatory note during an unscripted toast during lunch with Congressional leaders in Statuary Hall after the ceremony.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: “Regardless of our political persuasions and perspectives, I know that all of us serve because we believe that we can make America for future generations,” he said.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: For the nation’s 57th presidential inauguration, a broad section of downtown Washington was off limits to vehicles and a major bridge across the Potomac River was closed to regular traffic as military Humvees were stationed at strategic locations around the city.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: Joining the president through the long day were the first lady, Michelle Obama, and their daughters, Malia, 14, and Sasha, 11.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: The young girls were playful.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: Malia at one point sneaked up behind her father and cried out, “Boo!” Sasha used a smartphone to take a picture of her parents kissing in the reviewing stand, then made them do it again.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: Both girls bounced with the martial music at the Capitol.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: Mr. Obama’s day began with a service at St. John’s Episcopal Church, across Lafayette Square from the White House, where the Rev.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: Andy Stanley told him to “leverage that power for the benefit of other people in the room.” At the Capitol, Myrlie Evers-Williams, the civil rights leader, delivered the invocation and the Brooklyn Tabernacle Choir performed the “Battle Hymn of the Republic.” Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. was sworn in at 11:46 a.m. by Justice Sonia Sotomayor.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: The singer James Taylor then performed “America the Beautiful.” At 11:50 a.m., Mr. Obama was sworn in again by Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. After the two mangled the 35-word oath four years ago, necessitating a just-in-case do-over the next day, the president and chief justice this time carefully recited the words in tandem without error, although Mr. Obama did swallow the word “states.” Mr. Obama was more specific in discussing policy than presidents typically are in an Inaugural Address.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: Particularly noticeable was his recommitment to fighting climate change.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: “We will respond to the threat of climate change, knowing that the failure to do so would betray our children and future generations,” he said.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: He referred only implicitly to terrorism, the issue that has so consumed the nation for the past decade, but offered a more inward-looking approach to foreign policy, saying that “enduring security and lasting peace do not require perpetual war.” He also talked of overhauling immigration rules so “bright young students and engineers are enlisted in our work force, rather than expelled from our country.” For a president who opposed same-sex marriage as recently as nine months ago, the speech was a clear call for gay rights, as he noted the journey “through Seneca Falls and Selma and Stonewall,” symbolically linking seminal moments in the struggles for equal rights for women, blacks and gay men and lesbians.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: “Our journey is not complete until our gay brothers and sisters are treated like anyone else under the law — for if we are truly created equal, then surely the love we commit to one another must be equal as well,” he said.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: The expanse between the Capitol and the Washington Monument was filled with supporters, many of them African-Americans attending only the second inauguration of a black president.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: As large TV screens flickered in and out and the audio often warbled, the ceremony was difficult to follow for many braving the Washington chill.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: The speech was followed by song, poem and benediction from Kelly Clarkson, Richard Blanco, the Rev.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: Luis Leon and Beyoncé.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: The president and first lady got out of their motorcade twice to walk stretches along Pennsylvania Avenue.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: Mr. Biden and Jill Biden did as well, and the vice president greeted bystanders with fist-pumping gusto.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: The two families then settled into the specially built bulletproof reviewing stand to watch the parade.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: Mr. Obama, who often uses Nicorette to tame an old smoking habit, was spotted chewing as the bands marched past.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: In the evening, the Obamas attended two official inaugural balls, down from 10 four years ago.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: The president, in tuxedo with white tie, danced at each of them with the first lady, in a custom Jason Wu ruby chiffon and velvet gown, to Al Green’s “Let’s Stay Together,” performed by Jennifer Hudson.

column3: Obama Offers Liberal Vision: Ã¢â‚¬ËœWe Must ActÃ¢â‚¬â„¢
column4: The Obamas were back at the White House by 10:15 p.m.

column3: Obama vows to tackle unfinished business in second term, faces high hurdles
column4: With the oath, a punchy inaugural address and the traditional ride down Pennsylvania Avenue, President Obama began his second term Monday pledging to "finish what we started."

column3: Obama vows to tackle unfinished business in second term, faces high hurdles
column4: But the president's success, and ultimately his legacy, will depend now on whether he can shake the stalemate in Washington.

column3: Obama vows to tackle unfinished business in second term, faces high hurdles
column4: In the final four years, Obama faces a stack of unfinished business that only grew as he focused his political energy on winning re-election.

column3: Obama vows to tackle unfinished business in second term, faces high hurdles
column4: The president's personal agenda includes immigration reform, a new wave of gun control proposals and some action on climate change.

column3: Obama vows to tackle unfinished business in second term, faces high hurdles
column4: He also will be drawn into a renewed round of debate over the nation's finances -- deadlines pertaining to the debt ceiling, the budget and the triggering of automatic spending cuts all loom in a matter of weeks.

column3: Obama vows to tackle unfinished business in second term, faces high hurdles
column4: How much gets done, though, depends on both sides burying the campaign battle ax.

column3: Obama vows to tackle unfinished business in second term, faces high hurdles
column4: Obama's address Monday offered mixed messages to that end.

column3: Obama vows to tackle unfinished business in second term, faces high hurdles
column4: He urged the country to work together toward addressing the country's biggest challenges, saying "we are made for this moment, and we will seize it -- so long as we seize it together."

column3: Obama vows to tackle unfinished business in second term, faces high hurdles
column4: At the same time, he ripped what he described as "absolutism" and "name-calling" -- presumably among the Republicans -- and offered little in the way of an olive branch on the biggest issue that has divided Washington.

column3: Obama vows to tackle unfinished business in second term, faces high hurdles
column4: On the debt debate, Obama used some of his most forceful language to defend costly entitlement programs, like Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security, which could be the target of cuts in upcoming fiscal talks.

column3: Obama vows to tackle unfinished business in second term, faces high hurdles
column4: He described those programs as a vital safety net -- though, without some intervention, budget forecasters warn they will not be sustainable at current levels in the long-term.

column3: Obama vows to tackle unfinished business in second term, faces high hurdles
column4: "We must make the hard choices to reduce the cost of health care and the size of our deficit.

column3: Obama vows to tackle unfinished business in second term, faces high hurdles
column4: But we reject the belief that America must choose between caring for the generation that built this country and investing in the generation that will build its future," Obama said.

column3: Obama vows to tackle unfinished business in second term, faces high hurdles
column4: "The commitments we make to each other -- through Medicare, and Medicaid and Social Security -- these things do not sap our initiative; they strengthen us.

column3: Obama vows to tackle unfinished business in second term, faces high hurdles
column4: They do not make us a nation of takers; they free us to take the risks that make this country great."

column3: Obama vows to tackle unfinished business in second term, faces high hurdles
column4: Over the course of the speech, the president appeared to offer a series of assurances to his supporters that he would continue to fight for the issues he campaigned on.

column3: Obama vows to tackle unfinished business in second term, faces high hurdles
column4: For the time being, Republican congressional leaders muted any discontent they might have had with the speech.

column3: Obama vows to tackle unfinished business in second term, faces high hurdles
column4: "The president's second term represents a fresh start when it comes to dealing with the great challenges of our day; particularly, the transcendent challenge of unsustainable federal spending and debt," Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell said in a written statement.

column3: Obama vows to tackle unfinished business in second term, faces high hurdles
column4: Rank-and-file Republicans were less restrained.

column3: Obama vows to tackle unfinished business in second term, faces high hurdles
column4: Rep. Robert Pittenger, R-N.C., said the address that started "of the people, by the people and for the people" ended up being "of the government, by the government and for the government."

column3: Obama vows to tackle unfinished business in second term, faces high hurdles
column4: Rep. John Campbell, R-Calif., said the address was more controversial than the president's 2009 speech.

column3: Obama vows to tackle unfinished business in second term, faces high hurdles
column4: The president would appear to have two options for breaking the D.C. deadlock.

column3: Obama vows to tackle unfinished business in second term, faces high hurdles
column4: Either he uses the bully pulpit to pressure Republicans or the back channels to negotiate.

column3: Obama vows to tackle unfinished business in second term, faces high hurdles
column4: For the near term, he seems to be going the former route.

column3: Obama vows to tackle unfinished business in second term, faces high hurdles
column4: He already said when announcing his call for a new and stronger assault weapons ban that he wants to enlist the American people in calling for change.

column3: Obama vows to tackle unfinished business in second term, faces high hurdles
column4: "The only way we can change is if the American people demand it," Obama said last week.

column3: Obama vows to tackle unfinished business in second term, faces high hurdles
column4: His longtime political advisers are also forming a new group to promote the president's second-term policy agenda.

column3: Obama vows to tackle unfinished business in second term, faces high hurdles
column4: It's unclear whether that approach will work.

column3: Obama vows to tackle unfinished business in second term, faces high hurdles
column4: After battering Republicans in the final days of 2012, the Obama administration crafted a last-minute deal to avert the fiscal crisis.

column3: Obama vows to tackle unfinished business in second term, faces high hurdles
column4: But that deal put off big decisions -- on entitlements, on tax reform.

column3: Obama vows to tackle unfinished business in second term, faces high hurdles
column4: In the first year of Obama's second term, it should be clear whether Washington will start to make those decisions, or continue to punt.

column3: Obama vows to tackle unfinished business in second term, faces high hurdles
column4: House Republicans are now floating a three-month extension of the debt ceiling.

column3: Obama vows to tackle unfinished business in second term, faces high hurdles
column4: But even if that passes, they'll have to come to a broader agreement three months later.

column3: Obama vows to tackle unfinished business in second term, faces high hurdles
column4: And by March, lawmakers will have to decide whether and how they will shuffle around automatic spending cuts baked into the law in 2011 -- those cuts disproportionately affect the military.

column3: Obama vows to tackle unfinished business in second term, faces high hurdles
column4: Looming over all that is the challenge of striking what Obama once referred to as the "grand bargain," or a budget deal that would significantly reduce the deficit by $4 trillion or more over the next decade.

column3: Obama vows to tackle unfinished business in second term, faces high hurdles
column4: Obama and House Speaker John Boehner have twice tried to reach such an agreement, and twice those talks fell apart.

column3: Political cooperation? Little hope for change as Obama starts second term
column4: Americans enter President Obama’s second term more upbeat about the direction of the country than they were four years ago, when the recession was at its depths, but voters are less sure that government can be of any use to them.

column3: Political cooperation? Little hope for change as Obama starts second term
column4: Mr. Obama’s first inauguration, at the end of eight years of partisan warfare under President George W. Bush, was a bright spot of hope for bipartisanship: 50 percent of Americans predicted both parties would find ways to work together.

column3: Political cooperation? Little hope for change as Obama starts second term
column4: But four years later, even though voters returned the exact same balance of power to Washington, they are much less optimistic.

column3: Political cooperation? Little hope for change as Obama starts second term
column4: Just 23 percent expect cooperation, according to the Pew Research Center.

column3: Political cooperation? Little hope for change as Obama starts second term
column4: “The biggest shift is this idea that there would be partisan cooperation,” said Carroll Doherty, associate director for the Pew Research Center for the People & the Press.

column3: Political cooperation? Little hope for change as Obama starts second term
column4: “When Obama first took office, right before we did our poll, there was an expectation that the two parties were really going to get along.

column3: Political cooperation? Little hope for change as Obama starts second term
column4: This was a huge change.” The pessimism is high even as — or possibly because — the appetite for cooperation has grown.

column3: Political cooperation? Little hope for change as Obama starts second term
column4: Mr. Obama’s accomplished a lot during his first two years in office, though it was without much Republican support.

column3: Political cooperation? Little hope for change as Obama starts second term
column4: The economic stimulus package won the support of no House Republicans and just three Senate Republicans.

column3: Political cooperation? Little hope for change as Obama starts second term
column4: One of them, Sen. Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania, ended up leaving the Republican Party because of voters’ backlash to his vote.

column3: Political cooperation? Little hope for change as Obama starts second term
column4: Mr. Obama’s health care initiative passed without a single Republican vote in either chamber, and only after Democrats used a budget tactic to work around Sen. Scott P. Brown of Massachusetts, who cast the 41st Republican vote in February 2010, meaning they had the ability to filibuster.

column3: Political cooperation? Little hope for change as Obama starts second term
column4: Republicans went on to win control of the House and slice Democrats’ margin in the Senate in November 2010, and the final two years of Mr. Obama’s first term were defined by bruising budget fights.

column3: Political cooperation? Little hope for change as Obama starts second term
column4: All of that has taken its toll.

column3: Political cooperation? Little hope for change as Obama starts second term
column4: Mr. Obama enters his second term with a job rating parallel to that of Mr. Bush in 2005.

column3: Political cooperation? Little hope for change as Obama starts second term
column4: In each case, Mr. Doherty said, voters of the opposing party found little to like.

column3: Political cooperation? Little hope for change as Obama starts second term
column4: Mr. Bush accomplished little domestically during his second term and spent most of his final two years playing defense against a Democrat-led Congress.

column3: Political cooperation? Little hope for change as Obama starts second term
column4: Whether Mr. Obama will have better results remains to be seen.

column3: Political cooperation? Little hope for change as Obama starts second term
column4: There are some striking similarities between now and four years ago, when Mr. Bush turned over the Oval Office to Mr. Obama.

column3: Political cooperation? Little hope for change as Obama starts second term
column4: The unemployment rate stands at 7.8 percent, which is what it was in January 2009, though the rate is dropping.

column3: Political cooperation? Little hope for change as Obama starts second term
column4: Four years ago, the jobless rate was rising and Mr. Obama was a month away from pumping $800 billion into the slumping economy.

column3: Political cooperation? Little hope for change as Obama starts second term
column4: Other measures are more grim.

column3: Political cooperation? Little hope for change as Obama starts second term
column4: Federal debt has risen from $10.627 trillion on Inauguration Day 2009 to $16.433 trillion, a record level for any presidency.

column3: Political cooperation? Little hope for change as Obama starts second term
column4: The average price for a gallon of gas is $3.24, according to the U.S. Energy Information Administration, up dramatically from $1.83 in 2009.

column3: Political cooperation? Little hope for change as Obama starts second term
column4: But annual deficits, while still above $1 trillion a year, have dropped from a record peak of $1.4 trillion in 2009.

column3: Political cooperation? Little hope for change as Obama starts second term
column4: The economy is growing, posting a 3.1 percent rise in gross domestic product in the third quarter last year, compared with a 5.2 percent drop in January 2009.

column3: Political cooperation? Little hope for change as Obama starts second term
column4: Speaking on ABC’s “This Week” program Sunday, White House adviser David Plouffe said there are “atmospheric differences” between now and four years ago.

column3: Political cooperation? Little hope for change as Obama starts second term
column4: “We, obviously, had an economy that was collapsing all around us, and he was a first-term president.

column3: Political cooperation? Little hope for change as Obama starts second term
column4: So at that time, he’s still putting together his team, his Cabinet, his agenda,” Mr. Plouffe said.

column3: Political cooperation? Little hope for change as Obama starts second term
column4: “I think, now, the economy is still too weak but recovering.

column3: Political cooperation? Little hope for change as Obama starts second term
column4: And so the question is, right now, is building on that as opposed to just simply trying to stem the bleeding.

column3: Political cooperation? Little hope for change as Obama starts second term
column4: It’s a big difference.” Mr. Obama has said he is well-aware of what has come to be called the “second-term curse,” as presidents who get re-elected stumble — often as they deal with scandals or policies from their first terms.

column3: Political cooperation? Little hope for change as Obama starts second term
column4: Gallup reported that approval ratings dropped by double digits in the final four years of four of the past six presidents to win second terms.

column3: Political cooperation? Little hope for change as Obama starts second term
column4: Each of those four averaged well above 50 percent approval during their first terms.

column3: Political cooperation? Little hope for change as Obama starts second term
column4: Ratings rose during the second terms of two presidents, Ronald Reagan and Bill Clinton.

column3: Political cooperation? Little hope for change as Obama starts second term
column4: Both of them averaged 50 percent approval in their first terms, weighted down by sluggish economies that improved during their final four years.

column3: Political cooperation? Little hope for change as Obama starts second term
column4: Mr. Obama’s first term was strikingly similar to those two.

column3: Political cooperation? Little hope for change as Obama starts second term
column4: He averaged a 49 percent rating amid the worst economy since the Great Depression.

column3: Obama Sworn In for 2nd Term, This Time Quietly
column4: WASHINGTON — With only his family beside him, Barack Hussein Obama was sworn into office for a second term on Sunday in advance of Monday’s public pomp, facing a bitterly divided government at home and persistent threats abroad that inhibit his effort to redefine America’s use of power.

column3: Obama Sworn In for 2nd Term, This Time Quietly
column4: It was a brief and intimate moment in the White House, held because of a quirk of the calendar that placed the constitutionally mandated start of the new term on a Sunday.

column3: Obama Sworn In for 2nd Term, This Time Quietly
column4: But the low-key event seemed to capture tempered expectations after four years of economic troubles and near-constant partisan confrontation.

column3: Obama Sworn In for 2nd Term, This Time Quietly
column4: And it presaged a formal inauguration on Monday that will be less of a spectacle than the first one, when the nation’s first black president embodied hope and change for many Americans at a time of financial struggle and war.

column3: Obama Sworn In for 2nd Term, This Time Quietly
column4: For Monday’s festivities, with the traditional parade, balls and not least the re-enacted swearing-in outside the Capitol, there will be fewer parties and fewer people swarming the National Mall; organizers expect less than half the 1.8 million people who flocked to the city last time.

column3: Obama Sworn In for 2nd Term, This Time Quietly
column4: Once the parties end, Mr. Obama’s second-term challenges are formidable, not least given his ambitious priorities of addressing the national debt, illegal immigration and gun violence.

column3: Obama Sworn In for 2nd Term, This Time Quietly
column4: The economy, while recovering steadily, remains fragile.

column3: Obama Sworn In for 2nd Term, This Time Quietly
column4: The unemployment rate is as high as it was in January 2009, though it is down from the 10 percent peak reached late that year, and there is no consensus with Republicans about additional stimulus measures — or virtually anything else.

column3: Obama Sworn In for 2nd Term, This Time Quietly
column4: And as the terrorist attack in Algeria last week illustrated, Mr. Obama continues to confront threats around the globe, both from state actors like Iran and North Korea and from Qaeda-inspired extremists seeking to exploit power vacuums in the Mideast and across Africa and Asia.

column3: Obama Sworn In for 2nd Term, This Time Quietly
column4: At home, the emphasis is on reducing the deficits that piled up because of the economic downturn and the soaring costs of caring for an aging population.

column3: Obama Sworn In for 2nd Term, This Time Quietly
column4: Yet Mr. Obama and Republicans in Congress, divided by opposing views on the role of government, are no closer to a budget agreement that would overhaul taxes and costly, fast-growing entitlement programs like Medicare.

column3: Obama Sworn In for 2nd Term, This Time Quietly
column4: The next showdown in what has seemed a never-ending loop of fiscal brinkmanship and half-measures is likely to come as soon as next month over spending cuts.

column3: Obama Sworn In for 2nd Term, This Time Quietly
column4: The persistent partisan battles underscore Mr. Obama’s inability to make good on an original promise — that he would open a bipartisan era of problem solving.

column3: Obama Sworn In for 2nd Term, This Time Quietly
column4: While Mr. Obama’s words have become less soaring and more confrontational toward Republicans after four years in which they sought to foil him, David Plouffe, a senior adviser to Mr. Obama, said on the CNN program “State of the Union” on Sunday that the president had written a “hopeful” inaugural address for Monday’s ceremony.

column3: Obama Sworn In for 2nd Term, This Time Quietly
column4: But Senator John Barrasso, Republican of Wyoming, said on the same program, “The president seems so fixated on demonizing Republicans that he is blinded to the opportunities as well as the obligations that he has to deal with the big problems of this country on debt and the entitlements.” Mr. Obama draws approval from just over half of Americans — down 11 percentage points from his popularity in a New York Times/CBS News survey just after his first inauguration — with Republicans united in opposition and independents split.

column3: Obama Sworn In for 2nd Term, This Time Quietly
column4: If history is a guide, he has a limited time to act before his post-election leverage fades.

column3: Obama Sworn In for 2nd Term, This Time Quietly
column4: The official swearing-in of Mr. Obama, 51, was just the seventh time in history that a president was sworn in privately before the public ceremony, and the first since President Ronald Reagan’s second inauguration.

column3: Obama Sworn In for 2nd Term, This Time Quietly
column4: Each instance since 1821 occurred because the constitutionally mandated date for the inauguration fell on a Sunday.

column3: Obama Sworn In for 2nd Term, This Time Quietly
column4: The simplicity of Mr. Obama’s minute-long taking of the oath of office suggested a marriage before a justice of the peace, with a big ceremony and party planned for later.

column3: Obama Sworn In for 2nd Term, This Time Quietly
column4: Only Michelle Obama, holding her family Bible for the ceremony, and the Obamas’s daughters, Malia and Sasha, stood beside Mr. Obama in the grand Blue Room as he recited the 35-word oath in the Constitution that was administered, as it was four years ago, by Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. About a dozen relatives of the Obamas and Jane Roberts, the justice’s wife, watched out of camera range.

column3: Obama Sworn In for 2nd Term, This Time Quietly
column4: By contrast, the swearing-in hours earlier of Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. at the vice-presidential mansion, while simple, was large enough to suggest that Mr. Biden is indeed looking beyond the next four years to the 2016 election.

column3: Obama Sworn In for 2nd Term, This Time Quietly
column4: Among the 120 guests who watched Justice Sonia M. Sotomayor swear in Mr. Biden were Democratic dignitaries from the early presidential-nominating states, including Gov.

column3: Obama Sworn In for 2nd Term, This Time Quietly
column4: Maggie Hassan of New Hampshire.

column3: Obama Sworn In for 2nd Term, This Time Quietly
column4: On Saturday evening, Mr. Biden attended a party of Democrats from Iowa, the first presidential caucus state.

column3: Obama Sworn In for 2nd Term, This Time Quietly
column4: The private ceremonies were held because, under the Constitution, the two men’s first terms ended at noon on Sunday.

column3: Obama Sworn In for 2nd Term, This Time Quietly
column4: In between their events, Mr. Obama and Mr. Biden went together to Arlington National Cemetery to lay a wreath at the Tomb of the Unknowns.

column3: Obama Sworn In for 2nd Term, This Time Quietly
column4: And they prayed, separately: the Obamas attended services at the 175-year-old Metropolitan African Methodist Episcopal Church, where the enthusiastic congregation engaged in a call-and-response with the pastor evoking the president’s “Forward” campaign slogan; the Bidens and their guests celebrated a Mass in the vice-presidential mansion.

column3: Obama Sworn In for 2nd Term, This Time Quietly
column4: In the evening, Mr. Obama, Mr. Biden and their wives attended a gala for donors to both the 2012 campaign and the inaugural expenses, where performers included Stevie Wonder.

column3: Obama Sworn In for 2nd Term, This Time Quietly
column4: For Mr. Obama, the solemnity of his swearing-in was broken by his younger daughter, Sasha, who seemed to recall the problem four years earlier, when a garbling of the oath by both her father and Chief Justice Roberts at the Capitol forced them to repeat the oath at the White House the next day.

column3: Obama Sworn In for 2nd Term, This Time Quietly
column4: With warmth that belied their political differences, especially over campaign spending law, Justice Roberts congratulated Mr. Obama, and the president thanked him twice as they shook hands.

column3: Obama Sworn In for 2nd Term, This Time Quietly
column4: Mr. Obama then embraced his wife and daughters in turn.

column3: Obama Sworn In for 2nd Term, This Time Quietly
column4: “Good job, Daddy,” Sasha said.

column3: Obama Sworn In for 2nd Term, This Time Quietly
column4: “I did it!” he replied, only to have her quip, “You didn’t mess up” — leaving the president chuckling and rolling his eyes as he pivoted to thank the small group of witnesses and exit the room.

column3: Obama Sworn In for 2nd Term, This Time Quietly
column4: Elsewhere on a sunny winter Sunday, the streets of Washington were snarled with traffic, and hotels and homes were filling with the tens of thousands of visitors who, along with area residents, began partying through the weekend in bars and at receptions hosted by corporations and political groups.

column3: Obama Sworn In for 2nd Term, This Time Quietly
column4: Democratic women especially were feted.

column3: Obama Sworn In for 2nd Term, This Time Quietly
column4: At a party sponsored by Emily’s List, which helps elect Democratic women who favor abortion rights, the talk was of 2016 — and whether Hillary Rodham Clinton, the departing secretary of state, might run for president.

column3: Obama Sworn In for 2nd Term, This Time Quietly
column4: Flags, bunting and red, white and blue lights festooned streets, buildings and grounds, but as usual for such events, also ubiquitous were cement and metal security barriers, along with police and troops on downtown blocks.

column3: Obama Sworn In for 2nd Term, This Time Quietly
column4: Much is changed since January 2009, and much of it not in the way Mr. Obama planned.

column3: Obama Sworn In for 2nd Term, This Time Quietly
column4: His challenges ahead are perhaps not so great as then — 779,000 people lost their jobs that January, a one-month record, the financial and auto industries were teetering and millions of Americans were losing homes and savings — but they are nonetheless daunting.

column3: Obama Sworn In for 2nd Term, This Time Quietly
column4: While Democrats controlled Congress for his first two years, when Mr. Obama passed his signature laws for economic stimulus, expanded health insurance and financial industry regulation, Republicans captured the House majority in a conservative backlash at his midterm and are expected to keep it for his second term, given their success in drawing districts to keep them safe for Republicans.

column3: Obama Sworn In for 2nd Term, This Time Quietly
column4: That means Mr. Obama’s other priorities for a second term — chiefly addressing illegal immigration and gun violence — likewise will hardly come easy, if at all.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s relationship with Congress is key in second term
column4: As President Obama embarks on another four years in office, he is mindful that history is littered with the wreckage of presidents’ second terms.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s relationship with Congress is key in second term
column4: George W. Bush had the double-whammy of an unpopular war and a calamitous recession.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s relationship with Congress is key in second term
column4: Bill Clinton was impeached over lying about sex with an intern.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s relationship with Congress is key in second term
column4: Richard Nixon quit rather than face impeachment for Watergate.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s relationship with Congress is key in second term
column4: Even Ronald Reagan, whose second term included the beginnings of his cherished collapse of the Soviet Union, was damaged by the Iran-Contra scandal.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s relationship with Congress is key in second term
column4: Mr. Obama is starting out on the wrong foot by feuding with Congress over the nation’s borrowing limit and gun control, said Al Zacher, author of the book “Presidential Power in Troubled Second Terms.” He said the rare successful second terms have involved presidents who forged good relationships with strong congressional leaders, such as Mr. Reagan with Speaker Thomas P. “Tip” O’Neill Jr. and President Eisenhower with Senate Majority Leader Lyndon B. Johnson.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s relationship with Congress is key in second term
column4: “Getting along with Congress is the issue, and it was for the majority of those presidents who either succeeded or failed,” Mr. Zacher said.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s relationship with Congress is key in second term
column4: “The odds aren’t there for Obama.” Evening those odds may be why a key Obama surrogate blitzed the airwaves Sunday to talk about a more productive second-term relationship between the White House and Congress.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s relationship with Congress is key in second term
column4: Senior adviser David Plouffe, who made the rounds of several talk shows, told CBS’ “Face the Nation” that the president would do “a better job” working with lawmakers this term.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s relationship with Congress is key in second term
column4: “On the issues the president intends to really push and focus on, there’s massive support in the country, even amongst Republicans.” History lessons A week after his re-election, Mr. Obama said he understood the lesson about presidents trying to do too much in their final four years.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s relationship with Congress is key in second term
column4: “I’m more than familiar with all the literature about presidential overreach in second terms,” Mr. Obama said.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s relationship with Congress is key in second term
column4: “We are very cautious about that.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s relationship with Congress is key in second term
column4: On the other hand, I didn’t get re-elected just to bask in re-election.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s relationship with Congress is key in second term
column4: I got elected to do work on behalf of American families and small businesses all across the country who are still recovering from a really bad recession, but are hopeful about the future.” If working with Congress is the key to a successful second term, Mr. Obama’s tone has been notable in reflecting his refusal to negotiate with lawmakers on the debt ceiling.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s relationship with Congress is key in second term
column4: During the final news conference of his first term, on Jan. 14, the president used the language of terrorism to describe House Republicans.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s relationship with Congress is key in second term
column4: He said Republican lawmakers were trying to hold Americans hostage and were “holding a gun at the head of the American people” by demanding that Democrats cut deficit spending.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s relationship with Congress is key in second term
column4: Mr. Zacher said that attitude is reminiscent of President Wilson, whose inflexibility with Congress during his second term led to the failure of his League of Nations initiative.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s relationship with Congress is key in second term
column4: “[Mr. Obama] has a hidden ego, which is now coming out,” Mr. Zacher said.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s relationship with Congress is key in second term
column4: “Wilson is one of the presidents who would not compromise, and his failures were due to his unwillingness to compromise.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s relationship with Congress is key in second term
column4: It was a dictatorial mood, which is really becoming apparent with this president.” At least in terms of the debt ceiling, however, Mr. Obama’s approach may be winning the day.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s relationship with Congress is key in second term
column4: House Budget Committee Chairman Paul Ryan, Wisconsin Republican, said last week that colleagues in his party were considering a short-term extension of the debt limit.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s relationship with Congress is key in second term
column4: New faces Another challenge facing Mr. Obama, as with most other second-term presidents, is the loss of key personnel.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s relationship with Congress is key in second term
column4: Among the top players leaving his team are Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta and Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s relationship with Congress is key in second term
column4: Second-term nominees “tend to be a little less exciting,” said John Aldrich, professor of political science at Duke University.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s relationship with Congress is key in second term
column4: “By definition, it can’t be your first choice for secretary of state,” Mr. Aldrich said.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s relationship with Congress is key in second term
column4: “You already made that one.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s relationship with Congress is key in second term
column4: The biggest concern is a break in continuity, and that’s why there are appointments like [Jack] Lew” — a reference to Mr. Obama’s chief of staff, who has been nominated to replace Mr. Geithner at Treasury.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s relationship with Congress is key in second term
column4: For the moment, Mr. Obama and his advisers believe they have the political momentum.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s relationship with Congress is key in second term
column4: White House press secretary Jay Carney said Mr. Obama “feels very deeply” about his second-term agenda for improving the economy, reforming the immigration system and reducing deficits in a “balanced” way, i.e.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s relationship with Congress is key in second term
column4: with a blend of tax hikes and spending cuts.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s relationship with Congress is key in second term
column4: “He believes that we have work to do, and he believes that both the agenda he has put forward so far and the agenda he will put forward in the future will help this country move forward in a variety of ways,” Mr. Carney said.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s relationship with Congress is key in second term
column4: A new Obama machine The administration is being aided in advancing its early second-term agenda by the president’s campaign machinery, which is being transformed into a tax-exempt group by former campaign manager Jim Messina.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s relationship with Congress is key in second term
column4: Immediately after Mr. Obama introduced a package of gun control measures on Jan. 16, for example, Mr. Messina sent an email to millions of grass-roots supporters in the campaign’s database who had donated to the president’s re-election.

column4: “People like you spoke out and demanded action,” Mr. Messina wrote.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s relationship with Congress is key in second term

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s relationship with Congress is key in second term
column4: Learn more about the plan, and say you stand with President Obama in tackling this critical issue.” The email provided a link to a Web page detailing the gun control proposals.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s relationship with Congress is key in second term
column4: Federal Election Commission law required the Obama for America campaign to shut down after the election, but Mr. Messina said the social tools that were created by the campaign will remain active.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s relationship with Congress is key in second term
column4: “People just spent five years winning two elections together,” he said shortly after the election.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s relationship with Congress is key in second term
column4: “They’re not now just going to walk away.” Mr. Aldrich said there is little precedent for such a campaignlike operation working on behalf of a president’s second term, and it’s not clear how effective it will be on issues such as gun control, which Mr. Obama avoided studiously during his re-election bid.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s relationship with Congress is key in second term

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s relationship with Congress is key in second term
column4: “Gun control has not been central to his campaign.” Mr. Obama’s team also understands that in the dubious history of second presidential terms, the opportunity to achieve anything significant is usually limited to the first year or so.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s relationship with Congress is key in second term
column4: After that, opponents tend to wait out the president, and his party usually loses seats in the congressional midterm elections.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s relationship with Congress is key in second term
column4: By then, the jockeying is well under way in both parties among candidates hoping to replace the second-term president.

column3: ObamaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s relationship with Congress is key in second term
column4: “Only rarely do second-term presidents retain their power through more than 18 months or so,” Mr. Zacher said.

column3: Boehner wants Senate budget before any final debt ceiling deal
column4: WILLIAMSBURG, VA. — Capping a three-day GOP retreat, House GOP leaders announced that next week they will pursue a three-month extension of the nation’s borrowing limit to give Congress more time to pass a federal budget — warning that the proposal will also freeze members’ pay if they fail to do their job.

column3: Boehner wants Senate budget before any final debt ceiling deal
column4: House Speaker John A. Boehner, Ohio Republican, said the “principle is simple: no budget, no pay.” “Before there is any long-term debt limit increase, a budget should be passed that cuts spending,” Mr. Boehner said in his closing remarks at the posh Kingsmill Resort near Colonial Williamsburg.

column3: Boehner wants Senate budget before any final debt ceiling deal
column4: The Democratic-controlled Senate has failed to pass a budget for four years.

column3: Boehner wants Senate budget before any final debt ceiling deal
column4: That is a shameful run that needs to end, this year.” House Majority Leader Eric Cantor, Virginia Republican, said the move is the first step to getting the nation’s fiscal house in order.

column3: Boehner wants Senate budget before any final debt ceiling deal
column4: “The first step to fixing this problem is to pass a budget that reduces spending,” Mr. Cantor said.

column3: Boehner wants Senate budget before any final debt ceiling deal
column4: “The House has done so, and will again.

column3: Boehner wants Senate budget before any final debt ceiling deal
column4: The Democratic Senate has not passed a budget in almost four years, which is unfair to hard-working taxpayers who expect more from their representatives.” The White House gave a cautious welcome to the suggestion the House Republicans were open to a delay in the expected showdown over raising the federal debt limit, but said the offer fell far short of the president’s position on a long-term budget and spending deal.

column3: Boehner wants Senate budget before any final debt ceiling deal
column4: “We are encouraged that there are signs that congressional Republicans may back off their insistence on holding our economy hostage to extract drastic cuts in Medicare, education and programs middle-class families depend on,” said White House spokesman Jay Carney in a statement Friday afternoon.

column3: Boehner wants Senate budget before any final debt ceiling deal
column4: “Congress must pay its bills and pass a clean debt limit increase without further delay,” Mr. Carney said.

column3: Boehner wants Senate budget before any final debt ceiling deal
column4: “And as he has said, the president remains committed to further reducing the deficit in a balanced way.” Bu Mr. Boehner’s move will ramp up the political pressure on Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid to pass a budget through the upper chamber for the first time since 2009.

column3: Boehner wants Senate budget before any final debt ceiling deal
column4: Mr. Reid, Nevada Democrat, has been reluctant to force some of the more vulnerable Democrats to cast votes on spending plans that could come back to haunt them at the polls.

column3: Boehner wants Senate budget before any final debt ceiling deal
column4: Over that same four-year period, the national debt has mushroomed and the nation has run four straight $1 trillion-plus deficits.

column3: Boehner wants Senate budget before any final debt ceiling deal
column4: The House GOP spent a good chunk of time during its retreat mapping out a path forward on raising the nation’s $16.4 trillion debt limit, which is expected to breached as early as mid-February.

column3: Boehner wants Senate budget before any final debt ceiling deal
column4: Lawmakers also are weighing how best to deal with the looming $110 billion in across-the-board spending cuts, known as budget sequesters, set to kick in March 1 and the stopgap spending bill that has kept the government funded since September and is scheduled to run out on March 27.

column3: Boehner wants Senate budget before any final debt ceiling deal
column4: President Obama and Democrats meanwhile, have balked at the idea of attaching any strings to a debt limit hike, warning that failure to raise the federal borrowing limit would jeopardize the economy and global markets.

column3: Boehner wants Senate budget before any final debt ceiling deal
column4: House Budget Committee Chairman Paul Ryan, the party’s 2012 vice presidential nominee, told reporters on Thursday that a short-term extension of the debt limit was one of the ideas that Republicans are weighing — though even that move must be in exchange for Democrats ceding ground on spending or other budget reforms.

column3: Boehner wants Senate budget before any final debt ceiling deal
column4: “We think it is incredible that the Senate for three years has ignored the law and refused to pass the budget,” he said.

column3: Boehner wants Senate budget before any final debt ceiling deal
column4: “We think we need to have a big debate about a vision for the country and at least how we would budget.”

column3: Democrats Are Split Over How to Shape Approach to Gun Bills
column4: WASHINGTON — As Congressional Democrats shape their strategy for considering President Obama’s proposals to curb gun violence, sharp divisions are forming between lawmakers who believe the best path to success is through narrowly written bills and a meticulous legislative process, and those who advocate a more guerrilla approach.

column3: Democrats Are Split Over How to Shape Approach to Gun Bills
column4: Many Democrats, and some Senate Republicans, believe the only legislation that has a whisper of a chance of passing would be bills that are tightly focused on more consensus elements like enhancing background checks or limits on magazines, subjected to debate in committee and then brought to a vote after building bipartisan support.

column3: Democrats Are Split Over How to Shape Approach to Gun Bills
column4: That would be a departure from recent years, when the leadership often sidestepped committees and sought to take fights directly to the floor.

column3: Democrats Are Split Over How to Shape Approach to Gun Bills
column4: Others, particularly those senators who have long fought for gun control measures, believe a plodding process allows too much time for opposition to build, and prefer to fast-track measures by adding them as amendments to other bills, even blocking bills in ways that have angered Democrats, until they are granted votes on those ideas.

column3: Democrats Are Split Over How to Shape Approach to Gun Bills
column4: “We can’t sit around for months talking and letting the gun lobby run out the clock,” said Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey.

column3: Democrats Are Split Over How to Shape Approach to Gun Bills
column4: “If we’re going to make progress, it’s essential that we move quickly and start voting as soon as possible.” Democrats are united on one point: For any legislation to reach the Senate floor, Mr. Obama will have to put the full weight of his office and bully pulpit behind it.

column3: Democrats Are Split Over How to Shape Approach to Gun Bills
column4: Without constant public pressure and a concerted effort to woo conservative Democrats, especially those up for re-election in red states in two years, there will be little impetus, numerous Democrats said, to move legislation along.

column3: Democrats Are Split Over How to Shape Approach to Gun Bills
column4: Democrats also may be forced to decide whether to endure a lengthy legislative battle on guns at the expense of priorities like immigration.

column3: Democrats Are Split Over How to Shape Approach to Gun Bills
column4: Recognizing that public pressure is going to be required to move such contentious measures, the president’s former campaign aides in the weeks ahead will convert the Obama for America operation into a different kind of outside political group led by Jim Messina, Mr. Obama’s former campaign manager, according to people familiar with the plans.

column3: Democrats Are Split Over How to Shape Approach to Gun Bills
column4: The new organization will be able to raise money for grass-roots campaigning on behalf of the president’s second-term agenda, they said.

column3: Democrats Are Split Over How to Shape Approach to Gun Bills
column4: Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the majority leader who has spearheaded other legislation desired by the White House, will take a more passive role with any gun legislation, aides to Senate Democrats say, letting the administration set the agenda and allowing senators to press ahead through their committee leadership or interest in the issue.

column3: Democrats Are Split Over How to Shape Approach to Gun Bills
column4: Mr. Reid, who was deeply disturbed by the shootings last month in Newtown, Conn., is a longstanding gun rights supporter, a necessity for any statewide official from Nevada.

column3: Democrats Are Split Over How to Shape Approach to Gun Bills
column4: Mr. Obama’s efforts on Capitol Hill will provide the most crucial test of whether the mass shooting in Newtown, and the obdurate response from the National Rifle Association, has ushered in a new chapter in a legislative era that began in 2004 with the expiration of the assault weapons ban.

column3: Democrats Are Split Over How to Shape Approach to Gun Bills
column4: Since that time, most new gun legislation has emerged in statehouses, and Washington has largely enforced gun rights.

column3: Democrats Are Split Over How to Shape Approach to Gun Bills
column4: The political sensitivity around guns can be gauged somewhat through the measured statements of lawmakers long associated with gun rights.

column3: Democrats Are Split Over How to Shape Approach to Gun Bills
column4: “Some have asked whether I will try to block or filibuster this debate because of my support of the Second Amendment,” said Senator Tom Coburn, Republican of Oklahoma, who in 2009 sponsored a successful measure that repealed a gun ban in national parks.

column3: Democrats Are Split Over How to Shape Approach to Gun Bills
column4: “My goal is the opposite.

column3: Democrats Are Split Over How to Shape Approach to Gun Bills
column4: I believe Congress has a responsibility to review all of our laws and make adjustments as necessary in a transparent, open and deliberative manner.” Senator Patrick J. Leahy, the Vermont Democrat who is chairman of the Judiciary Committee and has a mixed legislative record on guns, said the first hearings he would schedule in the new Congress would be on gun legislation.

column3: Democrats Are Split Over How to Shape Approach to Gun Bills
column4: Mr. Leahy was the only senator to attend an event with Mr. Obama this week to announce his push on gun laws.

column3: Democrats Are Split Over How to Shape Approach to Gun Bills
column4: “Our hearing will be a first and essential step to building the kind of consensus needed for any legislation to move forward,” Mr. Leahy said, “and I look forward to leading that discussion.” Senate Democrats break down into roughly three groups when it comes to guns.

column3: Democrats Are Split Over How to Shape Approach to Gun Bills
column4: There are those like Senator Dianne Feinstein of California and Mr. Lautenberg, who have long labored to strengthen gun control laws.

column3: Democrats Are Split Over How to Shape Approach to Gun Bills
column4: On the other end of the spectrum are members like Senator Max Baucus of Montana, whose N.R.A.

column3: Democrats Are Split Over How to Shape Approach to Gun Bills
column4: scorecard is indistinguishable from those of conservative Republicans.

column3: Democrats Are Split Over How to Shape Approach to Gun Bills
column4: A third group, many of them up for election in 2014, have expressed tepid support for any gun regulation and will be a likely impediment to some, if not all, of Mr. Obama’s agenda, especially a proposed renewal of the ban on assault weapons.

column3: Democrats Are Split Over How to Shape Approach to Gun Bills
column4: Noting her “strong” record of support for the Second Amendment, Senator Mary Landrieu, Democrat of Louisiana, said: “That said, last month’s tragedy in Newtown, Conn., has become all too familiar.

column3: Democrats Are Split Over How to Shape Approach to Gun Bills
column4: We must find a way to balance our Second Amendment rights with the challenges of mental illness, criminal behavior and the safety of our schools and communities.” House Republicans are unlikely to bring legislation to the floor at all without clear Senate action, although a spokesman for Representative Eric Cantor of Virginia, the Republican majority leader, would not commit either way.

column3: Democrats Are Split Over How to Shape Approach to Gun Bills
column4: House Republicans have said they would look at anything the Senate passes.

column3: Democrats Are Split Over How to Shape Approach to Gun Bills
column4: “I just don’t like it when you sort of put false hope out there,” Representative Greg Walden of Oregon said Thursday at the House Republican retreat in Williamsburg, Va.

column3: Democrats Are Split Over How to Shape Approach to Gun Bills
column4: Speaking to the United States Conference of Mayors on Thursday, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. vowed that the administration would ceaselessly press its case.

column3: Democrats Are Split Over How to Shape Approach to Gun Bills
column4: “We’re going to take it to the American people,” he said.

column3: Democrats Are Split Over How to Shape Approach to Gun Bills
column4: “We’re going to go around the country making our case, and we’re going to let the voices, the voices of the American people be heard.”

column3: Senate Dems hesitant on Obama gun control plan
column4: President Obama's gun-control package was always going to be a tough sell in the Republican-led House -- but the plan is already running into resistance, or at least hesitation, from moderate Democrats in the Senate.

column3: Senate Dems hesitant on Obama gun control plan
column4: The lukewarm response in the Senate to Obama's highly anticipated anti-gun violence plan portends an uphill climb for the legislation.

column3: Senate Dems hesitant on Obama gun control plan
column4: And it underscores how, as the president's backers prepare to launch a veritable campaign to promote the plan, they will be pressuring members of their own party as much as reluctant Republicans.

column3: Senate Dems hesitant on Obama gun control plan
column4: No Democrat in the Senate came out against Obama's gun plan.

column3: Senate Dems hesitant on Obama gun control plan
column4: But several appeared to be on the fence or noncommittal, even as the president's allies in the House cheered the package as a long-sought solution to America's gun violence problem.

column3: Senate Dems hesitant on Obama gun control plan
column4: "We must find a way to balance our Second Amendment rights with the challenges of mental illness, criminal behavior and the safety of our schools and communities," Sen. Mary Landrieu, D-La., said in a statement, noting Louisiana's tradition of hunting, target shooting and gun collecting.

column3: Senate Dems hesitant on Obama gun control plan
column4: She said she would give the proposals "serious consideration."

column3: Senate Dems hesitant on Obama gun control plan
column4: The president on Wednesday called for a new and stronger assault-weapons ban as well as a 10-round cap on magazines and universal background checks.

column3: Senate Dems hesitant on Obama gun control plan
column4: The last assault-weapons ban expired in 2004 amid questions about its effectiveness and political considerations.

column3: Senate Dems hesitant on Obama gun control plan
column4: The shocking mass shooting at an elementary school in Newtown, Conn., has renewed interest in seeking a stricter crackdown on weapons that do the most damage -- yet more than a decade later, lawmakers remain leery about the perception of infringing on Second Amendment rights.

column3: Senate Dems hesitant on Obama gun control plan
column4: Many of the Democrats voicing concern are up for re-election in 2014.

column3: Senate Dems hesitant on Obama gun control plan
column4: A total of 20 Democratic seats are up in the next cycle -- 22 when special elections are included.

column3: Senate Dems hesitant on Obama gun control plan
column4: Among those senators is Sen. Mark Begich, D-Alaska, who has parted with the president before on energy and other issues.

column3: Senate Dems hesitant on Obama gun control plan
column4: He said he was "pleased" with Obama's call for an increase in mental health services, but said "there is no quick fix when it comes to keeping our families and communities safe."

column3: Senate Dems hesitant on Obama gun control plan
column4: "We must make smart investments to increase our safety while ensuring American's Second Amendment rights are protected," he said.

column3: Senate Dems hesitant on Obama gun control plan
column4: Sen. Joe Manchin in West Virginia and Sen. Max Baucus in Montana have also declined to take a position on the president's proposals.

column3: Senate Dems hesitant on Obama gun control plan
column4: Even Senate Democratic Leader Harry Reid of Nevada, who is considered to have a pro-gun rights record, said only that the chamber would "consider" the legislation.

column3: Senate Dems hesitant on Obama gun control plan
column4: "The tragedy at Sandy Hook was just the latest sad reminder that we are not doing enough to protect our citizens -- especially our children -- from gun violence and a culture of violence, and all options should be on the table moving forward," he said.

column3: Senate Dems hesitant on Obama gun control plan
column4: House Speaker John Boehner similarly did not take a position on the plan after Obama announced it Wednesday.

column3: Senate Dems hesitant on Obama gun control plan
column4: One lawmaker to watch is Sen. Al Franken in Minnesota.

column3: Senate Dems hesitant on Obama gun control plan
column4: Considered among the most liberal members of the Senate, Franken nevertheless represents a state with a strong gun-rights culture and one where both parties are well-represented - he is up for re-election in 2014.

column3: Senate Dems hesitant on Obama gun control plan
column4: His office scrambled on Thursday to clarify an article which suggested he was holding back on endorsing an assault-weapons ban.

column3: Senate Dems hesitant on Obama gun control plan
column4: In a carefully worded statement, Franken said he's "always supported the Second Amendment rights of Minnesotans to own firearms for collection, protection, and sport.

column3: Senate Dems hesitant on Obama gun control plan
column4: But I also think we need to find a balance between those rights and the safety of our children and our communities."

column3: Senate Dems hesitant on Obama gun control plan
column4: He noted he co-sponsored legislation to ban large magazines and supports "the principle that we should reinstate a ban on assault weapons."

column3: Senate Dems hesitant on Obama gun control plan
column4: Franken, though, did not endorse any specific assault weapons ban -- like one being introduced by Senate colleague Dianne Feinstein of California -- and stressed that he would "carefully review any proposal to do that."

column4: President Obama set up the first major fight of his second term on Wednesday as he vowed to directly confront gun rights supporters and called on average Americans to back him in his bid to limit ammunition and semi-automatic firearms sales, expand background checks to all gun purchases and encourage doctors to ask certain patients whether they own guns.
